title: More Companies Are Routing Calls via Internet
description: It was after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, that Tom Pyke, the chief information officer for the Department of Commerce, realized that he needed to expand the agency's emergency communications. Just over a year later, in December 2002, after a competitive selection process, a new telephone system was installed to support 4,000 people at agency headquarters in Washington and another 6,000 at the department's nearby Bureau of the Census.

title: Congress Tries Again
description: Members of Congress return this week newly educated about their constituents' growing doubts about the cost of the Iraq occupation, the health of the economy and the homeland's preparedness for disaster, whether by grid failure or terrorist plot. The troubling budget deficits so eagerly engineered by President Bush and his Republican majority have only worsened during the vacation. The G.O.P. leaders face a difficult agenda and there are already more signs of fresh procrastination than of resolve. A prime example is the leaders' unwillingness to break out the problem of the Northeast power grid's failure into an emergency measure free of the pork-laden energy bill.

title: E-Commerce Report; Web sites are becoming more upfront about revealing taxes, fees and shipping charges.
description: CLICKER shock is slowly becoming a thing of the past.

title: Labor Day and Beyond
description: It's always hard to tell just what ends and what begins on Labor Day. Schoolkids have the best answer, because for them a change of life is coming right around the bend. A surprising number of adults, with or without school-age children of their own, also feel the echoes of the educational calendar, as if the first few days of September still meant new teachers, new classrooms and the strange sense of starting over and picking up right where you left off.

title: Familiar Concertos Interpreted Anew by an Unlikely Duo
description: You never know what will happen when artists of completely different backgrounds collaborate. Sometimes things just don't click, as in the director Fred Schepisi's inert 1985 film ''Plenty,'' an adaptation of the David Hare play. You can almost sense the cast, which included Meryl Streep, Tracey Ullman and Sting, thinking, ''What are we doing here together?'' Only John Gielgud as an aging diplomat is riveting, though he seems to be in his own movie.

title: MENTAL CARE POOR FOR SOME CHILDREN IN STATE CUSTODY
description: Thousands of parents have given up custody of their children under pressure from states in order to obtain treatment for the children's severe mental illnesses, federal investigators say, but some states have not lived up to their end of the deal.

title: Libya to Inflate Amount Paid in '89 Bombing

It was Mr. Abplanalp's ambition to build a home for Fordham Prep to call its own. It was Mr. Abplanalp who saved the Prep when financial circumstances threatened the school in 1978. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife, Josie, his son, John, and his daughter, Marie. James F. Murray, '63, Chairman Joseph P. Parkes, S.J., President

title: Iraqi Shiites Flex Muscle Even as They Mourn
description: The funeral cortege for the slain Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim crawled south from Baghdad today in a tumultuous cavalcade freighted with both political and religious symbolism, with Iraq's Shiite Muslims determined to assert their importance even as one of their most significant voices has been stilled.

title: Big Steps, Baby Steps And High-Stepping

Some are not so successful -- check the way Auburn's vaunted running attack was grounded by Southern California -- while others are -- like the former baseball minor leaguer Joel Klatt's leading Colorado downfield for the winning score against Colorado State in a game delayed because of lightning.

title: As Championships End, Drug Imbroglio Goes On
description: After a slow start last week, the United States won three gold medals in relay races today as the world track and field championships concluded at the Stade de France. Both the 10 gold medals and the 20 medals over all led the competition. But two of the gold medals remained in jeopardy after the sprint champion Kelli White found herself embroiled in an unresolved drug case.

title: Kakata Journal; An Army of Educators Saves a Liberian College
description: The past and the present of this nation, and perhaps its future, lie here on a thousand acres of lush countryside, at the campus of the Booker T. Washington Institute, Liberia's sole surviving institution of higher learning.

title: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Are Said to Bid on Canary Wharf
description: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are expected to announce on Monday that they are teaming up to bid for the Canary Wharf Group, London's waterside financial services district that has been suffering from falling property values, executives close to the negotiations said today.

title: Anxiety Rises in a Muslim Enclave Near Bombay
description: The teeming streets of this suburb of Bombay are notable for two things: that most of the people are Muslim, and that a decade ago the streets were not teeming at all.

title: GQ, Under a New Editor, Is Not Quite So Coiffed
description: Historically, the GQ man has been a suave sort, a man who not only looks good in a suit but also has the kind of career and disposable assets that go with it. The GQ man is bold without being crude, sexy without being salacious, and witty without being puerile. The traditional GQ ideal would be a mythical combination of George Clooney and Frank Sinatra.

description: BEIJING, Sept. 1  China plans to trim its military by 200,000 troops within two years as it struggles to reinvent its armed forces, the world's largest, to better match the mobility and technological sophistication of the United States Army.

Dear brother of Marcia London, and the late Sherley Newman, devoted brother-in-law of Philip Newman. Services will be held Tuesday, September 2, at 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Real Problem With DNA Tests
description: The American public has eaten up the stories of wrongly convicted people freed by DNA evidence -- in print, on television and even in a recent, well-received play. What the public is less aware of is how hard the government often makes it for convicted people to get DNA testing. In a new twist, prosecutors are increasingly fighting to keep prisoners behind bars even when DNA testing points to innocence. This backlash should be resisted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIGHTER, VOLNEY FOSTER (TURK)
description: RIGHTER -- Volney Foster (Turk). On August 27, 2003, at age 100, of Bedford Hills and Fishers Island, NY. A founding partner of Harrington, Righter and Parsons. They were the first company to specialize in representing television stations nationally to the advertising industry. Mr. Righter was a graduate of St. Paul's School, Class of 1922, Harvard College, Class of 1926 (a longtime class agent) and Harvard Business School, Class of 1928. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERALTA, RAMOS, PAUL
description: PERALTA - RAMOS -- Paul. Patron of the arts and a founder of the Millicent Rogers Museum in Taos, New Mexico. Born February 18, 1931, passed away after a long battle with cancer August 26, 2003. A native of New York City, and longtime resident of Taos, New Mexico, he founded the Millicent Rogers Museum in 1956 as a posthumous gift from his mother Millicent Rogers to the people of New Mexico. He was the youngest of three sons of Millicent Rogers, who was the granddaughter of Henry Huttleson Rogers, a partner of John D. Rockefeller's in the Standard Oil Company and the driving force behind Anaconda Copper and U.S. Steel. In 1990, Mr. PeraltaRamos was honored with the Jefferson Award presented by U.S. Senator Pete Domenici who wrote, ''The selection for this honor acknowledges your commitment to preserving Native American and Hispanic art through your creation of the Millicent Rogers Museum. New Mexicans and you can surely take pride in this.'' U.S. Senator Jeff Bingaman wrote, ''To receive the 1990 Jefferson Award is a distinction that puts you above the rest and you are to be commended for outstanding service to our great state and nation. Through your public service, you have enriched the lives of others and have made your community a better place in which to live.'' He also received a Congressional Certificate of Merit in appreciation for his outstanding service to Taos and the State of New Mexico. Congressman Bill Richardson, now the Governor the State of New Mexico, presented him with an Achievement Award in recognition of his outstanding and invaluable service to the community. Mr. Peralta-Ramos was also responsible for bringing Roman Polanski's debut film ''Knife in the Water,'' to the United States. This was the first time one of Polanski's movies had been shown in this country. In addition to his brother Arturo, Mr. PeraltaRamos is survived by his children; Christina, Isabella, Philip and his former wife Inga; and two grandchildren. Charitable donations may be made in his memory to the Millicent Rogers Museum, P.O. Box A, Taos, NM 87571.

Conducted by Lorin Maazel, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, and starring the tenor Neil Shicoff and the mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina, the production is scheduled to begin tomorrow and run through Sept. 12, coinciding with Seville's International Music Festival. This ''Carmen'' is the latest venture of Michael Ecker, who transformed the Forbidden City in Beijing into a backdrop for Puccini's ''Turandot'' in 1998. Besides the original cigar factory and the bullring, ''Carmen'' will unfold at the Spanish-tiled Plaza de Espaa in Mara Luisa Park. Each site can accommodate as many as 8,000 spectators. Lengthy intermissions will enable audience members to walk from setting to setting along winding streets and riverfront promenades, but according to the production company, Opera on Site, buses and horse-drawn carriages will be available to those who prefer to move more quickly. With pills, condoms and other contraceptives often in short supply, most women in Russia expected to face at least one and sometimes more than a dozen trips to the abortion clinic over their childbearing years. Now the Russian government is attempting to slow the abortion rate. It is an admirable goal, given the toll that multiple abortions have taken on the health and fertility of Russia's women. title: Backward on Energy

title: GERMANY: STOLEN ART RETURNED
description: Nine years after it was stolen from a temporary exhibition in Frankfurt, a Caspar David Friedrich painting that was the subject of a $1.6 million ransom demand will go on view once more today at the Kunsthalle in Hamburg, Germany. Valued at $2.05 million, the painting, ''Waft of Mist,'' an oil on canvas depicting a farmer and his cottage against a turbulent landscape, was returned to the museum on Friday. ''We are overjoyed that after nine years we finally got our Caspar David Friedrich back,'' said Uwe M. Schneede, the director of the Hamburger Kunsthalle. ''And we didn't even have to pay a penny.'' Last January an unidentified man offered to arrange to return the painting upon payment of a ransom. The museum refused but continued negotiations with a go-between. In mid-July, when the middleman said he had taken possession of the painting, the museum threatened criminal action. The painting was returned without further demand for ransom. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

Canada, Germany and Australia allow restricted use of medicinal marijuana, but the Dutch will also provide the drug and regulate its quality. In the United States, 14 states allow medicinal use despite a federal ban on the drug.

She was beautiful, kind, brilliant, charming and full of life, with a smile and wit that lit up the room. Her life was about joy and love, and doing good for others. She devoted herself with great energy to many charitable causes. She loved the world and immersed herself in her many interests with much enthusiasm, becoming a great artist, sportswoman, entrepreneur, bridge player and student of current affairs. title: Deficit? What Deficit?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VON KLEMPERER, ALFRED HERBERT
description: VON KLEMPERER--Alfred Herbert. Of Doylestown, PA and formerly of Mill Neck, LI, NY, died on August 28, 2003 at the age of 88. A wise leader in his family. His principles and good example will live on through his family. He was for 60 years the greatly loved husband of Nancy Church Logan Von Klemperer. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his children and their spouses: William J. and Barbara S. Von Klemperer of Summit, NJ, Diana VK and James R. Resek of Doylestown and Marie VK and Paul A. Logan of South Pasadena, CA; also by his beloved grandchildren Ben, Matt, Anna, Willy and Katy, to whom he was a true friend, and by many nieces and nephews. Also surviving are his brothers and their spouses: Franz and Shirley Von Klemperer and Klemens and Betty Von Klemperer. His sister Lily preceded him in death. Mr. Von Klemperer retired from J.P. Morgan & Co. in 1976 as a Senior Vice President after a long and highly respected career at the bank. During this time he also served his adopted country as an Assistant to the U.S. Secretary of the Treasury acting principally as Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Finance. Following his retirement from J.P. Morgan, he became the President of PEFCO, Private Export Funding Corporation. He was an active member of the Council on Foreign Relations and at one time the President of The Bankers Association for Foreign Trade. Born in Berlin, Germany, Mr. Von Klemperer immigrated to the United States in 1937 and served in both the U.S. Army infantry and the Air Corps from 1942 until 1946, becoming a US citizen during this time and being discharged as a 2nd Lieutenant. In 1947-8 he worked for the US Military Government in Germany as a US representative to the Allies' Joint Foreign Exchange Agency that administered exports and imports in the occupied areas. A man of good will, he was generous with his time and talents: treasurer of the International Center in NY, President of the GermanAmerican Chamber of Commerce in NY, an officer of the Village of Plandome and a trustee of the Village of Mill Neck, President of the Board of Trustees of Buckley Country Day School, and for over 40 years the referee of his family's Christmas Eve touch football game. He will be missed and long remembered by all who knew him. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, September 6th at 1:00 PM at the United Methodist Church of Lahaska, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Food for Thought (and for Credit)
description: Want to combat the epidemic of obesity? Bring back home economics. Before you choke on your 300-calorie, trans-fat-laden Krispy Kreme, consider: teaching basic nutrition and food preparation is a far less radical remedy than gastric bypass surgery or fast-food lawsuits. And probably far more effective. Obesity tends to invite such drastic solutions because it is so frustratingly difficult to treat. This intractability, coupled with the sad fact that obese children commonly grow up to be obese adults, argues for a preventative approach. As the new school year begins, we need to equip kids with the skills and practical knowledge to take control of their dietary destinies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOHALEM, AARON S.
description: YOHALEM--Aaron S. Of Chappaqua, NY, died Sunday, August 31, 2003, at the age of 91. Mr. Yohalem was born in New York City in 1912, graduated from Townsend Harris, City College and NYU Law School. He began his practice of law with the firm of Davis & Gilbert in 1935 and joined the Best Foods Co. as corporate Secretary in 1943 where he championed passage of the federal oleomargarine bill. In 1953 he became a member of the Best Foods Board of Directors and in 1958, Executive Vice President of the company. After a merger with Corn Products, Inc. (later CPC International), he became Senior Vice President in 1960 and a member of CPC's Board of Directors in 1963, later becoming Chief Administrative Officer and member of the CPC Europe Board, as well. He retired in 1977. After retirement, he and his wife Lillian traveled estensively and he continued to serve on numerous boards, including lengthy service in Johannesburg, South Africa, with Raphaely & Sons and in Montreal, Canada, with Ouimet-Cordon Bleu. Mr. Yohalem was much loved by his family and a source of inspiration and great practical wisdom for all who knew him. He exhibited a compassionate interest in his family and wide circle of friends and was deeply involved in all their lives. He is survived by his children Nan and Allen Banks, Deborah and Frank Wadsworth, and Daniel and Jane Yohalem, 14 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Bernice Bruckner and her husband Sanford Bruckner. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, September 3, at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Meeting to Focus on Nets' Future
description: The future of the Nets will be debated at a meeting today of the YankeeNets holding company, a session that could set the stage for the teams relocation to New York. After months of rumors about the sale of the Nets and competing offers from bidders on both sides of the Hudson River, the warring factions within YankeeNets, which owns the Nets, the Yankees, and 30 percent of the Devils, are expected to culminate the matter, said one member of the YankeeNets board. The executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the 15-member board would decide whether to put the Nets up for sale through an auction process or come up with an interim financial plan to deal with team losses that could run as high as $100 million over the next two years. One potential bidder as well as state officials in New Jersey and New York said that they, too, had been told of the board meeting. Bruce Ratner, a New York developer, has been raising money to buy the Nets and move them to a new home in Brooklyn that would be the centerpiece of a large residential and commercial development. Senator Jon S. Corzine and the New Jersey developer Charles Kushner have developed a counteroffer that would keep the teams in New Jersey, either at the Meadowlands sports complex or in Newark. At the same time, Charles B. Wang, an owner of the Islanders, has expressed interest in buying the Nets and moving them to Nassau County.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: BEA EXECUTIVE TO START COMPANY William T. Coleman III, a founder of BEA Systems eight years ago, is leaving day-to-day involvement in the company for a start-up venture. He will remain on the BEA board and be a consultant, the company said. Mr. Coleman founded BEA, a business software company, along with Ed Scott and Alfred Chuang in 1995, and was chief executive until October 2001, when he handed that role over to Mr. Chuang. Since then, Mr. Coleman has been working with BEA's field sales force and has held the title of chief customer advocate of the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif.    Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: ING Sends 13 Workers From Mexico Into Hiding
description: ING, the Dutch insurance giant, said today that it had sent 13 Mexican employees into hiding abroad to prevent Mexican authorities from jailing them in a case involving accusations that the company falsified documents.

title: EMERGENCY ROOMS GET EASED RULES ON PATIENT CARE
description: The Bush administration is relaxing rules that say hospitals have to examine and treat people who require emergency medical care, regardless of their ability to pay.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On Jail Standards
description: A federal appeals court has overturned parts of a lower court's order forcing the city's Department of Correction to significantly change how it houses pretrial detainees. The decision yesterday struck down the district court's ruling that prison beds in pretrial detention facilities be spaced so that detainees' heads are at least six feet apart, instead of three feet, the current standard. Lawyers with the Legal Aid Society argued that the six-foot standard was necessary for both physical and emotional health reasons. Michael A. Cardozo, the city's corporation counsel, said such a change would require more jail space that would cost more than $100 million to build. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit also rejected another lower court order that the city provide a minimum lighting standard in certain cells and dormitories. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: A Little Skin, A Lot of Fire
description: THIS recipe could unite those who would become ecstatic when they see a dish of chicken skin on a restaurant menu and those who would flee into the street.

title: Saudi Arabia and Russia Sign Accord on Gas and Oil
description: Saudi Arabia and Russia, the world's two largest oil suppliers, agreed today to work on easing rules for setting up joint ventures in the oil and natural gas industry.

title: AT&T Suit Says WorldCom Used Fraud in Routing Calls
description: AT&T filed a federal racketeering lawsuit yesterday against WorldCom, accusing it of fraudulently routing calls.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL INC., Bethesda, Md., the nation's largest hotel company, said it had sold 14 Brighton Gardens assisted-living communities to CNL Retirement Properties Inc., Orlando, Fla., a REIT, for about $184 million to exit the senior-center business.

title: Damage Done: A Punk Rocker, From Sedated to Self-Aware
description: Since his 1980 documentary on the punk-rock movement, ''D.O.A.,'' Lech Kowalski has been the foremost chronicler of the punk generation's romantic myths and harsh realities. The musicians he has focused on in his rough, video-based documentaries include the Sex Pistols, Billy Idol, Richard Hell and Johnny Thunders, the last one a spectacularly suicidal junkie-rocker whose 20-year journey to death by overdose was detailed in Mr. Kowalski's ''Born to Lose: The Last Rock-and-Roll Movie'' (1999).

title: Golden Years, on $678 a Month; In City, Growing Older and Poorer Often Go Together
description: She trudged languorously along the thrumming streets of Elmhurst, Queens, lost in her early evening thoughts. The air was moist and still. She turned left on Justice Avenue, away from the crowds. She dislikes crowds. When she reached the Queens Center Mall, with its clatter of commerce, she turned around. Stores foster an undercurrent of tension in her.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the success of the Walt Disney Company during the summer movie season referred incorrectly to ''Freaky Friday.'' It is a comedy, not a thriller.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: About New York; Everyone Out Of the Pool (That's You!)
description: EIGHT hours remained until James Gomez could give the signal to begin draining the massive Astoria Pool. Eight hours until a few valves could be opened to release 1.3 million gallons into the East River, where the churning Hell Gate waters would rinse away any lingering hint of summertime splashes and butterfly strokes.

title: Edwards and Jets Are Ready
description: For almost five months, Coach Herman Edwards has heard the questions -- and has refused to answer -- about what it would be like opening day when the Jets face the Washington Redskins, who snapped up four of his free agents.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: World Church Group Wants U.S. Out
description: The World Council of Churches ended its meeting in Geneva with a call for American and coalition forces to withdraw from Iraq and transfer matters to the United Nations. The Council, which represents 342 Protestant and Orthodox denominations and church groups, said the invasion of Iraq was ''immoral, ill advised'' and bad for Christian-Muslim relations. The Council also called on the American and British governments to pay reparations to the Iraqi people for the damage caused by the war. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Franklin Ford, 82, Dies; Confronted Harvard Protesters
description: Franklin L. Ford, who as dean of Harvard's Faculty of Arts and Sciences confronted student protesters in the 1960's, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass. He was 82.

title: At a Sushi Bar, Fruits of the Sea, and Elsewhere
description: I CAN'T remember the last time I saw sushi chefs wearing ties, but there they were, two sushi chefs dressed for the office at Sushi Yasu, which opened in the Washington Jefferson Hotel near the theater district last spring. To avoid conflict with the food, or the knife, one wears his tie military style, the tip tucked between the buttons of his shirt, and the other tucks the tie into his pants.

title: Vinegars That Stand Out In a Crowded Field
description: Another flavored vinegar? Oh, please. But among the thousands that come my way, there are occasional standouts, like the three new subtle rice vinegars made by O Olive Oil in San Rafael, Calif.

title: Joint Venture Agency Will Open in Miami
description: MARCA Hispanic is being opened in Miami by two longtime agency executives as a joint venture with MARC USA in Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANTOR, LOUIS
description: CANTOR--Louis. Age 81, died Sept 1, 2003. An accomplished attorney, pre-eminent in the field of construction law, a graduate of Columbia Law School, actively involved in ARMDI (American Red Magan David of Israel), formerly its National Chairman. He also devoted his time to the City College Alumni Association, where he had been a Director and Secretary of the City College Fund and a member of the President's Advisory Board. Captain of the City College Track Team in 1942 and a member of the City College Athletic Hall of Fame. A man of immense style and grace, a patron of the arts and a father and grandfather without parallel. He is survived by his beloved companion Ruth Singer, daughter Diana Dorman and her husband Jay, son David Cantor and his wife Elizabeth and grandchildren Jennifer, Kenneth, Joanna and Dashiell. Services Wednesday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Fingers Are for Licking, Not Burning
description: I'll take caramel over chocolate any day, so ''Caramel,'' by Peggy Cullen (Chronicle Books, $19.95), could have been written just for me. Now is the time to bake little caramel-peach upside-down cakes and burnt-sugar and lemon tarts with blueberry compote, and you will find recipes for them in the book, along with classic lace cookies, toffee and caramel corn. Marshmallow confections called Mad Caps, above, take time and patience, but are well worth it -- even though they will be eaten in a flash. Recipes for ice cream desserts with caramel topping are included, but not for caramel ice cream. There is an excellent guide to making caramel, with good safety tips. (Sugar caramelizes at 320 to 350 degrees, hot enough to burn.) Ms. Cullen wisely cautions that handling caramel is not for small children.

title: Expulsion of Arafat Threatened by Israeli
description: Defense Minister Shaul Mofaz said that Israel might move to expel the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, by the end of the year.

title: Davis's New Commercials Have a Missing Element: Davis
description: Gov. Gray Davis of California today released his first television advertisements of the recall campaign. The commercials, though long anticipated, are perhaps most noteworthy for what they do not say and where they will not be seen.

title: BUSH LOOKS TO U.N. TO SHARE BURDEN ON TROOPS IN IRAQ
description: President Bush agreed today to begin negotiations in the United Nations Security Council to authorize a multinational force for Iraq but insisted that the troops be placed under American command, according to senior administration officials.

title: Vietnamese Influences
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaffected Teenagers And Looming Calamity
description: In ''Zero Day,'' the teenage high school student Cal (Calvin Robertson) has a sarcastic mantra that he often utters: ''These are the best years of our lives.'' But the first time he says the phrase sets the tone for this drama directed by Ben Coccio. It is late at night, and Cal and his best friend, Andre (Andre Keuck), are planning an assault on their school. ''We are the army of two,'' they chant, flexing and posing for the camera.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: CLINTON WANTS HEARINGS ON E.P.A. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called yesterday for Congressional hearings into whether the Environmental Protection Agency played down health risks in a report on the air quality of neighborhoods affected by the destruction of the World Trade Center. "A week after Sept. 11, the E.P.A. put out a statement which said the air was safe and that there were no concerns," she said during a luncheon at the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. "And we now know they didn't have the analysis and the data to make that statement." She cited asthma and bronchial problems among rescue workers and volunteers at ground zero and called for further testing of indoor air in Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn. Howard O. Stier (NYT)

title: People
description: * Jim Harrington was named president at O'Leary & Partners, Irvine, Calif., succeeding David Robinson, who was named to the new post of chief executive. Mr. Harrington had been president at the Irvine office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Foote, Cone announced in June that he would move to the agency's New York headquarters to work on what were described as special projects.

title: Train Bombing Kills 5 and Hurts 30 Near Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3  At least five people were killed and more than 30 were injured today when two bombs exploded under a passing commuter train near the wartorn southern republic of Chechnya, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOREY, SUSAN
description: MOREY--Susan, of Greensboro, VT, died August 30, 2003 in Lebanon, NH. Born in New York City, the daughter of the late Charles and Phyllis (Hedley) Bailey. She married Jonathan T. Morey in 1940. He died in 1995. Mother of Jonathan B. Morey of Mazomunie, WI, Sara Floody of Madison, WI, and Alexandra Norton of Ann Arbor, MI. Grandmother of seven. A memorial service was held on Monday September 1, 2003 in Greensboro. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Vermont Children's Aide Society, 79 Weaver St, Winooski, VT 05404. For information, Northern Vermont Funeral Service, Hardwick, VT.

title: Israeli Spy Appears in Court To Seek Reduction of Sentence
description: Lawyers for Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American convicted of spying for Israel who made his first public appearance in more than 15 years today, asked a federal judge today to allow them to continue appealing his life sentence.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Brazil posted arecord trade surplus of $2.67 billion in August, pushing the total surplus for the year so far to more than $15 billion, a welcome cushion for the country's finances amid declining foreign investment. The ministry for development, industry and foreign trade said exports in August were a record $6.4 billion, while imports, slowed by a weak economy, were $3.73 billion. The August surplus was larger than the $1.57 billion surplus recorded 12 months ago, and it lifted the figure for the year through August above the $13 billion for all of last year. Brazil needs a surplus to help compensate for a drop in direct foreign investment, which fell 63 percent, to $3.5 billion, in the first half of the year. Brazil has been a magnet for direct foreign investment in Latin America over the last decade, but inflows have slowed with the end of its privatization program. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Giants Rookie Copes With Mixed Emotions
description: Emotions have battered David Diehl from both sides for the past 10 days.

description: MIDDLETOWN, AMERICA

title: Africans Outdo U.S. Patients In Following AIDS Therapy
description: Contradicting long-held prejudices that have clouded the campaign to bring AIDS drugs to millions of people in Africa, evidence is emerging that AIDS patients there are better at following their pill regimens than Americans are.

title: Indonesian Art to Admire and to Wear
description: The exhibition is called ''Sari to Sarong,'' and the stunning gold-leaf cloths and vermilion wraps on display at the national gallery here give considerable perspective on Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation.

title: Off the Menu
description: STEPHEN HANSON, left, who owns the richly appointed Fiamma in SoHo, will spin off a casual version of the restaurant in November when he opens VENTO TRATTORIA at 675 Hudson Street (14th Street), in a triangular 19th-century building in the meatpacking district. Like Fiamma (''flame'' in Italian), Vento (''wind'') will be multilevel. Its basement lounge was once a stable.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: 3 STATES DROP TALKS ON RIVER WATER Alabama, Florida and Georgia have abandoned five years of negotiations and will return to litigation over Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River Basin. In July, the states reached an understanding on some points in their 13-year dispute, with Aug. 31 as the goal for a final accord. Three federal suits had been delayed for the talks. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: EVANS--Lester. Loving father of Deborah Evans-Giannone, devoted companion of Freda Rosenthal, loving grandfather of Jonathan and Jordan Giannone. Services Thursday, 12:30 PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Around Boston Harbor, a Burst of New Building
description: Several waterfront development projects are gaining enough critical mass to reveal silhouettes of the new urban concentrations rising around Boston Harbor.

title: Thousands at Burial of Slain Cleric
description: The central streets of this holy city convulsed with a final spasm of mourning today as Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, the assassinated cleric who had promised to deliver Iraq's Shiites from their repression, was buried in a large empty field that is expected to be transformed into a shrine.

title: RUBBERMAID PARENT EXPANDS DUTIES FOR 3 OFFICERS
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., which makes Calphalon cookware and Rubbermaid storage products, named three executives to new expanded positions as part of a plan to streamline its management structure. James J. Roberts was appointed president and chief operating officer of the Rubbermaid/Irwin group, Karl Kahofer was promoted to president of the group's European and Asian businesses, and Robert S. Parker will become president and chief operating officer of the Sharpie/Calphalon group, Newell Rubbermaid said. Newell is based in Atlanta.

title: Martha's Vineyard in a Shell
description: ROY SCHEFFER traces his seafaring lineage back to the 16th-century English navigator Sir Francis Drake. Mr. Scheffer spent his life fishing the waters around his home in Martha's Vineyard, until government restrictions and dwindling stock put him out of business.

title: CHRYSLER RAISES REBATES TO COMBAT SALES DECLINE
description: The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. is adding incentives to most 2004 models to increase sales and reverse a 4.7 percent sales decline so far this year. ''Instead of following, we're trying to aggressively set the pattern for incentives,'' a spokesman, James Kenyon, said. The rebates will be from $500 to $3,000 on almost all 2004 models. They replace incentives as high as $2,000 offered on nine models in August, Mr. Kenyon said. Incentives on 2003 models are mostly the same except for an increase in the rebates for PT Cruisers, from $1,500 to $2,500, he said. The rebates expire Oct. 31.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Little Play, Lots of Rain at U.S. Open
description: The rain-soaked United States Open absorbed another day that featured little tennis and a lot of speculation about what to do.

description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called yesterday for Congressional hearings into whether the Environmental Protection Agency played down health risks in a report on the air quality of neighborhoods affected by the destruction of the World Trade Center. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGUINNESS, BETTY
description: McGUINNESS--Betty, on August 29, 2003. Loving sister of Patricia Hosmer, Terry and Peter. Devoted sister-in-law to Mary McGuinness and Mamie Guidera. Caring aunt to eight nieces and nephews and an adoring great aunt. Compassionate and caring friend to many. Political activist and champion for lesbian and gay rights. You will always be in our hearts. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Empire State Pride Agenda Foundation, 647 Hudson Street, NY, NY 10014, prideagenda@prideagen da.org or the NOW Foundation, P.O. Box 1848, Merrifield, VA 22116-8048, 202-785-8576, www.now.org/foundation/do nation.html. description: The Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation named Ken Pilot as president of the company's factory stores. He will also help develop retail programs.

description: The Kmart Holding Corporation, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in May, has named three executives to top supply, administrative and creative positions as the discount retailer tries to halt losses and revive sales.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIGHTER, VOLNEY FOSTER (TURK)
description: RIGHTER -- Volney Foster (Turk). On August 27, 2003, at age 100, of Bedford Hills and Fishers Island, NY. A founding partner of Harrington, Righter and Parsons. They were the first company to specialize in representing television stations nationally to the advertising industry. Mr. Righter was a graduate of St. Paul's School, Class of 1922, Harvard College, Class of 1926 (a longtime class agent) and Harvard Business School, Class of 1928. A member of the Board of Trustees of the Katonah Museum of Art. Married to the late Sarah Williams Righter. Father of James Volney Righter, of Boston, MA, and Robert McCormick Righter of Denver, CO. Also survived by granddaughter Eliot Righter Ramos and grandson Mark Hamilton Righter, and four great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. Matthew's Church, on Saturday, September 6, 2003, at 3 PM, in Bedford, NY. Interment will be private. In memoriams to Katonah Museum of Art.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: New Leader For Party
description: Deputy Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, known for his crackdown on Basque terrorism when he was interior minister, will lead the governing Popular Party into the March general elections. Party leaders ratified Mr. Rajoy, left, Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar's choice as his successor, by a unanimous vote with one abstention. The 48-year-old Mr. Rajoy, who has served in four ministries since 1996, pledged continuity for Mr. Aznar's foreign and domestic policies, including opposition to Basque autonomy and support of the United States. Mr. Aznar said he would hand over leadership of the party immediately. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDERSON, HARRY B., JR.
description: HENDERSON--Harry B., Jr., Labor Day, 2003, age 88. Coauthor of ''A History of African-American Art'' and Editor of ''Medical Tribune.'' Survived by Albert of Milford, CT, Joseph of NYC and three grandsons. Plans for memorial service will be announced.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Parliamentary Elections In December
description: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a decree setting in motion the country's fourth post-Soviet parliamentary election, to be held Dec. 7. Presidential elections will follow in March. Forty-eight parties have registered to contend for 450 seats in the lower house of the national legislature. The president called for ''a fair competition without mudslinging,'' which he said could be ''splashed out onto the people on television.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: CABLE MAKER SEEKS TRANSFER TO ITS CREDITORS
description: Superior TeleCom Inc., a maker of copper-wire and cable products that filed for bankruptcy protection in March, won court permission to seek creditors' approval of a reorganization plan to transfer ownership to senior secured lenders. Under the plan, pre-bankruptcy lenders would get all of the company's reorganized common stock, the preferred stock of its subsidiary, $145 million of new senior notes and $58.1 million, court papers say. Judge Jerry Venters of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., scheduled a hearing for Oct. 22. Superior is based in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Wheat Monopoly Diversifies
description: The Australian Wheat Board, a national monopoly that ranks among the world's largest wheat exporters, is diversifying to expand its revenue base, the chairman, Brendan Stewart, said. The wheat board completed the acquisition last week of Wesfarmers Landmark, an agricultural services network, for 718 million Australian dollars ($456 million) and assumption of 107 million Australian dollars in debt. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Day by Day, the Bad News in Iraq (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuzzy Economic Thinking; Blaming Beijing
description: Unemployment in America is high, and elections are on the horizon. It must be time to look east again for scapegoats. Japan is only starting to recover from its protracted recession, so China will be handed the role of economic villain in the coming election cycle. Expect to hear a chorus of presidential candidates blame unfair Chinese competition for the nation's manufacturing woes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STULMAN, ELGA KRON
description: STULMAN--Elga Kron. On September 2, 2003, age 70. ''A Woman With Soul''. Beloved wife and best friend of Stephen L. Stulman for 50 years. Loving mother of Andrea and Richard Dennett, Jessica and Laurence Sheinman, James and Stacy Stulman, Laura and Jason Cooper; adoring grandmother of Alexandra, Adam, Jonathan and Rebecca; caring cousin and true friend of so many. Contributions may be made to the Hebra Kadisha Fund of Cong. B'nai Jeshurun. Service Thursday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 200 Bus Drivers Strike Schools On Long Island
description: About 200 bus drivers and monitors who serve school districts in eastern Long Island went on strike yesterday, the day before the first day of school, but negotiations between the union and its employer continued into the night, school officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEAVY, MORTON L.
description: LEAVY--Morton L., on Sunday, August 31, at the age of 87, after a prolonged illness. A practicing attorney for six decades, he was devoted to the law, the creativity of his clients, and his family. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Fay, daughters Annette and Jane, their husbands, Jack Muraskin and Peter Isakoff and three beloved grandchildren, David, Nick and Emma. Funeral services Wednesday, 11:30am, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Shiva will be observed Wednesday and Thursday. Donations may be made to Townsend Harris Library or the Hospice Care Network of Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, DORIS

Her devotion and love for her family were exceptional and exemplary. Our heartfelt condolences to all. May her memory be for a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Executive Director

title: Kerry Begins Campaign With Talk of 'Courage'
description: Wrapping himself in the imagery of military service and the Vietnam War, Senator John Kerry portrayed his White House campaign today as a mission ''of courage'' and berated President Bush as imposing a ''radical new vision of a government'' that he said favored the wealthy.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a celebration in Brooklyn by immigrants from the Caribbean island of St. Lucia misstated the date of the island's independence. It was in 1979, not six years ago.

title: Conservative Fights for Credibility in California Recall Race
description: The next question comes from Scott, calling on his cellphone. Scott, what would you like to know from State Senator Tom McClintock about his campaign for governor against his fellow Republican Arnold Schwarzenegger and 133 other candidates?

description: Two rival energy companies proposed a joint project yesterday to build two or possibly three generating plants in Suffolk County to meet Long Island's growing demand for electricity.

description: Among the more interesting contests in the Democratic primary for City Council on Sept. 9 are rematches of previous close races in Queens and the Bronx. Here are our choices:

title: Corrections

O'Neill as chief executive and co-chairman of Mitsubishi Motors North America misidentified the executive to whom he will report. It is Steven Torok, executive vice president for international sales and marketing, not Rolf Eckrodt, the parent company's chief executive.

title: Senate Democrats Take the Offensive, on Education and Labor
description: The Senate returned to work today after a monthlong summer vacation, and Democrats immediately went on the offensive, vowing to increase financing for education and block a White House proposal that could strip millions of workers of their right to overtime pay.

title: Islamic Cleric Gets Mixed Verdict In Indonesian Trial for Terrorism
description: An Indonesian court this evening acquitted the radical Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, widely identified as the spiritual leader of Al Qaeda's Southeast Asia affiliate, of charges that he ordered a series of terrorist attacks in Indonesia, and of plotting to assassinate the Indonesian president.

title: G.E. Bid for Instrumentarium Receives European Approval
description: The European Commission approved General Electric's planned $2.2 billion acquisition of the Finnish medical devices maker Instrumentarium today, on condition that G.E. sell one unit and promise not to shut out competitors in a European market the combined companies will dominate.

title: To Ease the Wait for the Train or the Taxi
description: The Campbell Apartment in Grand Central Terminal specializes in classic cocktails, some from the 1920's and 30's. At the small bar it has opened in a former taxi stand at the entrance to the station at 43rd Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, it has come up with some new ones, themed to the location.

title: Personal Debt Surges in Britain
description: Throughout this balmy summer, when temperatures hit their highs and people shopped for flimsy clothing and cooling drinks, Britons set records of their own -- mainly of red ink in soaring personal debt that could spell an imminent end to a feel-good era.

title: Union Organizers to Air Complaints Against Yale
description: The group seeking to unionize graduate students at Yale announced yesterday that a former labor secretary and a former general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board would serve on a committee investigating whether Yale administrators or professors broke the law while fighting the unionization drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DROB, FRANK
description: DROB--Frank. Age 77. On September 1, 2003. Of Inverrary, FL. and Flushing, N.Y. He lived and worked by the highest standards of honesty, responsiblity and fairness. He was a devoted and loving husband and father. He leaves his beloved wife of 56 years, Sylvia, two children Sally & Sandy and four grandchildren Elliot, Robin, Amarilla and Martin. He is greatly loved by us all and lives on in our hearts and souls.

title: Families of Uniformed Victims Are Urged to File 9/11 Claims
description: Federal and city officials said yesterday that they would reach out to relatives of the city's uniformed forces who lost family members in the Sept. 11 terror attack and encourage them to file claims with the victims' compensation fund.

title: Dog Ate Your Homework? Fall on Your Bread Knife
description: LAST October, when Robert Stalzer lost his job as an equities trader for Goldman Sachs in Zurich, he decided to enroll in the Institute of Culinary Education in New York. ''I did not want another banking job,'' said Mr. Stalzer, a 34-year-old Hofstra graduate. ''Living in Europe I learned a lot about food, and I had my mother fax me some recipes and I did some cooking.'' The experience hooked him. He wants to return to Switzerland as a chef.

title: As China Gallops, Mexico Sees Factory Jobs Slip Away
description: At the Gicsa Corporation, workers hunched over bulky sewing machines, busily producing stacks of blue jeans for stores like Target and American Eagle Outfitters in the United States.

title: Nice War. Here's the Bill.
description: In 1991, America's so-called Operation Tin Cup got enough money from its allies to cover the costs of the first Persian Gulf war. In contrast, what could be called ''Operation Begging Bowl'' after the latest war in Iraq has come up empty, leaving us stuck with the bill for the invasion and occupation -- the full extent of which is only now becoming apparent.

title: Tormented by Viral Stowaway, Cruise Ship Staggers Into Port

title: BANK OF AMERICA UNITS WIN REDUCTION OF JURY AWARD
description: Two Bank of America Corporation units won a $43 million reduction of a Texas jury verdict, as a state judge ordered them to pay $8.2 million to a debt collection company for breaching an agreement to sell a debt portfolio. A jury in Dallas had ordered the EquiCredit Corporation of America and the SunStar Acceptance Corporation to pay Cavalry Investments $51.3 million, including $25 million in punitive damages. Judge Bruce Woody reduced the award to $8.2 million on Friday. He overturned all the punitive damages and the verdict on contract interference. Judge Woody upheld the finding of breach of contract. Cavalry said it would appeal the reduction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DARTIGUE, ESTHER
description: DARTIGUE--Esther, retired educator and widow of Haiti's former Minister of Education and UNESCO's former Chief of Mission to the Congo, has died in Paris at 94. Born in Hungary, she earned degrees from Wooster College (Ohio) and Columbia's Teachers College, before moving to Haiti in 1931, where she directed a private nursery and elementary school, introduced sports for girls and worked with a number of charities. During 1948-56, she taught at New York's Mills College of Education and directed several nursery schools in Great Neck. From 1956-66 she directed the UN Nursery School in Paris and later taught English for a year in Burundi. She was the author of several articles on education and was a member of NEA in the US and of OMEP and UCA (which she helped found) in France. At 84, she wrote a biography of her husband, first published in France, which she then translated into English and brought out in the US as ''An Outstanding Haitian: Maurice Dartigue.'' She is survived by a son, John, of Los Angeles; sister Susan Rose and brothers John and Arthur Reithoffer, of Ohio; and nieces, nephews and beyond in Ohio, Illinois, Florida, Haiti and Jamaica.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit To Buy Innovative Software
description: Intuit Inc., the maker of taxpreparation software, agreed to buy Innovative Merchant Solutions for as much as $116 million in cash, gaining a provider of credit and debit-card processing services. Innovative Merchant, based in Calabasas, Calif., had revenue last year of $25 million. The purchase will enable Intuit to broaden its offering of merchant account services, which should increase revenue and profit, the company said. Intuit shares rose $1.20, or about 2.6 percent, to $46.71 in trading on Nasdaq. The news was announced after markets closed.

title: Meeting to Focus on Nets' Future
description: The future of the Nets will be debated at a meeting today of the YankeeNets holding company, a session that could set the stage for the teams relocation to New York. After months of rumors about the sale of the Nets and competing offers from bidders on both sides of the Hudson River, the warring factions within YankeeNets, which owns the Nets, the Yankees, and 30 percent of the Devils, are expected to culminate the matter, said one member of the YankeeNets board. The executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the 15-member board would decide whether to put the Nets up for sale through an auction process or come up with an interim financial plan to deal with team losses that could run as high as $100 million over the next two years. One potential bidder as well as state officials in New Jersey and New York said that they, too, had been told of the board meeting. Bruce Ratner, a New York developer, has been raising money to buy the Nets and move them to a new home in Brooklyn that would be the centerpiece of a large residential and commercial development. Senator Jon S. Corzine and the New Jersey developer Charles Kushner have developed a counteroffer that would keep the teams in New Jersey, either at the Meadowlands sports complex or in Newark. At the same time, Charles B. Wang, an owner of the Islanders, has expressed interest in buying the Nets and moving them to Nassau County.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: CHILD WELFARE CHANGES A federal judge has approved an agreement between New Jersey officials and a child welfare advocacy group to settle a lawsuit challenging the quality of the state's foster care system. The ruling yesterday by Judge Stanley R. Chesler of United States District Court formalizes a plan to overhaul the state's child welfare system under the terms of an agreement reached in June by state officials and lawyers for Children's Rights Inc., an advocacy group based in Manhattan. The agreement includes a provision for New Jersey to grant broad powers to an independent panel to shape the direction of the State Division of Youth and Family Services. The panel, for instance, can determine whether state officials are making enough improvements to the child welfare agency and can take the state back to court if enough progress is not being made. The settlement also called for more than $22 million to hire workers and provide better equipment and more than a million dollars to recruit foster parents. Children's Rights filed its suit against the state in 1999.

title: U.S. RAILROAD SUES TO CONTROL MEXICAN LINE
description: Kansas City Southern, the rail operator that is trying to buy control of Mexico's biggest railroad, sought a court order to block the Mexican line's parent, Grupo TMM, from canceling the $412 million sale agreed to in April. Kansas City Southern, based in Kansas City, Mo., said the request for a preliminary injunction was filed in a state court in Delaware. The companies had agreed to a sale that would raise Kansas City Southern's holdings in the Grupo TFM railroad unit to 80 percent. TMM, based in Mexico City, pulled out of the agreement on Aug. 18. Kansas City Southern had planned the transaction to create a 6,000-mile rail line linking Mexico City and Chicago. TMM officials were not immediately available to comment.

The tribes and the environmentalists said Bonneville had violated its duty to balance the need for power with conservation in the Columbia River Basin. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit said the federal agency, which markets power, had followed proper procedures for drafting and managing conservation programs. But in 1995, the Indians of the Cattaraugus Reservation in Gowanda, N.Y., near Buffalo, set up Pinewoods Community Farming, a nonprofit organization working to cultivate and market the corn with the Collective Heritage Institute in Santa Fe, N.M., and with Slow Food.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Testimony On Weapons Expert's Suicide
description: A suicide expert testified that David Kelly probably took his life because he was a private person who would have found it ''extremely painful'' being publicly identified as the source of a BBC report charging the government with falsifying intelligence on Iraqi arms. The report, which the government denies, led to a judicial inquiry into the death in July of Dr. Kelly, a weapons expert in the Defense Ministry, and what role the government played in it. The suicide expert, Keith Hawton, director of the Center for Suicide Research at Oxford, said ''the importance of the problems he was facing shortly before his death was that these really challenged his identity of himself, his self-esteem, his self-worth, his image of himself as a valued and loyal employee and as a significant scientist.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: RECREATIONAL BOAT BUILDER BUYS MARINE HARDWARE UNIT

Brunswick, based in Lake Forest, Ill., had $632.1 million in debt at the end of the second quarter. Gathered in the wild from Maine to Maryland, these tart-sweet, bracingly astringent fruit are prized for making preserves, and so far the unpredictable supply has only enhanced their mystique.

A native of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, he became the fourth-leading scorer in M.L.S. history (71 goals and 52 assists for 194 points). Moreno played seven seasons with D.C. United and was part of that clubs three M.L.S. championship teams, leading the league with 16 goals in 1997. The MetroStars (8-6-7) acquired Moreno from D.C. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Middletown: Wage Increase For Hospital Workers
description: Orange Regional Medical Center has agreed to grant an 18 percent wage increase over four and a half years to more than 850 nurses' aides and housekeeping, food and laboratory workers. Under the tentative agreement negotiated with 1199/S.E.I.U., New York State's largest union of health care workers, the wages for the housekeeping and food workers will rise to $13 an hour, from $9. The contract will provide training and child care benefits and give laid-off union members priority for being rehired at other unionized hospitals in New York. Orange Regional Medical Center was formed from the merger of Horton Hospital in Middletown and Arden Hill Hospital in Goshen. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: McDonald's campaign aims to regain the youth market.
description: WILL consumers be as ardent about the first coordinated worldwide campaign for McDonald's as the company, struggling to turn around its lagging sales and reputation, demonstrated itself to be yesterday?

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Cima Rejects Cephalon's Unsolicited Takeover Bid
description: Cima Labs, the drug maker that agreed to be bought by aaiPharma last month, has rejected a higher offer from Cephalon. The unsolicited cash bid of $26 a share from Cephalon is valued at $376.6 million; aaiPharma's all-stock offer would be worth $25.22 a share based on yesterday's close. Still, Cephalon's bid ''does not represent a superior proposal,'' Cima said yesterday, adding that it would not begin talks with the biotechnology company. Cephalon, which sells Actiq to treat cancer pain, and aaiPharma are vying to acquire Cima's technology that allows medicines to quickly dissolve in the mouth so patients do not have to swallow pills with water. Shares of Cima fell 19 cents yesterday, to $26.80. Cephalon shares rose 73 cents, to $45.08, while aaiPharma shares rose 50 cents, to $18.47. A company spokesman, Robert Grupp, said Cephalon had not decided whether it would raise its bid.

title: Soggy Stops And Starts At the Open
description: The day session at the United States Open was drizzling to a close yesterday, but two Canadian junior players, Stephanie Dubois and Alexandra Wozniak, were braving the elements and trading ground strokes in the rain as a few dozen spectators moved their heads back and forth in the traditional style to keep track of the ball.

title: Car Bomb Hits Central Offices Of Iraqi Police
description: A truck bomb smuggled into a police compound exploded this morning near the office of Baghdad's police chief, missing him but killing one officer and wounding 26 others, the police said.

title: Cleveland in Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Verizon Wireless and Workers Reach Agreement on a Contract
description: Verizon's largest union announced a tentative agreement yesterday with Verizon Wireless for a bargaining unit representing 51 workers. Officials from both sides said the accord could set the stage for a broader contract settlement later this week involving 78,000 workers.

title: Cool Breeze Brings a Legal Dispute
description: Dairy cows, it turns out, do not like sweltering weather any more than humans do. When it's too darn hot, they simply eat less -- and produce less milk.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COSTELLO, ALBERT J.
description: COSTELLO--Albert J. 9/03/02 We love and miss you, You're always in our hearts. Love forever, Barbara, Gregory, Peter, Albert & family

title: Device Could Yield Clues in Bank Bomb Death
description: The metal collar used to lock a bomb around the neck of a pizza deliveryman who died after a bank robbery near Erie, Pa., last week, was highly unusual and could help identify its maker, investigators said yesterday.

title: Miscellany
description: * Gerbig, Snell/Weisheimer, Columbus, Ohio, part of InChord Communications, opened an office in New York, to be headed by Vince Parry, who continues as president at the InChord New York office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORHEAD, MICHAEL J.
description: MOORHEAD--Michael J. We mourn the loss of our dear brother. You shared your generosity and intellect with all. You will live in our hearts forever. Rest in peace. Cora, Gloria, Janice, James, Margaret, Rodney, William

description: The Department of Defense has identified 283 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JASPAN, NORMAN
description: JASPAN--Norman. The President and Directors of American Friends of Ariel and the Chancellor, Vice-Chancellor, Directors, Faculty, Fellows and students of Ariel United Israel Institutes, express sincerest condolences to our devoted Director and Treasurer, Michael, on the passing of his father, Norman of blessed memory. Norman was a man of deep integrity and profound wisdom, who demonstrated steadfast devotion and commitment to his family. He accepted life's challenges with determination and strength. May his sons Michael and Ronald and their families be comforted by continuing his many good deeds and generosity. Natalio Fridman, President; Rabbi Shear-Yashuv Cohen, Chancellor

description: LAZARUS--Eda (nee Jay) of So. Orange, NJ. Wife of the late Max A. Lazarus, mother of Elaine Lieb, James L. Lazarus and Susan Shapiro. Grandmother of Richard Lieb, Andrew Lieb, Robert Lazarus, Wendy Lazarus Glotzer, Jeffrey Shapiro and Margo Shapiro. Services at Temple B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 So. Orange Ave. Short Hills, NJ Thursday 1:30 PM. For info call ''Bernheim-ApterKreitzman'' 800-938-6372

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Economic Growth Slips
description: Economic growth in Australia fell to 0.1 percent in the second quarter, hurt by declines in tourism and exports, the federal treasurer, Peter Costello, said. The downturn was a result of the outbreak of the SARS virus, the war in Iraq, the global economic slump and a drought, Mr. Costello said. The drought, the worst in the country's history, cut agricultural income 37 percent in the quarter and 72 percent for the year, Mr. Costello said. Farm exports declined 27 percent and tourism receipts fell 17 percent. Those losses were cushioned, in part, by non-farm growth of 3.9 percent and overall growth in business investment of 11 percent. John Shaw (NYT)

title: For Posada, Defense Has Become the Hit
description: When Jorge Posada leaves Yankee Stadium after a loss, his work is not done. When Posada gets home, he turns on his TV, flips to the YES Network and hopes that the Yankees' replay is on. He wants to relive each pitch as soon as possible.

title: Israeli Defense Chief Renews Call for Expulsion of Arafat
description: Regretting that Israel had not already done so, Defense Minister Shaul Mofaz said today that it might move to expel the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, by the end of the year.

title: French Feel the Anguish In Books Inspired by 9/11
description: Whether French writers love or hate the American government of the day, their fascination with the United States never seems to waver. And this is again apparent as France enters its principal book publishing season, known here as ''la rentre littraire.'' This fall, five authors have chosen the events of Sept. 11, 2001, as a way to explore the American way of life and to write about themselves.

title: BIG CALIFORNIA LAW FIRM TO ABSORB SILICON VALLEY FIRM
description: A Northern California law firm, Heller Ehrman White & McAuliffe, said yesterday that it would absorb the Venture Law Group, a 10-year-old Silicon Valley firm whose lawyers have specialized in serving technology and start-up companies. Under the deal, Venture Law Group's roughly 60 lawyers would all join Heller, bringing Heller's total complement of lawyers to about 720 in 12 offices across the United States and abroad. The two firms characterized the transaction as a merger but the surviving firm will use Heller's name. Jonathan Glater (NYT)

title: Empire Of Novices
description: The Bush foreign policy team always had contempt for Bill Clinton's herky-jerky, improvised interventions around the world. When it took control, it promised a global stewardship purring with gravity, finesse and farsightedness.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 2 Held In Omagh Bombing
description: A man and a woman were arrested in a sweep by 200 members of the police and British Army in South Armagh in connection with the 1998 bombing in Omagh that killed 29 people and injured 200. In Ireland last month Michael McKevitt was sentenced to 20 years for leading the dissident republican group that caused the explosion, Real IRA, and a pub owner, Colm Murphy, from the border town of Dundalk, was sentenced last year to 14 years for conspiracy in the case, but no one has yet been charged with murder for the actual attack. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLENBECK, LUKE
description: HALLENBECK -- Luke. On September 2, 2003. Cherished life partner of Thomas Pitcock. Loving brother of William and the late Robert and Germaine Petty. Dear uncle of Germaine Bolhman and many other loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Thursday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompeii Church.

title: For the Lonely Runner, No Rest Until the Finish Line
description: THERE is a special world fostered in the fading light of early September afternoons before school starts and summer ends. All across college campuses, students gather for practice. Football players, burly men in cutoff shirts, grunt and groan in the torpid afternoon heat. Soccer players dance through drills and cross-country runners take off like flocks of birds for punishing runs.

Beloved wife of the late Michael, devoted mother of William Lewis, Nora Lewis, Ogden (Daniel) Kruger and the late Peter Lewis, cherished grandmother of Ilana, Jason, Derinda Wendy, Andrew, Phillip and Haley-Jo. title: A Cook in Her Element, Summer
description: IF Marie Martin's cooking were a little confused, it would be understandable. Her father is a Frenchman who lived in Algeria and moved to Marseille. Her mother, who died when she was 6, grew up in Marseille as the daughter of parents who had immigrated from Barcelona. Ms. Martin was raised in Marseille by her father, her mother's mother, her mother's aunt and, occasionally, her father's mother, who had spent most of her life in Algeria.

title: Backing the Mission in Iraq, But Pondering Its Outcome
description: Not long after President Bush declared an end to the major fighting in Iraq, Jessica Porter hatched an ambitious plan: She would make a quilt for every family of an American soldier who had died in the war. There were about 150 back then, and Jessica, a resolute 19-year-old, had no doubt that she and a few friends could get the job done.

title: Drug-Plan Manager, Caremark, To Buy a Rival for $5.6 Billion
description: In a deal that will combine two of the nation's largest companies that manage prescription drug benefits, Caremark Rx said last night that it had agreed to buy AdvancePCS for $5.6 billion in stock and cash.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Loss For Winemaker
description: Australia's largest wine producer, Southcorp, reported a loss of 923 million Australian dollars ($587) for its fiscal year, in contrast to a profit of 312 million Australian dollars a year earlier, as it wrote down the value of some assets. Earnings before all charges, including taxes, were 132 million Australian dollars. ''The year's results are unacceptable and reinforce the need for urgent actions to improve efficiency,'' the chief executive, John Ballard, said. Since his appointment in February, Mr. Ballard has replaced 7 of the top 12 executives and 40 percent of middle management. He has cut costs at home and begun new sales strategies in Europe, Southcorp's largest export market. Sales in the United States rose 10 percent by volume, but revenue fell 8 percent as the company cut prices to compete with discount brands. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Hamstring And Agassi Too Much For Dent
description: Finally, in the hiccup of time between raindrops, an actual match, with real significance, with drama even, was developing into an eyebrow-raising contest last night on the Arthur Ashe Stadium court.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS IN DECEMBER President Vladimir V. Putin signed a decree setting in motion the country's fourth post-Soviet parliamentary election, to be held Dec. 7. Presidential elections will follow in March. Forty-eight parties have registered to contend for 450 seats in the lower house of the national legislature. The president called for "a fair competition without mudslinging," which he said could be "splashed out onto the people on television."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERMAN, SIDNEY J. KAYE SCHOLER LLP MOURNS THE LOSS OF SIDNEY J. SILBERMAN
description: SILBERMAN--Sidney J. Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the loss of Sidney J. Silberman, our colleague and partner from 1952 until his retirement in 1992. Mr. Silberman made invaluable contributions to Kaye Scholer as its Chairman. As head of the Corporate Department as well as an accomplished tax and estates lawyer, he set an example of excellence for the entire firm. He served as Chairman of the Lawyers Division of UJA, president of the Associated YM-YWHAs of Greater New York, and endowed scholarships at Columbia University from whose law school and college he graduated. Mr. Silberman, an accomplished lawyer, a World War II veteran and a friend, will be missed. We extend our sympathies to his dear daughter and son-in-law, Judy and Cantor Uri Aqua, his grandchildren Daniel, Talia and Adam, and his companion Helene Fagin.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Baby's Death Is Ruled A Homicide
description: The medical examiner's office has ruled the death of a 6-month-old Ozone Park boy a homicide, citing whiplash, as well as brain and spinal injuries, as causes of the Aug. 4 death. The boy, Christopher Adams, was born Jan. 16. On July 31, he was admitted to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, and was transferred to New York Hospital Center in Queens, where he died. The cause of death was listed yesterday as fatal child abuse syndrome, and the ruling said the injuries were caused by shaking and abuse. No charges have been filed. The investigation is continuing, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: U.S. Stand Could Stall Korea Talks, Chinese Say
description: As North Korea reversed itself and pledged to continue negotiating about its nuclear program, Chinese officials argued today that the bigger obstacle to a diplomatic solution is what it called the reluctance of the United States to bargain in earnest.

title: Lions Lose Top Rusher
description: James Stewart, who ran for 1,021 yards last season and was Detroit's leading rusher for the past three years, will miss the season after separating his right shoulder in the Lions' final exhibition game last Thursday against the Buffalo Bills.

title: For an Unassuming Red, a Simple Fish Supper
description: THESE Burgundies from lesser-known areas of the Cte de Beaune are, as our wine panel discovered, lesser known for a reason. Some were like shooting stars -- bright up front and instantly fading. Others were well made but lacked body. Many were just bad.

title: Critic's Notebook; Kit Kat Kick Endures, Old Chum
description: Nobody doesn't like ''Cabaret.'' O.K., that's probably an exaggeration, but unlike a lot of other long-running musicals you can name, nobody resents it. It never became a joke the way ''Cats'' did. It's not a symbol of corporate theater, as ''The Lion King'' is. You won't find anyone casting eyes upward in amazement at the taste of the theatergoing public and declaring, ''Egads, won't it ever close?'' the way they do with ''Phantom of the Opera.'' (Well, I do that, anyway.)

title: A Gentle Spin for a New American Bistro
description: WHEN a hot economy cools off, the temperature drop can be beneficial. The frantic restaurant culture of the day before yesterday encouraged mad dreams. Competent but unremarkable chefs, some of them still in their mid-20's, dreamed of superstardom. Investors with too much cash on hand stood ready to back them. Manhattan was engulfed by a wave of pretension, as restaurants intended by nature to be bistros or cafes decided that they were three-star temples of avant-garde cuisine. The bubble has burst, and in many cases diners can actually be grateful. There's only so much genius to go around.

title: Endangered Peace in Afghanistan
description: Afghanistan is paying a heavy price for the Bush administration's reluctant and miserly approach to nation-building. The central government is bankrupt and powerless. The economy remains inert. And now the Taliban appears to be making a deadly and alarming comeback, just 21 months after American-backed forces drove it from power. For weeks the White House has been hinting that more coherent, better-financed policies are on the way. They are badly needed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ECCLES, MARY, VISCOUNTESS
description: ECCLES--Mary, Viscountess. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of Mary Eccles, widow of the 1st Viscount Eccles. In 1949 she became a founding Fellow of the Library, and in 1966 she joined the Board of Trustees, serving as a valuable member for 37 years. She was an accomplished scholar of English literature and a distinguished book collector, especially of Samuel Johnson and Oscar Wilde. Passionate in her support of the Library and its collections, she was also a generous and beloved patron. We will greatly miss her and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. S. Parker Gilbert, President Charles E. Pierce, Jr., Dir.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Currents Cut Swim Field
description: More than 300 people were pulled from the ocean as strong currents battered the 34th Waikiki Roughwater Swim. Lifeguards, firefighters and the Coast Guard rescued swimmers with helicopters, motorboats and rescue boards. Of the 1,000 swimmers, 364 finished the race, said Jim Wiencke, a volunteer who worked on communications. The others were rescued or swam ashore. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: It's Back to School for Material Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Lieberman Proposes Insurance To Cover Everyone to Age 25
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said today that as president he would create a federal program to provide affordable health care coverage for 31 million people who do not have it, a group that includes the 9 million children who now lack health care benefits.

title: U.S. General Optimistic on Liberia Mission
description: A senior American general gave an upbeat assessment of the security situation in Liberia today, saying a West African-led peacekeeping mission was going well enough that American troops supporting it might soon go home.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 31 about a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the antiterrorism law known as the Patriot Act referred imprecisely to the six groups that joined the American Civil Liberties Union in the suit. While two were indeed Muslim, four were civil rights or community service organizations that do advocacy work on behalf of Muslims, Arab-Americans and others. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 5 Killed In Karachi
description: Gunmen shot dead five people, including four political workers, in the latest spate of political violence in the port city of Karachi, The Associated Press reported. The killings began in the morning, when gunmen shot and killed two officials of the Mutahida Qami Movement, or United People's Movement, a group that represents Muslims who fled India and settled in Pakistan after the two countries achieved independence from Britain in 1947. Later in the day, at the men's funerals, gunmen struck again, killing two other activists of the group and a Sunni Muslim cleric apparently caught in the cross-fire. It was not known who carried out the shootings, but members of the Mutahida Qami Movement have repeatedly clashed with a group that broke away from the party known as the Mohajir Qami Movement, or Refugee People's Movement. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORIENTER, ANDREE
description: ORIENTER--Andree. On August 31, 2003, aged 96. Beloved cousin of Peter Skomorowsky, Anne-Elisabeth and Jacques Moutet, Barbara Crane and Eleanor Fox; admired friend of countless people. She will be long remembered for her wit and intelligence by those fortunate to have known her.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Concern For Opposition Leader
description: The Bush administration is ''deeply concerned'' over the well-being of the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who is protesting her three-month detention with a hunger strike, the State Department said. Richard A. Boucher, the department spokesman, said that ''credible reporting from our embassy'' indicated that Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was refusing to eat, despite denials from government officials in Myanmar, the former Burma. ''We continue to urge the Burmese government to release Aung San Suu Kyi and all other political prisoners immediately,'' he said. Christopher Marquis (NYT)
