description: From Spain With Cheese

title: AMETEK BUYS INSTRUMENT MAKER FOR $50 MILLION
description: Ametek Inc., a maker of electric motors, has agreed to buy the closely held Chandler Instruments Company for about $50 million to add to its oil and gas equipment business. Chandler Instruments, based in Tulsa, Okla., will post 2003 sales of about $30 million, Ametek said. Chandler makes measurement equipment for the oil and gas industry. The purchase adds to Ametek's drilling and exploration equipment and brings in instruments that analyze fuel and other liquids. Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., will pay for the purchase by drawing on its $300 million credit line, a company spokesman, Bill Burke, said.

title: Judges' Rulings Imposing Death Are Overturned
description: The federal appeals court in San Francisco yesterday overturned the death sentences of more than 100 prisoners in three states because judges rather than juries had made the crucial factual determinations in sentencing them to death. The court ruled that a Supreme Court decision last year striking down the capital sentencing laws in the three states and two others because they allowed judges to make those factual findings must be applied retroactively even to those inmates who had exhausted all of their appeals.

title: U.S. BANCORP TO ADD TO SUPERMARKET BRANCHES
description: U.S. Bancorp said yesterday that it would open 163 branches in Safeway Inc. and Vons stores in the next two years to increase its presence in California and Arizona. The new outlets will increase U.S. Bancorp's in-store branch network by one-third, to 446, the bank said. Most of the branches will be in Sacramento, San Diego, San Francisco and Los Angeles. The remainder will be in Phoenix and Tucson. U.S. Bancorp has been building the its branch network by purchasing offices from competitors. Based in Minneapolis, U.S. Bancorp has branches at 30 retailers including Wal-Mart and Target stores.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Child Welfare Changes
description: A federal judge has approved an agreement between New Jersey officials and a child welfare advocacy group to settle a lawsuit challenging the quality of the state's foster care system. The ruling yesterday by Judge Stanley R. Chesler of United States District Court formalizes a plan to overhaul the state's child welfare system under the terms of an agreement reached in June by state officials and lawyers for Children's Rights Inc., an advocacy group based in Manhattan. The agreement includes a provision for New Jersey to grant broad powers to an independent panel to shape the direction of the State Division of Youth and Family Services. The panel, for instance, can determine whether state officials are making enough improvements to the child welfare agency and can take the state back to court if enough progress is not being made. The settlement also called for more than $22 million to hire workers and provide better equipment and more than a million dollars to recruit foster parents. Children's Rights filed its suit against the state in 1999.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: 3 States Drop Talks On River Water
description: Alabama, Florida and Georgia have abandoned five years of negotiations and will return to litigation over Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River Basin. In July, the states reached an understanding on some points in their 13-year dispute, with Aug. 31 as the goal for a final accord. Three federal suits had been delayed for the talks. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: China Resisting Pressure From U.S. Treasury Chief to Ease Its Currency Policy
description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said today that he was encouraged by ''interim steps'' China is taking to modernize its financial system, but acknowledged that Beijing had not committed itself to liberalize trading in its currency anytime soon.

title: First Lady Campaigns for Teachers and Trainees
description: Laura Bush, the first lady, visited Mercy College in Midtown Manhattan yesterday to draw attention to the school's role in training teaching fellows, people who switch careers to teach in some of New York City's most troubled public schools.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit For Fund Manager
description: The British fund manager Schroders said yesterday that first-half profit rose 69 percent to 22.5 million ($35.3 million), helped by job cuts that reduced costs and a drop in the pace of asset withdrawals by institutional investors. Still, revenue in the period, which ended June 30, was 202.4 million, down 19 percent from a year earlier because of the decline in stock markets, the company said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Cubs 4, Cardinals 2: Sosa's Homer in 15th Paces Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) - Feeling a bit weary after playing 15 innings, Sammy Sosa found a way to get some rest.

title: Officer Halts Rape Attempt At Midday
description: A man with a long criminal record attacked and tried to rape a 33-year-old woman yesterday in Prospect Park, but was stopped by a police officer who chased him down and arrested him, the authorities said.

title: Census Shows Ranks of Poor Rose in 2002 By 1.3 Million
description: The number of Americans living below the poverty line increased by more than 1.3 million last year, even though the economy technically edged out of recession during the same period, a Census Bureau report shows.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Farm Official Replaced
description: The minister of agricultural development replaced the head of the farm reform agency with a more moderate economist in a move seen as a favor to Brazil's powerful farming lobby. The minister, Miguel Rosetto, named Rolf Hackbart to succeed Marcelo Resende, who was widely considered an ally of landless peasants who have clashed violently with landowners. Mr. Hackbart promised to begin talks to end the clashes. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Young Blood Is Keeping Mets' Games Interesting
description: The crowd of 24,390 at Shea Stadium last night included one man who had taken a red-eye from Southern California, and his only concern was that the weather might wash out his son's major league debut. But the rain held off and Danny Garcia singled in his first at-bat for the Mets as his father, also named Danny, watched from the stands.

title: The National Bison Range
description: Later this week Native Americans representing the Salish and Kootenai tribes will meet in Denver with officials of the Interior Department and the federal Fish and Wildlife Service. They will be trying to negotiate an agreement to take over management of the National Bison Range, an 18,500-acre prairie reserve in northwestern Montana. If negotiations end successfully, this would be the first time a tribe has taken over the management of such a property since 1994, when the Tribal Self-Governance Act authorized such arrangements.

title: Mutual Funds Allowed Fraudulent Trading, Spitzer Says
description: Just six months after reaching a settlement with investment banks over tainted research, Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, said today that major mutual fund companies had engaged in fraudulent after-market trading practices with privileged institutional investors.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BEA Executive To Start Company
description: William T. Coleman III, a founder of BEA Systems eight years ago, is leaving day-to-day involvement in the company for a start-up venture. He will remain on the BEA board and be a consultant, the company said. Mr. Coleman founded BEA, a business software company, along with Ed Scott and Alfred Chuang in 1995, and was chief executive until October 2001, when he handed that role over to Mr. Chuang. Since then, Mr. Coleman has been working with BEA's field sales force and has held the title of chief customer advocate of the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Utilities Point Their Fingers At Each Other Over Blackout
description: Five electricity organizations involved in the Aug. 14 blackout have sent letters to the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee seeking to implicate one another, to varying degrees, in the cascading failure.

He was believed to be 64, not 63; he was an uncle, not a nephew, of Muhammad Said al-Hakim.

We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

description: MITTMAN--Joseph, on September 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Esta, devoted father of Larry and Harriet, fatherin-law of Ellyn, adored grandfather of Wesley, Jordan, Lanie and Howie. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN CLIMBS. The yen rose to its highest against the dollar in over a year on speculation an improving economy will reduce Japan's need to try to lower its currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 115.95, down from 116.29.

title: Say Ahhh (and Watch the Monitor)
description: YOU sit down, you open your mouth, you say ''ahhh.'' The dentist leans down and peers in, metal probe in one hand, angled mirror in the other, and starts poking.

title: Bertelsmann Encounters Some Turbulence
description: A day after the French media conglomerate Vivendi Universal struck a deal with General Electric to exit the global entertainment business, Europe's other big media empire, Bertelsmann of Germany, demonstrated the costs of staying in that business.

title: Florida Executes Killer Of an Abortion Provider
description: Nine years after he calmly shot and killed an abortion doctor and his volunteer escort outside a Pensacola clinic, Paul Jennings Hill died by lethal injection here today as his supporters declared him a martyr and warned that his actions might be replicated.

title: Werner Goldsmith, 79, Dies; Studied Mechanics of Impact
description: Dr. Werner Goldsmith, an authority on the mechanics of collisions who went on to become a leader in the study of head injuries, died on Aug. 23 at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 79.

title: Study Finds Europeans Distrustful of U.S. Global Leadership
description: Europeans are increasingly uncomfortable with the United States' global leadership, with majorities in almost every nation opposing the direction of American foreign policy, a new poll has found.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Aug. 23 about Alfred Kaarmann, one of the last of the so-called Forest Brothers, bands of Baltic-state guerrillas who spent years hiding from Soviet forces, misstated the date of the Soviet invasion of Estonia. It was June 1940, not June 1939.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Food Company To Expand
description: One of Asia's largest food-and-beverage companies, the San Miguel Corporation, will invest $700 million in China and other Asia-Pacific countries, its chief executive, Eduardo Cojuangco, said. He said San Miguel planned to build plants in Cambodia, Malaysia and Thailand and invest more in its existing breweries in Australia, China, Indonesia and Vietnam. Mr. Cojuangco said the plan is in line with the company's goal of becoming one of the 10 largest food and beverage companies in the Asia-Pacific by 2007. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: COACH LEATHER RAISES FORECASTS FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: Coach, a retailer of luxury leather goods, raised its forecast yesterday for its first-quarter earnings and revenue. Earnings for the quarter, which ends Sept. 27, will increase to at least 36 cents a share on sales of $245 million, the company said. Coach earned 24 cents in the first quarter a year earlier on sales of $192.8 million. It previously forecast a profit of 33 cents a share on revenue of $230 million. Sales at stores in the United States that have been open at least a year are ahead of expectations, the company said. The company's sales increased 73 percent in the fourth quarter. Sales at Coach stores in Japan are growing more than 10 percent, the company said.

title: Many Wary of Trenton Plan To Privatize Pension Fund
description: The McGreevey administration's plan to allow private investment firms to manage New Jersey's multibillion-dollar employee pension funds is beginning to emerge as a sensitive issue in several pivotal legislative elections this fall.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Questions Linger About Parade Killing
description: Two days after Anthony Bartholomew, 21, was shot dead in a crowd of thousands at the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, the circumstances remained unclear and the killer remained unknown, in part because the killing took place in such a public place, the police said yesterday. Initial theories of an attempt by Mr. Bartholomew and others to rush a parade float were discarded. Speculation by residents of the Crown Heights neighborhood, where the killing took place, that the killer or Mr. Bartholomew might have gang affiliations was similarly baseless, a police official said. All that seemed clear was that Mr. Bartholomew and his killer somehow bumped into each another and an altercation ensued, leading to gunfire, a police official said. Few witnesses have come forward, the official said. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CANTOR, LOU
description: CANTOR--Lou. The Board of Directors of The City College Fund mourns the loss of its distinguished member and former secretary, Lou Cantor. A devoted alumnus of the College and a member of its track team, he never lost his deep feeling for his alma mater and its students. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Stanley H. Kaplan, Chairman Herbert Robinson, Esq, President James L. Schatz, Executive Director

title: For the Democrats, No Lack of Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics Claim Failure to Lift Poor Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3  An educational advocacy group that helped write the No Child Left Behind Act, President Bush's signature education law, today ranked the federal Education Department "in need of improvement" for failing to carry out the law's requirements to raise the quality of classroom teachers.

title: Economic Scene; Necessities, not luxuries, are driving Americans into debt, a new book says.
description: THE booming economy of the 1990's spawned many a spurious piece of conventional wisdom. One is that Americans' materialism has run amok.

title: KRAFT TO ACQUIRE CEREAL BUSINESS FROM ORGANIC MILLING
description: Kraft Foods said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Back to Nature brand cereal and granola business from Organic Milling, which is closely held. Terms will not be disclosed, a Kraft spokeswoman, Donna Sitkiewicz, said. The Back to Nature brand generated almost $10 million in sales in 2002, Kraft said. Organic Milling, which is based in San Dimas, Calif., will produce Back to Nature cereals and granola for Kraft under a manufacturing agreement. Kraft is based in Northfield, Ill.

title: A Jog in Baghdad Offers Lessons About Life in a War Zone
description: Except for the barbed wire and the gunfire, running in this city is not so bad.

title: What Parents Can Do to Foster Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROOKER, NANCY NEU MANN
description: BROOKER -- Nancy Neu mann, age 61, beloved wife of T. Kimball Brooker; survivors include her daughters, Isobel (Brian M.) Case, Vanessa (Lee V.) Eastman, her son T. Kimball, Jr. (Katrina) Brooker, and her two devoted grandsons, T. Kimball Brooker, III and Charles Shaffer Case. A Funeral Service will be held at St. Chrysostom's Church, 1424 North Dearborn Parkway, Chicago, IL. 60610 at 11:00 A.M. Monday, September 8. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer contributions to be sent to The Nancy Neumann Brooker Fund at St. Chrysostom's Church. Funeral Info: Donnellan Family Funeral Services 847/675-1990.

title: Schumer Acts to Help Workers Form Unions
description: Citing organized labor's declining membership, Senator Charles E. Schumer introduced legislation today that would overhaul federal laws to make it easier for workers to join unions.

title: MAKER OF WATER PURIFICATION EQUIPMENT TO CUT 200 JOBS
description: Ionics, a maker of water-purification equipment, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 200 jobs, or 10 percent of its worldwide staff. In a revamping over the next six months, the company will also consolidate some operations and realign management. Ionics, which is based in Watertown, Mass., said it expected the moves to save about $15 million a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, JACK
description: SCHACHTER--Jack, September 2, 2003, in Boca Raton, FL. Loving husband of the late Shirley Schachter. Loving father of Robert and Wendy Schachter and Gloria and Norman Goldblatt. Devoted grandfather of Adam, Beatriz, Eric and Andrea. He is also survived by sisters Mildred Newman and Helen Lischner. Services September 5, 2003, in Southwest Ranches, Florida. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Adding Eye Contact To Your Web Chats
description: ALONG with the Dick Tracy wrist phone and the transporter in ''Star Trek,'' the videophone has long been on the wish lists of Jetsons-watching gadget lovers. And while there are a few videophone options available today that are not altogether clunky, they involve costly hardware that can usually only be used to call others who have the same setup.

title: Bodybuilder's New Goal: Learning Curve on Policy
description: The hosts of the debate tonight had considered placing an empty chair and a placard reading ''Arnold Schwarzenegger'' at the end of the table to highlight his absence. But in the end, they thought it wiser to ignore Mr. Schwarzenegger, who was 400 miles away, than to pay him notice.

title: A Scandinavian Spin on Country Casual
description: SWEDISH country style is gaining popularity as a casual alternative to French provincial and early American dcor. It's refined without being off-putting, elegant but understated.

title: Preventing Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: One Man's Trash Is Another Man's Purchase
description: Gomi is a Japanese word for trash. An East Village boutique called Gomi USA specializes in postconsumer products. It sells a $500 bench made from used snowboards that, by keeping the material from going into the trash, ''saved 117.84 kilowatt-hours of energy, 32.58 gallons of oil, 325.8 gallons of water, 2.7 cubic feet of air pollution and .15 cubic yards of landfill,'' said Tina Carr, above, an owner. A $29 clock was a New York taxi medallion, and a $50 basket, top, reuses 252 bottle caps. Doormats recycle rubber scraps from a flip-flop factory. This year, the shop plans to sell $9 spiral-bound sketchbooks with blank pages of recycled-denim paper. Gomi is at 443 East Sixth Street; gominyc.com. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Block Designs That Take Their Own Sweet Time
description: In these days of cheap-chic design, quickie do-it-yourself projects and 48-hour television makeovers, the slower arts can be overlooked. Two studios in upstate New York, however, can provide the patient customer with hand-block-printed wallpaper produced with early-19th-century techniques. The American Paper-Staining Manufactory at the Farmers' Museum in Cooperstown can take up to a year to produce a new pattern. ''The process goes as slowly as your hands can go,'' said Wendy Weeks (right), the shop's supervisor and master printer. Adelphi Paper Hangings (above), a Virginia-based company whose studio is in Sharon Springs, N.Y., has two presses, but there is still a three-month wait. At both, the background paint is hand-brushed onto the paper, then the pattern colors are applied one at a time using a press and wooden blocks. For those who need a quicker fix, the Farmers' Museum sells paper-covered boxes ($20 to $50), and each studio has stock pattern papers (the Adena Pin Rings pattern, from Adelphi, left, is $425 a roll, 11 yards by 21 inches), which take about a third of the time to print. The Farmers' Museum is at (888) 547-1450. Adelphi is at (540) 253-5367. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Eclectic Mix of Bands, And Likewise of Fans
description: In a time when music festivals, radio-station concerts and package tours all seem to depend on the same small subset of bands to fill their seats, the lineup of the Unlimited Sunshine Tour seems like a joke at first glance.

title: What Parents Can Do to Foster Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Readers React to Pogue's Suggestions for Microsoft
description: Last week in this space, I wrote up a little To Do list for Microsoft: a list of annoying features that Im hoping will be fixed in the upcoming Office 2003.

title: Raymond Walters Jr., 91, Book Columnist
description: Raymond Walters Jr., a retired editor for The New York Times Book Review who established and wrote the Paperback Talk column, died on Aug. 30 in Columbus, Ohio, where he moved in 2001. He was 91 and a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Hussein Tape Is Authentic, C.I.A. Says
description: The Central Intelligence Agency believes that Saddam Hussein was probably the speaker on a new audiotape that was broadcast on Arab television on Monday, officials said today. On the tape, the speaker denies that Mr. Hussein or his followers were behind last week's bombing in Najaf, Iraq, which killed a top Shiite Muslim cleric and almost a hundred others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELANEY, FLOYD J.
description: DELANEY--Floyd J., age 80, passed away on September 2nd in Summit, NJ. As an esteemed business owner for 53 years, he was a pioneer in the air conditioning and mechanical contracting trades. A distinguished and engaging gentleman, he was well-traveled and known to many, from heads of state to Nobel scientists. Floyd was a friend to everyone and loved by all. He converted to Judaism in 1994 and was a great friend to Israel. He was a patriarch in the true sense, not just to his own family. He is survived by his beloved wife Ariella, his children, Thorne, Douglas, Cathy, John, and his grandchildren, Kate, Annie, Max, Marjorie, Molly, Dylan, August, Adria, Margaret and Samuel. Services Thursday, 1:15pm, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATKINS, SADIE (NEE COHEN)
description: WATKINS--Sadie (nee Cohen). On September 2, at the age of 95. Beloved wife of the late John L. Watkins. Survived by two loving sons, Marvin Cohen and Walter Watkins, a sister Bella Huff and brother Martin Cohen and numerous grandchildren, great grandchildren and nieces.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toshiba Strategy
description: The Toshiba Corporation said it would introduce a flat-panel television model on a global basis, rather than just in Japan, to tap into stronger markets overseas. Japanese companies typically introduce marquee products at home where prices are generally higher and consumers more finicky. If sales take off in Japan, then they start to produce export models. But with revenue slumping and prices falling at home, companies are finding it harder to generate profits in Japan and see less value in using their domestic market as a testing ground. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Marines Turn Over a South-Central Area of Iraq to a Polish-Led International Force
description: The United States handed over command of an area south-central Iraq to Poland's military today, the incomplete transfer serving as a somewhat flawed model for the multinational cooperation the United States hopes to amplify.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Expanding Gas Production
description: The French-Belgian oil and chemicals group Total said it planned to expand its gas exploration operations and increase production amid continued high gas prices. It estimated that by 2007, exploration and production would account for 60 percent of capital employed, compared with 48 percent last year. Gas retailing and chemical production activities will be scaled back. Total estimated that by 2007 they would each account for 20 percent of capital employed, compared with 26 percent last year. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: * Carrefour Group, Paris, the largest European operator of supermarkets, hypermarkets and convenience stores, to agencies owned by Havas, Paris, to handle advertising in France, which had been handled by agencies owned by the Publicis Groupe, Paris. Billings were estimated at $180 million to $200 million.

title: Gambling Foes Try to Curb Growth of Connecticut's 2 Casino Giants
description: After battling successfully to block newly recognized Indian tribes from building casinos in Connecticut, opponents of the gambling industry are now turning their attention to the two giant casinos that already exist in the state, trying to limit their ability to grow even larger.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Vivendi Universal's agreement to enter exclusive negotiations with General Electric on a merger of their entertainment assets misidentified the parent of the Bravo cable channel. It is NBC, not Vivendi.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: CALENDAR
description: All Things Victorian

title: Mironov Re-Signed By the Rangers
description: The Rangers re-signed the free-agent defenseman Boris Mironov, who was acquired by the team in January from the Chicago Blackhawks. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: With a Torrid Month, Toyota Moves Ahead of Chrysler in Sales
description: The day that the American automobile industry has been dreading for years arrived today. Toyota outsold Chrysler in August, the first time one of Detroit's Big Three has fallen to fourth place.

title: White May Lose Gold, Not Shot at Olympics
description: The American sprinter Kelli White will not be barred from the 2004 Athens Olympics, but she may still lose the two gold medals she won in the 100 and 200 meters at the recent world track and field championships in Paris after testing positive for a stimulant, the sport's world governing body said yesterday.

title: Debate Flares in Catholic Church as Priests Question Celibacy
description: Adebate that has simmered for years among Roman Catholics in the United States about whether the priesthood should be opened to married men is now on the front burner, pressed by priests concerned about their dwindling ranks.

title: Canada Gets Second Cut In Key Rate This Summer
description: The Bank of Canada lowered its main interest rate today for the second time in less than two months but signaled that with economic recovery on the horizon, the cut might be the last for some time.

title: Big Investors Urged to Unite For Reforms
description: The New York State comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, proposed yesterday that big investors should work together to try to prevent more corporate scandals like those that hurt shareholders and employees of Enron and WorldCom.

title: Helpers to Get Seat at Table, Rumsfeld Says
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Wednesday night that countries that contribute troops and financial support to American-led military and reconstruction operations in Iraq could count on a seat at the table in decision making about the mission there.

title: The Midprice Market? It's Toast
description: The growing majority of toasters sell in the United States for less than $20. Luxury brands are also increasingly popular. But midprice toasters like the handsome Russell Hobbs model, above, less than $40 on the Internet, declined as a category, according to the NPD Group, a market tracking company in Illinois. Middle-class customers ''don't necessarily shop in the middle,'' said Donna Wallace, an NPD retail analyst. And neither upscale boutiques nor discounters stock many midprice brands. So consumers may find that the real bargains are not the utilitarian $7.79 toasters, nor the Dualits marked down from $200, but the Russell Hobbs toasters -- if they can find them. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Hey, Doll, You Ought To Be in Picture Windows
description: In 1961, Alexander Girard's Textiles & Objects opened on 53rd Street in Manhattan to showcase Herman Miller fabrics. In the shop window were fantastically colored dolls with bushy yarn hair. Ray Eames discovered the dolls, handmade around 1960 by Marilyn Neuhart in Los Angeles. Ms. Neuhart, 73, still embroiders them in limited quantities for up to $2,000 from Mximo. A women's collective in Albuquerque makes $72 silk-screen versions (above); (505) 245-8700 or www.maximodesign.com. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Organizers Still Hoping Not to Move Open's Finals
description: The rain that has transformed the second week of this United States Open into a waiting game continued yesterday. Only 13 minutes of tennis were played in the eventually canceled day session -- enough time for top-seeded Kim Clijsters to take a 3-0 lead over fifth-seeded Amlie Mauresmo at Arthur Ashe Stadium -- and no day matches were completed.

title: A Blockbuster Finale For a Soggy Summer
description: THE events in my garden this year sometimes seemed to belong in the Book of Job. But despite the cold rainy spring and the tropical heat wave that brought in the beetles, this summer's bounty surpasses any I can remember.

title: COUNCIL CONTESTS/28th District -- Queens; Written Off, an Incumbent Rejoins the Battle in Queens
description: Several weeks ago, City Councilman Allan W. Jennings Jr. found himself off the ballot for the Democratic nomination for his own seat, the only incumbent whose re-election was considered virtually impossible.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 19 about breeding dogs for desired traits misstated the name of the journal that published research about a large survey of dog behavior. It was Applied Animal Behavior Science, not The Journal of Applied Behavioral Science.

title: Suez Is Expected to Sell Off Its Water Treatment Division
description: Suez, the French utility, is expected to announce on Thursday that it is selling Ondeo Nalco, its water treatment and environmental service business, to an alliance of private equity investors for about $4 billion, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Public Lives profile on Tuesday about Jeff Benedict, a lawyer, author and leading opponent of Indian casinos in Connecticut, gave an incorrect location in some copies for his hometown, Niantic. It is 10 miles west of New London, not east.

title: That Pesky Artist Is at It Again, but Don't Tell Mom
description: SCOTT LoBAIDO, who fashions himself as a political artist, has a reputation that not even a mother can love. Not his mother, anyway. He was in the news again a few weeks ago for protesting the city's closing of a firehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, by painting a mural of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg shooting a New Yorker in the back.

title: 2 Cameras Seek Bliss As a Couple
description: IF you could ask a younger version of yourself -- say, the 1996 you -- which pairs of standalone gadgets would become commonplace hybrids by 2003, how would you answer you? Telephone + camera? Preposterous. PalmPilot + cellphone? Surely you jest. PC + television? Get outta town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLOTKIN, ZALMAN, MD.
description: PLOTKIN--Zalman, MD. On September 2, 2003. Renowned internist and cardiologist, whose 59 years of medical practice were in NY and CA. An ardent Zionist, he was medical student delegate to the Second Zionist Congress in Vienna; President of Revisionists Western States; Close personal friend of Menachim Begin; honored by the Technion along with Edward Teller, Edmund de Rothchild and Kirk Douglas. Physician devoted to his patients. Loving and passionate husband and father. Survived by his wife Paula and his daughter Dr. Frieda Plotkin of NYC. Services Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Small Businesses, Big Growth
description: Believe it or not, the little guys in the so-called outer boroughs could help revive New York City's economy. Small businesses have emerged as a strong growth sector in the city -- and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should find new ways to support them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUELAND, HAROLD
description: BRUELAND -- Harold. The Lawyer's Orchestra mourns the death of bassist Harold Brueland. A renaissance man of grace and humanity, he loved philosophy, music, art and political affairs. We will miss his wry wit, bravery and insuppressible spirit.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 23 about President Bush's order to the Treasury Department to block and freeze the assets of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group, misstated the day Hamas formally abandoned its declared cease-fire with Israel. It was Aug. 21, not Aug. 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIBBS, ELI C.
description: GIBBS--Eli C., September 2, at the age of 85. Beloved husband of Bernice. Adored father of Karen and Joy. Dear father-in-law of Jerry. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Bradley and Michele. He will live in our hearts forever.

title: Market Place; Merger of Drug-Buying Companies Has Some Doubting Purchase Price
description: Plans to combine two of the nation's largest drug benefit managers, Caremark Rx and AdvancePCS, raised concerns on Wall Street yesterday about the price of the deal. Some critics saw another problem, the possible narrowing of competition.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Concern Over Sentence
description: Prime Minister John Howard of Australia said that he was disappointed at the four-year sentence given the radical Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Bashir and that he remained convinced that Mr. Bashir was the head of Jemaah Islamiyah, which Australia and the United States consider a terrorist organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUCHS, ABRAHAM
description: FUCHS--Abraham. Congregation Ohab Zedek of Belle Harbor, NY, records with sorrow the passing of our beloved Hazzan. He served as our Cantor for more than four decades. In the course of this time he inspired our congregation with his masterful liturgical interpretation of our prayers, lifting us to spiritual heights at our Sabbath and Festival services. We will be forever grateful for his dedication to our Synagogue and for sharing his special talents with us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, to Miriam and Charles Selingut; his grandchildren, Nora and Philip Brooke, Suzanne, Erica and Tsvi Selingut; and great grandson, Elan. May the family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yehoshua Berkowitz, Rabbi Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Emeritus Joel Berkowitz, President Stanley Liker, Chairman, Board of Governors

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Investigate Abuse
description: The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who is thought to have sexually abused two boys in Manhattan and the Bronx. Investigators said the first assault, involving an 11-year-old, occurred at 5 p.m. June 25 in a building on Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem, and the other, involving an 8-year-old, occurred at 4:30 p.m. Saturday in a building on Carroll Place in the Bronx. Both boys were groped, the police said. They described the man as six feet tall, slim, and 18 to 20 years old. Investigators asked anyone with information to call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Bush Firm on Tax Cuts as Remedy for Economic Languor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  Undaunted by predictions that federal deficits might balloon in the next decade, President Bush said today that permanent tax cuts were the best way to reinvigorate the economy and keep it going.

title: Crumbled To Perfection
description: Prada-clad fashionistas may shudder, but country style is back on the radar. Paris Hilton, the ubiquitous hotel heiress, just completed a stint amid the hay bales for ''The Simple Life,'' a reality-show update of ''Green Acres.'' New York magazine has promoted the Catskills as the hippest place to be (if you can handle the rumored dearth of arugula). And newsstands are packed with consistently upbeat paeans to la vie provenal, like Country Home (colorful, low-clutter, 1.2 million circulation) and Country Living (wildflowers, folk art, 1.7 million circulation), two of the biggest shelter magazines in the country, as reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. What's a fad-conscious city slicker to do? Cancel the opera tickets and head for the hills, obviously. But is it possible to survive in style where D.S.L. service doesn't go? Two families -- one in upstate New York and one in Sweden -- show how it's done.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Opposition Gains
description: President Robert Mugabe's political forces lost ground in nationwide municipal elections over the weekend, gaining just about 100 council seats nationally as against 134 for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. Opposition forces also took six of seven mayoral contests. Mr. Mugabe's Zanu-PF party called the vote ''a rude wake-up call'' in advance of parliamentary elections in 2005, but some analysts said low voter turnout cast doubt on the meaning of the results. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A Bigger U.N. Role in Iraq
description: With terrorism on the rise in Iraq and American forces stretched to the limit, the Bush administration has stepped back from its stubborn resistance to greater United Nations involvement. Washington is now canvassing support for a new Security Council resolution that would place international military operations in Iraq under U.N. auspices, with an American general in command of the troops. Crucial details are now being negotiated. It is unclear how much authority Washington is willing to give the U.N., but the new resolution offers an approach all Council members should support. A broadened security effort has become more urgent since four massive bombs went off in Iraq over the past month, including one that destroyed the U.N.'s Baghdad headquarters and another that killed a leading Shiite cleric.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: A.T.F. To Open Satellite Office
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives will open a satellite office here in the next few months, officials announced yesterday. The office, at the Jersey City Police Headquarters, will have two officers who will coordinate with the local police on operations like undercover gun buys and the tracing of illegal guns. Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham said he sought federal help to combat what he sees as a ''very serious'' gun trafficking problem in the city and lobbied federal officials to get the new officers. Jonathan Miller (NYT)

title: Spreading the Rhythm (And the Joy) Around
description: These days, a set by Bill Charlap's trio is a merciless thing: it's the tight, polished showman's experience that we associate with the great era of American live music, captured on records like ''Ahmad Jamal at the Pershing'' and ''James Brown Live at the Apollo.'' Mr. Charlap, the pianist, has been working with the bassist Peter Washington and the drummer Kenny Washington (they are not related) for almost six years, and each member of the trio knows where each of the others is going to go. If that's not literally true, it seems so.

title: For Student Essayists, An Automated Grader
description: WHEN Camden County College in southern New Jersey introduced standardized final exams for English composition four years ago, Anthony Spatola, the chairman of the English department, knew he had a problem: he and other teachers had to grade 1,500 essays in a few days.

title: A Flirtatious Soundtrack To Romance
description: Sometimes the chemistry between musicians and the chemistry of love get all tangled up in wonderful ways. When watching the jazz singer Stacey Kent make music with her husband, the tenor saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, it is easy to imagine yourself eavesdropping on intimate pillow talk by besotted partners in a luxury suite atop some faraway pop-jazz Olympus.

title: For the Democrats, No Lack of Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Fine Over Trader's Mutual-Fund Moves
description: Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, said yesterday that his office had uncovered widespread illegal trading by hedge funds and mutual fund companies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fashion Stylist Sentenced In Jewelry Theft
description: A Manhattan fashion stylist who has worked with pop music and Hollywood celebrities was sentenced yesterday to one and a half to three years in prison for stealing more than $1.5 million worth of jewelry that was lent to him for work-related exhibiting and marketing. The stylist, Derek Khan, pleaded guilty in June to one count of grand larceny. He was freed on $50,000 bail. Mr. Khan's clients have included Sean Combs, Lauryn Hill and Monica. The jewelry included items from Harry Winston and Piaget stores. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: 26,000-Hit Wonder Keeps It Hopping
description: ON a rainy Monday night at 7, when most of the East Village bars in Manhattan are empty, a steady crowd is rolling into Hi Fi. Drinks are two for one until 8, but that is only one of the reasons many patrons choose the otherwise nondescript watering hole out of the many on Avenue A. They are there for EL DJ, an MP3 jukebox with 26,000 songs to choose from.

title: Must-Own TV
description: When he was on NBC, David Letterman became a cultural icon by mocking his corporate bosses at General Electric. The subtext to his gags: What can a maker of light bulbs possibly know about running a television network? Plenty, it turned out. NBC has been the most successful major network in the past decade.

title: Study Finds Appetites Reduced By Hormone
description: A single infusion of an intestinal hormone made people eat less for the rest of the day, regardless of whether they were fat or thin, researchers are reporting today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about a house in Vienna designed by the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein misidentified the city in England where he died. It was Cambridge, not London.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Tax Repeal Considered
description: Thailand said yesterday that it might allow overseas investors to buy local bonds and abolish a 15 percent withholding tax on interest paid to bondholders, in a bid to increase trading in bonds and persuade Asian nations to buy more of one another's debt. ''I am trying to overhaul the tax regime,'' the finance minister, Suchart Jaovisidha, said. The withholding tax is ''something I would like to do away with to bring it in line with the international community.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Charge Against D.E.A. Agent Dismissed
description: A federal judge yesterday dismissed a manslaughter indictment that prosecutors had filed against a Drug Enforcement Administration agent who killed an unarmed drug suspect by shooting him in the back. The agent, Jude Tanella, shot the suspect, Egbert David Dewgard, after a wild chase and violent struggle in East Flatbush last year. The judge, Nicholas G. Garaufis of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, said the federal agent was immune from a state prosecution because he reasonably believed that Mr. Dewgard was reaching for the agent's gun. Through a spokesman, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said he was preparing to appeal. William Glaberson (AP)

title: As Suburbs Grow, So Do Waistlines
description: TWO years ago, Jason and Maria Witt moved here, to the western suburbs of Washington, and fell in love with their 1970's subdivision, Poplar Tree Estates. The Witts bought a 4,800-square-foot house in which they are raising three boys, 8-month-old triplets. They have quiet streets and big lawns. What they do not have is an easy way to walk, as they once did when they lived in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Shots Close British Embassy
description: The British Embassy in Tehran came under gunfire just after Iran announced that it was temporarily calling its ambassador back from Britain. The diplomat was recalled to protest the arrest in London last month of Iran's former ambassador to Argentina in connection with a 1994 bombing in Buenos Aires. No one was injured in the gunfire, but the embassy was closed as an investigation was begun. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Comptroller Warns City Could Lose 9/11 Aid
description: New York City is in danger of losing nearly $4 billion of the more than $21 billion that President Bush had promised to it for recovery from the 2001 terrorist attack, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said yesterday.

title: So Many Coupons, So Few Redemptions
description: Advertisers distributed a record 336 billion coupons last year, up 3.4 percent from 2001, according to the Coupon Council of the Promotion Marketing Association in New York, but the redemption rate fell to its lowest level since 1980, 1.13 percent, compared with 1.23 percent in 2001.

title: Roddick Advances Between Raindrops
description: For the second consecutive day, only one match finished at the United States Open, and for the second consecutive day, the late-night winner was an American men's tennis star.

title: Latin Grammys Go On Minus Cubans
description: Juanes, a Colombian rocker whose songs merge romantic yearnings with hopes for better times in his homeland, was triumphant at the fourth annual Latin Grammy awards held here tonight and broadcast on CBS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISBERG, DAVID CHARLES
description: WEISBERG--David Charles, passed away in Los Angeles on August 31, 2003. Beloved husband of Katherine; father of Chloe and Victor; son of Alan and the late Marian Weisberg. VP of the architecture firm Wimberly Allison Tong & Goo. To our deep sadness, David's remarkable courage, determination and humor could not defy his battle with leukemia. Donations may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about the Bush administration's proposed energy plan misstated the extent to which President Bush would allow oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northeastern Alaska. He proposed opening 1.546 million acres, not all 19 million.

title: Pataki Names Panel to Study School Aid
description: Under pressure from the Court of Appeals to ensure a sound basic education for every New York City child in public school, Gov. George E. Pataki named a commission today to determine the cost of such an education and to recommend ways to provide it.

title: COURT CLEARS SALE TO BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY
description: A Tennessee appeals court ruled yesterday that Clayton Homes could proceed with its sale to Berkshire Hathaway, dismissing accusations of fraud made by an investor. The court said it would lift an order on Monday that had prevented Berkshire from paying Clayton shareholders $1.7 billion since Aug. 7. The timing will give the investor, the Denver Area Meat Cutters and Employers Pension Plan, time to appeal the decision, according to court documents. The fund asserted that Clayton Homes might have altered ballots to approve the takeover, and that the transaction helped only the Clayton family, which owns 28 percent of the company. The ruling stops a trial that had been scheduled to start within weeks.

title: Few Ways to Limit Farm Aid, Report Says
description: On the eve of global trade talks, the United States Department of Agriculture released a report today showing that there were few effective payment limits on the $20 billion that the country spends each year to subsidize farmers.

title: For Schooling, a Reverse Emigration to Africa
description: Najima and Nayaba Bawa were despondent when their parents first raised the subject of sending them home to Ghana. It was three years ago, one evening as their mother was braiding Nayaba's hair. Najima, then in junior high, had lost focus in school. Hanging out with friends had become more important than studying. She had even brought home a few C's on her report card.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSLER, JULIE ANN
description: OSLER--Julie Ann. Age 56, passed away in Chicago, September 3, 2003, from the devastating effects of a stroke she suffered nearly five years ago. She was a daughter of the late David Osler and Grace Osler Sonenblick and the sister of Susan Osler and Jordan Metzger, Sagaponack, NY. and Amy Osler and Michael Lowenthal of Chicago, IL. She also leaves her loving and beloved nieces, in New York, Dana Brockman and Abby Brockman and in Chicago, Dr. Lydia Sharp and Joanna Sharp and her wonderful caregiver Lily. Julie's loving and giving spirit, her love of classical music, cooking and photography, brought joy to those whose paths she crossed. It breaks our hearts we were unable to make the world a better place for our sweet and unassuming Jewel. We all lose. Her presence, her vitality, her voice has been silenced much too soon. We will miss her always. Memorial contributions in Julie's name can be made to the Animal Welfare Society in New Milford, CT. or the 92nd Street Y School of Music. Memorial to be announced.

title: Robber Killed by Neck Bomb Also Had a Gunlike Device
description: The mystery of the pizza delivery man turned bank robber who was killed by a bomb around his neck deepened today, as investigators said that the man had a gunlike weapon in his possession before he died.

title: Spurrier Is Learning That Less Can Be More
description: Steve Spurrier rarely takes his eyes off the football. It is the quarterback in him, the jock who still resides in a coach's body. When he needs to emphasize a point, Spurrier will brush his quarterbacks aside and grab the ball himself, dropping back to pass in a move that is both instructional and competitive.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Farms Report
description: Farmers and workers groups split over a report by the country's Human Rights Commission that alleged widespread rights abuses against black farm laborers but dismissed contentions that a spate of attacks on the nation's largely white farmers were racially motivated. Some 1,500 white farmers have died in attacks since apartheid ended a decade ago, and the deaths are under investigation by a government panel whose final report has been delayed. Some farmers acknowledged the poor working conditions cited in the report but said that ''the worst kind of human rights violation is to murder and maim'' farmers. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Senators Question Why NASA Failed to Assess Blame in Loss of Shuttle
description: In the first Congressional hearing since the release of the independent report into the loss of the space shuttle Columbia and its seven astronauts, NASA's administrator came under hard questioning today from senators who criticized the agency for not holding specific people accountable for the disaster.

title: Prague Journal; Travel Advisory: British Abroad, Staggering About
description: The party started early on Friday, when EasyJet's 6:15 a.m. flight to Prague took off from Stansted Airport in Britain.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life Column on Thursday, about an animated Web site created by two brothers after they abandoned careers in rock music, misspelled the names of two fictional bands that are favorites of a character on the site. They are Taranchula and Limozeen, not Tarantula and Limousine.

title: Into the Tundra: Does Oil Fit In? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday comparing Africans' and Americans' ability to take AIDS drugs on time misattributed a comment about American patients. The researcher who said that when those patients change their pill regimens, they often ''let a month's worth go to waste,'' was Dr. David Bangsberg of the University of California, San Francisco, not Dr. Merle A. Sande of the University of Utah.

title: Pierwise, One Person's Wreck Is Another's Art
description: For years, artists and architects drawn to elegant decrepitude have fought to keep the High Line -- the abandoned elevated railroad that snakes through Chelsea and the meatpacking district -- from being demolished. Now that a renovation is scheduled for the railroad, some of those artists and architects are focusing on another relic of the city's industrial past.

title: A Heated Chinese Economy Piles Up Debt
description: Looming through the gray smog of every big Chinese city these days, high above the incessant rattle of jackhammers, are the construction cranes, slowly swinging back and forth over huge steel and concrete boxes wrapped with fine lattices of bamboo scaffolding.

title: France and Germany Oppose U.S. Plan for U.N. Role in Iraq
description: BERLIN, Sept. 4  The leaders of France and Germany, giving their first response to the Bush administration's turn to the United Nations for help in the occupation of Iraq, announced that their countries would not support an American draft of a Security Council resolution that would authorize both an expanded international force and financial help in Iraq.

title: In Texas Fight, One Democrat Finally Blinks
description: And then there were 10.

title: Mortgage Index Declines
description: An index of applications for mortgages fell for the fourth consecutive week, to the lowest in more than a year, as rising loan rates discouraged refinancing, an industry report showed.

title: Sick and Suspicious
description: While I.B.M. officials deny it, evidence is being offered by stricken employees that unusually large numbers of men and women who worked for the giant computer corporation over the past few decades have been dying prematurely.

title: Embattled Estrada Withdraws as Nominee for Federal Bench
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  Miguel Estrada, President Bush's embattled nominee for an important federal appellate court, gave up his two-year struggle for confirmation today and asked Mr. Bush to withdraw his name from consideration. His decision ignited a smoldering political dispute on Capitol Hill over nominations for federal judgeships.

title: Into the Tundra: Does Oil Fit In?
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH INSURER AGREES TO SETTLE LAWSUIT BY DOCTORS
description: The Cigna Corporation, a health insurer, has agreed to pay $85 million to settle accusations that it routinely underpaid doctors, lawyers representing 700,000 doctors said yesterday. The company, based in Philadelphia, also agreed to make changes to its billing processes and business practices that may bring the value of the settlement to more than $700 million, the lawyers said. The settlement will be presented today to Judge Federico A. Moreno of United States District Court in Miami, said Archie C. Lamb Jr., a lawyer for the doctors. Cigna said the settlement would reduce third-quarter earnings about $40 million.

title: For the Democrats, No Lack of Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column yesterday about the rejection of a lawsuit by Indian tribes and environmentalists against the Bonneville Power Administration in Portland, Ore., carried an incorrect credit. It was by The Associated Press.

title: Play Like an Ostrich, You Might Lay an Egg
description: Ostriches are rumored to bury their heads in the sand, to shut out a view of danger. Some bridge bidders behave similarly, ignoring a clear peril. In the diagramed auction North raised to three no-trump following an overcall of two hearts on his right. He hoped his partner held a heart stopper, and South took the same position. The result was down one, which was slightly lucky. It would have been down two if West had held six hearts, or if the minor suits were divided less favorably. The declarer has only seven top tricks. The game-bid was certainly optimistic, for there was no assurance of success, even if South could stop the hearts.

title: A Lesson in Walking to School As Long Island Bus Drivers Strike
description: Thousands of children on eastern Long Island went back to school today on foot, on scooters or in their parents' cars after negotiations between striking bus drivers and their employer fell through.

title: Lottery Numbers
Take-Two Profit Increases 60%
description: Take-Two Interactive Software said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 60 percent, increased full-year forecasts a third time and announced its ''Grand Theft Auto'' video games will be sold for Microsoft's Xbox console.

title: Suspense Ends in North Korea: The 'Dear Leader' Is Re-elected
description: The election outcome was never in doubt, but when North Koreans heard ''the happy news,'' housewives left their houses, children left their schools and workers left their jobs, all ''dancing with bunches of flowers in their hands,'' according to the state news agency.

title: The City Life; Aboard the Sleeper
description: Nearly everyone on the commuter railroad platform looks immured in a sense of the coming day or, if it's an evening train, the day just past. Everyone projects a certain composure, an awareness of the unwritten rules of commuting, the cautious self-containment in the hopes that others will remain self-contained. The train pulls in. People board and quickly find their seats, and the wheels begin to rumble and clack. And one by one the commuters drop into sleep. Before long, the entire car is asleep, except for some wide-eyed first-time rider whose alertness looks like a kind of perversity. All that workday armor has been shuffled off, and though all the passengers are still wearing suits and ties and business ensembles, you can see the pajamas in their faces.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Suit Filed Against Discount Drug Plan
description: The Pharmaceutical Care Management Association, a trade group, has filed suit against the state, saying a prescription drug plan to take effect on Sept. 13 would damage the ability of pharmacy benefit managers to secure the lowest prices. Under the plan, about 275,000 state residents will be eligible to buy drugs at a discount up to to 60 percent. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Pennant Races, With the Works, to Go
description: Sammy Sosa's game-winning home run over the left-field ivy at Wrigley Field had been a souvenir for about 90 seconds on Tuesday afternoon, but two Chicago Cubs fans were already plotting to continue their long day of frenetic baseball. It did not matter that the first game with the St. Louis Cardinals lasted 15 innings and almost 5 hours.

title: U.S. COURT BLOCKS PLAN TO EASE RULE ON MEDIA OWNERS
description: A federal appeals court issued a surprise order today that prevents the Federal Communications Commission from enacting new rules that would make it easier for the nation's largest media conglomerates to add new markets and areas of business.

title: PEPSI BOTTLING REDUCES ITS EARNINGS FORECAST FOR YEAR
description: The Pepsi Bottling Group, the world's largest distributor of Pepsi-Cola beverages, cut its annual earnings forecast yesterday because of declining sales in Mexico. Net income this year will be $1.55 to $1.57 a share, compared with a July forecast of as much as $1.67 a share, company executives said at an investor presentation in Boston. Mexican sales will decline about 5 percent in the third quarter because of discounting by smaller regional soda bottlers, the company said. The $1.14 billion acquisition of Pepsi-Gemex, Mexico's largest Pepsi bottler, in November will contribute less to earnings than expected, the company said. Stock in Pepsi Bottling, based in Somers, N.Y., fell $2.36, or 10 percent, to $21.90 a share.

title: Bank of Japan Chief Vows to Continue Easy Policy
description: Seeking to halt the sharp rise in long-term interest rates and the yen, the governor of the Bank of Japan, Toshihiko Fukui, said today that the central bank would maintain its extremely easy monetary policy even if the economy improved.

title: 5 Dead in 2 Blasts Under Train Near Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3  At least 5 people were killed and more than 30 wounded today when two bombs exploded under a passing commuter train near the war-ravaged Chechen Republic, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JASPAN, NORMAN
description: JASPAN--Norman. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, husband of the late Dr. Jeanne Rafsky Jaspan, father of Michael (and Terry) Jaspan and Ronald (and Michele) Jaspan and brother of Ruth Hauser. The University is grateful for his and his family's enduring commitment to the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies as directors of the Harry and Jane Fischel Foundation. Our sincerest condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman BRGS Board of Directors

title: Acknowledging Difficulties, Blair Says He Will Stay the Course
description: LONDON, Sept.4  Prime Minister Tony Blair acknowledged that his government was facing a tough time at home and abroad but asserted he still thought Britain was right to go to war in Iraq and insisted he would forge ahead with an ambitious domestic agenda.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Steady With the Water

title: Carl Larsson Meets Ralph Lauren
description: Prada-clad fashionistas may shudder, but country style is back on the radar. Paris Hilton, the ubiquitous hotel heiress, just completed a stint amid the hay bales for ''The Simple Life,'' a reality-show update of ''Green Acres.'' New York magazine has promoted the Catskills as the hippest place to be (if you can handle the rumored dearth of arugula). And newsstands are packed with consistently upbeat paeans to la vie provenal, like Country Home (colorful, low-clutter, 1.2 million circulation) and Country Living (wildflowers, folk art, 1.7 million circulation), two of the biggest shelter magazines in the country, as reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. What's a fad-conscious city slicker to do? Cancel the opera tickets and head for the hills, obviously. But is it possible to survive in style where D.S.L. service doesn't go? Two families -- one in upstate New York and one in Sweden -- show how it's done.

title: YankeeNets Board Takes No Action to Sell Nets
description: The YankeeNets holding company once again stepped back from the brink of selling the Nets yesterday. A deal, if completed, could lead to a new home for the team in Newark or New York, or at the Meadowlands. Instead of designating a favored buyer for the Nets or setting up an auction, as many had expected, the 15-member YankeeNets board took no action at its meeting yesterday, Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for the holding company, said. The YankeeNets board is riven by disagreements and is unhappy about the poor financial condition of the Nets and the Devils. What happens next is anyones guess. Im still waiting, said Richard Monteilh, the city business administrator in Newark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATERS, DOROTHY F. (HOFFMAN)
description: WATERS--Dorothy F. (Hoffman), 84, Of Holiday, Florida. Formerly of the Bronx. On August 16 surrounded by her family after a courageous battle with cancer. Wife of Michael J. Waters of Manhattan, worked for AT & T for 35 years retiring in 1981. Survived by daughter, Mae Nohilly of CT. Beloved grandmother to Mae Archacki of CT, Thomas Nohilly of N.Y., Dorothy Buslewicz & Michael Nohilly of CT. Also survived by sister Lillian Grattan of N.J. & 9 great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held at Gate of Heaven in Hawthorne, New York. She will be loved and missed always.

description: By most measures, the Department of Veterans Affairs has solved the puzzle of making prescription drugs affordable for at least one big group of Americans without wrecking the federal budget.

title: Plea of Not Guilty in WorldCom Case
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chairman of WorldCom Inc., pleaded not guilty in Oklahoma yesterday to criminal charges that he cheated investors in an $11 billion accounting fraud.

title: Universal To Cut Prices Of Its CD's
description: Battered by online piracy, the Universal Music Group, the world's largest record company, said yesterday that it would cut prices on compact discs by as much as 30 percent in an aggressive attempt to lure consumers back into record stores.

title: ESPN Reaches a New Low: Deceit, Catheters and Football
description: A urological breakthrough was achieved in television sports Tuesday night in an episode of ESPN's ''Playmakers'' series. There have been few such moments before, except for Rafael Palmeiro's Viagra commercials. But on the very air that usually carries ESPN's Sunday night National Football League games, ''Playmakers'' featured a fictional crack-smoking running back being catheterized with a teammate's clean urine to fool a random drug test to which his owner alerted him.

title: White? Out.
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including advice on fall wardrobes and disagreements about World Trade Center memorials.

title: Don't Expect a System To Behave Uniformly
description: Q. My Windows Me operating system rarely shuts down properly, and it freezes and crashes about once a week. I have heard that this problem is common with Me; should I upgrade to a different system?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAIRCHILD, JULIAN
description: FAIRCHILD -- Julian. The Board of Trustees of The Green - Wood Cemetery mourn the passing of Julian Douglas Fairchild, Trustee and former Chairman, who served the cemetery faithfully for over 40 years. Throughout his tenure on the Board, he resourcefully guided Green-Wood with devotion and interest; wise in his judgment and clear in his thinking. In his passing, the Trustees have lost a most esteemed colleague. The Trustees extend to his wife and family our heartfelt condolences. By Order of the Board of Trustees of the Green-Wood Cemetery

title: White House Approved Departure of Saudis After Sept. 11, Ex-Aide Says
description: Top White House officials personally approved the evacuation of dozens of influential Saudis, including relatives of Osama bin Laden, from the United States in the days after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks when most flights were still grounded, a former White House adviser said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, LEWIS M. JR.
description: DAVIS--Lewis M. Jr., died on August 15, 2003. Graduate of USNA 1933 and RPI. Survived by beloved wife, Margaret, of Pittsburgh, and loving children, Rick Davis of Alexandria, VA, and Petie Davis Snow of Clayton, CA, and two grandsons. Service on September 22, 2003, at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Martin and Jets Are Ready to Take Off the Wraps
description: For the first time since the Jets' season opener last year, Curtis Martin will be able to run without pain.

title: CANADIAN COMPANY BUYS DRUG RIGHTS FROM ABBOTT LABS
description: Axcan Pharma, a Canadian drug maker, said yesterday that it would pay Abbott Laboratories as much as $75 million in cash for the rights to a gastrointestinal treatment, Itax. Axcan, based in Mont St.-Hilaire, Quebec, will pay $10 million up front, with the rest dependent on Itax reaching certain goals. Its sales may reach as much as $300 million within five years, Axcan said. The company will start testing Itax in the last of the three trials usually required by regulators, and expects to submit the drug to the Food and Drug Administration in 2006. Abbott is based in Abbott Park, Ill.

title: Betraying the Sick in Africa
description: There is an old joke about a man who kills his parents and then begs the court for mercy because he is an orphan. For such chutzpah on a global scale, consider President Bush's overseas AIDS initiative. In his last State of the Union address, the president announced a new program to fight AIDS in Africa and pledged $15 billion over the next five years. But instead of using existing channels, Mr. Bush created a new bureaucracy. Now the White House and Congressional Republicans argue that since the bureaucracy is not ready, dying patients must wait.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAVLOUNIS, STEVE
description: PAVLOUNIS--Steve on September 2, 2003, at age 77. Husband of Christine. Father of Constance, Elizabeth and James. Grandfather of Arielle, Chelsey, Logan, Isabella, Skylar and Madison. Brother of Demetri. Friends may call at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st St) Thursday 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral service will be held at St. Elftherios, 359 West 24th Street, Friday, 9:30 AM.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hilton And I.B.M. To Develop Hotel Kiosks
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it would work with I.B.M. to develop kiosks that Hilton plans to install in hotel lobbies. Terms were not disclosed. Hilton, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., planned to begin testing the kiosks, which allow guests faster ways to check in and out of their rooms, in the Hilton New York and Hilton Chicago hotels in the fourth quarter, the company said in a statement. Hilton is trying to attract more customers to its hotels after a drop in demand for rooms after the war in Iraq and the SARS virus led many leisure travelers to curb vacations. Shares of Hilton rose 18 cents, to $15.46; I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., rose 57 cents, to $86.33, both on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLENDER, SANFORD
description: SOLENDER--Sanford. Americans for Peace Now mourns the passing of our long-time Executive Committee and Board member, Sanford Solender, who was deeply committed to improving the lives of the Jewish people, securing a lasting peace for the State of Israel, and building a better country for all Americans. Sandy brought compassion, clarity, and sound reasoning to each endeavor that he undertook. He will be deeply missed. Luis Lainer, Chair Debra DeLee, President and CEO Board of Directors of APN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TELL, JEANETTE (NEE BARON)
description: TELL--Jeanette (nee Baron), formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, on Saturday, August 30, 2003 after a prolonged illness. Loving wife of the late Benjamin L. Tell. Mother of Robert Tell, Judith Feldman and Franklin Tell. Mother-in-law of Judith Tell, David Feldman and Phyllis Tell. Grandmother of Emily, Katherine, Justin, Caroline, Mathew, Samuel and Brette. Sister to Alvin Baron. A lady of grace, wit and style. Donations may be made in memory of Jeanette Tell to Jewish Family Services of Metrowest, Transitional Eldercare Services, 256 Columbia Turnpike, Florham Park, NJ 07932.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STULMAN, ELGA KRON
description: STULMAN--Elga Kron. On September 2, 2003, age 70. ''A Woman With Soul''. Beloved wife and best friend of Stephen L. Stulman for 50 years. Loving mother of Andrea and Richard Dennett, Jessica and Laurence Sheinman, James and Stacy Stulman, Laura and Jason Cooper; adoring grandmother of Alexandra, Adam, Jonathan and Rebecca; devoted sisterin-law of Joan Gilbert; caring cousin and true friend of so many. Contributions may be made to the Hebra Kadisha Fund of Cong. B'nai Jeshurun. Service Thursday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Palestinian Prime Minister Puts His Position on the Line
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Sept. 4  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, challenged the Palestinian parliament today to back his agenda or dissolve his government, seeking to broaden his authority over Palestinian security in hopes of renewing peace talks with Israel.

title: It's Tricky, Grafting Brando's Sneer to Bogart's Shrug
description: IT pales in importance when compared with the cloning of Dolly the sheep or the mapping of the human genome, but researchers from the University of Southern California are trying to deconstruct the basis of what makes humans look human. And this time Hollywood directors, not just scientists, care about the results.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: United Way Appoints Leader
description: The United Way of New York City yesterday appointed Lawrence Mandell, its chief operating officer since 1992, president and chief executive. Mr. Mandell, 60, is to assume the new post on Jan. 1, succeeding Ralph Dickerson Jr., 56, who announced in February that he planned to retire at the end of the year. The United Way of New York City is the city's largest privately operated provider of funds for health and human service organizations. It said that Mr. Dickerson's salary was $420,000 a year, but that the amount to be paid Mr. Mandell had not been determined. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Neither Fish Nor Fowl, a Department Store Defies Definition
description: A silver blob opens today in Birmingham, England, as Selfridges department store, left and right. The structure is clad in 15,000 aluminum disks, above right, and designed by the London firm of Future Systems, known for Comme des Garons boutiques in Manhattan and Tokyo and the media center at Lord's cricket ground in London. ''We were inspired by Paco Rabanne dresses with sequins or chain mail,'' said Amanda Levete, a Future Systems partner. ''Our other analogy was the scales of a fish.'' British critics have compared the design to the Guggenheim Bilbao as well as to a toadstool, spacecraft and soap bubble. ''People feel uncomfortable with something they haven't seen before and invent names for it,'' Ms. Levete said. And, she said, unlike the problems with cleaning Bilbao, to clean the new Selfridges, they will just hose it down once a year. EVE M. KAHN

title: China Agrees to Free Trading in Its Currency, but Not Now
description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow and his Chinese counterparts agreed today that China should eventually allow its currency to trade freely on international markets. But Beijing rejected calls to move quickly in that direction, saying it might cause financial instability in China and abroad.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Information Technology Chief Named
description: The chief information officer at the Energy Department, Karen S. Evans, left, will take over the government's top information technology job later this month, the White House said. Ms. Evans will succeed Mark A. Forman, who resigned in early August, as director of e-government programs and information technology at the Office of Management and Budget. In 20 years of government service, Ms. Evans has worked for several federal agencies, including the National Park Service, the Office of Personnel Management and the Department of Agriculture; before joining the Energy Department, she served as director of the Information Resources Management Division at the Department of Justice.

title: Hundreds of Rule Violations Tied to Possible Blackouts
description: Electric companies violated transmission grid rules hundreds of times last year in ways that could have led to a power failure, the president of the rule-making association testified today in the first hearing on the Aug. 14 blackout.

title: Nassau and Albany in Accord On Economic Recovery Plan
description: Nassau County officials and state lawmakers announced an agreement today to help the county out of its fiscal straits by creating a Nassau sewer authority and imposing new county fees, including a $10 surcharge on motor vehicle registrations.

title: Concerto for Orchestra and Hopeful City; Renewal Project In Detroit Blends A Concert Hall And a School
description: If one absent-minded real estate developer had not forgotten his Jackson Browne cassettes on a business trip 12 years ago, one of the country's most extraordinary urban and cultural development projects might never have happened. But forget he did, and partly as a result the Detroit Symphony Orchestra will move in October back into a renovated version of the hall it occupied during its glory days in the 1930's. There will also be a large new wing to provide space for student orchestras, jazz concerts, dances and other events.

title: Research, Reconsidered
description: To the Editor:

title: Spelling It 'Dinsey,' Children on Web Got XXX
description: Be sure to spell Britney Spears's name correctly when you type it into an Internet browser.

title: AirTrain Test-Driver's Family Files Suit Over Fatal Crash
description: Nearly a year after a Queens man was killed while test-driving the new AirTrain to Kennedy International Airport, his parents filed a lawsuit yesterday, saying the airport operator and a contractor failed to take adequate safety precautions.

title: In Yale's Eternal Labor Fights, A Volatile Mix Fuels Walkouts

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware

Terms were not disclosed. Hilton, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., planned to begin testing the kiosks, which allow guests faster ways to check in and out of their rooms, in the Hilton New York and Hilton Chicago hotels in the fourth quarter, the company said in a statement. Hilton is trying to attract more customers to its hotels after a drop in demand for rooms after the war in Iraq and the SARS virus led many leisure travelers to curb vacations. Shares of Hilton rose 18 cents, to $15.46; I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., rose 57 cents, to $86.33, both on the New York Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Wanted In Carjacking And Rape
description: The police are looking for a 21-year-old Brooklyn man who they say stole a car at gunpoint, tried to force a woman into the car and later abducted and raped a teenager. At 10:30 p.m. on Saturday, a man, whom the police identified as John Mercure, used a gun to steal a car from a man on East 37th Street in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. A few hours later, at Avenue A and East 89th Street in Remsen Village, the gunman pulled a woman out of a car, fired a shot into the ground, and tried to put the woman into his stolen car, the police said. She broke free and jumped back into the car she had been riding in. When that car pulled away, the man followed for a short while, firing another shot, the police said. A few hours later, at 2:30 a.m., he drove up to a 17-year-old girl who was walking with friends near Rogers Avenue in Flatbush. The police said he used a gun to force the girl into the car, and drove her about a mile to his home on Clarendon Road, in East Flatbush, and then raped her and fled. She went to an area hospital on her own, said Officer Louis Camacho. Tina Kelley (NYT)

The answer is the United States, because they attacked Iraq. Moreover, it is the terrorist king, waging war."
