title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Banker Supports Euro Rules
description: France's defiance of European Union rules on deficits came under attack yesterday from its own central bank governor, Jean-Claude Trichet. Any changes to the 3-percent limit on budget deficits ''could undermine the credibility of the economic and monetary union,'' Mr. Trichet said. President Jacques Chirac has called for a temporary suspension of the rules to give governments more room to spur their economies, and France and Germany plan tax cuts that might lead to violations of the rules. Mr. Trichet will take over as president of the European Central Bank on Nov. 1.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway To Cut At Least 450 Jobs
description: Gateway Inc., a personal-computer maker that has reported losses in 10 of the last 11 quarters, will cut at least 5.3 percent of its work force by hiring other companies to produce and assemble PC's. Gateway will eliminate 450 jobs by closing a manufacturing plant in Hampton, Va., and by paring an undetermined number of positions at plants in North Sioux City and Sioux Falls, S.D., a spokesman, Bob Sherbin, said. The initiatives will save $115 million to $130 million a year. That is in addition to $400 million of annual spending cuts the company announced in March. PC shipments at Gateway fell 25 percent in the second quarter as the company tried to compete with larger rivals like Dell Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company. Gateway shares rose 2 cents, to $6.10 on the New York Stock Exchange. Gateway maintained its forecasts for a loss of 19 cents a share on revenue of $874 million in the third quarter and for a loss of nine cents a share on sales of $954 million in the fourth period, the chief financial officer, Roderick Sherwood III, said yesterday.

Now that the federal government has given the island back to New York, the city must protect it, so the city is moving a truck from a closed firehouse in Williamsburg to the island. Other drivers stopped their cars in the middle of the autobahn, near the western city of Bochum, and started picking up the money, the equivalent of $108,000. When the police arrived to unclog the jam, they were able to retrieve only 3,000 euros, or about $3,250. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, HARRY CLARE, SR.
description: MOORE--Harry Clare, Sr. The Board of Directors and staff of the Lyford Cay Foundation, Inc. and The Canadian Lyford Cay Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of our friend Harry C. Moore, Sr. Mr. Moore became a Director of the Lyford Cay Foundation in 1979. He served as Treasurer from 1990 to 1993, as President from 1990 to 1995, as Chairman from 1995 through 2002 when he retired from the day-to-day administration of the Foundation to serve as Honorary Chairman. He also served as a Director of The Canadian Lyford Cay Foundation from 1990 through 2002. Mr. Moore was instrumental in the development of the Foundation's extensive tertiary level scholarship programs for Bahamian students studying in the US, Canada, UK, Caribbean and The Bahamas and was the driving force behind the Foundation's endowment fundraising efforts. His generosity of spirit, his passionate commitment to the Foundations and his strength provided a model for us all. He was an inspiration and will be missed by many. Our deepest sympathies to Monique and all of his family. Manuel J. Cutillas, Chairman Lyford Cay Foundation, Inc. Loretta A. Rogers, President The Canadian Lyford Cay Foundation

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shipbuilding Dispute
description: South Korea, accused by the European Union of unfairly subsidizing its shipbuilding industry, responded with a complaint of its own, charging that European countries are the ones subsidizing shipbuilders. South Korea's ministry of foreign affairs and trade said it had filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization denying that it unfairly subsidized ship builders and accusing members of the European Union of providing such subsidies. The South Korean complaint is based on a decision by the European Union that enables member countries to assist their shipbuilders in the face of South Korean competition. South Korean companies, led by Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's biggest builder of merchant vessels, hold a global market share of 36 percent, while European shipbuilders account for only 8 percent of sales worldwide. title: The Stalled Middle East Peace Plan
description: The Middle East peace plan, known as the road map, may be on the verge of collapse. The refusal of radical Palestinian groups -- and Yasir Arafat -- to abandon terror remains the biggest obstacle. But there is plenty of blame to go around. With the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, hinting yesterday that he might quit his post out of frustration over his impotence, it is clearer than ever that all involved -- the United States, Israel, Europe, the Arab states and Mr. Abbas himself -- are failing to live up to their commitments.

title: T-Shirt Resort Tries On a Tux
description: WHEN Dave Sanner decided to buy a weekend house in Lake Tahoe in 2001, it quickly became obvious that the lake's south shore offered the best deals, particularly on the small 1950's-era cabins (many needing work) that he was looking at. ''The north lake is more spectacular and whatnot, nicer and classier, but I like it up here a lot more,'' Mr. Sanner, 38, said as he hammered on a shed that he was converting into a guest house, sawdust in his hair and a nail gun at his feet. ''And it was cheaper.''

title: Strahan Revives Some Old Habits
description: They were three little words, but Giants Coach Jim Fassel and Michael Strahan, the team's most dominant defensive player, understood their significance and how they could impact the season.

title: Shuttle Panel's Head Says Current Craft Can Continue Flights
description: With increased vigilance, the space shuttle can be flown safely for a few more years, but the craft should be replaced as soon as possible, the head of the panel that investigated the Columbia accident said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOPAL, DONALD
description: TOPAL--Donald on September 3, 2003. Loving husband and companion of fifty-three years to Lois. Devoted father of Robert and the late Laurie. Father-in-law of Laurie, John and Atsuko. A proud grandfather of Jesse and Dylan, Ashley and Jeffrey, and Thomas and Christina. Two brothers and their loving wives also survive. Loyal friend of many for many years. He will be missed by everyone who knew and loved him. Funeral service Sunday 11 AM at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Interment at the Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANUEL, JEANNINE
description: MANUEL--Jeannine. Croix de Guerre 39-45, Chevalier of the Legion of Honor, Vermeil Medal from the City of Paris, Honorary Doctorate from the American University of Paris. It is with great regret and profound sorrow that the Ecole Active Bilingue Jeannine Manuel in Paris, France, announces the death of their founder. On Thursday, August 28, Mme. Manuel passed away in her home in France with her children by her side. She was 83. Jeannine Manuel was outstanding in her lifetime. Her entire life was devoted to international understanding. During WWII, she participated wholeheartedly in the Resistance and then she turned her own pedagogical project into a world renowned educational establishment: l'Ecole Active Bilingue Jeannine Manuel in Paris and in Lille. Jeannine Manuel was a pedagogical visionary and a linguistic specialist. She was actively present in the life of the school up until her death. Her inspiring presence will live on in the spirit of the school forever. A religious service will be held Saturday, September 6, 2003, at 3 P.M., L'Eglise Reformee du Saint Esprit, 5, rue Ruquepine, 75008 Paris France.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Future Network Expanding Into Consumer Magazines

title: A Bull, After Death, Touches Many Unrelated Lives
description: Winnie (Raphaelle Molinier) is a saucer-eyed 5-year-old, prone to occasional epileptic seizures, who lives in northern France with her parents and an enormous Great Dane named Fred. Perhaps because of her dog's size, Winnie's sense of proportion is slightly askew, as is her sense of language, in a charmingly childlike way that only her put-upon father seems to find annoying. When she witnesses a bullfighter being gored on television, she tells her parents he has been ''transfished,'' a pretty good subtitle for what sounds like a rather complex bit of false French etymology.

title: Coming Soon From Passaic Jail: Kinder, Gentler Inmate Photos
description: Earlier this summer, when Sheriff Jerry Speziale was conducting his routine walk around the Passaic County Jail, an inmate approached him about an idea that he said could raise revenue for the county and make inmates feel better about themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAYCOFF, EVELYN
description: KAYCOFF--Evelyn, 90. Loving sister of Dr. Aaron (Bob) Kaycoff (Leila); aunt to Virginia Kaycoff, Kathryn Kaycoff Manos (Mark), Michael Sherman (Janeth), the late William Sherman (Irma); and dear friend of Boris Kostelanetz. A true lady, loved by many. A memorial service will be held today, 11am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: In U.S. Web, Pakistani Man Contacts Wife
description: The wife of a Pakistani man who disappeared two months ago said today that she had received a letter from her husband saying he was in American detention in Afghanistan. The man, Saifullah Paracha, who has worked and traveled in the United States, has been missing since July 5, when he boarded a flight to Bangkok on a business trip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUAN, KAREN SUE (NEE SHAIN)
description: QUAN--Karen Sue (nee Shain). Age 45, passed away peacefully on September 2, 2003. She is survived by her husband David, her mother Maxine, her sister Sharon, brother Dennis, her father-inlaw Dr. Stuart Quan and mother-in-law Vicki Quan. Karen led a valiant and courageous fight against the cancer that took her life. She will be deeply missed. Burial arrangements are private. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Quan Fund in Neurobiology, C/O Patricia Flint, Harvard Medical School, 401 Park Drive, Boston, MA. 02215.

title: For Federer, Loss Has a Familiar Feel
description: Out of the capricious clouds and towel-ringing delays that have become the theme of the United States Open, a comforting sense of certainty emerged after tennis finally exploded onto the courts yesterday.

title: Paris Journal; The End of Chocolate (as a Chocolatier Knows It)
description: First, Christian Constant created a towering sculpture in solid chocolate, dozens of stylized chocolate bars soaring in a turbulent column skyward, out of an immense cracked chocolate egg. The Renaissance of Chocolate, he called it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRANCHE, REV. JOHN S.
description: BRANCHE--Rev. John S., 73 died peacefully September 3, 2003 in the home of his children in Easthampton, MA. The Funeral will be Saturday morning 9 A.M. from the Ahearn Funeral Home, 783 Bridge Rd., Northampton, MA followed by a Mass of Christian Burial in St. Mary's Church at 10 A.M. Burial will follow in St. Mary's Cemetery both in Northampton. Calling hours are Friday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. Memorial donations may be made to The House of the Inca Children, 88 East St., Easthampton, MA 01027.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   OLIVER, DORIS M.
description: OLIVER--Doris M. We think of your wit and wisdom so often it's hard to believe it's seven years. You'll always be part of our thoughts and our lives. Toni, Reuven, Seth, Donald, Billy, Robert, et. al.

title: U.S. and Afghan Forces Complete Operation to Root Out Pockets of Taliban
description: Dusty and sunburned Afghan soldiers swarmed around the courtyard of the governor's office here today, claiming success after 15 days of fighting the Taliban in the mountains to the northeast, some of the most serious combat in the country in months. American Special Forces soldiers, who took part in the operation alongside government troops, were also seen heading south on the main highway, apparently heading back to their base at Kandahar.

description: GETTING THERE

title: After 2 Concussions, Richter Is Forced to Retire
description: Veronica Richter brought a fistful of tissues into the room yesterday and began to hand them out to her relatives and friends before the news conference had even started.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRISONA, JAMES J.
description: CRISONA--James J., 96, on September 4, 2003. A graduate of NYU Law School, he had a long and distinguished career as an attorney in NYC. He was a director and general counsel of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from 1948-1954 and later a director and general counsel of the Phoenix Campbell Corporation. A dedicated public servant, he was elected to the NYS Assembly in 1946, to the NYS Senate in 1955 and, in 1957, was elected Borough President of Queens County. From 1959 to 1976 he was a NYS Justice of the Supreme Court. He served for two decades on the Board of Directors of various Shearson, later Smith Barney, mutual funds. Beloved father of Claire Cascella and Cynthia Crisona, loving grandfather of Elizabeth Auran and Nancy Cascella and their husbands James Auran and Steven Flatow, and greatgrandfather of four. His devoted wife, Claire Peysson Crisona, died in 1990 after 55 years of marriage. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st St) today from 5-8PM. Mass of the Resurrection on Saturday, September 6 at 10AM at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 St. Interment private.

title: A Refresher On Tragedies And Resilience
description: YES, there was Sept. 11, but New York has endured many disasters over the centuries, and prevailed. Not much of an original thought, perhaps, but it may be worth bearing in mind as we brace for the second anniversary of the terrorist attack.

title: Blix says 'spin' was used to justify the war in Iraq
description: LONDON:  Hans Blix, the former chief UN weapons inspector, said Thursday that the United States and Britain had employed "spin" in their justification for war in Iraq, issuing one of his strongest criticisms yet of the decision to resort to hostilities.

title: U.S. Does Not Plan to Raise Alert Before 9/11 Anniversary
description: The Bush administration said today that it had no plans to raise the nation's color-coded terrorist alert level in advance of next week's two-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 terror attacks and that a newly completed intelligence review had turned up no specific evidence suggesting threats against domestic targets timed to the anniversary.

title: Verizon and Unions Agree on Tentative 5-Year Contract
description: Verizon Communications and its unions announced last night that they had reached agreement on a tentative contract that includes a one-year wage freeze and retains strong job security protections that the company had sought to weaken.

title: Carter Issues Warning on North Korea Standoff
description: TOKYO, Sept. 5  Former President Jimmy Carter, who was credited with defusing the 1994 North Korean nuclear crisis, warned here today that the current standoff is the world's "greatest threat."

title: Cruise Ship Steams Off, Confident but Disinfected
description: Connie Deho packed Lysol. Jean McKinzie packed Sani-Wipes and Imodium A-D.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Tax Reform
description: The left-leaning government ofPresident Luiz Incio Lula da Silva pushed a crucial tax reform through its first vote in Congress, 378 to 53. The package is meant to streamline Brazil's labyrinthine tax system, which is often blamed for making the country's economy uncompetitive. About 40 proposed amendments must still be voted on individually. The passage was the second reform victory for Mr. da Silva, having won a vote to reform the nearly bankrupt social security system last month. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle yesterday provided an erroneous clue for 60 Down, seeking the answer ''ELAL.'' '' 'Raid on Entebbe' airline'' was incorrect because the hijacked passengers who were rescued at Entebbe in 1976 had flown on Air France, not El Al.

title: IN THE RADIO STUDIO WITH/Jonathan Schwartz; An Alchemist's 36-Year Seminar
description: Down the venerable blocks of West 57th Street I walked, past the Art Students League and the Osborne Apartments and Carnegie Hall, oblivious to all their architecture and history. To put it literally, I was bound on this serene Sunday morning for the Steinway building with its marble and brass, but truly I was searching for a location without substance or address, a Manhattan of my mind.

title: In One Town In Hamptons, Volleyball Stirs Trouble
description: Here among the winding sandy roads and wood-shingled summer homes, worlds are dividing over a volleyball net.

title: Crops in Plains Wither In Scorching Drought
description: Kevin Compton, a 48-year-old grain farmer, recently walked into his corn field to inspect the damage from a summer-long drought. He tore open an ear of corn and grimaced.

title: Freddie Mac Urged to Act Against 2 Ex-Officers
description: Federal regulators proposed yesterday that the board of Freddie Mac treat two top executives who left the company in June as if they were fired, a move that would strip them of more than $50 million in severance and other benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STULMAN, ELGA KRON
description: STULMAN--Elga Kron. Rest in peace, dear friend. You will be missed by many. My deepest condolences to Stephen and family. Ruth Weisgal

title: National Briefing | Washington: Raise For House Members
description: House members voted to allow a 2.2 percent raise for themselves to take effect on Oct. 1. They did not vote directly on the increase of about $3,400, to a salary $158,100. But they rejected on a 240-to-173 vote a procedural effort by Representative Jim Matheson, Democrat of Utah, to hold a separate vote on the issue. The raise still has to be considered by the Senate. Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: A Village Stroll, With Only the Dawn as a Guide
description: Astronomers call it civil twilight. The Spanish use the term madrugada, or the dark before the light. It's the period that begins about 30 minutes before sunrise, when the sun is six degrees below the horizon, and terrestrial objects can be clearly distinguished.

title: Corrections
description: A list of American military deaths yesterday referred incompletely to the unit of Sgt. Sean K. Cataudella. He was with the First Squadron, 10th Cavalry, part of the Fourth Infantry Division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, GREGORY JAMES
description: HYMAN--Gregory James, 47. On August 31 in New York City. Beloved son of Ellen Hyman and Kenneth Hyman. Adored brother of Kate and half brothers Michael, Andrew and Dominic. We will miss you with all of our hearts. Graveside service Sunday at 11AM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, N.Y. Donations may be sent to M.A.P., 817 Vine Street, Los Angeles, CA. 90038.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Steady
description: The number of jobless in Germany remained at 4.4 million, or 10.6 percent of the work force, in August, raising hopes for recovery of the job market after slightly declining numbers in the two previous months. In nonadjusted terms, the unemployment number fell to 4.3 million, leaving the jobless rate at 10.4 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Mutual Fund Misdeeds
description: Just when it looked as if there might be some hope of cleaning up the nation's financial markets, sullied by conflicts of interest and fraudulent investment advice at major banks and brokerage houses, along comes evidence that another segment of the securities business has been rigged in favor of big investors at the expense of the little guy. This time the villains are mutual funds, usually deemed a safe haven for unsophisticated investors. In his latest investigation of tawdry practices in the financial markets, Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, revealed this week that some mutual funds had been making secret, illegal deals that benefited big in-and-out traders at the expense of legions of long-term investors. The practices, he said, are almost certainly widespread.

title: On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHRIESHEIM, BEATRICE D.
description: SCHRIESHEIM--Beatrice D. 73, an active member of the Chicago community, wife of Alan Schriesheim, former director of Argonne National Laboratory, died on August 30, 2003. Born in Krakow, Poland, 1930 Bea came to the U.S. in 1947 at the age of 17, with Tyda Boehm, her adopted mother, after a remarkable journey from Poland through Siberia to the Middle East. Beatrice and Alan celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary this past June. Bea was a devoted and tireless mother who instilled a sense of values, ethics and obligations in her two children and loved and doted on her six grandchildren. Bea is survived by her husband, Alan; daughter, Laura (Bob Kriss); son, Robert (Kris); as well as six grandchildren, Carolyn and Carl Kriss, Karen, Eric, David and Rebecca Schriesheim. Services will be held at Rockefeller Memorial Chapel, 5850 S. Woodlawn Ave, Hyde Park, Chicago on Saturday, September 6 at 10 AM.

description: EVENTS

title: Staying Cheerful as Rain Closes the U.S. Open
description: HELD hostage by a mayhem-inducing midweek mist, the United States Open is enduring Day 3 of waterlogged paralysis: that happy cork-popping sound of tennis balls struck beneath summery skies has been pre-empted by the deathly dull plop of raindrops. Umbrellas, not rackets, are the equipment of choice. There may be a record $1 million awaiting the male and female champions, but at the moment, nobody's got game.

title: Some Ahold Investors Protest New Chief's Pay
description: Shareholders of Royal Ahold, the food and beverage retailer, voted today to appoint Anders C. Moberg chief executive, but some of them also said he would be paid too much to help rescue the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSLER, JULIE ANN
description: OSLER--Julie Ann. Age 56, passed away in Chicago, September 3, 2003, from the devastating effects of a stroke she suffered nearly five years ago. She was a daughter of the late David Osler and Grace Osler Sonenblick and the sister of Susan Osler and Jordan Metzger, Sagaponack, NY. and Amy Osler and Michael Lowenthal of Chicago, IL. She also leaves her loving and beloved nieces, in New York, Dana Brockman and Abby Brockman and in Chicago, Dr. Lydia Sharp and Joanna Sharp and her wonderful caregiver Lily. Julie's loving and giving spirit, her love of classical music, cooking and photography, brought joy to those whose paths she crossed. It breaks our hearts we were unable to make the world a better place for our sweet and unassuming Jewel. We all lose. Her presence, her vitality, her voice has been silenced much too soon. We will miss her always. Memorial contributions in Julie's name can be made to the Animal Welfare Society in New Milford, CT. or the 92nd Street Y School of Music. Memorial to be announced.

title: A New Spin For Turbos: Less Pain, More Power
description: HILNA MOSKOWITZ didn't know her Volvo was turbocharged when she bought it. ''All I knew was the car had great acceleration on the test drive,'' said Ms. Moskowitz, a 57-year-old psychologist from Wilmington, Del. ''I don't care what you call it. I love the power I have when I need it.''

title: Rumsfeld Eager For More Iraqis To Keep Peace
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, arriving in Iraq, said today that his highest priority was to speed up the recruitment, training and deployment of former Iraqi officers to work with the United States to combat disorder and violence here.

description: Senator John W. Warner, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, called on the Pentagon today to scale back drastically a $21 billion Air Force plan to lease 100 Boeing 767 aerial tankers, dealing a setback to a plan that had once been gliding through Congress.

description: WHAT is the New York Stock Exchange?

title: Miguel Estrada Bows Out
description: The Bush administration's announcement that it is giving up on Miguel Estrada, whose appeals court nomination has been repeatedly blocked by a Senate filibuster, is welcome news. The White House's drive to have Mr. Estrada confirmed while keeping key parts of his record secret showed contempt for the Senate's role, and for the American public's right to know. The Senate has made clear its resolve to prevent the White House from packing the federal courts with unworthy judges. President Bush should start nominating judges who can command support on both sides of the aisle.

description: SEIDELMAN--Phyllis. Mother dearest, it's been two years and you are so missed. With love forever

description: One of three dozen new members of the City Council two years ago, Leroy Comrie quickly rose to a key leadership position as the majority whip and a confidant of the speaker.

title: Celibacy Issue Flares Again Within Ranks Of Priesthood
description: A long-simmering debate among Roman Catholics in the United States about whether to allow married men to serve in the priesthood is back on the front burner, pressed by priests concerned about the dwindling of their ranks.

title: Sept. 11, Before And After
description: A DOCUDRAMA on a subject as raw as Sept. 11 is not easily watched. When American troops are still dying in Afghanistan and Iraq, a look back at the presidential decisions that brought us to this point is all the more sensitive.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When Django opened last year, it had a catchy name and not a whole lot else going for it. It pioneered a new kind of cuisine, beige bistro, designed to be forgotten even as it was consumed. Looking for a little more excitement, the owners have brought in Cedric Tovar, formerly a sous chef at Town, who has come up with a menu that puts a little more jazz in the food to match the restaurant's name.

title: Layoffs Rose Sharply Last Month, Report Says
description: Employers continued to shed workers in August, the Government reported this morning, but despite the drop in payroll employment the nation's unemployment rate ticked slightly lower last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BABSON, IRVING K.
description: BABSON--Irving K. We are heartbroken and mourn the loss of a magnificent friend and an extraordinary human being. Irv was a man of deep integrity and profound wisdom who continually demonstrated the bottomless nature of his heart. His devotion and commitment to his friends and family was an inspiration. He truly will be missed. Paul Dworin and Ilsa Klinghoffer

title: From Alaska to Maine, Being at One With the Sea
description: WHEN ferries are involved, the trip can be as important as the destination. Here are some of North America's most interesting ferry routes.

title: Salty Breezes. Great Views. This Is Mass Transit?
description: AT noon, with the sun high over the San Juan Channel and a warm breeze coming off the water, it's hard to imagine a better place to be. Leaning over the green iron railing of the Illahee, a 600-passenger refurbished 1927 ferry, you can see blue-green water gliding by below, while just yards away the rocky beaches and fir-covered bluffs of Shaw Island bask in the sun. Giant driftwood logs, the bleached bones of some faraway forest, lie along the uppermost edges of the gravel shores. The water laps at the beaches, delves around rocks jutting from the surface, and splashes against the base of dun-colored cliffs. The sweet, sharp scent of Douglas fir floats on the breeze, and a lone bald eagle wheels in great sweeping circles above the boat.

title: Sports of The Times; Sudden Rivalry Is Courtesy Of Salary Cap
description: THE Jets decided early this year that they couldn't cover wide receiver Laveranues Coles's seven-year, $35 million free-agent offer from the Washington Redskins, and last night they couldn't cover him.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Details 3rd-Quarter Forecast
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest chip maker, yesterday narrowed its forecast for third-quarter revenue to $7.6 billion to $7.8 billion, the top end of the revised forecast it announced less than two weeks ago. The company said it continued to see improved demand for its core semiconductor products used in personal computers. Shares of Intel rose 38 cents, to $28.60, on the Nasdaq. The company made the announcement after the close of markets, and the shares rose another 47 cents in after-hours trading on the news. On Aug. 22, Intel executives jumped in ahead of the company's scheduled quarterly update announcement to raise its revenue forecast to $7.3 billion to $7.8 billion, from the target of $6.9 billion to $7.5 billion the company had announced in July. At the time, Andy D. Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer, said the company was seeing stronger-than-expected demand for its microprocessors, but he stopped short of declaring a recovery in the technology sector. In its update yesterday, the company said its main chip business continued to see strong demand, but that demand for communications chips remains soft. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Mayor Renews Talks On Immigrant Policy
description: Just minutes before members of the City Council planned to declare an impasse yesterday in their efforts to get Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to amend a policy on how city workers should deal with illegal immigrants, the mayor called them back to the negotiating table.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Higher Emissions Of Heat-Trapping Gases
description: A report by the New England Climate Coalition says emissions of gases that trap heat in the atmosphere have risen sharply in New England over the past decade and that the region is not on course to meet pollution standards set in 2001. The standards, set in the Regional Climate Change Action Plan, call for emissions of heat-trapping gases to be cut 10 percent by 2020. The advocacy group said the region would barely reach one-third of its goals unless stricter controls were enforced.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Selling Shares
description: The Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, an insurer that has had three consecutive years of losses, plans to raise 960 million ($1.5 billion) by selling stock to shareholders.

title: Sports of The Times; Scheduling Creates Sense of Unfairness
description: IT was midafternoon when Andy Roddick rolled through the players' lounge yesterday, frisky as a puppy, bouncing on his toes and all ready to hit through a 45-minute window of clear afternoon sky.

title: Inquiry Clears British Colonel Of Beating Iraqis
description: A British officer who fought in Iraq has been cleared of accusations by an American reservist that he mistreated Iraqi prisoners, the Defense Ministry said this week.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: WARNING ON DIET DRUG Public Citizen, the consumer advocacy group, has renewed its call for federal regulators to ban the diet drug Meridia. The group said that since March 2002, when it petitioned for a ban that cited 19 heart-related deaths since Meridia went on the market in this country in 1998, it had found an additional 30 cardiovascular deaths in people using the drug. Abbott Laboratories , which produces Meridia, responded by noting that obesity is a serious threat to public health, carrying a risk of premature death and cardiac problems. (Reuters)

title: Torre Speaks, and Yanks Respond
description: The Yankees know that the Boston Red Sox bring out their best. So before tonight's game with the Blue Jays at the Skydome, Manager Joe Torre reminded his players to approach each game with the intensity they showed last weekend in Boston.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in World Business last Friday with an article about Grupo Punta Cana, which has developed a tourist resort in the Dominican Republic, was published in error. It showed a housing development by a rival company.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I know they earn a lot of money at this tournament, but apparently they don't earn enough to cover the courts.''

title: Gen. Raymond Davis, War Hero, Dies at 88
description: Gen. Raymond G. Davis, who received the Medal of Honor for leading a storied rescue of fellow marines besieged by Chinese troops at the Chosin Reservoir during the Korean War, died on Wednesday in Conyers, Ga., outside Atlanta. He was 88 and lived in the nearby town of Stockbridge.

title: Serb at Hague Pleads Guilty To Brutalities
description: A notorious Serbian prison camp commander confessed today at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague that he was guilty of the rape, torture and murder of numerous civilians under his control during the 1992-95 Bosnian war.

title: Umbrellas Anyone?
description: The extraordinary stretch of rainouts at the United States Open tennis tournament this week has officials desperately planning a skein of nonstop matches so the ultimate champions may yet be delivered to weekend television. The final contenders faced a grueling marathon of up to four matches across four days and nights -- providing the rain quits long enough. Such a jamming of the games has never happened in Grand Slam history. Drenched aficionados are damning whoever it was who decided not to build a roof on the stadium. They note that the Open is a world-class celebration that attracts legions of now-heartbroken tourists, enriching the city's coffers and buffing its global image.

description: WATERBURY: GIORDANO CONTESTS CHARGES

title: INVESTOR GROUP BUYS AUTO LUBRICANT MAKER
description: The private equity firm Vestar Capital Partners said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an Italian lubricant maker, FL Selenia, for 670 million euros ($727 million). Vestar, which has its headquarters in New York, will buy Selenia from a British buyout company, Doughty Hanson. In 2000, Doughty bought Selenia from the Italian carmaker Fiat for about 400 million euros ($434 million). Fiat created Selenia 90 years ago to provide lubricants for its cars. Selenia, which also makes lubricants and fluids for the manufacturing industry, had sales last year of 477 million euros ($517 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLENDER, SANFORD
description: SOLENDER -- Sanford. The Board of Trustees of North General Hospital extends heartfelt sympathy to our Advisory Committee Chairman, Stephen Solender, and his family, on the passing of his father, Sanford. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family during this time of mourning. Gene Norman, Chairman

title: Bush to Address Nation Sunday on Iraq and Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  President Bush will speak to the American people on Sunday night about his plan for rebuilding Iraq, the White House announced this afternoon.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan's Accounting
description: The Irish drug maker the Elan Corporation, which is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States, said it would file its annual report by today, beating a deadline that could have led to a default on as much as $2 billion in debt. The company, based in Dublin, will restate its results, cutting diluted earnings per share for 2001 to 75 cents from 95 cents, Elan said. For 2002, the diluted loss per share will be $6.65, down from $6.85, it said.

title: Bush Foreign Policy and Harsh Reality
description: Few administrations enjoy making midcourse corrections in their foreign policies, much less admitting to making them. But this week it has become unmistakable that President Bush's team has had to rethink its approaches on Iraq and North Korea after a succession of setbacks and pressures at home and abroad.

title: POLYMEDICA SAYS THE S.E.C. HAS CLEARED ITS ACCOUNTING
description: The PolyMedica Corporation, a maker of diabetes testing kits, said that the Securities and Exchange Commission had affirmed the company's accounting practices and that it would not have to restate earnings. The company, based in Woburn, Mass., said in July that it was talking with the S.E.C. about recording advertising costs as they occur instead of spreading them out over several years. Such a change would have reduced earnings per share in fiscal years 2002 and 2003, it said. Shares of PolyMedica rose $7, or 15 percent, to $54 on the Nasdaq.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: INTEL DETAILS 3RD-QUARTER FORECAST The Intel Corporation, the world's largest chip maker, yesterday narrowed its forecast for third-quarter revenue to $7.6 billion to $7.8 billion, the top end of the revised forecast it announced less than two weeks ago. The company said it continued to see improved demand for its core semiconductor products used in personal computers. Shares of Intel rose 38 cents, to $28.60, on the Nasdaq. The company made the announcement after the close of markets, and the shares rose another 47 cents in after-hours trading on the news. On Aug. 22, Intel executives jumped in ahead of the company's scheduled quarterly update announcement to raise its revenue forecast to $7.3 billion to $7.8 billion, from the target of $6.9 billion to $7.5 billion the company had announced in July. At the time, Andy D. Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer, said the company was seeing stronger-than-expected demand for its microprocessors, but he stopped short of declaring a recovery in the technology sector. In its update yesterday, the company said its main chip business continued to see strong demand, but that demand for communications chips remains soft.    Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

description: The case had the hallmarks of other notorious New York police shootings. After a wild chase through the streets of Brooklyn, a white federal drug agent had shot a black suspect to death. The dead man was unarmed. The agent had shot him in the back.

description: The YankeeNets holding company once again stepped back from the brink of selling the Nets yesterday. A deal, if completed, could lead to a new home for the team in Newark or New York, or at the Meadowlands.

description: Touring classrooms filled with stacks of glossy new library books and cartons of math texts, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday declared the ''start of a new era'' in the New York City public schools, one he said was ''built on a solid foundation of accountability.''

Nothing had been stolen, but another detail -- a teddy bear had been rearranged in her 13-year-old daughter's bedroom while the girl was out of town -- seemed even more peculiar.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Opera Strike Averted
description: The New York City Opera reached a settlement with the theatrical wardrobe workers union late yesterday afternoon, avoiding a strike at the start of the opera's fall season. The dispute had been mainly about wages. The four-year contract provides for a 3 percent wage increase retroactive to last November, when the previous contract expired, and increases of 3 percent per year for this year and the next two. The opera's wardrobe workers typically earn $23 to $25 an hour. The deal, subject to a ratification vote on Sept. 18, also addressed bereavement leave, pay while workers are on jury duty, and deductions for the 401(k) plan. The Theatrical Wardrobe Union Local 764 is affiliated with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, which includes most of City Opera's trade unions, including stagehands, makeup artists and box office workers. The union's membership voted unanimously last Wednesday to authorize a strike. The company's 60th-anniversary season is scheduled to open on Tuesday with a performance of Handel's ''Alcina.'' Robin Pogrebin (NYT)

description: HONG KONG, Sept. 5,  Yielding to public pressure to an extent seldom seen in China, Hong Kong's chief executive announced today that he was withdrawing internal-security legislation that had provoked huge protests in July.

title: Residential Real Estate; 96 Apartments for Low-  and Middle-Income Renters in Clinton
description: Construction has begun on a 96-apartment, 11-story building at 52nd Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan that will be limited to low- and middle-income families. The building's developer, a nonprofit corporation formed 17 years ago to manage low-income apartments in the neighborhood, is using $2.1 million that it has accumulated since then to help finance the new project, called Clinton Parkview Apartments.

description: When Chad Pennington's fingers bent back and broke under his weight two weeks ago, the Jets became a team that would survive only if different parts of its thin roster could produce breakout performances.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Giordano Contests Charges
description: Former Mayor Philip A. Giordano sought yesterday to have the state's child sex abuse charges against him dropped in Superior Court. Mr. Giordano, left, who was convicted and sentenced to 37 years in prison in June on similar federal charges, has pleaded not guilty to the state charges and is appealing his federal conviction. His public defender said the transfer of Mr. Giordano, 40, to federal authority while state charges were pending against him was a ground for dismissal of the state charges. The state's attorney for Waterbury, John A. Connelly, said Mr. Giordano had originally consented to delay the state trial until his federal appeal was resolved. Judge Frank A. Iannotti said he would rule on the motion on Oct. 16. If the motion is denied, the trial will begin then. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TACCHI, MARY JANE
description: TACCHI--Mary Jane, 61. On Monday, September 1, 2003. Coordinator of Young Adult Services at the New York Public Library. Mary Jane began her career within the branch libraries of the New York Public Library in 1966 after receiving her Masters in Library Science from the University of California at Berkeley. After serving in several Young Adult positions in the Bronx branches, she became the Supervising Borough Specialist responsible for oversight for Young Adult work in all Bronx branches. Using that broad experience, she went on to become Assistant Coordinator of Young Adult Services for the Branch Libraries and subsequently, in 1998, Young Adult Coordinator. She is survived by her brother Tom Tacchi, a niece Torry Dawn and two nephews, John and Charlie. Funeral services Friday, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Those wishing to honor Mary Jane's memory may contribute to the support of Young Adult Services in the branches of the New York Public Library, The Door, 121 Ave of the Americas, N.Y., N.Y. 10013 or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10022. Family will also receive written tributes at www.mem.com

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Copts Condemn Gay Marriage
description: The Coptic Orthodox Church condemned gay marriage in a statement issued by a council led by Pope Shenuda III. The church said same-sex marriage violates the Bible's teachings and threatens the stability of marriage, formation of families, and the sanctity of the church. Coptic Christians make up 10 percent of Egypt's total population of 70 million people. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOCH, ROBERT
description: KOCH--Robert. A great scholar of the work of Louis C. Tiffany. We will miss his expertise. Condolences to his family. Lillian Nassau Ltd.

title: Fresh Off the Boat From India And He's Yearning to Be Cool
description: ''Where's the Party Yaar?'' is a scruffy independent feature that carries on the tradition of the immigrant comedy, a form born early in the last century when waves of Jews, Italians, Irish and Germans arrived on these shores just as the new medium of motion pictures was getting under way.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sony Plans Music Downloading Service
description: Executives of the Sony Corporation said yesterday that the company planned its own music-download service next year in the United States, Europe and Japan to bolster its flagging music business. At their annual products show in Paris, Sony executives also said the company's overall consumer electronics business was showing strong sales everywhere but Europe. Sir Howard Stringer, Sony's vice chairman and the head of its American businesses, said the new service, Net Music Download, would start in the United States market in the spring and ''combine efforts of our music, electronics and pictures companies.'' The download service, known as Music Box within the company, which is based in Japan, is part of Sony's belated attempt to combat the free trading of songs in digital form over the Internet, which many in the industry blame for falling CD sales. But Sir Howard said the company's music division, which owns the Epic and Columbia labels, had not decided how to react to the announcement on Wednesday by the Universal Music Group, which is owned by Vivendi Universal, that it would cut prices of music CD's by as much as 30 percent. Victoria Shannon (IHT)

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Oman: Oil Investment
description: Petroleum Development Oman, in which Royal Dutch/Shell Group has a 34 percent stake, plans to spend $1.5 billion a year in the next five years to reverse a decline in oil output, the company said. It plans to pump 730,000 barrels a day after output fell close to 15 percent over the last two years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Antiterrorism Grant
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that New York would receive a $79.5 million federal grant to increase the state's readiness for bioterrorism and other health emergencies. Under the grant, the state will receive $45.8 million and New York City will receive $33.7 million. The money will provide for the distribution of vaccines, antidotes, antibiotics and other emergency supplies in every county. Health officials will also work closely with hospitals and other health care providers to prepare for handling a large influx of patients in the event of a large-scale emergency. The money is being awarded though the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Health Resources and Services Administration. Andrea Elliott (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, HYMAN ''BOB''
description: KAPLAN -- Hyman ''Bob''. Husband of Estelle (nee Richter, deceased), son of Bessie and Abram (deceased), brother of Dora (deceased) and Min, father of Robert, David and Lawrence, grandfather of Jake, Sarah, Veronica, Daniel, Leila and Jonathan (Tait), uncle of Esta, Rona, Michael and Susan died of natural causes at the age of 98 on the evening of September 2, 2003. A truly happy man, his remarkable, radiant goodness and love kindled an answering love in the hearts of all who knew him. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 7th at 1PM at The Riverside Memorial Chapel on Amsterdam Ave and 76th St in Manhattan, followed by a gathering of family and friends at the home of Meredith and David, 924 West End Ave. (105th Street), NYC.

title: MARATHON OIL TO CUT 265 JOBS IN REORGANIZATION
description: The Marathon Oil Corporation plans to cut 265 jobs, mostly at its Houston headquarters and will close its Denver office to save more than $65 million a year. The company will record $40 million in pretax expenses from a reorganization plan that includes consolidating the production offices in the United States. About 230 positions will be transferred to Houston from Denver, as well as Anchorage, Alaska; Cody, Wyo.; Lafayette, La.; Midland, Tex.; and Oklahoma City, Marathon said. About 40 percent of the expenses from the moves will be reported in the third quarter, and more cost cuts are likely, the company said.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Sides With Attorney General
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that the attorney general, Thurbert E. Baker, a Democrat, may continue to press an appeal meant to uphold a voter redistricting plan. The plan was approved in 2001 while majorities of both houses of the Legislature and the governor were Democratic. The current governor, Sonny Perdue, a Republican, had ordered Mr. Baker, left, to drop his appeal. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: Soon after he became the Jets' starting quarterback again, Vinny Testaverde joked that because he had missed all of the 1999 season with a torn Achilles' tendon and had not played much last season, he was really 37, not the 39 indicated by his birth certificate.

description: Miguel Estrada, whose nomination by President Bush to an important federal appeals court post was blocked by an extraordinary filibuster mounted by Senate Democrats, gave up his two-year struggle today.

title: France and Germany Differ With U.S. on Plan for Iraq
description: Giving their first responses to the Bush administration's turn to the United Nations for help in the occupation of Iraq, the leaders of France and Germany announced today that their countries would not support an American proposal that the Security Council authorize an expanded international force under American control and financial help for Iraq.

description: Companies are supplying an expanding economy with more cars, computers, machinery and services while cutting jobs and getting more out of remaining workers, reports released yesterday showed.

description: More than 100,000 low-income families could lose their rent subsidies next year under a spending bill passed today by a Senate committee and recently approved by the House, housing advocates said.

description: Should you choose to watch David Spade play the now grown up kiddie icon of a popular 1970's television sitcom in ''Dickie Roberts: Former Child Star,'' you may be nagged by the thought of how much funnier it might have been with Jim Carrey in the title role.

title: Former Economist at Goldman Is Indicted
description: A former senior economist at Goldman Sachs was indicted yesterday for insider trading, fraud, perjury and other charges in connection with the purchase of about $318 million of 30-year bonds and bond futures minutes ahead of the Treasury's announcement in 2001 that it was ending the sale of 30-year bonds.

title: All Aboard: Secaucus Rail Depot Is Ready
description: About 40 years after transportation officials first toyed with the notion of a new rail depot here, New Jersey Transit plans to open a handsome $600 million station on Saturday, built to allow thousands of passengers quicker and simpler train trips to and from Midtown Manhattan.

title: Girls From Opposite Cliques Bond After a Shared Horror
description: Deanna (Erika Christensen) and Alicia (Busy Philipps), the seriously troubled teenagers in ''Home Room'' who form an embattled friendship after a Columbine-like high school massacre, are the kinds of girls who would normally sit on opposite sides of the lunchroom and never speak.

description: AT roadside stands and farmers' markets and in backyard gardens, there is no escaping nature's bounty. Summer's last explosion of produce is too irresistible to ignore or to waste, so turn it into a winter larder with some handy preserving tools. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARCHILON, JOSE, M.D.
description: BARCHILON--Jose, M.D. The members of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the loss of their longtime colleague, Dr. Jose Barchilon. He was a beloved teacher and friend to many of our members during their psychiatric training and beyond. He was dedicated to psychoanalysis and will be deeply missed. We extend our condolences to his entire family. Paul Rosenbaum, M.D., President, Institute Leon Kupferstein, M.D., President, Society

title: Government to Give Fewer Lie Detector Tests
description: The Energy Department said yesterday in a surprise announcement that it was sharply cutting the number of lie detector tests it would give to people with access to nuclear secrets, particularly at the nation's weapons laboratories.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Suspicious Ferry Returns
description: A North Korean ferry long suspected of smuggling missile parts, drugs and money arrived in Niigata for the second time in 10 days. Ferry service had been suspended since January, largely owing to anti-North Korean sentiment over the North's nuclear-weapon program and allegations that it had kidnapped more than 100 Japanese in the 1970's and 80's. Though rightists protested the last two visits, North Korea gambled, successfully, that Japan would not suspend service again. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Publisher That Went Bust Is Hoping to Go Boom Again
description: No publishing company flew higher than Future Network USA in the late 1990's, propelled by the booming new-economy magazine Business 2.0, and few fell harder in the bust, done in by disappearing ad dollars and corporate hubris. But two years after a drastic restructuring, a chastened Future is growing again in the United States, this time with a twist.

title: Treasuring Ancient Secrets Of Patagonia
description: Collectors of art and artifacts are often an odd breed: secretive, passionate, dedicated and, sometimes, unbelievably generous. That is why so many museums have at their core collections assembled by individuals. Just imagine the Metropolitan Museum of Art's collection of Impressionist paintings without the H. O. Havemeyer bequest.

title: A Childlike Pizza Deliveryman at the Center of a Puzzling Crime
description: He was a single, 46-year-old man who lived with three cats, slept on a mattress on the floor and listened to music in his spare time. He was shy with people but animated with pets, the kind of person who would get on all fours to play with a neighbor's dog.

title: One-to-One Words Of a Blacklistee
description: Even beyond the sonorous trochees that make it stick in the mind like a musical phrase, Dalton Trumbo is a memorable name in Hollywood. You can still see it on the screen a lot. Trumbo, who died in 1976, was a prolific screenwriter whose 50 or so film credits included ''Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo,'' ''Lonely Are the Brave,'' ''Spartacus,'' ''Exodus,'' ''Papillon,'' ''The Fixer,'' ''The Sandpiper,'' ''Hawaii'' and ''Johnny Got His Gun,'' which he adapted and directed from his own antiwar novel. And of course he was a leading member of the Hollywood 10, a group of writers, producers and directors who, after appearing before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington in 1947, were branded as Communist sympathizers and blacklisted by the studios.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: MILITARY ON ALERT A Philippine general said opponents of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo had offered bribes to get soldiers to join a plot to remove her from office. The allegation set off rumors of a coup, putting the police and the military on high alert. The armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Narciso Abaya, said in a radio interview that the plotters were offering generals about $185,000 and ordinary soldiers about $950 to join a coup. But Roilo Golez, the national security adviser, said in an interview that not one general had taken a bribe. He refused to identify the reported plotters.    Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: What Carrie Could Learn From Mary
description: Thanks to HBO's ''Sex and the City,'' now wrapping up its sixth and final season, female sensibility has a new face. Four faces, to be precise: prim Charlotte, no-nonsense Miranda, slutty Samantha and every-girl Carrie, the sex columnist played by Sarah Jessica Parker who is the show's thematic center. Perched on Jimmy Choos and wrapped in Gucci, sipping pink cosmopolitans with an assortment of handsome suitors, the women are witty, glamorous, independent and sexually liberated -- in short, who wouldn't want to be them?

title: Blair Defends Iraq War Despite Problems
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair acknowledged today that his government was facing a tough time at home and abroad but asserted that he still thought Britain was right to go to war in Iraq and insisted he would forge ahead with an ambitious domestic agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINSON, ADELINE

Cherished by daughter, Bonnie, son Mark, granddaughters Liza & Emily and son-inlaw Dr. Donald Kay. Known to her family as ''Aunt Edie'' and friends as Addie, she was a real New Yorker, former ''Miss Brooklyn'', who loved movies, theater, museums, and a good veal parmesan. She will be missed. Graveside service Wellwood Cemetery Friday, Sept. 5 at 2 PM.

title: Horace W. Babcock, 90, Planner And Developer of Telescopes
description: Horace W. Babcock, an innovative astronomer who helped establish the Las Campanas Observatory in northern Chile and developed technology to improve the telescope, died on Aug. 29 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 90.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Money For Cancer Awareness
description: Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, who last month announced that he had prostate cancer, said yesterday that he had committed $500,000 to a program for educating people about prostate cancer and raising awareness of the need for screening and early detection of the disease. David Momrow of the American Cancer Society of New York and New Jersey said that having more men undergo early screening would undoubtedly save lives. Mr. Bruno said the money would come from a pool of revenue that he controls under the state's Health Care Reform Act, to go into the Prostate and Testicular Cancer Detection and Education Program, initiated in 1997. Personally, Mr. Bruno, 74, a Republican, said he had decided on a treatment of external radiation, to begin Monday, which would be supplemented with hormone injections that are already being administered. ''I'm going to deal with it, you know, as best I can and I expect that we're going to be fine,'' he added. Al Baker (NYT)

title: FORSTMANN AGREES TO SELL ITS STAKE IN YANKEE CANDLE
description: Forstmann Little & Company sold its remaining stake in the Yankee Candle Company to the Goldman Sachs Group for $216.6 million. Forstmann Little, the New York-based firm run by Theodore Forstmann, paid $497 million in 1998 for a 90 percent stake in Yankee Candle, consisting of $177 million in equity and $320 million raised through a debt fund. Forstmann Little's total proceeds from selling its shares in the company have reached $830 million. Yankee Candle, based in South Deerfield, Mass., designs and sells scented candles through more than 200 stores in more than 40 states.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: SERBS OPEN SEARCH FOR KARADZIC The Serbian police raided the home of an Orthodox bishop looking for the top war crimes suspect, Radovan Karadzic, but failed to find him, a senior police officer said. Dr. Karadzic and his commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, were twice indicted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal on genocide charges for their role in Bosnia's 1992-95 war, in which 200,000 people, mostly Muslims, died. The operation Wednesday was a rare move by officers of the Serbian republic in Bosnia and Herzegovina to pursue a fugitive war crimes suspect.    (Reuters)

title: Lag of Power Data May Be a Blackout Key
description: An important element in the Aug. 14 blackout may have been the inability of the consortium that manages the Midwest regional grid to learn about all the transmission line failures in Ohio and to adjust the system accordingly for 64 minutes before the system's collapse, the House Energy and Commerce Committee was told today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Military On Alert
description: A Philippine general said opponents of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo had offered bribes to get soldiers to join a plot to remove her from office. The allegation set off rumors of a coup, putting the police and the military on high alert. The armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Narciso Abaya, said in a radio interview that the plotters were offering generals about $185,000 and ordinary soldiers about $950 to join a coup. But Roilo Golez, the national security adviser, said in an interview that not one general had taken a bribe. He refused to identify the reported plotters. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

It's a typically nervy performance for the actor, whose blocky, pugilist's mug bubbles like tar in the heat. Mr. Keitel's crude, red-eyed fury lends the film, which opens today in New York, an edge of danger and pumps adrenaline into what is essentially a talky moral debate.

title: They Lived to Tell It: A Tale of the Club Scene
description: Fenton Bailey's and Randy Barbato's ''Party Monster'' tells the story of a young man from the provinces who finds glamour and celebrity in the big city, followed in short order by dissipation and ruin. In outline, this narrative is as familiar as a fairy tale or a cautionary fable intended to warn young people away from the temptations that brought about the young man's undoing. But ''Party Monster'' is preceded by the fateful legend ''based on a true story,'' which may only increase both its seductive and its cautionary power.

Ingres paints him as a dashing young man with long sideburns and soulful eyes, wearing a cape and a wide-collared, starched white shirt, casually clasping a sketchbook to his chest, with the Quirinal Palace, under gathering clouds, for a backdrop.

title: If the Actual Amazon Is Far Away, Invent One Nearby

A beautiful, elegiac but largely unsuspenseful meditation on the Brazilian rain forest and the creation stories of the Tupi Indians, this rarely seen movie was made between 1973 and 1977. It is being shown in New York for the first time, in continuous screenings at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

After four days, three court changes, one injured chair umpire, too much rain and too little sleep, Francesca Schiavone of Italy dropped to her knees with delight and relief after Ai Sugiyama of Japan knocked her last shot wide in what had been expected to be a routine fourth-round encounter.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CAMDEN: WIFE KILLER APPEALS AGAIN New Jersey's longest-serving death row inmate has begun his latest bid to have his sentence set aside. The inmate, Robert O. Marshall, a former Toms River insurance agent convicted in 1986 of arranging the murder of his wife, claims he did not receive effective legal representation from Glenn A. Zeitz. The latest hearing, which started Wednesday in Camden, was scheduled after the Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last year that Mr. Marshall had the right to argue his claim. Joseph Krakora, a public defender who now represents Mr. Marshall, spent most of the day questioning Mr. Zeitz about his legal strategy at the trial and its subsequent death penalty phase. Mr. Marshall, 63, has so far submitted 22 arguments to state and federal courts challenging his conviction and death sentence. He has nearly exhausted all his appeals. His case was the subject of a best-selling true-crime book and a television mini-series, both titled "Blind Faith." (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHALEK, DORIS
description: CHALEK--Doris, 78, was felled by a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday afternoon, September 3, and passed away some hours later with her beloved husband Mort at her bedside along with several other family members. Longtime residents of New Rochelle, the Chalek's were to have celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary next month. Doris served for 32 years as a volunteer in the therapeutic nursery program of the Guidance Center, a health and human services organization serving Westchester County. They were inveterate world travelers and when any friend or relative was contemplating a trip abroad, Doris could be counted upon to whip out the spiral notebook in which she had logged the interesting sites, restaurants and comfortable hotels in the appropriate part of the world. In addition to her husband Mort, Doris is survived by two daughters, Sonna Schupak and Robin Tzannes, and son Mitchel Chalek. There are seven grandchildren as well as a first great-grandchild who was born this summer. Also surviving is Doris' brother, Henry Wittenberg, a U.S. wrestling champion who won a gold medal in the 1948 Olympics. Friends and relatives will gather informally Sunday afternoon, September 7, at the Chalek residence in New Rochelle.

title: 36 Hours | St. Augustine, Fla.
description: AMERICA'S oldest continuously populated city, St. Augustine takes its history seriously. Weekends bring military re-enactments, blacksmiths in period costume and wenches slinging pints in bars that might as well be named Ye Old Drinking Hole. Yet St. Augustine is also a beautiful and laid-back Southern town, with a naturally attractive waterfront with some of the oldest and most distinctive architecture in the New World. Located on the northeast coast of Florida, and long a way station for families driving to Orlando or Miami, St. Augustine retains a share of the wax museums and alligator farms that define Old Florida tourism. The city is still family-friendly, but even the urbane can appreciate a restored luxury hotel or a 300-year-old house turned into a quaint bed-and-breakfast. Standing in the central plaza, with a fife and drum company marching past, it's possible to slip back centuries to a time when St. Augustine thrived as a military outpost and vital colonial port for Spain. It's also possible to step into a storefront art gallery and ignore that parade altogether. ROBERT ANDREW POWELL

description: The police have arrested two men suspected of committing five robberies in Chelsea, Gramercy and the East Village from March 15 to Aug. 29. Ishmael Melendez, 38, of East 14th Street, surrendered to the police yesterday at 2 p.m. and was charged with grand larceny. The second man, Efrain Quintana, 27, was arrested in Springfield, Mass., at 8 p.m. and charged with robbery. Other charges may follow, the authorities added. Photographs of the suspects that were obtained from a store's surveillance camera were published in newspapers and shown on television. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling In Discrimination Case
description: A federal court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that New York City's teacher certification tests do not discriminate against minorities. A class-action suit had been brought on behalf of hundreds of black and Latino teachers who were dismissed after failing the tests. The suit charged that the tests violate Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It also contended that the exams do not test a teacher's abilities or effectiveness in the classroom. The court found that though one exam had not yet been adequately tested or validated, both tests do relate to effectiveness in teaching. A spokesman for the Progressive Action Caucus, which supported the teachers, said the group planned to appeal. Katherine Zoepf (NYT)

title: Protests Thwart Security Rules In Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's chief executive, bowing to public pressure, announced today that he was withdrawing internal-security legislation that had provoked huge protests in July. The retreat by Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive, is a startling setback for Beijing, which rarely yields to popular demand.

title: Better Teachers, Better Schools
description: The Bush administration's mishandling of education policy is shaping up into a missed opportunity of epic proportions. The No Child Left Behind Act, passed by Congress with blaring trumpets two years ago, was supposed to remake public education by closing the performance gap between rich and poor children. Its most important provision requires that states and districts place a qualified teacher in every classroom by 2006 in exchange for federal dollars. That means ending the indefensible practice of dumping uncertified and unqualified teachers into the poorest and neediest schools.

title: Bloomberg Aide Rejects Idea Of Governor's Schools Panel
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver celebrated the opening of a new high school yesterday in Lower Manhattan, cracking jokes and making light of the rift over a new education panel appointed by the governor.

title: Drugstores Speak Out, With Success
description: Lobbying here is often about the little things a few choice words whispered in a few choice ears. That certainly was the case this year for Craig L. Fuller, a former White House official who lobbies for the nation's big drugstore chains, as Congress drafted legislation on a Medicare drug benefit.

title: Sports of The Times; Agassi Made Some Of His Own Luck
description: IT is one thing to stack the United States Open schedule so that venerable Andre Agassi gets his rest. But now the Open has gone too far.

title: Program to Help Youths Has Troubles of Its Own
description: Spring Creek Lodge Academy, home to thousands of wayward children since 1996, calls itself ''a safe haven for change.'' Many parents swear with near-religious devotion that the program, one of the nation's largest, has saved their sons and daughters. Others have come to curse it.

The stands won't be nearly as full, the betting handle won't be quite as big and the atmosphere won't be as festive at Belmont, but the two tracks share at least one thing in common: a lot of good horses run in a lot of important races.

description: After months of eluding searchers, Saddam Hussein finally seemed within reach.

title: Germ Warfare
description: Riding the subway during a visit to New York, I noticed the woman next to me busily massaging her hands with a lotion soap guaranteed to kill ''99.9 percent of all bacteria!'' To her left, a man wiped a subway pole with an antibacterial towelette before grasping it for support. (This may have been my imagination, but everyone on the train also seemed to be breathing less deeply so as to avoid inhaling any stray germs.)

title: When Eating Sin Just Loses Its Fascinating Allure
description: ''The Order,'' a murky ecclesiastical horror film, may be the nadir of the subgenre that produced ''The Exorcist'' (at its high end) and ''Stigmata'' (at its middle-to-low end). This is a movie so entranced by its own bogus solemnity that most of what passes for conversation is language warped into the heavy-breathing pontification of prophecy delivered in thudding Charlton Heston-style cadences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARZT, EDYA
description: ARZT -- Edya. Women's League for Conservative Judaism mourns the passing of its Education Director, Edya Arzt. For more than 30 years, Edya fostered adult education for women, encouraging Hebrew literacy, ritual observance and serious Jewish learning. She will be remembered by the many women whose lives she affected. May her memory be for a blessing. Gloria Cohen, President Bernice Balter, Exec. Dir.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In Japan we always believed that air, water and safety were free. But it's not like this anymore. Safety is not free anymore in Japan.''

title: Jobs Report Leads Bush to Defend Reliance on Tax Cuts
description: Today's unexpectedly bad employment report dashed the White House's hopes of going into the heat of the presidential campaign with clear evidence of an economic turnaround and forced President Bush to defend his reliance on tax cuts as a remedy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: President Will Not Run Again
description: President Johannes Rau, 72, said he would not seek re-election in May for the largely ceremonial post as head of state. Mr. Rau, a former Social Democrat premier of North Rhine-Westphalia, took over as president in 1999. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Corrections

The year was 1953, not 1952; the place was Westminster Abbey, not Westminster Cathedral.

title: Tibor Varga, 82, Violinist and Conductor
description: Tibor Varga, a violinist, conductor and teacher who was famous in Europe for his interpretations of modern classical compositions, died on Thursday at his home in Grimisuat, Switzerland. He was 82.

title: Violin and Guitar: Made for Each Other
description: In terms of texture and timbre, the violin and the guitar are natural allies, more natural in some ways than the far more frequently heard combination of violin and piano. No doubt the principal reason that recital collaborations between violinists and guitarists are so few and far between is that the repertory of works for these two instruments is so slender in both quantity and quality. Still, the program that Mark Peskanov and Simon Wynberg played at Bargemusic on Thursday evening showed how genial -- and at times, viscerally compelling -- the combination can be.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: BERMUDA: HURRICANE HEADS ASHORE A monstrous hurricane with winds of up to 120 miles an hour bore down on the archipelago of Bermuda as rains and wind began to lash the islands, knocking out electricity in some areas. Officials said it could be one of the most powerful hurricanes the island has ever experienced. An advisory from the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla., warned of coastal flooding of up to 10 feet. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: SISTERS SUE PRIEST AND ARCHDIOCESE Three sisters who say they were sexually abused by the Rev. George N. Rucker 30 years ago have filed civil lawsuits seeking damages from the priest, now 82 and retired, and the Archdiocese of Los Angeles. The women said they were angered that criminal charges had been dropped against Father Rucker, who had been accused of molesting 12 girls over 30 years, because of a Supreme Court ruling on the prosecution of past sex crimes. The women say Father Rucker molested them from 1971 to 1974, when they were 9 to 13 years old. They are seeking unspecified financial compensation.    (Reuters)

title: For Giants' Finn, There's No Place Like Home

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Al Jazeera Reporter Arrested
description: The police arrested a reporter for the Arabic television station Al Jazeera on suspicion of having links to the terror network Al Qaeda. The suspect, Tayseer Allouni, of Syrian origin, was accused of assisting the leader of the network's Spanish cell, who was arrested in November of 2001, and of transferring money to Al Qaeda operatives in Afghanistan, the news agency EFE reported. Mr. Allouni's wife disputed the accusations, as did the director of Al Jazeera. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: CARMAX SHARES SLIDE ON LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED SALES
description: CarMax, the used-car retailer spun off from Circuit City Stores, said second-quarter sales rose less than expected, setting off a 6 percent decline in its share price. The number of used cars sold at stores open at least a year rose 6 percent in the quarter ended Sunday, the company said in a statement. In June, CarMax forecast an increase of as much as 8 percent. The company, which operates 44 used-car lots, said newer stores were eroding sales at existing outlets more than expected. Stock in CarMax, which is based in Glen Allen, Va., fell $2.29, to $35.45.

title: Another Son of Iraqi Ex-Diplomat Indicted
description: A second son of a former Iraqi diplomat in New York has been charged with helping Iraqi intelligence officials find dissidents in the United States who were hostile to the government of Saddam Hussein, federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Hundreds Arrested In Protests
description: Thousands of people marched through Katmandu demanding that the king fire the prime minister and appoint a new government. The march, which followed similar protests on Thursday, was in defiance of a three-week protest ban imposed in the kingdom to maintain law and order. About 100 people were arrested yesterday, and about 400 on Thursday. The ban was imposed after Maoist rebels, who have waged a seven-year insurgency against the constitutional monarchy, walked out of peace talks on Aug. 28 and began attacks on security forces. At least 50 people have been killed in attacks and clashes since then. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUVEEN, BENJAMIN H.
description: DUVEEN--Benjamin H. Jr, 91, of Port Chester, NY, passed away on September 4, 2003, the result of a stroke. Ben was a naturalist and bird watcher and possessed a solid knowledge of bird migrations and habitats. He had a keen sense of humor and an undying faith in manners and decorum. He was co-founder of Duveen Travel of Stamford, CT. He is survived by his devoted wife, Anneta Applebaum Duveen, three stepchildren, and nine grandchildren. He loved and cared deeply about all of them. He was the son of Gertrude Moss and Benjamin Duveen and grandson of Sir Joseph Joel Duveen, co - founder of Duveen Brothers Art Firm. Member, Secular Franciscan Order. Donations to Holy Rosary Church, Don Bosco Pl, Port Chester 10573. Visitation is 2-5 PM on Sunday September 7, 2003 at Craft Memorial Home, Inc, 40 Leicester St, Port Chester, NY. Memorial services to be announced.

Funny, wise, compassionate and pragmatic are all attributes associated with her unending energy and desire to live life to its fullest. She was the consummate New Yorker, walking everywhere, attending theater and concerts, and volunteering to her utmost capacity. Mina, we celebrate your passing and take solace in knowing that you are with ''Coach'' now and with us forever. Much love to you, Bryan, Dennis, Arthur Louis Jr, Kevin, David, Paul, Doris, Carole, Diane, Kathleen, Valerie, Lois and 15 adoring granchildren. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREXLER, ALFRED, M.D.
description: DREXLER -- Alfred, M.D. Died September 4, at 92 in Harrison, NY. Cherished father of Dr. Steven and daughter-in-law Susan. Loving grandfather of David and Alyssa. Beloved husband of the late Gladys Nimaroff Drexler. Dear brother of Dr. Milton and sister-in-law Mollie. Treasured uncle to numerous nieces and nephews, and loving companion of Carol Greenbaum. As a caring practicing physician to generations of families in a 53-year career in Rye, NY, he was also Attending Physician at United Hospital, Port Chester, NY. Born and raised in the Bronx, he received his undergraduate degree from Columbia University and his medical degree from the University of Berne, Switzerland. Services will be held at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, Sunday, September 7, 10 AM. Interment to follow. In lieu of flowers contributions to a charity of choice.

title: Irish Drug Maker Resolves Accounting Issue

title: Yankees' East Perch Is Becoming Shakier

In the general manager's box, George Steinbrenner glowered and Brian Cashman held his chin in his hands. In the American League East pennant race, the Red Sox continued to torment the Yankees.
