title: A Win for Freedom in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, did something yesterday that Chinese Communist leaders never do on the mainland. He deferred to the clearly expressed majority will in Hong Kong and withdrew legislation for a repressive new security law he was trying to impose.

title: New Rules for the 2003 Season
description: Re-kicks of short free kicks will not be allowed within five minutes of the end of the game. Previously, a team was allowed to re-kick in that time.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Euro Deficit Debate
description: Two European Commission officials came to the defense of the stability rules intended to protect the euro as France, the euro area's second-biggest economy, showed no sign of adhering to them. In an unusual move, the trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, and the competition commissioner, Mario Monti, both warned France against flouting the stability pact, which calls on the 12 euro-area countries to keep their budget deficits below 3 percent of gross domestic product. France predicts a deficit of 4 percent this year, and the French premier, Jean-Pierre Raffarin, said he intended to cut taxes this year and next to bolster the economy. The European Commission has given France until Oct. 3 to explain how it intends to bring its deficit into line. Failure to do so should result in fines by the European Union, Mr. Monti said in an interview in the Italian business daily Il Sole 24 Ore. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Envoys Urge U.S. to Cede More Power to U.N.
description: Despite swift opposition from France and Germany, diplomats here and around the world said today that the American draft of a Security Council resolution on Iraq could be a basis for consensus if Washington would cede more political power to the United Nations and speed up the timetable for transferring authority to Iraqis.

title: Susan Chilcott, 40, Leading English Soprano
description: Susan Chilcott, a leading British soprano who had a winning Metropolitan Opera debut last year as Helena in Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' and received glowing reviews last June for her Royal Opera at Covent Garden debut as Lisa in Tchaikovsky's ''Queen of Spades,'' opposite Plcido Domingo, died on Thursday at her home in Timsbury, near Bath. She was 40.

description: Charles G. Taylor, who was forced out as president of Liberia on Aug. 11 and flew to exile in Nigeria, took with him $3 million donated for disarming and demobilizing thousands of armed combatants, a senior United Nations official said today.

title: Tennis Under a Lid

The roof, which costs no more than a fleet of small cruisers, has saved many a match from delay, even though it is sort of like adding turbo to a car; it's just something else to go wrong.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Birth Control Pills With A 12-Week Regimen
description: A new birth control pill, to be taken 84 days in a row, instead of the usual 21, has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The advantage of the new pill is that users menstruate only about once every three months instead of once a month. Some women use standard birth control pills to postpone periods by taking the pills continuously; menstruation does not start until the pills are stopped. The drug agency cautioned that in studies, women taking the new pill, Seasonale, made by Barr Laboratories of Pomona, N.Y., had more bleeding between periods than women taking conventional birth control pills. Barr said studies found no difference in safety with the new pill. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: In Same Case, DNA Clears Convict and Finds Suspect
description: In his final years in prison, Kirk Bloodsworth had a passing acquaintance with a fellow inmate, Kimberly Shay Ruffner. Mr. Bloodsworth, a prison librarian, delivered books to Mr. Ruffner. Sometimes they lifted weights together. But Mr. Bloodsworth said Mr. Ruffner seemed to behave ''kind of peculiar'' when they were together.

title: National Briefing | West: California: State Fire Department Drops Chaplains
description: The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection has agreed to drop its chaplain program after six firefighters sued, saying the program mixed church and state. The chaplain corps has been moved to the union representing the agency's workers and is no longer part of the official employee assistance program. Under the settlement, department employees who want to serve as chaplains must do so on their own time. The firefighters who sued, a group including Christians, a Jew and an agnostic, also said the chaplaincy put too much emphasis on Christian faith. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: No Free Ride For Toddlers
description: In ''Dr. Spock's Baby and Child Care,'' Drs. Benjamin Spock and Steven J. Parker wrote that ''when a baby has learned to walk, it's time to let him out of his carriage or stroller.'' Numerous child-development experts, from Dr. Maria Montessori to Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, agree that the toddler age -- 1 to 3 years -- is a time when parents should encourage their children's urge to move around on their own and explore.

title: Israeli Settlements, Palestinian Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Academic Industrial Complex
description: At the University of Illinois, more than 1,000 classes on hundreds of subjects were canceled during the last academic year because of severe budget cuts. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, meanwhile, is getting $25 million worth of money and materials from Microsoft as part of a five year-partnership with the company to develop educational technologies.

title: Defying Forecast, Job Losses Mount for a 22nd Month
description: The Labor Department announced yesterday that 93,000 jobs were lost in August, countering expectations that employment would finally begin to expand. The economic recovery in the United States is now in its 22nd month, without reversing constant job losses.

title: It's a Rare Laugher In the Bronx for Boston
description: Pedro Martnez was laughing so robustly about Manny Ramirez forgetting how many outs there were in the fourth inning last night that he placed his glove in front of his face to camouflage his smile. Nice try. Everyone realized Martnez was giggling, howling right there on the mound in the middle of Yankee Stadium. When was the last time a Boston player did that?

title: Success in Early-Season Heat Is No Sweat for Dolphins
description: Jay Fiedler had heard about the Miami Dolphins' hot-weather advantage against visiting teams early in the regular season, and he began to understand it during the club's regular-season opener against Seattle four years ago.

title: ABBAS SET TO QUIT, PALESTINIANS SAY
description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister favored by the Bush administration and Israel as an alternative to Yasir Arafat and as an agent of Middle East peace, plans to announce on Saturday that he is resigning, four senior Palestinian officials said tonight.

title: PFIZER AGREES TO DROP PATENT SUIT AGAINST ANDRX
description: The Andrx Corporation said Pfizer Inc. agreed to drop a patent-infringement lawsuit so Andrx can introduce a generic version of the Glucotrol XL diabetes drug. Andrx said it would get a royalty-free sublicense under patents owned by Johnson & Johnson's Alza unit and licensed to Pfizer, which is based in New York. Pfizer also agreed to supply Andrx with all strengths of Glucotrol by Jan. 1 so Andrx can sell it as a generic drug. Glucotrol XL had sales of about $320 million last year. The dispute over Andrx's plan to sell a generic form of extended-release glipizide, the main ingredient in Glucotrol, was scheduled to go to trial next month. Stock in Andrx, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., rose $2.11, or 11 percent, to $20.79.

title: Seeded Third, Ferrero Still Plays Second Fiddle
description: Juan Carlos Ferrero of Spain is the third-seeded player in the men's draw and one victory from being the ATP's top-ranked player. But yesterday he was relegated to the United States Open's second stage, Louis Armstrong Stadium, where he could hear the cheers for Andre Agassi soaring over the walls of Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, LORRAINE EILEEN (NEE MCDONALD)
description: KLEIN--Lorraine Eileen (nee McDonald) on September 3, 2003, daughter of the late William and Eileen McDonald. Beloved wife of Tom. Loving sister of Billy McDonald and Step-mother of Nan and Husband Doug Davis. Dear grandmother of Ian Greer Davis. Also survived by aunt and uncle Dolores and Steve Rozek and cousins Carolyn Lattinville, Michael & Stevie Rozek. Reposing Neufeld Funeral Home, 88-04 43 Ave, Elmhurst, NY Monday 6:309:00PM and Tuesday 2-5PM & 6:30-9:00pm. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:45AM at St. Bartholomew R.C. Church, Elmhurst, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, HAROLD
description: FREED--Harold. On September 4, 2003. My dearest husband, I am devastated, lost and alone. You are my only love. May you find peace with David. Esther

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas last Saturday with an article about new interest in the writing of John Dos Passos referred incompletely to the trip he took in 1921 and 1922 on which he painted ''Mogador,'' a watercolor of a Moroccan city now known as Essaouira. He traveled to Europe, Central Asia and North Africa, in addition to the Middle East.

title: Mayor Says Cheney Is Appropriate Choice for 9/11 Ceremony
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday welcomed Vice President Dick Cheney's attendance at the city's Sept. 11 memorial service at the World Trade Center site.

title: A Tax Increase? $1.2 Billion? Alabamians, It Seems, Say No
description: Bob Riley, the governor of Alabama, was shouting himself hoarse at a packed rally at Troy State University, promoting the largest tax hike in state history.

title: An English Housewife, Minding 297 Rooms
description: PEOPLE here in rural Derbyshire address Deborah, the Duchess of Devonshire, 83, as ''your grace,'' but she assigns herself less exalted status.

title: Is Trauma Being Trivialized?
description: Flashbacks. Nightmares. Feeling disconnected from your body. Whether it is the anniversary of Sept. 11, the continuing threat of terrorism, sexual abuse by the clergy, school shootings or any one of many other causes of angst, Americans have been inundated with the language of trauma and information about how to cope.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: BUSINESSMAN ARRESTED The police have arrested one of the richest men in China, Zhou Zhengyi, after months of investigations into questionable loans that have raised concerns about official corruption. Mr. Zhou was detained in May after state news media said an investigation had been initiated into $240 million in loans he obtained from the state-run Bank of China. The investigation has tarnished Shanghai's reputation as a haven for foreign investment, while shining a spotlight on a financial system dogged by poor risk controls. (Reuters)

title: White and Mutola Are Big Winners
description: Kelli White, competing for the first time since being involved in a drug controversy at the world championships, won the 100 meters today, and Maria Mutola of Mozambique won $1 million in track and field's last major meet of the season.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Asian Currency Controls
description: Asia-Pacific finance ministers rejected a call by the United States Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, left, to let markets decide the value of currencies, saying only that ending government controls would not promote economic growth in all cases. ''There is no single regime that suits all economies at all times,'' 21 ministers from the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum said in a joint statement. ''We noted a view expressed at the meeting that more flexible exchange-rate management, in some cases'' is beneficial. Mr. Snow said the agreement was an ''essential first step'' in ending managed exchange rates, which companies in the United States blame for a surge in imports from Asia.

title: Rumsfeld, on Iraq Tour, Cites 'Remarkable Progress'
description: Hopping to Tikrit and Mosul and back to Baghdad today, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld urged American soldiers and their Iraqi allies to regard recent setbacks here as no more than temporary obstacles in the American-led effort to build a new, democratic Iraq.

title: Hamas Leader and Israeli Die in a West Bank Shootout
description: A man identified as a leader of the Islamic militant group Hamas was shot and killed today in the West Bank after he fired on Israeli troops coming for him, killing a naval commando and wounding four others.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: WATER BOARD EMPLOYEE ADMITS THEFT A former Talladega Water and Sewer Board employee has admitted to stealing at least $20,000 from the board and spending most of it on lottery tickets, Barry Matson, the Talladega County chief deputy district attorney, said. Prosecutors had accused the employee, Patricia D. Borden, 47, of stealing at least $80,000. Ms. Borden pleaded guilty to theft and has yet to be sentenced. She will make restitution of the $20,000 from her retirement account, Mr. Matson said.    Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Crime Rattles Japanese Calm, Attracting Politicians' Notice
description: In a working-class neighborhood in far eastern Tokyo called Koiwa, rising crime spurred a merchants' group to start a collection and buy 60 surveillance cameras.

description: Correction Appended

title: Rosalyn Tureck Memorial
description: A memorial service for the pianist and Bach scholar Rosalyn Tureck will be held on Tuesday at 5 p.m. in the Lowenstein Auditorium at Temple Emanu-El, 10 East 66th Street, Manhattan. She died on July 17 at age 88.

title: DEFYING FORECAST, JOB LOSSES MOUNT FOR A 22ND MONTH
description: The Labor Department announced yesterday that 93,000 jobs were lost in August, countering expectations that employment would finally begin to expand. The economic recovery in the United States is now in its 22nd month, without reversing constant job losses.

title: A Marriage and Another Rare Experience
description: Those who travel the tournament circuit have an obvious benefit: They meet hundreds of potential partners, not necessarily for bridge purposes. There have been hundreds of bridge marriages, dating back 80 years to the marriage of Ely and Josephine Culbertson, who were to be the public face of the game a decade later. The number increases by one today, when Sylvia Summers, long one of the leading female players in the United States, weds Martin Caley, long one of the leading male players in Canada.

title: Man Is Killed in Ride Accident at Disneyland
description: A man riding a Disneyland roller coaster was killed today and 10 people were injured when passengers were spilled from the ride as it whizzed through a tunnel.

title: Senate Finance Committee Demands Tenet Documents
description: The Senate Finance Committee has opened an investigation into allegations of wrongdoing at Tenet Healthcare and requested yesterday that the company produce a large number of documents for the inquiry.

title: Glavine's Wish List Starts With Millwood at the Top
description: Tom Glavine stood by his locker this afternoon and mulled the question for about as long as he would need to decide whether he wanted to win the lottery. With all the other holes the Mets have to fill this off-season, could the rotation use another front-line pitcher to join him, Al Leiter and Steve Trachsel?

title: Seeking Return to Prominence, Zook and Gators Encounter a Difficult Test
description: When Ron Zook told his older brother, Bob, that he wanted to play football in junior high school, Bob said, ''You gotta be tough,'' and sent Ron to the bottom of a hill behind the family's home in Loudonville, Ohio.

title: Rapper Slain in Queens; Linked to Label in Inquiry
description: A rap performer affiliated with the Murder Inc. music label was shot dead on a street in South Jamaica, Queens, late Thursday, the authorities said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Investment
description: The French bank BNP Paribas is buying more shares in the Shinhan Financial Group to maintain its 4 percent stake. BNP Paribas agreed to invest another 27.6 billion won ($23.8 million) in Shinhan Financial, South Korea's second-largest financial group, to prevent the dilution of its stake after Shinhan issued new shares to acquire the Chohung Bank. The investment will add 1.9 million shares to BNP Paribas's stake, giving it a total of 13.6 million shares. The deal was announced after Goldman Sachs, the American investment firm, sold 13 million shares in the Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest, for $465 million. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Veterans and Officials Oppose Hospital Cuts
description: The way Ed Daniels figures it, if the VA Medical Center New York were to close, the effects on him could be summed up in one phrase: mass transit.

title: One Romp, One Dramatic Rally, Two Belgians in the Final
description: One of the precious few perquisites of the soggy second week of this United States Open was the opportunity to watch endless replays of Jimmy Connors pumping himself up and putting the chair umpire down on his way to victory in his classic 1991 match against Aaron Krickstein at the National Tennis Center.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: BLASTS AT ATHENS COURTHOUSE A policeman was injured when two bombs went off at the main court complex in Athens, raising security concerns for the Athens Olympics, now less than a year away. Government officials suggested the bomb blasts were linked to the trial of 19 suspected members of the country's deadliest terror group, November 17. The police said a new extremist group calling itself Revolutionary Struggle claimed responsibility for the predawn attack. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, DANIEL
description: DIAMOND--Daniel. Attorney at law on September 4, 2003 at the age of 94. Husband of the late Doe. Father of Peter and the late Richard. Fatherin-law of Alyce and Kate. Grandfather of Roberta, Debbie, Matt and Andy. Grandfather-in-law of Jeff and great grandfather of Michael, Zachary and Margot. He will be deeply missed by all of us.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about a dispute between the prime minister of Australia and the publicly financed Australian Broadcasting Corporation over what he considers its anti-American coverage of the war in Iraq misstated the year and place of Queen Elizabeth's coronation, cited as an example of the corporation's positive coverage in the past. The year was 1953, not 1952; the place was Westminster Abbey, not Westminster Cathedral.

title: About New York; Art Underfoot, And the Angel Who Guards It
description: THE round-faced sleuth with the orange visor knelt to take a closer look at a circular patch of concrete. Where others might see only Manhattan sidewalk, she saw evidence of a form of art theft: the disappearance of yet another of New York City's glorious manhole covers.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Way but No Will When It Comes To Foster Care
description: Recent revelations of foster care abuses in New Jersey and Florida have, once again, called attention to the state of foster care in this country. As someone who grew up in foster care more than 30 years ago, I am not surprised by the continued problems. Despite improvements, there is still a long way to go.

title: Moe Biller, 87, Labor Chief Of Postal Workers, Is Dead
description: Moe Biller, a union scrapper who battled postmasters and presidents to lead postal workers out of poverty with illegal strikes, protests and six decades of hard-nosed bargaining that made him America's best-known postal union leader, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Political Memo; Prepared for Arrows, Dean Is Hit Only by Kid Gloves

Gephardt of Missouri and Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, ran into each other outside a hotel ballroom hours before they joined the other presidential candidates for the Democrats' first debate here on Thursday night, Dr. Dean demurred at Mr. Gephardt's polite promise of ''it'll be fun.''

Beloved great-grandmother of Jacob and Julia; grandmother of Alissa, Diana, Megan & Kate; mother of Michael & Margaret, Jonathan & Robbie; wife of the late Benjamin Parmer; sister of Ted & Rachel Marks and the late Rita Godfried; former teacher & principal at PS 24. Memorial donations may be sent to Bon Secours Hospital Foundation, 160 East Main Street, Port Jervis, New York 12771.

title: Senior House Democrat Urges Top Defense Hands to Resign
description: A senior House Democrat called today for the resignation of the top two officials at the Defense Department, saying that miscalculations by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and the deputy secretary, Paul D. Wolfowitz, had cost American lives in Iraq and damaged the nation's fiscal health.

title: William Roy, 75, a Songwriter And Music Director in Cabaret
description: William Roy, a pianist, songwriter, singer, musical director and actor, died on Tuesday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75.

title: 3 Big Board Seats Are Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that three seats on the exchange had sold for $2 million each, unchanged from the previous sale on Aug. 12.

title: F.D.A. PANEL REJECTS GLAXO LUNG DISEASE DRUG
description: GlaxoSmithKline failed to win backing from a federal panel yesterday for its Ariflo emphysema pill. A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee voted 7 to 3 to recommend that Ariflo not be approved to treat diseases like emphysema and chronic bronchitis that are most often linked to years of smoking. The F.D.A. usually follows the advice of its panels. Ariflo proved no better than a placebo in two of Glaxo's four pivotal studies and showed only a small advantage in the other two, panel members said. More studies should be required to show whether Ariflo can make a significant difference in helping people breathe, they said. Glaxo is based in Brentford, England.

title: Not Molire! Ah, Nothing Is Sacred
description: To be or not to be Molire: that is the latest question wreaking havoc among French academics.

description: The owner of a New Jersey check-cashing service with Mafia ties pleaded guilty yesterday to laundering money for people who had defrauded the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in the renovation of its problem-plagued Manhattan office tower.

title: Despite Hiring Freeze, Pataki Protects Personal Appointees
description: On paper, Gov. George E. Pataki has shrunk the payroll of the Executive Chamber significantly this year, paring 30 salaried employees and cutting 10 part-time interns. But like most things in Albany, what appears on paper is not the whole story.

title: Democrats Spare the Friendly Fire
description: Beyond making some amiably assorted stabs at speaking Spanish, the Democratic presidential candidates were united in their first major debate on at least one thing, resolutely targeting President Bush for his foundering postwar policy in Iraq. The clownish intramural sideshows that usually haunt the Democratic Party on the early primary circuit were missing in Albuquerque.

title: Sailor Pleads Guilty in Shipmate's Fatal Fall From Midtown Hotel
description: A United States Navy petty officer pleaded guilty yesterday to first-degree manslaughter for the death of a shipmate he pushed from a sixth-floor window of a Midtown hotel last year.

Ms. James, whose Mereminne Dancers performed on Thursday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, moves with the awkwardness of someone who probably came to dance relatively late. (She studied English literature and comparative religion at Swarthmore College.)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Rises
description: The Canadian economy shed jobs in August for the fifth month in a row, Statistics Canada reported, pushing the unemployment rate up to 8 percent from 7.8 percent in July. About 46,000 jobs were lost in the private sector, the highest number since 1995, but self-employment rose. Statistics Canada estimated that one in four workers in Ontario, the most populous province, missed some work last month as a result of the power blackout. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Mazda Offers Buybacks on a Sports Car
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation is offering to buy back 2004-model RX-8 sports cars from customers disappointed that the vehicles have as much as 4.8 percent less engine power than Mazda advertised.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil dropped as rising inventories signaled reduced demand for fuel. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 10 cents, or 0.4 percent, to $28.88 a barrel.

title: H. Erich Heinemann, 71, Writer, Economist and Critic of the Fed
description: H. Erich Heinemann, an economist and financial writer who moved between careers for nearly 40 years, died in an automobile accident on Thursday in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 71 and lived in Great Neck.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about high-tech dental equipment misstated the price of one tool, Difoti, a digital imaging system for detecting tooth decay. It is $6,495, not $20,000.

title: 2 Are Charged Anew In Death of Daughter
description: A grand jury upgraded the charges yesterday against the parents a 3-year-old Brooklyn girl who died last month after a skull fracture and who, investigators say, had been deprived of food and plunged into a tub filled with ice water.

title: Judge Throws Out Suit Against Bengals
description: A judge threw out a lawsuit against the Cincinnati Bengals and the N.F.L. yesterday that accused them of violating the team's lease for the taxpayer-financed stadium with their poor play.

description: President Bush plans to address the nation on Sunday night to discuss Iraq and the campaign against terrorism, the White House said today.

title: At Ground Zero, Eyes on the Future
description: So many hours of programming will revist the destruction in Lower Manhattan on its second anniversary next week that an hour spent considering the site's reconstruction might fortify any viewer depressed by all the elegies.

title: Security at Iraq Munitions Sites Is Vulnerable, U.S. Officials Say
description: American officials said today that about 50 munitions sites in Iraq containing explosives similar to those used in the recent major bombings had only light security and were poorly guarded.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about conducting video chats on the Web misstated the software needs at one point. As noted later in the article, the Apple video-chat system includes a camera that can simply be plugged in; unlike the other cameras cited, it does not require the installation of driver software.

title: Jobs Report Leads Bush to Defend Reliance on Tax Cuts
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5  Today's unexpectedly bad employment report dashed the White House's hopes of going into the heat of the presidential campaign with clear evidence of an economic turnaround and forced President Bush to defend his reliance on tax cuts as a remedy.

title: Inquiry Opens Into Effects Of 9/11 Dust
description: One of the biggest public health investigations in history opened yesterday in Lower Manhattan, aiming to follow the long-term physical and mental journeys of up to 200,000 people who were exposed to fire and smoke on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Forging Links to Natural Gas From Abroad
description: The United States needs natural gas. Developing countries many thousands of miles away are willing to supply it. This sleepy beachfront town and other communities along the Gulf of Mexico are likely to become the links between producers and consumers.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review on Thursday about the pianist Bill Charlap omitted the composer of ''Lucky to Be Me,'' which he played with his trio on Tuesday at the Jazz Standard. It is by Leonard Bernstein.

title: Housing Complicates Boudin's Release
description: When Kathy Boudin was granted parole last month after 22 years in prison for her role in a 1981 armored-car robbery and shootout that left three dead, her supporters thought it would be just a matter of days before she gained freedom.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: 3 Die When Transmission Tower Crumples
description: A television transmission tower collapsed on Monte Sano, a mountain in Huntsville, killing three men working on it. The 1,000-foot tower, which SpectraSite Communications leased to an ABC affiliate, WAAY-TV, crumpled straight down, a Huntsville police spokesman, Wendell Johnson, said. The men, SpectraSite employees, were strengthening the tower before installing more equipment on it, Mr. Johnson said. The police and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration are investigating. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Charlotte Selver, 102, Guide To Sensory Awareness
description: Charlotte Selver, a teacher of sensory awareness who helped inspire the school of psychology that came to be known as the human potential movement, died on Aug. 22 at her home in Muir Beach, Calif., near San Francisco. She was 102.

title: For Malcolm X's Grandson, a Clouded Path
description: The grandson is back in prison. His name does not follow him around as much as it runs ahead, shouting down the cellblocks each time he is transferred to a new place, until soon enough, the other inmates come around, asking if it is true.

description: In 1914 Gen. Pancho Villa, the Mexican revolutionary, contracted with D. W. Griffith and the Mutual Film Company to embed cameramen with his soldiers and film them at war. Villa hoped to display his struggles and heroics to the world, and thereby win support for his cause. Griffith and Mutual hoped to pull off something dangerous and spectacular, and thereby to make money.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cuts At Electronics Maker
description: The electronics manufacturer Matsushita Electric Industrial will shut three factories in Japan to cut costs. The closings, which will be completed by the end of the fiscal year next March, will affect two plants on the southern island of Kyushu and one on Honshu. Production and workers from the plants will be shifted to other factories in Japan. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Wednesday about President Bush's plan for a new jobs creation post misstated the level of the post in the Commerce Department. It will be given to an assistant secretary, not an undersecretary.

title: North Korean Standoff Poses 'Greatest Threat,' Carter Says
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, the man credited with defusing the 1994 North Korean nuclear crisis, warned here today that the current standoff was the world's ''greatest threat.''

title: BIG U.S. LAW FIRM ACQUIRES CARNELUTTI OF ITALY
description: McDermott, Will & Emery, one of the nation's largest law firms, with 12 offices in the United States and Europe, acquired Carnelutti Studio Legale Associato, a Milan firm that is one of Italy's largest, with 70 lawyers. The combined firm will have more than 1,000 lawyers on its staff and will have two offices in Italy, a spokeswoman said yesterday. The firm's biggest office is in Chicago. Terms of the transaction, which the two firms characterized as a merger, were not disclosed. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Report of Ecstasy Drug's Great Risks Is Retracted
description: A leading scientific journal yesterday retracted a paper it published last year saying that one night's typical dose of the drug Ecstasy might cause permanent brain damage.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: More Fire Evacuations
description: For the second time in recent weeks forest fires threatened the city of Kelowna, British Columbia, forcing thousands to evacuate their homes, and destroying at least 6 of 18 nearby historic railway trestle bridges. A wind shift and dry weather helped breathe new life into the fire that two weeks ago lapped at the edges of the city, burning more than 200 homes. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: A Constitutional Anachronism
description: America is a nation of immigrants. Immigrants have shaped our politics and diplomacy, run our government and defended us in wartime -- more than 700 recipients of the Medal of Honor have been immigrants. Yet no matter how great their contributions or sacrifices, immigrants remain ineligible for the nation's highest office because of a provision in the Constitution that bars naturalized American citizens from becoming president. The provision has long since outlived its usefulness, if it had any in the first place.

title: Yankees May Give Henson New Role
description: The Yankees will decide at an organizational meeting next week whether to ask Drew Henson to change positions, said Gordon Blakeley, the team's senior vice president for baseball operations. That could clear the way for Henson, who joined the Yankees yesterday, to have a future with the team despite the presence of Aaron Boone at third base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIR, DAVID ANDREW JR.
description: WEIR--David Andrew Jr. Of Loudonville, former president of Pepsi-Cola Allied Bottlers died on September 4, 2003, in Boston, MA, of complications from surgery. He was 79. Mr. Weir was born on February 2, 1924, in South Bend, IN, to David A. and Marie Broussard Weir. Mr. Weir was raised and resided in New Rochelle, NY, until moving to Albany in 1954, when he purchased with his partner, John R. Strachan, the Albany Pepsi-Cola Bottling company. Located in Menands, the company had 13 employees. Over the next five decades, it grew to be one of the largest privately held bottling companies in the United States, with 900 employees, covering the greater portions of New York, Massachusets, and Connecticut. In 1998, Mr. Weir and his partner sold the business to Pepsi-Co. Inc., the parent company, allowing him to continue to pursue his many cultural interests. In addition, Mr. Weir had a distinguished military service record. In 1942, at age 17, Mr. Weir joined the United States Navy to fight in World War II, serving until 1946. In his time in the Navy, Mr. Weir piloted landing craft on D-Day at Normandy, and also served on ammunition convoys in the Pacific theater. During this time, Mr. Weir earned the European African Middle Eastern Ribbon-1 Star, American Theater Ribbon, Asiatic Pacific Ribbon-1 Star, a Good conduct Medal, and a Victory Ribbon. Mr. Weir was a lifelong sailor and an avid collector of antiques and contemporary art. He was a benefactor of many community organizations, including the Albany Institute of History & Art, Albany Academy for Girls, and the Albany Medical Center. He was a member of the Fort Orange Club, the Saratoga Reading Room, and Schuyler Meadows Club. He will be sorely missed by his family and friends for his steadfast integrity, keen intellect, and unfailing humor. He is the beloved husband of Candace King Weir, his wife of 31 years, and loving father of their two daughters, Amelia and Katherine Weir. Mr. Weir is also survived by his son and daughter from a previous marriage, David Weir III of Miami, FL, and Janice Allen of Stowe, VT, and three grandchildren. In addition, he is survived by his sister Frances Marie Strachan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10:30 AM, Tuesday, September 9, at The Historic Church of St. Mary, Lodge and Pine Streets, Albany. Relatives and friends are invited and may call Monday, from 6-8 PM, at the Tebbutt Funeral Home, 633 Central Avenue, Albany. Interment will be in St. Agnes Cemetery, Menands. In lieu of flowers contributions in Mr. Weir's memory may be made to Albany Medical Center, P.O. Box 8928, Albany, NY 12208.

title: Warning: 'Matrix' Spoilers Ahead (Well, One of Them Might Be Right, Anyway)
description: Here, on the surface of the Information Highway, the movie ''The Matrix Reloaded'' is a subject either closed or on hold until the Nov. 5 release of the final film in Larry and Andy Wachowski's trilogy, ''The Matrix Revolutions.'' A few layers down, though, in the rushing magma of the Internet, predictions of coming plot twists abound. We're talking about millions of words -- a phenomenon akin to a self-replicating computer virus. ''Matrix'' zealots argue in head-swimming detail over ''Reloaded,'' over the collection of linked short films, ''The Animatrix,'' and over the computer game ''Enter the Matrix.'' In this universe, storytelling that struck some of us as inept is regarded as purposefully ambiguous, while dialogue that thudded like a rain of squishy frogs is rich in veiled meaning.

title: THE NEW SEASON/CLASSICAL MUSIC: The Fall's One-Man French Invasion; Sunday in the Frick With a Bach Partita
description: THE round concert room at the Frick Collection, with its 175 seats and its intimate atmosphere, is probably the best place in New York to hear chamber music. It is certainly the most authentic; much of the repertory was written to be played in exactly such a room, not in a huge concert hall. From October to April, the Frick offers a dozen concerts on Sunday afternoons, free, and although it is sometimes possible to get in at the last minute, the Frick advises applying for tickets in writing, well in advance.

A teacher just back from a long vacation will see him in the halls, assume that he has also been off for the summer, and say, ''Good to see you back.''

description: LAST spring, SF Jazz -- the organization behind the San Francisco jazz festival for 20 years, which is now programming events year-round -- announced the formation of its own band, the SF Modern Jazz Collective. It will be an imposing eight-piece group led by the saxophonist Joshua Redman; it includes Bobby Hutcherson (vibraphone), Miguel Zenon (saxophones), Renee Rosnes (piano), Nicholas Payton (trumpet), Joshua Roseman (trombone), Robert Hurst (bass) and Brian Blade (drums).

title: Tip of the Iceberg
description: Your Aug. 24 issue was one to love. I even went out and bought some iceberg lettuce and found an old recipe for buttermilk dressing in one of my 1960's cookbooks. Delicious.

title: Discount Flying Enters New Era
description: ROLAND SCHRIEVER is the type of customer executives at major airlines dream about. As a sales executive in St. Louis with Murtosa, a shoe company, Mr. Schriever logs more than 100 flights a year on business, some of which he books at the last minute without the Saturday night layovers necessary for reduced fares.

title: Carmel Geraghty, Christian Martin
description: Carmel Geraghty, a daughter of Carmel Geraghty of Dublin and the late Eamon Geraghty, was married there yesterday to Christian Bryan Martin, a son of Dolores Martin and Dr. William Martin of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Brian Mulcahy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at University Church.

title: At Home With the Bombs
description: What is scandalous about the American nuclear arsenal is that the weapons are so elegant. There is a demoralizing beauty to the bombs made to kill millions in a flash, the rockets, airplanes, cruise missiles and submarines that deliver them, and the galaxies of technology that keep all this stuff menacingly alert. But for 50 years the $5 trillion machine -- the emblem of this nation in the imagination of the whole world, our Versailles, our St. Peter's -- was unseen by almost everyone but its operators. Between 1992 and 2001, Paul Shambroom, a photographer with no connections in the defense network, talked his way into 25 weapons and command sites across the continent. In FACE TO FACE WITH THE BOMB: Nuclear Reality After the Cold War (Johns Hopkins University, $34.95), 83 of his color images make the weapons as familiar as home appliances or toys. An airman sweeps up under 12 bombs that together contain six times the explosive power of all the munitions used in World War II. A mechanic worms himself into a missile's propulsion system. Some servicemen wrestle warheads onto mounts; others, men and women, squeezing what look like video game sticks, mind herds of missiles, each nesting many bombs. Minutemen missiles in silos gleam like metal sculptures; a giant CAT scan tube embraces one, probing its innards. It seems incredible that Shambroom was allowed to photograph these things, especially the warheads. The experience obviously terrified him, but his narrative and his endnotes about each picture testify that he has kept his wits and sharp sense of humor. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: A Horror, in Amityville and Beyond
description: ASK average people what they'd do if they won a million dollars and, as the television jingle goes, they'd likely buy a house. If they already own a house, maybe they'd buy a dream car or a boat or some other recreational vehicle. Some might even travel the world. As for me, if I won a million dollars, I'd pay my cable bill. With strategic budgeting, I may be able to stretch it to an entire year's worth of payments and come out clean.

title: 'Journal of the Dead'
description: There's an old story people still tell their children in New Mexico. It took place in 1598, when the Spanish founders of Santa Fe were forced to cross the hostile Chihuahuan Desert. Stretching from central Mexico to just south of Albuquerque, the Chihuahuan nearly wiped out the two hundred colonists by sapping away their water. They wandered through the cacti and tumbleweeds half mad for a week, and were spared an excruciating death only by a fortuitous rain. Afterward, they came to call the most brutal part of the desert el Jornada del Muerto , "the journey of the dead."

title: R. Kallman, 81, Is Dead; Studied Cancer Cells
description: Dr. Robert F. Kallman, a Stanford University scientist who did early research on the effects of radiation on cancer cells, helping to establish the practice as a standard treatment, died on Aug. 8 at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 81.

title: Pension Funds Weighing the Risks of Emerging Markets
description: FOUR New York City pension funds are on the verge of shifting $1.7 billion of their assets to one of the riskier sectors of the equity markets -- emerging-markets stocks.

title: Boomers Are Leaning On Retirement Plans
description: The results of a new survey show that company-sponsored plans are crucial to the retirements envisioned by baby boomers.

description: A discount shoe sale, perhaps, but there are certain things that should not be advertised boldly. At least according to some residents of the Upper East Side, where there is growing concern over a mental health clinic and its business practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CABRAL, PEDRO CHAPMAN
description: CABRAL--Pedro Chapman, beloved husband of Susan, father of Anna, Lorelei and Maggie, father-in-law of Josh Drew and Kit Griffith, died at home in his sleep on August 30, 2003. He was 80 years old. Pedro served in the 4th Infantry division of the US Army as a first aid man in World War II and received a Purple Heart. He was an avid bridge player and enjoyed discussing bidding theory and challenging hands. He wll always be remembered for his famous anti-percentage play of 7 NT in a team game tournament. More recently, he was a wellknown member of the Briarcliff Community, walking Jasper and chatting animatedly in town over breakfast. Funeral arrangements are private. For information Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, New York 10510.

title: The Teenage Film Star
description: In the movie ''Freaky Friday,'' Lindsay Lohan plays a teenager who clashes -- and swaps bodies -- with her uptight mother (Jamie Lee Curtis). In real life, Ms. Lohan and her own mother, Dina Lohan, are much more compatible, especially when it comes to clothes. ''I have over a dozen Juicy sweat suits, and my mom has a bunch,'' Ms. Lohan said. ''I wear hers and she wears mine.''

title: Crib Sheet: What to Read at the Movies
description: THE HUMAN STAIN -- It's 1998. Monica Lewinsky has a stain on her dress and President Clinton is arguing about the meaning of ''is.'' For the first five weeks of the fall semester, an elderly classics professor gets no response to a pair of names when he takes attendance. ''Does anyone know these people?,'' he asks. ''Do they exist or are they spooks?''

title: In New Army, All Soldiers Will Be Fighters
description: The Army is looking to instill the fighting spirit in some unlikely combatants -- its cooks, mechanics and other support troops who are normally far from the front lines.

DiScipio, a son of Elizabeth DiScipio of Lynn, Mass., and the late Benjamin DiScipio. It's true, at least, in 187 of the 195 Roman Catholic dioceses in the country. In eight others, including two of Connecticut's three dioceses, the Catholic Church has banned the group from meeting on diocesan property.

The restaurant is one of the few places on the Island where jazz can be heard in an intimate setting.

description: Dan Schnur, Rob Stutzman and Mark Bogetich are partners in a Republican consulting firm in Sacramento. But the recall election has divided them, at least through the vote.

title: Bedfellows Make Politics Strange
description: WHEN Arnold Schwarzenegger and Maria Shriver emerged last month from the Los Angeles County Registrar's office, where Mr. Schwarzenegger filed to run for governor, an interesting bit of political maneuvering occurred. No, not Arianna Huffington's linebacker blitz to get into the frame with Mr. Schwarzenegger, in which she inadvertently sacked a microphone stand. Rather, the debut of Ms. Shriver as the Schwarzenegger campaign's chief cheerleader. After leading the crowd in a chant of ''AR-nold! AR-nold!'' Ms. Shriver stepped in front of her husband and proclaimed, ''He will represent Democrats, independents, Republicans, men and women, all across this state.''

title: Individual Metering for Electricity
description: Q -- I am the board president of a 117-unit condominium. Recently, the board decided to explore the feasibility of individual apartment metering for electricity. (The building currently has a master meter and receives one monthly bill; common area charges include electric usage.) The board felt that the current arrangement does not encourage the conservation of electricity and that if we submetered, unit owners who conserve electricity would no longer be subsidizing those who do not. There are approximately 17 units in the building still owned by the sponsor and rented by long-term residents. What percentage of unit owners and tenants must be in favor of the conversion for us to proceed? . . . Lawrence Grant, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SORGI, VINCENT, JR.
description: SORGI--Vincent, Jr., part time resident of Santa Fe for 18 years, beloved friend of all who knew him, dutiful son, loving brother, and devoted companion, died Thursday, August 28, 2003 in Santa Fe. Mr. Sorgi was born in Delran, NJ, December 13, 1947. He resided at 815 East Palace Avenue and was a designer, gourmet cook, and imaginative gardener, as well as a student of Roman Architecture. Mr. Sorgi maintained residences in New York City and Rome, Italy. His models of Roman Cities were always on display at his studio on East Palace Avenue. He was a graduate of the Philadelphia Art Students League and currently President of the Lawrence Bonaguidi Foundation (a founding sponsor of the Santa Fe Opera and Santa Fe Cares). He studied in Italy with Marcella Hazan and Giuliano Bugiali, sponsoring Mr. Bugiali on his cooking visits to Santa Fe. He is survived by his father, Vincent Sorgi, Sr., a sister, Katherine Marino, two nieces and two nephews in Delran, NJ, as well as Lawrence Bonaguidi his long time companion of 27 years. A memorial service at Cristo Rey Church is planned for the last week in October to permit family and friends from New York, Paris, Rome and Los Angeles to attend. In lieu of flowers contributions should be mailed to The Lawrence Bonaguidi Foundation, 815 East Palace Avenue, #

title: Security Blankets
description: Zombielike, the assassin plunges through a nearly empty Madison Square Garden, site of the political convention, and climbs to a lighting booth high above the stage. Then he waits for hours until the candidate appears. He assembles his sniper's rifle. He aims. . . .

title: Multifaceted Memories
description: THIS is summer adventure season -- and everywhere there seem to be Kodacolor prints of high-resolution families having fun. They are shown wearing life vests, in orange rafts, on slashing silver rivers, backpacking toward misted mountain peaks. I note that camping images have not changed from my mother's time to mine: the glossed photos still feature (however statistically false) that nuclear norm -- Dad at the grill, Mom serving and two children looking up expectantly from a picnic bench. Is it because my little family does not fit this picture that I feel so compelled to fulfill my daughters' wilder summer dreams?

title: CRIME
description: Let's see -- Ethylene, the cousin who breast-feeds in public, is married to Jimmy, Aunt Martha's grandson. Aunt Pauline, Amy's mother's cousin, is the one who made off with Grandmother's dining room table in the middle of the night. And Curt, whose parentage I forget, is the cousin who died from eating poisoned fig preserves. The relatives come flying thick and fast in LAST LESSONS OF SUMMER (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23.95), Margaret Maron's first Southern mystery outside her Deborah Knott series, and the family tree thoughtfully provided by the author is a godsend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEFLICH, ESTELLE
description: HEFLICH -- Estelle. Passed away peacefully on September 5th at her home in Warren, NJ. A loving and sweet woman, she was a pillar of strength for her family and will be missed. She was an associate registrar at Queens College where she also received her Bachelor of Arts degree. She leaves her beloved husband of 65 years, Harry P. Heflich, two children, Louise Wallace (and husband John) of Key Biscayne, FL; Herbert Heflich (and wife Marilyn) of Martinsville, NJ, two grandchildren Marc (wife Laura) and Bradley. Contributions in her name may be made to the Alzheimers Association-Greater NJ Chapter, 400 Morris Ave, Suite 251, Denville, NJ 07834.

title: A Rare View Of Sept. 11, Overlooked
description: They did not even see the pale fleck of the airplane streak across the corner of the video camera's field of view at 8:46 a.m. But the camera, pointed at the twin towers from the passenger seat of an S.U.V. in Brooklyn near the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, kept rolling when the plane disappeared for an instant and then a silent, billowing cloud of smoke and dust slowly emerged from the north tower, as if it had sprung a mysterious kind of leak.

description: ''SHE steps out of her dress, stands in a slip of ivory satin and lace.''

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THINGS YOU SHOULD KNOW: A Collection of Stories, by A. M. Homes. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) Many of these tales by an author with a reputation for the excessively grotesque explore the nightmare corners of suburban life, but the gothic weirdness is balanced by precisely drawn portraits of the heart in crisis. At her best, ''Homes approaches the art of the great absurdists,'' Richard Eder wrote in the Book Review in 2002. ''Strangeness becomes a revealing back entrance into the human condition of our day.''

title: The Great Books Workout
description: An Englishman once told me that although he was shocked at how poorly educated the average American is, he considered the self-educated among us to be the best-read people he'd ever met. His statement might have been engineered to satisfy two contradictory stateside penchants: our persistent, self-flagellating faith in the superior sophistication of Europeans and our conviction that if we set our minds and most of our spare time to it, we can remake ourselves into savants. A surprising number of people harbor the belief that they will become thoroughly well read -- whatever that means -- once they get a proper chance to apply themselves. Carry around a new book like ''The Well-Educated Mind: A Guide to the Classical Education You Never Had,'' by Susan Wise Bauer, and friends will leaf through it earnestly, dreaming of a day when they'll finally be conversant with Sophocles and Ren Descartes. Surely that's why Mortimer Adler's ''How to Read a Book'' remains in print more than 60 years after it first came out and Harold Bloom's ''How to Read and Why'' became a best seller in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASSMAN, ROZ
description: GLASSMAN--Roz. Beloved companion of Al Tarantal. Adoring aunt, caring cousin, best friend, she was all of these things to those who knew her. A fine potter, just as she combined beauty with imagination when it came to creating a clay piece, so she did with life. She worked hard at friendship, sowing seeds of warmth, love and respect. She shall be sorely missed. Memorial service 10 AM, Saturday, September 13th, at Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Avenue at 28th Street.

title: Walls of Ivy, Tangled With Pickets; Students Begin School Year in the Middle of a Labor War at Yale
description: Inside the large auditorium where long red velvet curtains hang from cathedral-style windows and oil paintings of prosperous and powerful men line the walls, hundreds of Yale University students packed in to hear the introduction to a course about the transformation of the modern city, using New Haven as the model.

title: Trying to Avoid Another Sept. 11
description: IT'S not as if Mike Licata had not already served his country. Twenty years in the Air Force as a bomber navigator, posted from North Dakota to Oman and places in between. Eight consecutive 20-hour days at Ground Zero in the aftermath of the terrorism attack of Sept. 11, 2001, working as a liaison between the military and the City of New York, handling the issuance of security credentials and helping with the requisitioning of everything from troops to trucks.

title: Word for Word/Quality Control; Presidential Wannabes: Please Present Your Perspicacity
description: TESTIFYING before a House subcommittee three years ago, Forrest McDonald, a historian at the University of Alabama and the author of ''The American Presidency: An Intellectual History,'' recalled this bit of catechism: delegates to the American Constitutional Convention of 1787 had Poland on their minds.

title: How to Reignite the Culture Wars
description: One morning in the middle of July, in front of the federal courthouse in Charlotte, N.C., the Rev. Flip Benham summoned about 50 of his followers to hold the Supreme Court of the United States in contempt of the Court of Jesus Christ. Benham, the head of the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, is not an admirer of the Supreme Court, and after its decision in June in Lawrence v. Texas, which struck down every sodomy law in America, he was especially displeased.

title: Business People; Raising Your Voice Above the Engine's Roar
description: Finbarr J. O'Neill's reputation for novel takes on the car business was on full display last week. In his first news conference as the head of Mitsubishi's North American sales operations, Mr. O'Neill, a lawyer born in Northern Ireland, was asked whether he was concerned that the car market in the United States might soften this fall. He replied that he was optimistic. ''There are always people around that are naysayers,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''You'll remember that at the Conference of Rome in 1970, they said we'd all be starved off the planet by 1990.''

title: Riding on Snooze Control: Now That's Togetherness
description: AS a toddler, my son David was certain about what he wanted to be when he grew up: a garbage truck driver. At his request, we would follow the garbage men around our neighborhood to watch them do their jobs. We even bought him a ridiculously expensive toy garbage truck -- made in Germany, no less.

title: Iranians Divided on Nuclear Inspection Issue
description: TEHRAN, Sept. 6  Tension among political groups here is intensifying over whether Iran will allow more aggressive inspections of its nuclear sites.

title: Crib Sheet: Breakout Performances
description: MARIA BELLO -- Topping the list of guilty pleasures in Bruce Paltrow's ramshackle karaoke movie ''Duets'' (2000) is Maria Bello's sweetly husky yet dead-honest rendering of the Bonnie Raitt song ''I Can't Make You Love Me.'' Because her character trades sex for everything from a quick meal to a place to sleep, the mid-movie revelation of her talent is both thrilling and sad, and we immediately want to know more. Not that we ever will -- Ms. Bello's movies tend to strand her in second-tier parts that she makes more compelling than the main event.

title: A Modern Joan of Arc Has Her Own Trials
description: AMBER TAMBLYN, sipping a smoothie outside the Crunch gym in West Hollywood, says that when she finishes Joe Klein's biography of Woody Guthrie, she'd like to start learning about Joan of Arc. ''She was kind of a savior, right?''

title: Chile's Leader Presses Rights Issues Softly but Successfully
description: After several years of uncomfortable silence, the question of how to redress the human rights abuses of this country's violent past is once again on the public agenda. President Ricardo Lagos, the courts, opposition parties and even the military are searching for ways to achieve the reconciliation they all say they want.

title: 'The Coming Catholic Church'
description: The heat was on in downtown Dallas, and it had nothing to do with the scorching sun of a Texas June. Central air-conditioning in the luxury Fairmont Hotel took care of the weather. Other pressures were bearing down on the 250 Catholic bishops gathered in the hotel's grand ballroom, and as the morning wore on toward noon it became clear that the gathering storm was beyond their control.

title: Sculpture, Improved By a Martini
description: LIKE many marriages, the union of utility and high design can look better out in the world than at home. Impossibly fragile drinking glasses, for instance, may seem the height of simple chic until you get them home and find the concept to be oxymoronic. Without the oxy.

title: Only a Few Get to See Midnight Spectacle
description: IT was just before midnight when the recovery powers beneath the muscle of Jennifer Capriati kicked in as she desperately chased a sharp volley into the corner. With the swinging motion of a wrangler, she lassoed a forehand down the line for a winner, hopping into the air for emphasis as it landed.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Million Youth March in Brooklyn yesterday may have been far short on numbers -- only about a thousand people attended -- but it was long on rhetoric.

description: HEINEMANN--Erich H. With deepest sadness, we mourn your loss. Our sympathies to your beautiful family. Norma Mauro and family

title: Janis Ian and Patricia Snyder
description: JANIS IAN told a friend she was looking for a chess partner -- someone who knew the game well. But when the friend suggested to Patricia Snyder that she might fit the bill for Ms. Ian, the singer and songwriter, Ms. Snyder resisted. ''All I thought was, 'Oh, great, one more diva,' '' she said.

title: Coming Up: A Globalist, An Egotist And a Mystic; A Naked (and Nude) Narcissist
description: LUCAS SAMARAS may be the hardest-working, most modest narcissist in art showbiz. For more than 40 years, his obsessive, psychedelic, craft-crazed art has formed an alternate universe revolving around himself. That universe will be in full cry in ''Unrepentant Ego: The Self-Portraits of Lucas Samaras,'' opening at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Nov. 13, and it couldn't be more relevant.

title: Msgr. Robert P. Hupp, 88, Reformer of Boys Town, Dies
description: Msgr. Robert P. Hupp, who led Boys Town, the Nebraska home for needy and troubled boys, through far-reaching changes including the admission of girls, died on Aug. 29 in Mausten, Wis. He was 88.

title: Downtown, Fine Feelings Fall Victim To the Banal
description: JORDAN Zielin grew up in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. But in late 2000, he landed his dream job as a computer systems engineer for Banc of America Securities, and moved to Boston. In the back of his mind, he planned to return to New York someday.

title: How Hollywood Handled the Story Of an Irish Folk Hero
description: ON June 26, 1996, the Irish journalist Veronica Guerin was gunned down in broad daylight as her car was stopped at a light: the gunman shot five bullets through the window, and she died almost instantly.

title: John Holmes's Boogie Life
description: IN the summer of 1981, in one of the bloodier and more notorious murders in the annals of Los Angeles, four people connected to the legendary pornography star John C. Holmes were bludgeoned to death at 8763 Wonderland Avenue. The killings, which provided some of the inspiration for Paul Thomas Anderson's 1997 film ''Boogie Nights,'' are the focus of a new movie. ''Wonderland,'' which opens on Oct. 3, is a fact-based film, almost documentary in style, that explores the twisted world of Holmes and the convoluted relationships that ultimately led the police to charge him, a nightclub owner named Eddie Nash and Mr. Nash's bodyguard with the murders.

title: Page Two: Aug. 31-Sept. 6 -- The Week Ahead; SHARON STONE'S RETURN
description: The actress is back, after a two-year absence from the big screen. Her new film, ''Cold Creek Manor,'' opens Friday. She and Dennis Quaid star as a couple who purchase a dilapidated estate with a gory past. Can she pump new life into her career? Ms. Stone, 45, has not had a critical success since the 1995 release of ''Casino,'' which won her a Golden Globe. Ms. Stone dropped out of the spotlight when she adopted a son with her husband, Phil Bronstein, an executive vice president and editor of The San Francisco Chronicle. They were recently separated. Kari Haskell

title: I-Mod
description: ''Tommy Hilfiger went mod this season, with clean, sophisticated clothes that can bring out your inner dandy.'' -- David Farber

title: Hamptons Cachet in Montauk
description: IT'S the end of the summer season, but the Breakwater Cafe in Montauk is too good to put off till next year. Besides, now is the best time to visit this part of the island. The summer crowds have thinned, but the summer warmth remains.

title: Untying the Knot
description: I'm sure I won't be the only outraged feminist to respond to Melanie Thernstrom's article, but I do want to let Kate know that if she decided to forego mediation, renege on her settlement agreement and publicly out her ex, she would have plenty of angry women standing behind her (Aug. 24). The unmitigated gall of an American man earning $65,000 a year to demand (and receive!) alimony because his former spouse earned more is beyond belief. Max did not set aside his ambitions in order to keep house and raise children. His sense of entitlement to her earnings is shocking. This incredible story prompted me to have a heart-to-heart with my own daughter: marry the man with character, not the sanctimonious sap. By the way, the lawyer probably would have been more deserving of the dough.

title: Corrections

It was formed as a traditional media agency in 1989 and has worked with Web-based and traditional clients since 1995; it was not a start-up in 2000.

title: A Romantic Comedy by Woody Allen? You'd Never Know
description: What if they made a Woody Allen movie and nobody knew it was a Woody Allen movie? Well, in the case of DreamWorks, the studio executives may be hoping the secret will help, not hurt, the film's box office. After all, ''Anything Else,'' the last product of the studio's three-picture deal with Mr. Allen, is being marketed without much focus on Mr. Allen, who merely wrote it, directed it and took a role in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, HAROLD
description: FREED--Harold. On September 4, 2003. My dearest husband, I am devastated, lost and alone. You are my only love. May you find peace with David. Esther

The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, an American Baptist minister, officiated at the home of the bride's paternal grandparents, Senator and Mrs. Claiborne Pell of Newport.

title: Why Are We In Iraq?; (And Liberia? And Afghanistan?)
description: In the back alleys of Iraq, the soldiers from the 101st Airborne and First Armored Divisions are hot, dirty and scared. They want to go home, but instead they're pinned down, fighting off hit-and-run attacks and trying to stop sabotage on pipelines, water mains and electric grids. They were told they would be greeted as liberators, but now, many months later, they are an army of occupation, trying to save the reputation of a president who never told them -- did he know himself? -- what they were getting into. The Muslim fighters rushing to join the remnants of Saddam Hussein's loyalists in a guerrilla war to reclaim Iraq have understood all along what the war has been about -- that it was never simply a matter of preventing the use of weapons of mass destruction; rather, it was about consolidating American power in the Arab world. Some in the administration no doubt understood this, too, though no one took the trouble to explain all their reasons for going to war to the American people or, for that matter, the rest of the world.

title: Swazi King Encounters Stormy Weather
description: Not every grand event goes off without a hitch, but it is safe to say that few parades have been so decisively rained on -- literally and otherwise -- as the one over which King Mswati III presided here today.

description: Beware the MAC

title: Business People; Latte and Paintbrush, to Go
description: Orin Smith, the chief executive of Starbucks, has cut down trees and helped clean up a beach as part of his company's volunteer corps. This month, he wants customers to join him. September is ''Make Your Mark'' month at Starbucks. The company, based in Seattle, is sponsoring community projects, like painting houses and fixing up parks, across the United States and Canada. Starbucks started the program in 2000 for employees. Last year, it asked customers to join in, and got 25,000 hours of volunteer work. It hopes to make that a double this year: 50,000 hours.

title: Untying the Knot
description: What kind of system do we have when an able-bodied male with a graduate degree and from a family of means can demand financial support from his ex-wife? And just to twist the knife, a wife whom he belittled and derided for working long hours and participating in corporate culture.

title: THE NEW SEASON/CLASSICAL MUSIC: The Fall's One-Man French Invasion; Celebrating a Composer (Messiaen) And Rescuing a Composer (Schulhoff)
description: HEARING Pierre-Laurent Aimard play Gyorgy Ligeti's tudes at the Tanglewood Festival was the musical highlight of my summer. The French magician-pianist returns to New York to perform Messiaen's magisterial ''Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jsus'' at Zankel Hall (Dec. 15). Mr. Aimard studied piano with Messiaen's wife, Yvonne Loriod, and he has become one of the composer's greatest living interpreters. His Teldec recording of this music is exquisitely rich and attuned to the full spectrum of color that is so important to Messiaen's idiom. That said, an artist of Mr. Aimard's caliber seldom repeats himself, and his recital in Zankel Hall can be counted on to bring something new and surprising.

description: SLOAN -- Aaron. May 19, 1926--August 15, 2003. Loving father, brother, grandfather, visionary, environmentalist, humanist, lover, peace activist, photographer, film maker, professor, journalist, free thinker, critic, provocateur, mystic, American Jew.

title: Jennifer Leete, Mark Patterson
description: Jennifer Sue Leete, a lawyer, and Mark Ainsley Patterson, a Senate aide, were married yesterday evening at the Cosmos Club in Washington. The Rev. Lura M. Kaval, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

At its best, this restaurant provides the perfect backdrop for a marriage proposal. But as far as the food goes, it's a gamble.

title: Courtroom Couture: Stripes Are Optional, but Lose the Tie
description: Adress code seems to be emerging for executives charged with, or convicted of, corporate crimes. Call it business casual for being on the spot  neat, to be sure, but not too formal. For men, the most stylish look is an open-necked shirt and a blazer. That's what Bernard J. Ebbers, the former WorldCom chief executive, wore to court in Oklahoma City last week, where he pleaded not guilty to criminal charges, including fraud. His wife, Christy, came along in a similar outfit. (She does not face charges.) Mr. Ebbers was freed on $50,000 bail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASSO, DOMINIC WALTER
description: BASSO -- Dominic Walter. Died suddenly on August 22, 2003. A graduate of the H.S. of Art & Design and Pratt Institute, he founded Dominic Basso Design in the early 1980's, becoming nationally renowned for his unique architectural and decorative styles. He was a devoted brother, a beloved uncle, and a cherished friend whose sense of humor was only matched by his thoughtfulness and compassion. Although his time here was short, his impact on those around him was tremendous. He left us with empty hearts, but his goodness will live on in each of us. A memorial to be held at a future date, will be attended by family and friends.

description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that she would block the nomination of Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah as the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency until President Bush responded to her concerns about air quality around the World Trade Center.

title: THE NEW SEASON/MUSIC: Rebounds, Repertory and Rascally Rhymes; For New York Rock, It's the Morning After
description: THIS season will test whether New York City rock can outlast two years of ballyhoo. Can bands that deliberately hark back to the city's halcyon rock eras make the stripped-down aesthetic sound contemporary to the wider world? The Strokes, whose 2001 debut album was a lean, jaded, desolate and exhilarating summation of Gotham rock from the Velvet Underground to the Ramones, are due for their second album in October. The Rapture is also going to release its debut album, which was completed last June but tied up in negotiations about who would release it. It's called ''Echoes,'' and it unabashedly draws on the fusion of punk, funk, dance beats and noise that arose in New York and London as the 1970's ended.

title: Coming Up: A Globalist, An Egotist And a Mystic; Sister Gertrude's Revelations

She married in her 20's, but at 34 experienced a spiritual revelation that directed her to preach. She moved to New Orleans -- ''the headquarters of sin,'' she called it -- without her husband and affiliated herself with a group of street missionaries, who were, like her, African-American and praised God through music and dancing.

Given that there have been fewer than 300 U.S. military casualties since the war began last March, this is a startlingly high statistic.

title: Balancing Act
description: For the past two years, I've been telling my 10-year-old daughter, Briana, that she's not fat -- a little overweight, yes, athletic, strong, even chunky -- but not fat. Then in June, I received a letter from Cambridge's Public Health Department. It was a ''health report card'' and part of a plan to help parents in our city identify and help their overweight or underweight children. I knew that Briana was the biggest girl in the fourth grade. She is five feet tall and weighs 128 pounds. What I didn't realize until I opened the letter and saw it staring me in the face was that she is also in the 97th percentile based on her height and weight among girls her age. That number was like a kick in my stomach. Before that moment, I kept telling myself that it was a phase she would grow out of. I even found myself comparing her to other overweight kids I'd see and thinking to myself, Briana is not that big. I'd been living in total denial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOCHIOS, MARY L.
description: FOCHIOS--Mary L., age 77, formerly of Tuxedo Park and the Upper West Side, died September 2, 2003 after a prolonged illness. Born in Charleston, West Virginia to Landon Rodgers Jones and Mary Arthur. She attended the University of Maryland and received her Master's Degree from Columbia University Teachers College. She taught English for many years at the High School of Art and Design in NYC and was also a social worker and writer. She is fondly remembered for her culinary specialties. Survived by her brother, Landon, daughter Andrea, son Steven, daughters-in-law Martha and Gretl, and grandchildren, Evan and Stephen.

title: In Essex County, Secession Gathers Momentum

description: Eating out in Manhattan can be dauntingly pricey, but these places are kind to both taste buds and wallets.

title: Business; In Computer Security, a Bigger Reason to Squirm
description: LIKE prison wardens marveling at an escapee's spoon-dug tunnel, computer-security professionals acknowledge grudging admiration for the author of SoBig.F, the virus that deluged e-mail In boxes last month. At the epidemic's peak in mid-August, according to the antivirus company Central Command, SoBig.F-related messages accounted for 73 percent of e-mail traffic worldwide, making it history's most aggressive online contagion.

title: Calling All Ramblers: 2003 Plans Available
description: The 2003 Hudson River Valley Ramble guide booklet is now available, offering more than 140 guided walks, hikes, canoe trips and bike rides taking place in 10 New York counties during the Trails Festival on Sept. 20 and 21. Other events sponsored by the state Department of Environmental Conservation's Estuary Program and scheduled for Sept. 20 to 28 in New York Harbor and the Hudson Valley are also listed.

title: Public Building
description: In 1366, the wardens of the Opera del Duomo submitted to the citizens of Florence a referendum on the construction of the dome of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore. The wardens had chosen a design that would raise the widest and tallest dome ever constructed without recourse to the buttresses that typically supported great church buildings -- an act of boldness they decided required the stamp of public approval. The referendum passed, thus germinating a process that would flower half a century later with Filippo Brunelleschi's extraordinary design for a giant free-standing dome.

title: The Nimby Factor In the Blackout
description: Richard Kessel's comment in ''Could Long Island Disconnect and Avoid Future Blackouts?'' [Aug. 24] that ''anyone who thinks there is a way to isolate Long Island either permanently or in an emergency from what's happening in the rest of the world is kidding themselves'' appears quite reasonable. At the time of the Aug. 14 blackout, total demand on Long Island was 4,589 megawatts, requiring that 600 to 700 megawatts be supplied from the six interconnections linking Long Island to the regional grid.

title: Edging Closer To Gassing the Geese

The problem was, so were the gaggle of geese who waddled brazenly around him, undeterred by cyclists and strollers and the fact that 700 of their brethren in this and two other Union County parks had been rounded up and gassed two months ago.

Though the company is relatively unknown in the United States, over the last 20 years he has turned it into Europe's most daring and innovative laboratory of contemporary dance. Now, at the end of this season, the Frankfurt Ballet will also disappear.

title: The World: Who Won?; 9/11/03
description: THE physical fallout from the Sept. 11 attacks is as obvious as a low-flying plane in a bright blue sky. A new $38 billion cabinet department with the chilling name Homeland Security has risen out of an old naval facility in the quiet residential northwest quadrant of the capital, headquarters for an army of 170,000 employees. A jury sifts through thousands of designs for a memorial over the mass grave in Lower Manhattan, schools stash emergency water and food, people wear better socks when they fly on commercial flights -- and real American armies are in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: Tip of the Iceberg
description: Julia Reed's Food columns are as refreshing and as crisp as the iceberg lettuce featured on Aug. 24. I especially appreciated the line ''the days when you could go out and have a cocktail and a cigarette and a turn or two around a dance floor before sitting down to some food that was actually pretty good.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIANCHETTI, ALFRED JOSEPH
description: BIANCHETTI--Alfred Joseph. On September 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Alice. Loving brother of Edward. He is also survived by his children Robert, Richard and Susan, and grandchildren Matthew, Christopher, Samantha, Patrick, Caroline and Ryan. A truly accomplished man, Alfred was a very successful member of the business community which included becoming partner and member of the Board of Directors for Dean Witter Reynolds, Outside Director of Soloman, Smith Barney, President of the Municipal Bond Club, member of the Board of Directors for the Public Securities Assocation and a member of the National Association of Securities Dealers. Perhaps his proudest moments were in the volunteer field where he served as the Athletic Director for the Ramsey CYO, was a volunteer in the New Jersey Juvenile and Crimanal Justice System, served as a Volunteer Probation Counselor, was on the Child Placement Review Board for the State of New Jersey, was an active Big Brother and on the Board of Directors for Catholic Big Brothers and coached baseball in Ramsey, NJ, for 43 years. Alfred served in WWII as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy and was called back for active duty in the Korean War. He graduated St. John's University in 1955 with his law degree. He was a truly wonderful man and will be deeply missed. Visitation will be held on Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday, September 10, at 10 AM, at St. Paul's R.C. Church, 193 Wycoff Avenue, Ramsey, NJ. Interment to follow at Maryrest Cemetery in Mahwah. title: The Case for McCain-Feingold

The justices are returning early from summer break to hear a challenge to the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law. The law closes two gaping campaign finance loopholes, reining in corrupt ''soft money'' expenditures and bogus ''issue ads.'' It falls squarely within Congress's power to regulate federal elections, and does not infringe on any constitutional rights. The Supreme Court should uphold the law in its entirety.

title: 'General Ike'

As his only son to survive early childhood, I was able to observe him in different circumstances, sometimes official and sometimes intimate. Though I have previously avoided writing a book devoted solely to him, I have, through the years, read enough misleading material, most of it written by people who have no idea of what he was really like, that I finally decided to record my own view of him. Some of my conclusions are based on what I observed, but much stems from what I have learned in the course of my own writings. No matter how biased in his favor my slant may be, it cannot add much to the confusion that already exists.
