Now, starting on Saturday, the International Center of Photography is bringing its first Triennial of Photography and Video straight to midtown Manhattan. It is by far the largest and most expensive exhibition ever mounted by the center, taking four curators three years to assemble the more than 100 works, by 40 artists, photographers, photojournalists and filmmakers, that will be on view through November.

title: PROOF OF IDENTITY REQUIRED
description: The state Motor Vehicle Commission, which is trying to combat fraud, has begun requiring multiple identification documents from people applying for and renewing drivers' licenses. Under the new requirements, New Jersey residents have to provide several forms of identification that add up to six points in order to obtain a license. Different forms of identification, like passports, current drivers' licenses, birth certificates, high school diplomas and health insurance cards, with varying point values, are among the many types of documents that will be honored. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOSTER, COLONEL RAFE ROBERT
description: FOSTER -- Colonel Rafe Robert. Deputy chief counsel, administrative law division, office of The Judge Advocate General, age 42, died Thursday, September 4, 2003 after a brave battle with cancer, surrounded by his loving family. No words can carry the sweetness and strength of Rafe's character, the power and clarity of his mind, the truth and honesty of his life. Rafe was profoundly devoted to his family, to the military, and to his Jewish heritage, serving on the board of the Jewish congregation at Fort Belvoir, VA. He held himself to the highest standards, graduating first in his college class, attaining a full scholarship to law school, and earning the rank of colonel in May 2003. He had a wide-ranging and embracing intelligence, a direct and purposeful manner, and an unerring moral compass. Yet he retained his childhood sense of wonderment at the world and a deep belief in the goodness of mankind. Rafe was known by all for his clever and gleeful sense of humor, that at times he enjoyed more than anyone. And he measured the success of his stories and anecdotes by the laughter he inspired. Those who loved him are left with the joy and extraordinary privilege of having known him and with the unbearable sorrow of not having had more time. As his presence added so much to our lives, his absence leaves his family and friends a future that will never be as rich, an emptiness that can never be filled, hearts that can never mend and a world that is less kind and less special. Rafe loved and was beloved by his wife Ingela, his sons Jacob and Daniel, his parents Israel Howard and Estelle, his brother Michael and his sisters Stacy, Tamar, and Jody. Though he was with us a short time, he will be missed forever.

Witnessing Jimmy at night at the United States Open was a flashback to open-air prizefights of the 1920's. Tennis didn't get any better than that. Jimmy was storybook. A protagonist living a tale that drew a crowd beyond the tennis world. He was somehow more than American, raised on a street-fighter's game on public courts in the heartland of Illinois. He gave the impression that he would die on court, rather than leave an ounce of his spirit unused. Especially at the United States Open, he gave us the impression that he was our warrior, doing battle for us.

A lifelong resident of Manhattan, he worked for 22 years at the Library of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesman, serving as its head librarian for the last decade. He compiled and edited ''Magic and Madness in the Library,'' a unique collection of literary works about libraries now in its third printing, and wrote a number of essays and reviews on cultural subjects. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ANY parent who has just sent a teenager off to high school had better hope the place is nothing like the schools in Kevin Reynolds's film ONE EIGHT SEVEn (1997). The movie starts out in New York, where Samuel L. Jackson is Trevor Garfield, a caring teacher viciously attacked by a student over a grade. When next we see Garfield it is many months later and on the opposite side of the country, but the California school where he again tries his hand at teaching is even more lawless than the New York one. Mr. Jackson, in a perfectly controlled performance, keeps implying that a Sidney Poitier feel-good moment is around the next bend, but there is only more grimness. When he tells a fellow teacher that the school is ''a world where chaos rules, not order, a world where righteousness is not rewarded,'' the hollowness in his voice is chilling; you know his switch has flipped. The film lurches into unbelievability at the end, but fearlessly so -- Sunday at 4:05 p.m., Friday at 8 p.m. and Friday/

This is Hungry Man food in black tie, with crisp white tablecloths and sparkling candlelight against rough stone walls that have stood since the 1700's and have housed, through the years, an ice house, a grocery store, an ice cream parlor and a pelt trading center. This is the land of big white plates and sumo-size portions of meat and carbs to match, with a long list of exotic martinis, doubtless there to help all that food go down.

title: The Futile Pursuit of Happiness
description: If Daniel Gilbert is right, then you are wrong. That is to say, if Daniel Gilbert is right, then you are wrong to believe that a new car will make you as happy as you imagine. You are wrong to believe that a new kitchen will make you happy for as long as you imagine. You are wrong to think that you will be more unhappy with a big single setback (a broken wrist, a broken heart) than with a lesser chronic one (a trick knee, a tense marriage). You are wrong to assume that job failure will be crushing. You are wrong to expect that a death in the family will leave you bereft for year upon year, forever and ever. You are even wrong to reckon that a cheeseburger you order in a restaurant -- this week, next week, a year from now, it doesn't really matter when -- will definitely hit the spot. That's because when it comes to predicting exactly how you will feel in the future, you are most likely wrong.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: From Middle Earth to Dogville to Columbine; Killing Fields of All Sizes
description: AS mainstream Hollywood movies increasingly fail to confront complex, often unpleasant realities, independent films are rushing to fill the void. And with the war in Iraq threatening to turn into a Vietnam-like quagmire, Errol Morris's documentary ''The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons From the Life of Robert F. McNamara'' couldn't be more pertinent. The film, which was shown at this year's Cannes Film Festival (it opens Dec. 26), was constructed around more than 20 hours of interviews with the former secretary of defense under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. In it, Mr. McNamara, who is widely blamed for escalating the Vietnam War, sketches a history of how this country has justified its use of military force over the decades. While re-examining his roles in World War II (he and Gen. Curtis LeMay approved the fire-bombing of Japanese cities that cost a million civilian lives) and Vietnam, he imparts some cautionary advice.

title: Nuclear Strategy

May I take the job if I support politicians who are unlikely to bomb other countries? Or may I only do research that can't possibly be used for evil? I don't think there is any such thing. P.H., Wisconsin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, THE HONORABLE MATTHEW
description: BROWN -- The Honorable Matthew. Age 98, of Palm Beach, FL, and Boston. On September 5, 2003, at home in Boston, after a brief illness. Distinguished and respected lawyer for 62 years, Founder of Brown Rudnick, Freed and Gesmer, P.C., Boston, generous philanthropist, passionate lifelong advocate for Israel, committed public servant. Cherished husband of Edna (Goodrich) for 71 years. Adored father of Patricia Brown Specter, and the late Ronald G. Brown, admired father-in-law of David Kenneth Specter. Beloved grandfather of Matthew G. Specter and Evan R. Specter (Amy), great-grandfather of Luka, uncle of Roger A. Saunders and Donald L. Saunders. Dear brother of the late Shirley B. Saunders. Born March 26, 1905, in New York City. Graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, New York University 1925, Harvard Law School 1928. Special Justice of the Municipal Court of Boston, 1962-1972. Board of Selectmen of the Town of Brookline, 1961-1973, Chairman, 1970-1973, Mediator in the Palm Beach Circuit Court, Chairman of the Board of Boston Broadcasters, Inc., WCVB, Channel 5, Boston, 1972-1982. He was an Honorary Vice President of the American Jewish Committee, former President and Honorary Trustee of the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Boston, New England CoChairman of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, Founder and Director of the Palm Beach Fellowship of Christians and Jews, Board of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, Fellow of Brandeis University. He received an Honorary Doctor of Laws from Suffolk University. He gifted the Matthew and Edna Goodrich Brown Gallery of French Impressionism at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Contributions may be made to the American Jewish Committee and the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Boston. Services Monday, September 8, 1:30 PM, at Temple Israel, Boston.

title: A Catalonian Fantasy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BABSON, IRVING K.
description: BABSON--Irving K. 67, a well known trade publishing executive, passed from this earth on September 2, 2003. He was a resident of Turnberry Isle, Aventura (Miami, FL). Mr. Babson was the former Chairman of BMT Publications, Inc., New York, NY, a division of TSF Communications. He joined BMT in October, 1963, as an advertising sales executive, following a brief carrer in accounting with S. D. Leidersdorf. Mr. Babson flourished in sales and marketing, effectively marrying his background in finance and accounting with marketing and sales strategy. He rapidly advanced to Advertising Director of BMT and subsequently was named Associate Publisher of Ice Cream World, Co-Publisher of United States Tobacco Journal and Publisher of Radio and Television Weekly. In 1974, Mr. Babson became an equal stockholder with the two remaining company founders. Forseeing the growth of commerical gambling in the United States, he set his sights on the development of a publication specifically directed to this rapidly expanding segment of the economy. In 1979, Gaming Business magazine emerged as the first publication of its kind. As founding Publisher, Mr. Babson was active with state gaming commissions and legislatures, providing previously unavailable data on domestic and international commercial gaming, as well as on illegal gaming activities worldwide. Mr. Babson also served as Publisher of BMT's Convenience Store News, Smoke Shop Magazine, Electronic Distribution Weekly and a host of high tech trade show dailies, including IEEE, WESCON and others. During Mr. Babson's tenure, each of BMT's publications became the editorial and advertising leader in its respective industry. In December 1986, BMT was sold to publicly held Tribune/ Swab-Fox Companies, which named Mr. Babson a member of its Board of Directors. He retired in 1991, soon embarking on a second career in currency trading, founding Belize Equity, and, later, Holdsworth Investments. He also served on the Boards of a number of start up ventures. Mr. Babson was graduated from the Baruch School of Business, City College of New York (CCNY, now CUNY), in 1957. In the mid 1960s he participated in tobacco industry sponsored seminars conducted at the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration. For many years, he was listed in Who's Who in America, Who's Who in Finance and Industry, and the International Directory of Distinguished Leadership. He was invited in the 1970s to become a Friar--a member of the prestigious Friars Club of New York. He was also a member of the National Association of Corporate Directors and a number of other professional organizations. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife, Laurie, and his parents, Matthew and Miriam Babson. Mr. Babson is survived by his three adult children, Stacey Babson Smith (Craig), Mia Babson Goldklang (Robert, M.D), and Christopher. He is survived by his four grandchildren, Remy and Justin (Stacey), and Matthew and Cole (Mia). Mr. Babson's many, many friends and loved ones are heartbroken at the loss of this truly extraordinary man who possessed a rare combination of outstanding intelligence, exceptionally creative business skills and an utterly bottomless heart. A burial service will be held Monday, September 8, at 10 AM, at the New Mt. Zion section of Hillside Cemetery in Lyndhurst, NJ. Donations may be made in memory of Irving K. Babson to the Gilda's Club of South Florida, 119 Rose Drive, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33316.

The 28-foot pleasure boat was nearing Pier 17, at the South Street Seaport, about 4 a.m. when it collided with something, possibly the pier itself, said Timothy Donovan, deputy inspector. Water rushed into the boat's lavatory, which a woman was using at the time, and the boat quickly sank. The passengers, four of whom were clinging to an inflatable raft, were swept away. Within 25 minutes, the inspector said, the passengers and the captain had either been rescued by police officers throwing safety rings or, in a couple of cases, had swum to shore themselves. Investigators searched for the boat using ultrasound equipment but did not recover it. Shaila Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIANCHETTI, ALFRED JOSEPH
description: BIANCHETTI--Alfred Joseph. On September 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Alice. Loving brother of Edward. He is also survived by his children Robert, Richard and Susan, and grandchildren Matthew, Christopher, Samantha, Patrick, Caroline and Ryan. A truly accomplished man, Alfred was a very successful member of the business community which included becoming partner and member of the Board of Directors for Dean Witter Reynolds, Outside Director of Soloman, Smith Barney, President of the Municipal Bond Club, member of the Board of Directors for the Public Securities Assocation and a member of the National Association of Securities Dealers. Perhaps his proudest moments were in the volunteer field where he served as the Athletic Director for the Ramsey CYO, was a volunteer in the New Jersey Juvenile and Crimanal Justice System, served as a Volunteer Probation Counselor, was on the Child Placement Review Board for the State of New Jersey, was an active Big Brother and on the Board of Directors for Catholic Big Brothers and coached baseball in Ramsey, NJ, for 43 years. Alfred served in WWII as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy and was called back for active duty in the Korean War. He graduated St. John's University in 1955 with his law degree. He was a truly wonderful man and will be deeply missed. Visitation will be held on Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday, September 10, at 10 AM, at St. Paul's R.C. Church, 193 Wycoff Avenue, Ramsey, NJ. Interment to follow at Maryrest Cemetery in Mahwah. In lieu of flowers contributions can be sent to the Catholic Big Brothers, 45 E. 20th St, 9th Floor, NYC 10003. Please send tributes, condolences and memories to www.vanemburghsneider.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, THE HONORABLE MATTHEW
description: BROWN -- The Honorable Matthew. Age 98, of Palm Beach, FL, and Boston. On September 5, 2003, at home in Boston, after a brief illness. Distinguished and respected lawyer for 62 years, Founder of Brown Rudnick, Freed and Gesmer, P.C., Boston, generous philanthropist, passionate lifelong advocate for Israel, committed public servant. Cherished husband of Edna (Goodrich) for 71 years. Adored father of Patricia Brown Specter, and the late Ronald G. Brown, admired father-in-law of David Kenneth Specter. Beloved grandfather of Matthew G. Specter and Evan R. Specter (Amy), great-grandfather of Luka, uncle of Roger A. Saunders and Donald L. Saunders. Dear brother of the late Shirley B. Saunders. Born March 26, 1905, in New York City. Graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, New York University 1925, Harvard Law School 1928. Special Justice of the Municipal Court of Boston, 1962-1972. Board of Selectmen of the Town of Brookline, 1961-1973, Chairman, 1970-1973, Mediator in the Palm Beach Circuit Court, Chairman of the Board of Boston Broadcasters, Inc., WCVB, Channel 5, Boston, 1972-1982. He was an Honorary Vice President of the American Jewish Committee, former President and Honorary Trustee of the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Boston, New England CoChairman of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, Founder and Director of the Palm Beach Fellowship of Christians and Jews, Board of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, Fellow of Brandeis University. He received an Honorary Doctor of Laws from Suffolk University. He gifted the Matthew and Edna Goodrich Brown Gallery of French Impressionism at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Contributions may be made to the American Jewish Committee and the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Boston. Services Monday, September 8, 1:30 PM, at Temple Israel, Boston.

title: The 12 Percent Problem
description: One of the saddest statistics in the still eerily jobless recovery is that 1.3 million more Americans fell into poverty last year -- almost half of them children. Whatever else is on the national agenda, there should be no higher priority than directing already available help to these least among us. But the growth in the poverty roll to almost 35 million -- more than 12 percent of the population -- has been accompanied by an equally disturbing drop in those impoverished families who are eligible for limited welfare actually managing to obtain the aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEE, JOHN T.
description: DEE--John T. Of McAllister Drive, Saratoga Springs, and East 69th Street, Manhattan, died Friday, September 5, 2003, at Saratoga Hospital. He was 65. Born on July 25, 1938, in St. Louis, MO, he was a son of the late John F. and Alice D. (Kelly) Dee. Mr. Dee was a graduate of Cleveland High School and of the University of Missouri and had completed the Program for Management Development at the Harvard Graduate School of Business. He served as chairman of the board of Centerplate (trade name for Volume Services America Holdings, Inc) since August, 1998, and as director of Service America since January, 1993. He has been chairman of the board of Service America since January, 1997, and from August, 1998, to April, 2003, served as chief executive officer. He also served as president and chief executive officer of Service America from January, 1993, to April, 2002, and as a consultant to Service America from November, 1992, to January, 1993. From 1989 to 1992, Mr. Dee was president of Top Food Services, Inc, and from 1980 to 1989, he was group president at ARAMARK Corp. From 1979 to 1980, he held senior positions, including president at Sportservice Corp and was responsible for concessions and merchandise operations at many venues. From 1968 to 1979, he held various positions at ARAMARK Corp including president of Leisure Services Group. Mr. Dee was a member of several country clubs including the Loxahatchee Country Club in Jupiter, FL, the Innis Arden Country Club in Old Greenwich, CT, and the Aronimink Country Club in New Town Square, PA. He was also a member of the Rover Boys of New York City and The Skeeters, which was founded by the late Ted Husing. He was an avid horse patron and owned several thoroughbred racehorses, two of which won at Saratoga on July 26, 2003, as well as serving on the board of the New York Racing Association Backstretch Employee's Pension Fund. He also was trustee for the Committee for Economic Development and served as director of the USO of Metropolitan New York and The National Committee on American Foreign Policy. He is survived by his wife of nearly 35 years, Susan (Brier) Dee of Saratoga Springs and Manhattan; three sons, Ralph Dee and his wife Michelle of South Carolina, Ken Dee and his wife Judy of Manhattan and John Nicholas Dee of Saratoga Springs; his brothers, Patrick Dee and James and his wife JoAnn Dee, all of St. Louis, MO; and a niece and nephew, Jeanne and James P. Dee. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 a.m., Friday, September 12, 2003 at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church, 231 Lake Avenue, Saratoga Springs. Burial will follow in the family plot at St. Peter's Cemetery on West Avenue, Saratoga Springs. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, NY, NY, from 2-4 and 7-9 p.m., Tuesday and Wednesday. Memorial contributions may be made to the Saratoga Hospital Foundation, 211 Church Street, Saratoga Springs, NY 12866 or to the American Cancer Society, 260 Osborne Road, Loudonville, NY 12211 (800-227-2345). For more information contact William J. Burke & Sons/Bussing & Cunniff Funeral Homes, 628 North Broadway, Saratoga Springs (518-584-5373 or burkefuneralhome.com)

The strike centers on disputes over wages and teaching hours, Ms. Langdon said. The union sought a 26 percent raise over three years, while the university offered a 12 percent increase. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union: Teacher Charged With Sending Obscene E-Mail Messages
description: A 63-year-old science teacher at a Roman Catholic school was charged with sending obscene materials over the Internet to a police officer posing as a teenage girl, an official at the Archdiocese of Newark said yesterday. The teacher, Corrodo Diamonte, had taught at St. Michael's School, a kindergarten-through-eighth-grade school, for 31 years, said Jim Goodness, a spokesman for the archdiocese. An undercover officer began corresponding with Mr. Diamonte after the mother of a student at St. Michael's told the police that Mr. Diamonte had sent e-mail messages to her daughter, Mr. Goodness said. The arrest followed a four-month investigation, Mr. Goodness said, and the archdiocese immediately suspended Mr. Diamonte and began the process of firing him when it learned of his arrest. A 16-year-old, Reynaldo Farias, was arrested on seven counts of assault in the shooting, which occurred at 2:30 a.m. on 138th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues, the police said. Teenagers who had returned from a back-to-school party at the Key Skating Center at 220 East 138th Street were standing on the streets of their Harlem neighborhood when shots were fired, witnesses said. description: The Environmental Protection Agency and the White House Council on Environmental Quality have been sharply criticized for playing down the potential dangers of exposure to ash, smoke and dust generated by the collapse of the World Trade Center. The inspector general of the E.P.A. has criticized the agency for making overly reassuring statements that could not be supported by any evidence in hand, and blamed the environmental council for pushing the E.P.A. to eliminate caveats and accentuate the positive. Our own sense is that much of the criticism is retrospective nitpicking of decisions made in the midst of a crisis, but it does seem clear that federal and local agencies could have better informed residents of any hazards they would face when they returned to work or live in the area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, PAUL R

Paul was predeceased by his mother, Barbara Acoff Brittin. Paul graduated from Goddard College, earned his JD from UC Davis and his LLM from Temple University. Since 1984, he has served as a faculty member and Associate Dean of International and External Programs at Shepard Broad Law Center, Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale. Paul served as President of Florida ACLU and on the ACLU National Board. He was a Trustee of Goddard College for many years. Paul, whose warmth, intellect and refreshing lack of cynicism earned the devotion of friends from all over the world, gave Lynn and their family fifteen profoundly happy years together. Donations in Paul's memory can be made to The Shepard Broad Law Center of NSU, the Florida ACLU, American Cancer Society or National Public Radio, as you wish.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell And Hewlett To Sell Flat TV'S
description: Dell Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company are preparing to sell flat-panel televisions, in a move that will intensify price competition for the Sharp Corporation, the Samsung Electronics Company and other Asian makers, suppliers and analysts said yesterday. Flat-screen TV suppliers in Taiwan including Lite-On Technology and Amtran Technology said they had provided price quotations to Dell and Hewlett-Packard, the world's two biggest personal computer vendors. Gateway Inc. is already selling flat TV's with screens measuring as much as 50 inches diagonally. The PC makers are aiming at a display market that is forecast to grow 19 percent annually for the next four years as falling prices encourage consumers to switch from bulky glass-tube-based TV's. Japanese and South Korean companies including Sharp, Samsung and Sony dominate the market for flat-screen TV's, which typically cost five times what conventional sets do. Dell plans to offer its first flat-screen TV's with 26-inch and 30-inch screens next year, said Scottie Chiu, special assistant to the chairman of Amtran, which supplies flat-panel TV's to Sharp and Gateway. Lite-On has also solicited flat-panel TV orders from Dell and Hewlett-Packard, said K. C. Terng, president of a Lite-On unit. Shares of Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose 27 cents, to $20.50. Gateway, based in Poway, Calif., climbed 21 cents, to $6.27. Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., fell 41 cents, to $33.68.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINBERGER, HOWARD A. DR.
description: WEINBERGER--Howard A. Dr. A well known pioneering surgeon, died at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital on September 7. He graduated Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa in 1936 from the Johns Hopkins University. His medical degree was awarded by the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in 1940. During WWII he volunteered to serve in the ETO and participated in the allied D-Day landings in Algeria on November 8, 1942. After the war he continued his surgical work at Lenox Hill Hospital. In the course of his 50 year career as an attending surgeon there, he introduced the newest techniques in many areas. Dr. Weinberger was respected by his peers and patients for his dedication to the care of the surgically ill. One of his greatest rewards came from his contact with residents whose surgical training he had been instrumental in molding and whose characters he helped build by example. He was a long-time member of prestigious societies. He published many surgical papers and lectured specialty organizations in America, Europe and Japan. Dr. Weinberger lived in New York City, and maintained a residence in Bedford, NY. His first wife (nee Muriel Heller) died in 1971. He is survived by his wife of 29 years, Peggy F. Weinberger. His daughter Olivia, his son James (Deborah), their sons Samuel and Jacob and his brothers Arthur and Lester. Survivors also include stepchildren Joan Twigg and Thomas Foster; and three stepgrandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., on Wednesday, September 10, from 7-9PM. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, Thursday, September 11, at 11:30 AM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his name to Lenox Hill Hospital, or a charity of your choice.

Lucent said it would stop reimbursing management retirees and their dependents for the cost of some Medicare premiums in 2004. The company, based in Murray Hill, N.J., will no longer pay for dental coverage of those retirees, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lucent cited in part a decline in the value of pension-plan assets, which had been used to help finance retiree health-care expenses. Those expenses will amount to $850 million this year, Lucent said. The company expects to pay as much as $350 million toward health costs for retired managers next year.

description: A Clayton Homes investor seeking to block the company's sale to Berkshire Hathaway yesterday appealed a Tennessee court's decision to let the takeover proceed. The plan, which owns 45,000 shares of Clayton, asked the court to overturn an opinion last week by an appeals court. The latest effort to stop the transaction charges that Clayton Homes improperly postponed a shareholder meeting in July after the Clayton family, which owns 28 percent of the company, realized that it lacked enough votes to approve the sale.

About 3 a.m. yesterday, the man who was arrested, Jehng Delion, 18, grabbed a kitchen knife and stabbed his roommate, Feng-Lin Zun, several times in the chest. Mr. Zun turned the knife back on Mr. Delion and stabbed him in the leg, the police said. Mr. Delion then fled, leaving a trail of bloody footprintsHe was arrested two hours later in an alley on Ninth Avenue and 48th Street, the police said. Mr. Zun died at the scene. Shaila K. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AboveNet Emerges From Bankruptcy
description: AboveNet, formerly Metromedia Fiber Networks, said yesterday that it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection with $80 million in cash and plans to raise more. Craig McCaw, Franklin Mutual Advisers and the billionaire John Kluge will be among the largest shareholders, AboveNet said. The company sought bankruptcy protection in May 2002 after being unable to pay debts from building its fiber optic network. Metromedia Fiber blamed the telecommunications industry's decline for its being unable to pay creditors and vendors. The company listed $7.02 billion in assets and $5.35 billion in debts. A month later, Metromedia Fiber said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating how the company accounted for sales and expenses. David Rockefeller, a member of the company's audit committee, disclosed on July 24 that the S.E.C. had subpoenaed him for that inquiry. In its statement, AboveNet said, without elaborating, that it now had ''a low debt level.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Port Investment Ruled Out
description: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. said it had ruled out investing in a $2 billion expansion of Pusan port in South Korea because it did not think the facility would attract enough container traffic. John Meredith, group managing director of the company's port operating arm, said Hutchison made its decision after talks with the city government of Pusan. Pusan, now at full capacity, is looking for investors to build 17 of the 30 berths in the new facility, a few miles west of its existing port, an official from the city said last week. It wants to expand to improve efficiency and maintain its role as a hub for the shipment of goods to and from China. Hutchison, based in Hong Kong, operates 6 of the existing 22 berths in Pusan and 1 berth in Gwangyang, South Korea's second-largest deep sea port.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: RF Micro Lifts Revenue And Sales Forecast
description: RF Micro Devices, a maker of computer chips for mobile telephones, raised its revenue and sales forecasts for the fiscal second quarter yesterday and said that it would break even or have a profit. The shares rose as much as 15 percent. Net income for the quarter ending Sept. 30 will be ''at or slightly above break-even,'' RF Micro said in a statement. The chip maker said gross margin, the share of sales left after production costs are paid, will improve at least three percentage points. Gross margin was 38 percent in the quarter last year. Shares of RF Micro rose $1.45, or 16 percent, to $10.46. The company said sales in the second quarter would rise by a ''double-digit'' percentage, from $131.5 million in the first quarter. RF Micro had net income of $6.49 million, or 4 cents, on revenue of $119.7 million in last year's second quarter.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Officer's Shooting
description: The man arrested in the shooting of a police captain in Washington Heights on Aug. 27 has been charged with attempted murder and two counts of criminal possession of a weapon, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. Bail was set at $1 million. The man, Roland Roberts, 22, has admitted being at the scene of the shooting wearing a bulletproof vest and carrying a firearm, and he is believed to have been on the verge of robbing a social club on West 154th Street, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. The captain, Kenneth Girven, was shot once in the right side after he confronted Mr. Roberts and another man. Mr. Kelly said the police were still looking for accomplices. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Alcohol Test Debated
description: Lawyers representing suspected drunken drivers have challenged the use of a new machine to measure blood-alcohol levels that police officers in Pennsauken have been using in a pilot program since December 2001. The new test, called the Alcotest 7110 MKIII-C, uses two measures for alcohol content in the blood -- infrared absorption and fuel cell tests -- which the manufacturers say reduces human error in determining whether a driver has had too much to drink. Defense lawyers and Camden County prosecutors have been arguing the merits of the test in a hearing in State Superior Court that began yesterday, but the case is expected to end up in the New Jersey Supreme Court. The reason, according to the trade group, the Recording Industry Association of America, was in large part because of music downloaded on file-sharing services and music burned onto recordable CDs.

description: After boldly flouting the European Union's macroeconomic guidelines, France today appeared to be doing the same with the union's microeconomic rule book.

title: BUSH LIKELY TO GET MONEY HE SOUGHT, LAWMAKERS AGREE
description: Members of Congress said today that President Bush would get the $87 billion he requested for Iraq and Afghanistan, but that he would have to walk through a bit of fire first. Lawmakers said they expected sharp questioning of the request and a renewed debate about the effect on federal spending, taxes and the record-setting deficit.

title: The Rush to Resume Shuttle Flights
description: The missing element in NASA's ambitious plan to get the space shuttles flying again next year is what the plan does not provide. It lays out a series of technical fixes and management changes that will be made before any decision is made to launch another shuttle, and it sets forth additional reforms that will be carried out in coming years as the shuttle program moves forward. Left unaddressed is the matter of just why the aging shuttles should be kept flying, and whether the program is worth the risk and the cost. That is a task that Congress and the White House must tackle before racing back to business as usual.

In others, we may endorse again for the Nov. 4 general election. Polling hours in the metropolitan area are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Trying to Shed The Numbness In Middletown
description: Tina Grazioso bought a cemetery plot, Patricia Wotton threw a pool party and Barbara Minervino finally emptied the drawer that held her husband's socks and underwear. For the grieving widows, mothers and children of Middletown, it was a year of shedding the numbness, embracing the rituals of death and, for even some of the most distraught, dipping a toe into the pleasures of living.

description: Three prominent jazz musicians, three new albums and three aesthetic positions: one transgressive, one regressive, one progressive. That's the size of it in shorthand, and that may even be what the musicians want you to feel. But what's going on is, naturally, more complicated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Arrested In Stabbing Death
description: A man was arrested yesterday in the stabbing death of his roommate, and the police said there appeared to have been a dispute over a 21-year-old woman who lived with them in their apartment in Sunset Park. About 3 a.m. yesterday, the man who was arrested, Jehng Delion, 18, grabbed a kitchen knife and stabbed his roommate, Feng-Lin Zun, several times in the chest. Mr. Zun turned the knife back on Mr. Delion and stabbed him in the leg, the police said. Mr. Delion then fled, leaving a trail of bloody footprintsHe was arrested two hours later in an alley on Ninth Avenue and 48th Street, the police said. Mr. Zun died at the scene. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: 37 Injured in Fire At Newark Apartments
description: A fire in a high-rise apartment building in Newark last evening injured 37 people, including two firefighters. Thirty of those injured were taken to local hospitals, and three were in critical condition, said Firefighter Herb Harris, a spokesman for the Newark Fire Department.

title: In California, Davis and Schwarzenegger Split the Pronunciation Vote
description: Gray Davis, the embattled governor of California, is getting an unwanted lesson in speech pathology. Namely, how difficult it is to say you're sorry with your foot in your mouth.

title: HILLENBRAND WILL PURCHASE ADVANCED RESPIRATORY
description: Hillenbrand Industries, a maker of caskets and a manufacturer of hospital beds and incubators, agreed to buy the closely held Advanced Respiratory for $83 million. Hillenbrand, based in Batesville, Ind., may make additional payments of as much as $20 million if Advanced Respiratory achieves certain revenue goals, it said. Advanced Respiratory focuses on in-home therapy equipment for patients with cystic fibrosis and other respiratory diseases.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: London Calling
description: Commissioner Paul Evans of the Boston Police Department will retire to take a job helping the British government. Mr. Evans will lead the British Police Standards Unit, which was created in 2001 to help the government improve policing. Mr. Evans, who has served as police commissioner since 1994, put into effect a collaboration with neighborhood groups and businesses to deter crime. Violent crime has decreased by more than one-third in his tenure. Mr. Evans, who has served in the Boston Police Department since 1970, is expected to start the new job in November. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: MetroStars' Coach Is a Mathis Backer
description: Clint Mathis may be in the final months of his contract with Major League Soccer, but MetroStars Coach Bob Bradley nonetheless believes Mathis is ready to lead his club to championships, in the league and in the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup for the American club championship.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Providence; A Mecca For Tourism And the Arts
description: Providence, R.I., the much-promoted ''renaissance city,'' has become a tourist mecca with its rejuvenated downtown, trendy restaurants and vibrant cultural scene. It is also becoming more business-friendly. Rhode Island's governor, Donald L. Carcieri, a former managing director of the $3 billion Cookson Group, has made economic development of the state a priority, and the legislature has approved nearly $11 million in tax breaks for manufacturers, financing for the biotechnology industry and investment in small businesses.

title: Official Says Qaeda Recruited Saudi Hijackers to Strain Ties
description: Osama bin Laden told a top Qaeda operative to recruit Saudis for the September 2001 hijackings in an effort to strain relations between the United States and the kingdom, a Saudi official said today.

title: Firm Wins Grant to Develop Oral Drug to Prevent Smallpox
description: The government is giving $36.1 million to a small biotechnology company to develop a pill that could be used to treat and possibly prevent smallpox infection, providing a possible alternative to a vaccine.

title: Forensic Botanists Find the Lethal Weapon of a Killer Weed
description: For over a century, spotted knapweed has been a growing scourge on the North American landscape, spreading across millions of acres of prairies, hillsides, roadsides and rangeland -- pretty much anywhere it can get a root in the dirt. Everywhere it spreads, it replaces native grasses and other plant species to the consternation of conservationists as well as ranchers, whose cows refuse to eat it.

title: Plans for Terror Inquiries Still Fall Short, Report Says
description: The Justice Department, criticized for its treatment of hundreds of illegal immigrants jailed after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, has not done enough to avoid a repeat by spelling out clear criteria for determining who is considered a terrorist suspect, an internal report concluded today.

description: Columbia University said yesterday that it would cut all ties with Biosphere 2, casting into doubt the future of the $200 million ecology experiment that Edward P. Bass, the Texas billionaire and oil heir, built in the Arizona desert.

title: Disturbing the Nighttime Peace
description: People with asthma that gets worse at night might do well to avoid using melatonin as a sleep aid, according to a study issued yesterday.

title: Poor Workers Finding Modest Housing Unaffordable, Study Says
description: With the rise in housing costs outpacing that of wages, there is no state where a low-income worker can reasonably afford a modest one- or two-bedroom rental unit, according to a study issued today by the National Low Income Housing Coalition, an advocacy group based in Washington.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Forecast Of PC Shipments Is Increased
description: Worldwide shipments of personal computers will grow more than forecast this year because of heavier consumer spending and a better-than-expected second quarter, the market research company IDC said yesterday. Shipments will rise 8.4 percent, to 148.2 million units this year, compared with the company's prior estimate of 6.3 percent, said IDC, based in Framingham, Mass. Shipments next year will increase 10.3 percent, to 163.3 million units, IDC said. The forecast follows other signs that a three-year slump in computer-related sales is ending. Intel, the biggest chip maker, said on Thursday that third-quarter sales would rise 17 percent. Back-to-school and holiday sales will help shipments in the United States, while price-cutting and a strong euro will improve European results, IDC said. Asian shipments have picked up significantly since SARS was controlled, IDC said. IDC also revised its second-quarter growth estimate to 9.6 percent, from the 7.6 percent it reported in July. Shipments rose last year by 1.5 percent to 136.7 million units, IDC said, after falling in 2001 for the first time since 1985.

title: Fewer Antibiotics Prescribed
description: After decades on the rise, antibiotic use by American children fell by almost 25 percent from 1996 to 2000, according to a new study published in the journal Pediatrics.

title: Presidential Hopefuls Courting Huge Union for Endorsement
description: With an endorsement possibly imminent, most of the Democratic hopefuls for president lobbied the nation's fastest growing union for support today, though Howard Dean, Richard A. Gephardt and John Kerry appeared to have an edge.

description: After years of suffering with stress urinary incontinence, an annoying and embarrassing disorder that forced her to shun her favorite activities and think twice even before lifting a heavy bag of groceries, Gloria Rose of Wellesley, Mass., wants the world of fellow sufferers to know there are ways to curtail this distressing problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KONVITZ, MILTON R.
description: KONVITZ--Milton R. The Center for Jewish Living at Cornell mourns its beloved friend and mentor Milton R. Konvitz. His devotion to liberty, freedom and tolerance will always be remembered. His exemplary courage in advocating and establishing a residential living unit at Cornell University where Jewish students could live in an atmosphere conducive to their tradition is a legacy we cherish. The Students, Faculty, Alumni and Staff of The Center for Jewish Living at Cornell University

title: Jumping Continents In the Name Of Opera
description: There seems no end to the cheerful irreverence of Simone Young, the Australian conductor bound for the Hamburg State Opera. She had just finished ''Otello'' here in her hometown's famous scalloped opera house on the harbor, and at an after-performance supper she ordered a sizable bowl of mashed potatoes. Oysters followed. A splash of red wine accompanied the above. Her conversation was spunky, too. ''The brass really let rip tonight; I'm very proud of them,'' she said at a restaurant table high above the opera house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REINGOLD, HAIM
description: REINGOLD--Haim, 93. Beloved husband of Badonna Levinson Reingold and the late Leah Jacobson Reingold, father of Edward (Ruth), Arthur (Gail Bolan) and David, grandfather of seven grandchildren, great grandfather of five brother of the late Samuel, Dvora and Jacob. Born in Lodz, Poland, raised in Tel Aviv and came to U.S, in 1930 where he was educated at the University of Cincinnati. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fire Cuts Steel Output
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation said yesterday that a fire at its factory in Nagoya might reduce the company's profits by 42 percent, or 30 billion yen ($255 million). Because of the fire, Nippon, Japan's largest producer, may have to cut crude steel production by 500,000 metric tons. The affected plant produces steel used by the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Honda Motor Company and others. In a separate incident on Monday, a fire broke out at the third largest of the Bridgestone Corporation's nine factories in Japan. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Troubles in Iraq Dim Rumsfeld's Star, but He Fights Back
description: Only a few months after basking in the military's swift victory over Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld seemed to be on the defensive today after absorbing criticism from several sides over the Pentagon's planning for postwar Iraq.

title: PROFIT AT ECKERD UNIT OF PENNEY IS EXPECTED TO FALL 30%
description: The J. C. Penney Company said that third-quarter profit at its Eckerd drugstore division would fall about 30 percent amid increased competition and sluggish sales. The operating profit margin at the chain this year will be about 2.5 percent to 3 percent, the retailer said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. J. C. Penney previously said the division probably would not reach its profit-margin goal of 4 percent to 4.5 percent this year. J. C. Penney, which dropped plans in 2000 to sell 20 percent of Eckerd to the public, has said it was continuing to consider alternatives.

description: Warren Zevon, a singer and songwriter who came up with hard-boiled stories and tender confessions of love, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 56.

description: The recording industry filed 261 lawsuits yesterday against people who share copyrighted music over the Internet, charging them with copyright infringement in the first broad legal action aimed at ordinary users of file-sharing networks.

Hotels Are Tilting Toward Luxury to Lure Convention Business
description: Here is one of the abiding early images of the conventions and meetings business: In a 1956 episode of ''The Honeymooners'' television series, Ralph Kramden and Ed Norton, decked out in ceremonial coonskin caps and armed with a bagful of convention-style gag tricks, congratulate each other on an overnight train for managing to keep their wives from tagging along to the annual convention of their Raccoon Lodge -- before they accidentally manacled themselves to their berths with a pair of joke handcuffs.

Mr. Robb had been senior vice president and creative director at Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: WorldCom and Dissident Creditors Settle on Payment Plan
description: In an agreement that seems to remove a major impediment to its emergence from bankruptcy protection, MCI said it had reached agreement with two groups of dissident creditors on repayment terms.

title: Deep in the Heart of New Mexico
description: The risk that a new twist in bare-knuckled partisanship could spread nationally is becoming ever clearer in the opra bouffe in Texas over redrawing Congressional districts. Democratic lawmakers in Austin have been fleeing the Statehouse since spring, choosing exile in Oklahoma and New Mexico to deny the Republican majority a quorum in its attempt to gerrymander Democratic representatives out of their seats in Washington. One of the key holdout Democrats has returned home from a monthlong exile in Albuquerque. He is searching for a flag of truce after the close of a second 30-day special session called by Texas's governor, Rick Perry. But no such truce seems likely amid speculation that Governor Perry may have the returned runaway dragooned by state troopers, then obstinately call still a third special session on behalf of the craving of Tom DeLay, the House majority leader in Washington, for more G.O.P. members.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Funds For Tourism Company
description: A tourism company, Hyundai Asan, which operates tours by land and sea to the Mount Kumkang region of North Korea, plans to raise money by offering 380,000 shares at 5,000 won ($4.28) each. The president of Hyundai Asan, Kim Yoon Kyu, above, held out the possibility of more share offerings even though the company was not yet listed on the Korea Stock Exchange. The offering comes amid efforts at opening North Korea to increasing numbers of South Korean visitors. The two airlines of South Korea, Korean Air and Asiana, and the North Korean airline, Air Koryo, plan to operate regular charter service between Pyongyang and Seoul beginning this month. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Fluttering Rat-a-tats to Celebrate a Birthday
description: Painkiller is based on the good old rock 'n' roll model of a power trio, but it has shifted to an area of music where genres are useless. The band is alto saxophone (John Zorn), bass (Bill Laswell) and drums (Hamid Drake). The music it played on Friday night at Tonic was, in brief, a mixture of noise, reggae, rock and free jazz.

title: James Rachels, Ethicist, 62; Ignited Euthanasia Debate
description: Dr. James Rachels, a philosopher and medical ethicist who wrote some of the most influential works on euthanasia, arguing that the legal distinction between killing and passively allowing a patient's death had no rational basis, died on Friday at a hospital in Birmingham, Ala. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAUBARD, BLANCHE K.
description: GRAUBARD--Blanche K. The partners and employees of Graubard Miller deeply mourn the passing of Blanche Graubard, beloved wife of Seymour Graubard, our esteemed founding partner. We remember her graciousness, intelligence and warmth and will miss her. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Mr. Graubard and the Graubard family. Graubard Miller

title: Deep Sea on Big Screen
description: The new IMAX movie ''Volcanoes of the Deep Sea,'' which has its world premiere today in Los Angeles at the California Science Center, illuminates the dark world of the vents as never before, giving its creatures, hot springs and towering chimneys a remarkable new venue.

description: ''A little of our son lives in each and every one of you.''

title: Outbreak on the Concert Circuit
description: Some music lovers carried the hepatitis A virus with them this year on the concert tours of their favorite bands, causing an outbreak of 25 cases involving residents of nine states, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Research In Motion Raises Forecasts
description: Research in Motion Ltd., maker of BlackBerry pagers, said yesterday that second-quarter sales and profit would be higher than prior forecasts because of increased subscribers. The company now expects net income of 2 cents to 5 cents a share on revenue of $123 million to $126 million, higher than its previous forecast of $105 million to $115 million, the company said. Analysts had expected it to break even, according to a poll by Thomson Financial. Research in Motion, based in Waterloo, Ontario, is expecting to have 94,000 to 97,000 subscribers, exceeding the previous prediction for 80,000 to 90,000. The higher-than-expected revenue and cost-cutting have helped increase profit, the chief financial officer, Dennis Kavelman, said. Shares of Research in Motion rose 39 cents, to $28.24, on the Nasdaq. The company will report complete second-quarter results on Sept. 25.

Former political columnist for three New York City newspapers and former assistant press secretary to Governors Rockefeller and Wilson. Past president of The Inner Circle. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Sharon Dannis and Wayne Harris. Dear brother of Ruben J. Harris. Devoted grandfather of five. Services Tuesday 12:15pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-50 Horace Harding Expswy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Corrections

Stern, who agreed to pay $10 million in fines and provide $30 million in restitution to settle a complaint that he used illegal trading tactics to take in profits at the expense of mutual-fund investors, misspelled the surname of a founding editor of Spy magazine, where Mr. Stern once worked. description: After guiding the city through last month's blackout and spending much of the summer courting voters, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has gained a modest lift in his job-approval ratings, the latest New York Times poll has found.

title: Fake Licenses Are Still Seen as Easy to Obtain
description: Despite many states' tightening of procedures for issuing driver's licenses after the Sept. 11 attacks, undercover federal investigators still found it relatively easy to obtain fake licenses by using counterfeit documents, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Limbaugh Thrives as an Outsider While Talking Football
description: If Rush Limbaugh talking football on ESPN's ''Sunday NFL Countdown'' seems the equivalent of Bill O'Reilly jumping bare out of Al Franken's birthday cake, think again. Tanned and trim (had he been to training camp?), Limbaugh brings a tart, arrogant outsider's viewpoint to a studio program designed for core pigskin fans and which, in past years, added the insiders Marty Schottenheimer and Bill Parcells.

title: Getting Personal, With Alcohol
description: A new study indicates that the first National Alcohol Screening Day, observed four years ago at hundreds of sites nationwide, has been characterized a success, both in terms of attendance and results.

title: 78% of Bush's Postwar Spending Plan Is for Military
description: President Bush's $87 billion request for postwar costs is heavily weighted to maintaining military operations, with $65.5 billion directed to the armed forces, $15 billion toward rebuilding Iraq and $5 billion toward building its security forces, and $800 million to new spending for civilian programs in Afghanistan, administration officials said today.

But at 72 he still looks like, well, a beach boy, albeit older. And his career and personal life, if not exactly sunny, are far livelier than most of his films, which he groans about.
