title: Outbreak That Wasn't: A SARS False Alarm
description: It seemed like the typical viral ''summer cold'' as it began spreading through a nursing home in the Vancouver area in early July. Then in August, test results from the Canadian National Microbiology Laboratory suggested that the ''cold'' might be from a mutated SARS coronavirus.

title: Thomasville Furniture Moves Duties to Martin
description: Thomasville Furniture Industries in Thomasville, N.C., part of Furniture Brands, has consolidated the creative, media and public relations duties on its account at the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Although billings were not disclosed, Thomasville spent $23.4 million to advertise in major media last year and $19.1 million in the first half of 2003, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: 2 Men Sought In Bomb Death After Robbery
description: The F.B.I. today released drawings of two men wanted for questioning in a bank robbery in Erie, Pa., last month that resulted in the death of a pizza deliveryman.

title: WorldCom Hearing Starts, Then Stops for More Talks
description: Soon after a hearing began yesterday on whether WorldCom has come up with a viable and fair plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection, lawyers for the company and a group of creditors that has been among the plan's most vocal critics asked for more time to negotiate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: College President To Retire
description: Byron N. McClenney, left, president of Kingsborough Community College since July 2000, announced on Friday that he would retire in December. Under his leadership, Kingsborough has expanded its full-time faculty 5 percent to 260 members, improved student retention and doubled its grants and contracts to nearly $5 million, the college said. The chancellor of the City University of New York, Matthew Goldstein, said he would recommend Fred B. Malamet, a Kingsborough professor and former dean, as interim president. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Despite Bonds's Loss, the Show Goes On
description: October, and the opportunity it signifies, is still more than three weeks away for the San Francisco Giants, who came so close to a winning the World Series last fall. Within two innings, actually, before the Anaheim Angels rallied to win in seven games.

title: 14-Year-Old Is Charged With Murder
description: A 14-year-old boy was charged yesterday with second-degree murder after witnesses said he had shot his best friend with an unlicensed handgun. But several people who knew the friends said the shooting, on Sunday afternoon in a housing project in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was an accident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SURKIS, BERNARD
description: SURKIS--Bernard. Died September 7, 2003. ''The Original Good Guy''. Devoted husband of Hilda, beloved father of Michele, Wendy and Scott, adored grandfather of Ian, Darren and Justin, brother of Emanuel, the late Herman and sister Shirley. We will miss your love, your caring, your willful ear and your support of all our accomplishments. Rest and watch over us all. With loving and fond memories: Bernard and Michele, Wendy and Peppi, Scott and Carol, Ian and Halie, Darren and Liz, and Justin and Dana.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about new books in France on the Sept. 11 attacks misspelled the surname of the author of ''Nine Eleven,'' which is based on reminiscences of students at Stuyvesant High School and P.S. 234. He is Jean-Jacques Greif, not Grief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOPATIN, JOSEPH
description: LOPATIN--Joseph. The Auxiliary Minyan of Congregation Ahavath Torah expresses its profound and heartfelt condolences to Sara, Uri, Shoshana and Amir on the loss of your dear husband and father, Yussie. We shall always cherish and admire his deep love for his friends, community and people.

title: Quirky Runway Hits Signal a Mood Swing
description: A dozen years ago, Karen Gates dressed to project the kind of muted authority she felt fitted her status as a public relations consultant for the tourism industry. ''It was really about keeping up with what you thought was classic -- the Armanis and Chanels,'' she said. ''You spent a lot of money but you didn't have a lot of fun.''

title: Italian for Astronomers
description: To the Editor:

title: Annan Wants Security Council To Grow to Better Reflect World
description: Hoping to use the Iraq crisis to kick-start the stalled process of overhauling the United Nations, Secretary General Kofi Annan today suggested enlarging the Security Council to make it more representative of 21st-century geopolitical realities.

title: Candidate's Choice Adds To Democrats' Challenge
description: The decision by Senator John Edwards of North Carolina to step down from the Senate and devote his full attention to his presidential campaign presents yet another challenge for Democrats, who have struggled for years to elect more senators from the South.

title: McKeon Has Marlins In Rare Playoff Run
description: Jack McKeon made his way through the visitors' clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday, a cloud of pungent cigar smoke preceding and trailing him. It was three hours before the game and the cigar was nearly down to a stub. McKeon has enough victories that he is not out of line lighting up a victory cigar any time of day.

title: Abbas's Departure: What's Changed?
description: To the Editor:

title: October
description: In this preview of October's new shows, the show titles are linked to Times reviews as they are posted throughout the month.

title: AMERICAN HEALTHWAYS TO BUY STATUSONE FOR $65 MILLION
description: American Healthways said that it had agreed to acquire StatusOne Health Systems, a closely held provider of health management services, for $65 million. StatusOne, based in Westboro, Mass., provides health management services to high-risk health plan customers. American Healthways, based in Nashville, provides diabetes treatment programs and other services for health plans and hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELCH, ROBERT C.
description: WELCH--Robert C. 72, of Princeton, NJ, died September 4, Memorial service 3 P.M. Wednesday September 10th Kimble Funeral Home, 1 Hamilton Ave, Princeton.

title: Protests Mar Opening of Expanded Harvey Milk School
description: For the 75 students who attend the Harvey Milk High School, the first day of classes yesterday included not just the usual confusion over new classrooms and new electives, but also a walk past a crowd of chanting demonstrators.

title: How Teachers Can Stop Cheaters
description: ''Academic cheating is a major problem and has negative results on everyone involved.''

title: Dr. Jose Barchilon, a Psychoanalyst, 90
description: Dr. Jose Barchilon, a psychoanalyst and educator who studied the unconscious roots of creativity and mental illness, died on Aug. 6 at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 90.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Sentenced For Biting Officer's Ear
description: A man convicted of attacking a court officer during a hearing and biting off part of his ear has been sentenced to 25 years in prison, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The man, Gaeton Remy, 31, of Jamaica, Queens, was convicted in late July of multiple assault charges after a courtroom attack that left Officer Patrick Glynn disfigured. The attack took place on Oct. 10, 2002, after Judge Stephen Knopf told Mr. Remy that he had violated his probation and would be taken into custody. Mr. Remy flew into a rage and bit Mr. Glynn's ear with his metal denture, severing part of the lobe. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Abuse Victims in Boston to Receive $85 Million From Church
description: The Archdiocese of Boston agreed today to pay $85 million to settle lawsuits filed by about 560 people who said they had been sexually abused by Catholic priests, a spokeswoman for the law firm representing about half the victims said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 14 about Diana Mosley, the British aristocrat who was a staunch supporter of Hitler and fascism, referred incompletely to Esmond Romilly, who had married one of her sisters, Jessica Mitford. Although Mr. Romilly was a rebellious young man of privilege, he also became a published writer and an ardent anti-fascist who fought against Franco in Spain and, while serving in the Royal Canadian Air Force, died in 1941, at 23, in a bombing raid against Nazi Germany.

title: Deep Under the Sea, Boiling Founts of Life Itself
description: What started as a hunch is now illuminating the origins of life.

title: Irvington Ex-Mayor Is Sentenced To a Year in Witness Tampering
description: Sara B. Bost, the former mayor of Irvington, was sentenced today to a year in prison for attempted witness tampering by a federal judge who said he could not ignore the calculation she showed in the case.

title: Presidential Character
description: George Bush's long-term plans for 2003 probably did not call for his August vacation to be followed by a national television address trying to justify a floundering policy in Iraq. Just about nothing, in fact, looks like what he must have hoped for in the run-up to an election. To many Americans, the economic recovery is anything but -- 2.7 million private-sector jobs have been lost in the last three years. The number of people living below the poverty line is rising, the trade imbalance has reached unnerving proportions, and the federal budget deficits have grown so huge that even the International Monetary Fund has begun expressing concern. Most of the Bush domestic agenda is a sad deflated version of its earlier incarnation.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose as some investors speculated the Japanese economy will benefit as the global economy expands. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.58 yen, down from 116.83 on Friday.

title: The Jets Want to Squeeze More Plays Out of Their Offense
description: The Jets are searching for a way to run more offensive plays and are casting about like someone reaching deep into his pockets, hoping to unearth some spare change.

title: F.T.C. ASKS FOR INFORMATION ON TAKEOVER BID FOR DANA
description: The Dana Corporation and ArvinMeritor said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had asked for more information about ArvinMeritor's hostile $2.2 billion takeover bid for Dana. The request shows ''the serious nature of antitrust obstacles'' to the offer, Dana said. ArvinMeritor said separately that it would work with the agency and that ''the request is not unusual for transactions of this kind.'' The board of Dana, a maker of axles for pickups, sport utility vehicles and minivans, has urged stockholders to reject the $15-a-share offer, citing antitrust issues and the amount ArvinMeritor would have to borrow. ArvinMeritor, a maker of commercial-truck axles, disclosed its bid July 8 and has extended it until Oct. 2.

title: Letters
description: ACosmic Quandary

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 30 about Mary Viscountess Eccles, a leading bibliophile and collector of material on Samuel Johnson, misspelled part of the name of her home in Somerset County, N.J., where she died. It is Four Oaks Farm, not Oakes.

title: Vial of Blood Is Laid to Rest As Fire Dept. Salutes Its Last
description: Under yesterday's clear late-summer sky, flanked by two thousand firefighters frozen in white-gloved salute, nine men in dress blue uniforms slowly pulled a wooden casket from a fire truck and carried the box containing what remained of their final lost comrade into St. Bernard Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ex-Baseball Commissioner Dropping Out of California Race
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 — Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, announced today that he was dropping out of the race for governor of California.

title: A Measurement Whose Time Has Come
description: With all eyes on Mars, this may be the right time to demystify distances used in astronomy.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Arguments on the Campaign Finance Law
description: Following are excerpts from arguments yesterday before the Supreme Court about the new campaign finance law, the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act, or B.C.R.A., as recorded by the Alderson Reporting Company. Arguing against the law were Kenneth W. Starr and Floyd Abrams; arguing for it were Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson and Seth P. Waxman.

title: Fighting the Idea That All the Internet Is Free
description: With the club of lawsuits and the olive branch of an amnesty program, the music industry is waging a campaign against online piracy that relies on both public relations and economics to attack the idea that everything in cyberspace can be free.

title: 2 Bombings in Israel
description: Two Palestinian suicide bombers killed at least 15 people in separate attacks on Tuesday.

title: Changes at Ground Zero
description: Two years at the site of the World Trade Center.

title: Happy Together
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS SALES OUTLOOK IMPROVES Texas Instruments, whose chips were used in half the cellphones sold worldwide last year, said yesterday that third-quarter sales would rise to the high end of its forecast. Net income will be 20 cents to 22 cents a share in the quarter ending this month, with revenue at $2.39 billion to $2.49 billion, the company said. In July, the company forecast net income of 19 cents to 23 cents on sales of $2.29 billion to $2.49 billion. Demand is increasing for semiconductors used in cellphones with new features like cameras and MP3 audio players, Texas Instruments executives have said, echoing comments from competitors including Intel and National Semiconductor . The Dallas-based company had net income of $188 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $2.25 billion in last year's third quarter. Shares fell 62 cents to $24.70 in extended trading after the announcement. The stock fell 71 cents in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OELBAUM, GILBERT
description: OELBAUM -- Gilbert. Died September 7, 2003, at peace and with loving family by his side. Husband of Carol. Father of Steve and Barbara. Grandfather of Matt, Elizabeth, Erica and Kyle, storyteller to the world. We love you and miss you already.

title: What Will It Be, New York City? For $166 Million, Make It Snapple
description: For the right price, the Big Apple is happy to be called the Big Snapple.

title: A Voice of the Mets Ready to Step Aside
description: Bob Murphy will call his final game for the Mets on Sept. 25, when the team will honor him in a pregame ceremony. On Sept. 19, he and Ralph Kiner, two of the team's original announcers, will unite for a retro game on Fox Sports New York with camera angles and graphics like those Channel 9 used in 1973.

title: Congressional Committee Agrees on Drug Benefits
description: In a small but potentially significant step, House and Senate negotiators voted today to help elderly people buy prescription drugs with discount cards endorsed by the federal government.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''From this day forward, in the eyes of you people and in the eyes of the church, I am not an alleged victim of clergy abuse. I am recognized. I am a survivor.''

title: Is the alcohol industry pitching products to young audiences? Congress hears two views.
description: THE battle over alcohol marketing and under-age drinking erupted again yesterday, as two significant reports to Congress gave ammunition to each side.

title: Whose Fault? The Blame Game (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Council Chief Gives Support Others Can Hum To
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller can sing six national anthems, but the Dominican Republic's is not yet one of them, so he substituted something more local yesterday while campaigning for Councilman Miguel Martinez in Inwood, a predominantly Dominican neighborhood in upper Manhattan.

title: Chile's Wound, 30 Years Later, Is Still Inflamed
description: All over the world, Salvador Allende is a legendary icon of the left. But here in his homeland, he tends to divide the Socialist-led coalition government and the Chilean left as a whole.

title: Ex-Treasurer of Enron Is Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
description: Ben F. Glisan Jr., the former treasurer of the Enron Corporation , pleaded guilty this morning to a federal charge that he committed securities and wire fraud. He becomes the highest-ranking former Enron executive to admit wrongdoing in the accounting scandal that drove the energy company into bankruptcy.

title: CALENDAR
description: So a Child Might Hear

title: Incumbents Victors In Primary Battles
description: In an election with an unusually large number of challengers, all incumbents prevailed with relative ease in yesterday's primaries for City Council seats. But in the Bronx, Pedro Gautier Espada, a former councilman with a well-known political name in that borough, was unsuccessful in his quest to return to office.

title: Healing Humanity on His Own Terms
description: MOUNTAINS BEYOND MOUNTAINS

title: After a Death, a Family Is Left Wondering
description: Petra Cachola got around pretty well at age 85, her family said, but she accepted a wheelchair anyway, for the longer walks around Spanish Harlem, to shop, to see her daughters, or to attend Mass at St. Cecilia's Catholic Church.

title: U.S. aid offer prods Turkey on troops for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON:  There were hints Tuesday that the U.S. decision to seek a broader United Nations mandate in Iraq might be starting to pay off: The Bush administration said it was ready to provide Turkey with up to $8.5 billion in loans, and the acting Iraqi president said he would welcome up to 10,000 peacekeeping troops from Turkey, under certain conditions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NORTON, WILLIAM
description: NORTON--William. On the tenth anniversary of your death, you are always remembered with love. Sassona

title: A Cue for Action
description: Faced with lawsuits from hundreds of people who say they were sexually abused by priests, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston fought back last year with legal tactics befitting any corporation under siege, at one point even trying to obtain the confidential notes of an accuser's therapist.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Israeli Rabbi Visits
description: The new Ashkenazi chief rabbi of Israel, Yona Metzger, spoke to hundreds of Jews and more than two dozen rabbis from all over Russia on his first visit to the huge modern synagogue near the center of Moscow. The visit underscored the transformation of ties between Russia and Israel after decades of bitterness over the difficult emigration of Soviet Jews. Moscow's mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, met Rabbi Metzger and promised land in central Moscow for Russia's first Jewish museum. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Charges In Credit Card Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn charged 15 people yesterday with what they said was a $2 million scheme in which credit card holders allowed fraudulent charges to be made to their accounts until their credit limits were exhausted. In addition to four customers, 10 residents of New York and New Jersey were charged with being ''brokers'' who took a cut of the proceeds for connecting customers with an employee of a travel agency where the cards were used. At the time, the prosecutors said, a Bronx man charged with being a broker, Hicham Fayad, 36, was out on bail after pleading guilty last year in an earlier credit-card case. More than 100 people have been charged in Brooklyn federal court with similar credit-card schemes totaling more than $20 million in the last two years. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Mayoral Flaws (and Chances)
description: Asked the meaning of two new polls showing a modest improvement in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's approval ratings, politicians and academics divided into two camps: those who dwell on the silver lining, and those who dwell on the clouds.

title: The Line Between Life and Death, Still Indelible
description: Everyone above them died.

title: Militant Behind Bali Blasts Gets Death Sentence
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10  A defiant Islamic militant was sentenced to death today after being convicted of playing a major role in the Bali nightclub attacks that killed 202 people last year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the use of DNA evidence to clear a convicted man and identify a new suspect in the 1984 rape and murder of a 9-year-old girl in Maryland included an erroneous reference from the Baltimore County Police Department to the source of evidence analyzed this summer. It was the victim's underwear, not a sheet.

title: U.S. Moves to Halt Import Of Drugs From Canada
description: The Justice Department moved yesterday to close a chain of Canadian drugstores, signaling that federal regulators are cracking down on the import of cheaper drugs from abroad.

title: Remains Found Near Ground Zero
description: The authorities said yesterday that nine pieces of bone and muscle were found on Monday by construction workers at a building near the site of the World Trade Center, and that these may be the remains of a victim of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: Giants' Green Linemen Manage to Clear a Path
description: At one point in the third quarter of the Giants' opener against St. Louis on Sunday, running back Tiki Barber surveyed the landscape in front of him, an offensive line so shuffled it nearly made him shudder.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, several words were omitted in some copies yesterday from the last paragraph of a Sports of The Times column on the main sports page. In the column, Derek Jeter of the Yankees speculated on the possible benefits of a close race in the American League East Division. The affected passage, with the omission shown by brackets, should have read: '' 'With this group here, I think it could be good -- beneficial -- to play big games at the end of the regular season,' he said [yesterday morning, in the quiet of the clubhouse. 'There are a] lot of new faces, and you have to go through some things. Good things and, more importantly, bad things. It's good to win, but you have to be tested to see how you'll react.' ''

title: Recipe: New England Clam Chowder
description: Adapted from Mix in New York

title: Tea and Amnesty Recover Thousands of Antiquities for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Through a far-reaching international investigation built on traditional detective work, raw luck and the consumption by investigators of vast amounts of tea, more than 3,400 items looted from the national antiquities museum in Baghdad have been recovered, the head of the inquiry said today.

title: Edward Teller Is Dead at 95; Fierce Architect of H-Bomb
description: Edward Teller, who was present at the creation of the first nuclear weapons and who grew even more famous for defending them, died yesterday at his home on the Stanford University campus in Palo Alto, Calif., according to the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, which Dr. Teller once headed. He was 95.

title: Questions Grow on Pakistan's Commitment to Fight Taliban
description: Two years after the Sept. 11 attacks, questions are growing about whether Pakistan, a crucial American ally in the campaign against terrorism, is mounting a sincere effort to crack down on a resurgent Taliban and other Islamic militants.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about increased enrollment at professional cooking schools omitted part of one school name. It is the United States Personal Chef Institute, not the Personal Chef Institute.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUCKER, MARVIN
description: TUCKER--Marvin. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Marvin Tucker, beloved father of Neil Tucker, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. Neil is a past chair of the Westchester general campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to Neil and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: Waiter, There's a Vegetable in My Soup
description: ''I'M not a big vegetable fan,'' Rebecca Charles said as she cored a tomato the size of a softball, its yellow skin streaked with red and orange. She was at the shucking station of her Manhattan restaurant, Pearl Oyster Bar, where she is the chef. Among the restaurant's daily array of saltwater proteins -- raw littlenecks, grilled whole fish, lobster rolls and fried oyster rolls -- there are just a few simply prepared vegetable side dishes like snap peas and shoestring fries.

title: Singapore Reports a SARS Case at Odds With W.H.O. Definition
description: The Singapore Health Ministry confirmed today that a 27-year-old postdoctoral researcher who worked in two of the city's medical laboratories had SARS, the first new case reported since the World Health Organization said in July that the highly contagious disease had been contained worldwide.

title: U.S. Plans More Sea Exercises On Halting Illegal Arms Trade
description: The Bush administration, stepping up pressure on North Korea and Iran on the issue of nuclear programs, announced today that the United States and other nations would carry out 10 joint military exercises in coming months to train for the interception of shipments to and from nations suspected of having illegal arms programs.

title: Hacker Ran Up $300,000 Bill At The Times, The F.B.I. Says
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged a man yesterday with hacking into the computer network of The New York Times, creating fictitious user identities and running up $300,000 in database research charges over three months last year.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Click Control C To Zap Lillian

title: It's Mexico in Chelsea: Cue the Iguanas
description: THERE aren't too many restaurants that make a better first impression than Sueos, Sue Torres's latest excursion into the new-wave Mexican cuisine she pioneered at the Rocking Horse Cafe Mexicano. What could have been a murky underground lair has been craftily decorated, with a hot tropical color scheme and folk-art dioramas in place of windows on an otherwise forbidding blank wall. In a small niche between the restaurant and the building next door, there's a little piece of Arizona, a rock garden open to the elements. All it needs is a violent lightning storm.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Wrangling Over a Cleanup at 90 Church Street
description: Two years after the collapse of the World Trade Center across the street rained debris and contaminated dust on 90 Church Street, the Art Deco former federal building is still in the midst of legal wrangles and problems with cleaning it up.

title: Bush Calls for End to 'Past Bickering' Among Allies on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  President Bush called today for an end to "past bickering" so that the way can be cleared for a United Nations resolution to send more soldiers from other countries to bolster peacekeeping forces in Iraq.

title: Development Bank Agrees to Finance Gas Project in Peru
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10  An ambitious project to develop Peru's natural gas fields, sharply criticized by environmentalists, won an important victory today when the Inter-American Development Bank approved a $75 million loan, bank officials in Washington said.

title: High Profile of 9/11/02 Shifts to Low on 9/11/03
description: When it came time to commemorate the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks last year, President Bush raced to all three sites of horror: The Pentagon, ground zero and the field in Shanksville, Pa., where the jetliner that did not hit Washington left a fearsome scar. The television cameras rarely let him step out of the center of the picture.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Indicted Judge Loses Challenge
description: A State Supreme Court judge's attempt to get criminal corruption charges against him dismissed was rejected yesterday on procedural grounds. The judge, Gerald P. Garson, is accused of accepting gifts and cash from a divorce lawyer in return for favorable treatment and client referrals, and his lawyers had argued that even if Justice Garson did that, he was subject only to judicial discipline, not criminal prosecution. Yesterday, the judge hearing the case, Steven W. Fisher of State Supreme Court, ruled that the form of the challenge -- a civil suit to halt prosecution -- was not appropriate, and he advised Justice Garson's lawyers to file a simpler motion to have the case dismissed on grounds of insufficient evidence. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marketer's Profit Falls
description: The British marketing and research company Aegis Group said pretax profit fell 20 percent for the six months ended June 30 from a year ago, to 13.4 million ($21.3 million). Sales at Aegis increased 11.4 percent to 3.46 billion ($5.51 billion), but the company took restructuring charges. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: At Debate, Democrats Clash Over Mideast
description: The Democratic presidential candidates battled tonight over United States foreign policy in Iraq, with candidates who opposed the invasion ridiculing rivals who voted for the war but who have become critics of it as the campaign has taken off.

title: BIDDER SWEETENS OFFER FOR ELDER-BEERMAN STORES
description: The Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation, the unprofitable operator of 68 department stores in eight states, said yesterday that it had received a higher buyout offer, of $81.6 million, from Wright Holdings Inc. The new price topped a competing proposal from Bon-Ton Stores Inc. Wright Holdings, which previously offered to pay $6 a share, is now offering $7.05 a share in cash, said Elder-Beerman, which is based in Dayton, Ohio. Bon-Ton offered to pay about $81.1 million, or $7 a share, for Elder-Beerman.

title: All Council Incumbents Win Their Primary Races, Despite Many Challenges
description: In an election with an unusually large number of challengers, all incumbents prevailed with relative ease in yesterday's primaries for City Council seats.

title: Fresh Salsas Dance To Hot and Cool Tune
description: Scoop these vibrantly fresh-tasting salsas out of their containers and call them your own. The fire-roasted red, green and papaya-mango varieties, made by Native Kjalii Foods of San Leandro, Calif., have enough chili in them to add a nice kick. The company's chunky-texture fresh cucumber salsa is both hot and cooling, and the guacamole will please the dip-and-chip set. The salsas are $7.50 for a 15-ounce container at Dean & DeLuca, $6.99 at Gourmet Garage and $6.98 at Zabar's, except for the cucumber, which is $5.49.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: WASHINGTON: SCIENTIST CALLED INCOMPETENT The State Patrol has determined that its embattled forensic scientist, Arnold B. Melnikoff, of Spokane is incompetent and should be fired. The patrol reviewed 100 cases completed by Mr. Melnikoff from 1999 to 2002 and found that his work on drug analysis did not meet professional standards. The investigation began after questions arose about his work in Montana, where he was a crime laboratory manager until 1989. Two men there who were convicted of separate rapes based largely on Mr. Melnikoff's research and testimony were later exonerated. (AP)

title: Panel Proposes Safety Changes For Pickups And S.U.V.'s
description: A task force of auto industry engineers has proposed redesigning some sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks so they inflict less damage on cars and making side air bags standard equipment on all vehicles.

title: Whose Fault? The Blame Game
description: To the Editor:

title: A Popular Idea: Give Oil Money to the People Rather Than the Despots
description: Few Iraqis have heard of the ''resource curse,'' the scholarly term for the economic and political miseries of countries with abundant natural resources. But in Tayeran Square, where hundreds of unemployed men sit on the sidewalk each morning hoping for a day's work, they know how the curse works.

title: Straight Talk on Judicial Nominees
description: When Miguel Estrada withdrew his nomination for a federal judgeship last week, his backers blamed anti-Hispanic bias. Republicans are regularly tossing around such charges over judicial nomination setbacks, calling them anti-Hispanic, anti-Catholic, anti-woman. But these battles have been over ideology, and the scope of the Senate's questioning of nominees. The name-calling is puerile and divisive. The administration and its supporters should argue for their nominees on the merits.

title: Casting a Cold Eye on Arctic Oil
description: Here's a helpful hint for backpackers here in the Arctic: If you're lying in your sleeping bag and suddenly feel a pat on the behind from outside the tent, YELL!

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 12-Year-Old Robbery Suspect
description: The police have arrested a 12-year-old boy, his mother, and a teller who authorities said were involved in the robbery of a Citibank branch on Avenue A. The mother, Tamara Rivers, 34, of Harlem River Drive in Manhattan; the teller, Monique Gray, 19, of Astoria Boulevard in Queens; and the boy were arrested yesterday in connection with a robbery on Aug. 28 the authorities said. The boy entered the bank, at 50 Avenue A, passed a note to a teller demanding money, and fled with $30,000 in cash, the authorities said. Only about $16,000 was recovered. Charges against the three were pending as of early this morning. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Designing Dance As Art Installation
description: In her new work, ''insideout,'' the choreographer Sasha Waltz forces viewers to make choices, and in choosing, they must miss something. The audience strolls through the dance as if through a museum, some chatting or drinking water.

title: Sprinter Likely to Lose Medals
description: Track and field's world governing body has rejected the sprinter Kelli White's explanation for taking a stimulant, recommending that she be stripped of the gold medals she won at 100 and 200 meters at the recent world championships in Paris.

title: Times Names First Editor For Standards
description: Allan M. Siegal, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, has been appointed the newspaper's standards editor, filling a new post.

title: Charles E. Bennett Dies at 92; Put 'In God We Trust' on Bills
description: Charles E. Bennett, a Florida Democrat who was a champion of ethical reforms in Congress and who sponsored the legislation that put ''In God We Trust'' on currency, died on Sept. 6 in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 92.

title: Off the Menu
description: TOM VALENTI, left, who opened Ouest on 84th Street in spring 2001, braving the Upper West Side well north of Lincoln Center, has added another place in the neighborhood. With GODFREY POLISTINA and his other partners in Ouest, he has opened 'CESCA at 164 West 75th Street. The restaurant is named for one of Mr. Polistina's daughters, Francesca. Dark wainscoting, stone flooring and subtle, beige frescolike wall decorations give the place a slightly Renaissance feel. A bar area is separated from the main dining room by an open kitchen, where AMANDA FREITAG, the chef de cuisine, runs the show. The food has an Italian personality -- fritto misto, arancini, meatballs, pancetta-wrapped calf's liver -- bolstered by Mr. Valenti's robust approach to flavor.

title: New Jersey Set to Seek Damages to Pay for Reversing Effects of Pollution
description: After months of threatening imminent action, New Jersey officials say they will soon begin broadly enforcing a law that requires polluters to pay the total costs of restoring water sources and other natural resources damaged by contaminants, not just clean up the mess left behind.

title: Farm-Country Campus Goes Online Full Time
description: Amid the alfalfa fields and horse farms of Madison County, Morrisville State College might seem an unlikely campus to be at the forefront of a technological revolution.

title: In 2 Bombings, Arab Attackers Kill 13 in Israel
description: Two Palestinian suicide bombers killed at least 13 people in separate attacks today, striking a popular cafe in Jerusalem's most left-leaning neighborhood and a bus stop crowded with soldiers southeast of Tel Aviv.

title: TV and Ownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFE, ROSE
description: WOLFE--Rose. On September 8. Beloved mother of Paula W. Brill, M.D., and the late Stephen Wolfe. Cherished grandmother of Laura and Stephen Brill. Beloved greatgrandmother of Jackson, Sophie and Benjamin. Loving grandmother-in-law of Frances Wolfe and Ellen Evans. She was a retired New York City school principal and wife of the late Dr. Jack M. Wolfe, professor of mathematics and founder of the Department of Computer Science at Brooklyn College. Services Wednesday, September 10, 11:30 AM at Temple EmanuEl, 5th Ave. at 65th St.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 23 about lobbying by the electric power industry misspelled the name of the company that serves the San Diego area and referred incorrectly to Edwin Guiles, a senior official of the company. It is Sempra Energy, not Sampra. Mr. Guiles is chairman and chief executive of Sempra's utilities division, not chief executive of the parent company.

title: Article 2003091090870295192 -- No Title
description: The principal of a Washington Heights intermediate school continued to insist that a group of girls who had attended a "hooky party" during school hours take pregnancy tests, even after being warned that it was illegal to do so, according to an updated lawsuit filed yesterday.

title: Market Place; S.E.C. Penalizes Schering-Plough Over a Fair Disclosure Violation
description: Using inside information, institutional investors were able to save tens of millions of dollars by selling stock before the public found out how badly profits were deteriorating at Schering-Plough, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: 10 Named in Attack on Group in S.I. Park
description: The police yesterday released the names of 10 people they arrested in connection with a Staten Island attack on a black college student and her Hispanic and white friends.

title: Rotting Piers: A Forlorn Beauty to Savor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Venerable Bakery Gets a Makeover as a Cafe
description: Vesuvio Bakery, a fixture at 160 Prince Street (Thompson Street) since 1920, has changed hands, undergone several months' renovation and reopened as a bakery-cafe. Anthony Dapolito, whose parents founded the bakery, sold it last year to his friends Lisa and Christine Gigante, who are sisters-in-law. Mr. Dapolito died in July at 82, just weeks before Vesuvio reopened.

title: Many Civilians Wounded in Attack on U.S. Office in Iraq
description: ERBIL, Iraq, Sept. 10  A suicide bomber driving a sport utility vehicle attacked a building used by Americans in this northern city, killing a local child and wounding about 50 people, 15 seriously, witnesses said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tellabs To Cut Work Force
description: Tellabs plans to pare its work force again by Oct. 3 and will offer employees based in the United States incentives to leave. A company spokesman, George Stenitzer, could not say how many jobs the unprofitable company would cut. Workers have until Tuesday to volunteer to quit, he said yesterday. Tellabs, a maker of fiber optic network equipment, expects to reduce operating expenses to $125 million by the fourth quarter. The chief executive, Michael J. Birck, has slashed the work force by more than half, to about 3,800, since 2001. Tellabs has racked up more than $700 million in losses since then because phone companies reduced network spending. The company, based in Naperville, Ill., said last month it would close a plant near Chicago and send the manufacturing work to the Sanmina-SCI Corporation, eliminating 325 jobs. Shares of Tellabs fell 31 cents, to $7.71.

title: Two Rookies Lead MetroStars Over Chinese National Team
description: The last time China's national team played at Giants Stadium was in 1977. That match against the Cosmos ended in a draw. Tonight, in an exhibition before a crowd of 7,611, China fell to the MetroStars, 2-1.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: BAIL DENIED IN SMUGGLING CASE A federal judge in Manhattan denied bail yesterday to Cheng Chui Ping, who federal officials say was the head of an international smuggling ring trafficking in people. The ring's operations included that aboard the steamer Golden Venture, which ran aground off Queens 10 years ago, leaving 10 hostages from China dead. A prosecutor argued before Judge Michael B. Mukasey of Federal District Court that Ms. Cheng was a major flight risk because of her access to vast financial resources and fake travel documents. When Hong Kong officials arrested her in April 2000, they found her with $31,000 in cash, three Belize passports with false names and a phone list of contacts in 16 countries. Ms. Cheng was charged in June with conspiracy to smuggle illegal immigrants, hostage taking, and money laundering, among other things, in a seven-count indictment. If convicted, she faces life in prison. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHONY, GRACE M. (NEE SULLIVAN)
description: MAHONY--Grace M. (nee Sullivan). Died peacefully on September 6, 2003, after a short illness at Lenox Hill Hospital. Age 95. Beloved wife of the late Paul A. Mahony. Devoted mother of Paul A. Mahony, his wife, Mary, Sheila A. Mahony, her husband Charles Riggs, Robert E. Mahony, his wife Christina, and the late Peter Mahony. Loving grandmother of Patrick Mahony, Matthew Mahony, Megan McFarlin and Nora Mahony, Charles Riggs III and Julia Riggs Shultis, and great-grandmother of eight. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 A.M. at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Ave at 84th St. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: U.S. Diet Proposals Reflect Nation's Lack of Fitness
description: The Department of Agriculture is proposing dietary advice that for the first time recognizes that a majority of Americans, 64 percent, are overweight and sedentary and need to eat less.

title: Primedia Said to Be Selling New York Magazine
description: Senior executives of New York magazine are meeting with employees today to inform them that the magazine is in the process of being sold, a company executive said. Primedia Inc. , which owns the magazine, is expected to be looking for a price in the neighborhood of $80 million for the weekly, which would be a very high price and reflects the company's belief that there will be interest from a number of competing buyers.

title: Potential Witness in Moxley Case Denies Knowing Who Killed Girl
description: A potential witness whom defense lawyers want to use to try to reverse the conviction of Michael C. Skakel in the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley said today that his statements on the matter had been ''blown out of proportion'' and that he did not know who had committed the murder.

title: DaimlerChrysler Struggles To Turn the Corner; Troubling Economic Signs for Giant Automaker
description: It is hard to shake the feeling that DaimlerChrysler owns the Frankfurt International Motor Show: the company showcases its cars in imperial style over three exhibition halls.

title: The Decline and Fall of Sports Ratings
description: Down. That is where the ratings of most major sports events went in the past year. Whether it was the World Series, the N.B.A. finals, all four Grand Slam golf tournaments or the recently completed United States Open, network ratings tumbled.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Insect Thought Extinct Begins To Breed
description: It may not seem like a cork-popping event, but the hatching of a single insect egg at the Melbourne Zoo was big news for the Lord Howe Island stick insect, a five-inch-long segmented bug that has been teetering on the edge of extinction. Dryocecelus australis, a k a the ''land lobster,'' is native to a tiny island group off eastern Australia. The species was thought to have been wiped out by rats in 1918, until scientists rediscovered a small colony in 2001. The breeding pair at the zoo are the only adult stick insects in captivity. An official said the female began laying eggs in February, and the first of about 100 eggs hatched on Sunday. Scott Veale (NYT)

title: From Short Order to Tall Order For Ducasse's New Protg
description: WHEN you are seated at Mix in New York, the restaurant in Midtown that Alain Ducasse opened on Monday, the first thing you are served is a little white Corian rack with slices of sourdough toast. Alongside, with spreaders, are little pots of butter, grape marmalade and peanut butter. Peanut butter?

title: Sports of The Times; Tigers Are Nearing a Dubious Distinction
description: ''IT'S like something mysterious is going on this season, like 'This can't be happening, can it?''' first baseman Carlos Pena said, looking around the Detroit Tigers' clubhouse at Yankee Stadium before last night's game. ''You have to wonder if there's some unreal power at work.''

title: Treasury Head Urges Overhaul of Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae
description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- Treasury Secretary John Snow asked Congress Wednesday for a stronger government hand over mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, saying ``we cannot be complacent'' about the housing finance market.

title: President Bush Delivers Remarks On Homeland Security
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks on homeland security, delivered in Quantico, Va., as recorded by FDCH e-Media, Inc.:

title: War Budget Request More Realistic but Still Uncertain
description: As the war wound down last spring and gave way to armed occupation, administration officials reassured Congress that rebuilding Iraq would be no big deal, at least in terms of cost to the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIONNE, BRIAN J.
description: DIONNE--Brian J., of Concord Village, Brooklyn, NY, on September 6 at age 51. Devoted friend and inspiration to many, and the developmentally disabled of NYC. His humor and guidance will be sorely missed by all including his mother, Mary Dionne, sister, Mary (Frank) Lopez, brothers, Daniel and Joseph, nephew, Frank Lopez Jr. and niece Theresa (Jason) Wells. Wake today 3PM-5PM at St. Boniface R.C. Church, 190 Duffield St, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass at 7PM. Donations to Mercy Home for Children, 243 PPW, Brooklyn, NY, 11215.

title: Martha Stewart Magazine Drops Her Calendar
description: For the last 13 years, Martha Stewart Living magazine has included Martha's Calendar, a month's worth of information about the activities of Ms. Stewart, the magazine's founder, namesake and guiding spirit. It has described her hurricane of domestic duties, from planting flowers to planning carriage rides.

title: Central Bank in South Africa Is Expected to Cut Key Rate
description: Faced with slowing growth and mounting accusations from industry that the country's strong currency is hurting exports and threatening jobs, South Africa's central bank will hold a special meeting on Wednesday when it is expected to cut interest rates for the third time in two months.

title: And a Prize in the Package, Jack
description: When Leutisher Scott and Kimberly Check joined forces to start a company called Bad to the Bone, selling products based on Ms. Scott's family recipes, they went tongue-in-cheek. They called a treat made with dried banana slices glazed with caramel Black Cracker Jack because ''it is what people who tasted it were calling it,'' Ms. Scott said. Though it has its own trademark, this irresistible snack does borrow from the original Cracker Jack. Instead of a sailor, there is a firefighter with his dog on the label, but each foil packet includes a prize. (I got a little plastic train whistle.) The banana slices trigger the urge to polish off the whole package at once. Black Cracker Jack is $2.49 for a two-ounce package, on sale until the end of October for $1.99, and can be ordered from (866) 351-5779. Shipping is extra. Bad to the Bone also makes a smoky, tart and spicy barbecue sauce, Big Butt Multipurpose Hickory Sauce, packaged to look like industrial glue, with the slogan ''Taste that sticks like glue.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the use of DNA evidence to clear a convicted man and identify a new suspect in the 1984 rape and murder of a 9-year-old girl in Maryland included an erroneous reference from the Baltimore County Police Department to the source of evidence analyzed this summer. It was the victim's underwear, not a sheet.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., the computer services company, won a contract for about $400 million to perform payroll and benefits work for Procter & Gamble, Cincinnati.

title: CHURCH IN BOSTON TO PAY $85 MILLION IN ABUSE LAWSUITS
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston agreed today to pay $85 million to settle almost 550 lawsuits by people who say they were sexually abused by priests. The settlement is the largest ever by an American diocese to resolve sexual abuse cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, MARTHA (MCCOR MICK)
description: KELLY -- Martha (McCor mick) of New York City on August 30, 2003. Devoted wife of the late Joseph, beloved daughter of the late Joseph E. McCormick and Alice G. title: Democrats Demanding Answers From Bush on His Plans for Iraq
description: Democrats on Capitol Hill intensified their criticism of the Bush administration's Iraq policy today, with moderates as well as liberals demanding a detailed strategic plan from the White House, along with an explanation of why domestic priorities were being shunted aside.

title: A Restaurant in Mourning Keeps Its Sights on Its Stars
description: FOR customers arriving at La Cte d'Or, one of the high temples of gastronomy in Burgundy, nothing seems to have changed.

title: Sports of The Times; Suspend Stars, Unless a Game Is at Stake
description: MOST college coaches have no legal expertise beyond their own income-tax loopholes, but there is a distinct Perry Mason complex oozing from the powerful and the paranoid these days.

title: River Days: No Cares, No Clothes, but (Sigh) No More
description: ''The Same River Twice,'' a piercingly poignant then-and-now portrait of five friends who worked as summer guides on the Colorado River in the 1970's, suggests that there may be exceptions to the adage that youth is wasted on the young. As you watch vintage film clips of the five, frolicking naked in the turquoise waters at the bottom of the Grand Canyon, you sense that they knew they were in heaven and were savoring every minute of it.

title: Swedish Foreign Minister Is Stabbed in Stockholm Store
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 10 — Foreign Minister Anna Lindh was stabbed today as she shopped in a department store here, an attack that rekindled memories of the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme on a Stockholm street in 1986.

description: To the Editor:

title: Snacker's Paradise: Devouring Singapore's Endless Supper
description: ''FOOD is the purest democracy we have,'' K. F. Seetoh said as we dug into breakfast bowls of bak kut teh, a peppery, restorative Teochew soup of pork ribs, mushrooms and kidneys. ''Singaporeans recognize no difference between bone china and melamine.''

title: Legislator Appears Winner in Democratic Race for Suffolk County Executive; Pulling Ahead in Yonkers
description: With returns incomplete, Deputy Mayor Phil Amicone held a lead of five percentage points in the Republican primary for mayor of Yonkers last night, the first hurdle he must clear in his campaign to succeed John Spencer, the two-term mayor and Mr. Amicone's political mentor, who is barred by term limits from running for re-election. Mr. Amicone ran against Michael J. Spano, an assemblyman from a powerful political family, who had 38 percent of the vote to Mr. Amicone's 43 percent.

title: More Troops Will Destabilize Iraq, Says Rumsfeld
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that increasing the number of American troops beyond the 130,000 there now would only destabilize the country further, saying in his starkest statement yet that Iraqis were responsible for their own future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KONVITZ, MILTON R.
description: KONVITZ--Milton R., September 5, 2003. Cornell University mourns the passing of Milton R. Konvitz, Cornell Professor Emeritus. A brilliant scholar in constitutional and labor law, civil and human rights, and a beloved professor and mentor to countless Cornell students, Professor Konvitz was a member of the faculty of Cornell School of Industrial and Labor Relations and Law School from 1946 until his retirement in 1973. He was a founder of Cornell's Department of Near Eastern Studies and Program of Jewish Studies. A prolific scholar, he continued to write and publish until his death. The Milton Konvitz Chair in Jewish Studies, established at Cornell in 1998 on the occasion of his 90th birthday, honors his name in perpetuity. He will be profoundly missed by the entire Cornell community. Jeffrey S. Lehman, President Peter C. Meinig, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Memorial for Benny Carter
description: A memorial service for the jazz musician Benny Carter will be held on Monday night at 7:30 at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Mr. Carter died on July 12 at 95.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Gas Venture Advances
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation won state approval to build a plant off Western Australia to liquefy natural gas for export to Asia and the West Coast of the United States. The Chevron-led group plans to use part of its Barrow Island reserve to process gas from its 11 billion Australian dollar ($7 billion) Gorgon field.

title: Courts and Patrols Approved As Way to Volleyball Peace
description: The East Hampton town board has found room for compromise in the battle over backyard volleyball.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest column yesterday about a new marketing effort for People magazine in light of intensified competition misstated the publication that Peggy Mansfield joined this week as publisher. It is In Touch Weekly, not People.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Orders for new machinery fell more than anticipated in July, as semiconductor makers cut purchases. Machinery orders, a leading indicator of corporate capital spending, fell 3.1 percent compared with June. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Senate Votes to Block Changes in Overtime Pay Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  President Bush's plan to change the definition of who is eligible for overtime pay ran into a major roadblock on Capitol Hill today, as Democrats led the Senate in voting, 54 to 45, to block the White House from issuing the new rules.

title: Delicious Deception to Go With Wine
description: A BASKET of browned shortbread cookies is not the usual fare at a wine tasting, especially when the tasting is in the Campania region of Italy and the wines are robust reds made from the Aglianico grape. Thinking that the cookies were my Italian hosts' misconception of what a group of Americans would want to nibble, I did not try one.

title: With Animals and Masks, Five Folk Tales Arabs and Jews Have in Common
description: As the last nights of summer ebb toward autumn, folding chairs and picnic blankets blossom under a canopy of leaves in the garden of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Ralph Lee and his Mettawee River Theater Company assemble their masks and puppets and musical instruments and set out to enchant an audience of young and old with tales drawn from the the world's folklore.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Profit To Fall
description: The European carmaker Volkswagen forecast a third consecutive drop in quarterly profit as the company spends money cutting 4,000 jobs in Brazil. A one-time charge for reorganizing the Brazilian business, including a 20 percent capacity cut, means third-quarter net income will be less than in either the first or second quarter, the chief financial officer-designate, Hans Dieter Ptsch, said at a news conference at the Frankfurt International Motor Show. The Volkswagen do Brasil unit is scaling back amid an economic slowdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, EDWARD V., JR.

Cherished grandfather of Peter, Stephen, Bridget and Connor Walsh. Dear Brother of Marion Coffey. Mr. Walsh was a LCDR in the U.S. Navy in WWII, a former New York City Fireman and practiced law in New York State for 50 years. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12 St, Garden City 2-4 & 7-9PM Wednesday & Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 10AM Friday. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday about the Million Youth March in Brooklyn misstated the given name of the city councilman walking with Malik Zulu Shabazz, chairman of the New Black Panther Party and lead organizer of the march. The councilman is Charles Barron, not James.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Debt Relief
description: The Korea Asset Management Corporation promised to buy another 3 trillion won of nonperforming loans from the country's nine credit card companies. The corporation earlier this year purchased three trillion won of bad loans as part of a government-orchestrated plan to deal with the mounting debts of individual consumers. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZITO, FRANK
description: ZITO--Frank (founder of Frank Zito Enterprises in (NYC), 65, of New York City died on Monday September 1, 2003. Beloved husband of Susan Zito. Loving brother of Nancy Colella. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Memorial visitation at Whalen and Ball Funeral Home, Yonkers, NY. (914) 965-5488 on Friday September 12, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial in St. Joseph's Church, 404 E. 87th St New York, NY on Saturday September 13, at 1 PM.

title: Africans' Burden: West's Farm Subsidies
description: Erikangin Thembo does not think much about agricultural policy as he farms. Sweating in the midday heat, he keeps his mind focused on the earth in front of him. He raises his hoe above his head. With a grunt, he sends it plummeting into the rich soil.

title: Man Dies of West Nile on Long Island
description: A62-year-old Suffolk County man died of West Nile virus yesterday afternoon, the first person in the metropolitan region to succumb to the mosquito-born disease this year, according to the New York State Department of Health.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Stake In Auto Venture
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan may sell 10 percent of its Indian unit to its local partner next year, according to Vikram Kirloskar, the vice chairman of the Indian venture. Toyota Kirloskar Motor, a joint venture with Kirloskar Systems Ltd. of India, started selling cars in India in 2000. Toyota has a 99 percent stake in the venture and has invested 9 billion rupees ($195 million) in India. The Toyota factory near Bangalore makes the Qualis sport utility vehicles and the Corolla sedans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GABRIEL, CHARLES A.
description: GABRIEL--Charles A. General USAF retired. Age 75 of McLean, VA on September 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Dorothy Gabriel. Loving father of Jane L. Gabriel and husband Jerry L. Copper and Charles A., Jr. and wife Kelli L. Gabriel. Also survived by one sister Betty Ross and three brothers Paul Gabriel, Jr., Steve Gabriel and S.G. Gabriel and five grandchildren, Darcy, Hillary, Courtney, Charlotte (Charlie) and Matthew Gabriel. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, September 17, 2003 at Ft. Myer Memorial Chapel at 1PM. Burial will follow at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. In lieu of flowers the family requests that memorial contributions be made to Alzheimer's Assoc.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Study On Underground Cable
description: Gov. John G. Rowland said yesterday that the state would hire an independent environmental consultant to evaluate the effects of burying the Cross Sound Cable to the depths required by the State Department of Environmental Protection. Critics have complained that blasting rock under the Sound to bury the cable, which runs 24 miles between New Haven and the former Shoreham Nuclear Power plant on Long Island, could harm the environment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANOFSKY, ESTRELLA (STELLA)
description: GRANOFSKY--Estrella (Stella). On September 8, 2003. Survived by son William Arraez and daughter Norma Kamali. Prayers at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home Tuesday, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday 10 AM at St. Monica's RC Church. She was a extraordinarily talented, unforgettable woman.

title: Color Me Orange (and Purple, Red, etc.)
description: Like just about everything else in the Greenmarket these days, carrots have gone rainbow. At Windfall Farms, they come in purple, yellow, white and red in addition to orange. Small carrots are sold in mixtures by the box, usually for around $3. Bigger carrots are $2 to $3 a pound. Alex Paffenroth of Paffenroth Gardens has carrots in assorted colors and sizes for $1.50 a bunch. Both farms, at Union Square on Wednesdays and Saturdays, will have the carrots through the fall. For a cold carrot soup, for example, make two batches of different colors, and gently swirl them together in their bowls. To make soup, boil carrots, peeled and in chunks, in salted water, puree in a blender, season with ground cumin, salt and pepper and a little lemon, then chill. Adjust the texture with more water, if it is needed.

title: Meeting Low Expectations, Happily
description: WHEN the economy slows, the restaurants retreat. Except for a few publicity-seeking barkers who choose a slow moment to hawk their Kobe beef hot dogs and caviar burritos, the luxury ingredients have largely given way to the basics: pizza, burgers, sandwiches and the rest.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Equipment To Become Standard In Accords
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings, which operates the nation's biggest satellite-radio service, said yesterday that its equipment would become standard on certain models of Honda Motor's Accord. XM might also be installed at the dealership on all 2004 Honda S2000 roadsters and Honda Pilots, Andy Boyd, a spokesman for Honda, said. XM is hoping to gain subscribers by making the equipment needed to receive its 101-channel satellite radio network standard in popular vehicles. Earlier this year, XM announced that its equipment would be standard on the 2004 Acura RL and TL sedans made by Honda. Honda owns about 8 percent of XM, Mr. Boyd said. General Motors has installed XM equipment in more than 500,000 vehicles since it was first put in Cadillacs in the 2002 model year, said Chance Patterson, an XM spokesman. G.M. owns a 15 percent stake in XM, he said. Shares of XM Satellite Radio rose $1.52, or 10 percent, to $16.10.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Sales Outlook Improves
description: Texas Instruments, whose chips were used in half the cellphones sold worldwide last year, said yesterday that third-quarter sales would rise to the high end of its forecast. Net income will be 20 cents to 22 cents a share in the quarter ending this month, with revenue at $2.39 billion to $2.49 billion, the company said. In July, the company forecast net income of 19 cents to 23 cents on sales of $2.29 billion to $2.49 billion. Demand is increasing for semiconductors used in cellphones with new features like cameras and MP3 audio players, Texas Instruments executives have said, echoing comments from competitors including Intel and National Semiconductor. The Dallas-based company had net income of $188 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $2.25 billion in last year's third quarter. Shares fell 62 cents to $24.70 in extended trading after the announcement. The stock fell 71 cents in regular trading.

title: Yankees Are Not at Best, but Still Beat the Worst
description: In this late-season matchup of the ridiculous versus the sublime, the Yankees' main challenge seemed to be to get to the ballpark on time. The rest would surely take care of itself. The opponent was, after all, America's most inept baseball team, the Detroit Tigers.

title: Terror Lesson Fading for Some, Aschcroft Says in Manhattan
description: Standing on the site where Congress adopted the Bill of Rights, Attorney General John Ashcroft brought his defense of the Patriot Act to the edge of ground zero yesterday and suggested that critics of the act, a sweeping antiterrorism law, ''have forgotten how we felt'' on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINBERGER, HOWARD A., M.D.
description: WEINBERGER--Howard A., M.D. The Physicians' Attending Association, Inc. of Leonox Hill Hospital deeply mourns the passing of Howard A. Weinberger, M.D., a member of the Department of Surgery for the past 59 years. Dr. Weinberger was a very esteemed and well loved physician who passed along his rich fund of knowledge to the resident staffs over his years at Lenox Hill Hospital. His friends and colleagues will miss this most dedicated of physicians and offer their heartfelt condolences to his wife Peggy and their family. Norman Schulman, M.D., President Jean-Michel Loubeau, M.D., Secretary

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: SARS Alarms Investors
description: News that health authorities in Singapore had confirmed a fresh case of SARS sent many airline and other tourism-related stocks tumbling as investors factored in the risk that another outbreak might send the region's travel industry back into a tailspin. The Ministry of Health said that a lab technician appeared to have developed the first known case of severe acute respiratory syndrome since spring, when the disease killed 33 people in Singapore. Shares of Singapore Airlines fell 6.1 percent;the hotel company Shangri-La Asia fell 8 percent; and Singapore-based Star Cruises dropped 12 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: For New York's Best Digs, Price of 'Wow!' Keeps Rising
description: There was a time when Kirk Henckels, director of private brokerage for the tony firm of Stribling & Associates, would refer to an apartment on the market for $10 million as "a trophy property." No more.

title: Dvorak In Spirit Revisits New York
description: It was a nice touch to open the second season of the free music series Great Music for a Great City with a Dvorak-themed program on Sunday afternoon. After all, the Czech composer had a personal connection to New York, having spent a storied three years here in the 1890's, when he came to teach at the National Conservatory and to found a new American school of classical music. (Yes, it was thought that the United States needed a real European to help develop its own classical music. In some ways, little has changed.)

title: Alabama Voters Crush Tax Plan Sought by Governor
description: Alabama voters overwhelmingly rejected a $1.2 billion tax increase today, delivering a crushing blow to their Republican governor, Bob Riley, who had staked his political career on the vote. His ambitious plan was to close a $675 million budget deficit, ease taxes on the poor and catapult the state's school system from among the nation's worst to one of the best.

title: Sun Microsystems' Co-Founder and Chief Scientist Resigns
description: William N. Joy, one of Silicon Valley's most respected and provocative technologists, said yesterday that he was leaving Sun Microsystems, a company he helped found 21 years ago.

title: WATSON WINS APPROVAL TO SELL GENERIC DIABETES DRUG
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had won Food and Drug Administration approval to sell a copy of Clucotrol, the diabetes drug from Pfizer Inc. Watson is entitled to six months on the market without competition from other generics on its 5-milligram copy because it was first to file for regulatory approval. Pfizer sued Watson over the patent last year and the case was dismissed in April. Watson, based in Corona, Calif., said it would begin selling the drug in the fourth quarter. Its exclusive marketing rights expire on Oct. 22.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Invoking the memories of Sept. 11, 2001, President Bush prodded Congress today to "untie the hands" of law enforcement and enact broader search-and-seizure powers and wider use of the death penalty to combat terrorism.

A devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, brother-in-law and an incomparable friend of ours. Our loss is beyond sadness, but we cherish over 75 years of wonderful memories. Never to be forgotten, Alan was unique. With all our love to all the family, Audrey and Dick

title: Hay Fever Is Delayed, Not Diluted
description: Dr. Leonard Bielory, an allergist in New Jersey, was startled by the size of the giant ragweed plants he saw in a field while hiking last week on the Appalachian Trail near the Delaware River. He said some were eight or nine feet high, or two to three feet taller than those he saw there late last summer. Some plants of another species, short ragweed, ranged up to six feet, nearly twice the height of last year's, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINDORAK, KATHLEEN
description: FINDORAK -- Kathleen. On September 8, 2003 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Jim O'Neill, dear sister of Joanne, devoted daughter of the late John and Bertha. She will be deeply missed by all her family and friends. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9 PM Wednesday and 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday September 12 at 10 AM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSBORNE, JAMES M. JR.
description: OSBORNE--James M. Jr. Passed away peacefully on September 6, 2003, at Appleberry Farm, Sandy Hook, Connecticut. Beloved husband of Betty Lou Brown Osborne, his wife of 55 years, he will also be dearly missed by his family: J. Robert Osborne, his wife Inge of Hamden, their children Owen, Devin and Carly; Michael B. Osborne, his wife Deb of Sandy Hook, their children Rebecca and Katherine Osborne Munno, her husband David Munno; Dorothy Osborne Cox, her husband W. Jay Cox of Guilford, CT and their children Dalton, Kendall, Elizabeth and Alice Frances; Susan Osborne White, her husband Brian White of Newtown and their children, Andrew, Ian and Emmett. He is also survived by his sister, Allison Osborne Titgemeier, her companion Richard Herr and sister-in-law Audrey S. Osborne of Chardon, Ohio. His nieces and nephews are John Titgemeier and Amy TitgemeierStevens, David A. Osborne, Richard M. Osborne, James M. Osborne III, Anne L. Osborne. His brother David A. Osborne died in August 1999. A graduate of Choate School in Wallingford, CT, Jim left his Class of 1947 at Dartmouth College to serve in the US Navy in the Pacific where he was a lieutenant on the cruiser USN Biloxi. He was among the first US Navy personnel ashore after Hiroshima and Nagasaki to ensure the release of the US prisoners of war held in Japan. He returned to graduate from Dartmouth where he was recognized as an All American Soccer player. Jim and Betty Lou Brown of Sandy Hook, CT were married on May 8, 1948 and settled on Appleberry Farm in Sandy Hook, where he worked for the Y&O Coal Company and then the Connecticut Coal Co, serving as President for 40 years. He was also the Chairman and President of the family owned Dock, Inc. Shopping Center in Stratford, CT. Jim and his sons Bob and Mike worked together for over 20 years and Miss Marion Philbin worked with him for his entire career. Jim served in many capacities on behalf of the Sandy Hook public school system, volunteer fire department and Boy and Girl Scouts. A fervent Cleveland Indians fan, he coached Little League and Babe Ruth for many years, also playing and coaching on the local Jacoby Bombers softball team. Jim served as a loyal member of the Newtown Rotary Club for over 50 years and was instrumental in establishing and assuring the achievements of the Heritage Preservation Trust. He was a member of the Men's Literary Social Club of Newtown and Treasurer of the Zoar Cemetery Board. A Corporator and Trustee of the Newtown Savings Bank for over 35 years, he was elected Chairman of the Board in 1996. He also served as Chairman of the Board at Gray Horse, Inc. and The United Garage Door Company in Ohio. Jim was the dearly loved patriarch of the Osborne Family. His friends and colleagues all found support in his company and were touched by his gentle spirit. Those who loved him will cherish their memories--he will be with us always. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Newtown Scholarship Association, PO Box 302, Newtown, CT 06470 or the Heritage Preservation Trust of Newtown, PO Box 3082, Newtown, CT 06470 on Jim's behalf.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: XM EQUIPMENT TO BECOME STANDARD IN ACCORDS XM Satellite Radio Holdings , which operates the nation's biggest satellite-radio service, said yesterday that its equipment would become standard on certain models of Honda Motor's Accord. XM might also be installed at the dealership on all 2004 Honda S2000 roadsters and Honda Pilots, Andy Boyd, a spokesman for Honda, said. XM is hoping to gain subscribers by making the equipment needed to receive its 101-channel satellite radio network standard in popular vehicles. Earlier this year, XM announced that its equipment would be standard on the 2004 Acura RL and TL sedans made by Honda. Honda owns about 8 percent of XM, Mr. Boyd said. General Motors has installed XM equipment in more than 500,000 vehicles since it was first put in Cadillacs in the 2002 model year, said Chance Patterson, an XM spokesman. G.M. owns a 15 percent stake in XM, he said. Shares of XM Satellite Radio rose $1.52, or 10 percent, to $16.10.   (Bloomberg News)

title: California Governor's Race Loses Another Major Name
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, dropped out of the race for governor of California today, diminishing the crowded field by one of its brand-name candidates but doing little to clarify the outcome of the Oct. 7 recall election.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Stocks Surge
description: The Nikkei 225 stock average hit a 14-month high, helped by a recommendation from Morgan Stanley that investors buy more shares. The benchmark index surged 2.2 percent to close at 10,922 as shares in NTT DoCoMo jumped 2.5 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Hero For Today: He's Super Techie!
description: With his white pocked forehead, sticky hair and delicate features, Christopher Gorham, the star of the new UPN series ''Jake 2.0,'' may be the actor that television needs most right now: a persuasively awkward tech-support geek who can become, as if by a trick of the light, an equally persuasive action hero.

title: BERLIN: SEX AND OPERA
description: How does an opera house attract young audiences? In the case of the Komische Oper in Berlin, history provides an answer: with sex. The house will open its 2003-4 season on Friday with an operetta and a singles party. During intermission at ''The Gypsy Princess'' by Emmerich Kalman, operagoers can post flirtatious messages to the objects of their desire. The performance will be followed by a dating party in the lounge. In the early 20th century, when the Komische Opera was the Metropol Theater, it was both Berlin's leading house for operetta and a forum for the flirtatious that attracted visitors from all over Germany. Prostitutes seeking customers had only to pay half price for admission at intermission. Kevin Clarke, a spokesman for the Komische Oper and an organizer of Friday's festivities, said, ''We won't issue reduced tickets to prostitutes this time but will definitely provide our guests with a very erotic atmosphere.'' KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: MR. REDFORD GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: Robert Redford had a message for members of Congress yesterday: Give arts financing the priority it deserves. Delivering the annual Nancy Hanks Lecture on Arts and Public Policy to an audience of lawmakers at the Kennedy Center, Mr. Redford said: ''Government support for the arts is not the frivolous giveaway that some would have you believe.'' He added, ''It's a good investment, and it is sound economic development.'' Mr. Redford, who received the 1996 National Medal of Arts, said nonprofit arts were a $134-billion-a-year industry, employing millions and generating nearly $81 billion in spending and $24 billion in state, local and federal taxes. But, he declared, not only are state legislatures cutting arts programs, but the Bush administration has also recommended ''virtually no increase'' in federal arts grants and termination of financing of the arts-in-education program. While Americans cherish freedom, ''to be able to be part of a freedom of expression that allows us to tell stories of our choice in the uniqueness of our own voices as citizens and as artists is not to be taken lightly,'' Mr. Redford said, adding, ''To be able to freely voice dissent in our hearts or in our arts is something to protect at all costs.'' ELIZABETH OLSON

title: $400 Bottle's Too High? Try Its $18 Cousin
description: WINEMAKERS have reacted in a variety of ways to the continuing economic downturn. Some have simply ignored it. The 2000 vintage Bordeaux, which sold at record prices, are gone with the exception of a few leftovers, like Cheval Blanc at $800 a bottle or Leoville-Barton at $235. Cult cabernets from the Napa Valley still command $200, even $300 a bottle and $100 a bottle, once a shocking excess, is now commonplace. Restaurants, the top ones anyway, roll blithely on, their wine lists seemingly recession-proof. Just the other day, in a moderately expensive place in New York, I discovered a Corton-Charlemagne at $1,300. A good fish wine.

description: Merck & Company has formed an alliance with a small biotechnology company to develop drugs using a widely watched new technology aimed at precisely shutting off genes involved in disease.

description: The 17-year-old driver of a car that crashed into a school bus full of campers last month died of his injuries yesterday, the Nassau County police said.
