description: Edward Teller, who was present at the creation of the first nuclear weapons and who grew even more famous for defending them, died yesterday at his home on the Stanford University campus in Palo Alto, Calif., according to the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, which Dr. Teller once headed. He was 95.

title: National Briefing | Health And Science: Grant To Fight Dengue
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said it would spend $55 million over the next six years to help accelerate the development of a vaccine to prevent dengue and dengue hemorrhagic fever, which are increasing globally. Over the last three decades, the number of countries reporting cases of dengue has more than quadrupled. The grant will help underwrite clinical trials of vaccines in Asia and South America, where the fever is most virulent. The foundation estimates that a vaccine would eliminate more than half a million hospitalizations and 3,000 deaths each year. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Saturday about the credit rating of the NEC Corporation misstated the action taken by Standard & Poor's. It set an initial rating of BBB-; it did not downgrade the rating.

title: Finding The Face Of Terror In Data
description: The amount of data available to the federal government far exceeds the human capacity to analyze it. This has long been the case, but since 9/11 the need for better tools to help America fight the war against terror has become more urgent. Unfortunately, the Senate appears set to cancel financing for a promising and innovative set of technology programs that would help make America safe.

title: 4 Found Dead Inside a Home In Queens
description: Four people were found fatally stabbed last night in their house in Queens, including a woman in her 80's known for the treats she gave neighborhood children, as well as her 21-year-old granddaughter and two male relatives, the authorities said.

title: Wake Forest Evolving Into an A.C.C. Power
description: Each fall, the movie ''Brian's Song'' is screened on the main quad at Wake Forest. It is the story of Brian Piccolo, who played alongside Gale Sayers in the Chicago Bears' backfield in the 1960's before dying of cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAINES, ALEXANDER
description: HAINES -- Alexander died peacefully on September 8, 2003. Born in London on July 11, 1914, Alec served with honor in the RAF in Africa and Italy during WWII, and emigrated to New York in 1946. A past secretary of the Designer's Club in New York's garment district, Alec was also an active member and past Trustee of the Riverdale Temple, and past Vice President of the Temple's Men's Club. Alec, beloved partner of Theodora ''Doris'' Yuden and pre-deceased by beloved wife Catherine ''Kitty'' Haines, is survived by his brother Mark, as well as by seven nephews, three nieces, three grand step-children, three great-grand step-children, and numerous grand nieces and nephews. Services Thursday 9 am at Riverdale Temple, West 246th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, New York.

title: Showdown in Cancn
description: The world's attention should be focused on the World Trade Organization's meeting at Cancn this week for reasons having nothing to do with the anti-globalization protests. The protesters will be trying to be as colorful and disruptive as they were when the W.T.O. met in Seattle in 1999, but their role is marginal. The real drama involves the delegates from 146 nations. They are bound to be speaking in eye-glazing bureaucratic Esperanto, but they will be engaged in crucial negotiations aimed at making life fairer for poor countries' farmers, who are struggling haplessly against a rigged global trading system.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Basques To Challenge Party Ban
description: The Basque regional government said it would challenge in the European Court of Human Rights a year-old Spanish law that banned the radical party Batasuna. A Basque government spokesman said the law violated the right to freedom of association. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Cautious Optimism on Leetch
description: Four days before the Rangers begin training camp, their best defenseman, Brian Leetch, cannot skate because of a bruised left ankle.

In lieu of flowers donations in his memory preferred to the National Audubon Society, 700 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

description: Senior Pentagon officials told Congress today that American forces were straining in many cases to meet President Bush's security and reconstruction missions in Iraq. Their comments came as the Army announced that the tours of 20,000 Army Reserve and National Guard troops in Iraq and Kuwait would be extended to as long as a year, months longer than many reservists had expected.

Services Thursday, 11AM at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Rd., Trenton, N.J. Period of mourning will be observed at the residence.

title: Keepin' the Nation Strong, the Gals Quiet
description: Toby Keith's country-music persona surrounds him like welded steel: a beefy, rakish farm boy who lives by intuitive certainties. And in his remarkably well written songs, which have improved as he gets deeper into his 40's, he keeps introducing himself by telling you what he likes and what he dislikes.

description: Lawyers for WorldCom said yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement with some creditors that would resolve some of the strongest objections to its plan for emerging from bankruptcy.

description: President Bush sandwiched a speedy promotion of his education policies today in between two Florida fund-raisers that reaped $3 million for his re-election campaign, bringing his harvest to more than $60 million.

description: Assemblyman Steve Levy swept the Democratic primary for Suffolk County executive yesterday, trouncing his challenger, William J. Cunningham III, according to unofficial returns.

title: James J. Crisona, 96, Lawyer, Legislator and New York Judge
description: James J. Crisona, a Democrat who served successively in New York State's Assembly and Senate, as borough president of Queens and as a justice of the New York State Supreme Court, died on Thursday at the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Despite U.S. Hopes, Japan Continues to Weaken the Yen
description: On Monday the Japanese government intervened in the foreign exchange market to weaken the value of the yen. That was the second intervention of the month, after an August without any intervention at all.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Birthday Parade
description: Parading through Kim Il Sung Square in Pyongyang, soldiers goose-stepped, civilians waved flags, and children unleashed balloons. High on a reviewing stand, ''Dear Leader'' saluted smartly. But there were no missiles. North Korea's 55th birthday came and went without a peek at a new missile reportedly capable of hitting Guam. Tanks were not even on display. To make up for fearsome hardware, Kim Yong Chun, army chief of staff, unleashed fearsome bombast. Soldiers should fight ''as human bombs and bullets, devotedly defending the leader,'' he said as Kim Jong Il, the country's leader, stood impassively by his side. Reportedly self-conscious about his poor public speaking skills, Mr. Kim did not address the 10,000 marchers. The most prominent visitor on the reviewing stand was from Russia, a special envoy of President Vladimir V. Putin. China sent a little-known bureaucrat. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Legislator Appears Winner in Democratic Race for Suffolk County Executive; Victory Claim in Bridgeport
description: In primaries for the first mayoral election in Bridgeport, Conn., since former Mayor Joseph P. Ganim was convicted on federal corruption charges last spring, the incumbent mayor, John M. Fabrizi, declared victory late last night, in the Democratic primary before an official tally was reached.

title: Washington Talk; Seeking the Words That Will Win Back the House
description: In politics, winning depends not so much on what you say as how you say it.

title: Iranian's 6-Year Journey to Celebrate Democracy
description: Some people are born with a patriotic fervor for America. Others come to love the country despite its faults.

title: A Broadway Baby Without a Minute to Spare
description: Gestation, gestation, gestation: there's a newborn in her arms, a 2-year-old entwined around one shin and a play series ripe for a Broadway debut. If Tina Fallon's life has a manic theme, gestation is it. For the children, it took the regulation nine months. For the plays, 24 hours, tops. The quickie concept is her baby. Her other baby. Next week she brings both to Broadway; she will, she jokes, be the only producer performing an emergency breast-feeding backstage as The 24 Hour Company cavorts up front.

description: Flames swept through the older half of a 400-family synagogue here this morning in what officials said was most likely an electrical fire near a caretaker's apartment on the third floor.

description: The French advertising holding company Publicis Groupe said first-half profit rose 18 percent after the purchase of the Bcom3 Group. Net income rose to 65 million euros ($72.7 million) from 55 million euros a year earlier.

description: In the intensifying debate over whether companies should split the jobs of chairman and chief executive, Canada's big banks are parting company with their American counterparts.

description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is to go to Geneva this weekend to discuss the American resolution to broaden international involvement in Iraq with Security Council members. Three of them announced today their own proposals to accelerate the transfer of civil authority to Iraqis.

title: EMPLOYEES PAYING EVER-BIGGER SHARE FOR HEALTH CARE
description: People in employer-sponsored health plans are paying 48 percent more out of their own pockets for care than they did three years ago, according to an authoritative new study, and the cost will be even higher next year.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular Fined $12.1 Million By Regulator
description: Cingular Wireless has been fined $12.1 million by California's utility regulator after it ruled that the company had provided inadequate service and violated state law. From January 2000 to May 2002, Cingular did not allow new users a grace period to cancel service without paying contract-termination fees as high as $550, the state agency, the California Public Utilities Commission, said in a decision posted on its Web site yesterday. The company also did not tell users about problems with its wireless network in 2001, the decision said. A spokesman for Cingular, a joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth based in Atlanta, did not immediately respond to a call for comment. Earlier yesterday, Cingular and 22 other United States cellular companies adopted voluntary customer rights standards, trying to derail tougher rules proposed by the California commission. The commission also ordered Cingular to reimburse customers who paid the contract-termination fee during the period.

title: Torre Hopes a One-Game Pause Will Refresh Giambi
description: Despite going 2 for 3 in Monday's victory over Toronto, Jason Giambi was kept out of the Yankees' lineup against the Detroit Tigers last night.

title: Bucs Add Some Beef To Offense
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers' defense is out of this world. The Buccaneers' offense is more earthly. So how do the Bucs, in their attempt to repeat as Super Bowl champions, elevate their offense to another galaxy?

title: F.D.A. PANEL SUPPORTS TREATMENT FOR PSORIASIS
description: Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company, and its partner Xoma Ltd. moved closer to federal approval of their Raptiva drug for the skin disorder psoriasis by winning the backing of a government advisory panel yesterday. The Food and Drug Administration committee voted 11 to 0 that Raptiva's benefits outweigh its risks for treating psoriasis, a skin condition. The agency often accepts the recommendations of its advisers. Raptiva would be Xoma's first product and could eventually generate sales of $500 million a year, analysts said. Xoma is based in Berkeley, Calif., and Genentech is based in South San Francisco, Calif.

title: Those Beggars And Thieves Are on the Loose
description: Those who associate ''The Threepenny Opera'' with crowd scenes and sprawling urban decay may think they have wandered into the wrong place when they enter the Bouwerie Lane Theater, where the Jean Cocteau Repertory is staging that Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill musical. The space looks impossibly small; the saga of the clash between Macheath, the ladies' man, and Peachum, the king of the beggars, seems destined to spill into the audience and out the fire exit.

title: Argentina Defaults on $3 Billion I.M.F. Debt
description: Defiantly refusing to make concessions to seal a three-year aid package from the International Monetary Fund, Argentina today defaulted on a $3 billion loan payment to the fund rather than dipping into its scant foreign reserves to pay the debt.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Air Alliance Rejected
description: Regulators in Australia rejected a proposed air alliance that would have allowed Qantas to acquire a 22 percent stake in Air New Zealand for $300 million. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, a business watchdog agency, said the terms of the Qantas bid, revised after an earlier rejection, were still highly anticompetitive and likely to raise fares and cut services on routes between the countries. New Zealand regulators are expected to rule on the alliance proposal next month. If they approve, Qantas has the option to appeal the Australian decision. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Deliverance From the Cob
description: CORN is probably best in its natural form, cooked as simply as possible. But late summer is a good season to play with corn -- the time just may have come when we have finally had our fill of it on the cob.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Capital Punishment Change
description: Firing squads will give way to lethal injection for defendants sentenced to death. ''Lethal injection allows the condemned to die with no pain or suffering,'' said an official of the Corrections Department. There are about 950 prisoners on death row in Thailand, most for drug offenses. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Physicist for Nuclear Age
description: Few, if any, physicists of this century have generated such heated debate as Edward Teller. Much of it centered on his decade-long effort to produce the hydrogen bomb, his ardent promotion of nuclear weapons in general, his deep suspicion of Soviet intentions and his opposition to curtailment of nuclear testing.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Carlstadt: Adding Express E-ZPass Lanes
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will begin work today on new E-ZPass express lanes at the Exit 18W toll plaza in northern New Jersey, which will enable drivers with the electronic passes to cruise through the toll plaza at 55 miles per hour. Drivers with E-ZPass now have to slow down to about 15 m.p.h. for their electronic passes to be read. The $5.4 million project will be completed in January, when the exit will become the second one, after Exit 6 onto the Pennsylvania Turnpike, to feature the express lanes, said Joseph Orlando, a spokesman for the highway agency. During construction, three of the toll plaza lanes at Exit 18W in each direction will be closed. Express lanes will be installed in the near future on the Garden State Parkway, at the Hillsdale, Raritan South, Asbury Park and the Toms River toll plazas. Mr. Orlando said the current schedule of express lane construction was focused on plazas where 50 percent to 70 percent of drivers use E-ZPass during peak hours. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: U.N. Council Postpones Vote on Libya Penalties
description: As the survivors of the victims of Pan Am 103 fumed quietly in the Security Council gallery, the Council today postponed a vote on the end of Libyan sanctions rather than risk a promised French veto.

title: Leni Riefenstahl, 101, Dies; Film Innovator Tied to Hitler
description: Leni Riefenstahl, the German filmmaker whose daringly innovative documentaries about a Nazi rally in Nuremberg in 1934 and the Berlin Olympics of 1936 earned her both acclaim as a cinematic genius and contempt as a propagandist for Hitler, died on Monday night at her home in Pcking, south of Munich. She was 101.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SLOVAKIA: POPE'S VISIT TO BEGIN Pope John Paul II is to start his last scheduled trip of the year tomorrow, a four-day visit to Slovakia. Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to turn out for the four open-air Masses he is to offer during his swing around the mainly Catholic country.    (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, SAUL
description: GOODMAN--Saul. Born April 20, 1919, died September 8, 2003. Beloved uncle of Sandra G. Ortner, I. Michael Goodman and Michael Steig. Dance author and lecturer. Feature writer for ''Dance Magazine'' where he published 232 dancer biographies and 13 featured articles. Publications: ''Dancers You Should Know, Baryshnikov: A Most Spectacular Dancer''.

title: Whose Fault? The Blame Game
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fatherless Boy
description: To the Editor:

title: The AES Corporation Has Deal to Restructure Debt
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 9 - After nearly a year of political and financial brinkmanship, the AES Corporation has struck a deal with the Brazilian government to rework $1.2 billion of debt it incurred to buy Eletropaulo, the Sao Paulo utility, and build up a business that brings it more revenue than all its North American operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUNSHINE, BETTY
description: SUNSHINE--Betty. Died September 8, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Harry, mother of Roberta and Barry Sussman, and Joan and Al Weisinger. Grandmother of Linda Sussman, Susan Sussman, Bonnie Sussman, Ronni and Brian Siff, Marci and Paul Schneider, Julie and Scott Zelnick. Great-grandmother of Noah and Adam Siff, Brett, Joley and Ryan Schneider, Eliza and Mack Zelnick. Her physical beauty was only surpassed by her inner beauty. Forever in our hearts. Your Loving Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, DR. CRAIG
description: ROBERTS--Dr. Craig. We mourn the loss of and fondly remember our brother-inlaw, Dr. Craig Roberts. Beloved husband of our dear sister Flori. Devoted and caring father, grandfather and friend to so many. May his soul rest in peace. Mildred and Abby Levine and Family

title: S.E.C. INQUIRY ON RAYTHEON ACCOUNTING IS MADE FORMAL
description: The Raytheon Company, a manufacturer of military equipment and commercial aircraft, said the Securities and Exchange Commission has made formal its investigation of a unit that makes Beech Jet and King Air aircraft. The S.E.C., which began an informal inquiry in January, is reviewing accounting at the company's commuter aircraft business from 1997 to 2001. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., said it was cooperating with the agency. A formal order allows the agency to subpoena documents and compel testimony from witnesses at the company and third parties, like customers. Raytheon announced the investigation after the close of market trading. Its stock fell 14 cents, to $32.46 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bail Denied In Smuggling Case
description: A federal judge in Manhattan denied bail yesterday to Cheng Chui Ping, who federal officials say was the head of an international smuggling ring trafficking in people. The ring's operations included that aboard the steamer Golden Venture, which ran aground off Queens 10 years ago, leaving 10 hostages from China dead. A prosecutor argued before Judge Michael B. Mukasey of Federal District Court that Ms. Cheng was a major flight risk because of her access to vast financial resources and fake travel documents. When Hong Kong officials arrested her in April 2000, they found her with $31,000 in cash, three Belize passports with false names and a phone list of contacts in 16 countries. Ms. Cheng was charged in June with conspiracy to smuggle illegal immigrants, hostage taking, and money laundering, among other things, in a seven-count indictment. If convicted, she faces life in prison. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Judge's Ruling Opens Door For More Families to Sue Airlines and Port Authority
description: The federal judge handling the litigation over the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks opened the courtroom door yesterday for the families of the thousands of people killed or injured in the attacks.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Drilling Down'' chart in Business Day on Monday, devoted this week to the swapping of music over the Internet, mislabeled the scale showing the number of files copied or acquired from March through June. The figures were in the hundreds of millions, not billions.

title: Jets Need Defense to Hold the Line Against Miami
description: It has been almost a year since the Jets' defense reached its nadir, a Groundhog Day-like cycle of missed tackles, blown assignments and so much confusion you might have thought the entire unit had sustained a concussion.

title: Color Me Orange (And Purple, Red, etc.)
description: Like just about everything else in the Greenmarket these days, carrots have gone rainbow. At Windfall Farms, they come in purple, yellow, white and red in addition to orange. Small carrots are sold in mixtures by the box, usually for around $3. Bigger carrots are $2 to $3 a pound. Alex Paffenroth, left, of Paffenroth Gardens has carrots in assorted colors and sizes for $1.50 a bunch. Both farms, at Union Square on Wednesdays and Saturdays, will have the carrots through the fall. For a cold carrot soup, for example, make two batches of different colors, and gently swirl them together in their bowls. To make soup, boil carrots, peeled and in chunks, in salted water, pure in a blender, season with ground cumin, salt and pepper and a little lemon, then chill. Adjust the texture with more water, if it is needed.

title: Iraqi Takes Seat at Arab League
description: The foreign minister of the Iraqi Governing Council assumed Iraq's seat at a meeting of the Arab League today, pledging a new Iraq that respects human rights and democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKENNAN, DAVE
description: McKENNAN--Dave. A gentle, humorous, capable, intelligent man who brought out the best in all whose paths crossed his. His life with Betsy was magical. We will miss him. Alvin & Eleanor Donnenfeld

title: More Troops Will Destabilize Iraq, Says Rumsfeld
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that increasing the number of American troops beyond the 130,000 there now would only destabilize the country further, saying in his starkest statement yet that Iraqis were responsible for their own future.

title: Warren Kremer, 82, Who Drew Richie Rich
description: Warren Kremer, a cartoonist whose lush, rounded brush style defined the appearance of comic-book characters from Richie Rich to Casper the Friendly Ghost, died on July 24 in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 82 and lived in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Italy Loses Ruling on Modified Food
description: In a judgment that appeared to offer ammunition to both sides in the debate on genetically modified foods, the European Court of Justice ruled today that Italy's grounds for banning foods derived from certain genetically altered corn seeds were unjustified.

title: Cultural Center in Brooklyn Will Bear Name of Slain Councilman
description: A new center for arts, media and cultural groups associated with the Brooklyn Academy of Music will be named after the slain Councilman James E. Davis, officials responsible for the project said yesterday.

title: Grasso Giving Up $48 Million in Benefits
description: Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that he would give up $48 million in compensation that he was owed by the exchange.

title: A New Bid to Get Off New Jersey's Death Row
description: During the 17 years since Robert O. Marshall was condemned to New Jersey's death row for arranging his wife's murder, there has been no shortage of public information about the case that landed him there.

title: House Blocks Treasury Work On Pensions
description: The House of Representatives voted decisively last night to block the Treasury's work on pension regulations, citing concerns that the rules might be used by companies intent on changing their pension plans in ways that would strip older workers of benefits.

title: Whose Fault? The Blame Game
description: To the Editor:

title: A Long Wait on Fame's Doorstep
description: Kevin Whelan is 33, and he worked as a temp for so long that he defied the term. But in every temp-filled cubicle there lives a dream -- about a novel to write, a symphony to compose, a scale model of the Empire State Building to build out of soup cans -- and Mr. Whelan had one, too. He wanted to be a rock star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINGER, RITA
description: SINGER--Rita. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Rita Singer, beloved wife of the late Edwin M. Singer. Rita was a valued and dedicated member of ADL's Women's Division. We extend our sincere condolences to her entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: No Child Left Behind Law Leaves No Room for Some
description: BOYS and girls, I apologize for not having enough chairs,'' said Brent Wyso, the sixth-grade math teacher at Intermediate School 89. ''We will be getting more chairs.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Business Confidence Rises
description: Italian business confidence rose to the highest level in almost a year last month, a sign the country's economy may be emerging from a mild recession. A survey of 4,000 executives carried out during the first two weeks of August showed the index of business confidence rose to 95.3, the highest level since September 2002. Italy's economy, the fourth-largest in Europe, shrank 0.1 percent in the first and second quarters of the year. Analysts are expecting the economy to grow 0.4 percent this year, half what the Italian government has forecast. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the radio host Jonathan Schwartz misspelled the given name of a singer about whom he was asked, before declining to confirm a guess about the secret voice on the theme music of his show. She is Astrud Gilberto, not Astrid.

description: Adapted from Mix in New York

Beloved husband of Toni; devoted father to Ira and Harold; loving grandfather to Amy, Tracy, Jodie and Adam, and doting uncle and granduncle. Memorial service 11:15am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, on Wednesday, September 10. Contributions may be sent to United Jewish Federation of NY, 130 E. 59 St, Suite 457, NY, NY, 10022.

title: Nokia Says It Expects Flat Sales Of Handsets
description: Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, left investors unimpressed today with a forecast that its third-quarter profit would come in at the high end of its expectations, but that it would earn less on its handset sales.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BEDDARD, ANITA P.
description: BEDDARD--Anita P. We miss you so because we love you so. You are in our hearts, minds and souls every day and always. Michael, Fred and Devon

title: Paying the Bills for Iraq
description: With American military casualties rising and Iraqis restive over shortages of electricity, water and most other things, Congress is inclined to give President Bush the full $87 billion he wants for Iraq and Afghanistan next year. But sticker shock is just starting to set in -- not to mention an awareness of potential costs the president neglected to bring up. Members of Congress are right to ask hard questions about how these huge bills will be paid, whether yielding some authority over Iraq may induce other countries to share the burdens and just how much a prolonged occupation will damage the military.

title: Jesus Statue Found Outside Midtown Church
description: Astatue of Jesus that was stolen from the Church of the Holy Cross at 329 West 42nd Street in Midtown Manhattan was found at 6 a.m. yesterday in the alley next to the church, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Salamanca: Vote On Indian Casino
description: The 4,000 eligible voters of the Seneca Indian Nation of New York conducted a referendum yesterday on a proposal to open the tribe's third gambling casino, this one on its Allegany Reservation in western New York. Under a compact with the state, the tribe is authorized to operate three casinos in western New York. The first opened on Jan. 1, and a second is planned for the Buffalo suburbs. Tribal leaders said the referendum was intended to measure the tribes' response to its gambling operations. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A calendar entry in the Long Island section on Sunday for the Herb Fest sponsored by the Herb Society of America misstated the day. It is this Saturday at 11 a.m. at the Smithtown Historical Society, on Route 25; it was not last Sunday. Information: (631) 666-3647.

title: Smoking Tied to Pneumonia Cases in War Zones
description: A puzzling cluster of pneumonia cases among American troops in Iraq and other countries in the war region seems to be partly related to the fact that many had taken up smoking shortly before they became ill, Pentagon officials said yesterday.

description: The spaces and forms and details of the scar that was once the World Trade Center still have the capacity to engage the fresh eye.

description: On a recent Sunday morning, a series of visitors took turns to gaze through the rift at construction activity at the World Trade center site.

description: Romare Bearden is the first African-American artist featured in a solo retrospective in the 62-year history of the National Gallery of Art.

title: Deal Clears Way for U.N. to Lift Libya Sanctions
description: Libya agreed today to increase compensation to the families of the victims of a terrorist attack on a French airliner in 1989, clearing the way for passage of a resolution at the United Nations to lift sanctions on Libya.

description: VIEWERS of ''The New This Old House Hour'' are going to be watching the world through rose-colored safety goggles, if the premiere is any indication.

title: Troubled HealthSouth Faces Medicare Fraud Investigation
description: Federal law enforcement officials are investigating possible Medicare fraud at HealthSouth, the troubled chain of rehabilitation and surgery centers, after a Texas jury awarded $1.5 million in damages to the former medical director of a Houston hospital, officials said yesterday.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 288 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

description: In this tormented city, responding to terror attacks has become a grim medical specialty, and Dr. David Applebaum was known as ''the first man on the scene.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia:Tobacco Profit Falls
description: The second-largest cigarette maker of Indonesia, Hanjaya Mandal Sampoerna, said net profit in the first half of the year fell 10 percent, with to 796.2 billion rupiah ($94 million) compared with the period a year earlier, as higher excise taxes raised prices and hurt sales. Profits were also hurt by the sale of a stake in one of the retailing units of Hanjaya Mandal Sampoerna last year. Hanjaya Manda Sampoerna is a leading maker of Indonesia's trademark clove-flavored cigarettes. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: Just before the interview starts, Denzel Washington flashes something, exposing it just enough to draw a reaction, then putting it away.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MCGOVERN, SCOTT
description: McGOVERN--Scott. My dear Scott, two years may have passed but we are as close to you as ever. You are in our home and in our hearts. Each and every day, the girls and I find a moment to think of Daddy and smile. You would be so proud of your precious jewels as we will always be proud of you. We miss you with all our hearts. See you in our dreams. Love, Jill, Alana and Nicole

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LASKY, SOLOMON
description: LASKY--Solomon. Of Fresh Meadows, NY, passed away peacefully at 94 years of age on September 10, 2003 with his family by his side. Loving and devoted husband to Ruth for 60 years, wonderful father to Diane and husband Joel Kushins, Malla Pollack, and Gail and husband Mark Posner, loving and kind grandfather to Lisa Ryder and Michelle Goldstein, Leah and Rachel Posner, and greatgrandfather to Ethan Ryder. He was a founder of the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center and officer for over 40 years. Services are to be held Thursday 1:30PM at Mount Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Blvd., Flushing NY.

title: H&R BLOCK TO OFFER TAX SERVICE IN WAL-MART STORES
description: H&R Block plans to sell its services in as many as 850 Wal-Mart stores during next year's tax season, the companies said yesterday. The agreement with Wal-Mart Stores may be signed this week to permit H&R Block to install outlets by Jan. 15, an H&R Block spokesman, Bob Schneider, said. It will increase H&R Block's 9,300 sites as much as 9 percent in the United States.

title: At Central Park's Coronation, 11,000 Chips-in-Waiting
description: In a display of computerized pyrotechnics, exploding fireworks shells will form a 1,000-foot-high vertical circle of light over the Central Park reservoir on Monday. The white-hot halo is the centerpiece of ''Light Cycle,'' a three-part, four-minute fireworks exhibition marking the park's 150th anniversary. The display is scheduled to start at 7:45 p.m.

title: White House Backs Most Items in Emerging Energy Package
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  The Bush administration today endorsed the bulk of the provisions being considered by House and Senate negotiators as part of a new energy policy and renewed its call to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Tuesday about the popularity of quirky fall designs misstated the given name of the designer of a jacket embellished at the rear with a billowing panel of lace-covered silk. (An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about the restaurant 66, where patrons are wearing the designer's clothes, included the same error.) He is Olivier Theyskens, not Oliver.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TOPPS CO., New York, a maker of cards and bubble gum, said it planned to acquire some assets of the Foreign Candy Company, Hull, Iowa.

title: Design Dispatch; In an African City, All Roads Lead to Rome
description: THERE is a joke about an Asmarino, as the proud residents of this African capital call themselves, who visits Italy and is surprised at how much the architecture there mimics the buildings back home.

title: An American Life in Mixed Media; Bearden Is Honored With a National Gallery Retrospective
description: Romare Bearden was born in segregated Charlotte, N.C., in 1911 and lived through both the Harlem Renaissance and the modern civil rights movement, creating collages of black life so stunning that he earned a reputation as a major 20th-century American artist.

title: Huge Union Decides to Endorse No One Now
description: Torn between the longtime favorite and two fresh faces, the largest union in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided today not to endorse any of the nine Democratic hopefuls for the presidency for now.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: An Interest Rate Cut
description: The central bank of South Africa reduced its benchmark lending rate by one percentage point, after a surge in the value of the currency pushed manufacturing into a recession and the economy slid to its slowest growth rate in nearly five years. The cut follows a 1.5 percentage-point reduction in June, and a 1 percentage-point cut in August.

title: De La Hoya and Mosley at a Crossroads
description: Oscar De La Hoya says he will retire if he loses to Shane Mosley on Saturday night. But De La Hoya does not plan on retiring, or losing, anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MATTHEWS, JUDY
description: MATTHEWS--Judy. A renaissance woman. We think of you always. We love you everyday. Love, Steve, Howard, Sandy, Dave and Juliette

title: Some House Democrats Fault Dean on Mideast
description: Criticism of Howard Dean for his assertion that the United States should not take sides in the Middle East conflict moved beyond presidential debating today when a group of Democratic House members rebuked him in a letter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   THOMPSON, NIGEL BRUCE
description: THOMPSON -- Nigel Bruce. ''And, when he shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine that all the world will be in love with night, And pay no worship to the garish sun.'' Always, Rosana

title: Swedish Foreign Minister Wounded in Knife Attack While Shopping
description: An unidentified assailant stabbed Foreign Minister Anna Lindh as she shopped in a department store here today in an attack that stunned many Swedes and rekindled memories of the killing of Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Msgr. Robert P. Hupp, who led Boys Town during a period of change, including the admission of girls, misspelled the name of the Wisconsin city where he died. It is Mauston, not Mausten.

title: National Parks, Under a New Umbrella
description: Hoping to entice more visitors to its New York area sites, the National Park Service is placing Jamaica Bay and 21 other scattered outposts under the umbrella of a single and more catchy sounding entity called the National Parks of New York Harbor. The new entity plans to arrange ferry links among the sites and have a single visitors' center at Federal Hall in Lower Manhattan to steer tourists around the harbor.

title: A Day to Look Forward
description: For the second anniversary of Sept. 11, New York's leaders have planned a simpler ceremony than the one held a year ago, which marked the conclusion of 12 months of deep mourning. The less-elaborate event at ground zero in many ways suits the moment. It signals a city slowly beginning to mend, a community moving toward the hope that something worthy, even inspiring, will come of so much grief.

title: Violence in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Another 9/11, and the Nation Mourns Again
description: Two years after terrorists turned commercial jetliners into missiles bearing down on quintessential symbols of American wealth and power, the nation paused yesterday to remember the 3,016 fathers and mothers and friends who did not come home that day.

title: Hedge Fund Investigated
description: The attorneys general of Illinois and New York have opened an investigation into Samaritan Asset Management, a $200 million Chicago-area hedge fund that trades mutual funds, an Illinois state official said.

title: F.C.C. Adopts Rules On Digital TV Sets
description: Federal regulators took another step in the transition to digital television, adopting rules to allow consumers to plug their cable-system line directly into a digital TV set without the need for a set-top box.

title: Market Place; A Summer Uptick For the Airlines, But Then What?
description: Airline stocks jumped yesterday, continuing a rally in which some shares have doubled or even tripled in value this year. The latest gains were driven by analyst forecasts of even better days ahead.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: ARMY LINKED TO ENVIRONMENTAL VIOLATIONS The Alabama Department of Environmental Management has cited the Army for violations of its permit to burn chemical weapons at the Anniston Army Depot. The department said the violations were not serious. It said they included improperly marked pipe flanges and high liquid levels in a drainage pump. Michael B. Abrams, a spokesman for the depot, said the problems were being addressed. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, RUTH TAFT
description: HAMILTON--Ruth Taft. Of Needham, MA., formerly of Tenafly, N.J. Died peacefully September 9, 2003. She is survived by her daughter Betsey Taft Colby of Wayland, MA., her son Ned Taft of Wellesley, MA., five grandchildren, two stepchildren and five step grandchildren all of whom loved her dearly. A family celebration of her life will be held later. Donations may be sent to North Hill Employee Recognition Fund, 865 Central Ave, Needham, MA. 02492.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SERBIA: FORMER FOES EXCHANGE APOLOGIES The presidents of Croatia and Serbia apologized for their citizens' actions against each other during the 1990's war between the countries. In the first state visit to Belgrade by a Croatian head of state, President Stjepan Mesic, above right, strode across a red carpet and shook the hand of Svetozar Marovic, left, the president of Serbia and Montenegro, the union that is the remnant of Yugoslavia. "I want to apologize for all evils that any citizen of Serbia and Montenegro inflicted upon or committed to anybody in Croatia," Mr. Marovic said. Mr. Mesic quickly responded. "I, for my part, apologize to all those to whom any citizen of Croatia caused pain or damage," he said. The war left 20,000 dead. (AP)

title: Merrill Media Team Moves to First Boston
description: All three of Merrill Lynch's senior media bankers defected to Credit Suisse First Boston yesterday, according to executives close to the firms.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas prices rose on increasing demand from utilities and factory operators for winter supplies. In New York, natural gas for October delivery rose 23.8 cents, or 5 percent, to $4.968 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Former Enron Treasurer Enters Guilty Plea
description: A former Enron treasurer pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to commit fraud, providing the first public admission by a former executive that certain transactions at the heart of the scandal that crippled the company were used to manipulate its financial statements.

title: Two Years Later, a Thousand Years Ago
description: Among the ideas that seemed to collapse along with the twin towers two years ago was a view of globalization as a kind of manifest destiny. Unlike the 19th-century version of manifest destiny, this vision didn't involve expanding America's borders. Rather, America's values -- notably economic and political liberty -- would spread beyond those borders, covering the planet. And this time around America's mission didn't have the widely assumed blessing of God. But it had the next best thing: the force of history. Globalization was seen by some as a nearly inevitable climax of the human story -- destiny of a secular sort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAYRE, HARRIET HART
description: SAYRE--Harriet Hart, died September 6, 2003 of cancer. She was the wife of the retired Dean of the Washington National Cathedral, Rev. Francis B. Sayre. Funeral and interment will be 2:00 pm Saturday, Sept 13 in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington National Cathedral. A Memorial Service will be held October 4, at Grace Church, Vineyard Haven, on Martha's Vineyard. Gifts in lieu of flowers may be made to Martha's Vineyard Community Services, c/o Jan Hatchard, Director of Development, 111 Edgartown Rd, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568.

title: Dolphins Won't Consider Possibility of an 0-2 Start
description: In the depths of the Miami Dolphins' bewilderment after their stunning loss to the Houston Texans on Sunday, middle linebacker Zach Thomas said he saw what he thought could be a silver lining.

title: Indonesia Sentences Defiant Islamic Militant to Death for the Bali Nightclub Bombing
description: An Indonesian court sentenced a defiant Islamic militant to death today after convicting him of playing a major role in the Bali nightclub attack that killed 202 people last year.

title: For Some, the First Notes Are Sung at Zankel Hall
description: Zankel Hall, which opens to the public tomorrow night, had a press preview concert yesterday at noon. As usual with such events, critics, performing arts administrators and other insiders were invited.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Baltimore Mayor Wins Primary
description: Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore scored a wide victory on Tuesday in the city's Democratic primary. With all precincts reporting, Mr. O'Malley, 40, defeated Andrey Bundley, a high school principal, by about two to one. Mr. O'Malley is considered likely to be elected to a second term because the winner of the Democratic mayoral primary nearly always wins the general election. The general election for mayor will not take place until November 2004. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: House Panel Wary on Plan For Shuttle
description: Lawmakers expressed concern today that NASA was rushing to resume space shuttle flights before fully carrying out the recommendations of the panel that investigated the Columbia disaster.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I used to feel like, 'Hey, I'm going somewhere, it's fun.' Travel is not such a frivolous activity anymore. It could result in your life.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SYNAGOGUE WINS REPRIEVE An Orthodox Jewish synagogue in the Flatiron district has won a reprieve from eviction and a legal victory over its umbrella movement, the National Council of Young Israel. On Tuesday, a ruling by a judge in State Supreme Court, Debra A. James, rejected the National Council's petition to sell its headquarters, which also houses the Young Israel of Fifth Avenue synagogue. The judge said the council's board of directors failed to follow the proper procedures in voting to sell the six-story building, at 3 West 16th Street, to a developer for $5.4 million. Rabbi Israel Wohlgelernter said, "Maybe they'll see the light, the light that Jewish law forbids selling a synagogue." In her ruling, the judge also rejected the synagogue's claim that it, too, was an owner of the building. A lawyer for the umbrella group said it had not decided whether to appeal or to hold another board meeting to approve the sale. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: WHITE HOUSE MEETING FOR DALAI LAMA The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, met at the White House with President Bush. The Dalai Lama said Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, with whom he met on Tuesday, had shown "genuine interest and sympathy" regarding his efforts to win some degree of autonomy from China for Tibet. Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush "reiterated our strong commitment to support the preservation of Tibet's unique religious, cultural and linguistic identity, and the protection of the human rights" of all Tibetans. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Getting More From a PC's Spare Time
description: SOME people talk, sometimes in jest, about leaving their brains to science. But others have found a more immediate way to help: lending their computers' brains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASCHENBRAND, SEYMOUR
description: ASCHENBRAND -- Seymour. Died peacefully on September 8, 2003. Beloved husband, devoted father, caring grandfather of seven. Services at graveside at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ on September 11, 2003 at 11:00 AM.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday about flat-rate telephone plans that allow customers to make unlimited local and long-distance calls reversed two labels on fees shown. The fee that helps cover the costs of allowing customers to keep the same number when they switch phone companies is the number portability charge. The fee that helps subsidize phone service in low-income and rural areas and in libraries and schools is the federal universal connectivity charge.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Russian Tycoon Receives Asylum
description: Boris A. Berezovsky, the Russian tycoon who once was close to the Kremlin and whom the authorities in Moscow have charged with fraud and sought to extradite, received political asylum in Britain, where he has been living for nearly two years, said an aide to Mr. Berezovsky and a senior British official. ''A letter came from the Home Office today,'' said the aide. ''He received asylum.'' Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Pope Struggles While Giving Speech in Slovakia
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, Sept. 11  Pope John Paul II arrived here today to urge Slovaks not to follow Western Europe's drift from Christianity, but he could not manage to deliver that message in his own voice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Liquor Executive Arrested
description: Prosecutors have arrested the former chairman of Jinro, the world's biggest liquor manufacturer, and the company's two top executives in an investigation into suspected misuse of 634 billion won ($544 million) intended to rescue the company before the 1997-98 economic crisis. Prosecutors say that the former chairman, Chang Jin Ho, diverted funds to four affiliates and to his personal use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIFKIN, BERNARD M.
description: RIFKIN--Bernard M. The Zionist Organization of America mourns the passing of an esteemed leader and colleague Bernard M. Rifkin. He was an ardent Zionist and served the cause of Israel and ZOA for six decades. We extend heartfelt condolences to his bereaved family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Morton A. Klein, Nat'l Pres. Alan A. Mazurek, Chairman of the Board

title: 3Com Will Cut 1,000 Jobs And Close Its Last Plant
description: The 3Com Corporation, the struggling maker of networking equipment, said yesterday that it planned to cut its work force by nearly a third and close its last manufacturing plant in an effort to cut costs and weather the prolonged slump in corporate technology spending.

title: SOUTHWEST SEEKS MEDIATION IN CONTRACT TALKS
description: Southwest Airlines has asked the National Mediation Board to help the company reach a contract with its flight attendants after 16 months of talks. Concluding an agreement with the Transport Workers Union Local 556, which represents the 7,200 attendants, no longer appears possible ''without outside assistance,'' the chief executive, James F. Parker, said in a statement. The airline, which is based in Dallas, said it expected a mediator to set a schedule and ground rules for future sessions. A spokeswoman for Southwest, Ginger Hardage, declined to comment on specifics of the talks. Thom McDaniel, president of the union local, said a crucial issue was pay for holidays and for time spent doing tasks like cleaning aircraft or waiting for flights.

title: Drug Panel Rejects Pleas to Curb Sales of a Widely Abused Painkiller
description: A federal drug advisory panel yesterday rejected pleas from members of Congress and drug enforcement officials that sales of the widely abused painkiller OxyContin be severely restricted.

title: This Solemn Day: To Mourn, Reflect and Heal; A Symbol of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Gehry Stakes a Claim in Scotland With a Wavy-Roofed 'Clubhouse'
description: Frank Gehry's first building in Britain is to open in Dundee, Scotland, on Sept. 25. Named Maggie's Center, for Maggie Keswick Jencks, who died of cancer in 1995, the 2,000-square-foot structure is ''a clubhouse for cancer patients,'' Mr. Gehry said. Made from concrete and timber, with a wavy stainless-steel roof, it has a 30-foot tower that Mr. Gehry called ''a lighthouse.'' The third of 13 planned Maggie's Centers in Britain, it will offer free supplemental care and counseling on a walk-in basis. The building's $1.6 million cost was raised by the Maggie's Center Trust, which includes among its founders Ms. Jencks's husband, the architecture critic Charles Jencks. ''The architecture has to be inspirational,'' he said. ''Patients have to feel welcome but have to take risks.'' Valerie Busher, one of the fund-raisers, said community response has been positive, partly because ''there is not another building like it in the world.'' MICHAEL KILLEEN

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Senate Blocks Bush Plan To Alter Overtime Eligibility

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: An Ivy Pest

title: For This Old Program, An All-Thumbs Host
description: IF ignorance is bliss, Kevin O'Connor is one happy man. Last year, he was a new homeowner who couldn't figure out how to strip his wallpaper. Next month he joins Norm Abram, Tom Silva and the rest of the ''This Old House'' team to become their improbable new host.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: PRESIDENT URGING WIDER U.S. POWERS IN TERRORISM LAW
description: President Bush called today for a significant expansion of law enforcement powers under the USA Patriot Act, using the eve of the second anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist acts to say that his administration was winning the war on terrorism but that ''unreasonable obstacles'' in the law impeded the pursuit of terror suspects.

title: Limpopo National Park Journal; Refuge for the Wild, With No Land Mines, Please
description: Wildlife specialists released seven elephants into this new game sanctuary the other day, and Santos Ngoverne, dressed in a blue plaid shirt and battered sandals, was on hand to watch.

title: Rumsfeld Says More G.I.'s Would Not Help U.S. in Iraq
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that increasing the number of American forces in Iraq would put them at greater risk, hurt reconstruction efforts and sidetrack the goal of having Iraqis take greater responsibility for their own security.

title: A World of Pattern to Spread on Your Floors
description: NEW carpet designs this season have been inspired by Moroccan embroideries, Navajo serapes and African-American quilts. The multicolored geometric designs of quilts by African-American women in rural Gee's Bend, Ala., have been reproduced by Classic Rug Collection as hand-knotted rugs made of wool and silk in Nepal, hand-tufted ones made of wool in the United States and flat-weave cotton rugs hand-woven in India. Royalties from the rug sales will help build a community center in Gee's Bend, as well as a museum there to house the quilts -- 60 of which were shown last year at the Whitney Museum of American Art. (From Sept. 27 to Jan. 4, they will be at the Milwaukee Art Museum, 414-224-3200.)

title: Ex-Mayor of Buffalo Wins Council-Seat Primary
description: Buffalo's longest-serving mayor moved a step closer on Tuesday to returning to the City Hall he dominated for 16 years, soundly defeating an incumbent city councilwoman in a Democratic Party primary.

title: Challenger In Queens Race Won't Concede To Councilman
description: Leaders of the Queens Democratic Party said yesterday that they considered the Democratic primary race between City Councilman Allan W. Jennings and their candidate, Yvonne Reddick, too close to call, despite unofficial results that showed that Mr. Jennings won by 106 votes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Slim Gain At Heineken
description: The brewer Heineken said it had earned 334 million euros ($375 million) in the first six months of this year, an increase of 1 percent excluding one-time items, as a strong euro and declining demand in the Northeastern United States cut into profits. The company forecast similarly slow growth for the rest of the year. The overall net profit of Heineken rose 21 percent, to 400 million euros, helped by a one-time gain of 71 million euros from the sale of its 15 percent stake in the Argentine brewing group Quilmes.

title: Steal This Music?
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including positions on the morality of downloading music and ruminations on happiness.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blackout Explained
description: National Grid Transco, the company that controls most of Britain's high-voltage power lines, said that the Aug. 28 blackout in London was caused by two faults in the system, one that occurred because the wrong-size fuse was installed on one of the four lines that carry power into the city. Two of the four lines were shut down for regular maintenance. A third line was shut just after 6 p.m., after an alarm went off. A fuse on the fourth line was one ampere, not the required five amperes. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Political Memo; Bush's Speech Offers Focus for Democrats' Attacks
description: In a classic case of unintended consequences, President Bush's major address to the nation on Iraq seems to have emboldened -- rather than muted -- his Democratic critics.

title: Furniture to Go With the Flow
description: MERRILY they roll along: beds, tables, even bookcases come equipped with wheels these days. Which means the rooms they inhabit can serve any purpose at any time.

title: Sports Briefing
description: SOCCER

title: REYNOLDS TOBACCO TO CUT DISCOUNTS TO DISTRIBUTORS
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings will eliminate some financial incentives it paid to distributors to bring its discounts into line with those offered by Philip Morris USA. The program, which gave wholesalers discounts based on the percentage of sales, will change on Sept. 29, a spokeswoman for Reynolds, Carole Crosslin, said. She declined to comment on specifics about the changes or savings. Philip Morris, a unit of the Altria Group, said last month that it would end its program, which was the subject of lawsuit asserting that the payments violated antitrust laws. R. J. Reynolds, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has appealed a ruling in a similar lawsuit that requires it to resume doing business with two wholesalers that sued the company.

title: Mideast Violence Threatens 'Quartet' Plan
description: With attacks by both Palestinians and Israeli forces continuing, President Bush appealed today, once again, for restraint on both sides. Yet, with each attack and counterattack, the Middle East peace plan championed by him is receding further from view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, LOUIS
description: LEVINE--Louis. Surrounded by his loving family, on September 9, 2003. Husband for 66 years of Janet Levine, father of Karen Feldgus (Robert) and Alan D. Levine (Sandra), grandfather of Gabriel Levine, Kyle Moreno (Luis) and Grady Feldgus. Services at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, today 1PM. Contributions to Princeton Hospice, 208 Bunn Dr, Princeton, NJ 08540

title: Bomb in Kurds' Area, Aimed at Americans, Kills Iraqi
description: A suicide bomber killed a young boy and wounded 50 people, most of them Iraqis, when his minivan filled with explosives detonated on Tuesday night as he sped toward a house used by American officials, officials here said.

title: Familiar Look as Democrats Pick State Court Candidates
description: The leaders of Brooklyn's Democratic Party gathered last night in a smoke-free, mirror-and-glass-lined room to pick their candidates for State Supreme Court.

title: Accounts
description: * The United States Olympic Committee, Colorado Springs, to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., to handle strategic, branding and creative duties on its account for the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens. Billings have not been determined. GSD&M, part of the Omnicom Group, handled the same duties for the committee for the Summer Games in 2000.

title: Poorer Nations Plead Farmers' Case at Trade Talks
description: The world trade talks began here today with the developing nations mounting a quiet revolt in the name of their farmers.

title: Colorful, Handmade Miniatures From a Hobbyist Turned Master
description: Amateur enamelists created a vast supply of ashtrays and trinkets in the 1950's, and some of those amateurs went on to become masters. Among them was Annemarie Davidson, who says she was busy raising four children when she started taking lessons in 1957. Today her vintage enameled copper pieces, which include boxes and plates, sell for $200 and up. Mrs. Davidson, now 83, is still making six-inch enameled copper dishes one at a time in a studio attached to her home in Sierra Madre, Calif. Alan Rosenberg Works of Art, a vest-pocket gallery in New York, sells new ones for $80 and vintage ones for $280 (shown is a mix). The gallery is at 46 East 65th Street; (212) 288-2505.

title: Spots for the Hummer and the hybrid Prius, opposites on the road.
description: SOME car ads play nice, some play naughty.

title: Primedia May Put New York Magazine on the Block
description: Primedia Inc. announced yesterday that it had retained Allen & Company to explore the sale of New York magazine, the archetypal city magazine that has struggled along with its parent company in recent years.

title: Operating Officer Is Leaving Burnett
description: Stephen J. Gatfield, chief operating officer at Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, is leaving, the agency said yesterday, and his post, which he has held since January 2001, is being eliminated.

title: World Briefing | Europe: It Just Rained a Lot
description: Last summer, many officials and residents were ascribing the severe flooding in Dresden and Prague and other parts of Europe to global warming and its effect on storm patterns. But a new study of the Oder and Elbe rivers, both of which have produced record floods in recent years, shows an overall decline in the frequency of floods, German researchers are reporting in the journal Nature. The scientists went as far back as 1021 and said they found no trend in big summer floods and a downward trend in extreme winter floods.

title: Tyson Wins a Round in Court
description: A bankruptcy court judge has granted a request by Mike Tyson to have Shelly Finkel, his former business adviser, and executives of Showtime, the cable network, submit to questioning and provide documents sought by Tyson.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Warning On Terror Trial
description: The Justice Department renewed its warning that the case against Zacarias Moussaoui might have to be dismissed if the trial judge continued to insist that Mr. Moussaoui have access to captured terrorists of Al Qaeda for questioning. The department acknowledged that its refusal to comply with the order ''obligates the court now to dismiss the indictment unless the court finds that the interests of justice can be served by another action.'' The department made a similar statement earlier this year when Judge Brinkema ordered that Mr. Moussaoui be given access to another captured Qaeda member. Mr. Moussaoui, a French citizen,is charged with conspiring in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Philip Shenon (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: On Writing at Night, In the Tub

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: COUNCILMAN WINS MAYOR'S RACE A former city councilman, Phil Gordon, left, easily defeated a venture capitalist, Randy Pullen, to become mayor of Phoenix, the nation's sixth-largest city. Mr. Gordon will succeed Skip Rimsza, who has been mayor since 1994 but was prevented from running again by term limits. A Democrat in a nonpartisan race, Mr. Gordon had been the heavy favorite. (AP)

title: Hollywood Publisher Seeks Bankruptcy After Losing Suit
description: Michael Viner, a Hollywood publisher best known for books tied to scandals, sought bankruptcy protection yesterday for his company, New Millennium Entertainment. Last month, a jury ordered New Millennium to pay $2.8 million to a bookstore owner for breach of contract and other improprieties.

title: Arnold Shows a Flair
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Teller, a Fierce Architect of the Hydrogen Bomb, Is Dead at 95
description: Edward Teller, a towering figure of science who had a singular impact on the development of the nuclear age, died late Tuesday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAUBARD, BLANCHE
description: GRAUBARD--Blanche. North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Blanche Graubard. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Peter J. Baum, President Stuart Bednoff, Secretary

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Cellphones That Reach Alter Egos
description: ON Oct. 1, Cingular will begin selling a unique $40 cellphone cradle called the FastForward. What it does can be described by a single sentence: whenever you slip your cellphone into it, the FastForward automatically routes incoming cell calls to your home or office phone.

title: Subpoenas Seek Records From Suffolk G.O.P. Chairman's Office
description: A Suffolk County panel investigating political corruption subpoenaed records yesterday from the insurance office of the county's Republican chairman and from several local government offices that did business with him.

title: Slip-On Shoes, Long Waits: Airline Passengers Are Still Adjusting
description: Jay Lowell stopped taking the first flight in the morning, having learned that in his waking fog he invariably left something -- wallet, wedding ring, sport coat -- at the security check.

title: Coiffures Make the Dude (He's Downwardly Mobile)
description: ''The Mullets,'' a UPN sitcom that begins tonight, tries to tap into the current fascination with white lower-class Southern male culture -- nostalgie de la Boo Radley.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FRIEDMAN, PAUL
description: FRIEDMAN--Paul. Perished on September 11, 2001 on Flight 11. He was a precious son, husband, Daddy, and brother, and there is an emptiness in our lives where he once was. Selma, Iris, Amy, James, Meryl, Audrey & Little Rocky

title: Tigers Offer Yanks Relief, Comic and Otherwise
description: Forget Dangerfield's or the ''Saturday Night Live'' set at Rockefeller Center. For pure comedy, Yankee Stadium was the place to be last night.

title: Hearts Stranded on an Isle By a Sorceress's Wiles
description: Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director of the New York City Opera, has been spending a lot of time lately trying to win support for his proposal to build an opera house as part of the ground zero development project. Meanwhile he and the company have a 60th-anniversary season to present at their current home, the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center. That season opened ambitiously on Tuesday night with a new production by Francesca Zambello of Handel's ''Alcina.''

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about a fire that destroyed part of a White Plains synagogue misstated its name. It is Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, not Temple Beth Am Shalom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COWEN, ROBERT TODD II.
description: COWEN--Robert Todd II. Adored son of the late Dorothy and Morton. Dear brother of Priscilla, Rise and the late Robin. Beloved fiance of Laura Lear. Cherished uncle. Service Friday, September 12, 2003, 11:30 AM, at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Kidney Cancer Coalition, c/o 17 White St., NY, NY 10013.

title: Counterterror Proposals Are a Hard Sell
description: President Bush, seeking still greater powers to fight terrorism, appears to have calculated that the renewed memories of the Sept. 11 attacks evoked by their second anniversary will be enough to outweigh rising concerns over civil liberties.

title: Sluggish Mets Maintain They Haven't Given Up
description: Denying that they had given up on their season a few weeks early, the Mets quietly packed their bags yesterday afternoon for another road trip on a season to nowhere. The Florida Marlins had just completed their first three-game sweep at Shea Stadium with a 7-3 victory, and the Mets were again left to find something positive amid the wreckage.

title: With Tax Plan Rejected, Alabama Braces for Cuts
description: On Tuesday, as his prized $1.2 billion tax plan was going down in flames in a statewide referendum, Gov. Bob Riley quietly unveiled a plaque depicting the Ten Commandments in an exhibit room of the state Capitol.

title: On the Scent of Natural Remedies
description: I HAVE lived in Northern California for a year now.

title: Bates Fills Jets' Needs On Special Teams
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards peeked into the hallway, took one look at the clutch of reporters surrounding his newest player, Michael Bates, and joked, ''You're not back in the Pro Bowl, are you?''

title: Two Years On
description: Even as the twin towers were falling, we wondered what kind of world we would find ourselves living in in the future. The trauma of that day led us to expect an abrupt demarcation in our lives and in the life of the nation. How abrupt, how tragic it has been for many people cannot be overemphasized. But coming into this second anniversary, our response is more measured; there is a recognition that we are now living among the uncertain ripples thrown out by that collision of worlds. The purity of our first reactions has been eroded by time and by some of the uses that have begun to be made of 9/11.

title: M. Konvitz, Scholar of Law And Idealism, Is Dead at 95
description: Milton R. Konvitz, an influential constitutional scholar who prepared pioneering civil rights cases with Thurgood Marshall, inspired Ruth Bader Ginsburg when she was a student and helped write a constitution for Liberia, died on Friday in Monmouth, N.J. He was 95 and lived in Oakhurst, N.J.

title: Two Suits Filed Over Police No-Knock Raids at Wrong Homes
description: Two families whose doors were broken down last year in mistaken raids by police officers with drawn weapons filed federal lawsuits yesterday seeking damages and a change in the procedures of the New York Police Department.

title: Attack Near House Used by U.S. in Iraq
description: A suicide bomber, driving a minivan full of explosives, killed a child and wounded more than 50 people -- most of them Iraqis -- when his van exploded as it sped toward a house used by American officials in Erbil, the center of Iraq's large Kurdish population in the north of the country. It was the first such strike against Americans in a region that had been the most peaceful and pro-American part of Iraq.

title: For Andrew, Party Time Seems to Be All the Time
description: With Andrew W. K., every sentence demands an exclamation point.

title: Study Says Ground Zero Soot Lingered
description: New research into the impact of air pollution from the World Trade Center disaster mostly confirms, for better and for worse, some of the earliest tentative conclusions reached just after the attack, scientists said yesterday. The air across most of Lower Manhattan quickly returned to generally normal conditions, with periodic jumps in the levels of ash and soot, but remained downright horrible for weeks at the smoldering mound of ground zero itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGE, ERIKA BERSON
description: LANGE--Erika Berson. On September 9, 2003. Beloved wife of Mike. Mother of Jason. Daughter of Joel and of Dale. Step-daughter of Linda and sister of Jeremy. Our loss is beyond sadness but her great goodness, intelligence, devotion and wit has forever enriched us and all whose lives she touched. Ted and Ellen Berson and family

title: Within a Lilliputian Player, a Hefty Archive That Travels
description: IT seems so simple: You push the Play button and you get an earful of Missy Elliott, Daniel Barenboim or whatever your musical whim. Unlike portable cassette or CD players, svelte digital audio jukeboxes like the silvery Creative Nomad Jukebox Zen or that sassy little white Apple iPod do not require swapping tapes or discs. Your entire digital music collection is on the device in the form of computer-encoded files in MP3, AAC, WMA or any of the other formats belonging to the alphabet soup of digital audio.

description: In percent

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Lieutenant Governor Takes Charge
description: Two days after Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon collapsed from a stroke in a Chicago hotel room, the Indiana Supreme Court has declared Lt. Gov. Joseph E. Kernan acting governor. Governor O'Bannon is still in critical condition, though his vital signs are more stable and doctors said they were more confident he would survive. They said that he moved his leg when a doctor yelled a command in his ear and that he responded to a pinch. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Army Linked To Environmental Violations
description: The Alabama Department of Environmental Management has cited the Army for violations of its permit to burn chemical weapons at the Anniston Army Depot. The department said the violations were not serious. It said they included improperly marked pipe flanges and high liquid levels in a drainage pump. Michael B. Abrams, a spokesman for the depot, said the problems were being addressed. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: While growing up in Cudahy, Wis., John Navarre no doubt heard the Badgers' popular fight song, ''On, Wisconsin!''

description: SCHONBERG--George. 1922--1995. Gone eight years. So absent--so present. Love always, Doris

title: At the Pentagon, Sept. 11 Victims Remembered as Heroes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  The people killed in the attack on the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001, were honored today as heroes, not because of how they died but because of how they lived.

description: Overtime Rules Opposed

title: Mexican Cellphone Provider Expanding in Latin America
description: It dominates its home market in Mexico and now Amrica Mvil, Latin America's largest provider of cellular phone service, is stretching its reach across the entire region, looking to extend its hegemony by snapping up assets from fleeing global companies.

title: You Want a Nursery? Here's a Reality Check
description: HERE'S my pitch for the next big reality TV show. It's called ''The Nursery,'' and it follows a couple -- call them Frank and Barbara -- who dream of turning their love of gardening into a small business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAIFETZ, ELEANOR
description: CHAIFETZ -- Eleanor. Be loved wife of the late Oscar. Cherished aunt of Howard and Marcia Shafran and great-aunt of Brad and Lisa Shafran. Devoted sister-inlaw of Barbara Garb, Sylvia Shafran and the late Sam Shafran. Loving sister of the late Harold Garb. Graveside services today, 2 PM, at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. For information, contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, (718) 377-7300.

title: Some New Riffs On the Rollaway
description: In his SoHo loft, Chico Lledo, a graphic artist, is the master of a 4,200-square-foot urban universe. Every piece of furniture -- bed, sofa, coffee table, bookcase, television cabinet and an 18-foot-long titanium dining table -- is set on casters. With just one hand, Mr. Lledo, 29, who shares the loft with his companion, Doris Fontanilla, 28, an olive oil importer, can reconfigure the space all day long -- and sometimes, it seems as if he does.

title: This Solemn Day: To Mourn, Reflect and Heal (9 Letters)
