title: A Speedy Drive That Can Slip Into Your Pocket
description: Luckily for people whose file sizes have outgrown the mere megabyte or so of space on a diskette, pocket-size flash memory drives that can hold 32 megabytes or more keep getting smaller and faster. The tiny Verbatim Store 'n' Go U.S.B. Drive, equipped with a high-speed U.S.B. 2.0 connection, can copy 256 megabytes of data in 30 seconds, making it at least five times faster than drives that have the older U.S.B. 1.1 connection.

title: Heredia Showing His Worth To Yanks
description: Three years ago, when the Yankees claimed Jose Canseco off waivers from Tampa Bay, they ended up stuck with a superfluous player. This year's accidental waiver claim is working out much better.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in The Arts on Aug. 27 with an article about the influence of the comic book artist Jack Kirby on movies carried an erroneous credit. The picture, of Mr. Kirby in the 1980's, was by Susan Skarr/''The Art of Jack Kirby.''

title: Newspaper Group Fills 2 Senior Posts
description: The Newspaper National Network in New York, owned by the Newspaper Association of America and 23 large newspaper publishers, is naming two executives to senior posts in a reorganization.

title: C. H. Sisson, 89, British Poet; A Loyal Civil Servant by Day
description: C. H. Sisson, a respected though not widely known British poet, translator and critic, who carefully avoided living the literary life, died on Friday at his home in the village of Langport in southwest England. He was 89.

title: Council Chief Backs Change In City Policy on Immigrants
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller waded into the politically charged issue of what the city should do about illegal immigrants yesterday, throwing his weight behind a proposed law intended to pressure the Bloomberg administration to change its policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, STANLEY
description: ROBERTS--Stanley. On September 10, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Peggy. Devoted father of Robin Stessel. Loving brother of Muriel Brinn. Cherished grandfather of Jason and Sara. Services Friday, 11:45am ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Pay Package Protest
description: The two big-gest pension funds of the Netherlands are objecting to a decision by the food retailer Royal Ahold to award its new chief executive, Anders C. Moberg, left, 6 million euros ($6.7 million) in compensation over two years along with a severance package that could amount to 9 million euros ($10 million). The pension funds, ABP and PGGM, contended in a letter to the management of Ahold, that the company did not give investors enough time to consider Mr. Moberg's compensation before the vote by shareholders last week. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: This Solemn Day: To Mourn, Reflect and Heal; Our Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Case That Crawled Through Courts Returns to Go
description: For 16 years in the Case of the Missing Coffee, the wheels of justice have turned slowly. Then on Tuesday, they started in reverse.

title: Families of Victims File to Meet a Legal Deadline
description: Dozens of lawsuits were filed yesterday on behalf of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, as families sought to meet a legal deadline for wrongful-death suits against airlines, security firms and other defendants.

title: Court Session Set Today On Rap Impresario's Suit
description: Lawyers for Russell Simmons and the state are set to meet in federal court in Manhattan Thursday over Mr. Simmons's complaint that he was unfairly singled out by the state lobbying commission for his efforts to change New York's drug sentencing laws.

title: Collins to Work on MSG
description: Doug Collins, who is returning to TNT to call National Basketball Association games, will also call 10 Knicks games for the MSG Network. He will work with Marv Albert, with whom he formerly worked at TNT.

title: Blair Gets a Pass From Iraq Intelligence Panel
description: LONDON, Sept. 11  A parliamentary committee cleared Prime Minister Tony Blair's government today of falsifying intelligence findings, but questioned its claim that Iraq could deploy unconventional weapons in 45 minutes and faulted its portrayal of Iraq as a threat to Britain.

title: New Accounts Of Meetings At Big Board On Chief's Pay
description: Richard A. Grasso decided to give up $48 million in benefits owed to him by the New York Stock Exchange only hours before the decision was announced, and after some members of the board said he should, several directors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEDERMAN, RUTH
description: LEDERMAN--Ruth. August 1, 2003 of North Miami, FL and Bayside, NY. Beloved wife and partner of 61 years to Ziggy, loving mother of son, Stuart (Ellen), grandmother of Scott (Tricia), great-grandmother of Joshua and Megan. There will never be another you. Your life was a blessing, your valiant fight amazed us, and filled us with awe. We will never forget all of the fun times we shared. Missing your love, our hearts are broken. You accepted life's challenges with determination and strength. A shinning light extinguished. Many thanks to Dr. Peter Rosenberg, Drs Melvin and Ira Breite of Bayside, and Ruth's nurses. Services were held, Schwartz Brothers, August 3rd, 2003. Born September 11, 1923. Happy 80th Birthday, Cookie. All our love always. We will watch your star #

title: Stop Automatic Help
description: When It's Unwelcome

title: Critic's Notebook; One Vision: A Hill of Green at Ground Zero
description: Last Wednesday morning, without warning or fanfare, a FedEx box arrived at my door. Inside was a shipping folder of white foam board, with a letter attached to it addressed to me and signed by Ellsworth Kelly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOLKIN, ANDREW
description: GOLKIN--Andrew. Dearest Andy, you are forever in our hearts. We miss your beautiful smile and generous heart. Love, Mom, Dad and Susan

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   TRAVERS, WALTER
description: TRAVERS--Walter. May 22, 1957-Sept. 11, 2001. Wally you will always be the heart and soul of our family. You are with us always. Your Loving Family

title: Deal Reflects Archbishop and His Franciscan Roots
description: On Sunday evening, at a secret, hastily called negotiating session between lawyers for 550 people who say they had been sexually abused by priests and representatives of the Boston Roman Catholic Archdiocese, one of the lawyers handed over photographs that a paralegal had taken of six large buildings that the church rented out for commercial or residential use.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Two More West Nile Cases
description: Two Queens residents were found to have the West Nile virus yesterday, bringing the total number of people in the city who tested positive for the virus to five, health officials said. A 69-year-old man from Ridgewood was in intensive care yesterday, but health officials said he may not have contracted the virus in New York. A 66-year-old woman from Whitestone was also hospitalized and in stable condition. The three other city residents who tested positive for the virus this year were from the Bronx, Manhattan and Staten Island. So far, 13 people in New York State have tested positive for the virus, and two of them have died. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEORGIS, TED W.
description: GEORGIS--Ted W., born 1924 in Chicago, died September 8, 2003, in San Diego, CA. He was 78. Ted Georgis is survived by his wife and dearest friend of 50 years, Mitzie of La Jolla, CA; a daughter and two sons: Demetra Bowles Lathrop, and spouse Thomas Lathrop, of San Francisco; Dr. Theodore W. Georgis, Jr., and spouse Tracy, of Rancho Santa Fe, CA; and William T. Georgis, and partner Richard Marshall of NYC. He is also survived by a brother, Nick Georgis of Oakbrook, IL; and five grandchildren. Servicesto be held at 10:30am, Thursday, September 11, at Saints Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church, Cardiff-bythe-Sea, CA.

title: Shares Fall Sharply After Tape of bin Laden Is Broadcast
description: Stocks had their biggest losses in five weeks yesterday after Osama bin Laden appeared in a videotape broadcast on the eve of the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, raising concerns that there might be more assaults.

title: Breaking Death's Grip
description: I learned something new the other night in Tel Aviv. I learned that your neck is actually the weakest part of your body. The Israeli police spokesman taught me that as he explained why the Palestinian suicide bomber's head was blown straight up, like a champagne cork, and was still sitting on a ledge atop the bus stop, like a human gargoyle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KELLERMAN AND SILVER DEAR PETER AND DAVID
description: KELLERMAN AND SILVER Dear Peter and David, Two years have gone by and you are sorely missed, deeply loved and constantly in our thoughts and prayers. We know you are together watching over us. You both had hearts of gold. You are forever loved, Robi Kellerman Holli, Rachel, Danielle Silver

title: KEYCORP WARNS OF LOWER PROFIT FOR THE YEAR
description: KeyCorp, a bank holding company based in Cleveland, expects to earn less this year than analysts expected because of slowing demand for commercial loans, its chief executive said yesterday. The bank forecast a profit of $2.10 a share, short of the $2.12 expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The chief executive, Henry L. Meyer III, speaking at a conference in New York, said the bank had cut some jobs and had closed brokerage offices to offset the decline. Mr. Meyer also said that the bank planned to open 35 consumer branches in the next two years.

title: Blood on the Street, and It's Chic; Landmark Status for a Meatpacking District
description: Michael Diamond walked past the trucks for Woolco, Sysco and the meat purveyors yesterday as he crossed Little West 12th Street. A famed rap performer and Spiritual Guy, he is the obligatory Beastie Boy on hand to assure the followers of fashion eating brunch at outdoor cafes that they had arrived at the scene of a scene.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SIMON, MICHAEL JOHN
description: SIMON--Michael John. July 27, 1961 - Sept. 11, 2001. In celebration of your life, Michael, a life so lived that it earned you the respect and admiration of all who knew you, we offer a prayer. Your name brings a smile to our lips, your remembrances a joy to our hearts. We miss you terribly. We thought we had time with you. We will honor you all the days of our lives.

title: Mixed Data Leave Doubts on Cancer Drug
description: A biotechnology cancer drug developed by Genta Inc. extended the lives of patients with melanoma by about a month in a large clinical trial, the company said yesterday, an outcome that fell short of expectations. But Genta and its partner, Aventis, said that the overall results were strong and that they would apply for approval of the drug.

title: Japan's Economy Grows at 3.9% Pace
description: Japan's economy expanded 3.9 percent at an annualized pace in the April-to-June quarter -- nearly twice as fast as originally reported -- as capital spending was better than expected.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Accountant Sentenced In Tax Fraud
description: A federal district judge has sentenced a Mobile accountant to three years in prison for fraud in connection with his scheme to apply for tax refunds for black clients on the basis of historical discrimination. Through his Web site, the accountant, James D. Buckley, 46, promised clients $40,000 refunds, saying they were based on tax overpayments by generations of black Americans who lived without civil rights, Charlie McNichol, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office, said. Mr. Buckley must also return a total of $59,000 to 489 victims. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Police Want To Question Rapper
description: The police said yesterday that they want to question the rap artist 50 Cent, left, after a shooting early Tuesday outside a hotel. No injuries were reported, but the police said they found 10 gun shell casings in the parking lot of the Doubletree Club Suites, where the rapper was staying. Sgt. Edgar Martinez, a spokesman for the Jersey City police, said a parking attendant heard the shots and saw 10 to 12 people, including 50 Cent, flee the scene in limousines. Sergeant Martinez said ''several sources'' identified 50 Cent, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, 27, as being near the scene. A lawyer for Mr. Jackson did not return calls seeking comment. Jonathan Miller (NYT)

title: Buckeyes Suspend Clarett For Year
description: The worst-kept secret in college football became official yesterday when Andy Geiger, the Ohio State athletic director, announced that running back Maurice Clarett had been suspended for the season by the university for receiving extra benefits worth thousands of dollars and for lying to investigators.

title: This Solemn Day: To Mourn, Reflect and Heal; My Husband's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REGES, ALICE M.
description: REGES--Alice M. Died in Paris on August 31st, 2003. Beloved mother of Marianna Reges, loving grandmother of Rebecca Reges Green and Charles P. Green, III; she was a truly remarkable person with great energy and interest in tennis, dancing, bridge, opera, theater, travel and real estate sales. Family will receive friends Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service on Saturday 12:30PM, at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Political Memo; Low Turnout In Primaries Gives Mayor Ammunition
description: Most New Yorkers hardly noticed, but on Tuesday there was a Democratic primary, a civic exercise that could become extinct if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has his way.

title: We're Not Happy Campers
description: The Saudi religious police are harassing Barbie.

title: In Yonkers, Deputy Mayor Faces Former Schools Chief
description: The messy fight over the Republican nomination for the mayoral race has turned out to be a relatively safe victory for Deputy Mayor Phil Amicone, and Joe L. Farmer, the former schools superintendent, has emerged as the Democratic nominee for the job.

title: Jobs, Tourists and Nail-Biters: Taking the City's Pulse After 9/11
description: It's two years later. New Yorkers are taking more antidepressants. They fear they will be the target of another terrorist attack. They are still staggering from the jobs and money lost after the last one.

title: Where Sculpture Meets Utility, A Place to Hang Your Coat
description: The humble coat rack will be elevated to art at a show opening Wednesday at R 20th Century, a store and gallery in TriBeCa. About three dozen free-standing and wall-mounted racks will be on display, all of which are for sale. ''A coat rack is not only a piece of furniture but also a piece of sculpture,'' said Zesty Meyers, one of the gallery's owners. The show includes a lacquered prototype of the 1968 Renna, right, designed by Bruce Tippet for Gavina ($4,200); and a 1950's Danish design, left, by Nanna Ditzel ($3,500). A 1960 wall-mounted rack by Jules Wabbes is $15,000. The gallery is at 82 Franklin Street (Broadway), (212) 343-7979 or www.r20thcentury

title: Patriots' Super Bowl Seems Like Long Ago
description: Sipping a can of Red Bull at his locker today, Lonie Paxton, the long snapper of the New England Patriots, reflected on the team's serendipitous run to winning Super Bowl XXXVI 20 months ago.

title: Sports of The Times; Families of the Victims of Sept. 11 Find They Have a Friend in Fassel
description: EVEN now, two years later, whenever the Giants are on their practice field as a jetliner roars over Giants Stadium, many of the coaches and players quickly peek up at it. Just to make sure it stays headed toward Newark Liberty International Airport, not toward the Manhattan skyline just a glance away.

title: HotJobs Ends Ties To Creative Agency
description: HotJobs in New York, the job search Web site owned by Yahoo, has ended its relationship with Brand Architecture International in New York, which served as the creative agency for HotJobs consumer campaigns that included Super Bowl commercials. HotJobs spent $7 million to $10 million on ads in major media last year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about a falloff in ratings for sports programming on television from 1996 to 2001 misstated the change. Ratings for sports programming fell by 10 percent. Televised sports suffered the smallest drop in those years, not a bigger drop than for any other segment of the audience.

title: Senate Democrats, With Republican Help, Block Administration's New Overtime Rules
description: President Bush's plan to change the definition of who is eligible for overtime pay ran into a serious roadblock on Capitol Hill today, as the Senate, in a rare Democratic victory, voted to block the White House from issuing the new rules.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Tuesday about the popularity of quirky fall designs misstated the given name of the designer of a jacket embellished at the rear with a billowing panel of lace-covered silk. (An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about the restaurant 66, where patrons are wearing the designer's clothes, included the same error.) He is Olivier Theyskens, not Oliver.

title: Show Off Those Snapshots (Hear and Read Them, Too)
description: Pacific Digital's new 8-by-10-inch MemoryFrame is obviously bigger than the 5-by-7-inch model the company introduced last year. Less apparent is how much sharper the image is.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: No Bail Sought In Missile Case
description: A man charged with trying to sell shoulder-fired missiles to terrorists has decided not to seek bail and will remain in jail while a federal grand jury considers his case. Hement Lakhani, 68, was arrested in Newark on Aug. 12 and charged with providing material support to terrorists and trying to sell arms without a license. .

title: North Korea's Isolation
description: To the Editor:

title: Costs Mount for Yale and Union as Strike Drags On
description: With the strike at Yale University entering its third week and no end in sight, the showdown is starting to exact sizable costs on both the university and the unionized workers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Second Arrest In Police Shooting
description: A second man has been arrested in the Aug. 27 shooting of a plainclothes police captain patrolling near Washington Heights. Police charged Jason Rivera, 18, of 1110 St. Lawrence Avenue in the Bronx, with first-degree assault and second-degree attempted robbery after he turned himself in to the police on Tuesday. A man accused of being the gunman, Roland Roberts, 22, was arrested on Sunday. He was charged with attempted murder and two counts of criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. The two men are believed to have been planning a robbery of a social club near West 154th Street when the captain, Kenneth Girven, drove past and saw one of them duck behind a vehicle. According to the police, he got out of the car and called: ''Police. What's up?'' and Mr. Roberts shot him once in the side. He is recovering from injuries to his bladder. Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the police are looking for one other person, the driver. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Suffolk Democrats Optimistic About This Year's Election
description: Westchester County was the first of New York's big Republican suburbs to go Democratic. Then Nassau County followed. Now Democrats in Suffolk say this year is their turn.

title: Israel Authorizes Removal of Arafat, but Puts Off Action
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Sept. 11 -- The Israeli government decided tonight to "remove" Yasir Arafat, authorizing actions in the future to exile, jail or possibly kill him.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Msgr. Robert P. Hupp, who led Boys Town during a period of change, including the admission of girls, misspelled the name of the Wisconsin city where he died. It is Mauston, not Mausten.

title: New case not viewed as harbinger of massive outbreak : Experts see less SARS danger
description: PARIS:  Singapore's reports of the first confirmed SARS case since May has placed governments in Asia on high alert, but experts at the World Health Organization say that a massive resurgence of the disease is unlikely.

title: FINNISH COMPANY SELLS ITS TRACTOR DIVISION TO AGCO
description: The Finnish manufacturer Kone said yesterday that it had sold its tractor division to the Agco Corporation, a farm equipment maker in Duluth, Ga., for 600 million euros ($672 million). The tractor group, known as Valtra, had net sales of 762 million euros in 2002 and a 15 percent return on assets. Kone said it would also sell its forest machines unit as it concentrates on operations like elevators, escalators and automatic doors. Agco makes farm equipment under several brands. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Dear Campaign Diary: Seizing the Day, Online
description: SIX years ago, when Reva Renee Renz was waiting on tables at a bar in Southern California, she knew little about politics. But a few times a week on a blackboard next to the daily drink specials, she recalls, she wrote short rants about whatever was on her mind: a problem in the city, or a new ordinance that she thought unfair. Her messages won her a steady following.

title: The Other Sept. 11
description: Death came from the skies. A building -- a symbol of the nation -- collapsed in flames in an act of terror that would lead to the deaths of 3,000 people. It was Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 30 about 20th Century Fox's decision against releasing ''The Passion,'' Mel Gibson's movie about Jesus' last hours, misstated the precedent for the studio's distribution of Mr. Gibson's movies. While it has the right to release films he makes before they are offered to other distributors, it has not yet released any.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   APPLEBAUM, RABBI DR. DAVID AND NAAVA
description: APPLEBAUM--Rabbi Dr. David and Naava. ''She (Jerusalem) weeps bitterly in the night and her tear is on her cheek.'' Heartbroken and devastated, we mourn the tragic deaths of a treasured jewel of the Jewish people together with his beloved daughter Naava, both of whom died Al Kiddush Hashem, on the eve of her wedding. An extraordinary and humble man whose very being radiated kindness, dignity and modesty, his ability to synthesize the teachings of Torah and Medicine made him a living model of Torah Im Derech Eretz. Among his colleagues, students and friends, he was considered a ''great Torah scholar'', ''a sparkling personality'' and ''a model family man.'' As head of our Department of Emergency Medicine, his visionary thinking, expertise, impressive professional achievements and warm bedside manner, established him as one of the country's leaders in the field. Likewise, in her short life, Naava exhibited compassion, courage and deep commitment to the Jewish people through her national service work with children suffering from cancer. Our profound condolences to his wife Debra and their five children. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Comm. for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Sidney A. Adler, Treasurer Lee Weinbach, Secretary Michael S. Strauss, NY Chair Paul S. Glasser, Nat'l Dir

description: CASH for trash?

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as some investors said its recent drop against the euro reflected too much pessimism about the outlook for the economy. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1216, down from $1.1235 on Tuesday.

title: Digital Dealmakers Meet in the Middle
description: PICTURE two people haggling over a debt -- say, $1,000 -- that is due in a month. The lender wants the money, but the debtor wants to cut a deal.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Declined in August
description: Magazine advertising pages declined in August for the third consecutive month, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported yesterday.

title: Tips for Avoiding Viruses and Spam
description: The explosion of Windows viruses and spam has been headlines daily for weeks now. Together, theyll cost U.S. businesses $23 billion this year. It certainly seems as though these problems have grown well beyond the nuisance stage.

title: Leader Suggests Democrats May Forgo Public Financing
description: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic National Committee chairman and his party's chief fund-raiser, said today that Democratic presidential candidates vying to take on President Bush next year should consider opting out of the country's public financing system during the primary season.

title: Best Antidote to Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Voice Recognition, to a Computer That Reads Lips
description: PERSONAL computers have changed a lot in the last few decades, but not in the way that people communicate with them. Typing on a keyboard, with the help of a mouse, remains the most common interface.

title: Dean Asks General to Join Him in Primaries, Aides Say
description: After months of friendly discussions about national security and other issues, Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, asked Gen. Wesley K. Clark to join his presidential campaign in some capacity if General Clark decided against making the run himself, aides for both men said tonight.

title: New Agency Proposed to Oversee Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae
description: The Bush administration today recommended the most significant regulatory overhaul in the housing finance industry since the savings and loan crisis a decade ago.

description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina Reaches Deal On 3-Year Aid Package
description: A day after defaulting on a $3 billion debt payment to the International Monetary Fund, Argentina said today that it had clinched a three-year aid package from the fund without having to make any major concessions on points it considers crucial to help revive its moribund economy.

title: Cassell Pledges to Energize Sprewell
description: Sam Cassell said that he and all of New York saw a conservative, watered-down version of Latrell Sprewell over the past five years. The slashing and dunking that made Sprewell one of the N.B.A.'s most exciting players for Golden State gave way to pull-up jumpers and spot-up 3-pointers when he played for the Knicks.

title: With Its Reinvented Wheel, a Mouse Scampers to the Side Margins
description: In contrast to Microsoft's high-profile plunge into the video game console business in 2001, the company's hardware group has been quietly breaking new ground with a continued focus on those PC essentials, the keyboard and mouse.

title: How the Block Was Chosen
description: The initial goal was to find a typical block, one that included all the ethnic and economic tribes of New York City. But that had to change.

title: Quayle Back In the Capitol For Good, Set in Stone
description: Dan Quayle, the politician who will be remembered for his youth, conservatism and mishap in spelling, proudly assumed his place in marble today alongside John Adams, Thomas Jefferson and 41 other vice presidents of the United States.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA SAYS STARZ ENCORE INCOME MAY FALTER
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the company controlled by John C. Malone, said yesterday that higher programming expenses and a legal dispute with the Comcast Corporation might reduce operating income next year at Liberty's Starz Encore cable TV networks. Starz Encore expects its programming expenses to rise as much as $225 million. Comcast, which bought AT&T's cable TV systems last year, is disputing a contract that lets Starz Encore pass along some programming costs to AT&T. Liberty was the cable programming unit of AT&T until it was spun off in 2001. Comcast is suing Starz Encore, saying its agreement with the networks should replace the agreement with AT&T. Comcast has withheld $45 million this year that Starz Encore says it is owed. Liberty's chief executive, Robert R. Bennett, said the company and Comcast were discussing a settlement. A Comcast spokesman, Tim Fitzpatrick, declined comment.

title: Cowboys' New Tight End Will Feel Right at Home
description: There will be a homecoming when the Dallas Cowboys play at Giants Stadium on Monday night, one that Giants players and coaches talk about with pangs of nostalgia and regret, one that has nothing to do with Cowboys Coach Bill Parcells.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MOND, BERTRAND
description: MOND--Bertrand September 11, 2002 Dear Bert, losing you has been unbearable. You will always live in my heart and the hearts of your children and grandchildren. Love, Phyl

title: Gas Project In Peru Gets Crucial Loan
description: An ambitious project to develop Peru's natural gas fields, sharply criticized by environmental advocates, received a significant endorsement today when the Inter-American Development Bank approved a $75 million loan, bank officials in Washington said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Metro section on Tuesday about conjoined twins from the Philippines misstated the birthplace of another set of twins who underwent surgery in Salt Lake City. They were from Honduras, not Salt Lake City. The article also misstated the location of the headquarters of Children's Chance, a foundation that helped obtain medical care for the Filipino twins. It is in Waterbury, Conn., not Westport.

title: Economic Scene; When it comes to books, Internet selling has not led to uniformly low prices.
description: LIKE every author I know, I'm obsessed with the Amazon ranking of my new book. Several times a day, I check the number on the book's Amazon.com page to see how its sales compare with sales of every other book. Best-seller lists rank just the top 10 or 20 books. Amazon ranks more than two million -- every book it sells.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Debenhams Bid Extended
description: Permira Advisers, the Blackstone Group and Goldman Sachs extended their bid for the British department store chain Debenhams until Sept. 23, the private equity groups said yesterday in a statement to the London Stock Exchange. They have offered $2.4 billion for the chain. Just 2.6 percent of the shareholders of Debenhams have approved the offer, below the 50 percent approval the buyers need for a deal. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Westchester: Court Allows 'Perp Walks'
description: A federal appeals court has affirmed that a ''perp walk'' that allowed the news media to show the arrest of a correction officer in 1999 did not violate his Fourth Amendment rights. The officer, Joseph Freeman, was arrested with several other officers in an investigation into fraudulent disability claims. A county employee videotaped Officer Freeman and the others as they were led away in handcuffs. The tape was later provided to the news media. Officer Freeman sued, accusing the county executive and the Correction Department of violating his right to privacy. A judge in Federal District Court ruled against him in 2001. On Tuesday, the United States Court of Appeals affirmed that ruling. ''The image of the accused being led away to contend with the justice system powerfully communicates government efforts to thwart the criminal element,'' Judge Fred I. Parker wrote. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Synagogue Wins Reprieve
description: An Orthodox Jewish synagogue in the Flatiron district has won a reprieve from eviction and a legal victory over its umbrella movement, the National Council of Young Israel. On Tuesday, a ruling by a judge in State Supreme Court, Debra A. James, rejected the National Council's petition to sell its headquarters, which also houses the Young Israel of Fifth Avenue synagogue. The judge said the council's board of directors failed to follow the proper procedures in voting to sell the six-story building, at 3 West 16th Street, to a developer for $5.4 million. Rabbi Israel Wohlgelernter said, ''Maybe they'll see the light, the light that Jewish law forbids selling a synagogue.'' In her ruling, the judge also rejected the synagogue's claim that it, too, was an owner of the building. A lawyer for the umbrella group said it had not decided whether to appeal or to hold another board meeting to approve the sale. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: All-White Jury Challenged
description: An all-white jury was selected yesterday in the federal corruption trial of a former candidate for secretary of the state who is black, and his lawyer filed for another jury selection. The defendant, Ben F. Andrews, was charged with racketeering, bribery and obstruction of justice; he is accused of illegal dealings with an investment fund. His lawyer, Jeremiah Donovan, asked Judge Ellen Bree Burns to choose another jury for the trial, to start on Monday. Mr. Donovan said one black juror was excused because prosecutors said she was not intelligent enough. She attended college for two years, while seven of those selected have only high school educations, he said. One alternate is black. Assistant United States Attorney Leonard Boyle said the woman's race was not a factor in her being excused. The judge is expected to rule on the motion on Friday. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SAVAS, ANTHONY
description: SAVAS--Anthony. October 8, 1928--September 11, 2001. Cassandra, John, Christina & Phaedra, Jackie & Jessica

title: Rethinking a Hartford Museum With a Grand Past
description: IF the narrative of a city can be found in the life of its cultural institutions, then Hartford's story is that of the Wadsworth Atheneum, America's oldest public art museum.

title: National Briefing | Religion: Bishops Turn To Constitution To Bar Gay Marriage
description: Leaders of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops, meeting on Tuesday in Washington, endorsed an amendment to the United States Constitution to effectively bar gay marriages by defining marriage as a union between a man and a woman. The bishops said they would oppose legal or judicial efforts ''to grant same-sex unions the equivalent status and rights of marriage.'' The Vatican issued a denunciation of gay marriages in July. Bishops in Canada on Tuesday said they would fight measures by Canada's government to expand the definition of marriage. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Brooklyn Native Helps Beat the Cyclones
description: Williamsport's Anthony Bocchino, a Brooklyn native, broke the hearts of Brooklyn Cyclones fans last night in the New York-Penn League championship series.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT BUYS TOOTHPASTE UNIT FROM UNILEVER
description: The Church & Dwight Company, the maker of Arm & Hammer toothpaste, has agreed to buy Unilever's Mentadent and Pepsodent business in the United States and Canada for $104 million to more than double its oral care sales in the United States. Unilever, one of the world's largest makers of soaps and food, may also receive performance-based payments of as much as $12 million. The business had sales of $61 million in the first six months, said Church & Dwight, based in Princeton, N.J.

title: Bond Sales, A Lifeblood For Italians, Face Problems
description: When Barilla, the world's largest pasta maker, refinanced its debt last year, it turned to the bond market. That was no surprise, considering that stocks were in their third year of decline and the Barilla family had always shunned the possibility of an initial stock offering that would sap their jealously guarded control.

title: Bill on Changes in Welfare Advances to Full Senate
description: Welfare legislation cleared a major hurdle today as the Senate Finance Committee approved a bill that would increase work requirements for welfare recipients.

title: Playing On Till the Cards Come Home
description: Bridge events normally last a few hours, but there is one that, like round-the-world yacht racing, goes on and on and on and on. It is the New York Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams, which starts annually in November and frequently finishes the following September. The 2003 championship ended a week ago, and might have continued. The winners, against a group led by Josh Parker, were Barry Rigal, John Diamond, Jill Levin, Sue Picus, Alan Miller and Alex Ornstein. The diagramed deal was highly significant.

description: EUROPE

title: U.S. Bars Five Saudi Pilots on Watch Lists
description: The United States has barred five pilots from the Saudi national airline from flying to the United States after their names turned up this summer on watch lists of people tied to international terrorism, Bush administration officials said today.

title: From the Torch To the Toes, Digital Insurance
description: ONE HUNDRED TWENTY years ago, the Statue of Liberty sat in packing crates; France had created it, but there was no money to erect it. Then Joseph Pulitzer used his newspapers to shame Americans into contributing the needed $100,000.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUSTIG, TRUDI
description: LUSTIG--Trudi. Died September 9, 2003, exactly 15 years to the day after her beloved husband Mike. Trudi and Mike are dancing together in heaven now. Trudi was an enormous, loving presence to all who knew her. Her sense of humor, love of fun, family and friends brought happiness to any situation. Mother, wife, grandmother, aunt, sister, friend, she will be missed by all. Lori and Morgan Hertzan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, HAROLD, M.D.

Private practice Brooklyn, NY 1949-1988. Diplomate National Board Medical Examiners, American Board of Internal Medicine. Contributed numerous articles to professional journals; Lt. Col. U.S. Army 1941-1946, decorated Bronze Star; recipient Merit Citation General Chiang Kai Shek China 1945; BS Columbia University, BS Medicine West Virginia, M.D. Cum Laude Boston University. More than $1 million and 13,000 volunteers have been pledged as part of an online movement to draft General Clark, the former NATO supreme commander and CNN military analyst, to enter the 2004 race.

title: National Briefing | Washington: White House Meeting For Dalai Lama
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, met at the White House with President Bush. The Dalai Lama said Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, with whom he met on Tuesday, had shown ''genuine interest and sympathy'' regarding his efforts to win some degree of autonomy from China for Tibet. Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush ''reiterated our strong commitment to support the preservation of Tibet's unique religious, cultural and linguistic identity, and the protection of the human rights'' of all Tibetans. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: American Indian Baskets and Blankets Ask a Question, 'What Is Art?'
description: Three exhibitions explore the enduring appeal of American Indian blankets, baskets and decorative art. ''Navajo Blankets of the 19th Century'' will be at the Textile Museum in Washington until March 14 (www.textilemuseum.org), and ''The Language of Native American Baskets'' will be at the National Museum of the American Indian in New York from Sept. 20 to Jan. 9, 2005 (www.americanindian.si.edu). Bruce Bernstein, who curated the basket exhibition, said his goal is to have people see baskets as art. The works he selected for the exhibition include a deer antler sheathed in woven cedar strips, top, and a basket that incorporates Victorian embroidery patterns, above left. In connection with the exhibition, basket weavers, including Terrol Johnson, top center, and Lisa Telford, top right, will hold demonstrations on Sept. 20 and 21 at Culture Fest 2003 in Battery Park; pieces will sell for $50 to $500.

title: What's Smaller Than the Tate And Hangs From the Ceiling?
description: Herzog & de Meuron, the Swiss architecture firm best known for turning a London power plant into the Tate Modern, invented a flexible floodlight for the ceiling of an insurance company in Switzerland and has now put it into production. Called Pipe Suspension, it starts with a metal snake in a sleeve of ribbed white silicone and ends with an energy-conscious 32-watt compact fluorescent bulb. The light is focused by a translucent plastic Hershey's Kiss-shaped shade, lined with aluminum that has been pierced to add a sparkle like bottled fireflies. The 55-inch fixture is $555 at Artemide, 46 Greene Street (Broome Street), or from www.artemide.com.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Music Industry Sued Over 'Amnesty'
description: The Recording Industry Association of America has been sued over its ''amnesty'' program after it filed lawsuits accusing 261 people of illegally trading songs over the Internet. A California resident, Eric Parke, sued the association, a trade group, on Tuesday because of its amnesty program, which it introduced on Monday and that it said would allow people to avoid legal action by stepping forward and forfeiting any illegally traded songs. The lawsuit, filed in the Superior Court of California in Marin County, asserts that the program is a deceptive and fraudulent business practice designed to lure people ''to incriminate themselves and provide the R.I.A.A. and others with actionable admissions of wrongdoing under penalty of perjury.'' But the program provides ''no legally binding release of claims,'' according to the complaint. The association responded to the lawsuit with a maxim: ''No good deed goes unpunished, apparently.'' And added: ''It's also unfortunate that a lawyer would try to prevent others from getting the assurances they want that they will not be sued.'' The lawsuit asks the court to bar the association from falsely advertising its program.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Settles Lawsuit
description: The Intergraph Corporation, a computer services and software company, said yesterday that Texas Instruments had agreed to pay $18 million to end patent litigation over digital signal processors used in cellphones and electronic organizers. Texas Instruments, a leading maker of chips that run cellphones, will get a license for three Intergraph patents in return for the payment, Intergraph said. Texas Instruments also agreed to end two patent-infringement lawsuits it filed against Intergraph, which is based in Huntsville, Ala. Executives at Texas Instruments, which is based in Dallas and reported $8.38 billion in sales last year, had no immediate comment. Intergraph, which has collected $450 million from Intel in a dispute over the patents, is also suing Hewlett-Packard, Dell and Gateway over the patents. A lawsuit Hewlett-Packard filed against Intergraph was dismissed, Intergraph said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Free Rock Concert In Central Park

The mayor's office confirmed that the concert had been approved, but details were sketchy. The band said tickets would be required and directed people to a fan association Web site that charges a $30 annual fee. The concert will be held a day after Mr. Matthews releases his new solo album, ''Some Devil.'' Patrick Healy (NYT)

World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Acquired
description: The Belgian brewer Interbrew, which makes Stella Artois, agreed to buy Apatinska, Serbia's largest beer maker, for 326.9 million euros ($368 million) to expand in central Europe and make up for lackluster demand in the West. Interbrew, based in Leuven, Belgium, said it would offer 167.64 euros for each share of the closely held Apatinska, valuing the company at 262 million euros, and pay 64.9 million euros for extra shares Apatinska plans to issue. Apatinska, which makes Jelen and Pils Light, has a 39 percent share of the Serbian beer market.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: ADOBE SHARES RISE ON STRONG RESULTS Shares of Adobe Systems rose 8 percent yesterday and flirted with a new high for the year, a day after the company, a maker of desktop publishing software, reported strong quarterly results and analysts grew more bullish on the stock. After the stock market closed on Wednesday, Adobe said that fiscal third-quarter profits jumped more than 36 percent, to $64.5 million, as sales of its Acrobat electronic document software led to a 12 percent rise in revenue. The company also said fourth-quarter profit would be better than expected, calling for net income of 30 to 32 cents a share on revenue of $330 million to $350 million. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., also scheduled a product introduction for Sept. 29, which analysts took to mean that it would release new versions of Photoshop, its popular photo-editing software, and other products in the current quarter. Adobe shares rose $3.07, to $39.46.   (Reuters)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BARENTS SEA: NO RADIOACTIVITY AT SUB Tests in the Barents Sea have shown no sign of increased radioactivity since a Russian nuclear submarine sank there in August, Norway's atomic safety authority said. The 40-year-old K-159 sub sank in a storm on Aug. 30, killing nine servicemen, while being towed to a scrapyard. Russia says that radiation levels are normal in the area, and that the sub is lying at 787 feet, with about 1,765 pounds of spent nuclear fuel in its two reactors. The commander of the Russian Northern Fleet, Adm. Gennady Suchkov, has been suspended indefinitely while the sinking is investigated.    (Reuters)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Carreker Stock Surges On Profit News
description: Shares of the Carreker Corporation, whose software and computer-consulting services help banks process checks and manage cash machines, rose sharply yesterday after the company reported a second-quarter profit. After a first-quarter loss, Carreker said it had second-quarter net income of $3.9 million, or 17 cents a share, a 51 percent decline from $7.9 million, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter that ended on July 31 fell 17 percent, to $36.2 million from $43.5 million. The chief financial officer, Frank W. Tilley, said in an interview that Carreker would have a profitable year and positive cash flow. Though Carreker does not give more specific forecasts, he said the company's order backlog for the current quarter, which ends on Oct. 31, totaled $23.6 million at the end of August. Carreker has had to restate profit and sales results since fiscal 1998 because some revenue was recorded too early. Some customers delayed payments because of the restatement, depressing first-quarter revenue and causing a loss, Mr. Tilley said. Carreker shares rose $1.75, or 34 percent, to $6.89.

title: A Passion For Blue And White

description: The state health agency has chosen Seattle for a halfway house for violent sex offenders, prompting protests from city officials. ''With so many people living, working, attending school and visiting this area, it is not appropriate for housing violent sexual predators,'' Mayor Greg Nickels said. The state is under a federal court order to find housing for convicted sex offenders being released from the state's Special Commitment Center on McNeil Island. Once it is built, the facility will house 12 violent sex offenders under 24-hour surveillance, state officials said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: ROCKWELL COLLINS REVISES FORECAST ON CASH FLOW

Rockwell Collins, based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, decided this month to make an additional $200 million contribution to its pension fund.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Thousands Enroll In 9/11 Study
description: More than 6,500 people signed up in the first six days to participate in a new multiyear study of the health consequences of the 9/11 terrorist attack, New York City officials said. The World Trade Center Health Registry, which began last Friday, is designed to track up to 200,000 people over the next 20 years and is open to people -- whether or not they have had any adverse health effects -- who were exposed to the dust and smoke from the disaster. Details and sign-up information are available at (866) 692-9827, and at 311, the city's information line. The information is also online at wtcregistry.org. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLANDER, GORDON D.
description: FRIEDLANDER--Gordon D. Died peacefully at home in Tarrytown, NY on September 9, 2003 at age 83. He is survived by his beloved wife Florence Covino and many loving nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews and very dear cousins in Germany. He was the son of the late eminent American sculptor Leo Friedlander. Mr. Friedlander was a professional engineer who studied at RPI and the University of Michigan. He had experience as a structural and project engineer and was engaged in the design and construction of fossil fuel and hydro-electric power plants. He worked for many of the leading engineering firms in New York and Toronto. He had several consulting assignments involving MIT, The Univeristy of VA and the Research Institute of America and lectured at several major universities. He was a senior editor of the IEE SPECTRUM of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and later served as generation editor of the magazine Electrical World. Mr. Friedlander's many accomplishments earned him a place in Who's Who In The East. He was a kind and gifted man who enjoyed many friendships here and abroad and who enriched the lives of all who knew him. He will be missed forever. A memorial service will be held at the Community Unitarian Church of White Plains NY on Sunday September 21 at 2:30 PM. Donations in his honor may be made to the Community Unitarian Church, New York Cornell Hospital or a charity of your choice.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Are Arrested In A.T.M. Thefts
description: The police arrested three men yesterday morning who are suspected of stealing automatic teller machines from businesses in Manhattan. The men, Angel Ortiz, 37, of Prospect Avenue in Brooklyn, Jose Rodriguez, 26, of Houston Street in Manhattan, and Alberto Lugo, 19, of 50th Street in Brooklyn, were arrested at 3:30 a.m. at Lane Market Farms, at 1391 Madison Avenue, between 97th and 98th Streets, as they were trying to remove an A.T.M., the police said. The police are investigating whether the men are responsible for similar burglaries in which a thief or thieves broke into stores and stole A.T.M.'s. Charges against the three men are pending, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: The head of Bank of America's mutual fund business, Robert H. Gordon, whose actions were highlighted in an investigation into improper trading of fund shares, left the company this week, executives who know him said last night.

title: Editorial Observer; When Racial Discrimination Is Not Just Black and White
description: The historian John Hope Franklin is black to the naked eye. A boulevard named in his honor runs through Greenwood, the black section of Tulsa, Okla., where he lived as a child. The Franklins are not just black, however, but also Native American. Milley Franklin, Mr. Franklin's grandmother, was one-quarter Choctaw and was raised as Choctaw, attending Indian schools. Her children -- including John Hope Franklin's father, the lawyer B. C. Franklin -- are clearly listed on the official tribal rolls that determined who was a member of the Choctaw Nation. The rolls were important, since tribal members got land when the reservations were dissolved.

description: First Midwest Bancorp, which operates bank branches in metropolitan Chicago, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CoVest Bancshares for $102.5 million. First Midwest said it would pay $27.45 a share for CoVest, which is based in Des Plaines, Ill. The acquisition will give First Midwest, based in Itasca, Ill., three branches in suburban Chicago and will be a good fit with the bank's acquisition of the O'Hare Financial Center earlier this year, the company said.

title: A Sudden Bout of Success
description: The wait for baseball glory has been interminable for three historic franchises, involving more lean, frustrating seasons than any loyal fan should have to endure. The unfulfilled expectations stretch back almost a century, several lifetimes of futility. If you love the Chicago Cubs, the Chicago White Sox or the Boston Red Sox, you learn to live with losing. Endless, endless losing.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS SOAR. Soybean prices climbed after the government lowered its crop estimate because of a Midwest drought. In Chicago, soybeans for November delivery rose 19.25 cents, or 3.2 percent, to $6.1575 a bushel.

title: An American in Japan, Making a Connection
description: The director Sofia Coppola's new comic melodrama, ''Lost in Translation,'' thoroughly and touchingly connects the dots between three standards of yearning in movies: David Lean's ''Brief Encounter,'' Richard Linklater's ''Before Sunrise'' and Wong Kar-wei's ''In the Mood for Love.'' All three movies are, in their way, about a moment of evanescence that fades before the participants' eyes -- as is ''Translation.'' (''Translation'' also exhibits the self-contained, stylized lonesomeness found in post-punk, like New Order's ''Bizarre Love Triangle.'')

title: Ill Scientist May Be Evacuated From Station at the South Pole
description: Rescue planes are flying from Canada to the southern tip of Chile to be ready to evacuate a seriously ill member of the scientific team at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station, the National Science Foundation said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TriQuint Shares Rise On Raised Forecast
description: Shares of TriQuint Semiconductor Inc., a maker of chips for mobile telephones, optical networks and military systems, rose 20 percent yesterday after the company raised its forecast for third-quarter sales. Ralph Quinsey, the chief executive, said new products were helping the company, based in Hillsboro, Ore., gain market share. Shipments and orders have improved this quarter, he said, citing demand for wireless-phone products. Shares gained $1.13, to $6.81. TriQuint's sales will rise to as much as $77 million, compared with a July forecast of as much as $74 million, TriQuint said. The company expects a loss of as much as 8 cents a share, narrower than its previous forecast for a loss of as much as 11 cents.

title: Some City Prisoners to Get Special Smocks to Thwart Suicide
description: People jailed in New York City who are considered potentially suicidal will soon be required to wear special one-piece garments that, unlike street clothes, cannot be fashioned into nooses.

title: Anna Lindh, 46, European Unity Backer
description: Anna Lindh, who died early yesterday at the age of 46 after a stabbing attack, was one of Sweden's most popular politicians. A lifelong member of the governing Social Democrats, she had been mentioned as a future party leader. In 1998, when she became foreign minister under Prime Minister Goran Persson, the Swedish press called her ''Persson's crown princess,'' seeing her as his likely successor.

title: S.&P. CUTS CREDIT RATING OF PARK PLACE ENTERTAINMENT
description: The credit rating of Park Place Entertainment, the world's largest casino company, was cut to a level below investment grade by Standard & Poor's yesterday because of concern that a $376 million expansion of Caesars Palace Las Vegas might hinder debt repayment. The rating was reduced one level, to BB+ from BBB-, Standard & Poor's said. Park Place, which had $4.7 billion in debt as of June 30, may face higher borrowing costs because of the downgrading. The expansion at Caesars Palace Las Vegas, along with lower-than-expected earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in the first six months of the year, is likely to slow Park Place's repayment of debt, Standard & Poor's said.

title: A Collector's-Eye Look at North American Indian Art
description: Maybe the best compliment one can give an art exhibition, especially one devoted to historical material, is that it makes you want to look long and close at everything on view and that the installation enhances this process. ''The Responsive Eye: Ralph T. Coe and the Collecting of American Indian Art'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art handily meets those goals. It puts on view a glorious promised gift from the collector Ralph T. Coe: more than 200 works, many hovering near masterpiece level, some dating from prehistoric times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGEL, DOROTHY LAPIN REINER
description: VOGEL--Dorothy Lapin Reiner. Died at the age of 87 after a short illness at her home in Sag Harbor, NY on September 1. Loving mother of Nora Reiner Gluck and Louise Reiner Baker. Loving grandmother of Benjamin Gluck and Janina Reiner. Dorothy was a poet, tennis player, folk singer, artist, advocate for civil and women's rights and peace activist. A private memorial service will be held at her home in Sag Harbor on October 26. Contributions may be made in her honor to East End Hospice 631-288-8400 and the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom 734761-7967.

description: Along with neat cubbies and welcome signs, preschoolers starting the year in the Addie Mae Collins Community Service Head Start program this week were greeted by something new -- two security guards.

title: Shockey Willing to Talk, But Not About Parcells
description: The last time Jeremy Shockey spoke at length to the news media, denials, apologies and a vow of silence quickly followed. So, before approaching a throng of cameras and notepads today, Shockey stopped for last-second instructions from Giants Coach Jim Fassel and then carefully chose his words to reporters.

description: THE crooked confluence of warping floor boards, fun-house steps and shaky wrought iron may not look like much, but it's my paradise.

title: Carnies, Dust Bowl, Apocalypse
description: HBO does not do drama lightly. ''Six Feet Under'' is bubbly compared to ''The Wire,'' a dense crime series that requires almost as much time and concentration as Thomas Pynchon. In December viewers will have to brace themselves for ''Angels in America,'' a six-hour HBO movie based on the epic plays of Tony Kushner, starring Meryl Streep and directed by Mike Nichols.

title: Redefinitions of Drawing Go to the Wall (and Off It)
description: Twice a year the Drawing Center mounts an exhibition of works by emerging artists discovered in its viewing program. The process, in which artists are invited to show their work to the gallery for possible exhibition, regularly turns up interesting aspirants. But the shows are rarely more than mildly exciting, and the current 14-artist installment, ''Internal Excess,'' is no exception.

title: Zankel Hall, Carnegie's Buried Treasure
description: ZANKEL HALL may persuade you to rethink your attitude toward underground spaces. Technically, it may be in a sub-subbasement just inches away from hell. Architecturally, the new hall couldn't feel more privileged. Designed by James Stewart Polshek and Richard M. Olcott of the Polshek Partnership, the Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall is a serene, grown-up place, made for a maximum of 644 listeners who like to concentrate together at the same place and time.

title: FPL AGREES TO BUY HALF OF AMERGEN FROM BRITISH ENERGY
description: The FPL Group, owner of Florida's largest utility, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy British Energy's 50 percent stake in AmerGen Energy for $276.5 million. AmerGen owns the Three Mile Island Unit 1 nuclear plant in Pennsylvania and two other United States reactors. Combined, the plants have the capacity to generate 2,480 megawatts, enough power for about two million homes. Exelon, which owns the other half, has 30 days to match the bid, FPL said. FPL said it would sell stock to help finance the purchase. The company would receive $8.3 million from British Energy should Exelon elect to buy all of AmerGen. British Energy wants to sell AmerGen to cut debt.

description: The resurgent Taliban has embarked on a strategy of small guerrilla attacks intended to frustrate and steadily bleed American forces in Afghanistan and to force the United States to expend billions of dollars in military costs, according to two Taliban officials interviewed recently.

title: The Cancn Delusion
description: The World Trade Organization meeting in Cancn, Mexico, has highlighted a surprising new cause, promoted by a surprising new alliance. The new cause is the campaign to reduce or eliminate agricultural subsidies in the United States, Europe and Japan, to make room for agricultural exports from poor nations. The alliance between idealists of the left, third world producers and traditional conservative promoters of free trade is equally unprecedented.

title: Guitar in His Hand, Revenge in His Heart
description: Judging from the opening credits of ''Once Upon a Time in Mexico,'' Robert Rodriguez, whose antic spirit also animates the ''Spy Kids'' franchise, is both becomingly modest and a bit of a control freak. The movie, the latest in his series of gaudy post-modern folk ballads about a gun-toting guitarist (Antonio Banderas) known mainly as El (as in the), is unassumingly presented as a Robert Rodriguez flick. His technical contributions are enumerated in similarly stripped-down lingo. The credits for cinematography, editing and music are summed up as follows: shot, chopped and scored by Robert Rodriguez. This is sufficiently unusual -- and impressive -- to make the ''written and directed by'' credit seem like an afterthought.

title: Inquiry Ordered After Release Of Suspect in 7-Year-Old's Death
description: The Essex County executive asked a special investigator today to determine how the teenage suspect in the death of a 7-year-old boy, whose killing led to sweeping changes in the state's child welfare system, was mistakenly released from jail.

description: Airports across the country appeared light on passengers and heavy on security today, even by the standards of a post-Sept. 11 world conscious that any airplane loaded with jet fuel is a potential terrorist weapon.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: GHANA: SLAVE BOYS GO HOME Nearly 200 boys, some as young as 4, were reunited with the families who sold them to Lake Volta fishermen as laborers, local officials said. The fishermen buy the youngsters for up to $180 because their fingers are nimble enough to work the tiny mesh of their nets. Some 3,000 children are thought to be involved. The return of the children was organized by the International Organization for Migration in Geneva, which ensured that their parents and the fishermen got farm tools, building materials and training in other ways to make money.    (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Real Estate Plan
description: China has approached Hong Kong about buying 25,000 vacant public housing units valued at about 20 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.6 billion), a government official in Hong Kong said. ''They have conveyed to us their idea and the concept of solving the overhang of flats,'' said Timothy Li, a spokesman for the Housing, Planning and Lands Bureau, who added, ''It's too early for us to say whether we will sell the flats.'' The China National Real Estate Development Group suggested turning the apartments into budget hotel rooms, The Standard, a Hong Kong newspaper, reported. Officials at National Real Estate, which is controlled by China's cabinet, could not be reached for comment. ''Changing the usage of the flats will help the property market,'' said Sam Ho, an analyst at the East Asia Management Company. ''At the same time, Hong Kong needs more low-end hotel accommodation because of the rise in mainland tourism.''

description: ''It's time to move on but it's not time to forget.''

title: Galen and Barr Make Deal on Drug Rights and Patents
description: Galen Holdings P.L.C., a pharmaceutical company in Northern Ireland that specializes in health care products for women, will sell the rights in the United States and Canada for Loestrin, an oral contraceptive, to Barr Laboratories of Pomona, N.Y., for $45 million, the companies announced today. Galen will also settle Barr's legal challenge to the patents on two other drugs by giving Barr a nonexclusive license to make generic versions of them six months before their patents expire.

title: U.S. Soldiers Are Said to Kill Iraqi Policemen by Mistake
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Sept. 12 - American soldiers mistakenly killed at least eight Iraqi policemen and a Jordanian hospital employee in an early-morning firefight today outside a hospital here, Iraqi police and local residents said.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Says Cheney Must Provide Documents
description: The full Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit let stand a panel's decision ordering Vice President Dick Cheney to give the Sierra Club documents from his task force on energy. Mr. Cheney has claimed executive privilege in keeping the documents secret. Some papers made public so far through the Freedom of Information Act have shown that the task force met with oil, gas, nuclear and coal interests in developing its plan. No decision has been made on an appeal. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Dave Matthews Band Sets Free Concert
description: The Dave Matthews Band will play a free concert on Sept. 24 in Central Park to benefit public education, says the band's Web site, www.davematthews.com.

description: UNWANTED human and animal visitors to a second home can be an aggressive lot, unless they're caught by surprise. Sudden lights, noise and movement from seemingly benign sources can be very effective break-in busters. Our favorite sentries are perfect all-weather house sitters, too. They never sleep, eat or take a break. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Something's Rotten Out in the Woods
description: Making a satisfying horror film is as difficult as cooking a perfect risotto. Split-second timing and a meticulous balance of ingredients are critical for achieving a rich but chewy consistency. The elements that make up ''Cabin Fever,'' a movie that finds an unusually potent blend of dread, gore and gallows humor, are as commonplace as rice, butter, cheese and broth.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Lower Outlook At Bic
description: The world's largest maker of disposable pens, Socit Bic, said its first-half profit fell 7.4 percent, to 60 million euros, amid increased competition for disposable lighters and razors. The company, which is based in Paris, said sales fell 13 percent, to 676 million euros. Bic is vying with competitors like Gillette, whose Mach3 and Mach3 Turbo razors generate more than $2 billion of sales a year. Bic is trying to increase sales of higher-margin goods by introducing products like Comfort 3, a three-blade razor, as demand for its single-blade brands falls.

title: High Tuition Debts And Low Pay Drain Public Interest Law
description: Often saddled with huge debts taken on to pay for their legal educations, more and more law school graduates are finding it hard to work in low-paying positions as public defenders, legal aid lawyers and -- notwithstanding the popularity of ''Law and Order'' -- prosecutors.

title: PLAN APPROVED FOR NATURAL GAS TERMINAL IN LOUISIANA
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said yesterday that it had approved a plan for a liquefied natural gas import terminal in Hackberry, La., making it the first such project in the United States in more than 20 years. The terminal, called Cameron LNG, will be able to receive tanker shipments of supercold natural gas. It will hold the equivalent of 3.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas and will include a 35.4-mile pipeline to facilities in Beauregard Parish, La. Sempra Energy, which acquired the project in May from Dynegy, will build the terminal. The project is one of about 20, many in the Gulf Coast, seeking regulatory approval as energy companies rush to meet demand for natural gas by importing from developing countries. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Early Warnings
description: Ethylene glycol ethers are a group of organic solvents that proved to be extremely effective at coating surfaces evenly. They've been used in paints, nail polish, de-icers and many other products. One of their most important industrial applications was in the semiconductor industry. These marvelous chemicals, E.G.E.'s, were the key ingredients in a solution used in the fabrication of computer chips.

title: Sparring Seattle Papers Can't Even Agree to Break Up
description: The convoluted process of determining whether Seattle will remain one of the few big cities with two daily newspapers, and if so for how long, begins in earnest today in State Superior Court.

title: State Senate Democrats Return to Texas
description: Vowing defiance, feeling homesick and in one case nursing a broken shoulder from an ice skating accident, the reduced band of Texas Democrats who fled the Republican-controlled State Senate more than six weeks ago are back on home soil, returning from New Mexico for a showdown next week in Austin.

''Europe is a great place to drive,'' he said. ''The speed limits are higher than the U.S. The roads are more challenging.'' His company car, a Renault minivan, was just not going to cut it.

title: Suing Music Downloaders
description: Suing a 12-year-old girl for illegal file sharing is hardly a way to generate good press. But the music industry was intentionally ''playing the heavy,'' in the words of its main lobbying group, when it filed lawsuits this week against Brianna LaHara and 260 other alleged online music swappers. Music companies are right to aggressively pursue people, even minors, who steal their products, but that alone will not solve their problems. They need to change how they do business, and fast, if they want to survive in the 21st century.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Liechtenstein: Monitoring Democracy
description: Concerned that recent constitutional amendments return absolute power to Liechtenstein's prince, a Council of Europe committee recommended monitoring democratic processes there. The constitutional changes, approved by voters in March, let Prince Hans Adam II exercise power at will. The Liechtenstein government responded that the country is a ''vibrant democracy.'' If the recommendation is approved, Liechtenstein would join 10 other European countries being monitored. Alison Langley (NYT)

description: MANHATTAN: DOWNTOWN BUILDING OWNER SUES Deutsche Bank sued New York State yesterday, contending that the state was negligent in failing to protect the bank's headquarters building, at 130 Liberty Street, after the collapse of the World Trade Center towers. The lawsuit follows the dismissal last month of a similar complaint against New York City. Both actions were filed in United States District Court in Manhattan. title: Dad's Furious, Son's Broke And the Grandson's Cute
description: John Amos's capacity to be furious and funny at the same time -- Archie Bunker-style -- propels WB's new show ''All About the Andersons'' as far as it goes. As far as it goes is about halfway to sitcom deliverance, the point at which viewers will forgive the intrusiveness of the laugh track and yield to its rhythms. ''All About the Andersons,'' which has its premiere tonight, is not at that point, but if Mr. Amos's role were expanded it could be.

title: The Refractions of Coltrane
description: John Coltrane's style has been an amplifier for four decades of saxophonists: they plug themselves into it, and though different things come out, they're all mediated by the same source. Pharoah Sanders, 14 years younger than Coltrane, recorded and performed with him at the end of his life, in the mid-1960's. Kenny Garrett came along in the 1980's. They're bigger than themselves, in a sense, each representing something crucial about the jazz improvising of his time.

title: Middle East Math
description: No one who witnessed the first years of Israeli-Palestinian reconciliation will forget them -- the tentative embraces, the joint patrols and business ventures, the mutual visits by ordinary citizens. Tomorrow marks the 10th anniversary of the handshake and signature by Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat on the South Lawn of the White House, a luminous moment of hope that turned into a vicious tangle of mutual disdain symbolized by yesterday's ill-conceived announcement by Israel that it was planning to expel Mr. Arafat. The problem all along has been that certain things never changed -- anti-Israel terror and incitement on the Palestinian side, extensive Jewish settlement building in the West Bank and Gaza Strip by Israel. Together, they have brought the process to its knees.

title: 36 Hours | Camden, Me.
description: THE Maine coast around Camden is so stony, cold and forbidding that for centuries visitors came only to collect shiploads of granite and limestone. In the 19th century, however, intrepid painters like Thomas Cole and Frederick E. Church let out the secret that the Penobscot Bay's rocky pine-covered cliffs and mountains made for pretty spectacular scenery. In the 1880's, when steamships made Camden an easy trip from Boston, rich New Yorkers and Philadelphians known as ''rusticators'' discovered Penobscot Bay in their search for a more authentic immersion in nature than could be found in summer resorts like Lennox and Newport. Their descendants and successors still inhabit the islands of Vinalhaven, North Haven and Isleboro over the summer, sometimes sailing to Camden to pick up groceries or just the morning paper. Camden is no longer so undiscovered. Its merchants are now well aware that their town is picture-book Maine, and they hang ''Lobsta Festival'' and ''Maine Maple Syrup'' signs in their windows to tempt out-of-state eyes. But still, who can deny the charms of a little steamed ''lobsta'' and a glass of white wine as twilight settles over the harbor and the mountains? DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Manhattan diners intent on finding out-of-the way places may finally meet their match in the Restaurant at Splashlight Studios. In a neighborhood where trucks outnumber people, and sidewalks can be deserted at high noon, it has the lonely, defiant air of a fort on the Western frontier. The restaurant, in a large industrial building that has been converted into a digital photo studio, feels a little like a company canteen, but it may turn out to be a lifeline for harried visitors to the nearby Javits Center. The dcor is cool and industrial, with concrete floors, severe chairs and punishing acoustics. The food is hip, modern and hit or miss. The people watching can be world class, depending on who's booked for a photo shoot.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Wins First Trial On Ink Cartridges
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company yesterday won the first trial of almost three dozen lawsuits accusing it of duping consumers by selling them new printers with cartridges that were only half-full of ink. A jury at a state court in Hillsborough, N.C., found that consumers typically did not expect the cartridge in new printers to be the same as replacement cartridges they bought, said Richard McCune, a lawyer for the consumers. The North Carolina suit, certified as a class action, was the first to go to trial over this issue, and the jury verdict could affect the outcome of other pending cases, Mr. McCune said. Analysts and investors have said ink cartridges are the most profitable part of Hewlett-Packard's business as consumers often buy replacements. Hewlett-Packard began putting in half-filled cartridges in 1998 and told consumers only in 2001 after it was sued, he said. Class-action lawsuits have been filed, in coordination with the original consumers who brought suit, in 32 other states, the company said in a filing. Courts in 13 other states have found no basis for class-action suits on this matter, a Hewlett-Packard spokeswoman, Rebeca Robboy, said, adding that the company was confident that it would win ''copycat lawsuits'' in other states.

title: A Three-Ring House of Music, Willing and Able to Surprise
description: ONE thing Robert J. Harth insisted on, in mapping out the inaugural season at the Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall, is that there not be an opening night. He argues vehemently that the hall's first 22 concerts should be taken whole as a festival, rather than as a debut event followed by two packed weeks of performances. He points out that when the hall opens its doors tonight, it will be for not one, but two concerts -- a program of modern chamber orchestra works, conducted by the composer John Adams at 7, and a jazz concert by the Omar Sosa Octet at 10. But as the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, he realizes that ultimately this is a quixotic argument, and when a literal-minded visitor observes that Mr. Adams's concert is nevertheless the opener, he throws up his hands with a good-natured laugh.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Challenge To 'Recovery' Of Sturgeon
description: Scientists working to save the beluga sturgeon, whose caviar is the most valuable wildlife commodity, are strongly challenging a declaration by a United Nations organization that the Caspian Sea sturgeon is recovering from decades of overfishing. Cites, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, endorsing Russian data, said stocks rose 24 percent. But such an increase ''is not biologically possible,'' said Dr. Ellen Pikitch of the Wildlife Conservation Society. Kazakhstan fisheries officials say beluga catches in the Ural River, the main spawning ground, are continuing to fall. Christopher Pala (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Waste Disposal Investigation
description: The German utility RWE and almost 120 other waste-disposal companies were searched by the country's antitrust regulator and a public prosecutor in a price-fixing investigation, the regulator said. The Federal Cartel Office in Bonn and the Cologne-based prosecutor are investigating suspected fraud and antitrust violations relating to 3.6 billion euros ($4 billion) of contracts with Duales System Deutschland, the dominant waste recycler in Germany. RWE was among those that were searched, said Peter Werz, a spokesman for the company's waste-management unit. Frank-Rainer Billigmann, managing director of BDE, a lobbying group for the waste-disposal industry, said that the allegations were unfounded.
