title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: RESPONSE TO U.S. ON MILITARY BUDGET The official media accused the Pentagon, in its annual report in July, of "wantonly misrepresenting" China's policy and overstating the amount China spends on the military. The report detailed China's acquisition of Russian-designed fighter aircraft, destroyers and submarines, and its new missile deployments and preparations for cyber-warfare. The Chinese press, including the Liberation Army Daily, did not specifically rebut many factual assertions, but said American military analysts misunderstood Chinese intentions. The article said the Pentagon was exaggerating a "China threat" to justify increased arms sales to Taiwan. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: COURT SAYS CHENEY MUST PROVIDE DOCUMENTS The full Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit let stand a panel's decision ordering Vice President Dick Cheney to give the Sierra Club documents from his task force on energy. Mr. Cheney has claimed executive privilege in keeping the documents secret. Some papers made public so far through the Freedom of Information Act have shown that the task force met with oil, gas, nuclear and coal interests in developing its plan. No decision has been made on an appeal.    Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Rangers Receive Word: Bure Unfit to Play
description: As expected, the Rangers got bad news today when the players took their physicals. Pavel Bure, the 32-year-old right wing, was declared medically unfit to play because of the deteriorating condition of his right knee.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about changes in foreign views of the United States since Sept. 11, 2001, misspelled the surname of a Russian literary critic who was quoted. He is Dmitri Olshansky, not Ostalsky.

title: The Long Road From Idea to DVD
description: Directors love DVD but don't think it replaces movie theaters. "We're going to work so hard and go straight to video? Hell, no," says Gene Cajayon on a disc of "The Debut," his modest, winning first feature, released this week by Columbia TriStar.

title: Another 9/11, And a Nation Mourns Again
description: Two years after terrorists turned commercial jetliners into missiles bearing down on quintessential symbols of American wealth and power, the nation paused yesterday to remember the 3,016 fathers and mothers and friends who did not come home that day.

title: Microsoft Doubles Annual Cash Payout
description: Nine months after declaring its first-ever dividend payout, the Microsoft Corporation said this morning that its board had approved a doubling in the size of its annual cash payout, to 16 cents a share.

title: Paris Journal; A Thin Blue Line Rolls Where Peugeots Roam
description: They roll faster than a speeding scooter, they jump curbs in a single bound. Regarde, crossing the boulevard! It's an errant hockey player, it's an office messenger on wheels, it's the French in-line skating police!

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Sentence For Bogus Tax Refunds
description: A federal district judge has sentenced a Mobile accountant to three years in prison for his scheme to apply for bogus tax refunds for black clients on the basis of historical discrimination. Through his Web site, the accountant, James D. Buckley, 46, promised clients across the country $40,000 refunds, saying they were based on tax overpayments made by generations of black Americans that lived without civil rights, said Charlie McNichol, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office. Mr. Buckley must also return a total of $59,000 to 489 victims. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Returning From Iraq War Not So Simple for Soldiers
description: Susan W. Wilder paced the auditorium here like a motivational speaker and asked the new veterans of the war in Iraq what pleased them most now that they were, at last, home.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: County Prosecutor Is Nominated
description: Paula T. Dow, counsel to the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, and the third-ranking official in the 130-lawyer office, was nominated today to be the Essex County prosecutor by Gov. James E. McGreevey. Ms. Dow, a 1980 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania Law School, served as an assistant United States attorney in Manhattan for seven years before joining the New Jersey federal prosecutor's office in 1994. She was appointed counsel in March 2002. Ms. Dow would take over the office from the acting prosecutor, Donald C. Campolo, a career official with the State Division of Criminal Justice, who ran the office after Patricia Hurt was forced to resign in 1999 amid charges of mismanagement. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: To the Samurai and Godzilla, With Love
description: According to emerging conventional wisdom in Hollywood, the triumph of 3-D computer animation, exemplified this summer by the smashing success of ''Finding Nemo,'' means that old-fashioned flat animation is obsolete. The failure of DreamWorks's dreadful ''Sinbad'' was widely taken as confirmation of this notion. But the idea does not take account of a very large fact, which is the existence of Japan, where two-dimensional animation, or anime, is experiencing an astonishing artistic vitality.

title: Columbia Debris to Find a Resting Place at the Space Center
description: NASA officials said today that the wreckage of the space shuttle Columbia would be moved starting next week to its final resting place: an unused room on the 16th floor of the same building here at the Kennedy Space Center where it was prepared for its last mission.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: WASHINGTON: CHURCH SETTLES ABUSE SUITS The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Seattle said it had agreed to pay $7.87 million to settle suits brought by 15 men who say they were sexually molested as boys by the Rev. James McGreal. Court documents said the archdiocese knew of the accusation against Father McGreal as early as the late 1960's. He resigned in 1988 after accusations of abuse became public and has never been charged with a crime. He now lives in a locked treatment center for priests in Missouri.    (AP)

title: Trying to Make His Special Students Feel Ordinary
description: AFTER what surely is one of the most taxing summers he has ever faced, Bill Salzman shows remarkably little sign of wear.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Court Urged To Manage Agency
description: Lawyers who sued the Connecticut Department of Children and Families for negligence in 1989 asked a federal court yesterday to assume management of the agency. The two plaintiffs, Children's Rights of Manhattan and the Center for Child Advocacy at the University of Connecticut School of Law, filed the request after a report issued in August found that the agency substantially failed to meet the standards of a 1991 court settlement in areas like providing proper mental health and dental care for children in state custody. After a 30-day negotiation period and a hearing, a court monitor will make a recommendation on the request to a federal judge, said Ira P. Lustbader, associate director of Children's Rights. Officials of the state agency did not return calls seeking comment. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: For Mets' Howe, A Losing Experience
description: It was Wednesday morning, a little more than an hour before the Mets played the Florida Marlins, and, all things considered, it was a good time to be at Shea Stadium. The Mets had not lost yet and Art Howe, winding down his first season as the Mets' manager, was upbeat, walking through the bullpen as the pitching coach, Vern Ruhle, instructed Jeremy Griffiths, one of the 16 rookies on the roster.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Response To U.S. On Military Budget
description: The official media accused the Pentagon, in its annual report in July, of ''wantonly misrepresenting'' China's policy and overstating the amount China spends on the military. The report detailed China's acquisition of Russian-designed fighter aircraft, destroyers and submarines, and its new missile deployments and preparations for cyber-warfare. The Chinese press, including the Liberation Army Daily, did not specifically rebut many factual assertions, but said American military analysts misunderstood Chinese intentions. The article said the Pentagon was exaggerating a ''China threat'' to justify increased arms sales to Taiwan. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, PETER R.
description: WEISS--Peter R. of Montclair, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, on September 6, 2003. Cherished husband of Margaret Schmidt; dear son of the late Louis and Charlotte (Friedman) Weiss; dear son-in-law of Thomas and Margaret (Di Cocco) Schmidt; dear nephew of Edwin and Edith Friedman, Antoinette and the late Robert Friedman, the late Philip and Martha Kerr and the late Howard and Edith Geffner; dear nephewin-law of Ann Di Cocco, Frank and the late Pauline Di Cocco, Louis and Olga Schmidt, Joseph and the late Doris Schmidt, Marie and the late William Schmidt; dear brother-in-law of Dr. Ann Marie Schmidt and her husband, Dr. Paul Fondacaro, and Thomas Schmidt and his wife, Nancy; beloved lifelong friend of Barbara (Rothman) Bergeron and Annelise Rothman; dearest friend of Judith Locorriere; dear uncle of Matthew Fondacaro and Daniel, John and Nicholas Schmidt; also survived by many cousins, other relatives and friends; great benefactor of Mystery and Terrapin. A private memorial service will be held.

title: U.S. Wary Of Steps By Israelis On Arafat
description: Responding to Israel's threat to expel Yasir Arafat, the Bush administration avoided direct criticism, instead repeating its stance that ousting the Palestinian leader would ''not be helpful'' and could be counterproductive.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CAMDEN: PLOT DEFENDANT TO BE TRIED AS ADULT A 15-year-old boy accused of planning a killing rampage in Oaklyn with two other teenagers will be tried as an adult, a judge ruled yesterday in Camden County Superior Court. Cody Jackson, left, and his companions were arrested on July 6, carrying an assortment of firearms and more than 2,000 rounds of ammunition, and Mr. Jackson now faces charges of conspiracy to commit murder, carjacking and aggravated assault by pointing a weapon. Defense lawyers had said Mr. Jackson should be tried as a juvenile, contending that he was pressured into the plot by 18-year-old Matthew Lovett and pointing out that the defendants surrendered without firing a shot. Judge Louis F. Hornstine said that trying Mr. Jackson in adult court could deter other teens from similar behavior. If convicted, Mr. Jackson could face more than 40 years in prison. Jessica Bruder (NYT)

title: Aide Steps In for Pope at an Airport to Finish a Garbled Speech to Slovaks
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today to beseech Slovaks not to follow Western Europe's drift from Christianity, but he could not deliver that message in his own strained, trembling voice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Contractor Cuts Loss
description: The military contract-or BAE Systems reported a loss of 47 million ($74.9 million) for the first six months of 2003, an improvement from last year's first-half loss of 63 million ($100.4 million), on a strong performance from its North American unit and good results from its operations in Britain. The chief executive, Mike Turner, said that the company expected that earnings over all would be flat in 2003. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: A WEAPONS CHARGE The former stepfather of an American soldier accused of a deadly grenade attack on his own unit in Kuwait pleaded guilty on Wednesday to illegally possessing four guns. The defendant, William M. Bilal, 56, a convicted felon, was married for five years to the mother of Sgt. Hasan Akbar, who is accused of killing two soldiers and wounding 14 others in a March attack on his 101st Airborne unit in Kuwait. A few weeks after the attack, the authorities, acting on a tip, seized weapons, ammunition and body armor from Mr. Bilal's home. They said there was no connection between the firearms charges and the attack in Kuwait. (AP)

description: More than two years after closing to the general public, the White House and the rotunda of the National Archives are reopening to visitors.

description: SHORE -- Dorothy Kimmel man, (of Philadelphia), died peacefully on September 10, 2003, a truly elegant lady, beloved wife of the late William Shore, devoted mother of Madge Shore Miller, of New York City and Joan Shore Steinhouse, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, cherished grandmother of Jennifer Miller Symonds, Darcy Miller Nussbaum, Jonathan Ian Steinhouse, Peter Leigh Steinhouse and Nancy Steinhouse Rosenthal. A great grandmother to seven great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Sunday, September 14, 2003, 12:30 PM at the Roosevelt Memorial Park, (Section E) Trevose, Bucks Co. PA, (Just north of Philadelphia). The daughters will receive family and friends at their respective homes from 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM for 2 days following the day of the service. She was greatly loved and will be sorely missed by all who knew her. The family respectfully requests that contributions in her memory be made to The Friends of Rittenhouse Square, or to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. Joseph Levine & Son www.levinefuneral.com

description: Inside the mayor's office here in Connecticut's largest and second-poorest city, a door in the corner leads to a secret staircase and supersecure magnetic locks seal the main entrance.

description: The Treasury Department issued new tax rules yesterday that sharply reduce the appeal of a life insurance benefit that corporations have provided for decades to top executives like Martha Stewart, Ralph Lauren and Ted Turner.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) — Mortgage rates around the nation were slightly lower this week, ending a string of gains that reached back to mid-June, Freddie Mac , the mortgage company, said today.

description: The families of victims killed in a 1989 terrorist attack on a French airliner said today that they had reached a preliminary agreement with Libya that would eventually provide extra financial compensation.

Bloomberg was denouncing efforts in Congress to shield firearms makers from lawsuits, his criminal justice coordinator was criticizing a City Council initiative to make such suits easier.

description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a man accused of breaking into the computer network of The New York Times may remain free on $250,000 bond and must continue to restrict his use of computers.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the nuclear physicist Edward Teller on Thursday misstated the number of hydrogen atoms that join to make helium in the fusion process. It is four, not two.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Saturday with an article about the life of Malcolm X's grandson Malcolm Shabazz, who set a fire in 1997 that resulted in the death of his grandmother, Dr. Betty Shabazz, misstated the place and time. Dr. Shabazz was shown at the New York premiere of the movie ''Malcolm X'' in 1992, not at a Nation of Islam meeting in Harlem in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ZIMMETH, LEAH
description: ZIMMETH--Leah. Loved for all of her 95 years, she will always be in our hearts and will be missed forever by her beloved daughter Meryl Slater and Ira Kader, grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the decision by John Edwards of North Carolina to leave the Senate and about the challenges it creates for Democrats hoping to keep his seat misstated the year in which Republicans won four open Senate seats in the South. It was 2002, not 2000.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Sept. 5 about ''Party Monster'' misstated the crime that led to the imprisonment of Michael Alig, the 1980's party promoter whose life is the basis for the movie. He pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter, not murder. The review also misspelled the surname of the victim. He was Angel Melendez, not Menendez.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKENNAN, DAVE
description: McKENNAN--Dave. Beloved husband of Betsy Adams. Loving son of Doris and Robert McKennan. Ideal sonin-law of Margot and Mason Adams. Best brother of Debby McKennan, Don McKennan and Jane Rottenbach. Cherished brother-in-law of Bill Adams and Alix Pearlstein. A special man cherished by all who knew him. Memorial services Sunday, September 28, 7pm at Matawan United Methodist Church, Aberdeen, NJ; Monday, September 29, 6pm at City Center, 55 St. between 6th and 7th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Dave McKennan Memorial Fund, c/o Community Funds, Inc., 2 Park Ave., NY 10016.

title: John Ritter, 54, the Odd Man In 'Three's Company,' Is Dead
description: John Ritter, who played the lovably goofy closet heterosexual Jack Tripper in the television comedy series ''Three's Company,'' a smash hit in the 1970's, died on Thursday night in Burbank, Calif. He was 54.

title: Yells Replace Yawns In a Texas Ballot Ritual
description: Yup, it's constitutional amendment time again in Texas. Time for another stab at improving, or at any rate expanding, an already enormous document of 82,800 words, more than eight times as long as the federal Constitution, that has been amended no fewer than 410 times since 1876, according to the Texas Legislative Reference Library. And 174 other efforts failed.

title: Israel Rejects Wide Criticism of Its Threat to Exile Arafat
description: Israel fended off worldwide criticism today of its decision in principle to oust Yasir Arafat, even though it seemed unlikely to carry out the threat, at least for now.

description: To the Editor:

title: Cargill Challenges Pork Giant With Rival Bid for Farmland Foods
description: Cargill Inc., one of the nation's biggest food processors, made a bid today to acquire Farmland Foods, a big pork processor, for $385 million in cash.

title: A Trio With Symmetry
description: When a pianist, a violinist and a cellist join to present a chamber concert they usually get around to playing a piano trio, even if the rest of the program is devoted to music for smaller combinations. There's no law saying it has to be that way, of course, but it seems a sensible and symmetrical use of the resources at hand, and an almost inevitable musical consummation.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Air Alliance Talks
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines confirmed that its talks with Air France about a possible alliance were in an advanced stage but said that no final deal had been reached. Dutch and French media are speculating that an alliance, possibly a merger, could be announced as early as next week. But KLM said that it was still in negotiations to ensure that it retained its Dutch identity as well as landing rights around the world, which are generally awarded country by country. KLM also wants to preserve its existing alliance with Northwest Airlines and wants to ensure that Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam retains its status as one of Europe's largest hubs. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Soft Voice Urges Europe to Carry A Bigger Stick
description: Tzvetan Todorov is something of an outsider in French intellectual circles. Born in Bulgaria on the eve of World War II, he was raised and educated under a Stalinist regime before moving to France in 1963. He is married to the Canadian novelist Nancy Huston, and he frequently lectures at American universities. His life has required him to see the world from different angles. As a social critic, historian and moral philosopher, he is a man of nuances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RITTER, JOHN
description: RITTER--John. The Officers and Board of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with deep sorrow the passing of our longtime friend and supporter John Ritter. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife Amy Yasbeck and his children Stella, Jayson, Tyler and Carly. Leo Hausman, Chairman UCP of NYC, Inc.

title: Mayor's Survey Is Asking: How Did We Do in Blackout?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg invited public comments yesterday about the city's handling of the recent blackout, but emphasized that he was looking for constructive criticism, not finger-pointing.

title: Bred For Power
description: If you were to pick a presidential candidate on the basis of social standing -- and really, darling, who doesn't -- you'd have to pick Howard Brush Dean III over George Walker Bush. The Bush lineage is fine. I'm not criticizing. But the Deans have been here practically since Mayflower days and in the Social Register for generations. It's true Bush's grandfather was a Wall Street financier, a senator and a Yale man, but Dean's family has Wall Street financiers going back to the Stone Age, and both his grandfathers were Yale men.

title: Ground Zero Plan Seems to Circle Back
description: When the revised master plan for the rebuilding of the World Trade Center is released this month, it will include scores of changes to Daniel Libeskind's design, both major alterations and minor refinements, many of them never before seen in public.

description: ABC executives, anguished by the unexpected death of John Ritter Thursday night, now face the problem of whether to continue producing his show, the most popular comedy on the network.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Oil Rig Collapses
description: An oil rig collapsed off the coast of Louisiana and Mississippi, tipping drilling equipment and 41 workers into the Gulf of Mexico. Commercial vessels in the area and the Coast Guard rescued the workers. One of them was hospitalized, said the Parker Drilling Company, which owns the rig. The rig held 10,500 gallons of diesel fuel, but the amount of fuel leaked is minimal, the Coast Guard said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: The Plague of Lead Poisoning
description: The federal goal to eliminate lead poisoning in children by 2010 seemed achievable when it was set in 1991. With bans on leaded gasoline and paint in place, progress has been made -- the number of cases detected has fallen by 50 percent. Still, hundreds of thousands of small children, most of them black, Hispanic and Asian, face one of the most preventable environmental hazards in the nation by simply breathing inside their homes.

title: Parsing the President
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Grapes and Culture in Romania
description: THE city of Iasi was already vivid in my mind. Not because it is the capital of Moldavia province, in the northeast of Romania near the Ukrainian border, nor because it's home to an old university and beautiful churches. But because in 1876, when Iasi (pronounced yahsh) was a lively Jewish center, the world's first performance of Yiddish theater took place in a wine garden there called Pomul Verde (the Green Tree). Last fall I attended a conference organized by the Romanian Ministry of Culture to commemorate the Yiddish theater's creator, a flamboyant down-at-the-heel intellectual named Avrom Goldfadn. Before leaving, I pictured myself on a bench in the old Green Tree, glass in hand.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Judge Reopens Qaeda Case
description: A high court judge has reopened a case against four men suspected of having links to Al Qaeda who were arrested in January but released when the supposed chemical weapons material found in their possession turned out to be laundry soap and other household products. Judge Guillermo Ruiz Polanco called the men to testify after receiving an F.B.I. laboratory report that said the chemicals, when mixed with the right elements, could produce a homemade version of napalm. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: LUXURY PROFITS RISE The French lux- ury group LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported that net profit rose 24 percent, to 265 million euros ($297 million), in the first half of 2003, helped by cost-cutting measures. The group's operating income rose 4 percent, to 874 million euros ($980 million), despite the fall of the dollar and a drop in tourism during that period. "These results reflect the exceptional capacity of our leading brands to increase market share whatever the circumstances," said Bernard Arnault, above, the chief executive. LVMH said it was banking on the rise of the dollar exchange rate this summer and the recovery of the tourism industry to confirm its growth objective for 2003. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

description: Neil Parry, a special-teams player on the San Jose State football team, walked into the room and took a seat. He seemed ordinary enough. He didn't even limp.

Mark was a man of great integrity and compassion. He will be remembered as a gentle man and a gentleman. Services 1 PM, Sunday, September 14, Congregation Beth Mordecai, 224 High St., Perth Amboy, NJ.

description: A few years after the end of World War II, George Orwell wrote that the ''the word Fascism has now no meaning except in so far as it signifies 'something not desirable.' ''

title: Old Cities, Full of Life: London
description: The Savoy Grill has always represented English dining at its most stodgily traditional: the sumptuous roasts on their shiny carving trolley; the bevy of old-school waiters; the genteel decor suggesting an exclusive gentleman's club. Completely overhauling this stately old icon to give it a new, modern feel, and a new, modern menu, requires a certain bravery, but that is what its owners have done, reflecting a major trend in London restaurants this fall.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Second Illness At South Pole
description: A day after announcing that rescue planes had been dispatched from Canada to Chile to be ready to evacuate a seriously ill worker at the South Pole, the National Science Foundation confirmed that a second employee at the Amundsen-Scott Research Station is ill. That man, Tony Black, recently had a mild heart attack. His condition was first reported on Wednesday by KHOU-TV in Houston. The science foundation, which manages the polar research station, said Mr. Black was in reasonably good health and would probably not be evacuated. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Unchanged

The Bank of Japan also said it would study whether to extend the maximum maturity date for the buying and selling of Japanese government securities using repurchase agreements. Ken Belson (NYT)

''It's another burial of my boy,'' he said quietly, as the 13 aye votes and two abstentions, by the United States and France, were tallied inside the lofty chamber.

title: The Line Cash Walked
description: Johnny Cash was as down-home as they come. Born in a shack in Arkansas to a family of farmers and living most of his life in the vicinity of Nashville, he sang about venerable country subjects like trains, work, cowboys, jail, temptations, guitars and God. But what made him an American icon were the ways he was like no country singer before or since.

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Pondering the Clanging Noise of Victorian Hubbub

title: Plugging Into Connecticut
description: It took the worst blackout in American history to persuade the federal government to activate the long-dormant Cross-Sound Cable, which is buried under Long Island Sound and runs between New Haven and the decommissioned Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island. The 300 megawatts of power it delivered helped restore power on Long Island. Now, thanks to an emergency order from the federal Department of Energy, the juice should flow indefinitely, or at least until the larger problems with the power grid are sorted out.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Luxury Profits Rise
description: The French luxury group LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported that net profit rose 24 percent, to 265 million euros ($297 million), in the first half of 2003, helped by cost-cutting measures. The group's operating income rose 4 percent, to 874 million euros ($980 million), despite the fall of the dollar and a drop in tourism during that period. ''These results reflect the exceptional capacity of our leading brands to increase market share whatever the circumstances,'' said Bernard Arnault, above, the chief executive. LVMH said it was banking on the rise of the dollar exchange rate this summer and the recovery of the tourism industry to confirm its growth objective for 2003. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: C.I.A. Says bin Laden Tape Is Likely Authentic
description: An audiotaped message broadcast earlier this week that was said to be the voice of Osama bin Laden is ''probably'' authentic, an official at the Central Intelligence Agency said today.

title: New PSAT, Minus Writing Test, Will Be Introduced in Fall '04
description: The College Board will introduce a revamped PSAT in October 2004, five months before it rolls out its new SAT, which will, for the first time, include a writing sample. But there will be no writing sample on the new PSAT, a math and reading test that 2.6 million high school students take each year both to practice for the SAT and to qualify for the National Merit Scholarship program.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chip Profit Forecast
description: Royal Philips Electronics told analysts that it expected its semiconductor division to return to profitability in the fourth quarter and predicted that sales growth in the third quarter, measured in United States dollars and excluding mobile displays, would exceed the 3 percent originally forecast. Philips said it would take a charge of 150 million euros ($166.5 million) in the third quarter in association with plant closings in San Antonio and Albuquerque, N.M. Philips's semiconductor unit posted an operating loss of 139 million euros ($154.3 million) for the second quarter. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sales of Software Licenses Decreased 6.7% at Oracle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GENTRY, HERBERT
description: GENTRY -- Herbert. Artist. Died on September 8, 2003 in Stockholm, Sweden at age 84. He is survived by his wife Mary Anne Rose of New York City; his children Stefan James Gentry, Nickolas Gentry, Elsa Kant, Alain H. Gentry and Therese Gentry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, CECILY
description: LEVIN--Cecily. The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Cecily, wife of our former esteemed member Stanley Levin and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Board of Governors Lowell Kwiat, President

title: Old Cities, Full of Life: Moscow
description: Even in the grimmest of Soviet times, Moscow did not lack world-class concert halls and theaters - the Bolshoi, the Conservatory, the Tchaikovsky. Now, in a new Russia and a new Moscow, a new hall has arrived with aspirations to join the city's elite venues.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've applied for many jobs, and they politely tell me I'm too old, that they're hoping to find someone they can train and keep for a long time.''

description: BASEBALL

title: Classrooms Are Bulging, Teachers Union Says
description: More than 9,200 classes in city public schools have so many students that they exceed limits in the teachers' contract, Randi Weingarten, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, charged yesterday.

title: Thomson and Stein Serve Up Shards of a Life
description: Like any good American, ''The Mother of Us All'' has come West to seek its fortune. With music by Virgil Thomson, a libretto by Gertrude Stein and a half-century of notoriety but not many productions, this benignly jumbled paean to Susan B. Anthony played at the San Francisco Opera on Wednesday night.

title: Mideast Path: Hard Choices Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Molire, Corneille, Rumsfeld
description: Last week's revelation by a French scholar that all of the masterpieces attributed to the great comic playwright Molire, including classics like ''Tartuffe'' and ''Le Misanthrope,'' were actually written by his rival, Pierre Corneille, has provoked shock and dismay throughout the world of letters. Now, a tortured conscience and a desire to further clear the literary air compel me to reveal that nearly all of my own published writings -- including, but by no means limited to, my 1999 memoir about gay culture and my recent monograph on the role of gender in Euripidean drama -- were, in fact, written by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Partnership Talks
description: The printing machinery maker Heidelberger Druck has entered into talks on a partnership with a rival in the United States, Goss Graphic Systems, the company said. After recording a net loss for the fiscal year ended March 31, Heidelberger started a cost-cutting program and is seeking partners in the industry to fight weak demand. The chairman, Bernhard Schreier, has warned of a possible decline in annual sales of as much as 10 percent. A partnership with Goss Graphic, based in Westmont, Ill., would be aimed at increasing earnings at Heidelberger's newspaper printing division and strengthening its position in North America, which already contributes a quarter of the company's revenue. Heidelberger, based in Heidelberg, employs more than 3,000 people in the United States. The closely held Goss manufactures printing presses for newspapers and commercial printers. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: In Madrid
description: Anew star shines in Madrid's firmament this fall: the world's most famous - and most fashionable - soccer player, David Beckham, has just moved to the Spanish capital to join the Galacticos, the high-earning soccer gods playing for Real Madrid. The arrival of Beckham - accompanied by his pop-star wife, Victoria Adams, better known as Posh Spice - prompted a frenzy of news media coverage that went far beyond the sports pages and included good-buy guides aimed at helping Posh and Becks to spread their largesse among the purveyors of luxury goods centered on the Calle Serrano in the 19th-century Salamanca district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPE, MARIA T.
description: PAPE--Maria T. Of Scarsdale, NY on September 11, 2003. Beloved wife of Michael and loving mother of Dr. Lawrence G. Pape and Dr. Gerard Pape. Also survived by two grandsons Samuel and Louis Daniel. Friends may call the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue Scarsdale, NY, on Saturday 7-9 and Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian burial the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Tuesday at 9:45 AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brewers' Outlook Improves
description: Moody's Investors Service raised the outlook for the Baa3 credit rating of Asahi Breweries, Japan's largest brewer, to positive from stable, citing its strong lineup of beers and improved cash flow. Moody's raised the credit rating for another brewer, Suntory, to Baa2 from Baa3 because of its successful diversification into nonalcoholic beverages and its sale of several unprofitable businesses. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mideast Path: Hard Choices Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Cities, Full of Life: Paris
description: There is nothing particularly Japanese about the Palais de Tokyo. But with its bookstore, odds-and-ends gift shop and new restaurant, this contemporary art space at the Place de Tokyo has emerged as a place to browse, eat and meet from noon until midnight every day except Monday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: BBC Chief Called To Kelly Inquiry
description: Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, has been called as a witness when the inquiry into the suicide of the weapons expert David Kelly resumes on Monday. Dr. Kelly took his life in July after being identified as the probable source of a BBC report that charged the government with ''sexing up'' an intelligence report on Iraqi arms. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Look Up, and Trade Center's Story Is Readable Again
description: Tourists attracted to ground zero by the abundance of Sept. 11 coverage may notice that the history panels are back. But this time they cannot be scribbled on.

title: Hark! Voices From the Street Are Heard in the Trade Talks
description: The menu featured Mexican lobster caught under strict environmental standards, washed down with pure Mexican hibiscus water. The speeches were just as politically correct.

title: A 311 Caller Who Knows How Potholes Are Fixed
description: Oh boy, here we go again -- it's the pothole guy, what's-his-name. Bloom-something.

title: Six Neo-Nazis Are Arrested In Bomb Plot Against Jews
description: A group of German neo-Nazi extremists arrested in raids across the country this week are suspected of planning to bomb a new Jewish cultural center in Munich, prosecutors said today.

title: New Coach Makes His Points Quietly
description: Steve Stirling, the Islanders' new coach, likes to steal glances at the wristwatch that he wears under his blue hockey gloves. But he does not blow his whistle very often, or very hard, and he does not yell much.

title: Wide Contrasts In Demeanor Of the Pope
description: On the 102nd foreign trip of a papacy that will reach the quarter-century mark next month, Pope John Paul II has projected a confusing portrait of surprising resilience and alarming weakness, of clear determination and equally clear limitation.

title: National Briefing: South
description: MISSISSIPPI: OIL RIG COLLAPSES An oil rig collapsed off the coast of Louisiana and Mississippi, tipping drilling equipment and 41 workers into the Gulf of Mexico. Commercial vessels in the area and the Coast Guard rescued the workers. One of them was hospitalized, said the Parker Drilling Company , which owns the rig. The rig held 10,500 gallons of diesel fuel, but the amount of fuel leaked is minimal, the Coast Guard said.    Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: The Giants View The Inactive List As an Opportunity
description: It is only a footnote at game time. An N.F.L. team's inactive list rarely draws much attention. It raises an eyebrow now or then, signaling a player's descent into a coach's doghouse, or a surprise injury.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Oil Contract Investigation
description: Statoil, Norway's largest oil producer, dismissed its head of international expansion and canceled an Iranian consulting contract as a result of a local police investigation into possible corruption. The consulting contract was a $15 million, 11-year agreement with Hortoil Investment undertaken to help Statoil invest in Iran. The National Authority for Investigation and Prosecution of Economic and Environmental Crime is investigating whether Statoil broke rules on dealing with officials of foreign states. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MOSES, EMILE
description: MOSES--Emile. Daddy, we feel your loving, guiding presence. You are forever with us. Hannah, Debbie, Maureen and Janic

title: Cancn Targets Cotton
description: It's not often you see Africans looking like potential big winners at big international gatherings. But this week Franois Traore, the head of Burkina Faso's National Cotton Producers Union, has been positively beaming, and at center stage, at the World Trade Organization's meeting in Cancn. He is part of the West African delegation that has managed, much to the chagrin of United States trade negotiators, to make cotton a test case of the W.T.O.'s commitment to a level playing field for trade in agricultural goods. It is a fitting test case, and it is up to the Bush administration to address the Africans' legitimate demands and give the trade talks a significant boost.

title: FAO Loses $18.8 Million
description: FAO Inc., the owner of the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy stores, had a second-quarter loss of $18.8 million after it closed 111 stores in a financial reorganization.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Judge Criticizes Riot Trial
description: The chief justice of India's Supreme Court said he had ''no faith'' in the willingness of the Hindu nationalist-led government in Gujarat State to faithfully prosecute the perpetrators of killings during Hindu-Muslim riots last year, Reuters reported. The comments came during a hearing on a request to reopen the trial of 21 Hindus acquitted in July of burning alive a dozen people, most of them Muslims, in a bakery during the riots. David Rohde (NYT)

title: After Some Slips, Quick Thinking Makes Sure No One Is Forgotten
description: The overwhelming grief and intense national interest in the three-hour commemoration at ground zero on Thursday left no room for a mistake. And so at the last minute, Michele Stabile of Staten Island stood up and delivered a correction that preserved unblemished the most somber message of that moment.

title: U.S. SOLDIERS KILL 8 IRAQI POLICEMEN, TOWNSPEOPLE SAY
description: American soldiers killed at least eight Iraqi policemen and a Jordanian security guard early this morning in a gun battle outside the Jordanian Hospital here, residents and town officials said. Falluja lies at the heart of Iraqi resistance to the occupation, and the killings will further incite the city, residents said.

title: Sports of The Times; Buckeyes Would Gain by Giving Up Title
description: EIGHT months ago, Maurice Clarett scored the winning touchdown in the second overtime of the Fiesta Bowl to propel Ohio State to a 31-24 victory over Miami and an undisputed national championship. The game was an example of how enthralling intercollegiate sports can be.

Loving mother of Professor Joshua L. Rosenbloom of Lawrence, KS, Daniel H. Rosenbloom of Brooklyn, and Rachel E. Rosenbloom of Jamaica Plain, MA. Adored grandmother of six. title: WRIGHT HOLDINGS INCREASES BID FOR ELDER-BEERMAN
description: The Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation, the unprofitable operator of 68 department stores, received an increased offer, of $90 million, from Wright Holdings Inc. to fend off a competing bid from Bon-Ton Stores Inc. The amended agreement with Wright would offer shareholders $7.80, compared with a previous offer of $7.05, Elder-Beerman said. That tops an offer Bon-Ton made earlier this week of $7.25 a share for Elder-Beerman. The companies have been competing to acquire Elder-Beerman, which is based in Dayton, Ohio, and has stores in eight Midwestern states.

title: Mets Defend Beefing Up Cyclones for Playoffs
description: The Mets were unable to field a winner in Queens this season, so they did their best to have one in Brooklyn. And when they were unable to surround pitcher Tom Glavine with a contending team, they offered him the opportunity to play with his brother.

title: Older and Working? Why We Have Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: An Aspiring Rapper Son Gets No Help From Dad
description: The Miller brothers of New Orleans -- Master P, Sikk the Shocker and C-Murder -- made good in the 1990's with their rap trio, Tru. In 1990 Master P, with seed money from his grandfather, founded No Limit, a record store that became a lucrative hip-hop record label. And since 2000 the Miller dynasty has been maximizing its latest asset: Master P's 14-year-old son, Lil Romeo, a child who had a No. 1 hit song when he was 11.

title: Funny Endings Department
description: Monty Python had a memorable Ministry of Silly Walks. Similarly, but less hilariously, bridge theory has a Department of Funny Endings. The funniest of last year arose from the deal shown in the diagram. It was played in August, during a Regional Open Pairs in Santa Clara, Calif., and was reported by Stu Goodgold of San Jose, Calif., who sat South.

title: For Leguizamo, Boxing Film Was More Than Acting
description: John Leguizamo wore a beige suit, white shirt opened three buttons to show a gold-chain necklace, an outfit that one of his boxing idols, Roberto Duran, might have worn after a victory, heading for night out at Victor's Cafe Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, ROSE
description: RUBIN--Rose. Loving mother of Barbara Heller and Sandra (with her husband Gerald) Bogatz. Adored grandmother of Ronald, David and Michael Heller and William Bogatz, Debra Klein and Rhonda Levy. Cherished great-grandmother of Lauren, Samuel, Lindsay, Chad, Michael, Alexis and Adam. Private Services.

title: Democrats Find Some Traction On Capitol Hill
description: With President Bush on the defensive over his handling of postwar Iraq, Democrats on Capitol Hill have been scoring a few victories in the Republican-controlled Congress, gaining a measure of political momentum that they hope will grow more pronounced as the 2004 elections draw nearer.

title: Lewdness Charge for Child Agency Worker
description: A worker for the city's Administration for Children's Services was arrested yesterday after exposing himself to a 19-year-old woman on a subway train, the police said.

title: G.O.P. Dealing With Split Over 2 Top Contenders
description: The governor's office may be within its grasp, but the state Republican Party convened here today facing a growing split over whom to support as a successor to Gov. Gray Davis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about effects of increased airport security on the habits of travelers misspelled the given name of a woman whose bag was searched in Chicago because a barrette inside looked like a knife in baggage screening. She is Susana Vitale, not Susane.

title: Ruling Voids Spending Caps In New Jersey's Primary Races
description: In a court decision that has startled New Jersey election officials and political leaders from both parties, a Superior Court judge has ruled that the state's campaign spending limits do not apply to candidates in primary elections.

title: Europe to American Tourists: Wish You Were Here!
description: IT is not exactly the routine for Queen Elizabeth II to visit a theme park, but she did so in June, traveling to the miniature models of Legoland near the royal palace at Windsor to survey a tiny likeness of herself in molded plastic inspecting the equally Lilliputian guard. Neither is it quite the norm for Prime Minister Tony Blair to do sound bites for television and Web site commercials. But he did so this summer, urging Americans to visit Britain "for great times with good friends."

title: Bush Travels to Georgia to Welcome Home Troops From Iraq
description: President Bush traveled here today to welcome home thousands of the troops who had led the allied charge into Baghdad, saluting their courage and vowing that attacks against American and other foreign targets in Iraq would not deter the United States from finishing ''the fight between civilization and chaos.''

title: Second Suitor Offers to Buy British Chain
description: CVC, the Texas Pacific Group and Merrill Lynch made a long-awaited bid for the Debenhams department stores today, valuing the chain at 1.66 billion ($2.67 billion), 7 percent more than a rival bid.

title: Old Cities, Full of Life: Rome
description: Rome tends to resist change rather than embrace it. But it has recently added some bold and unexpected flourishes that tempt a visitor in surprising directions.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia And New Zealand: Australia: Retailer's Profit Rises
description: Harvey Norman Holdings, Australia's largest furniture and electronics retailer, said its full-year profit rose 18 percent, helped by demand for plasma televisions and DVD players. Sales in July and August rose 21 percent. Net income for the year ended June 30 climbed to 151 million Australian dollars ($100 million), or 14 cents a diluted share, from 128 million Australian dollars, or 12 cents a diluted share, the previous year. During the latest year, Harvey Norman opened 15 stores in Australia and New Zealand as well as one store in Slovenia.

title: Beliefs; Stating the case for why the Vatican ought to consider an exit plan for old and infirm popes.
description: The Roman Catholic Church has detailed provisions, honed by centuries of sometimes painful experience, that regulate the election of popes. It has virtually no provisions for the very modern problem of aging and physically or mentally declining popes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHORE, DOROTHY KIMMEL MAN
description: SHORE -- Dorothy Kimmel man, (of Philadelphia), died peacefully on September 10, 2003, a truly elegant lady, beloved wife of the late William Shore, devoted mother of Madge Shore Miller, of New York City and Joan Shore Steinhouse, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, cherished grandmother of Jennifer Miller Symonds, Darcy Miller Nussbaum, Jonathan Ian Steinhouse, Peter Leigh Steinhouse and Nancy Steinhouse Rosenthal. A great grandmother to seven great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Sunday, September 14, 2003, 12:30 PM at the Roosevelt Memorial Park, (Section E) Trevose, Bucks Co. PA, (Just north of Philadelphia). The Millers will receive family and friends on Monday and Tuesday, from 4:00PM to 9:00PM, at their home, and Dr. and Mrs. Steinhouse will receive family and friends at their home on Tuesday from 4:00PM to 9:00PM. The service will commence at 8PM. She was greatly loved and will be sorely missed by all who knew her. The family respectfully requests that contributions in her memory be made to The Friends of Rittenhouse Square, or to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. Joseph Levine & Son www.levinefuneral.com

title: Old Cities, Full of Life: Prague
description: There are still plenty of low-rent pubs and sleazy strip joints in Zizkov, a district that stayed scruffy long after much of Prague fancied itself up to its old splendor. Even its signature landmark - the huge moon rocket of a television antenna that invades Prague's otherwise spired skyline - announced that Zizkov (pronounced ZHISH-koff) might be a tough sell for gentrification.

title: Bush Seeks $2.1 Billion More for Iraqi Oil Industry
description: The Bush administration is calling for an additional $2.1 billion to repair the Iraqi oil industry, a sharp increase from previous estimates that underscores how the sabotage of pipelines and the electricity grid has throttled the flow of oil for export and into domestic refineries.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Milton R. Konvitz, a constitutional scholar, misstated the name of the Zionist monthly publication he helped found and misstated the number of letters he wrote to Ruth Bader Ginsburg. (A correction in this space yesterday misstated the timing of the correspondence.) The publication is Midstream, not Mainstream. Justice Ginsburg received 10 to 20 letters, not 107, and the correspondence took place long after she was a student, not while she was.

description: WALGROVE -- Suzanne. Of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away peacefully at home after a long battle with cancer on September 11, 2003. Survived by her husband Richard, step-sons Daniel and Steven, four grandchildren and her sister Stephanie.

title: Patients in Florida Lining Up For All That Medicare Covers
description: It is lunchtime, and the door to Boca Urology's office is locked. But outside, patients are milling about, calling the office on their cellphones, hoping the receptionist will let them in. To say they are eager hardly does them justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOLOFF, CAROL HELENE
description: SOKOLOFF--Carol Helene. Of New York City and Ancramdale, NY, on Thursday September 11, 2003. Beloved daughter of the late Sylvia and David, cherished sister of Martin, Karen and nephew Greg. Devoted niece of Gussie. title: R. B. Sims, 68, National Geographic Official
description: Robert B. Sims, retired executive vice president of the National Geographic Society and president of its magazine group, died on Wednesday in Jackson, Tenn. He was 68 and lived in the nearby town of Alamo.

title: Willingham Stares Down the Scrutiny
description: To see Notre Dame football players smile and to hear them laugh, ask them why they call their coach, Tyrone Willingham, the Prophet.

title: Nike Move Ends Case Over Firms' Free Speech
description: A lawsuit that only months ago was expected to produce a landmark ruling on the free speech rights of corporations ended with a whimper yesterday. Nike Inc., the athletic shoe and clothing company, agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle the case, in which it had been accused of making misleading statements about its global labor practices.

title: TV Show Brought Debate Plus for Dean
description: Howard Dean got help from an unusual source in preparing for the Democratic debate in Baltimore on Tuesday: two veteran political consultants appearing with him on a television series.

title: High Alerts For Terror Get Harder To Impose
description: The Bush administration's color-coded terrorism alert system, which has been strongly criticized by counterterrorism specialists and much of the public, is being revamped to make it far more difficult for the government to justify raising the threat level, senior administration officials said.

title: CASE OF SPARRING SEATTLE PAPERS OPENS
description: A state judge in Washington heard opening arguments yesterday in a legal battle that could determine whether Seattle retains two daily newspapers. Lawyers for The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, owned by the Hearst Corporation, hoped to convince Judge Greg Canova that The Seattle Times, majority owned by the Blethen family, cannot move to dissolve a joint operating agreement under which the two newspapers have shared business and production operations since 1981. The judge said he would issue a ruling on Sept. 25. The legal case hinges on whether The Times can invoke the agreement's ''loss operations clause,'' which allows it to back out of the agreement after three consecutive years in the red. The Times has posted losses since 2000, but Hearst contends that a newspaper strike that year should rule out including 2000 in the calculations. Both sides have threatened to sell or close their papers if the other prevails in court.

title: To Help Learning, City Offers Free Breakfast to All Pupils
description: New York City schools have begun to offer a free breakfast to every child, rich or poor, in the hope that a good meal first thing in the morning will help students concentrate and learn.

title: Jets' Abraham May Have a Sidekick in Ellis
description: They are friends and like any friends, they compete and tease each other. For the last two years, when the subject is sacks, Shaun Ellis has not been able to get in a word against John Abraham.

title: A Better Primary
description: To the Editor:

title: Shutdown of Nuclear Complex Deepens North Korean Mystery
description: American intelligence agencies are puzzling over evidence that North Korea has halted operations at its nuclear complex in Yongbyon, according to senior United States officials.

title: AUDIT FINDS SPIEGEL MAY HAVE MANIPULATED DATA
description: Spiegel Inc., the owner of the Eddie Bauer clothing store chain, failed to disclose information about the company's deteriorating condition to investors and may have manipulated some data to stave off a Chapter 11 filing, according to a court-appointed examiner. Spiegel's majority owner, the Otto family of Germany, and its audit committee, rejected advice to file financial reports because they were worried that the company's creditors would refuse to extend credit, according to the report, which was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A Spiegel spokeswoman, Debbie Koopman, declined to comment on the report.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the decision by John Edwards of North Carolina to leave the Senate and about the challenges it creates for Democrats hoping to keep his seat misstated the year in which Republicans won four open Senate seats in the South. It was 2002, not 2000.

title: As Recall Vote Nears, Animosity Between 2 Onetime Allies Grows
description: When Gray Davis and Cruz M. Bustamante were running for California governor and lieutenant governor in the fall of 1998, they frequently appeared together before Latino audiences in the Central Valley. Some even dubbed them the ''two amigos.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: MORE MONEY FOR HOSPITALS The government said it would provide about $750 million in extra funding in an effort to improve hospital emergency services and prevent a repetition of the disaster this summer in which more than 11,000 people died during a heat wave. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

description: Pittsburgh Steelers (1-0) at Kansas City Chiefs (1-0), 1 p.m. ET

title: 2 International Giants in Aluminum Agree to Merge in a $4.5 Billion Deal
description: Alcan, the world's second-largest aluminum company, won the support of Pechiney of France today for a $4.5 billion merger that will form the world's largest aluminum company by revenue.

title: Old Cities, Full of Life: Berlin
description: It may seem strange, given that East Germany was a police state, but 14 years after the reunification of Germany, there's nostalgia for old East German products. The trend was spurred in part by the movie "Goodbye, Lenin," a big hit here a few months ago, in which Spreewald Pickles, which are no longer on the market, play a big role.

title: But Who Says the Heights Have to, Like, Wuther?
description: No need for Wuthering. It is just ''the Heights.''

title: In the Council, Leader Treads Delicate Line On Lead Paint
description: Under increasing pressure from children's advocates and fellow City Council members, Speaker Gifford Miller said yesterday that the removal of lead paint hazards from city apartments was his highest priority. But he stopped short of endorsing a proposed law that has been in the works for more than a year.

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: Arkansas (1-0) at No. 6 Texas (1-0)

title: Venezuela Council Rejects Petition to Recall Chvez
description: Electoral authorities in Venezuela today rejected an opposition petition, signed by 3.2 million people, demanding a recall referendum on the rule of its leftist president, Hugo Chvez.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about statistics on New York since the attack on the World Trade Center gave incorrect figures supplied by Bowker's Books in Print about 9/11-related books. According to its database, 468 books, not 760, have been published about 9/11. Of those published, 458, not 724, are still in print. Forty-one of the hardcover books, not 39, made at least one best-seller list. And 15 more 9/11 books, not 40, have been announced for publication in 2003 and 2004.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Women Lagging In Parliaments
description: Women make up less than 20 percent of national lawmakers in nearly half of the 15 European Union member countries, said Anna Diamantopoulou, the European commissioner for employment and social affairs. Ms. Diamantopoulou said she was ''dismayed'' by the statistics. A European Union report published this month showed that Sweden, Finland and Germany had the most women in parliament, at more than 40 percent, while Italy and Greece had less than 10 percent. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, SHELDON

title: First Love Illustrated
description: At a time when the overused publishing term ''graphic novel'' most often refers either to ungainly superhero sagas or meandering, I-did-this-I-did-that Harvey Pekar rip-offs, Craig Thompson is correct to try to distinguish BLANKETS (Top Shelf, paper, $29.95) from its genre by calling it an ''illustrated novel.'' His forthright semiautobiographical tale follows a very young Craig, raised in a devout Christian family, through a romance with Raina, a ravishingly idealized first love. It is Raina who sews him a quilt, each square of which has emotional significance to her; it is Craig who questions the constraints of his faith when presented with her vulnerable, soul-bared love. Thompson's art -- black-and-white drawings of simple power, a technique of crosshatched realism that slips without melodrama into a vertiginous surrealism the deeper our hero falls for Raina -- possesses the artistic detail of a novel rendered in comic-book panels, omniscient-narrator description and word-balloon dialogue. Craig's blankets include not only Raina's gift but also the snug Michigan and Wisconsin snow that covers his contained patch of earth. In telling his story, which includes beautifully rendered memories of the small brutalities that parents inflict upon their children and siblings upon each other, Thompson describes the ecstasy and ache of obsession (with a lover, with God) and is unafraid to suggest the ways that obsession can consume itself and evaporate. Ken Tucker

title: Growing Grapes And Culture In Romania
description: THE city of Iasi was already vivid in my mind. Not because it is the capital of Moldavia province, in the northeast of Romania near the Ukrainian border, nor because it's home to an old university and beautiful churches. But because in 1876, when Iasi (pronounced yahsh) was a lively Jewish center, the world's first performance of Yiddish theater took place in a wine garden there called Pomul Verde (the Green Tree). Last fall I attended a conference organized by the Romanian Ministry of Culture to commemorate the Yiddish theater's creator, a flamboyant down-at-the-heel intellectual named Avrom Goldfadn. Before leaving, I pictured myself on a bench in the old Green Tree, glass in hand.

title: The Martyr Complex

But in the Muslim Middle East, where religious terminology permeates the culture, it seems as if almost everyone is a martyr. Realizing this is a small but crucial step in understanding a major cultural gap between the West and the Muslim Middle East, a gap that becomes more obvious with every audiotape supposedly from Osama bin Laden.

title: Catalonia

The rough communal tables covered in red-and-white checked oilcloth, the wine bottles smothered with candle drippings, the walls decorated with framed photos of portly, satisfied customers all seem like tickets for travel to an another era, though it's oddly hard to pinpoint our final destination. Rural Spain in the 19th century? Greenwich Village in the 50's? Casa Anita's proprietor -- one of those jolly, theatrical, life-loving guys whose girth seems like an advertisement for the skills of his chef -- would seem at home in any number of regions and decades.

title: 'Who Owns Native Culture?'
description: Anyone who has read about the Hopi Indians, a small Arizona tribe famous for multi-story dwellings and a resolute commitment to traditional religious practices, is likely to have seen photographs taken by the Reverend Heinrich (Henry) R. Voth. The years that have passed since Voth's death in 1931 have done little to stem the controversy surrounding his activities as missionary and anthropologist. Contemporary anthropologists, even those who respect his ethnographic work, are uncomfortable with Voth's religious zeal and with the oppressive Indian policies in force during the years that he worked at Hopi. Among Hopis, anger at Voth's publication of sensitive information about their religion continues to smolder as if his alleged misdeeds had taken place only yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEERIN, MAGGIE
description: SHEERIN -- Maggie. Began her final and most highly anticipated journey on Friday, September 12, 2003. Born in Texas, on September 22, 1940, she attended school in Temple and resided in San Antonio for many years where she married (the late) Bobby Sheerin. She was a self-described spiritualist and kept an open mind, eager to explore everything new. As an avid traveler and true adventuress, her vast and varied interests led her to the far corners of this world and most especially to antiquity's sacred and mystical sites. At home, she was an inveterate volunteer and philanthropist closely associated with the Cancer Therapy and Research Center, the Cancer Center Cabinet, the Winston School of San Antonio, the Rock Art Foundation, the Mind Science Foundation and a diverse mix of other notfor-profit organizations. She also served as a director of local business enterprises and operated her own business, ''Magties.'' Her contributions to her community were recognized with a number of prestigious awards, and she found immense joy in the simple pleasures of photography, reading, collecting, live theater, fine art, entertaining, playing Backgammon, Bridge and Canasta, meeting new people and forming new friendships. The regret of those she leaves behind is tempered by the wonderment of her adventure. They include son and daughter-in-law Jack and Traci Sheerin, son Jimmy Sheerin, daughter and son-in-law Cynthia and Andy Berry, granddaughter Ellie Berry, cousins Nancy Bitting and her daughter Lesley, soulmate Paul Rossbach, devoted helpmates Virginia Lopez and Vivian Little, her Temple High School classmates, many, many more friends in many parts of the world and a large contingent of true admirers. At her specific request, no memorial service will be held and, following cremation, her ashes are to be distributed on four continents at places which held special meaning for her during this lifetime. For more information contact Porter Loring Mortuary, 1-800-460-2704.

We know this partly because he's marooned in Tokyo, shooting an advertising campaign for a local brand of whiskey and consenting to appear on a bizarre Japanese talk show. We also intuit, through his tiniest gestures and movements, a complicated, unspoken history of success and eclipse, of gratification and disappointment. Bob's celebrity clings to him like a threadbare bespoke suit, and he protects his dignity with the tarnished armor of irony. We -- my 13-year-old son, Tom, and I -- followed him up a medieval stairway to the upper town, to a viewpoint from which you can look down upon this perfect replica of a northern European port city in the 19th century: the Lutheran spires topped with rooster weathercocks, the cupolas of Orthodox churches, the glimpses of Gothic and Baroque, the narrow streets just lighting up for the dinner trade, the tiled rooftops and chimneys sending up a scent of baking. Except, of course, that it is no replica. It is the real thing, alluringly intact despite centuries of trampling by Danish conquerors and Teutonic knights, Swedes, Russians, Nazis and Soviets.

title: The Calvinist Ethic
description: Last October, Frances Stein ran into her old friend and boss Calvin Klein in Paris. It had been years since she had seen the designer, who was in the process of selling his company to Phillips-Van Heusen. The next day, they went to see the ''Matisse Picasso'' exhibit at the Grand Palais and afterward went to lunch at a cafe that Stein knew on the Rue de Verneuil. A woman of mercurial chic, who has spent the last 22 years designing accessories for Chanel, Stein first met Klein in the early 1970's when she was an editor at Vogue under Diana Vreeland. Almost a decade earlier, Vreeland, with her usual farsightedness, pushed Stein toward Halston, then a milliner at Bergdorf Goodman. ''Get to know him,'' she said. And Stein did, becoming part of one of fashion's most glamorous circles. Surrounded by his court of Halstonettes, and catering to a new breed of socialite who hung out with rock stars and Pop artists, Halston cultivated an air of superiority that set him apart from the rag-trade ethos of Seventh Avenue, where Klein started out in 1968 as a coat designer. Though friendly with Klein, Halston was privately dismissive of the younger man's talent, once saying, ''I wouldn't know a Calvin Klein from a load of coal.''

title: 'Transatlantic'
description: Before steamships started crossing the North Atlantic, the best way to travel between Europe and America was by the sailing ships called packets. Built and run mainly by Americans, the packet lines introduced new concepts and comfort levels for ocean voyages. They dominated the transatlantic traffic for decades, setting key precedents for the steamships that eventually replaced them. Along with their more famous contemporaries, the whaling and clipper ships, they comprised the golden age of American sail. Of these three types, the packets lasted the longest and made the most voyages and money for their owners and crews. Yet today whalers and clippers remain drenched in popular legend, while the packets are scarcely known beyond dedicated circles of ship buffs. No packet builder ever became as famous as Donald McKay with his clippers, and no novelist ever wrote a Moby Dick about the packets. They just did their jobs quietly and well, year after year, and then passed into the historical obscurity reserved for predictable competence.

title: A Rejected Writer Tries a New Genre
description: STEVEN BOCHCO'S credits as a producer and writer include ''Hill Street Blues'' (1981-7), ''L.A. Law'' (1986-92) and ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' which begins its 11th season on ABC on Sept. 23. They won't include ''Marriage,'' a drama set entirely in a New York apartment that HBO dropped this summer after seeing the pilot, and ''N.Y.P.D. 2069,'' a sci-fi-police pilot that Fox didn't pick up. But this fall isn't without a new Bochco production: ''Death by Hollywood,'' his first novel, was published last week. It's a thriller about a screenwriter whose big break involves a murder. Mr. Bochco, 59, recently spoke from his Los Angeles production office about becoming a novelist and persevering as a television writer.

description: SURKIS--Bernard. Died September 7, 2003. ''The Original Good Guy''. Devoted husband of Hilda, beloved father of Michele, Wendy and Scott, adored grandfather of Ian, Darren and Justin, brother of Emanuel, the late Herman and sister Shirley. We will miss your love, your caring, your willful ear and your support of all our accomplishments. Rest and watch over us all. With loving and fond memories: Bernard and Michele, Wendy and Peppi, Scott and Carol, Ian and Halie, Darren and Liz, and Justin and Dana.

title: The Week Ahead; WHOOPEE FOR WHOOPI?
description: Keep an eye on the 8 p.m. time slot on NBC Tuesday night. ''Whoopi'' the new NBC comedy starring Whoopi Goldberg, drew fairly strong ratings in its debut last week, giving hope to all the networks that a long drought in hit sitcoms might be ending. Many thought the show would be a bomb but Ms. Goldberg, playing a politically incorrect, chainsmoking hotel owner, attracted a fairly hefty 14.7 million viewers. Its popularity may have carried over to the next time slot. ''Happy Family'' with John Larroquette and Christine Baranski, drew 14.5 million people.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; In Built-Up Greenwich, Subdividing by Nibbling
description: THE breakup of large estates in Greenwich, a town fiercely protective of its green space, has often been a cause for local consternation, if not outright mourning. But the sales of private parcels from estates or the subdividing of expansive properties have been infrequent events.

title: Nickels and Dimes Built This Mansion
description: IN the early years of the 20th century, Long Island's North Shore was home to about 1,000 magnificent mansions along the so-called Gold Coast. Among the more majestic and expensive was Winfield, built for F.W. Woolworth of five-and-dime fame, for $9 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HABER, LOUIS
description: HABER--Louis. 93 of Brooklyn Heights, NY on September 8, of Parkinson's Disease. Violinist and composer, Lou was a leading studio musician from the early 1960's to the 1990's, playing on recording sessions of well known popular artists. Lou wrote the song, ''Thursday'', for Lew Leslie's Blackbirds of 1939. It was sung by Lena Horne and recorded by Count Basie. Lou studied composition with Darius Milhoud at the Paris Conservatory and wrote many trios, duets, and other chamber works. Those recorded were Trio for Violin, Flute and Piano and Six Miniatures for Flute and Violin. Lou was born on January 10, 1910. During WWII, he served in the U.S. Army Air Corp. He was a member of the American Federation of Musicians, ASCAP and the Bohemian Club. He is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Nelle, three brothers, Dr. William Haber of New York, Bernard and Milton Haber of Florida, a step brother Moe Sussell of Long Island, and many nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews.

title: The Week Ahead; NUCLEAR ARMS DEBATE
description: As the Bush administration focuses on the nuclear capabilities of Iran and North Korea, some members of Congress are taking aim at the nuclear intentions of the White House. Democratic Senators Dianne Feinstein of California and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts plan to try this week to strip money for study into a new generation of smaller nuclear bombs from an Energy Department spending bill.

description: William Wegman, the artist famous for his photographs of Weimaraners in human garb, spends summer and early fall in a hunters' lodge in western Maine, along with his wife, Christine; their two children, Atlas and Lola; and, of course, the dogs: Batty, Chip, Candy and Bobbin.

description: Jennifer Marie Giampietro and Stephen Andrew Cooke were married yesterday at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Jeffrey J. Madley performed the ceremony.

title: Jets Running a Reverse on Their Offensive Scheme
description: In the nine days after the Jets lost to Washington, they watched tapes of Buffalo from last season, a New England game from three years ago and Houston's shocker over Miami last week. The quest to divine what the Jets can do to energize an offense that seemed stuck in the mud in the season opener also delved deep into the offense's gray matter.

title: Everyman, With a Voice
description: Only those who were there at the beginning can remember how different he really was. The records, when they first started coming out on the Sun label in 1955, in the immediate wake of Elvis Presley's success, sounded ''so unusual,'' said the Sun session guitarist, Roland Janes, ''that I never would have dreamed he could have even gotten a record played on the radio. But he set country music on its ear.''

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: VERSAILLES, by Kathryn Davis. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) Sprung from the mind of Marie Antoinette after her death, this novel takes a soul's-eye view of the queen's life from her marriage at 14 to Louis XVI to her rendezvous with the guillotine. Unbounded by walls or flesh, she wanders the gardens and rooms of Versailles, listening to conversations at which she wasn't present and bearing witness. The book is ''rapturous, like an aria,'' Stacey D'Erasmo wrote here in 2002. The queen is ''very much alive here, and she's magnificent.'' The same publisher has reissued two of Davis's earlier novels. Hell ($13.95)is a mlange of meditations, voices, scenes, sermons and proverbs that cross-cuts between two households: that of a troubled family in 1950's Philadelphia, and the residence of a 19th-century expert on domestic management. In 1998 in these pages, Nancy Willard admired the tale's ''intelligence and verbal brio.'' The Girl Who Trod on a Loaf ($14.95) tells of the friendship between a Juilliard-trained waitress and an elderly Danish composer, who on her death leaves her friend an unfinished opera based on a Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale. In 1993 our reviewer, Maggie Paley, found this philosophical novel ''heated, dramatic'' and ''grand in its ambition.''

title: A Neighborhood on the River Seeks a Waterfront View
description: Urban it is. Urban planning, it is not.

title: National Gallery: Watch Your Step
description: How many visitors who walk into London's National Gallery, and continue up the stairs to its landings and side vestibules, notice what's beneath their feet before they turn left or right? If they looked down, they'd find they were treading on Winston Churchill and Virginia Woolf, Greta Garbo and T.S. Eliot, Bertrand Russell and Lord Rutherford, who is seen splitting a round, black atom into zigzags.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTRIN, DORA ZIFF
description: ESTRIN--Dora Ziff. On September 7, 2003. Beloved wife of Abraham, a blessed memory. Mother and mother-in-law of Roberta and William Bruenn, Phyllis and Monte Berkoff and Elaine and Arthur Friedman; grandmother of seven, great grandmother of five. We love you, miss you dearly and know that you and Daddy are reunited at last.

title: Page Two: Sept. 7-13; MIDEAST: BACK AGAIN
description: And so Yasir Arafat, declared ''irrelevant'' by Israel in Dec. 2001, isolated by the Bush administration since June 2002, ignored lately even by the European Union, was again the talk of the world's capitals after Israel decided, in principle, that he was ''an absolute obstacle'' that it ''will act to remove'' at some point.

title: The Hardest Stuff
description: The year 2003 may go down as the year the stat geeks won over organized baseball, converting the evaluation of talent from art into science. But there are still some things about the game that don't yield so easily to cold calculus, and chief among them is the mystique of the fire-balling pitcher, the guy who pitches close to and can break the 100-mile-per-hour mark. According to Robert Adair, a physicist and professor emeritus at Yale University and the author of ''The Physics of Baseball,'' throwing a ball this hard transcends the ordinary parameters of the game. ''It's really at the edge of what human beings can do,'' Adair told me.

title: National Archives Building to Reopen Its Doors
description: The National Archives building in Washington will open its newly renovated exhibition space in the Rotunda on Thursday, the 216th anniversary of the signing of the United States Constitution.

description: In Control

title: A Co-Production Of Sinatra and J.F.K.
description: INTENTIONALLY or not, all movies are time capsules, preserving in some form a particular historical moment. A few embody something more -- the imaginative history of their times. Such movies realize social anxieties and desires not yet fully articulated. ''The Manchurian Candidate'' (1962), which inaugurates Film Forum's John Frankenheimer retrospective next weekend, is such a movie, steeped in what Norman Mailer called ''that concentration of ecstasy and violence which is the dream life of the nation.''

Does a shareholder, for example, vote her full number of shares for each candidate of her choice, or does she have to divide her voting shares over various candidates? . . . Ann Brady, Long Beach, N.Y.
