title: Yankee, Leave Home!
description: IT is not exactly the routine for Queen Elizabeth II to visit a theme park, but she did so in June, traveling to the miniature models of Legoland near the royal palace at Windsor to survey a tiny likeness of herself in molded plastic inspecting the equally Lilliputian guard. Neither is it quite the norm for Prime Minister Tony Blair to do sound bites for television and Web site commercials. But he did so this summer, urging Americans to visit Britain ''for great times with good friends.''

title: Deals and Discounts
description: LONDON WEEKEND -- Starting Nov. 1 and continuing through March 31, 2004, the ETM Travel Group of Westport, Conn., has weekend trips to London starting at $399 a person, based on double occupancy. The rates include round-trip air fare from New York on Virgin Atlantic, three nights in a first-class hotel in central London (such as the Thistle Kensington Palace), hotel taxes and service charges and daily breakfast. Airport fees and taxes are extra and some dates are blacked out. Information: (800) 992-7700.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Converting Old Supermarkets for Other Uses
description: IN 1926, a second life for the small town of Sparta was devised, and an old iron-mining town was turned into a lake vacation spot when a dam was constructed that inundated 10 miles of surrounding farmland.

title: INVESTING WITH: Carl Domino; Northern Large Cap Value Fund
description: CARL DOMINO typically buys big, unpopular, high-dividend-paying companies for his $650 million Northern Large Cap Value fund.

title: Despite Assurances, Bush's Antiterror Plan Is Rekindling Concern
description: For months, President Bush's advisers have assured a skittish public that law-abiding Americans have no reason to fear the long reach of the antiterrorism law known as the Patriot Act because its most intrusive measures would require a judge's sign-off.

title: Public Art Both Violent and Gorgeous
description: I PRACTICALLY jumped out of my shoes when the Chinese-born artist Cai Guo-Qiang finished a drawing in a borrowed Long Island studio earlier this summer. I wasn't shocked because the results were fabulous but because the final touch involved gunpowder, a lighted fuse, a bang and an orange flash.

title: Investing; Some Age Can Help Closed-End Funds
description: FOR some investors, the words ''initial public offering'' may still conjure up dreams of riches. But in the realm of closed-end funds, at least, I.P.O.'s this year have generally been disappointing.

title: That Pesky Lump in Glen Cove's Gravy
description: ON Tuesday, when Glen Cove officials formally opened their city's new waterfront esplanade, Mayor Mary Ann Holzkamp promised that the waterfront project ''will breathe new vitality into the City of Glen Cove.''

title: Laura Butti and Bruce Mason
description: THREE years ago, Bruce Mason went to Silver Rock Farms in Orangeburg, N.Y., hoping to arrange lessons in horse jumping. He had heard about a great teacher there named Laura Butti (pronounced BOO-tee). ''I was wearing my business suit, and I said, 'Is Laura here?' '' Mr. Mason, now 49, recalled. ''And she said, 'Who's asking?' ''

title: Half-Full or Half-Empty?
description: I was drinking too much, and I had to cut down soon or check myself into a rehab with a tight curfew. My liver enzymes were high, my spirits low and my prospects in life profoundly middling. I tried all the tricks: no drinking before dinner, no hard liquor except on weekends, no beer unless accompanied by food or a televised sporting event of national import. Still, every time, that first drink proved too many, as it does for many of my kind. For us, there is no cutting down. We have to quit -- one day at a time, as corny as that sounds. And so, with the help of prayer and other people, I've been sober for more than 10 years. It hasn't been easy.

title: Inside Washington Politics, Turned Inside Out
description: HBO's ''K Street'' might as well be called ''K Street and Vine.'' Tonight's pilot episode of Steven Soderbergh's mock-documentary expos of Washington lobbyists reveals more about the power of Hollywood than it does about the shadowy inner workings of government.

title: An Unsustainable Policy on Iraq
description: After a summer of worsening news from Iraq, it is time to rethink America's postwar strategy.

title: Faith That Reaches Out
description: Long before the Bush administration began talking about ''faith-based initiatives'' in social services, dozens of churches and synagogues across denominational lines have been committed to social outreach work in Westchester County. They house and feed the homeless, educate adults and children and care for AIDS patients, the elderly and the disabled. They reach out to immigrants, to prisoners and to the mentally ill.

title: Untying the Knot
description: Max talks about the ''chump'' factor, which had him worrying that he may have left Kate with more of her own money than she deserved (Melanie Thernstrom, Aug. 24). Kate ended up supporting the lifestyle of her condescending, manipulative ex-husband: he got a huge cash settlement, the apartment, the furniture, the pet, the car -- plus a rent subsidy and other perks. Is this one of the unintended consequences of the women's movement? Will successful women from working-class backgrounds end up supporting privileged men with ideological objections to earning a six-figure income but no qualms about enjoying the options such an income affords?

title: Business People; Keeping a Top Dog Away From the Leash At the Ritz-Carlton
description: Being a top dog at a luxury hotel chain has its privileges. Apparently, walking the top dog isn't one of them.

title: The Wind, Scary. The Water, Deadly
description: THE 65-year-old memory of Sept. 21, 1938, remains etched in my mind. That afternoon, quite suddenly, a fierce wind began to blow against our house on Mackey Avenue in Port Washington. It made my father very jumpy. We were new to the East, but hadn't been warned of anything like this!

title: Beige, Beloved and Sadly Silent
description: IN nearly every quarter of New York, the digital age forges ahead. Passive-aggressive e-mail is flung back and forth, sitcoms are TiVo'd for prime time anytime, and stereo, computer and television components are patched together in an orgy of coil hitherto seen only in anaconda mating season.

title: NOW's Woman Problem
description: The National Organization for Women has chosen a peculiar way to enhance the clout of women in politics. The group has joined another feminist outpost, the National Women's Political Caucus, in endorsing Carol Moseley Braun, the former senator from Illinois and ambassador to New Zealand, for president of the United States.

title: On the Heights, A Chill Wind Begins to Blow
description: TO hear the veteran activists of Morningside Heights tell it, the defining moment came in 1997, when Columbia University descended from its ivory tower and held an audience with its rambunctious neighbors.

title: It Was Northrop Grumman's Party All the Way
description: STANDING in front of a Northrop Grumman building in Bethpage on Monday, surrounded by military aircraft on display, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proclaimed the company's ''unparalleled contribution'' to defense and the economy. Executives talked about plans to hire a thousand more engineers. Politicians wore pleased expressions and discussed the ripple effects of Northrop Grumman's prosperity.

title: Putting Down New Roots
description: YVONNE HARTSFIELD glanced down the street to the corner of Read Street and Shelton Avenue in New Haven. ''Oh, good,'' she said. ''The drug dealers are gone for now.'' She opened the gate of the chain-link fence surrounding her little house on Read Street, built courtesy of Habitat for Humanity. Growing there, by the stone walkway and the lawn, was a garden, flooded with color despite the withering heat.

title: Jessica Toonkel, Maceo Mrquez
description: Jessica Toonkel, the daughter of Jane Dystel and Michael Toonkel, both of Manhattan, was married yesterday in Staatsburg, N.Y., to Ricardo Maceo Mrquez, the son of Dr. Madelaine Mrquez and Prof. Roberto Mrquez of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. James R. Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Belvedere Mansion, an inn.

title: Man Is Shot to Death After a Fraternity Party
description: A 21-year-old Long Island man was killed and two of his friends were wounded in an early-morning shooting yesterday at an off-campus party held by a fraternity at the State University of New York in Stony Brook.

title: Where the Rare Things Are
description: IF we told you where they grew, we would have to kill you. And that would be bad for circulation.

title: For Swedes, Vote on Euro Is Also About Independence
description: As she prepared to shop at the Spar supermarket in this bucolic woodland town, Monica Junevall barely hesitated when asked if she would prefer to shop with the krona, the Swedish currency, or the euro single currency.

And Mr. Nash should call the nursery what it actually is -- a pet shop designed to seduce a gullible public into taking home a baby bird without any idea that it is the equivalent of adopting a creature that will attain the intelligence of a 3-year-old and live 50 to 75 years. Bird lovers are outraged by the new concrete jungle on Watson Island.

description: The Market Watch column last Sunday, about possible conflicts of interest in the mutual fund industry, misidentified the chairman of the Nations Funds of Bank of America, who was described as unavailable for comment. The present chairman is William P. Carmichael; the previous chairman, A. Max Walker, died on Aug. 9.

description: Picture a 280-pound man in full football gear, bent at the waist, feet three feet apart, looking back between his legs and propping a football in front of him.

title: 'That Stomach Is Going to Make You Money Someday'
description: It was hard to read Chris Ballard's article (Aug. 31) and not be sick, but I hope it helps bring about the end of eating competitions. Beyond the obvious contempt they show for those who do not have enough food to live, along with the potential health problems that could come from abusing a body this way, they raise questions I'd like to see the Ethicist address. (Should a restaurant have to let someone ''train'' at its buffet table? Should health insurance have to cover the associated costs?)

title: Slavery in Old New York, A Hospital Bed in the New
description: PIERRE TOUSSAINT

title: Office Rentals Tepid, but Sales Stay Hot
description: THE sluggish economic recovery has held down demand for office space in the metropolitan area. But an abundance of capital has meant that trophy office buildings in Manhattan have sold for eye-popping prices, such as the $1.4 billion paid for the General Motors Building. This apparent paradox continues the pattern of recent quarters, according to real estate professionals, suggesting that not much has changed in the commercial real estate market since the beginning of the year.

title: David Bowie Returns To Earth (Loudly)
description: IN an act of characteristic understatement, David Bowie describes his 26th studio album, ''Reality,'' as ''a bit thrusty.'' Written and recorded shortly after last year's marathon five-borough mini-tour of New York City, ''Reality'' is more than a bit thrusty. The rush of drums and electric guitar that opens the 10th and title track alone is such an adrenaline shot to the heart that the song makes you feel that Mr. Bowie and his spectacularly hard-rocking band might be about to materialize in your living room ready for an encore.

title: SNAPSHOT
description: The true finish is the work of time, and the use to which a thing is put. The elements are still polishing the pyramids. Henry David Thoreau

title: Boston College Not Just Another Visitor
description: The University of Connecticut and Boston College are only 90 miles apart, although the last mile to Rentschler Field today might have taken as long to navigate as the first 89 for many in the sold-out crowd of 40,000 that crawled through the back roads leading to the stadium.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Warwick; Wide Open Spaces and 'Funky Flair'
description: HEADING north on a house-hunting mission on the New York Thruway last summer, Maureen and Robert Cuddeback had no final destination in mind. They knew only that they wanted to escape the high housing prices and congestion of Long Island, where they lived. Exiting in Sloatsburg, they followed a winding road through fields and forests, crossed through Sterling Forest and over Mount Peter and finally stopped when they got to Warwick.

title: Is Fashion Still Cool?
description: WHO killed the cool in fashion? What exactly was it that drained the excitement out of this fascinating, frivolous, inspiring, transformative, gossamer and endlessly diverting business, one that also happens to be among the largest employers in New York City?

title: Stylish Spot on Yonkers' New Waterfront
description: DINERS looking for a dining and drinking spot with sophisticated Manhattan style and Westchester spaciousness will find both at Zuppa, the pioneering restaurant in a revitalized waterfront area that the city of Yonkers had promised for almost two decades. Without apology, Robert Leggio and his co-owners have opened well-groomed Zuppa, a standout beauty on wide Main Street that is a little unkempt now from nearby construction sites.

title: Greed Is Still Good At Some Companies
description: EXECUTIVE greed has become so commonplace that it threatens to join death and taxes among life's grim inevitabilities. When set against the continued layoffs hitting employees across corporate America, however, the cupidity of some executives can take even the most jaded shareholder's breath away.

title: Business People; Don't Disturb the Boss. He's Cruisin' on a Harley.
description: More truckers are becoming techies, according to the Atlas World Group, which last week released a survey of its 3,200 drivers. It showed that 95 percent of them use cellphones on the road, compared with just 62 percent who use CB radios, while nearly a quarter take along laptops.

title: Floating Above Barcelona
description: RETURNING to a city you love is always an iffy proposition. The vintage postcards inside your head can get a little mildewy after, say, a week of downpours in Sydney or getting pickpocketed in Prague. So there were a few jitters last June when my wife, Ruth, and I went back to Barcelona, not just because we adore the place and wanted to keep it that way but also because this time we were meeting up with my in-laws.

title: Labor Leaders Arrested At Rally for Yale Strikers
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president and 120 other union leaders and members were arrested today for civil disobedience as an estimated 5,000 people rallied to support workers on strike at Yale University.

title: Who Can Afford a Yacht?
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Needs Gingerbread?
description: FOR 17 years, David Brown of Old Saybrook has lived in a house made of hay. He has no electricity, makes do without indoor plumbing and gets his water from a pump. His meals, mostly made of food he raises, are cooked with kerosene.

title: Teller's World
description: It would be hard to find a more paradoxical scientific career than that of Edward Teller, a prodigiously creative physicist and weapons expert who died last week at the age of 95. Dr. Teller was widely reviled in the scientific community, reflecting lasting animosities generated by testimony he gave in 1954 that helped brand J. Robert Oppenheimer, the revered leader of the World War II atomic bomb project, as a security risk. It didn't help that most top scientists were liberal proponents of arms control, whereas he was famously hawkish. But in the broader political world, no other scientist had such impact over the past half century as this bushy-browed Hungarian refugee whom critics likened to Dr. Strangelove, Hollywood's fantasy of the mad military strategist. Dr. Teller's doomsday voice warning of the Soviet menace and his optimism about breakthrough weapons found a receptive audience in America's right wing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALIL, EUGENE
description: KALIL--Eugene. Of Manhattan died August 5, 2003, at Bayview Health Care Center in Waterford, CT. He was 92 years old. Born in Lawrence, MA in 1911, he was the son of the late Marie Fakoury and Elias Kalil and the brother of the late Alice Abood of Willimantic, CT and Fred Kalil and Jennie Kalil both of New London. He is survived by his brother Sam Kalil, also of New London and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Kalil graduated from Chapman Technical School in 1930 where he was an Eastern Conference Champion pole vaulter. He went on to Columbia University where he held the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Title in pole vaulting and participated in the Penn Relays. Mr. Kalil graduated from Columbia with a degree in metalurgical engineering in 1938. After graduation, he worked at International Nickel where he developed a procedure for making nickel sheet of the right porosity to separate uranium 235 from uranium 238, a process involved in making the atomic bomb. The War Department recognized his work on the Manhattan Project by awarding him a Certificate of Appreciation on August 6, 1945 for effective service contributing to the successful conclusion of World War II. Mr. Kalil graduated from NY School of Law and went on to become a patent attorney eventually becoming a senior partner at the law firm of Hopgood, Calimafde, Kalil and Judlowe on East 42nd Street in NYC. He was also a teaching instructor for the metalurgical laboratories at Columbia. Mr. Kalil was married to the late Rose Stevens for forty-two years. He was a member of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, NY Athletic Club, The Society for Metals, and he served on the board of the Assad Abood Foundation. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 26 at 11:00 am at the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East 29th St, NY. Interment will follow. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105-1905.

title: Arbus Reconsidered
description: 'Giving a camera to Diane Arbus is like giving a hand grenade to a baby,'' Norman Mailer said after seeing how she had captured him, leaning back in a velvet armchair with his legs splayed cockily. The quip was funny, but a little off base. A camera for Arbus was like a latchkey. With one around her neck, she could open almost any door. Fearless, tenacious, vulnerable -- the combination conquered resistance. In an eye-opening sequence in ''Revelations,'' the compendious new book that is being published in tandem with a full-scale retrospective at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, you discover with a start the behind-the-scenes drama that produced her famous photograph of ''A Naked Man Being a Woman.'' As her title indicates, it is a portrait of a young man standing naked in his apartment, genitals tucked out of sight, in a Venus-on-the-half-shell pose. First she photographed him as a bouffant-haired young matron on a park bench; then at home in a bra and half slip; unwigged and unclothed a few moments later, with legs demurely crossed; up posing for the prized shot; and finally, as a seemingly ordinary fellow back on a park bench. Somehow, she had persuaded him to take her home and expose a secret life. It's what she did again and again. ''She got herself to go up to people on the street and ask if she could photograph them,'' recalls her former husband, Allan Arbus. ''One thing she often said was, 'I'm just practicing.''' He chuckles. ''And indeed, I guess she was.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE first image in THE GARDEN OF THE FINZI-CONTINIS (1970) is of a group of pretty young people in tennis whites, bicycling on the sunny streets of Ferrara, Italy, to their friends' grand home. In this poignant, glowing reverie from Vittorio De Sica, the Fascists are in power and life has begun to change frighteningly for the country's Jews. On the tennis court, the young people joke about being expelled from clubs and schools. Then days roll into weeks, and while the common dramas of life (a serious illness, a love affair, homework) distract them, their world turns quietly upside down. The cast includes Dominique Sanda, Helmut Berger and Lino Capolicchio -- Friday at 12:45 p.m. and Saturday at 10 a.m. on IFC.

title: Northern Exposure
description: In Norway, land of the , the and the Rated X, rebellion may have come to the cuisine at last -- though if I'm right, it will be one in which no shots are fired. Ever since the Vikings took over Iceland and Greenland as pre-Australian penal colonies for their incorrigibles in the 10th century, the culinary stereotype has been that all food in Norway has to look and taste white. A typical serving is boiled cod plated next to florets of cauliflower with a cheese sauce juxtaposed with a few boiled potatoes accompanied by the sour-cream porridge that is a national dish. This is followed by aged cheese snowy as a cleric's collar and concluded with fruits smothered in whipped cream -- all served on bleached china, making the meal a circular celebration of Wite-Out. You might need not just sunglasses to get through dinner but also a can of Jolt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALTERS, RAYMOND, JR.
description: WALTERS -- Raymond, Jr., age 91, passed away on August 30, 2003. A retired New York Times Book Review editor and columnist, he was a well-respected American historian. A courtly and gentle man, his family and friends knew him as the ''local Marco Polo'' as he traveled extensively throughout the world during his lifetime. Some of his favorite pastimes included writing, the theatre, and during his later years, working The New York Times crossword puzzle and eating Hershey bars with almonds. He was a loving and caring mentor and loyal friend to his family and friends. His nephews, Garry, David and Peter Walters, his nieces, Diane Hearne, Ginni Walters, Debbie Sugrue, Martha Walters and numerous nieces and nephews survive him. Donations may be made Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, PA. There will be a memorial gathering to celebrate Ray's life in Manhattan on September 22nd starting at 6 PM. For further details, please contact his niece, Martha Walters, at 415927-4581 or e-mail her at rosewalt@aol.com

title: Romantics Of the Road: The Next Generation
description: AS archetypes go, the wandering songwriter may well be eternal. That figure is as old as African griots, Greek bards and French troubadours, and it rejuvenates with every generation of lone guitar-slingers. Technology stole many of the roles of the old troubadours; they no longer have to carry news from afar or memories of history. Praise songs for particular patrons have given way to love songs anyone can use. What remains for troubadours is to look inward. Now, the job as it has been defined for most of a century is to tell a settled audience about a life in motion, torn between the need to connect and the urge to move on. John Mayer and Josh Ritter, two husky-voiced songwriters in their mid-20's, sing on their new albums about both the romance of the road and the roads taken by romantics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOUSTON, FREDERIC P.
description: HOUSTON--Frederic P. On September 6, 2003 in Maine, at the age of 93, Frederic P. Houston, a superb lawyer, colleague, mentor and friend passed away. He was admitted to the Bar in 1934 after receiving a degree from Williams College in 1931 and a law degree from Harvard Law School. Fred joined Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen in 1936 where his father, Charles A. Houston, was a founding partner in 1909. Fred was a senior member of and counsel to our firm until 1985 when he retired at the age of 75. From 1952-1962, Fred was counsel to the Textile Fabrics Association. He was an Associate Counsel and General Counsel of the New York Board of Trade, Inc. and member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and New York State and American Bar Associations and New York County Lawyers Association where he served on the Committee on Professional Economics. Fred also served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Air Force from 1942-1945 in England and later attained the rank of Lt. Colonel in the Reserves. His wife, Lisa, whom he met in England, predeceased him. Active in his community, he was a founder of the House of the Redeemer where he was a board member, counsel and advisor for forty-five years. He is survived by his son, Douglas, and his daughter - in - law, Heather, of Bristol, ME, and his daughter, Jane McCready and son-in-law, Richard McCready, of Lexington, KY, and by two grandchildren. His good advice, sense of humor and friendship will be missed. The Firm expresses its deepest sympathy to Fred's family. The family has advised that a memorial service in celebration of Fred's life will be held on Saturday, September 27th at noon at St. Andrews Church in Newcastle, ME. The family requests that in lieu of flowers contributions in memory of Fredric P. Houston may be made to House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th Street at Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128. Otterbourg, Steindler, Housont & Rosen, P.C.

title: A Schoolroom Where Life Is the Curriculum

Consider the classroom of Georges Lopez, the teacher and hero of ''To Be and to Have,'' a new film by the French documentarian Nicolas Philibert. For some 20 years, Mr. Lopez (who has retired since the film was shot) stood before the blackboard of a snug village school deep in the Auvergne mountains, introducing about a dozen children ages 3 1/2 to 11 to the magic of multiplication and conjugation, as well as coloring and cooking.

title: Going to Great Lengths
description: Prescribing growth hormones to perfectly healthy youngsters to satisfy some cultural criteria may be going in the wrong direction (Virginia Postrel, Aug. 31). ''Big'' may have been important when men depended on size and muscle power to survive, as well as to attract mates. But it is brain-power that a world of diminishing resources and space appears to need now. In a world of smaller people, pressure on resources -- food, housing, energy -- would be greatly reduced, and so would garbage and pollution. We might also be healthier and live longer. Eventually, women will get past their ancient preference and accept brain-power as the path to the future. Small may indeed turn out to be beautiful.

title: Look, Up in the Sky! A Cablevision Alternative
description: Although Claudia Copquin says, ''Truly, I don't want to hate my cable company'' [Soapbox, Sept. 7] let me give her one more reason to add to her unhappiness. I too was unhappy with Cablevision and decided to switch to DirecTV (incidentally, I'm not totally happy with them either). After my new installation, I called Cablevision to cancel my service. Not knowing that I had already signed with a new provider, the representative immediately offered to cut my $49 bill to $26 and to restore the sports channels they had taken away for an additional $6. Too late! Can you really love a company that admits it has been overcharging you for years?

title: Father in Exile
description: My daughter Alena was born on July 20, and I am lucky I was there. I'm a Democratic Texas state senator from Houston. Things started heating up in Austin early on in my wife Licia's pregnancy, but by her ninth month, they had reached a boiling point. In the Texas Senate, you need two-thirds of the members to agree to bring up a bill. Ten Democrats and one Republican voted to not bring up redistricting. That should have ended it -- until our lieutenant governor changed the two-thirds rule. The House members had broken quorum in May by fleeing Texas, so my fellow Democratic senators and I decided to follow suit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KWIATEK, URSZULA, M.D.
description: KWIATEK--Urszula, M.D. An internal medicine physician who served the diverse ethnic community of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, died at her home in North Hills, NY on September 3, 2003. Born January 9, 1954 in Warsaw, Poland she graduated from Warsaw Medical Academy in 1979. She completed an internal medicine residency and a fellowship in hematology at Jamaica Hospital, NY. She had a passion for entertaining and outdoor activities. Dr. Kwiatek was one of those rare people in whom intelligence, warmth and caring were delicately balanced. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Matthew Kwiatek, and her son Olek, 8 as well as her mother, father and brother in Warsaw, Poland. A memorial service will be held at St. Hyacinth R.C.C. in Glen Cove on September 20 at 11 AM.

title: Fanning Island. Where ?

Fanning is part of the Republic of Kiribati (formerly the Gilberts), and its capital, Tarawa, lies far to the west, more than 2,000 miles away, with nothing but open water in between. The 1,200 residents of Fanning (or it might be 1,600 or maybe 2,000; it keeps changing and no one has made an accurate count) exist amicably in the dreamy, time-honored fashion of South Pacific paradises.

title: The 21st-Century Debate
description: It's been obvious for a long time that the concept of debates between political candidates has fallen upon hard times. We fantasize about Lincoln-Douglas. What we get, frequently, is a scene like the one in Baltimore last week, in which nine Democratic candidates for president stood patiently waiting for their turn to give a one-minute answer to a question from a panel of journalists. It took so long to get down the line that by the time someone popped up for the second time, you felt a flicker of surprise that John Edwards/Bob Graham/John Kerry was still there.

title: Panthers Obstruct the Bucs' Path to Victory
description: Kris Jenkins could not explain how he blocked the extra-point attempt today that forced overtime and helped to create an eventual victory against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, but Jenkins, the Carolina Panthers' defensive tackle, certainly felt the gravity of his feat.

title: Clinton, a Davis Ally, Tries to Provide Boost
description: The beleaguered governor of California imported some out-of-town talent today for aid in his struggle to stay in office.

title: Will 25 be too many at EU's new table?
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union's headquarters here was a hive of activity during the normally languid summer months. Workers tore down walls, laid cable and assembled furniture  literally making space for the 10 countries set to join the European Union in May.

title: Hume Cronyn Memorial
description: A memorial service for the actor Hume Cronyn will be held at noon today at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Cronyn died on June 15. Among those scheduled to speak at the service, which is open to the public, are Robert Redford, Mike Nichols, Zoe Caldwell, Karl Malden, Sigourney Weaver and Glenn Close; there will also be a performance by James Naughton.

title: British Spy Chief Defends Prewar Report on Iraqi Weapons
description: LONDON, Sept. 15  In a rare instance of a head of Britain's MI6 Secret Intelligence Service going public, Sir Richard Dearlove told a judicial inquiry today that his agency had been fully involved in preparing a controversial dossier on Iraqi weapons and considered "reliable" its claim that Saddam Hussein could deploy unconventional weapons in 45 minutes.

title: New Material, Girl: Madonna, a Mama, Starts Writing Books for Children
description: This morning, at tens of thousands of bookstores across the United States and around the world, literary fans of all ages will be able to purchase the latest endeavor by Madonna, whose previous effort, the 1992 erotic picture book ''Sex,'' introduced untold numbers of readers to her views on bondage, bisexuality and the joys of lounging au naturel with the rapper Vanilla Ice.

title: Sharon Aide Says Israel Is Considering Killing Arafat
description: Israel's vice prime minister said today that killing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was one of several options now under government consideration. His remarks came as a beaming Mr. Arafat soaked up the cheers of supporters who descended on his compound for a fourth consecutive day.

title: A Literary Award For Stephen King
description: Under pressure from publishers to shake up its sleepy image, the organization that presents the National Book Awards is planning to give its annual medal for distinguished contribution to American letters to Stephen King.

title: Sun Plans Licensing Strategy To Ease Sales and Upgrades
description: Sun Microsystems is set to announce this week a new strategy for licensing its software to corporations -- an approach intended to simplify the way the company sells, maintains and upgrades its software and, with any luck, help turn its fortunes around.

title: Royal Kaliber Beats Field Again
description: Chris Kappler and the Dutch-bred stallion Royal Kaliber continued their dominance of show jumping in North America yesterday, beating a field of 34 to win the $75,000 American Gold Cup World Cup qualifier at the Devon Horse Show in Devon, Pa., for the second consecutive year.

title: Labor Deal at Chrysler
description: The United Auto Workers and the Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler announced a new labor contract just as the old four-year agreement expired. Negotiations continued between the union and the other two big automakers, Ford and General Motors.

title: The Barnes Takes Steps To Move to Philadelphia
description: After years of wrangling, a major step has been taken toward moving the quirky Barnes Foundation and its fabled collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art from a cozy Philadelphia suburb to an urban site near the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Rodin Museum.

title: A Rap Diva. A Painful Divorce. Cue the Laugh Track.
description: Agents have to stop telling celebrities that their lives could be a sitcom. The results are all too visible in two new UPN shows best described as agenda sitcoms.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a judge's order to transfer control of the Mall of America from the Simon Property Group to a Canadian company, Triple Five, referred incorrectly to parties that were found to have breached their fiduciary duty to Triple Five. They were Melvin and Herbert Simon and Si-Minn L.P., not Simon Property. (Si-Minn is a subsidiary of Melvin Simon & Associates that is controlled by Melvin and Herbert Simon, who are also co-chairmen of Simon Property.)

title: Cell-Tower Plan Trips Up Sale Of Nuns' Land
description: But for an unbuilt 100-foot cross, the Bernardine Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis would have found a way by now to save the 40-room stucco mansion they have owned since 1947.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, FRANKLIN W.
description: WEISS--Franklin W. ''Fred.'' Philanthropist and businessman of Longmeadow, MA, founder and chairman of Plastic Packaging Corp, of West Springfield, MA. died Saturday, September 13, 2003. He leaves his wife Ruth (Calish) Weiss, two daughters, Susan (William) Weiss Firestone of Longmeadow, MA, and Debra (Robert) Weiss Finkel of Swampscott, MA, and five loving grandchildren Rachel, Andrea, Max, Hannah and Aliyah. The funeral is today, September 15, 1 PM, at Sinai Temple, with burial in Sinai Memorial Park, Springfield, MA.

description: Finally, football has become fun, said an exhausted Ricky Williams, who ran inside and outside the Jets' defense today for 125 yards on 34 carries.

title: Death in Underground Frat's Hazing Ritual Shakes a SUNY Campus
description: On a raw, overcast day last March, Walter Dean Jennings, a freshman at the State University of New York here, fell unconscious. By midnight, he was dead. The cause, according to a medical examiner, was hyponatremia, a condition in which sodium in the blood drops to dangerous levels.

title: Editors' Note
description: A design review on Aug. 8 assessed ''USDesign 1975-2000,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Arts & Design in Manhattan, which included household objects by Michael Graves. The review suggested that Mr. Graves's work might have been ''preferentially featured'' because Target Stores, which sells some of his creations, is a main sponsor of the exhibition -- a circumstance that was said to undermine ''the intellectual credibility of the whole show.''

title: Porky Pets
description: Americans, who seem ready to study everything, have now measured the weight problem in the pet world and found it . . . large. The National Academy of Science has reported that a quarter of the dogs and cats in the Western world are now seriously overweight. The usual suspects of snacks and lack of exercise appear to be the problem, along with pet meals that food chemists have made increasingly nutritious and palatable.

description: With weather forecasters all but certain Hurricane Isabel will strike the central Atlantic coast late this week, state and local governments up and down the Eastern Seaboard are bracing for what is expected to be an extremely dangerous storm.

title: Fixing Albany; An Important Afternoon's Work
description: To walk through New York State's Capitol these days is to see a government at rest. Legislators deserted Albany in June, departing with very, very little to brag about after six months on the job. Only the Senate has made firm plans to return tomorrow, maybe only for the afternoon. But even in one day, Joseph Bruno, the majority leader, and his Republican senators could add substance to this year's paltry record by passing a better law on the lobbying of state agencies and agreeing to computerization of campaign finance data statewide.

Lichter, devoted brother to Ruth Soperstein. A respected attorney and retired U.S. Army Colonel, 187th Airborne-Rakkasan. Lester was also a dedicated Jew and Zionist. Funeral today, 1 PM, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry (Saw Mill Exit 17). Memorials to Hadassah or other Jewish charities.

description: The letter from the Republican Party to Bristol-Myers Squibb is as subtle as a sledgehammer. The Republicans expect a $250,000 contribution. The payoff? Jim Nicholson, then the Republican National Committee chairman, encloses the Republican health care package and asks for suggested changes. ''We must keep the lines of communications open,'' he tells the drug giant ominously, ''if we want to continue passing legislation that will benefit your industry.''

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15  A federal appeals court here today delayed the recall election for Gov. Gray Davis, ruling that the scheduled date, Oct. 7, did not give several counties with large minority populations enough time to replace outdated punch-card voting machines.

title: Is Legal Action Against File Swappers Good Business?
description: When ''Hulk'' hit the small screen early, Hollywood hit the roof. Two weeks before this summer's film adaptation of the angry green giant opened in theaters in June, copies started showing up on file-sharing networks around the world. The film cost Universal $150 million to make and distribute, but anyone with a fast Internet connection, a big hard drive and plenty of time could see it free.

description: Angel Koyfman was all alone when she crossed the finish line of the Danskin Women's Triathlon today. In fact, not one of the 397 participants was within a football field of her when the cheers of a small crowd reached her through a thick fog that enveloped the course.

title: Colombia Plans to Ease Penalties for Right-Wing Death Squads
description: President lvaro Uribe, who enjoys strong public support for vowing to bring order to Colombia, is proposing a law that would effectively grant impunity to right-wing death squads that lay down their arms.

title: The Chiefs Start Slowly, And Then Pour It On
description: The Kansas City Chiefs picked a peculiar way to start against the Pittsburgh Steelers. They won the toss, elected to receive, were called for unnecessary roughness after the kickoff and started their first drive on their 15-yard line. A run by Priest Holmes gained 2 yards. On the next play, Trent Green threw an interception that was returned 26 yards for a touchdown by cornerback Chad Scott.

description: The flowers were turning yellow at ground zero yesterday. Tourists were once again posing for smiling snapshots at the edge of the hole, and unlicensed souvenir hawkers were back with their wares set up on tables that snap shut in a hurry should the police arrive.

description: Soon after arriving at the site of the bomb explosions in Bombay that killed more than 50 people last month -- the sixth and most lethal in a recent series of blasts in the city -- Lal Krishna Advani, the deputy prime minister in India's Hindu nationalist government, blamed terrorists based in Pakistan.

description: Steve Stirling, the Islanders' new coach, said yesterday that he would eventually try different combinations of his forward lines, but he does not appear interested in mixing his players just to experiment.

title: New Economy; To stay viable, record companies should make all their music available online, some experts say.
description: THE music industry, hurt by a decline in CD sales and the continued free swapping of files on the Internet, took the drastic action last week of filing more than 250 lawsuits against consumers. But whatever catharsis record executives and their lawyers may feel, the courts cannot solve the music industry's fundamental problem. Nor does the answer lie in getting people to pay for each music file they download from the Internet.

title: With No Knockouts, NBC's Champ Faces Jabs
description: Something about Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment, rubs some people, especially Hollywood people, the wrong way. It may be his style: brash, cocky, hyper-competitive. It may be his high profile: Mr. Zucker and his opinions find their way into numerous news reports. And it may be the self-professed outsider status: he has steadfastly resisted embracing the Hollywood lifestyle, to the point that his return to NBC's corporate suite in New York has been all but assured since he left his previous job running the ''Today'' show in 2000 to move to Burbank, Calif.

title: Drinking at Colleges Is Focus of Study
description: The marketing of lower-priced beer and liquor near college campuses is linked with higher rates of heavy drinking among students, according to a study by the Harvard School of Public Health. The study, released on Friday, was the third major report in a week to focus on alcohol marketing and drinking among young people.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 15 Taliban Killed, U.S. Says
description: American-led forces fighting in the south called in airstrikes on a group of militants in the province of Kandahar, killing 15 suspected Taliban, a military spokesman said. A statement, issued from the United States headquarters at Bagram Air Base outside Kabul, said the strikes were part of Operation Mountain Viper, begun more than a week ago to tackle the growing Taliban insurgency in the south and southeast of the country. There were no reported American casualties. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

description: In an operation closely monitored by President lvaro Uribe, hundreds of troops swarmed today over a coastal mountain range in northern Colombia searching for eight foreign tourists who were kidnapped on Friday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Acquisition
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's biggest phone company, agreed to buy the 51 percent of Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa it did not own after raising a cash offer by 10 percent, to 1.1 billion euros ($1.24 billion). Deutsche Telekom will pay Vivendi Universal 691 million euros, Elektrim 400 million euros and Ymer Finance 9 million euros, Deutsche Telekom said. Polska Telefonia, a cellular telecommunications company, posted profit after tax of about 90 million euros on sales of 1.3 billion euros last year, Deutsche Telekom said. The wireless operator had 5.6 million subscribers at the end of June.

title: Gen. Howard D. Graves, 64; Led West Point and Texas A&M
description: Howard D. Graves, a retired lieutenant general in the Army, a former superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point and the chancellor of the Texas A&M University System until two weeks ago, died on Saturday at his home in College Station, Tex. He was 64.

title: Killing Arafat as Official Policy Is Denied
description: A day after Israel's vice prime minister, Ehud Olmert, said that killing Yasir Arafat was one option under consideration, Foreign Minister Silvan Shalom said today that such a move was ''not the official policy of the Israeli government.''

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: MAYOR RE-ELECTED Anibal Ibarra, an ally of President Nestor Kirchner, won a second term as mayor of Buenos Aires, receiving 53.5 percent of the vote in a runoff against Mauricio Macri, one of the country's richest men. Mr. Kirchner's hand was also strengthened when Peronist candidates for governor and Congress whom he supported won handily in three provinces, including Buenos Aires, which has nearly 40 percent of the country's population. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Wool Production Falling
description: Raw wool production in Australia, the world's largest producer, is expected to fall about 6 percent in 2003-2004, to 440,000 metric tons shorn from 104 million sheep. Australia is the world's leading exporter of wool, particularly of the finer varieties. A drought over the last two years reduced the national sheep stock by about seven million head. It is now recovering as rains return. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNER, ILSE K. (NEE SCHAEFFER)
description: BRENNER -- Ilse K. (nee Schaeffer). Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, and Forest Hills, NY, passed away peacefully on September 14, 2003. Widow of Max Brenner, married for 58 years. She was a devoted and caring daughter, sister, wife, mother, sister-in-law, grandmother, and great grandmother. We were blessed to have her with us for more than 88 years and cherished all of our wonderful memories. She will be sorely missed by her daughter, Joan S. Toder, and her son-in-law, Richard S. Toder, of Scarsdale, NY. Her passing will also be mourned by her grandchildren, Elizabeth Toder, of NY, and David Toder and his wife Colleen, of Highland, NY. Her thoughtfulness will be remembered by her great grandchildren, Sol, Max, and Kiernan. Contributions in her name may be made to: Westchester Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605-2523.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Godard Is Impressive
description: Eric Godard is not with the Islanders to score goals, although he apparently can do that, too. Godard scored twice in a scrimmage today, reinforcing the team's belief that he can do more than throw devastating punches.

title: As Hurricane Isabel Bears Down, Disaster Plans Are Put Into Effect
description: The East Coast girded for the worst today as Hurricane Isabel, its maximum sustained winds easing slightly to a still-powerful 120 miles per hour, churned up the Atlantic. Forecasters said that if the storm stayed on track, it would slam into the fragile Outer Banks of North Carolina in three days and grind on up Chesapeake Bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, BERNARD
description: FRANK -- Bernard, Concert Pianist, 91. He began his music studies at the prestigious Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia and performed for the first time at Carnegie Hall when he was nine years old. He toured the world passionately performing the music of his favorite composers. He inspired all his students, of which there were more than 5,000 in the course of his life. He loved his family with unparelled devotion and have the gift of giving everyone who knew him the sense that they were special in some way to him. His multiple achievements as an artist, teacher, husband, brother, father and friend have earned him a permanent resting place in the hearts of all who knew him. He is survived by his daughter Helene Resnick and her husband Gerry, beloved granddaughter Kimberly and son Steven Richard Frank of Fort Lauderdale. For information ''Wien & Wien'',1-800-322-0533.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Three Students Hurt In Shooting
description: Three high school boys were shot yesterday, but none fatally, during a confrontation after school that apparently involved dozens of youths near the Brooklyn-Queens line, the police said. A 16-year-old and a 17-year-old were shot in the ankle, and a 17-year-old was shot in the arm, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education. All three, 10th graders at Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn, were taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center and were in stable condition, she said. The shootings occurred at 3:30 p.m. at Jamaica Avenue and Eldert Lane, the police said. A witness, who identified himself only as George, 19, a Queens College student, said he heard shots and watched from Jamaica Avenue as about two dozen young men ran south on Eldert Lane. A 9-millimeter handgun was found at the scene, the police said. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | People: Chiron Chairman To Retire Next Year
description: The Chiron Corporation, the nation's third-biggest biotechnology company, said yesterday that its chairman, Sean P. Lance, would retire in May 2004. The chief executive, Howard H. Pien, has been selected by the board to succeed him. Mr. Lance, 56, also held the titles of president and chief executive until April, when Mr. Pien, 45, replaced him in those roles, Chiron said. Chiron's products include more than 30 vaccines, drugs for cancer and multiple sclerosis and medical tests like one for West Nile virus.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Eavesdropping Evidence Left Intact
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that the federal government had acted properly in conducting surveillance of Lynne F. Stewart, a prominent lawyer, and two co-defendants. In July, the most serious charges against the three were dismissed. Ms. Stewart had been accused of supporting terrorism by helping an imprisoned sheik direct terrorist operations in Egypt. The three still face lesser charges, including that Ms. Stewart lied to and conspired to defraud the federal government. Yesterday, Judge John G. Koeltl refused to suppress evidence collected under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Ms. Stewart was not a target of the surveillance, the judge noted, but was intercepted while communicating with others who were targets. All three have pleaded not guilty. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, PAUL I.
description: BROWN--Paul I. On Saturday, September 13, 2003. Beloved husband of Arline Brown for 50 years. Devoted father of Alan Brown, Jeffrey Brown and Susan Brown Mandel. Dear father-in-law of Linda Foxworthy and Victoria Brown, and Andrew Mandel. Loving Zadie of Sam and Aaron Brown, Isabel and Daniel Brown and Henry and Lucy Mandel. Services were held at Sol Levinson and Bros. Home, Baltimore, MD, 1-800338-1701, on Monday, September 15. Interment Baltimore, MD. In honor of his caring physicians Dr. David Posner and Dr. Lynn Ratner Memorial Contributions may be sent to Lenox Hill Hospital, 160 East 77 St., NY, NY 10021; or Thorasic Surgery Dept., c/ o Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, 622 W. 168th St., NY, NY 10032 in honor of Dr. Mark Ginsberg. In mourning at, his late residence Wednesday 210pm & Thursday 11am-3pm.

description: US Airways has finally relented and changed its policy on nonrefundable tickets to bring it in line with the other big network carriers. Under the revision, passengers who cancel a ticket before departure have a year to use the value of that ticket for another trip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDEL, JOSIE
description: MENDEL--Josie. We at Congregation B'nai Yisrael mourn the loss of our friend, neighbor, and Religious School teacher; we will miss the warmth of her smile. We share our deep sadness with her husband Andy, and her sons Adam and Josh. Barby K. Siegel, President Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz Rabbi Seth M. Limmer Cantor Miriam Eskenasy

title: U.S. Says 8 Captives in Iraq Claim to Be American or British
description: KHALDIYA, Iraq, Sept. 16  A United States general said today that six people identifying themselves as American and two people saying they are British were being held prisoner in connection with guerrilla attacks here.

title: General Manager Is Replaced In a Reorganization at CNN
description: Trailing in the ratings behind the Fox News Channel, CNN announced a reorganization yesterday meant to help it produce more compelling news programs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telewest Plan Advances
description: Telewest Communications, Britain's second-biggest cable-television company, said its two biggest shareholders, Liberty Media and IDT, had agreed to back a plan to hand bondholders control. Liberty's and IDT's assent means Telewest needs approval only from its banks before presenting the accord to shareholders with smaller stakes. Bondholders will get 98.5 percent of the shares in return for 3.5 billion ($5.6 billion), Telewest said in a Regulatory News Service statement.

title: NORTHWESTERN CORP. IS SEEKING BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The NorthWestern Corporation, a Montana utility owner and ener gy trader with losses in five of the past six quarters, filed for bankruptcy protection, with $1.76 billion of debt, after failing to refinance or sell stock. Bank One provided a commitment for $100 million of bankruptcy financing to continue operations, NorthWestern said. The company, based in Sioux Falls, S.D., agreed to sell Expanets, a communications services unit not part of the Chapter 11 filing, to Cerberus Capital Management and TenX Capital Management Inc. for $107.5 million.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Comptroller Running For Senate
description: State Comptroller Daniel W. Hynes has announced that he is running for the United States Senate, adding his name to those of about a half-dozen other Democrats seeking the position. The seat is being vacated by Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, a first-term Republican. Mr. Hynes, who, like other candidates, is seeking the endorsement of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., announced his candidacy on Sunday in front of members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers in Chicago. Mr. Hynes, 35, was elected comptroller in 1998 and re-elected in 2002. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Council Seeking Notice on Homeless Shelter Plans
description: Concerned about efforts to open more emergency shelters to accommodate a growing homeless population, the New York City Council appears likely to adopt legislation requiring the city to alert local communities to any plans for new shelters there.

title: British Spy Chief Stands Behind Disputed Iraq Dossier at Inquiry
description: In a rare instance of a director of Britain's Secret Intelligence Service, M.I.6, going public, Sir Richard Dearlove testified today at a judicial inquiry that his agency was fully involved last year in preparing a dossier on Iraqi weapons and had considered ''reliable'' its claim that Saddam Hussein could deploy unconventional weapons in 45 minutes.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CORNING INC., Corning, N.Y., the world's largest maker of fiber optic cable, said it sold most of CIV, its venture capital investment unit, to Scimitar Capital Partners, a private equity firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Comfort Foods Switch Off Stress, Scientists Find
description: When life is not going so smoothly and people reach for goodies full of fat and sugar, they are doing more than surrendering to cravings. Comfort foods like chocolate cake and ice cream literally blunt the body's response to chronic stress, scientists reported last week.

title: Some Top Prospects Missing In Rangers' Intrasquad Game
description: As the Rangers held their annual Blue-White intrasquad game tonight at the University of Vermont, one of the purposes of the scrimmage at the end of training camp was to get a better look at the organization's prospects in game situations.

title: Corrections
description: The Religion Journal column on Sept. 6, about Web sites for people questioning their faith, misidentified the one founded by Eric Kettunen when he left the Mormon Church. It is exmormon.org, not ex-mormon .org. The column also misspelled the surname of a woman who is president of another site for former Mormons, exmormonfoundation.org. She is Sue Emmett, not Emmet.

title: Cubs' Fan On Mets Gets Look At Wrigley
description: Mets outfielder Jeff Duncan grew up 30 miles from Wrigley Field, one of the few fans who could divide his Chicago allegiance between the Cubs and the White Sox. Last year, when he completed his minor league season at Class A, Duncan attended a few games here in September, watching the Cubs close out another losing season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPICK, MORRIS
description: POPICK--Morris. A great many members of the staff of GVA Williams were lucky enough to have spent many decades in association with Morris Popick. Morris was generous, caring, considerate, honorable, warm and friendly and on top of that very knowledgeable. He could virtually name every tenant on every floor in every building in the areas of the city in which he was most active. Morris always went out of his way to be helpful to others for the more than forty years he was with us. We shall miss him. We extend our condolences to his family.

title: TEACHERS BARTER WITH WORK RULES
description: New York City's teachers' union will propose a wide-ranging experiment to do away with the bulk of the work rules that have long enraged city officials in exchange for getting teachers a greater say in how individual schools are run, the union president, Randi Weingarten, said yesterday.

title: Southampton Blocks Petition for 'Dunehampton' Village
description: It's going to take a lot more to raise a village.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Defibrillator Distribution Expands
description: The New York City Police Department has equipped every precinct, transit and housing district with defibrillators to help save the lives of people having heart attacks, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday. Since the department began outfitting precincts with portable defibrillators, officers have restarted the hearts of 16 people, 4 of whom survived, the Police Department said. The Fire Department has also equipped each of its 197 engine companies with defibrillators. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Friday about the playoff hopes of the Cubs and the White Sox incompletely described the life cycle of cicadas in Chicago. While some have appeared after 13 years underground, most emerge after 17 years.

title: A Tribute to the Legacy of Johnny Cash in Word and Song
description: Johnny Cash, country music's Man in Black, was laid to rest in a jet-black coffin today, exactly four months after the death of his wife, June Carter Cash. In a two-hour private ceremony that was closed to the general public and television cameras at Mr. Cash's own church, the First Baptist Church of Hendersonville, preachers, country stars, family members and former Vice President Al Gore paid tribute to Mr. Cash's music and legacy in word and song.

title: Shows Blur Football and Showbiz
description: With just minutes left the other day on ''Fox NFL Sunday,'' the comedian Wanda Sykes (a guest promoting her Fox sitcom, ''Wanda at Large'') referred to the gay slur that Jeremy Shockey allegedly used to describe Dallas Coach Bill Parcells, then jokingly said that Parcells ''looks a little like a lesbian.''

title: Medical History's Oddballs Go Prime Time
description: The medical oddballs today who feel shunned by mainstream practitioners can take comfort, for better or worse, in a new mini-series on medical history that makes heroes of fanatical scientists of yesteryear. To say the least, they lacked tact.

description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Mexico City; Old City Is Seeking Its Place In New Era
description: Mexico City, with a population of more than 20 million, is slowly overcoming its reputation as an urban nightmare of poverty, crime and smog. ''There is a feeling of being proud of the city,'' said Carlos Carrillo, the lifestyle editor for the Mexico City business magazine Expansin. ''It is becoming hip.''

title: Live or Digital? The Bugler's Lips Are Sealed
description: It was bound to happen in our technology-mad world. A device has been invented that not only replaces humans, but also lays them to rest.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Drug Users' Center Opens
description: Canada's first legal and supervised drug-injection clinic opened in a downtown storefront in Vancouver, despite criticism from the Bush administration that the policy would encourage more heroin use. The clinic is expected to service 800 drug users a day, who will bring their own drugs. The injection site, modeled after clinics in Europe and Australia, is the only one operating openly in North America. Its objective is to dispense clean needles to reduce disease. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: When a Doctor Stumbles on a Family Secret
description: A group of health professionals were evaluating potential donors for a kidney transplant recently when they received a surprise. Through routine genetic testing, the group inadvertently learned that one of the adult children was not the child of the man with kidney failure.

title: Untangling the Knots Of a Brooklyn Boyhood
description: When Jonathan Lethem was growing up on Dean Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, one of the few white faces in a black and Hispanic sea, he was constantly being grabbed and frisked for his pocket change or bus pass by the neighborhood kids, he recalled the other day. It was the 1970's, before great waves of middle-class homesteaders cascaded through the leafy streets, buying and renovating historic brownstones, back when the few whites living in the shadow of a jail and two housing projects tended to be socially conscious types like Mr. Lethem's parents.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Argentine Utility For Sale
description: lectricit de France, Europe's largest power company, said it was seeking a buyer for Empresa Distribuidora de Electricidad de Mendoza, an Argentine unit that has never had a profit because of a rate freeze. lectricit de France, the government-controlled utility, said the decision to sell Edemsa, as the unit is known, will not affect the company's other interests in Argentina, like Edenor, an electricity distributor that serves Buenos Aires and 20 municipalities in the city's outskirts. Edemsa distributes electricity in the western province of Mendoza. lectricit de France is based in Paris.
