description: State Looks to Canada

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIM, MILAGROS, M.D.
description: SIM--Milagros, M.D. The physicians and staff of QueensLong Island Medical Group, P.C. are profoundly saddened by the passing of our beloved friend, colleague and Group shareholder. Dr. Sim was a distinguished and dedicated obstetrician/gynecologist with our Group for 24 years. She was admired and respected by her patients and fellow physicians. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Suman Reejsinghani, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer

title: Luring Customers Back to the Water
description: What does a designer of Italian luxury motorboats do when he visits the coast of Maine? He goes home and builds a $900,000 lobster boat.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: BRIBERY TRIAL DELAYED OVER JURY ISSUE A federal judge dismissed the jury yesterday in the trial of a man charged in connection with the bribery scandal involving former State Treasurer Paul J. Silvester. All the jurors are white, and the defendant, Ben F. Andrews, is black. Judge Ellen Bree Burns did not mention the racial composition of the jury as a reason for dismissing the jurors. In a ruling dated Friday and made public yesterday, the judge said a new jury should be impaneled "in the interests of justice and to ensure that both the government and the defendant receive a fair trial." She ordered selection of a new jury to begin Oct. 1. Mr. Andrews, a former candidate for secretary of the state, faces charges that include racketeering, bribery and witness tampering, for what prosecutors said were illegal dealings with a state investment fund. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Delay Could Allow Recall Fever Time to Cool
description: COMPTON, Calif., Sept. 15  Word of a federal appeals court decision that could postpone the recall election for months reached Gov. Gray Davis this morning as he was preparing to join former President Bill Clinton at the dedication of the William Jefferson Clinton Elementary School in this poor suburb of Los Angeles.

title: New Twist in Recall Brings Anger From Right
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15  In yet another dizzying week for the California recall, the following occurred:

title: AMERICAN EQUITY IS SEEKING $247 MILLION IN OFFERING
description: The American Equity Investment Life Holding Company, which offers annuity and life insurance products, plans to raise as much as $247.3 million in an initial public offering, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said it would use the proceeds to add capital to its two life insurance units, the American Equity Investment Life Insurance Company and the American Equity Investment Life Insurance Company of New York. The insurer, whose chief executive is David Noble, hired Merrill Lynch & Company, along with Advest Inc. to arrange the sale.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Self-Immolation Attempt
description: A homeowner seeking to prevent the government from seizing his house and relocating his family tried to set himself on fire in Tiananmen Square, the latest sign that forced relocations to make way for development had pushed some people to take extreme measures. The New China News Agency said the man, from Anhui Province, poured gasoline on himself and set his clothes on fire. He suffered slight injuries. Displaced urban residents have been traveling to Beijing in large numbers, demanding that the government force developers to pay higher compensation for their homes. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Tone Turns Divisive In Discussion of Race In Attacks on S.I.
description: A news conference called to condemn recent racially charged incidents on Staten Island was itself cause for disunity yesterday, as the two white city councilmen present found themselves disagreeing with their black colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEMIATIN, JACOB
description: SEMIATIN -- Jacob. Artist. Born 1915 in Dublin, Ireland. Died August 28, 2003 in Manhattan where he lived most of his life. His watercolors, acrylics and oils were praised at numerous shows in NYC during his lifetime; works hang in museums and private collections around the world. Leaves devoted family including beloved wife of 49 years Ludmila (nee Rosenfeld), brother Lionel, sister Eva Gilbert, eight nieces and nephews and twelve grandnieces and grandnephews. Predeceased by parents Herman and Sarah and sisters Esther Rosenthal and Leah Citron. His humor and free spirit will be greatly missed.

title: AOL Time Warner Is Set To Sell Two Atlanta Teams
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its N.B.A. and N.H.L. teams in Atlanta, the Hawks and the Thrashers, along with their arena. The company would not reveal the buyer until today, but it did say it was not the previously disclosed suitor.

title: Canada's House of Commons Debates Definition of Marriage
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16  The House of Commons debated today an opposition motion reaffirming that marriage is by definition a union between men and women. The vote, scheduled for late in the day, was expected to be close and a crucial test for the Liberal government's effort to extend marriage rights nationwide to same-sex couples.

title: U.N. Session on Middle East Turns Fractious
description: A scheduled Security Council meeting on the Middle East was transformed today by the events of the last few days into a series of speeches, many of which attacked Israel for its recent actions in the West Bank and most recently its decision to expel Yasir Afafat, the Palestinian leader.

title: Lockheed Set To Buy Titan For $1.8 Billion
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said last night that it would buy the Titan Corporation for $1.8 billion in cash and stock to handle more of the government's communications systems and information networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERIN, HELEN L.
description: HALPERIN--Helen L. On September 15, 2003, peacefully after a long illness. Survived by two sons, Dr. Mitchell Halperin of Spring Hill, FL, and Dr. Peter Halperin of Port Jefferson, NY, and four grandchildren, Laura, Jennifer, Jonathan and Daniel. Service September 18, 2003, 1pm, Hillsdale NY, burial September 19, 2003, 11am, Montefiore Cemetery, Queens NY.

title: WORLDCOM INCORRECTLY REPORTS INQUIRY IN VIRGINIA
description: WorldCom Inc. made a mistake in a bankruptcy court filing, incorrectly stating that a federal prosecutor in Virginia was investigating its call-routing practices. WorldCom, the second-biggest long-distance telephone company in the United States, will submit a corrected filing as soon as possible, said Sudie Nolan, a spokeswoman for WorldCom. Federal prosecutors in New York are examining WorldCom's call routing, as well as the company's $11 billion in accounting misstatements. The AT&T Corporation, the market leader, has accused WorldCom of disguising some calls and improperly routing others to skirt network-access fees. WorldCom, based in Ashburn, Va., reiterated yesterday that an internal investigation turned up no wrongdoing.

title: Republicans for Dean
description: The results of the highly prestigious Poll of the Pollsters are in! I called eight of the best G.O.P. pollsters and strategists and asked them, on a not-for-attribution basis, if they thought Howard Dean would be easier to beat than the other major Democratic presidential candidates. Here, and I'm paraphrasing, are the results:

title: Fumes Inside a Bronx Boiler Kill 2 Workers
description: Two maintenance workers trying to clean out a fuel tank in the basement of a Bronx apartment building were killed yesterday when they apparently inhaled lethal vapors inside the tank, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EWY, BRADLEY J.
description: EWY--Bradley J. The staff of The Corkery Group mourn the passing of our colleague and friend, Brad Ewy on September 11, 2003. Deeply committed to his work and to the cause of HIV prevention, Brad was instrumental in building support for national efforts to stop the disease's spread. He was an inspiration and mentor to all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his parents, Harold and Joan Ewy of Sunrise Beach, MO, his sisters, Chris Simon, Cindy Thompson and Laura Davis, and his fiancee Tiffany Woolf. Memorial service will be held at a later date. In honor of his work, his family requests that donations be made to WhitmanWalker Clinic in Washington, D.C. (www.wwc.org).

title: Disco Legend, but No Feathers
description: They were fabulous figures from a bygone era, prancing about Plaid night club last week as if it were 1995.

title: Tokyo Journal; A Flashy Teenage Trend Capital, and Its Dark Side
description: Up and down Shibuya's iridescent streets, Japan's teenage girls come and go, on their pilgrimage to their own corner of Tokyo. The heavily made-up Ko-gals, the tanned surfers in their beachwear, the dancers, or those sticking to the now fashionable school uniforms -- they represent the panoply of Japan's quickly shifting teenage fashion.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about an appearance by former President Bill Clinton at a rally in Indianola, Iowa, omitted a word from a statement he made about the Democratic contenders for the presidential nomination. He said (with the restored word indicated by brackets), ''I get tired of [people] saying the field can't beat the incumbent president.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Abuse Of Elderly Increases
description: Accounts of abuse of the elderly have risen 15 percent in the state, probably because of better reporting and a growing population of old people, said Sinikka Santala, administrator of the State Health Department's Division of Disability and Elder Services. There were 3,721 reports of abuse of the elderly in 2002, up from 3,223 in 2001, according to the annual Wisconsin Report on Elder Abuse. While many of the cases stem from self-neglect, including poor dietary habits and unsanitary living conditions, some elderly people are also abused by their children or spouses, Ms. Santala said. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: THREE STUDENTS HURT IN SHOOTING Three high school boys were shot yesterday, but none fatally, during a confrontation after school that apparently involved dozens of youths near the Brooklyn-Queens line, the police said. A 16-year-old and a 17-year-old were shot in the ankle, and a 17-year-old was shot in the arm, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education. All three, 10th graders at Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn, were taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center and were in stable condition, she said. The shootings occurred at 3:30 p.m. at Jamaica Avenue and Eldert Lane, the police said. A witness, who identified himself only as George, 19, a Queens College student, said he heard shots and watched from Jamaica Avenue as about two dozen young men ran south on Eldert Lane. A 9-millimeter handgun was found at the scene, the police said. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: Voting Machines, Again; Delaying the California Recall
description: It is a serious matter for a court to stop an election, but the federal appeals court that put off California's gubernatorial recall did the right thing. If the vote goes ahead as scheduled, using defective punch-card ballots in some areas, tens of thousands of votes will not be counted. Routinely throwing out votes is unacceptable, as is discriminating based on where voters live. California should replace its punch cards and hold the recall next March.

title: 4 States Sue E.P.A., Citing Health Risk Of Pesticide Residue
description: The attorneys general of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts sued the federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday, claiming that it fails to protect children from the risk of eating food containing unsafe levels of pesticide residue.

title: Judge Hears Age-Bias Suit By Agents At Allstate
description: A lawyer for agents in a long-running age discrimination dispute against Allstate said today that company executives told the board in the summer of 1999 that summarily dismissing ''low-performing agents'' in a drive for greater efficiency was ''not legally possible.'' It was the first face-to-face courtroom confrontation in the case.

title: Soriano Attains 30-30 Milestone
description: When the Yankees came to Camden Yards last September for the final series of the regular season, Alfonso Soriano was desperate. He needed one home run to join the 40-40 club, hallowed home for the fast and the fearsome. Flailing away, Soriano went 1 for 14 in the series and finished with 39 homers.

title: From the Road to Recovery to Memory Lane
description: Noteworthy older films are the news this week. John Sayles goes from Secaucus to outer space in three of his movies from the 80's. With ''The Lion King'' due on Oct. 7, Disney warms up with a fairy tale from 1959. For a new special edition of one of its old movies, Monty Python packs in even more extra features than it had on the last special edition (an old video trick). And there's some good television from the late 70's.

title: Top Aide in Kerry Campaign Announces His Resignation
description: A senior consultant to Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts who favored a more aggressive approach to his presidential campaign announced his resignation today, less than two weeks after Mr. Kerry said he did not expect any major changes in his staff.

title: Open War Over, Iraqis Focus On Crime and a Hunt for Jobs
description: The judge sits in his chambers, waiting.

title: Ex-Managers at Bank May Face Charges
description: Bank of America has been notified that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York attorney general are considering bringing cases against former employees of the bank later this week, people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: The Perils of Pleasant, Or Spacey, on Talk Shows
description: At the end of ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show,'' a new syndicated daily talk show, Ellen DeGeneres takes questions from the audience. On Monday she fielded inquiries about interior decoration, the food in her fridge and her plans for the holidays. These were polite questions, asked by guests humoring their host; no one appeared to care about the answers.

title: Company That Cloned Sheep To Sell Assets and Shut Down
description: Scotland's PPL Therapeutics, a spinoff of the Roslin Institute that propelled the biotechnology industry into a new realm seven years ago when it cloned a sheep named Dolly, said today that it would sell its last assets and close.

title: Administration Joins Outcry Against China Trade Policies
description: The Bush administration today singled out China for criticism over trade practices, adding to a groundswell of objections against China in political and business circles.

title: Delay Could Allow Recall Fever Time to Cool
description: Word of a federal appeals court decision that could postpone the recall election for months reached Gov. Gray Davis this morning as he was preparing to join former President Bill Clinton at the dedication of the William Jefferson Clinton Elementary School in this poor suburb of Los Angeles.

title: Indian Point Security Test Is Called Too Easy
description: A mock attack to test security at the Indian Point nuclear plant this summer used too few attackers and assumed they would not have access to some commercially available weapons, according to a nonprofit group here that has reported extensively on reactor security.

title: The Cancn Failure
description: Cancn means ''snakepit'' in the local Mayan language, and it lived up to its name as the host of an important World Trade Organization meeting that began last week. Rather than tackling the problem of their high agricultural tariffs and lavish farm subsidies, which victimize farmers in poorer nations, a number of rich nations derailed the talks.

title: Excerpts From Ruling by Three-Judge Panel on California's Recall Election
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling yesterday by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that delayed the California recall election until next March. The full text of the ruling is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: 2 Investment Banks Asked to Help in Nets Sale
description: YankeeNets officially put the Nets up for sale yesterday and named two investment banks, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers, to find buyers.

title: Yes, a School Breakfast, but What Kind?
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Placed on Leave After He Backed Grasso
description: The controversy over the pay of Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has stirred such a cauldron of emotions that a former vice chairman of the exchange has been placed on leave after voicing support for Mr. Grasso.

title: Retail Operator At Trade Center Is Pulling Out Of the Deal
description: Westfield America, the mall operator that owns the lease for retail space at the World Trade Center, said yesterday that it was negotiating a cash settlement to pull out of its deal on the downtown complex.

title: Coming U.S. Vote Figures In Walkout at Trade Talks
description: It may be more than a year away, but the United States presidential election is already throwing a long shadow. Here in Cancn this week, it was enough to touch off a walkout by delegates from developing nations at the World Trade Organization talks who were convinced that it was hopeless to expect any realistic negotiations with the Americans this year on farm subsidies.

title: We Got Rhythm; the Mystery Is How and Why
description: In lovers' songs, military marches, weddings and funerals -- every occasion where a degree of emotion needs to be evoked -- music is an indispensable ingredient.

title: Forgo Flu and Attack Asthma
description: Despite a government recommendation that people with asthma receive annual flu vaccinations, only about a third do so, a new study reports.

title: Many Miles, Many Moons: A Galileo Album
description: On Sunday, several hundred engineers and scientists will gather at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., and await the end of the Galileo spacecraft in a suicide plunge into Jupiter's dense atmosphere.

title: Small Town U.S.A. Losing Air Service
description: Planning a business trip if you live in Ottumwa, Iowa, is not easy. The town of 25,000 people lost its only commercial air service two years ago when the regional carrier United Express ended its two daily flights to Chicago.

title: New York and S.E.C. Charge Broker in 'Late Trading' Case
description: Furthering his investigation into the mutual fund industry, New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, filed criminal charges today against a former broker at the Bank of America Corporation who is accused of helping a hedge fund illegally trade mutual fund shares.

title: Radio Ad Revenue Grew 3% in July
description: Advertising revenue for radio networks and stations grew again in July, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERMAN, GEORGE
description: LIEBERMAN--George. We were fortunate to have had George Lieberman as our partner for 37 years. George possessed keen intelligence, consummate integrity and a tremendous dedication to our firm and our profession. He was a friend to all of us and we will always remember the sweetness of his spirit. We want to express our deepest sympathy to his cherished wife, Renee, his daughter, Jeanie Gallancy, and his grandson, Daniel Gallancy. The funeral will take place today at 9:30 AM at Schwartz Bros., 114-03 76th Road at Queens Blvd., Forest Hills. The Partners of Eisner LLP

title: Goodyear's Union Approves Contract
description: Workers at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire maker, ratified a three-year contract that calls for wage freezes in exchange for unusually strong job protections, union and company officials said yesterday.

title: Putting the Rank in Subway Rankings
description: With the hot weather drawing to a close, it is finally time to reveal the results of this column's long-awaited survey of summer subway smells.

title: Oil Company In Norway Under Cloud
description: Directors of Statoil, Norway's state-controlled oil company, were weighing the fate last night of the company's chief executive, Olav Fjell, after revelations about a $15.5 million consulting contract said to involve the son of the former president of Iran, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.

title: Dallas Ruins Giants' Comeback in Overtime
description: A soaking rain finally stopped at halftime, and the Giants finally started, turning a no-hope, 16-point third-quarter deficit into a Monday Night Football game with enough twists and turns for a whole season.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Suit Is Dismissed
description: Verizon Wireless was blocked yesterday in a bid to sue an official at the Communications Workers of America for using its advertising slogan during a conference call. Verizon Wireless had asserted that a union vice president violated an agreement by publicly using the phrase, ''Can you hear me now,'' a tagline used in Verizon advertising. Judge Mary Cooper of United States District Court in New Jersey threw out the case, the union said in a statement. Verizon Wireless is a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, KURT
description: ROSENTHAL--Kurt, on September 14, 2003. Beloved husband of Doris; father of Kenneth and the late Stuart, six grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren. His photography mirrored the beauty of his life.

title: Ashcroft Mocks Librarians and Others Who Oppose Parts of Counterterrorism Law
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft today accused the country's biggest library association and other critics of fueling ''baseless hysteria'' about the government's ability to pry into the public's reading habits.

title: Analyst Leaves Wells Fargo
description: Jennifer Black, one of the country's most outspoken retail analysts, has left Wells Fargo Securities to open her own firm, Jennifer Black & Associates, effective today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBLER, PHILIP
description: DUBLER--Philip, age 83, was a very remarkable person who, in life, gave freely and enjoyed every moment he shared with his devoted wife Shirley. He was an adoring father and special friend to his children Karen and Steven. He was a loving grandfather to Justin and Alex and shared a very special loving relationship with his grandson Scott. He leaves behind his loving sister Gertrude and brother-in-law Jack, daughter-in-law Pam, his adoring sister-in-law Lois and brother-in-law Wade, his cousin Lester and a multitude of cousins and devoted friends.

title: Of Bluebloods And Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fort Lee: $30 Million For Bridge Project
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey joined with Fort Lee officials and Bergen County officials yesterday to announce a $30 million improvement in a number of local streets that lead to the George Washington Bridge. The widening, realignment, new construction and signal enhancements are intended to ease congestion in the area around the bridge and on the local ramps leading to the bridge, which is owned by the Port Authority. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell to a four-month low after OPEC said it would invite Iraq to attend a meeting next week. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 13 cents, or 0.5 percent, to $28.14 a barrel.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: A Bank Robber With a Routine?
description: A 42-year-old man was arrested yesterday for robbing or trying to rob the same bank five times since January 2001, most recently on Sept. 4, the police said. The man, Darry Alexander, of Atlantic Avenue, was charged with robbing or trying to rob the Washington Mutual Bank, at 12 Graham Avenue in East Williamsburg, in March, June, August, and September of this year. He also robbed the Dime Savings Bank that was previously at that address, in 2001, the police said. He took a total of more than $6,000, they said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Microbes Beating the Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Huge Debt, Large Farm Co-op Is Closing Down; Farmland Industries Battled Major Food Conglomerates
description: Two years ago, Farmland Industries, the nation's largest farmer-owned co-op, dedicated a new headquarters here that seemed to symbolize the company's emergence as a corporate giant.

title: The Shining Moment
description: When they call the roll of the great figures of modern American literature -- Bellow, Miller, Morrison, Updike, Roth -- they can now add a name: Stephen King.

title: Music of the Heavens Turns Out to Sound a Lot Like a B Flat
description: Astronomers say they have heard the sound of a black hole singing. And what it is singing, and perhaps has been singing for more than two billion years, they say, is B flat -- a B flat 57 octaves lower than middle C.

title: Labor Pacts Reached at Ford and Chrysler
description: The Ford Motor Company and the auto parts giant Visteon said late this evening that they had reached tentative agreement on four-year labor contracts with the United Automobile Workers union.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pumatech To Acquire Synchrologic For $60 Million
description: Pumatech Inc., a maker of software for wireless devices, agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Synchrologic Inc. for about $60 million, its fourth purchase this year, to add products. Synchrologic, based in Atlanta, sells software that allows customers access to e-mail, data and Internet content from laptops and cellphones. Pumatech, based in San Jose, Calif., has increased revenue by adding services and licensing software to companies, including Microsoft and Oracle. Shares of Pumatech rose 28 cents, to $4.15.

title: Provision in Energy Bill Brings Unease in G.O.P.
description: To conservative Republicans, especially those from the West, few things are more sacred than property rights. Their attitude is usually that the government, especially the federal government, should keep its hands off private land.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Seeking Better Campaign Finance Reports
description: Nearly two years after a state agency began posting candidates' campaign finance reports on the Internet, none are presented in a way in which they can be easily searched, a government watchdog group said. And the group, Money and Politics Iowa, said that with many candidates choosing instead to file paper reports with the state, it is difficult to compare financial records. State Representative J. Scott Raecker, chairman of the House Ethics Committee, is sponsoring legislation that would require all candidates for statewide offices, as well as all legislators, to file their campaign reports on the Web, as opposed to paper filing. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: McDonald's Enlists Trainer To Help Sell Its New Meal
description: How many footsteps would it take to burn off the calories in a supersize Big Mac value meal? Bob Greene, Oprah Winfrey's personal trainer, may soon have the answer.

title: U.S. Officials Pull Questions From Surveys About Children
description: The board that oversees national achievement tests has moved to curtail sharply the background surveys of students, teachers and principals that accompany the examinations, alarming researchers and others who rely on the surveys as an important source of information.

title: Yes, a School Breakfast, but What Kind?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Arrested in Killing of Tennis Champions' Half-Sister
description: The authorities charged a 24-year-old man today in the killing of Yetunde Price, a half-sister of the tennis champions Serena and Venus Williams, and sought four other possible suspects.

title: The Readers Write Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panel Expected to Vote On Bill to Aid Pension Plans
description: The Senate Finance Committee is expected to vote tomorrow on a bill that would offer relief to severely troubled pension plans -- including those at airlines -- and would radically change the way companies calculate their pensions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Record Label Selling Bonds
description: The EMI Group P.L.C., the record label of the Beatles and of Robbie Williams, said it planned to sell about 300 million euros ($339 million) of 10-year senior notes to refinance debt. The terms of the new senior notes will depend on market conditions, EMI said. The planned sale of notes is part of EMI's strategy to lengthen the maturity of its debt and diversify its sources, the company said. The company, based in London, sold $243 million of convertible bonds last week and said it might sell more debt soon, heightening speculation that EMI might be lining up financing for an acquisition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Improved Forecasting Helps Hurricane Experts See Five Days Into Storms' Futures
description: As Hurricane Isabel churns toward a probable collision with the Middle Atlantic coast on Thursday, it is providing the first significant test of a new government effort to produce five-day forecasts of hurricane movements.

title: Mind Over Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: A Visit From The South
description: For the first time since the partition in 1945, the North allowed a South Korean commercial flight to bring tourists to the North. The flight was part of a five-day tour offered by a private South Korean company. The 114 tourists will visit a sports stadium, royal tombs, a mountain, an automotive plant and other sites in Pyongyang, the capital. The five-day tour cost $1,900 a person. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A map grouping on Saturday showing cascading power failures that led to the Aug. 14 blackout mislabeled the state southwest of Ohio. It is Kentucky, not Tennessee.

title: Peyote's Hallucinations Spawn Real-Life Academic Feud
description: In the 1960's and 70's, Carlos Castaneda captivated millions of readers with his tales of self-discovery under the influence of peyote, jimson weed and other hallucinogens.

title: CALIFORNIA'S VOTE DELAYED BY COURT OVER PUNCH CARDS
description: A federal appeals court here today ordered that the recall election for Gov. Gray Davis be delayed, ruling that the scheduled date, Oct. 7, did not give several counties with large minority populations enough time to replace outdated punch-card voting machines.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Mayor Re-Elected
description: Anbal Ibarra, an ally of President Nstor Kirchner, won a second term as mayor of Buenos Aires, receiving 53.5 percent of the vote in a runoff against Mauricio Macri, one of the country's richest men. Mr. Kirchner's hand was also strengthened when Peronist candidates for governor and Congress whom he supported won handily in three provinces, including Buenos Aires, which has nearly 40 percent of the country's population. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Without Glue of Euro, Bond May Dissolve
description: One day after Swedish voters ruled out for years to come the likelihood of adopting the euro single currency, Europe's great project to bond its disparate players into a single force to rival the United States seemed doubtful.

title: Return of Texas Democrats Sparks Celebration
description: The boycotting Texas Democrats returned today to the State Senate for the first time since fleeing to New Mexico on July 28, but not before the chamber quickly adjourned, ushering in a raucous floor rally by the 10 lawmakers and their cheering supporters.

title: Exercise Is a Habit; Here's Why to Pick It Up
description: A strikingly large number of Americans have failed to catch the exercise bug, and the effects are showing up not only in their expanding girth but also in their health -- and death -- statistics.

title: Lottery Numbers
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: How To Help Garbage Disappear
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spotted an illegal dump in Bushwick last month, he called the Sanitation Department and got them to clean up it up -- all 147 tons of it. Yesterday, he returned to the dump to ask New Yorkers to follow his example by calling the city's new 311 phone number to report illegal dumping. The Sanitation Department has added 32 enforcement officers to crack down on illegal dumpers. Last year, the city cleaned up 6,000 vacant lots, most of them city-owned. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Remembering Hume Cronyn, Vivacious on Stage and Off
description: The stage at the Shubert Theater yesterday afternoon was filled with familiar images of Hume Cronyn, the big-eared actor with a gleam in his eye who died in June at the age of 91. There were, of course, pictures of him in some of his famous roles, playing cards with his wife of 52 years, Jessica Tandy, in the Broadway production of ''The Gin Game,'' and with Ms. Tandy again in ''Cocoon,'' the hit 1985 film that introduced Mr. Cronyn to a whole new generation of fans.

title: Mosley's Lawyers Ask Commission to Discipline De La Hoya
description: In a letter to the Nevada State Athletic Commission yesterday, lawyers for Shane Mosley took a few swings against former super welterweight champ Oscar De La Hoya and promoter Bob Arum, calling them "sore losers" and requesting that the commission chairman Luther Mack begin disciplinary proceedings against them for suggesting that Mosleys l unanimous decision on Saturday night was the result of judge tampering. "This has gone too beyond the pale, " said Judd Burstein, an attorney for Mosley. "Bob Arum should be suspended for his irresponsibility. " In an interview with the Las Vegas Review, , Arum accused Nevadas ringside physician Dr. Flip Homansky of orchestrating a behind-the-scenes "payback" against Arums promotional company, Top Rank, a claim Homansky denied as "utterly and completely ridiculous." In the letter, Burstein also chided De La Hoya for poor sportsmanship, saying he should "look into the mirror" for any explanations of his loss.While De La Hoya was down on all three judges cards by the score of 115-113, he was shocked at the loss and has pointed to CompuBox statistics, which shows De La Hoya landed virtually a hundred more punches then Mosley. . , Chairman Mack said the Nevada commission was looking into both the severity of Arums statements and allegations about Homansky. Were not pointing the fingers at anyone yet," he said in a telephone interview. "Its tough to judge a perfect fight. It was toe-to-toe all the way."

title: Crossing the Border Without Losing Your Past
description: Along with it being diez y seis de septiembre, Mexican Independence Day, today is my father's 89th birthday. Everardo Issasi Casares was born in 1914, a little more than a hundred years after Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla rang the church bells of Dolores, summoning his parishioners to rise up against the Spaniards.

title: Public Atlas Of the Brain In the Works
description: Backed by millions of dollars in financial support from Paul G. Allen, a founder of Microsoft, a team of scientists has set out to pinpoint the roughly 20,000 genes responsible for building and operating the human brain. From there, the scientists will put together a highly detailed atlas of the mammalian brain and make it available to the public through an online database.

title: After 22 Years in Robbery Case, Former Radical Nears Freedom
description: Kathy Boudin, the 1960's radical who has served 22 years for her role in a deadly armed robbery, could leave a New York state prison as soon as tomorrow, the State Division of Parole announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERK, LEON S.
description: BERK--Leon S. Of Hackensack, NJ, and Boynton Beach, FL, on September 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Frances (nee Epstein). Devoted father of Judith Dorr, Nancy Schneyer and Jane Berk. Doting grandfather of Jennifer, Amy, Brian, David and Rebecca. Services GuttermanMusicant, corner Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, on Wednesday at 12:30 PM. Contributions to Alzheimer's Assoc. would be appreciated.

title: Rules for Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Defends New Environmental Rules
description: President Bush toured one of the nation's largest power plants today and hailed the sprawling complex here as a symbol of how the relaxation of clean air rules would boost the economy and protect the environment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OMANOFF, BENJAMIN
description: OMANOFF--Benjamin. Born September 18th, 1920. Departed September 13th, 2003. Survived by his brother, Samuel Omanoff, nephews, Richard Omanoff, Norman Ochs, Marvin Ochs, and nieces, Judy Sullivan, Julia Omanoff and Ellen Omanoff. Benjamin appeared in several movies including ''Act of Love'' with Kirk Douglas. He owned and ran a successful car business in France and real estate business in NY. He served in the army in Burma/India/China and was an avid moviegoer and baseball fan. He will be deeply missed by all who loved him. Graveside services Wednesday, 11:15, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, Queens, NY. Information: call Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 718-377-2700.

title: Survival of the Fattest: How Pets Got So Big
description: Marley is a friendly orange tabby on a weight loss plan. About a year ago he was up to 22 pounds 2 ounces, his personal best, or largest, at any rate. Now, after nine months on a low-carbohydrate, high-protein diet that could have been invented by Dr. Atkins, he's down to 21 pounds 3 ounces.

title: Nassau Executive Offers Budget With No New Taxes
description: Nassau County has ''turned the critical corner'' in its fiscal crisis and is now rebounding, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said today as he proposed a new budget with no new taxes.

title: China Told Not to Relax Yuan Limits
description: Credit-rating agencies strongly warned today that China should not let its currency appreciate soon or relax controls on the movement of large sums of money in and out of the country, as the Bush administration has asked. The Chinese banking system was not ready, the rating agencies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, SYLVIA M.
description: GREENE--Sylvia M. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Devoted mother of John and mother-in-law of Gwen. Cherished grandmother of Angela and Priscilla. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASSOVER, LAWRENCE GERALD
description: KASSOVER--Lawrence Gerald. September 15, 2003, after a long illness. He is survived by wife Patricia, beloved children, Elliot and Rosalie, and grandchildren, Robert, Max, Hannah, Christina, Leslie, and Julia. Burial Wednesday in Palm Beach, FL.

title: Senior U.S. Official to Level Weapons Charges Against Syria
description: The Bush administration says that despite pledges, Syria has not stopped militants from crossing into Iraq to kill American soldiers.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS CHOSEN BY WARNACO
description: The Warnaco Group, maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Olga bras, said yesterday that it had named Lawrence Rutkowski as its chief financial officer. Mr. Rutkowski, 45, the former chief financial officer of Primedia Inc., will succeed Jim Fogarty, who resigned, Warnaco said. Mr. Fogarty had served as Warnaco's chief financial officer since December 2001.

description: AS dozens of United States Open crews employed a SpongeBob method of drying the courts this month -- dabbing with towels that had a thread count from the Holiday Inn collection -- the cheap means prompted an innocent question:

title: Corrections
description: The Q & A column in Science Times on Sept. 2 about the forming of clumps in table salt misstated the cause, the electrical state of salt and water and the behavior of salt in solution. Clumping occurs because atmospheric water molecules randomly bump into salt crystals and stick to the ions on their surface; the salt does not attract atmospheric water because of an electric charge. Both table salt (sodium chloride) and water are electrically neutral, not negatively or positively charged. In water, sodium chloride dissociates into sodium ions and chloride ions, which attach to the negative and positive ends of water molecules; it does not dissociate into elemental sodium and chloride.

title: Veiled and Worried in Baghdad

The word is ''himaya,'' or security. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Economic Growth

Gross domestic product expanded 0.9 percent in the second quarter after growing 1.3 percent in the previous three months, the government said. Economists had forecast second-quarter growth of 0.5 percent. Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, above, said Thailand might raise taxes if growth accelerated too quickly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Fight Over Campaign Cash
description: After being criticized for his fitful defense of New Jersey's campaign finance laws, Attorney General Peter C. Harvey said yesterday that he would join in the effort to appeal a recent court ruling that would end spending limits in primary elections. The ruling came in a case filed by Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria, a Democrat from Bayonne, who had accused his primary opponent of using money that had been channeled through a political action committee. During the case, an assistant attorney general filed a letter arguing that the state campaign finance law should regulate primaries, but supervisors in the attorney general's office ordered that it be withdrawn, according to lawyers involved in the case. Mr. Harvey's spokesman said last week that the attorney general had an obligation to remain neutral in the matter. But Mr. Harvey met yesterday with directors of the Election Law Enforcement Commission, a nonpartisan agency, and said that he had decided to join the appeal effort.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: For Stolen Metrocards, All May Not Be Lost
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority tentatively approved plans yesterday for a program to credit riders whose 30-day MetroCards, which cost $70 each, are lost or stolen. The program, scheduled to begin Oct. 1, was approved by a panel of the M.T.A. board and is expected to gain the approval of the full board. Under the program, which applies only to 30-day unlimited ride cards, riders who buy a MetroCard with a credit card or debit card from a MetroCard machine will be able to call 1-800-METROCARD (1-800-638-7622), to report the card lost. The agency will deactivate the MetroCard and credit the rider's debit or credit card for the balance remaining. The program will cost the agency about $1.8 million a year. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

description: DENNIS--Frank. On September 15, 2003, died peacefully after a courageous fight. Loving father of Maggi Siegel and Kelly Israel. Devoted father-in-law of Arthur Siegel and Michael Israel. Cherished ''Danpa'' of Alexa, Madison and Justin. Dear brother of Allen and former husband of Lynn Dennis. You will be forever in our hearts. Services Thursday, 1 P.M. at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Brazil Pushes for South American Trade Pact
description: Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, is pushing hard to form a continentwide trade pact by the end of the year that would give South American nations greater leverage as the United States pursues its own trade agreement for the hemisphere.

title: Amtrak Workers Plan Strike To Protest Lack of Financing
description: Six Amtrak unions are to announce on Wednesday that they will stop work on Oct. 3, shutting the railroad for the day, to protest Congress's failure to pass a $1.8 billion appropriation for the railroad for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: Sweet, Sour, Switchable
description: ONE of the most common and intriguing preparations in Vietnam is a quickly assembled stew that features tomato and pineapple at its base. Though the combination might seem reminiscent of the sweet-and-sour concoctions so common in the ersatz Polynesian restaurants of a couple of decades ago, its sole source of sweetness is the pineapple.

title: Call Hazing What It Is
description: To the Editor:

title: Typhoon Hits South Korea Economy
description: Called the ''typhoon of the century,'' the storm that roared through here last weekend left a trail of wreckage that threatens to slow South Korea's recovery from its first recession since the Asia financial crisis of 1997.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Rises
description: Investor confi-dence in Germany rose in September for the ninth consecutive month, according to the ZEW economic research institute, providing fresh evidence that the German economy may be on the mend. ZEW's index of expectations for economic growth rose to 60.9 from 52.5. The president of the Bundesbank, Ernst Welteke, above, said in a television interview that the rosy results pointed ''to a clear economic improvement in the second half and in 2004.'' Mark Landler (NYT)

title: The A.T.M. Governor and Tom DeLay
description: New York has always been lush territory for anyone raising campaign funds, but Gov. George Pataki has turned it into a Garden of Eden for his fellow Republicans. This year he has already raised $5 million for President Bush. And Arnold Schwarzenegger had lunch at the Four Seasons restaurant with New York's fund-raising heavyweights, courtesy of the governor and his fund-raising machine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKOLNIK, DAVID
description: SKOLNIK--David. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of David Skolnik, beloved father of our cherished friend, Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik. A dedicated spiritual leader in the Queens community, Rabbi Skolnik is a member of the Board of Directors and the Commission on Jewish Identity and Renewal at UJA-Federation. May the members of the Skolnik family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: 6 Held in Iraq By U.S. Claim To Be American
description: Six people identifying themselves as Americans, and two others saying they are British, are being held prisoner in connection with guerrilla attacks in Iraq, a United States general said today.

title: 2 English Tests Speak Very Different Tongues
description: THREE years ago, when Ammar Naeem immigrated to Queens from Pakistan and enrolled at Richmond Hill High School, he did not speak English. But he has learned much since then. He has maintained an 87 average, and was named to the school honor society. Through long hours of study, he has passed all the state Regents tests required for a high school diploma in New York, including science, global studies, math and English. His English Regents score was his best, 78. ''Now I know how to speak,'' said Ammar, who hopes to study engineering in college.

title: What Would Teachers Do If They Had the Chance? This
description: Salaries for teachers at the new primary school at Columbia University go as high as $100,000. The student-teacher ratio is five to one. And the school, which opens today, intends to develop individual learning plans for every student.

title: The Vote Must Go On
description: The federal appeals court order delaying the recall election in California cites the Supreme Court's decision in Bush v. Gore more than a dozen times. It is undeniable that California's recall election, which will use punch-card voting systems, has the potential to become another voting fiasco replete with hanging chads and changing standards. But this is not nearly enough to make it a legal rerun of Bush v. Gore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LESSER, STEPHEN
description: LESSER--Stephen. Of Westport, CT, aged 50, died peacefully at his home after a long battle with lung cancer. He was the beloved husband of Carol Burton, devoted father of Jackson and Rosalie, adored son of Bert and Mimi Lesser and dear brother of Robin Simon, brother-in-law of David Simon and uncle of Nicholas and Alizah. Steve was a well known architect in Westport, CT as well as an avid golfer, poker player, and witty friend. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 5 PM at the Westport Unitarian Church on Lyons Plains Road in Westport, CT.

title: A Singer Who Shakes A Valiant Fist at Pain
description: As Chavela Vargas sang ''Un Mundo Raro'' at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, she paused and wagged a cautionary finger at the audience when she reached the line, ''If you want to know about my past . . .''

title: Researchers on Stem Cells Are Making Do, and Hoping
description: Dolly the cloned sheep is dead, her carcass stuffed and mounted at the Royal Museum in Edinburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUCKMAN, SIMON
description: DUCKMAN--Simon, 92, on September 16, 2003. Husband of the late Helen. Father of Linda Keller, Robert Duckman, Matthew Duckman. Grandfather of four. Dedicated physician, avid tennis player and musician. Services Thursday, 10 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Parent Groups Will Get Money To Publicize New Councils
description: A day after a hearing on new parent councils failed to draw more than a few dozen people, the city's Department of Education announced yesterday that it would spend $350,000 to help parent associations publicize the councils.

title: In picking a new leader, J. Walter Thompson is pursuing a simple goal: staying relevant.
description: IT is difficult for an agency as old as J. Walter Thompson, which will turn 140 next year, to record some firsts at so venerable an age. But it will do just that with a rare changing of the guard.

title: New Federal Battle Over Disciplining Students
description: When Nancy Davenport, a retired teacher in Dallas, thinks about discipline and special education, she thinks of the times her mentally retarded son got involved in some ''pushing and shoving.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GILLETTE, NOETH B.
description: GILLETTE--Noeth B. September 17, 1925--June 17, 1993. Happy birthday to my father, the bravest, smartest, most charismatic man. You inspired our family with your joyful life, charmed us with your sense of humor, thrilled us with your sense of adventure and nourished us with your cooking. Thanks for your continuing love, guidance and understanding. Your daughters, Maria and Lisa, son-in-law, John, and granddaughter, Alisa

description: Time: 1 hour

title: Bolshoi Decides It's Over Before 'Fat' Lady Dances
description: One of Russia's best-known ballerinas and post-Communist celebrities was fired today by the Bolshoi Theater after a war of insults over whether she was fit for a pas de deux.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'Hussein' Tape Calls U.S. Withdrawal From Iraq Inevitable
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 17  As a man claiming to be Saddam Hussein urged in an audiotape more attacks on Americans in Iraq, the United States military today played down the possibility that eight prisoners held here on suspicion of taking part in such attacks might be American or British.

title: Garner Ted Armstrong, Evangelist, 73, Dies
description: Garner Ted Armstrong, a silver-haired television evangelist known for his easy charm and dark message, died on Monday in Tyler, Tex. He was 73.

title: Tenet Healthcare Names Chief
description: Tenet Healthcare, the troubled chain of for-profit hospitals, said yesterday that it had named Trevor Fetter as its chief executive.

title: An Older Bipolar Drug Is Linked to Fewer Suicides in a Study
description: Lithium, an old and inexpensive drug that has fallen out of favor with many psychiatrists, is better than the most commonly prescribed drug, Depakote, at preventing suicide in people who have manic-depressive illness, researchers are reporting.

title: Holocaust Insurance Effort Is Costing More Than It Wins
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the chairman of a widely criticized commission to help Holocaust survivors collect claims from European insurance companies, said today that his organization had spent 60 percent more for operations than it had persuaded insurers to pay in claims.

title: U.S. Cutting Loan Guarantees To Oppose Israeli Settlements
description: The Bush administration announced today that it would reduce loan guarantees to Israel to meet Congressional restrictions on providing financial support to Israel's continued expansion of settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. The administration said it might further restrict the guarantees to protest Israel's construction of a barrier dividing what it considers its land from Palestinian territory.

title: Explaining Himself, Kicking Themselves
description: After an agonizing off-season, a determined training camp, a triumphant first game, a gutsy comeback to what felt like a sure victory with 11 seconds left in Monday night's game against the Cowboys, the Giants could not believe their eyes.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: LIVING LONG, 2 DAYS AT A TIME Kamato Hongo, who has proof of age that qualifies her for the listing in the Guinness Book of World Records as the oldest living person, turned 116. Born in 1887, Mrs. Hongo is known for her habit of sleeping for two days and then staying awake for two days. This year, her birthday fell on a day that she was awake, and she welcomed well-wishers at her home in Kagoshima, on the southern island of Kyushu. According to an Internet site devoted to Mrs. Hongo, her favorite snack as unrefined brown sugar and reveals her secret to long life: "Not moping around." She is said to enjoy a glass of sake when she is awake. (AP)

title: New Jersey and Long Island Watch, Wait and Plan
description: With ample warning of Hurricane Isabel's eventual landfall, emergency response planners around the New York region spent a radiant late summer day weighing the what ifs of the season's first big storm while coastal residents playing out their familiar roles in the drama of an approaching storm divided themselves into the worriers and those who wait and see.

title: W.N.B.A. Exceeded Its High Expectations
description: The 2003 season of the Women's National Basketball Association was expected to be the most competitive of the league's seven seasons.

title: Women Called Mideast's Untapped Resource
description: The World Bank said today that women remain a ''huge, untapped'' economic resource in the Middle East and North Africa, where more women workers are needed to transform economies that must depend increasingly on private-sector exports to compete worldwide.

description: WOLOSOFF -- Morty. Gone two years. Forever loved and always in my heart. Rest in peace. All my love, Gloria

description: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that first-quarter profit climbed 29 percent as new products including Nouriche yogurt drinks bolstered sales and costs related to its purchase of Pillsbury fell.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Council Bans Erotic Dances
description: The Los Angeles City Council passed a measure that bans erotic lap dancing by requiring dancers to stay at least six feet from customers. The ordinance, passed unanimously over opposition from dancers and club owners, applies to any bodily contact between dancers and customers in strip clubs, bikini bars and adult bookstores. People living near adult clubs had complained about prostitution, drug use, noise and streets littered with condoms. Braden Phillips (NYT)

title: Planned Assault on Republican Bastion Lands McGreevey in Power Struggle
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey's plan to shake up the leadership of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, a rich source of political patronage, has set off a heated battle between the governor and one of Trenton's most powerful Republicans.

title: Big Board Under Siege
description: Richard Grasso, the head of the New York Stock Exchange, may soon have a lot of time to enjoy that $140 million in deferred compensation he recently cashed out. The widespread furor -- most notably among prominent investors and at the Securities and Exchange Commission -- over his excessive pay and the way it was disclosed will probably force his ouster. Mr. Grasso would do a great service by stepping down promptly.

description: Following is the text of a statement released by the New York Stock Exchange after the resignation of Richard A. Grasso, its chairman and chief executive:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Monday about a shake-up at Consumer Reports referred incompletely to the founding of the magazine's parent, Consumers Union. Strikers from Consumers' Research started Consumers Union in 1936. It was not founded as Consumers' Research in 1926.

title: 'Taste My Prosciutto,' He Said With a Drawl
description: RUFUS BROWN looks up and observes his hams. They are hanging by the hundreds in neat rows high above him. After climbing stairs and crossing a creaky catwalk, he finds the one he is looking for, up near the roof, where he put it last year. With a poke and sniff of the hard, musty ham, he decides it is ready: by tomorrow, it will be sliced thin and tucked into panini by customers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Suit Given Class-Action Status
description: A Texas judge granted class-action status yesterday to a lawsuit filed by a computer user who asserted that I.B.M. made and sold faulty disk drives. Judge Terry Flenniken of state district court last week had denied I.B.M.'s request to dismiss the case, filed in December 2001 in Caldwell, Tex. The decision allows the case to go forward on behalf of customers in 18 states who bought I.B.M. Deskstar 75 GXP hard drives from March 15, 2000, to Jan. 17, 2003. ''We're pleased to be able to continue prosecuting the case on behalf of the class,'' said Paul Paradis, a lawyer who represents computer users. The Texas lawsuit, filed by a Caldwell resident, Andrew Daugherity, asserts the drives are prone to failure, causing the loss of all data stored on them. I.B.M. sold ''tens of thousands'' of the drives, the suit claims. Problems with the drives drew widespread complaints on Internet message boards, where customers refer to the drives as ''Deathstar.'' I.B.M. has denied Mr. Daugherity's assertions and said defect rates for the Deskstar were in line with other products. ''The judge has reached no conclusions regarding the merits of the case,'' said Joseph Stunkard, an I.B.M. spokesman. ''We respectfully disagree with the judge's ruling. We plan to immediately appeal the judge's decision.''

title: Off the Menu
description: In the spring of 2001, GALEN ZAMARRA, left, who was the chef de cuisine at Bouley Bakery but relatively unknown, was named rising star chef of the year by the James Beard Foundation. By the fall, Bouley Bakery had closed because of the Sept. 11 attack, and Mr. Zamarra, 27, seemed to have vanished from the scene. Now he is back, having spent a fruitless year trying to open a restaurant, and then cooking dinners in Greenport, N.Y., at Trummer Home. In November he plans to open MAS at 39 Downing Street (Bedford Street). The food will be seasonal French-American. His partners are TOM WILSON, who was the bar manager at Nice Matin, and HUGH CRICKMORE, the former sommelier at Marseille.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEMPER, SOPHIE
description: KEMPER--Sophie. in Miami, FL at age 103. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother and great great grandmother. She will live in our hearts forever.

title: The Group Dynamics of the Women's World Cup
description: On Saturday, the 16 best women's soccer teams in the world will begin play in the fourth Women's World Cup. Below are the 16 teams, which are divided into four round-robin groups designated A through D. The top two teams from each group advance to the quarterfinals. By JERE LONGMAN

title: That Club on eBay. The Farmer Knew It Well.
description: The Case of the Missing Knife-Blade War Club was cold, see. Colder than the dark end of the Kansas museum storeroom where someone snatched it nine long years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLUMMER, NANCY DONO VAN
description: PLUMMER -- Nancy Dono van, known to her friends as Winkie. Loving wife of James Plummer and sister of Sally Madden. Died on September 16, 2003, after a brief illness. She will be missed by her many friends.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GILLETTE CO., Boston, said it would buy back up to 50 million shares of its common stock over two to three years.

title: Grandmother's Coconut Cake Is a Layer Above
description: There may be as many recipes for lush coconut cakes as there are bakers in the South. But how many are as grand as the coconut cake that Robert Carter, above, the executive chef at the Peninsula Grill in the Planters Inn in Charleston, S.C., has adapted from his grandmother's recipe? Coconut-infused butter cream is slathered between six layers of golden poundcake made with coconut milk in the batter. The outside of the cake is covered with toasted coconut and the whole thing tips the scale at 12 pounds and serves at least 25. It will hold up for a week in the refrigerator and can be frozen. In Charleston, some brides are ordering it as wedding cake. And now it is available for $55 from (843) 723-0700, www.peninsulagrill.com or www .coconutcakes.com. Overnight shipping charges are $30 to $60, depending on the destination.

title: Hurricane Isabel Shifts Down Gear but Remains a Threat
description: Hurricane Isabel shifted down a gear today, losing some of its wind speed and drifting onto a new track that would skirt Virginia's densely populated Chesapeake Bay region. But it remained a threat to wallop the Outer Banks of North Carolina and cause flooding from central Virginia to Pennsylvania.

title: ABC Will Continue Series That Starred John Ritter
description: ABC announced yesterday that it would continue its hit comedy ''8 Simple Rules for Dating My Teenage Daughter'' with episodes that deal directly with the death of the character played by John Ritter, the show's star who died unexpectedly last week.

title: Queens Man Sentenced to Prison; Claimed Fake Son Died on 9/11
description: A Queens man was sentenced yesterday to 11 to 33 years in prison for creating a ''nonexistent son'' so he could make money by claiming that the son had died in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: How the World Sees Us
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Schools Get $51.2 Million From Gates
description: In the largest single private donation ever to benefit the New York City public schools, Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft , announced $51.2 million in grants today to create small public high schools.

title: Edwards Formally Enters Race For President
description: Standing by a shuttered textile mill where his father had worked, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina presented himself today as a champion of the working class who as president would bring more jobs to America and end what he considers special breaks for the wealthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IACONO, DOMINICK A.
description: IACONO--Dominick A., 94, of Ft. Lee, NJ, on September 15, 2003. A former commodities trader, AC Israel Commodities Co., NYC, retired in 1975. Husband of Laura (nee Curry). Uncle of many. Funeral Mass Friday 10AM, St. Cecilia Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visitation Thursday 3-7PM, Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, Fort Lee.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Lifting Of Poultry Quarantine
description: The federal government lifted quarantines on six counties in Southern California, signaling victory in the fight against a deadly poultry virus, exotic Newcastle disease. The action comes 11 months after the disease was confirmed in California, the Department of Agriculture said in a statement. The government ended quarantines last month on three other California counties and areas of Arizona, Nevada and Texas, a department spokeswoman said.

title: Shockey Beats Himself Up After the Beating by the Cowboys
description: It was nearly 2 this morning when tight end Jeremy Shockey came back to his locker. Most of the Giants had already departed into the gloomy aftermath of an overtime loss to the Dallas Cowboys. Shockey wore his baseball cap backward, but all other signs of his youthful defiance were gone.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: $72 Million Deal For Datamark
description: ECollege.com, whose software and services are used by colleges and universities to provide online learning, agreed to buy Datamark Inc. for about $72 million in cash, debt and stock. ECollege will use about $58 million in cash, $12 million in debt and 150,000 shares to buy the stock of Datamark from Leeds Weld & Company, a private equity firm, eCollege said in a statement. Datamark, based in Salt Lake City, provides recruitment, enrollment and retention services to post-secondary schools. Datamark's headquarters will remain in Salt Lake City and no jobs will be cut, eCollege said. Shares of eCollege rose $4.67, or 32 percent, to $19.35.

title: From a Court, a Most Unusual Request
description: It was a highly unusual step that the federal appeals court in San Francisco took yesterday when, assuming the initiative, it asked opposing sides in the California recall fight whether a larger panel of the court should review the delay ordered on Monday by three judges.

title: In Chicago, Changing of the Guard at Sears Tower
description: When Trizec Properties acquired a second mortgage on the 110-story Sears Tower in 1997, it looked as if the company had made a shrewd investment.

title: Yashin Tweaks His Gear
description: Center Aleksei Yashin would rather work on his equipment than cause a ruckus, and he has spent a lot of time at training camp making sure that his blue and white helmets fit right.

title: At Long Last, Real Barbecue Makes a Stand In Manhattan
description: THE smoky romance of the barbecue pit, with its dry rubs and wet mops, its fruit woods and burnt ends, has long been a New York fantasy. But real barbecue has proved harder to produce locally than baguettes, baba ghanouj and banh mi put together.

description: The trappings of autumn have begun to descend upon New England.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the role of cultural institutions in plans for the World Trade Center site and in urban development elsewhere misstated the title of Tessa Jowell, who commented on the investment in culture in Manchester, England, and other cities. She is Britain's secretary of state for culture, media and sport, not Manchester's cultural secretary. A caption with the article misstated the site of the Imperial War Museum North in Britain. As reflected in the article, it is in Manchester, not Liverpool.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed In Hit-and-Run
description: A woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver yesterday as she crossed a street in Brighton Beach, the police said. They are looking for the driver of a white box truck that hit her about 4 p.m. The woman, who was in her 60's, was hit as the truck turned onto Brighton Beach Avenue from Brighton Fourth Street. The woman, whom the police did not identify, was taken to Coney Island Hospital, where she died at 5:20 p.m., the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: He's Back Again, But Not So Regal
description: When Omar Sharif stepped out on the stage the 1,500-seat Elgin Theater last week to introduce the Toronto International Film Festival screening of a new French film, ''Monsieur Ibrahim,'' in which he plays the owner of a tiny neighborhood convenience store, he was greeted by a standing ovation. Perhaps it was the light, but those famously dark, soulful eyes seemed to glisten for a moment with tears.

title: Borders Signs Up Crispin, Porter
description: Borders Inc. in Ann Arbor, Mich., the book retailer, said yesterday that it had named the Venice, Calif., office of Crispin, Porter & Bogusky as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

description: Nearly a year ago, Khalid Mishaal, a senior leader of Hamas, the militant Palestinian organization, attended a charitable fund-raising conference here where he talked at length with Crown Prince Abdullah, the de facto Saudi ruler.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday incorrectly identified the host of the National Book Awards ceremony. It will be the author Walter Mosley, not the actor Steve Martin, the host for previous ceremonies.

title: U.S. Has 'No Evidence' Linking Hussein to 9/11, Bush Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  President Bush said today that he had seen "no evidence" that Saddam Hussein was involved in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as the White House tried to correct an assertion that Vice President Dick Cheney left extremely murky on Sunday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Tourism Flat In 2002
description: The number of visitors to New York City essentially did not change last year, but business travel and international tourism dropped substantially, according to tourism figures released yesterday. Last year, 35.3 million tourists visited the city, up 0.3 percent from 2001, generating a total economic impact of nearly $21 billion. Officials said the total included record numbers of families and leisure travelers from other parts of the country, many of whom came out of a sense of patriotism after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. But business travel dropped 7 percent, to 9.4 million visitors, and international tourism fell 10 percent, to 5.1 million, though city officials pointed out that those areas were showing signs of recovery. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMUELS, HARTLEY L.
description: SAMUELS--Hartley L. On September 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Margery. Services Thursday, 2 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Canadian Legislators Narrowly Reject Move Against Gay Unions
description: The Canadian government won an important but narrow victory today in its efforts to extend marriage rights to same-sex couples.

title: A Tax-Cut Victim
description: If there was one thing Americans had a right to expect from Congress, it was a federal plan to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs. It is a promise that has been made again and again -- in particularly high decibels during the last presidential election. The House and Senate have passed bills, and although both are flawed, this page has urged Congress to finish work on them as a first step toward fulfilling this longstanding commitment.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Announces New Technologies
description: Intel, the world's largest chip maker, introduced a number of new technologies yesterday and reinforced its view that wireless and computing industries are converging to produce a new class of electronic devices. Speaking at the company's developer conference in San Jose, Calif., Paul S. Otellini, the president of Intel, demonstrated a prototype of a hand-held device called the Universal Communicator that is based on an Intel processor and can automatically switch between Wi-Fi and cellular networks. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., also disclosed plans to produce powerful chips that can function as multiple processors. Mr. Otellini demonstrated one such chip, code-named Vanderpool, which will eventually allow users to partition their PC processor to run two operations at once, like a television program and a 3-D computer game. The company plans its first dual-core processor in 2005. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Sweden's Brooding Dramas, and Deadly Puzzles
description: On the day that Anna Lindh, the Swedish foreign minister, died of stab wounds last week, another less publicized killing added to the nation's dismay. In western Sweden a 5-year-old child identified only as Sabina was abducted and stabbed to death by an inmate from a psychiatric institute, able to come and go at will in part because the cost of looking after such patients in this land's cradle-to-grave welfare system is becoming too high.

title: Art Imitated Crime, but the Jail Term Is Real
description: While directors of films like ''Hackers'' and ''Before and After'' have chosen the marbled halls of the Bergen County Justice Center as a backdrop for their movies, Daniel Provenzano, a film director, probably would have preferred to leave today's scene there on the cutting room floor.

description: The long-running negotiation between AOL Time Warner and Bertelsmann about a merger of their music businesses appeared to be in doubt yesterday after the two companies let lapse an agreement to negotiate exclusively, executives close to the talks said.

description: When the Brooklyn Democratic Party met yesterday to pick its candidates for the state Supreme Court, the scene resembled nothing so much as a squeaky-clean and very serious student council election.

description: One of the strongest Democratic supporters of the invasion of Iraq joined the growing offensive against the administration's postwar planning today, demanding that President Bush fire his defense leadership team.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: 'Dirty War' Figure Arrested
description: Alfredo Astiz, a notorious former navy captain known as the ''blond angel of death'' for his role in the disappearance of opponents of the military dictatorship that ruled Argentina from 1976 to 1983, was arrested in response to a French government warrant. Mr. Astiz, convicted in absentia in France in 1990 of killing two French nuns, is one of 40 former military officers who were recently detained at the request of a Spanish judge but were later released after Spain declined to formally request their extradition. Larry Rohter (NYT)

description: SONKIN--Milton. The Levin Family Tree records with sorrow the passing of our beloved cousin and president.
