description: TITUS--Alice Stevens. Suddenly on September 11th, 2003. Loving wife of the late James Gulden Titus. Dearest mother of Stephanie and Sandra and the late Jimmy. Beloved Gram of Willy, Ali, Jimbo, Caroline, Megan, Ty, Andy and Shire and GreatGram of Brooks. A private service for immediate family is scheduled for the end of the month. Contributions may be sent to The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 92nd Street, 10128.

title: Palestinians Hint at a Cease-Fire, but Israel Rejects It
description: Yasir Arafat's security adviser called today for a Middle East cease-fire, but Israel immediately dismissed the plan as inadequate without Palestinian action to break up violent factions.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Suit To Remove Ten Commandments
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has sued in Federal District Court to have Barrow County remove a framed copy of the Ten Commandments in the County Courthouse in Winder, said Maggie Garrett, a lawyer with the A.C.L.U. The County Commission voted unanimously in June to keep the donated display. The suit was filed on behalf of ''John Doe,'' a man who is afraid of reprisals if he is identified, Ms. Garrett said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Jets' Running Game Has Mysteriously Evaporated
description: The bedsheet hung limply from a parking lot fence at Giants Stadium on Sunday night, long after the Jets' latest debacle. ''Let Vinny Throw'' it read, a remnant of what felt like a protest march crossed with a tailgate party.

title: A Czarist Disaster As Musical Challenge
description: The last of the Romanov rulers are ripe material for opera. What more could a stage composer want? There are Nicholas, the reluctant czar; Alexandra, his devoted and strong-willed wife; and Alexei, the hemophiliac son, his young life bleeding away. Behind them is the drama of the Russian Revolution, which will bring this family to its violent death, and above this richness hovers Rasputin, the kind of mystical devouring villain over which a Mussorgsky or a Verdi would have salivated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Cuts Operations
description: The German utility RWE abandoned plans to buy power plants in the United States and will shut trading operations in the country as it struggles to cut debt piled up with acquisitions. RWE will focus on its European business, said a spokesman, Ralf Schfer. RWE has 134 employees in Houston.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SLAIN COUNCILMAN'S MOTHER SUES CITY The mother of the slain City Councilman James E. Davis is suing the city and the Police Department for failing to protect her son from a political rival who fatally shot him in City Hall in July. Mr. Davis's mother, Thelma Davis, is seeking $100 million for wrongful death, pecuniary losses, pain and suffering and fear of impending death, according to court papers. Ms. Davis and her lawyers say that the city and the police "failed to properly secure the building and grounds upon which James Davis was killed." Ms. Davis has also asked the court to preserve and allow her to review the city and Police Department's records from July 23, the day of the shootings. A spokeswoman for the city's corporation counsel called the situation a "tragic case" and said that the suit would be thoroughly evaluated. The rival, Othniel Boaz Askew, 31, was fatally wounded by shots fired by a plainclothes officer. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Reporter Admits BBC Report on Iraqi Arms Had Errors
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  The BBC correspondent at the heart of a battle between the state broadcaster and the government conceded today that there had been errors in his report that touched off the firestorm, and he apologized for having tried to influence parliamentary questioning of his source.

title: Relentless Foe of the Amazon Jungle: Soybeans
description: It takes only a trip on the busy but rutted highway that leads north from here to understand how an area of the Amazon jungle larger than New Jersey could have been razed over the course of just a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLICKMAN, JOY DORIS
description: GLICKMAN--Joy Doris. On September 16, 2003. She will be remembered with love and affection by her family and friends. Service Thursday, 11:30 A.M. at ''the Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In Florida, Soaking Up Medicare?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Dog Attack Leads to Inquiry on Shelter
description: In August, Valerie DeSwart, a 67-year-old animal lover from Medford, N.J., did something that hundreds of thousands of people do every year: she adopted a dog.

title: Chief of Norway Oil Company Holds Job but Faces Inquiry
description: Olav Fjell, the chief executive of Norway's government-controlled oil company, Statoil, survived harsh questioning today by his company's directors, but he still faces a criminal investigation into a $15.5 million consulting contract intended to improve Statoil's access to oil fields in Iran.

title: U.S. Uses Its Veto to Block Anti-Israel Measure in U.N.
description: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution, backed by Islamic and nonaligned nations, demanding that Israel back off its threat to deport the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. Eleven Council members voted in favor of the measure, while Britain, Germany and Bulgaria abstained.

title: Officers May Be Disciplined For Conduct in S.I. Attack
description: Two police officers who came under scrutiny last week for their handling of an attack on a black college student and her friends on Staten Island are likely to face disciplinary charges for their conduct in the case, two people who have been briefed on the investigation said yesterday.

title: Party Leader In Suffolk Steps Down, Citing Illness
description: A week after his insurance company came under investigation, Suffolk County's Republican Party chairman told fellow leaders yesterday that he was leaving his post because of a severe kidney ailment.

title: After 1920 Blast, The Opposite Of 'Never Forget'; No Memorials on Wall St. For Attack That Killed 30
description: On the block where it happened, there were no ''we will never forget'' speeches, no candles or bronze plaques bolted to the wall that has never been repaired. All that was there yesterday was the noontime crowd, swirling by with lunch to be gulped, errands to be run and an afternoon of work waiting to be done. In other words, no one was paying much attention.

title: Iraq to Take a Seat At OPEC Meeting
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries announced yesterday that a delegation from Iraq would take part in the cartel's meeting in Vienna next week. The decision overcomes months of resistance among OPEC members to the idea that an occupied Iraq should have a seat at the table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LICHTENBERG, ALAN
description: LICHTENBERG--Alan. A customer, a friend, and an admired man. We will miss you. The Glass & Caplan Families

title: Getting Personal 3 Ways at Toronto Festival
description: Something that makes film festivals distinct from, say, a special schedule at the local multiplex is the attention paid to movies that are either explicitly personal or that implicitly exhibit a great deal of a filmmaker's personality.

title: The Reality, With the Reality Show Gone
description: ROCCO'S on 22nd is New York's first meta-restaurant.

title: Self-Evident Truths, Now More Evident; National Archives Reopens With New Display of Historic Documents
description: Despite its imposing architecture and stunning collection, the National Archives has never quite made the A-list of tourist attractions here. Even the city's official convention Web site does not list it on a suggested tour.

title: Hurricane Isabel Could Drench World Cup
description: Already relocated from China because of the SARS epidemic, the Women's World Cup is now bracing for the potential disruption of Hurricane Isabel.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Supermarket Profit Rises
description: Britain's largest supermarket chain, Tesco, said yesterday that profit grew 21.3 percent, to 661 million ($1.06 billion) in the first half of its year, helped by sales of nonfood items and international expansion. Overall sales in the period, which ended August 9, were up 17 percent from a year ago, to 14.9 billion, Tesco said. Outside of Britain, sales grew 30 percent to 3 billion. The company has been expanding in Eastern Europe and Japan and adding items like clothing and washing machines. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Senate Approves Plan to Clean Polluted Sites, Ending 10-Year Impasse
description: The Republican-controlled Senate approved landmark environmental legislation today that proponents say will result in the rehabilitation of thousands of scarred industrial wastelands across New York, many in urban areas.

title: Fed Leaves Short-Term Rates Unchanged
description: The Federal Reserve retained its cautious outlook for the economy today, leaving short-term interest rates unchanged at 1 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, BARRY
description: EPSTEIN--Barry. September 16, 2003, after a heroic battle with brain cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife, Diane, adored daughter, Kira, mother, Sylvia and brothers, Stephen & Marc. The funeral will take place on Thursday at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon.

title: Lottery Numbers
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Standard Microsystems Raises Forecast
description: The Standard Microsystems Corporation, which designs semiconductors for personal computers, raised its forecast for 2004 profit yesterday as sales of personal computers, networking and mobile products improve. Last year, the company had a net loss. The shares rose as much as 12 percent. The company expects profit, excluding some costs, of 30 cents to 35 cents a share in the year ending in February and estimates sales will rise 20 percent to 25 percent. Standard Micro, based in Hauppauge, N.Y., had forecast income, excluding some costs, of 24 cents to 28 cents and a 15 percent sales gain. Standard Micro supplies devices that direct information to peripherals like the keyboard, mouse and printer. The company hires contractors to make its chips. The industry researcher IDC predicted that global PC shipments would rise 8.4 percent this year and said demand for chips used in PC's, mobile phones and DVD players is starting to recover after two years. Shares of Standard Micro rose $1.06, or 4.8 percent, to $23.10.

title: Kenyan Champion Ndereba To Compete in New York
description: Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, the former world record-holder and the newly crowned women's world marathon champion, will compete in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 2, the New York Road Runners, sponsor of the race, announced yesterday. Ndereba has not competed in the event since 1999, when she finished second in 2 hours 27 minutes 34 seconds. On Aug. 31, Ndereba, 31, won the women's marathon at the world championships in Paris in 2:23:55. Her world record, 2:18:47, set at the 2001 Chicago Marathon, has since been lowered to 2:15:25 by Paula Radcliffe of Britain. Lena Williams

title: L.I. May Lose A Hospital For the Poor
description: Nassau County's public hospital, nursing home and health centers are losing millions of dollars and could go broke by next year, saddling county government with a debt that would endanger its own financial recovery, the state and county comptrollers said today.

title: Graduation Study Suggests That Some States Sharply Understate High School Dropout Rates
description: With a number of states reporting dropout rates in low single digits, a national study estimates that in fact, 3 in 10 high school freshmen, and half of all black and Latino students, never make it to graduation.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And Yet, They Take Weeks To Return a Call

title: Officials in 2 States Urge Big Board Chief to Quit
description: State officials in New York and California called for the resignation of Richard A. Grasso yesterday, saying his enormous pay package was unconscionable for the chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Senate Says No
description: How are a majority of Americans, standing with a bipartisan majority of both houses of Congress, going to stop the Federal Communications Commission from making the biggest mistake in its existence?

title: Voters in Seattle, Where Coffee is King, Reject a Tax on Espresso
description: A measure to levy a 10-cent-per-cup tax on espresso in what is known as the coffee capital of the nation was overwhelmingly rejected tonight by Seattle voters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN--Gladys. In our hearts forever. Our love, Leslie, Alan, Jonathan, Justin, Keri, Arnold, Giulia & Rebecca.

title: Fed's Decision to Maintain Rate Moves Shares Higher
description: Stocks rose yesterday as the Federal Reserve decided to keep benchmark interest rates at 45-year lows, which bolstered investors' confidence that economic and profit growth would accelerate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Rules Against Interrogation Rule
description: A ruling last year that effectively ended ''the 48-hour rule'' that bars police officers suspected of misconduct from being questioned immediately after an incident was upheld by a state judge yesterday. The police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said it would appeal the ruling, by Justice Edward A. Sheridan of State Supreme Court. The earlier decision, by a state hearing officer with the Public Employment Relations Board, found that the 48-hour rule could no longer be negotiated into the police union's contract with the city. Police critics say the rule adds to a public perception that accused officers get special treatment. But police officials and prosecutors say the rule seldom affects cases of misconduct that rise to the level of a crime because statements officers make in such interviews cannot be used against them in court anyway. Such statements are compelled under penalty of dismissal.

title: Microsoft's Setback in Patent Case Ripples Through World Wide Web
description: Watching Microsoft be sued -- by the federal government, states, class-action plaintiffs and aggrieved rivals -- has become a common pastime in the computer industry. The enjoyment of the industry spectators is usually all the greater if the world's largest software company loses, and loses big, in court.

title: Ex-Broker Charged in Criminal Fraud Case
description: A former broker at Bank of America was charged with larceny and securities fraud yesterday, accused of helping a hedge fund engage in after-hours trading of mutual fund shares.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Aug. 21 about search tips for the Web misstated the address of one site, NewsNow, which offers a live feed of news articles. It is www.newsnow.co.uk.

title: A Biennale That Puts Indonesia On the Map
description: Djie Tjianan, a prominent collector of contemporary Indonesian art, and Jim Supangkat, a curator, wondered: If Indonesian art was so alluring to collectors in Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo, why not show the best at home?

title: FURR'S RESTAURANT WINS COURT APPROVAL FOR SALE
description: The Furr's Restaurant Group, which operates 55 cafeterias in six states, said yesterday that it had received bankruptcy court approval for its sale to Buffet Partners as part of its reorganization. Buffet will pay $25.8 million and assume about $3.2 million in liabilities, Furr's said. The United States Bankruptcy Court in Dallas approved the sale, which Furr's expects to close by the end of this month. Furr's, based in Richardson, Tex., filed for protection in January, after losing more than $31.2 million in the first three quarters of 2002. The company also operates Dynamic Foods, its food preparation, processing and distribution unit, in Lubbock, Tex.

title: Citigroup Chief Speeds Up Succession Plan
description: Citigroup's succession plan is moving faster than scheduled.

description: A WALKING GUIDE

description: To the Editor:

description: Sometimes in the National Football League, dynamite comes in a matchbox and the eye of a needle seems as wide as a hula hoop.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: TRADING BEGINS TO REBOUND, SCHWAB REPORTS
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount broker, said yesterday that trading by its customers started to rebound in September after declining in August for a second month. The chief financial officer, Christopher Dodds, said Schwab expected to meet Wall Street forecasts for earnings of 9 cents a share in the third quarter. Schwab clients made an average of 126,800 commission-generating trades a day in August, down 15 percent from 148,600 in July and up 8 percent from August 2002. In the first nine trading days of September, average client trades rose to 164,000 a day, Schwab reported. Mr. Dodds said Schwab might exceed its third-quarter earnings goals.

title: Other Voices, Other Lives From Solo Conjurers
description: Heather Woodbury and Michael Isaac Connor may be solo performers, but they take up a lot of psychic space. Their shows are overflowing with characters. In Ms. Woodbury's eight-hour American panorama, ''What Ever,'' there are something like 90. Mr. Connor's autobiographical show, ''Berkshire Village Idiot,'' is considerably more modest in scope: 90 minutes, with a microscopic focus on one small family in a tiny New England village. Still, he squeezes in three dozen people.

title: Grandmother's Coconut Cake Is a Layer Above
description: There may be as many recipes for lush coconut cakes as there are bakers in the South. But how many are as grand as the coconut cake that Robert Carter, right, the executive chef at the Peninsula Grill in the Planters Inn in Charleston, S.C., has adapted from his grandmother's recipe? Coconut-infused butter cream is slathered between six layers of golden poundcake made with coconut milk in the batter. The outside of the cake is covered with toasted coconut and the whole thing tips the scale at 12 pounds and serves at least 25. It will hold up for a week in the refrigerator and can be frozen. In Charleston, some brides are ordering it as wedding cake. And now it is available for $55 from (843) 723-0700, www.peninsulagrill.com or www.coconutcakes.com. Overnight shipping charges are $30 to $60, depending on the destination.

title: Three European Leaders Will Meet to Discuss Postwar Strategy
description: The leaders of France, Germany and Britain announced today that they will hold a summit meeting here on Saturday that seems intended to work out a common position on the American request for help in the postwar reconstruction of Iraq.

title: Fund Set Up to Aid Columbia Families
description: A group of corporate executives and public officials today announced the creation of a trust fund to benefit the families of the seven astronauts who died aboard the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Slain Councilman's Mother Sues City
description: The mother of the slain City Councilman James E. Davis is suing the city and the Police Department for failing to protect her son from a political rival who fatally shot him in City Hall in July. Mr. Davis's mother, Thelma Davis, is seeking $100 million for wrongful death, pecuniary losses, pain and suffering and fear of impending death, according to court papers. Ms. Davis and her lawyers say that the city and the police ''failed to properly secure the building and grounds upon which James Davis was killed.'' Ms. Davis has also asked the court to preserve and allow her to review the city and Police Department's records from July 23, the day of the shootings. A spokeswoman for the city's corporation counsel called the situation a ''tragic case'' and said that the suit would be thoroughly evaluated. The rival, Othniel Boaz Askew, 31, was fatally wounded by shots fired by a plainclothes officer. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: A Strong, Hearty Drink Deserves a Strong, Hearty Meal
description: PRUNE, a restaurant in the East Village, serves a dish of buttered brown bread with salted onions and goat's-milk cheese. Diners assemble the dish to their taste. Some like lots of onion. Some go straight for the cheese. No matter which way you choose, it's a hearty dish. Add a bottle of stout and you have a fine meal.

title: A Jewish Recount
description: According to reports in major news outlets, a study published last week included a startling discovery: the nation's Jewish population is shrinking. The study, the National Jewish Population Survey, found 5.2 million Jews living in the United States in 2000, a drop of 5 percent, or 300,000 people, since a similar study in 1990. What's truly startling is that the reported decline is not true. Worse still, the sponsor of the $6 million study, United Jewish Communities, knows it.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Stock Plan Extended
description: The Bank of Japan's policy board said yesteday that it would continue buying stocks from the nation's banks for an additional year, through September 2004. The program, which can spend up to 3 trillion yen ($25 billion), was started a year ago under the leadership of the former governor, Masaru Hayami, and intended to help banks sell shares they have trouble selling on the open market. So far, the central bank has bought 1.782 trillion yen in stocks. Japan's banks are under pressure from regulators to reduce the amount of the stocks they hold. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: PANEL TO WEIGH BOSTON SCIENTIFIC PRODUCT IN NOVEMBER
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, a leading maker of heart stents, said yesterday that a Food and Drug Administration committee would meet on Nov. 20 to consider the company's application to sell its Taxus device in the United States. Taxus is a drug-coated stent, a metal tube that holds arteries open after they are cleared in angioplasties. It had a 7.9 percent rate of reclogging in a study, compared with 26.6 percent for the same type of stent without the coating, researchers said on Monday. Boston Scientific expects Taxus to be approved by January or February. Taxus, which is coated with paclitaxel, has been approved in some European markets.

title: Program in Connecticut Puts Focus on Immigrants Evading Deportation
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 16  In a pilot program ordered by the federal Department of Homeland Security, illegal immigrants in Connecticut are being arrested immediately after their final deportation notice rather than remaining free while on appeal.

title: Review/Fashion; Bypassing Lithe Youth To Serve Middle Age
description: Fashion designers are often maligned for catering almost exclusively to women who are 23. Older women are ignored, the complaint goes. It is the lithe college graduate off to begin a career at a publishing house or record company who remains the inspiration.

title: Loving Stout for All the Right Reasons
description: SOLEMNLY and with not a bit of Irish guile, the Guinness people in Dublin will tell you that each day of the year, through feast and famine, war and pestilence, 10 million glasses of their rich, dark stout are consumed around the globe.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Somerville: Williams's Lawyers Weigh Issues
description: Lawyers for the former basketball star Jayson Williams are considering using his mental condition as an element of their defense. They may also ask some New Jersey state troopers who investigated the case about perceived racial bias. But prosecutors said they would not attempt to introduce indirect evidence of Mr. Williams's level of intoxication at the time of the shooting. Mr. Williams, who is black and a former New Jersey Net, was examined for intoxication eight hours after the shooting. He is accused of the shooting death of a limousine driver, Costas Christofi. During a hearing, William A. Martin, a lawyer for Mr. Williams, said that he might explore psychological issues in the aftermath of the February 2002 shooting at Mr. Williams's estate. He said Mr. Williams had been in ''state of shock'' after the shooting.

title: CALIFORNIA MOVES TO APPEAL DELAY OF VOTE ON RECALL
description: Trying to stave off further chaos in the recall election for Gov. Gray Davis, California officials moved today to overturn a court decision that postponed the vote scheduled for Oct. 7.

title: Online Games Grab Grim Reality
description: As flames crackled and the wind howled through a gash in the skyscraper's wall, a gray-suited businessman wandered in a daze through the smoke. Unable to find an escape route, he suddenly strode toward the sky and leaped.

title: In New Jersey, a Taste of the Andes
description: JOSEPHINE VIZUETA took a bite of the Ecuadorean seviche with popcorn at the restaurant Patria in New York. Then she called the waiter over.

title: NASA Says It Can't Meet Investigation Board's Goals
description: NASA officials said today that they would be unable to comply fully with a critical recommendation from the board that investigated the loss of the Columbia and its crew, giving the space shuttle the ability to repair damage to its heat-protection system in orbit.

title: Tough Times Force U.A.W. To Employ New Strategy
description: The nearly simultaneous deals the United Automobile Workers union announced Monday with the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Group represent a sharp break with tradition and underscore how tough times are for the Big Three and their suppliers.

title: Oprah, Arnold and Equal Time
description: Oprah Winfrey did Arnold Schwarzenegger a big favor this week when she had him on her show. Now she needs to do the voters a favor, and extend an invitation to the other top candidates in the California governor's race. The federal equal-time rule has little force these days, but the principle behind it remains sound: broadcast television should not use its tremendous influence for partisan purposes in an election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIM, MILAGROS, M.D.
description: SIM--Milagros, M.D. The physicians and staff of QueensLong Island Medical Group, P.C. are profoundly saddened by the passing of our beloved friend, colleague and Group shareholder. Dr. Sim was a distinguished and dedicated obstetrician/gynecologist with our Group for 24 years. She was admired and respected by her patients and fellow physicians. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Suman Reejsinghani, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TALLEY, ASTRID ONSTAD
description: TALLEY -- Astrid Onstad. Died peacefully on September 15, 2003 in Palm Beach, FL. Loving wife of John J. Talley. Mother of Christine Moseley, Kari Talley and the late Elizabeth and Mary Jane Moseley. Step sister of Bradley Goodyear Smith, L.R. Gwynn and Richard Bacon. Daughter of the late Niels Onstad and step daughter of film star, Sonja Henie. Services private.

title: Iraqis' Bitterness Is Called Bigger Threat Than Terror
description: New intelligence assessments are warning that the United States' most formidable foe in Iraq in the months ahead may be the resentment of ordinary Iraqis increasingly hostile to the American military occupation, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Carrying the Weight
description: CAMP DOHA, Kuwait, Sept. 17  There is a sobering fact that has been overlooked in the Bush administration's drive to win United Nations support for a new multinational peacekeeping force in Iraq: establishing that force may not ease the main danger for American forces and is unlikely to substantially limit the growing American casualty toll.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: LIFTING OF POULTRY QUARANTINE The federal government lifted quarantines on six counties in Southern California, signaling victory in the fight against a deadly poultry virus, exotic Newcastle disease. The action comes 11 months after the disease was confirmed in California, the Department of Agriculture said in a statement. The government ended quarantines last month on three other California counties and areas of Arizona, Nevada and Texas, a department spokeswoman said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARFIELD, HENRY
description: HARFIELD--Henry, on Saturday, September 13, 2003 in New York City at age 89. Beloved father of Susan Harfield Leness Peck. Survived also by grandchildren Amanda Leness Gubbin and her husband Keith of London, England, Susan Leness Gilbert and her husband David of New York City, Anthony Harfield Leness and his wife Katharine of Boston, MA, Sarah Piel and her husband Douglas McAlinden of New York City and Katherine Piel of West Hollywood, CA. Great-grandfather of Henry Maxwell Gilbert, Eliza Leness Gilbert and Griffin Piel McAlinden. Pre-deceased in 1999 by his wife of 59 years, Marion Bussang Harfield and in 1996 by his daughter, Ellen Harfield Piel. Yale '34 and Columbia Law School '37. At his death, he was of counsel to Shearman & Sterling. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St & Fifth Avenue at 10:30am on Thursday, December 18, 2003. Memorial donations may be made to Yale University, Class of '34, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038 or to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Escalator Death Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a 90-year-old man who fell at the Port Authority Bus Terminal after being jostled by a pickpocket has been ruled a homicide, the police said yesterday. The man, Louis Caprio of Carlstadt, N.J., was riding the escalator on Aug. 23 when a man bumped into him and took his wallet from his pocket, the police said. Mr. Caprio fell down the escalator stairs, injuring his head and neck. He died last Friday, and the medical examiner has ruled that his death was caused by his injuries, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Younger Vick Faces Burden From Bench
description: Michael Vick's jersey has been retired, his place in the Hall of Legends at Virginia Tech already secured. A painted portrait hangs on the door of Michael Vick Hall in the Merryman Athletic Center next to Lane Stadium.

title: Administration Creates Center for Master Terror 'Watch List'
description: The Bush administration announced the creation of a new counterterrorism center today intended to develop a master ''watch list'' of more than 100,000 terrorism suspects and avoid the communication breakdowns that plagued the federal government before the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Many California Employers Face Health Care Mandate
description: With the ranks of the uninsured rising rapidly across the country, California -- where the problem is especially acute -- is on the verge of requiring thousands of employers to provide health benefits for their workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAUL, MARK W.
description: SAUL--Mark W. The Lawrenceville School mourns the passing of Mark W. Saul, Class of '79, an esteemed trustee and loyal Lawrentian. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family and friends. Willard Bunn, III '62 President Board of Trustees Elizabeth A. Duffy, Head Master

title: Butterfly! Butterfly! An American Flag Can't Help You!
description: The dignity in Mark Lamos's production of ''Madama Butterfly,'' which returned on Friday night to City Opera, flows from its sense of graceful understatement. Puccini's tale of love, loyalty and abandonment in Japan provides its own healthy dose of WD-40 for the tear ducts. One of the most important things a production can do is simply stay out of the way of the emotionally freighted drama and let Puccini's lush score take care of the rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, SYLVIA
description: GREENE--Sylvia. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Sylvia Greene, beloved mother - in - law of Gwen Greene, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation and the Wall Street Division. We extend our deepest sympathies to Gwen and her husband, John, and to their entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

title: The Snapple Deal: How Sweet It Is
description: THEY banished soda from school vending machines, calling it nothing but empty calories and tooth-rotting sugar. They brought in Snapple with the promise of healthier, all-juice drinks for students -- and $8 million a year to city school coffers.

title: It Isn't La Dolce Vita, But It's Pretty Close
description: WE all have our regular ways of cooking, our kitchen routines -- and I don't apologize for that. It's what makes inviting people over for supper manageable in the first place. My standby dinner nearly always involves some chicken or duck breasts or ruby-fleshed steaks immersed in a marinade and stashed in the fridge until dinnertime, when I get the griddle out and proceed on autopilot.

title: The Recall Ruling: Those Chads, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: SARS Patient Released
description: A 27-year-old medical researcher who acquired a mild case of SARS while working in a laboratory has recovered and was discharged from a hospital. He will be in quarantine at home for two weeks. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta performed tests over the weekend on the researcher's specimens, which had been sent from Singapore. It confirmed the diagnosis, the World Health Organization in Geneva said. The agency said that because none of the researcher's contacts had become secondarily infected, the case was not regarded as a public health concern. A W.H.O. team began working in Singapore to review safety issues in the affected laboratory. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Whale on the Table
description: You've heard about the Atkins diet, the South Beach diet, the Dean Ornish diet, the Zone. Well, based on my research here in the Arctic, let me present to you the one approach that is guaranteed to help you lose 10 pounds a week or your money back!

title: COURT CUTS BOND FOR PHILIP MORRIS APPEAL
description: The Illinois Supreme Court in Springfield has cut to $6.8 billion the bond that Philip Morris USA must post to appeal a class-action verdict won by smokers of ''light'' cigarettes. Yesterday, the court threw out a trial judge's order requiring the company to post a $12 billion bond. The court also said it would hear Philip Morris's challenge of the $10.1 billion awarded to the smokers in the original verdict. In March, Judge Nicholas Byron of Madison County Circuit Court ruled that Philip Morris, a unit of the Altria Group, had misled Illinois smokers and ordered the company to pay $10.1 billion in damages.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Gov. George E. Pataki's prowess at campaign fund-raising for Republicans, including George W. Bush, referred imprecisely to the two men's Yale connection. Mr. Pataki (class of 1967) and Mr. Bush (class of 1968) graduated a year apart; they were not classmates.

title: Indonesia Vows to Pursue Economic Plan
description: Ending a month of delays, Indonesia's government released an economic blueprint today, drafted to reassure the investment community that it will not backslide on making changes once it emerges from the supervision of the International Monetary Fund next year.

title: Recall Decision Roils Presidential Race, Too
description: On the first Tuesday of next March, 11 states, from California to New York, will hold Democratic presidential contests, a flurry of voting that party officials say will probably produce a Democratic presidential nominee.

description: The Internal Revenue Service and 40 states announced an agreement today to share investigative leads on promoters of fraudulent tax schemes and to coordinate efforts to shut them down, prosecute them in some cases and warn the public.

title: Toshiba Sees Larger Loss In First Half
description: The Toshiba Corporation, under pressure from lower-price rivals like Dell and Hewlett-Packard, expects a larger loss in the first half of its fiscal year as part of its plan to overhaul its personal computer division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDEL, JOSIE
description: MENDEL--Josie. After a long courageous battle with breast cancer passed away prematurely on Monday, September 15, 2003. Daughter of the late Betty and Joseph Germano, beloved wife of Andrew Mendel, devoted mother of Adam and Joshua, loving sister of Toni Dodici and Howard Germain, adored aunt of Melissa and Joanna Dodici and Caren and Ira Mendel. She taught nursery school at the Rosenthal J.C.C. in Pleasantville, New York. She leaves a host of friends and relatives whose hearts she captured and wherein she will always reside. Funeral services were held at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Rd. in Armonk on Tuesday, September 16th. Shiva calls will be received Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday evening and Sunday at her home at 6 Banksville Road, Armonk.

title: In Speech, Spitzer Casts Himself as the Main Democratic Challenger to Pataki in 2006
description: Eliot Spitzer staked out his position as the leading Democratic challenger to Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday in a speech to New York City business leaders, saying the state government was failing to take the right steps to revive the economy.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: NEWSPAPER'S EQUIPMENT SEIZED The police seized computers and other equipment from the offices of the country's biggest and only independent daily newspaper, The Daily News, a lawyer for the paper said. The paper, with a circulation of 100,000, was shut down by armed police officers on Friday because it had failed to register with a state commission. The paper is fiercely critical of President Robert G. Mugabe. "They are simply using brute force," Gugulethu Moyo, the lawyer for the paper, said in a telephone interview. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Refiners Sales Delayed
description: The Supreme Court of India delayed a government asset-sale program and caused refiners' shares to fall when it said lawmakers must approve a $1.6 billion sale of shares in the Hindustan Petroleum Corporation and the Bharat Petroleum Corporation. The court in New Delhi upheld a petition challenging the plan to sell Hindustan Petroleum, the second-biggest government refiner, and Bharat Petroleum, the third-biggest, without approval from the Parliament. Opponents said the approval was required.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Muslim Girl Punched In Face; Boy Is Arrested
description: A 14-year-old Muslim girl was punched in the face after school on Monday by a boy who used an anti-Muslim slur, the police said yesterday. The police arrested a 14-year-old boy in connection with the incident, which occurred in Baychester, on charges of assault and aggravated harassment. The police did not release the name of the victim or the suspect or the exact location of the incident. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOO, CHIN, FU
description: WOO--Chin-Fu. Beloved husband of Yu Tsung; devoted father of Lily and Rose; sonsin-law, Michael and John; cherished grandfather of Natalie, died on Sunday, September 14, at Fairview Nursing Care Center. He was 93. Born in China in 1910 and became a U.S. citizen in 1970. Earned his B.S. degree from Nankai University in Tientsin and his M.B.A. degree from the University of Washington in Seattle. Founder, publisher and editor of the United Journal since 1952. Author of The Principles of Desirable Society. You will always be with us. We love you.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel Still Eclipsed By Parcells's Aura
description: BILL PARCELLS didn't really return to the Meadowlands because he never actually left. Part of him, anyway, stayed behind through the decade past and beyond to haunt Ray Handley and Dan Reeves and now Jim Fassel, remind them how they were and will forever be nowhere as Giants coach unless they exorcise him by winning the Super Bowl, the way Parcells did twice.

title: Bush Links Pollution Measure To His Effort to Create Jobs
description: President Bush made a pitch today for his plan to reduce air pollution, and while he outlined the environmental benefits, his focus was just as much on the issues that his advisers say are more likely than any others to determine his chances at re-election: jobs and the economy.

title: Rasmussen Fits In
description: When Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president and general manager, expressed an interest in signing the free-agent forward Erik Rasmussen this summer, the 26-year-old Rasmussen experienced a flood of emotions.

title: Abraham Fischler, 78, Trader Who Revived a Diamond Mart
description: Abraham Fischler, a diamond trader who returned to Antwerp, Belgium, after World war II to make the city a diamond center once again, died there on Sept. 9. He was 78.

title: Aides to General Say He Will Enter '04 Campaign
description: Aides to Gen. Wesley K. Clark said today that he had decided to join the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, leaving prominent Democrats to speculate that that Army general with no elective experience could soar or crash -- and in a relatively short time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, LEWIS
description: WEINER--Lewis. The Society for the History of Czechoslovak Jewry, Inc. mourns the death of its distinguished past president on September 15th, 2003 at the age of 93. The Society was founded by Dr. Kurt Wehle in 1961 to publish accurate historical essays describing Jewish participation in every aspect of Czechoslovak life between the two World Wars, thus counteracting the distorting revisionism of the Czech Communist regime. Lewis Weiner followed Kurt Wehle, Hugh Colman, and Ludovic Sturc as President of the Society. He brought his vast energies, broad vision and total dedication to the Society in the 1980s and early 1990s, supervising the publication in 1984 of the most challenging volume in the Society's trilogy, ''The Jews of Czechoslovakia,'' dealing with the Holocaust, as well as six annual reviews in the subsequent years, ably assisted by Gertrude Hirschler. Lewis Weiner's leadership was characterized by gentlemanly grace, dignity, a generous spirit and dry wit. He was a true heir of Tomas Masaryk's legacy and a worthy son of the Jewish people; his contributions a substantial tribute to the rich, complex and tragic story of Czechoslovak Jews. We extend condolences to his family: Joyce, Lynn, Ted, Susan, former wife Anita, and first cousin, Society member Hannah Gruna. May God console the family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Norman R. Patz, Pres. Prof. Dr. Fred Hahn, VP Dr. Amira Kohn-Trattner, VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PANARELLA, THOMAS J.
description: PANARELLA -- Thomas J., age 87, of Middletown, NJ (formerly of Brooklyn), on September 16, 2003. Beloved husband of Mary Aquilino Panarella. Devoted father of Olympia Hydeck, Nancy Moscuzza, Vincent Panarella and Sal Panarella. Grandfather of two, great-grandfather of 1. Funeral services private.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Queens; Knitting Business Departs And Leaves Space Behind
description: Twenty years ago roughly three out of every four sweaters worn in the United States came from the New York area, especially from the corner of Queens that includes Ridgewood, Glendale and Maspeth.

title: In Court, Verizon Challenges Music Industry's Subpoenas
description: As Congress intensifies its scrutiny of the special subpoenas that the recording industry is using to track down and sue people who share music over the Internet, a federal appeals court panel questioned today whether legislators had intended the subpoenas to be used in such a way.

title: Channeling Thurston Howell III
description: ''No one can pull the wool over my eyes,'' the billionaire castaway Thurston Howell III once proclaimed on ''Gilligan's Island,'' the irresistibly inane television series. ''Cashmere, maybe, but wool, never.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Appeal Sought On Energy Documents
description: The Bush administration told a federal appeals court that it would ask the Supreme Court to review a decision that requires Vice President Dick Cheney to give the Sierra Club documents from his task force on energy. Last week, the full United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit let stand a panel's decision that the government had no basis to ask the appeals court to block a lower court's ruling that called for disclosure of information. Mr. Cheney has invoked executive privilege in keeping the documents secret.

title: Mets' Sour Season: Can't Anybody Here Play Spoiler?
description: Al Leiter will arrive at Wrigley Field on Wednesday morning, go to his locker and begin his preparations for his afternoon start. He will try to convince himself of the importance of the game against the Chicago Cubs. He will forget his team's poor record and remind himself he is facing Kerry Wood, one of baseball's best pitchers, and that this game means everything to the Cubs.

title: Spanish Judge Charges Bin Laden in 9/11 Attacks
description: MADRID, Sept. 17  He has already tried to prosecute the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, as well as dozens of military officers accused of atrocities in Argentina's dirty war. Now Spain's most renowned judge, Baltasar Garzon, has set his sights on Osama bin Laden.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 295 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sabotage Of Illusionist Charged
description: A man was charged with criminal damage after he tried, unsuccessfully, to cut the line supplying the American illusionist David Blaine with water, the police said. The man, in his 40's, is accused of climbing onto a scaffolding support tower connected to the plexiglass box where Mr. Blaine, 30, is living, pelting him with water bottles and other objects, and trying to cut the water line and other cables. According to The Evening Standard, the man pulled on the cables and caused the box to swing violently as he yelled: ''Go home, David. Go back to America. We don't want you here.'' Mr. Blaine, who entered the box -- suspended from a crane near Tower Bridge in London -- on Sept. 5, vowing to go without food for 44 days, has been repeatedly taunted and has had objects thrown at him by Britons unimpressed by his stunt. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Review/Fashion; From Miguel Adrover, A Beautiful Mosaic
description: That the shopping public benefited from one big sprucing up during the 1990's is part of our cultural understanding. Because of the creative efforts of the Gap, Target and other mass retailers, the thinking goes, average Americans now have access to the clean designs that constitute an upper-middle-class conception of good taste. Everyone looks chic and polished in the same homogenizing way, and the world is a better place for it.

title: Accounts
description: * Schieffelin & Somerset, New York, expanded its relationship with the Tracy Locke Partnership, Wilton, Conn., by naming Tracy Locke as creative agency of record on the account of Grand Marnier. Billings have not been determined. Tracy Locke, part of the Omnicom Group, now handles promotional marketing for Grand Marnier; the creative duties had been handled by agencies on a project basis. Schieffelin & Somerset, a joint venture between Diageo and LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, imports and distributes Grand Marnier in the United States.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: UNLAWFUL HEALTH CLAIMS ONLINE Herbal remedies are often marketed on the Internet with misleading or unproven health claims that violate federal law, according to a study of 443 Web sites. An editorial published with the studies in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association called for improvements in the regulation of alternative treatments. Of the Web sites examined, 292 made health claims for their products, saying they could cure, prevent or treat a disease. Of those, 153 omitted a federally required disclaimer saying that the claims had not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration and that the products were not intended to treat or prevent disease. The Council for Responsible Nutrition, a trade group for makers of dietary supplements, said it advised members not to make unsubstantiated claims. (AP)

title: Yanks Cruise With Jeter As Leader
description: It was not Roy Hobbs throwing off his hospital gown, bleeding through his flannel jersey and blasting the game-winning homer. But if the Yankees go on to win the World Series, it might become the stuff of legend.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't eat ice cream now. I eat spinach leaves and vegetables.''

title: Reinventing the Whisk: Presto! It's a Pancake
description: With their bulky shapes, whisks have always presented a storage problem. Now Kuhn Rikon has come up with two models that can fit in the shallowest of kitchen drawers.

title: Death in Stormy Marriage Results in No Charges Filed
description: Renee Silecchia and her husband, Jack, did not get along.

title: U.S. Will Give City $5 Million To Cut Air Pollution by Ferries
description: Over the last few years, thousands of smoke-spewing buses on New York City streets have been rebuilt and cleaned up, leading to the reduction of tons of dangerous diesel soot.

title: World Briefing | Americas: El Salvador: U.S. Suit In Archbishop's Killing
description: The Center for Justice and Accountability, a California-based organization that sues rights abusers who live in or visit the United States, has filed a federal lawsuit against a Salvadoran immigrant accused of plotting the 1980 assassination of the Roman Catholic archbishop scar Arnulfo Romero during El Salvador's civil war. The civil suit, filed in Fresno, Calif., accuses Alvaro Rafael Saravia of having provided weapons, a vehicle and driver to the men who killed the archbishop while he was celebrating Mass. Mr. Saravia moved to the United States in 1987. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARK, LAWRENCE
description: MARK--Lawrence. And the lights just turned green on 42nd St.

title: Crowning the King
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including differing opinions about Stephen King's place in the literary pecking order.

title: Arguments on California Recall Submitted to Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The people who want the California recall election postponed argued today that it would be a disservice to the people of the state to hold the vote on Oct. 7. And those who want it to proceed insisted that it would be a disservice to the people to delay it.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Sept. 5 about ''French Artists in Rome: Ingres to Degas, 1803-1873,'' at the Dahesh Museum in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to the Michelangelo work depicted by Ingres in his painting of the Sistine Chapel. It is ''The Last Judgment,'' not ''The Last Supper.''

title: In the Treasurer's Office, a Baseball Trove
description: WHEN John McCormac was appointed state treasurer, he was given the choice of two offices in the New Jersey State House. One had a lot of wall space. One did not. It was not a difficult decision. For along with Mr. McCormac came a large collection of memorabilia that makes his office look like a shrine to professional baseball.

title: About New York; Bringing Us The Head Of Dan Quayle
description: LAST year, a crate containing a plaster bust of James Danforth Quayle was delivered to the doorstep of a squat, dusty building in Long Island City. A bust of the former vice president, lifelike down to the dimple in his tie, just sitting there, in a box. In Long Island City.

title: Jitters in the Philippines
description: Repeated coup rumors and allegations of corruption in high places are destabilizing the Philippine government at a time when it needs more than ever to focus on repairing the battered economy and fighting poverty. President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo must remove the ambiguity over whether she will run next May so she, and the country, can concentrate on the tasks that lie ahead. If Mrs. Arroyo chooses not to run, as she has previously vowed, she should declare this once and for all, rise above the fray and set about fulfilling some of her promises to reform the economy and the military. If she has changed her mind -- and there is no shame in doing so -- she should explain why and spell out what she would do with a new mandate.

title: F.C.C. PLAN TO EASE CURBS ON BIG MEDIA HITS SENATE SNAG
description: The Senate approved a resolution today to repeal all of the new regulations that would make it easier for the nation's largest media companies to grow bigger.

title: New Work In New Hall (Some Old Stuff, Too)
description: In its performance at Zankel Hall on Monday evening the Emerson String Quartet honored the hall's tilt toward contemporary music by playing Ned Rorem's String Quartet No. 4 (1994). But the group also planted a flag (figuratively) on the Zankel stage on behalf of the conventional repertory with robust performances of Haydn's String Quartet in D (Op. 76, No. 5) and, with the pianist Emanuel Ax, the Dvorak Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81).

title: A Little Pucker From New Zealand
description: With autumn on the horizon, Forage Organic Apple Glaze, a new import from New Zealand, is a must for the pantry. Blending a variety of organic apples gives the syrupy glaze a complex tart sweetness. It adds a glossy, flavorful finish to roasted pork, chicken, winter squash or root vegetables. A splash of cider vinegar will sharpen the flavor, especially with scallops or fish like salmon. It can be brushed, straight from the bottle, on an apple tart or cobbler warm from the oven, and be used to drizzle on the ice cream served alongside. The glaze is $12 for 8.8 ounces at Williams-Sonoma stores. It can also be ordered from the Williams-Sonoma catalog at (800) 541-2233 or www.williams-sonoma.com. For customers in New York, once the shipping charges are added, it's actually less expensive to order the glaze directly from its source in New Zealand, www.productsfromnz.com. The shipping charges are higher but the product is only $5.99 a bottle, so the total is a little less.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Holding Those Who Face Deportation
description: In a pilot program ordered by the federal Department of Homeland Security, illegal immigrants in Connecticut are being arrested immediately after their final deportation notice rather than remaining free while on appeal. Twenty illegal immigrants have been arrested and jailed since Aug. 1, when the program began. The program may be expanded nationwide if federal officials find it is effective in reducing the number of immigrants who evade deportation. Federal officials said there were active cases involving 400,000 people nationwide who had fled after being ordered to leave the country. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Morgan Stanley Fined Over Fund Sales Incentives
description: When it comes to selling shares in its own mutual funds, Morgan Stanley knows how to move the merchandise. Toss the sales staff tickets to a Britney Spears concert and throw in gift certificates to spas, restaurants, golf courses and department stores. Then the sales will roll in.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Banks To Recover Tax
description: The Tokyo government will probably repay 30 of Japan's largest banks 234.4 billion yen ($2 billion) in taxes that it collected over two years. The government imposed the tax on the banks to increase tax receipts. The banks had been paying less tax because they were declaring losses as they wrote off bad loans. The two sides have been working out the details of the repayment after 15 of the banks successfully sued the city. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Explosion Ends Hostage Siege
description: A 52-year-old man apparently involved in a pay dispute set off a huge explosion inside the building of a courier company in the western city of Nagoya, killing himself, the branch manager and a police officer. The suspect was a contract driver for the company, Keikyubin, and was reportedly demanding about $2,200 in unpaid wages. He entered the building armed with a knife and initially took eight people hostage before sprinkling the office with a flammable liquid. The blast injured 41 other people. The three-hour standoff was carried live on national television. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: In Gathering Storm, Surf Meets City
description: As Hurricane Isabel churned up the Atlantic yesterday, many communities around New York were stoked with fear. But one group -- New York City's surfers -- was just plain stoked, dude.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Home Intruder (a Large, Furry, 4-Legged One)
description: In northwestern New Jersey, where encounters between people and bears have become increasingly frequent, a black bear broke into the same house twice yesterday, terrifying the occupants, before it was shot and killed by the police.

title: Federal Workers' Health Premiums to Rise Less Than Others'
description: Health insurance premiums for federal workers and retirees will rise next year by an average of 10.6 percent, which is much less than the increases planned by many private employers, the Bush administration said today.

title: A Sweet Combination of Belgium and Australia
description: The name of the new East Village confectionery shop, Australian Homemade, takes some explaining. To be sure, swirling aboriginal-style patterns cover the floor of this bright, industrial-looking glass, stainless steel and wood place at 115 St. Marks Place (between First Avenue and Avenue A). And the ice cream that is made fresh on the premises in small batches, not just daily, but every few hours, is from an Australian recipe. But the shop is the first American branch of a European chain with stores mostly in Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Minister Offers Resignation
description: The Japanese finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, said he would leave the government if asked by the prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi. Mr. Koizumi is expected to reshuffle his cabinet if he wins another term as president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party on Sept. 20. Mr. Shiokawa, 81, was hospitalized on Sept. 3 and missed a meeting of finance ministers from the nations of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum soon after. Mr. Shiokawa will also miss a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven nations who will meet later this week in Dubai. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: City Seeks Police Costs From Yale
description: New Haven is billing Yale University for police overtime costs prompted by the continuing strike of two Yale unions. The city has billed $105,000 to Yale since Aug. 27, when 2,000 clerical, technical, maintenance and service workers walked off the job to protest wages, pensions and job security. Last Saturday, the police arrested 152 people at a rally of 10,000 demonstrators, said Bonnie Winchester, a Police Department spokeswoman; a second overtime bill is being prepared. Thomas Conroy, a spokesman for Yale, said university lawyers were reviewing the request. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: After Surviving, Twins Battle to Keep Thriving
description: More than a year removed from the threat of contraction, and without Commissioner Bud Selig to use for motivation, the Twins spent much of the summer struggling to regain the magic that made them the feel-good team of last season.

title: Fierce Words by DMX, But From a Fretful Face
description: What's going on with DMX? This rapper from Yonkers hasn't released much music over the last two years, though he did appear in the film ''Cradle 2 the Grave.'' It seemed possible that hip-hop's greatest growler (and stubbornest loner) spent his sabbatical recharging his batteries and honing his skills. And so at Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night DMX's fans were hoping for a triumphant return.

title: Swedes Arrest Suspect in Assassination of Minister
description: The Swedish police said last night that they had arrested a 35-year-old man suspected of the killing of Foreign Minister Anna Lindh, who was stabbed to death as she shopped in a department store in Stockholm last week.

title: Senate, Opposing House, Backs Study of New Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The Senate today backed the Bush administration's request for money for new nuclear weapons, putting it at odds with a House decision to scale back spending on research into a new generation of nuclear arms.

title: Mosley's Lawyers Criticize Arum and De La Hoya
description: In a letter to the Nevada State Athletic Commission yesterday, lawyers for Shane Mosley took a few swings against Oscar De La Hoya and the promoter Bob Arum, calling them sore losers and requesting that the commission chairman, Luther Mack, begin disciplinary proceedings against them for suggesting that Mosley's unanimous decision on Saturday was the result of judge tampering. ''This has gone too beyond the pale,'' said Judd Burstein, a lawyer for Mosley. ''Bob Arum should be suspended for his irresponsibility.''

title: Sweden's mistrust of euro's big boys
description: Sweden's rejection of the European Union's common currency was a coldly rational statement of mistrust in the euro. It distanced itself from the stagnant economic performance of the euro zone, and flatly refused to place its monetary future under the sway of big countries like France and Germany, who have bent the euro's rules to suit themselves.

title: Boudin Freed From Prison After Serving 22 Years
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Sept. 17  Kathy Boudin, the former 1960's radical and fugitive, walked out of prison into the brilliant September sunshine today, 22 years after her involvement in an armored-car robbery that left three dead.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: `DIRTY WAR' FIGURE ARRESTED Alfredo Astiz, a notorious former navy captain known as the "blond angel of death" for his role in the disappearance of opponents of the military dictatorship that ruled Argentina from 1976 to 1983, was arrested in response to a French government warrant. Mr. Astiz, convicted in absentia in France in 1990 of killing two French nuns, is one of 40 former military officers who were recently detained at the request of a Spanish judge but were later released after Spain declined to formally request their extradition.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Newspaper's Equipment Seized
description: The police seized computers and other equipment from the offices of the country's biggest and only independent daily newspaper, The Daily News, a lawyer for the paper said. The paper, with a circulation of 100,000, was shut down by armed police officers on Friday because it had failed to register with a state commission. The paper is fiercely critical of President Robert G. Mugabe. ''They are simply using brute force,'' Gugulethu Moyo, the lawyer for the paper, said in a telephone interview. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid For Power Plant
description: A Malaysian company has offered 3.5 billion Australian dollars ($2.3 billion) for the Loy Yang power station, a coal-fired generator that supplies 5 percent of Australia's electricity. The Malaysian company, Genting Berhad of Kuala Lumpur, said it made the bid last week for the 2000 megawatt station, 100 miles east of Melbourne. The plant is owned by Horizon Energy Investment Group of Australia, CMS Energy of Jackson, Miss., and NRG Energy, a unit of Xcel Energy of Minneapolis. John Shaw (NYT)

title: When There's Only One of a Chain
description: I usually avoid places like Chipotle Mexican Grill, which opened last month on 44th Street, near Third Avenue. It belongs to a chain partly owned by McDonald's. That places it squarely among the forces that are ironing the country's quirky regional wrinkles into a smooth national uniform in which Anchorage equals Akron. Each franchise, whether restaurant, coffee shop or drugstore, arrives with focus groups, market surveys and other tools of bureaucracy, relentlessly homogenizing flavor and creativity.

title: Nedved, Hlavac, Kovalev: Rangers' European Union
description: Rangers center Petr Nedved knew that Jan Hlavac, his countryman from the Czech Republic, would be an unrestricted free agent this summer. Nedved was also aware that he had played his best hockey with the Rangers from 1999 to 2001 with Hlavac on his left wing.

title: Coca-Cola Decides To Consolidate Work
description: The Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta has decided to consolidate the North American media planning and buying assignments for all its soda and juice brands, with total spending estimated at $300 million to $400 million. The assignments, now divided among three agencies, have been placed in review.

title: Riding Across America for Immigrant Workers
description: Borrowing a page from the civil rights movement, immigrants rights groups announced yesterday that they would stage an updated version of the 1960's Freedom Rides by sending 18 buses across the nation to draw attention to the plight of many immigrants.

title: Woman Is First in City to Die of West Nile This Year
description: Health officials said yesterday that an 85-year-old Bronx woman who tested positive for exposure to the West Nile virus earlier this month had become the first New York City resident to die from the disease this year. And in Flushing, Queens, a 35-year-old woman's illness has been diagnosed as West Nile, said the authorities, who also noted that she was the 10th city resident known to have contracted the disease this year. They said the woman has been released from a hospital and is recovering at home.

title: The Dalai Lama on Tour, an Exile on Main Street
description: On his 15th trip to the United States, the Dalai Lama has been met by sold-out crowds from coast to coast. Tickets to his events have been bid up on eBay. He filled Davies Symphony Hall in San Francisco, and on Sept. 11 packed Washington National Cathedral, as 3,000 more people listened outside on the lawn. Scalpers did brisk business outside the basketball arena in Boston last Sunday selling last-minute tickets.

title: Review/Fashion; This American Moment
description: At the heart of the spring 2004 collections now under way in Bryant Park and in other parts of New York City is a craving for a freedom that contemporary life rarely provides. It isn't just that the clothes this season are prettier or more relaxed or more generous in their use of color. These are clothes, as the designer Peter Som said in the notes for his show yesterday, ''that embody a wide-eyed optimism.''

title: Warming Up for Dinner
description: At 325 Spring, a SoHo restaurant and bar, there is a downstairs dining room where you can bring your parents for dinner, and an upstairs lounge where you might not.

title: Dcor's Textured Veil
description: Curtains, rugs and pillows say "touch me." So do lamshades.

title: Adding a Personal Touch to Concerts at the Met
description: SO this is where one teenager who decided not to become a concert pianist ended up: in an office with no windows, a few steps from the stage door to a concert hall. title: Editorial Observer; In Hurricanes' Most Familiar Territory, Paradises Are Routinely Lost
description: As Hurricane Isabel nears North Carolina, where it is expected to veer toward Pennsylvania, there is mystery in its winds. For many of the people bracing for the effects of the storm along a broad swath of the East Coast, a hurricane is a rare event, and even the ones that arrive generally strike only a glancing blow. But in the Caribbean, where a storm's potential for death, destruction and ruin is too well known, residents are on the equivalent of a constant red alert virtually every day of the Atlantic hurricane season. There, from June through November, a churning anxiety accompanies the news of each weather system that is spawned, usually in waters off the west coast of Africa, and sets its sights on the Caribbean Sea.

title: Warming Up for Dinner, and Something After, in an Old Building
description: At 325 Spring, a renovated SoHo restaurant and bar that used to be Tho, there is a downstairs dining room, above left, where you can bring your parents for dinner, and an upstairs lounge where you might not. Jonathan Morr, seated on the right, felt that Tho was too cold, so he hired Jim Walrod, a Manhattan designer, left, to warm it up. ''Every time I approach an old building, I always have dreams that they're almost intact, but they never are,'' Mr. Walrod said. He restored the first floor to something like its original style in 1938, when it was a post office built by the Works Progress Administration. By researching other W.P.A. buildings from the 1930's, he conjured up the colors for the dining room -- a pinkish beige on the top half of the walls and a caramel below with a raked terra cotta finish. He even found the original lighting fixtures at a salvage company.

title: A Jolt of Caffeine For the Sluggish PC
description: CHRISTINA CORNISH-LAURIA was perplexed by a gradual but noticeable decline in her computer's performance. Ms. Cornish-Lauria, the executive director of a nonprofit group, regularly ran one utility that defragmented the hard drive and another that updated her antivirus software. Nonetheless, over the course of six months the PC's performance continued to deteriorate. It was taking longer to boot, and applications ran with a serene indifference to her deadlines. Finally, when Web pages with information that she needed to do her job failed to load completely, Ms. Cornish-Lauria started searching for the cause of her PC's misbehavior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASSEY, JOHN CLIFFORD
description: MASSEY--John Clifford, was born on June 16, 2003, in New York, NY. He died in his sleep on September 14, 2003, in Houston, TX. John Clifford was the light of our lives. He was only with us on this earth for a short time, but his precious little smile will live in our hearts forever. No one has ever been more loved. John Clifford was preceded in death by his great grandparents: Mary Beth and Ray Allen Walker; Clifford Walter Ligon; and Marie Noonan and Eugene Aloysius Massey. John Clifford is the beloved child of parents Kendall and Tom Massey of New York, NY. He is also survived by his great grandparents Joy Barringer Ligon and Katherine and John Brennan Mowry; his grandparents Robert and Linda Ligon of Houston, TX and Mary Ellen and Eugene Aloysius Massey, Jr., of Washington, DC; his aunts Lacey Ligon Thomas and her husband, James Thomas; Elizabeth Whitney Ligon; and Elizabeth Massey Hopkins and her husband, Ryan McGill Hopkins; his uncles, Robert Walker Ligon and Michael Patrick Massey and his cousin Walker Michael Thomas. Services will be held in New York on Saturday, September 20, at 11am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave at 84 St. Interment services private. A reception for family and friends will be held later that afternoon. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NY, NY 10022 and designated for the John Clifford Massey Memorial Fund. A bench at the Central Park Children's Zoo will be dedicated in John Clifford's memory.

title: Israel's Threats Against Arafat
description: If the Israeli government hopes to marginalize Yasir Arafat -- an aim we heartily endorse -- then recent threats by senior ministers to have him killed show how poorly they understand the Palestinians. They have propelled Mr. Arafat back into the warm embrace of his besieged and increasingly desperate people -- returned him to where he is happiest, to the role of a scrappy fighter standing firm against the Israeli behemoth. This posturing on both sides serves neither people. Ariel Sharon and his ministers have a responsibility to pull back from their explosive language and take real steps that could alter the Palestinian political dynamic for the better.

description: The state attorney general is challenging former Gov. George Ryan's landmark decision to grant blanket clemency for death row inmates. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mixed News On Infant Mortality
description: Infant mortality in New York City dropped to a record low last year, but remained high in some poor neighborhoods, the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday. Of every 1,000 babies born in the city, 6 died before their first birthdays in 2002, compared with 6.1 in 2001, the previous record. The national rate was 6.9 per 1,000 in 2000, the most recent figure available. Rates in the poor, black and Hispanic communities are sometimes double that of the city as a whole. Last year, the highest rates were in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, at 13.9 per 1,000; Brownsville, Brooklyn, at 10.9; and Westchester in the Bronx, at 9.6. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JESSOP, DOROTHY JONES, PH.D.
description: JESSOP -- Dorothy Jones, Ph.D. Died on Sunday, September 7, 2003, at her home in Forest Hills Gardens. Dr. Jessop retired from full-time employment in September 2000 due to health problems. She had been Director of Research and Evaluation at Medical and Health Research Association of New York City since 1989. She continued her academic appointments at the Mailman School of Public Health of Columbia University and Albert Einstein College of Medicine (Pediatrics). Dr. Jessop, a graduate of the College of New Rochelle, trained as a sociologist and received her Ph.D. from New York University (1979). She spent her 35-plus year career developing, conducting and overseeing applied research projects in health and human services, focusing on chronic illness and disabilities, and the welfare of women and children. She was active in professional organizations as well as community and parish activities. Dr. Jessop is survived by her daughter Dorothy (aka Daryl) Rijos, son-in-law Jose Rijos, and granddaughter Bryanna Marie. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills on Saturday, September 20, 2003, at 10 AM. Memorial donations can be made to either YAI/National Institute for Persons with Disabilities, 460 W. 34th St, NY, NY, or the Marian Residence of the Ursuline Nuns, North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOGERFO, PAUL, MD.
description: LoGERFO--Paul, MD. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Paul LoGerfo, David V. Habif Professor of Surgery, Co-Director of the New York Thyroid Center and President of the American Association of Endocrine Surgeons. Dr. LoGerfo was a world-renowned leader in the field of thyroid and parathyroid surgery, a superb teacher, and a genuinely loving friend. He developed the thyroglobulin assay, one of the most commonly used methods for detecting recurrent thyroid cancer, and was a pioneer in the field of thyroid and parathyroid surgery by developing a technique using local anesthesia for most of these procedures. He also established the New York Thyroid Center, a comprehensive center dedicated to providing superior medical care and education for patients with thyroid disease, and implemented surgical registries which are invaluable resources for outcomes research. Three years ago, Dr. LoGerfo collaborated on ''The Thyroid Guide'', a comprehensive book intended to empower patients through education about their thyroid condition so they could play an active role in their own treatment decisions. Dr. LoGerfo was an extremely kind and generous person who was beloved by his patients and colleagues, and by scores of students who knew him as both mentor and friend. We extend sincere condolences to his wife, Kristin Larkin LoGerfo, his father, Mr. Paul LoGerfo, his brothers, Dr. Frank LoGerfo and Dr. James LoGerfo, his daughters, Susan Goetz and Cathy Haims, and his three grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to The Paul LoGerfo Art Research and Education Trust, c/o Kenneth A. Forde, M.D., Department of Surgery, 177 Fort Washington Avenue, MHB 7SK, New York, NY 10032. The Department of Surgery Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center Eric A. Rose, M.D. Chairman and Surgeon-in-Chief

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Removal Of Feeding Tube
description: A circuit court judge ordered the removal of a feeding tube that has kept a brain-damaged woman alive for a decade. The judge, George Greer, also turned down a request that the woman, Terri Schiavo, 39, be given therapy to learn how to eat without the tube, after doctors testified that she could not be rehabilitated. The woman's husband, Michael Schiavo, wanted the feeding tube removed, while Ms. Schiavo's parents sought to keep her alive. Doctors have testified that Ms. Schiavo will live 10 to 14 days after removal of the tube, scheduled for Oct. 15. Terry Aquayo (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Search Service From I.B.M.
description: I.B.M. is introducing a service today that combines World Wide Web searching with text analysis and database queries. The service, called WebFountain, represents the combined effort of 300 I.B.M. scientists, who have collected more than 100 patents on this research since it began in the late 1990's. The project is collecting and indexing 25 million Web pages a day, about 4 billion pages this year, half of them stored in I.B.M. databases. Those not stored include Web pages not likely to be relevant to I.B.M.'s business customers, like the 30 percent of all Web pages that feature pornography. Robert Carlson, a vice president in the company's Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif., said the technology goes well beyond the text searches and popularity ranking of Google. He said it could analyze billions of Web pages instead of the millions of pages that services like Biz360 and Intelliseek do. The I.B.M. service will also search and analyze commercial information services. I.B.M. is to announce a partnership today with Factiva, a company backed by Dow Jones and Reuters. Steve Lohr (NYT)
