title: UAL'S DISCOUNT AIRLINE TO FLY FROM DENVER IN FEBRUARY
description: United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, said yesterday that its new discount carrier would begin with flights from Denver International Airport in February, as the company tries to compete with low-cost airlines. The new unit, which has not been named, will initially have four Airbus A320 aircraft, increasing to 40 by the end of next year, United said. From Denver, flights will be to Reno, Nev.; Las Vegas; Phoenix; New Orleans; Tampa, Fla; Ontario, Calif.; and Orlando, Fla. Other destinations will be added later, the company said. UAL is reorganizing after seeking bankruptcy protection in December.

title: Team Selected for T.J. Maxx Tour
description: USA Gymnastics named five women and five men yesterday to take part in next month's T.J. Maxx Tour of Gymnastics Champions. From Oct. 3-19, the tour will stop in Bridgeport, Conn.; Philadelphia; Norfolk, Va.; Chicago; Green Bay, Wis.; St. Paul; Omaha; Dallas; and Houston.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Kevin O'Connor, the new host of ''This Old House'' on PBS, misstated the name of another home-improvement show. It is ''Bob Vila's Home Again,'' not ''At Home With Bob Vila.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ban On Secret Kohl Files Lifted
description: A court in Berlin ruled that East German secret police files on former Chancellor Helmut Kohl may be made public. The decision overruled two earlier court verdicts and is itself subject to appeal. Mr. Kohl has been trying to block the release of the files, claiming that he was a victim and entitled to privacy. But the court sided with a new law that gives researchers access to the Stasi files on public figures. The Kohl records contain nearly 9,000-pages of secret police information and tapped telephone conversations from at least 1982 until 1989. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Kingfisher Profit Rises
description: The British home-improvement retailer Kingfisher said that first-half profit before interest and tax increased 29 percent on increased sales of power tools and paint. Earnings for the six months ended Aug. 2 rose to 335 million ($539 million) from 259 million ($416 million) a year earlier. The results excluded Kesa Electricals, an electronics unit that Kingfisher spun off in July. Sales rose 15 percent, to 3.9 billion ($6.2 billion), but shares of Kingfisher declined 3 percent, partly because a heat wave in Europe discouraged do-it-yourself projects.

title: For a Moment, Steinbrenner Talks of Retiring
description: Roger Clemens seems certain to retire after this season, but what about George Steinbrenner? Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, said yesterday that he was inclined to bow out if the Yankees won another World Series this year, but a short while later he reversed himself and insisted that he definitely would not head for the exit. Honestly, can anyone conceive of the Boss spending his days watching ''Dr. Phil,'' then heading to the early-bird dinner at Applebee's?

title: Genetic Basis To Fairness, Study Hints
description: ''It's not fair!'' is a common call from the playground and, in subtler form, from more adult assemblies. It now seems that monkeys, too, have a sense of fairness, a conclusion suggesting that this feeling may be part of the genetically programmed social glue that holds primate societies together, monkeys as well as humans.

title: U.S. Inquiry On Towers Looks Closer At Response
description: Two years after the World Trade Center attack, federal investigators are intensifying their focus on the initial response by the city's rescue workers as part of their broad examination of how to make tall buildings safer.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Sentence Doubled
description: A former mathematics teacher turned prison warden during the Bosnian war looked aghast as judges at the international war crimes tribunal not only rejected his appeal, but also doubled his sentence to 15 years. The defendant, Milorad Krnojelac, 63, ran a notorious Serb prison, KP Dom, in the town of Foca in 1992 and 1993, where 1,000 non-Serb men were detained without charges, and were abused, starved and in some cases killed. Both the prosecution and the defense had appealed the earlier sentence. The five appeals judges ruled that Mr. Krnojelac merited a punishment that was more severe. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Investing Unit Formed
description: The British money manager Gartmore Investment Management plans to start a private equity unit to increase investments in closely held companies. The new business puts Gartmore in a higher- margin part of the asset management industry, said Peter Gale, who will run the division. Gartmore, which has about 45 billion ($72 billion) of assets, hired Nick Shaw in London from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group's pension unit to work with Mr. Gale.

title: INSURER PLANS TO RAISE $230 MILLION IN OFFERING
description: The United National Group, a property and casualty insurer that was acquired Friday by the equity firm Fox Paine & Company, plans to raise as much as $230 million in an initial offering, according to a regulatory filing. United National, based in the Cayman Islands, said it planned to use the proceeds to redeem all preferred shares held by Fox Paine, which paid $240 million to acquire an 82 percent stake. United National is now run by Fox Paine executives, including the chief executive, Saul A. Fox; the president, Troy W. Thacker, and the chief financial officer, Kevin L. Tate. United National said Fox Paine would maintain control of the board after the offering. The company hired Merrill Lynch & Company, along with Bank of America Corporation and Dowling & Partners, to underwrite the sale.

title: Irish Are Told, By Giuliani, To Let Smokers Stay Indoors
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said in an interview on Irish radio today that the government here might be going too far in its proposal to ban smoking in bars and restaurants.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Drug Sales Approved
description: Ranbaxy Laboratories and Dr. Reddy's Laboratories received the approval of the Food and Drug Administration to sell their versions of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's antidepressant Serzone in the United States. The two Indian drug makers got approval to sell 50-, 100-, 150-, 200- and 250-milligram tablets of nefazodone hydrochloride, the main ingredient in Serzone, the companies said. Serzone has annual sales of about $261 million in the United States

title: Ex-Mayor of Toulouse, France, Is Clear in Murder Inquiry
description: PARIS, Sept. 18  A French prosecutor has cleared the former mayor of Toulouse, Dominique Baudis, of any involvement in an alleged sadomasochistic ring that purportedly led to the murder of at least one prostitute, bringing to a close a sordid and thinly sourced tale that titillated the nation for much of the past six months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHILLING, SARAH WEINER
description: SCHILLING--Sarah Weiner. Of Park Ridge, NJ. On September 17, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Devoted mother of Joel and David Schilling and the late Deborah Dornbusch. Dear sister of the late Dorothy Goldberg and Edith Davidofsky. Loving grandmother of Amy, Scott, Jaime and Stephanie. Service Thursday, 11:30 AM Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, on Thursday 11:30. Contributions may be made to Hadassah Pascak Valley Chapter.

title: Militant Gets Life Term for Bali Bombing
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 18  An Indonesian court sentenced an Islamic militant to life imprisonment today for his role in the Bali bombings that killed 202 people last year, many of them foreign tourists.

title: Congress Advances $29.4 Billion Plan For Security Agency
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on the first spending bill for the Department of Homeland Security, approving $29.4 billion but stripping out a plan to require screening of air cargo carried aboard passenger jets.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Interest Rate Cut
description: Norway's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point to a 48-year low and indicated that it was done with reductions as the economy shows signs of a recovery and inflation picks up. Norges Bank lowered the deposit rate to 2.5 percent from 3 percent, the seventh cut since December as inflation fell below its target for the 13th month. ''There are signs that the easing of monetary policy is beginning to have an impact,'' Svein Gjedrem, the Norges Bank governor, said. ''Households are now more optimistic about the economic outlook.''

title: Donald Dahlsten, 69, Biologist Whose Insects Fought Pests
description: Dr. Donald L. Dahlsten, an insect biologist who fought California's pest problems with predatory insects as an alternative to chemical pesticides, died on Sept. 3 at a hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 69.

title: INSIDE
description: Calvin Klein's Successor Signals a New Day

title: The Mets Do Their Part To Help a Contender
description: The Cubs had a day game at Wrigley Field against the hapless Mets this afternoon and the North Side was flooding into Wrigley Field, ready to watch one of its best pitchers overwhelm the opposition.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: House Backs Tax Ban
description: The House of Representatives passed legislation yesterday that would permanently extend a ban on taxing Internet connections. The bill, which was approved with bipartisan support, covers all means of Internet access, including dial-up connections; D.S.L., or digital subscriber lines; and cable modem connections. Congress passed the original ban in 1998 to prevent states and local governments from imposing taxes that some thought might stunt the growth of the World Wide Web. Governors and state officials have asserted that millions of dollars are lost in taxes every year because of the ban, which is set to expire on Nov. 1. Representative Christopher Cox, the California Republican who was the lead sponsor of the bill, said it would help make Internet access more affordable. The Senate Commerce Committee approved a similar bill in July; the full chamber is expected to take up the matter before November. Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans and Treasury Secretary John W. Snow praised the passage of the legislation, which does not affect sales taxes on goods bought over the Internet. John Files (NYT)

title: AXA MAKES $1.5 BILLION BID FOR MONY GROUP
description: AXA, Europe's second-biggest insurer, agreed yesterday to buy Mony Group Inc. for about $1.5 billion in cash, or $31 a share, to expand in the United States. The offer, made by AXA Financial Inc., a unit of the Paris-based AXA, represents a 5.7 percent premium over Mony's closing price yesterday. The agreement was announced after the close of market trading. AXA, which already sells insurance and annuities in the United States and owns fund manager Alliance Capital Management, will become the fourth-largest seller of variable annuities in the United States and the biggest provider of variable life insurance, based on new sales, the company said.

title: Senate Makes a Curb on Abortion Likely
description: The first federal law that would restrict a woman's right to abortion moved a step closer to President Bush's signature today when the Senate, which had refused to send the bill to conference with the House, agreed unanimously to do so.

title: Czerkawski Thrilled To Be Back With Isles
description: The twinkle falls from Mariusz Czerkawski's eyes as he begins to talk about last season, the worst of his hockey career. His voice plummets to a whisper. He gazes downward, as if eye contact would rub raw the wounds to his ego.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Moses On The Move
description: Chief Justice Roy Moore, suspended for ignoring a federal judge's order to remove a Ten Commandments monument from the State Supreme Court building, has offered the monument to Congress. Jessica Atteberry, a spokeswoman for Justice Moore, said that he was sending the offer to the Congressional leadership and that the office of Representative Tom DeLay was researching who had the authority to decide whether to accept it. Justice Moore turned down offers from Gov. Ronnie Musgrove of Mississippi and others to display the granite block. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: A Design Rethought, With Judgment Deferred
description: Yesterday, in a presentation lasting less than an hour, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation unveiled Daniel Libeskind's ''Refined World Trade Center Site Master Plan.'' The design will delight those who have been pressuring public officials to go full speed ahead toward the completion of a master plan. These people may ultimately get the architecture they deserve. The plan looks like a rush job.

title: At 95, a Hit-and-Run, and an End to a Fiercely Independent Life
description: Even at age 95, Bobbie Sobel never let anyone tell her what to do, her family and friends said. She still rode the subway. She still lived alone. And she still insisted on shuffling along the streets of Brighton Beach every day, pushing her shopping wagon in front of her and picking up the things she needed.

title: Clark Makes It 10, Roiling Democratic Race
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark's entrance into the presidential race today has forced all the Democratic presidential candidates to rethink how they were approaching what was already a complicated and unwieldy primary contest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, HOWARD
description: KATZ--Howard. The Board of Trustees, Administration, Associate Board and League of Parker Jewish Institute deeply mourn the passing of Howard Katz, beloved father of our dear friend and Trustee, Alan B. Katz. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Howard's wife, Gilda; to his children, Alan, Stuart and Jonathan; to his grandchildren; and to his entire family. May your time of grief be eased by the warm love you shared and fond memories you hold. Jerry Landsberg, Chairman, Board of Trustees Michael N. Rosenblut, Acting CEO

title: From an Earlier Era, Designer-Name Decorative Tiles
description: This weekend, David Rago Auctions in Lambertville, N.J., will auction Arts and Crafts pieces, including 178 lots of tiles. A group of three Villeroy & Boch tiles, one plain and two with fish, like the one above left, are expected to sell for $375 to $500. A pair of Ernst Teichert tiles (one is above right) for Meissen should go for $200 to $300. ''Art pottery prices are up 20 to 25 percent,'' Mr. Rago said. The auctions, which also include pottery by George E. Ohr, are on Saturday and Sunday at noon at 333 North Main Street; admission is free. Information: (609) 397-9374.

title: U.A.W. Reaches Tentative Pact With Last of Big 3 Automakers
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18  The United Automobile Workers reached tentative agreements this morning with General Motors and Delphi, wrapping up labor contracts in the American automobile industry with unprecedented speed.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the movie actor Charles Bronson on Sept. 2 and in some late editions on Sept. 1 misstated his military record. Mr. Bronson had indeed been an aircraft gunner during World War II, as his publicity materials said. (His initial assignment, in Kingman, Ariz., involved maintenance and operations of the base messes.) He was a member of the 760th Flexible Gunnery Training Squadron, not the 760th Mess Squadron. In 1945 Mr. Bronson was attached to a B-29 squadron of the 39th Bombardment Group, based in Guam, which conducted combat missions against the Japanese home islands.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Give Pension Relief To Companies
description: The Senate Finance Committee voted yesterday to give companies a break on their pension requirements, which would save them about $60 billion over the next three years, according to a new government analysis.

title: As Hurricane Approaches, Many in North Carolina Dig In
description: Hurricane Isabel began jabbing the North Carolina coast today, emptying out low-lying areas up to 40 miles inland in expectation of the approaching storm's torrential rains, fierce winds and tidal flooding.

title: Times Co. Says Profit Will Not Meet Estimates
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that because of weaker-than-expected advertising demand, its earnings for the third quarter will probably be lower than analysts have forecast.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about surfers in New York City who were taking advantage of the waves preceding Hurricane Isabel misstated the name of the South African bay where one surfer, Jianca Lazarus, learned the sport as a child. It is Jeffreys Bay, not Johannesburg Bay.

title: KFC Dismisses BBDO Worldwide
description: Significant advertising and marketing changes are continuing at KFC as it dismissed its creative agency of three years, BBDO Worldwide in New York, and shifted the assignment to the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding. Billings were estimated at $200 million to $225 million.

title: Article 2003091800000333476 -- No Title
description: ''ESSENTIALLY unchanged'' -- that is how Kathleen Utgoff, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, described the unemployment rate in August compared with July. The secretary of labor, Elaine Chao, however, hailed the news, saying, ''I'm pleased that the unemployment rate has dropped.''

title: Their Whale Meat, And Our Piety
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Protesters Arrested
description: The police arrested 100 people protesting the government's closing of the only independent daily newspaper last week. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: Iraqi Artifact Is Recovered
description: Officials at the Iraqi National Museum, which was badly looted in the days after Saddam Hussein fell from power, announced the return of one of its most precious artifacts.

title: Recent Plays
description: Immigrants' Losses and Anger in Linked Coming-of-Age Tales

title: A DVD Recorder to Settle Those Thursday Night Fights
description: As DVD recorders continue to muscle in on turf long held by analog videocassette recorders, Panasonic is promoting a new model that offers several ways to snag, store, transport and play back your favorite television shows, home videos or photos. Within its slick silvery shell, the Panasonic DMR-E100H holds a 120-gigabyte hard drive next to its DVD recorder. There are also slots for PCMCIA and Secure Digital memory cards and a connection for a camcorder's FireWire cable.

title: Disputes Erupt Over Service For Poor Internet Typists
description: Less than 48 hours after the company that controls the most popular Internet names started a site to make money from millions of misspelled or mistyped Web addresses, it found itself under siege from critics who said it was taking unfair advantage of its privileged position.

title: Neighbors Think Outside the Block
description: ON a sunny morning last week, Judith Stonehill stood along the Hudson River, gazing ruefully across West Street at two glass towers designed by Richard Meier. ''They are striking. They are even elegant,'' she said of the condominium towers, which stand one block outside the Greenwich Village Historic District. Ms. Stonehill let out a heavy sigh. ''They look as if they are from another planet.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: An Award for Stephen King? Horrors!
description: To the Editor:

title: Cte Basque, a Society Temple, Is Closing
description: La Cte Basque, the high-society temple of classic French cuisine that became the setting of a catty and thinly veiled excerpt from an unfinished novel by Truman Capote, plans to shut down early next year and reopen as a more casual belle poque brasserie with lighter and less expensive fare and a different name.

title: Retooling the Hero Without Forgetting What Works
description: TOMB RAIDER: ANGEL OF DARKNESS

title: A French Education At the Hardware Cafe
description: SEPTEMBER is the beginning of the new year in France, a time to recover from four weeks of vacation by plunging into home repairs. For many this means a descent into the souk-like basement of the BHV department store, where the hardware emporium addresses every problem of This Old French Apartment, from leaky pipes -- an obsession among Parisians -- to wine-cellar security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOPE, DOROTHEA STATER
description: HOPE--Dorothea Stater. Age 89. On Sunday, September 14, 2003 in South Nyack, NY. Widow of William Hope, she is survived by her children, Suzanne Hope Graham of South Nyack, Thomas Hope of South Gouldsboro, ME., Margaret Hope of Mechanicsburg, PA., four grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and her sister, Phroso Stater of Cliffside Park, NJ. Graduated from Wellesley, 1935 and received her Sc.D from Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, 1939. Memorial service at Grace Episcopal Church, 130 First Ave., Nyack, NY. on Saturday, September 20th at 11 AM.

title: Their Whale Meat, And Our Piety
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Reappearing in Court, Sides in Recall Ruling Press Their Cases Regarding Appeal
description: Having achieved a stunning victory on Monday, the lawyers for the coalition of minorities that persuaded a federal appeals court to delay the California recall election told the full court yesterday that it should let that decision stand because the decision was narrow, unexceptional and ''a model of caution.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPPAGELIS, JOHN
description: PAPPAGELIS -- John of Mountainside, NJ. Husband of the late Mary Mechalakos Pappagelis. Father of George. Grandfather of Gregory John and Alexandra Jean. Brother of Anna J. Minas and Antigone J. Monaster. Funeral from Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Ave, Westfield, NJ Friday, September 19 at 9AM. Service 10AM at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church. Interment Fairview Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: A New Yorker Feast, From Books to Bjork
description: Every weekend true believers of one sort or another come together somewhere in America to celebrate an idiosyncrasy they hold in common: there are Trekkie conventions (still), conclaves for people who treasure Hummels, and festivals for banjo music. This weekend The New Yorker magazine will be the host of an event celebrating yet another charming obsession: reading.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Reverses Loss
description: The Irish drug maker Elan Corporation, which is making changes to address concerns about its past accounting practices, reported a second-quarter net profit of $17.3 million, in contrast to a net loss of $719.7 million in the period last year. Revenue fell 46 percent, to $245.5 million from $451.6 million, as the company shed noncore products and terminated 37 of its 55 joint ventures. But it said that earnings from retained products increased 7 percent, to $148.4 million. Elan faced bankruptcy this summer when it failed to file its annual report on time with the Securities and Exchange Commission, potentially starting a run on its $2.3 billion total debt, but it now has $973 million in cash to cover obligations of $634.5 million due this year, it said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: After Allegations of Abuse, A Football Season Is Canceled
description: The Bellmore-Merrick Board of Education voted unanimously tonight to cancel this year's football season at a Long Island high school that had been reeling from allegations that three older football players sexually abused freshman teammates.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the architecture of Asmara, the capital of Eritrea in Africa, misspelled the given name of a former member of Parliament who regretted the preservation of a building that had been used as a prison when the country was ruled by the Italians. He is Mesghenna Almedom, not Mesghina.

title: Quickly Download a Movie, Then Watch at Your Leisure
description: Movielink, the online movie rental service, is pinning its fortunes on immediate gratification.

title: Ashcroft Relents on Data
description: Under pressure from lawmakers and civil rights groups over the Justice Department's antiterrorism initiatives, Attorney General John Ashcroft reversed course today and agreed to declassify data showing how often federal agents had demanded records from libraries and other institutions.

title: An Eames Sofa In a Multicolored Skin
description: The Sofa Compact by Charles and Ray Eames dates to 1954. Nearly 20 years later, Alexander Girard created Millerstripe, a fabric with bright red, yellow, green, pink and blue stripes, for the Herman Miller furniture company in Zeeland, Mich. It now seems made for the sofa, but it was not until this year that Design Within Reach, and Herman Miller collaborated on the combination, above. Ray Kennedy, director of Herman Miller for the Home, said that in the 1970's, the fabric was used only on tack boards and as a panel to divide work stations. Millerstripe, a wool and nylon blend, is now made by Maharam, a textile company in Manhattan. Design Within Reach (www.dwr.com) sells the 72-inch-long sofa, on a chrome steel frame, in the Millerstripe fabric for $3,450.

title: Counterterror Aid Is Tied Up by the States, Mayors Assert
description: Mayors from some of the nation's largest cities declared today that the safety of their people was being endangered because cities had not received their share of the billions of dollars in federal counterterrorism aid promised by Washington after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: A Chink in the Armor
description: Two years after 9/11 and one year before the presidential election, concern about terrorism continues to dominate American politics. For President Bush no less than his Democratic challengers, it is an unpredictable issue.

title: The Prices Tumble Down At a Warehouse Sale
description: A warehouse sale of traditional furniture and textiles by Brunschwig & Fils begins tomorrow morning at 9 a.m. and continues through Sunday. More than 1,000 pieces of furniture will be offered, including the Steamer Chairs above, which were $3,500 each, and are now $1,500. Sofas that were $7,000 are $2,600.

title: Eyes on Sky, Yanks Rush Through A Defeat
description: The Yankees played as if they had a flight to catch tonight, and they only wish that were true. After sprinting through a 5-3 loss to the Baltimore Orioles in 2 hours 12 minutes, the Yankees wondered openly about the wisdom of playing on Thursday with Hurricane Isabel bearing down on this city.

title: House Approves Increase In Insurance for Museums
description: In response to pressure from museums across the country grappling with the rising cost of insuring artwork since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the House of Representatives voted on Tuesday evening to raise the federal backing available to American museums through the Arts and Artifacts Indemnity Program to $8 billion from $5 billion.

title: Most New Jersey High Schools Could Get U.S. Warning Letter
description: About two-thirds of New Jersey's public high schools could receive early warning letters in the next few weeks saying they are in danger of failing to comply with stricter federal educational standards, state education officials said yesterday.

title: Ex-Mayor of Toulouse, France, Is Clear in Murder Inquiry
description: PARIS, Sept. 18  A French prosecutor has cleared the former mayor of Toulouse, Dominique Baudis, of any involvement in an alleged sadomasochistic ring that purportedly led to the murder of at least one prostitute, bringing to a close a sordid and thinly sourced tale that titillated the nation for much of the past six months.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK ONE CORP., Chicago, said it had agreed to buy some real estate operations from a unit of General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn. Terms were not disclosed.

title: R.J. Reynolds to Quit Marketing 2 Cigarette Brands
description: Smokers will still find Winston and Doral cigarettes on store shelves across the country. They just won't be seeing them much anywhere else.

title: Colleges Caught In a Vise
description: When a parent calls to complain about overcrowded classrooms or a reduction in courses and thinks to cinch the case by saying, ''After all, I'm a taxpayer and I pay your salary,'' I respond by asking a question: what percentage of the university's operating costs do you guess are covered by public funds? Almost always, the answer is something on the order of 75 percent. When I say, no, the figure is just 25 percent and heading downward -- and add that in some states the figure has dipped below 10 percent -- the reaction is usually equal parts surprise and dismay.

title: A Long Shot In 'Chicago' Pays Off; For Melanie Griffith, Last Laugh Is Sweet
description: Why would you do it? You already have fame and presumably fortune. Your marriage to Antonio Banderas alone gets you more attention than you probably want. It is hard enough preserving your professional reputation when your latest work includes providing the voice of a bird in ''Stuart Little 2,'' and the tabloids seem most interested in your bouts with rehab and plastic surgery. Why step into a lead role in a Broadway musical when you can't sing or dance, have never performed on a professional stage and could very well fall flat on your face?

title: Sun Will Trim 1,000 Jobs
description: Sun Microsystems, which has had nine consecutive quarters of falling sales, said yesterday that it would eliminate as many as 1,080 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, to concentrate on products and services that are doing well.

title: French Aide Warns Militant Mosques and Radical Muslims
description: PARIS, Sept. 18  France's law-and-order interior minister threatened today to close any mosque in France that is considered extremist and expel any Muslim prayer leader who preaches a radical message.

title: Saturn to End Sponsorship Deal
description: While Lance Armstrong of the United States Postal Service team has dominated international cycling by winning the last five Tours de France, the Saturn team has quietly dominated the sport at home. Today, after its most successful racing year ever, the Saturn Corporation will announce that it is ending its 12-year sponsorship of its men's and women's teams.

title: DISSIDENT SHAREHOLDERS OPPOSE CONE MILLS BUYOUT
description: A Cone Mills Corporation shareholders' committee, led by Marc Kozberg, a dissident director, said yesterday that it would oppose a buyout offer for the company from the financier Wilbur Ross. The committee urged shareholders to elect its three director nominees in a proxy vote next week. Mr. Ross offered on Tuesday to buy the assets of Cone Mills through a bankruptcy reorganization, which Cone Mills plans to file soon. Cone Mills, a denim maker based in Greensboro, N.C., said Tuesday that shareholders were not expected to receive anything under the Ross plan because the proceeds would not be enough to satisfy secured creditors. The group said Cone Mills's management and Ross's company, W.L. Ross & Company, are consolidating the denim industry at the expense of shareholders.

title: A Toolbox for Improving Your PC's Performance
description: Tips for keeping your computer running smoothly.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: SENTENCE DOUBLED A former mathematics teacher turned prison warden during the Bosnian war looked aghast as judges at the international war crimes tribunal not only rejected his appeal, but also doubled his sentence to 15 years. The defendant, Milorad Krnojelac, 63, ran a notorious Serb prison, KP Dom, in the town of Foca in 1992 and 1993, where 1,000 non-Serb men were detained without charges, and were abused, starved and in some cases killed. Both the prosecution and the defense had appealed the earlier sentence. The five appeals judges ruled that Mr. Krnojelac merited a punishment that was more severe.    Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: SUNY Enrollment Sets Record
description: Enrollment at the State University of New York this fall has reached 409,348, a record for SUNY, its chancellor, Robert L. King, said on Tuesday. The figure, based on a preliminary count, was 1.6 percent higher than last year's and was the sixth consecutive increase.

title: A Complaint Box Turns Frustration Into Fun
description: WHILE staying at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco this spring, Mark Hurst was annoyed when he learned that it charged guests $2 to make a toll-free call and $1.50 for a local call. As an Internet consultant who specializes in improving the ''customer experience'' of corporate and commercial Web sites, he found the charges akin to getting a dead fish on his pillow. When he vented his annoyance in a weekly e-mail newsletter he publishes that deals with a range of consumer experiences, he struck a chord with readers.

title: How Much Is That View In the Window?
description: A VIEW of Central Park was the centerpiece of each of 160 fund-raising parties given on Monday night to celebrate the park's 150th birthday. Park views are reason for celebration the rest of the time as well, since prominent real estate brokers unanimously declare Central Park the most valuable view in the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a split in the California Republican Party over whom to endorse in the recall election misstated the time elapsed since Republicans last held the governor's office. That occurred in 1999, not a decade ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERMAN, DR. BERNARD
description: LERMAN--Dr. Bernard. Manhattan School of Music notes with sadness the passing of Bernard Lerman, brother of our dear friend and Vice Chairman of the School's Board of Trustees, Bella Linden. Music was an important component of his life and a passion he shared with his beloved sister. We extend our most sincere and heartfelt sympathies to Bella and the entire Lerman family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: First Aid; For a Creaky Mac, Tricks to Jog the Memory
description: LIKE Windows-based PC's, Macintosh computers -- at least those using the OS 9 operating system or earlier versions -- can be afflicted by memory malaise. Antidotes for the Mac can be tricky, though, depending on which operating system is involved.

title: BBC Journalist Admits Errors in a Report on Iraq Intelligence
description: The BBC correspondent at the heart of a battle between the state broadcaster and the government conceded errors today in the report of his that touched off the firestorm, and he apologized for having tried to influence parliamentary questioning of his source.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Points column on Sunday about the reputation of Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio for candor as he seeks the Democratic presidential nomination misstated the party affiliation of Edward Fitzpatrick Herman, who is running for Mr. Kucinich's House seat. He is a Republican.

title: A Toolbox for Improving Your PC's Performance
description: Tips for keeping your computer running smoothly.

title: I.R.S. Asks Judge to Order Firm To Name Buyers of Tax Shelters
description: In a new skirmish over tax shelters, the Internal Revenue Service asked a federal judge yesterday to require Grant Thornton, the fifth-largest American accounting firm, to turn over the names of people and companies that bought what the government suspects were abusive tax shelters.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Phone Maker's Shares Surge
description: Shares in Curitel Communications, one of two allied companies that form South Korea's third-biggest cellphone maker, surged 86 percent on their first day of trading on investor expectations that it would catch up with larger brands. The shares rose to 4,830 won ($4.12) from their offer price of 2,600. Curitel, whose first-half sales more than doubled from a year ago, raised 109.2 billion won ($93 million) this month in a first-time sale that attracted orders for 188 times the stock available. Investors are betting that products like Curitel's S2 camera phone will help it follow the lead of bigger Korean rivals, the Samsung Electronics Company and LG Electronics.

title: For the Kitchen, Top-Drawer Touches
description: REPORTS that I moved to California for the sole purpose of avoiding a visit to my friend Lisa's newly renovated kitchen are untrue.

title: At a College Campus, Lowering the Roar, in Koolhaas Style
description: There are powers of concentration. Then there is the challenge of studying at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago. An elevated train roars through the campus, dividing academic buildings on the west from student housing on the east. ''People stopped talking every 20 minutes when the train went by,'' Donna Robertson, dean of the institute's College of Architecture, said. When Rem Koolhaas's Office for Metropolitan Architecture won a competition to design a campus center, Mr. Koolhaas threaded the train through a stainless steel and concrete tube, left, to reduce the noise. Outdoors, decibels dropped from 120 (between loud rock music and a pneumatic drill) to under 80 decibels. Inside the building, the noise is now below 70 decibels, or about the level of a noisy restaurant. The acoustic tube is open at the top, sending the sound upward. ''We linked the two sides of the campus,'' said Jeffrey Johnson, the project architect. The tube, Mr. Koolhaas's first completed structure in this country, cost $13.6 million. His 110,000-square-foot McCormick Tribune Campus Center, which opens on Oct. 4, cost $34.6 million. The center is at 3201 South State Street.

title: U.N. Says U.S. Eradication of Coca in Colombia Is Working
description: The United Nations said today that American-financed aerial eradication of Colombia's vast coca fields is starting to pay big dividends and released estimates that show the size of the crop dropping by 32 percent in the first seven months of the year.

title: Jets Face Patriots' Resurgent Defense
description: As Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb gazed aimlessly toward the heavens last Sunday evening, the bewildered look on his face told the story of the Patriots' re-energized defense.

title: A Light Show Beyond Lasers
description: FOR decades, planetariums and science centers have mixed their offerings of instructive starscapes and educational films with more fanciful fare: laser shows customarily set to thunderous rock music. But in these times of computer-generated special effects and home entertainment centers with theater-quality sound systems, even lasers may be starting to show their age.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MIXED NEWS ON INFANT MORTALITY Infant mortality in New York City dropped to a record low last year, but remained high in some poor neighborhoods, the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday. Of every 1,000 babies born in the city, 6 died before their first birthdays in 2002, compared with 6.1 in 2001, the previous record. The national rate was 6.9 per 1,000 in 2000, the most recent figure available. Rates in the poor, black and Hispanic communities are sometimes double that of the city as a whole. Last year, the highest rates were in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, at 13.9 per 1,000; Brownsville, Brooklyn, at 10.9; and Westchester in the Bronx, at 9.6. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GANS, HAROLD DAVID
description: GANS--Harold David. Beloved and adored husband of Jeanne for 61 years. Cherished father of Ellen (Bruce) Aldewereld and Barbara (Nat) Russo. Devoted grandfather of Lisa (Thomas) Krommenhoek and Melissa (Andrew) Moss. Dear brother of Felicia Price and the late May Miller. Passed away peacefully at home in his 94th year on Wednesday, September 17, 2003.

description: Unable to decide quickly on an interim replacement to Richard A. Grasso, the New York Stock Exchange's ousted chairman and chief executive, the exchange's directors squabbled today over possible successors and even the eventual composition of the board, reflecting a sense of disarray.

description: Richard A. Grasso is gone. But the changes at the New York Stock Exchange are only beginning.

description: A commercial for PBS by Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, has been awarded the annual Emmy for best spot by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: Alert Bay Journal; Reclaiming the Stolen Faces of Their Forefathers
description: A local newspaper column last year suggested that the Namgis, a small band of Native Canadians in British Columbia, ought to go to London and steal the Crown Jewels to get some bargaining leverage over the British Museum.

title: $1,000 Prk Vu, Dinner and Wine Included
description: ''THE dog just ate my shoe,'' Eleanore Kennedy told John Loring, the patrician design director of Tiffany & Company, as he arrived at her 23rd floor apartment at Hampshire House, on Central Park South, on Monday afternoon. He had come to put finishing touches on decorations for the dinner party she was giving that night for nine guests, including Sigourney Weaver and Bianca Jagger.

title: Our War With France
description: It's time we Americans came to terms with something: France is not just our annoying ally. It is not just our jealous rival. France is becoming our enemy.

title: After Deals With 2 of Big Three, Auto Union Still Talking to G.M.
description: The United Automobile Workers continued contract negotiations today with General Motors and Delphi, the parts giant spun off from G.M. in 1999.

title: Dutch Grocer Tries to Calm Furor Over Pay
description: Hoping to quell a national outcry over corporate compensation here that has spread to its own supermarkets, the Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said today that its chairman would resign and that it would overhaul its chief executive's multimillion-dollar pay package.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bottled Water Recalled
description: More than three million bottles of water are being recalled because the caps come off unexpectedly, posing a choking hazard to children, federal officials said. The manufacturer, CCDA Waters, a joint venture of Coca-Cola, Groupe Danone and Danone Holdings, announced the recall with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The company, based in Atlanta, said it had no reports of injuries. The water was sold under the brands Dannon Fluoride to Go, Pure American, Enon Springs, Alhambra Junior Sport Drinking Water and Sparkletts Junior Sport Drinking Water beginning in March 2002. Consumers can return the bottles for a refund, or call (800) 322-4616.

title: Bus Carrying the Handicapped Overturns in Crash
description: At least one person was seriously injured and 19 others were taken to area hospitals after a car and a bus full of handicapped people collided yesterday afternoon on Route 22 in Branchburg, N.J., the authorities said. The heavily traveled highway was closed for four hours.

title: FEDEX REPORTS 19% DROP IN FIRST QUARTER INCOME
description: The FedEx Corporation said yesterday that net income in its first quarter fell 19 percent because of costs linked to an early retirement program. Net income dropped to $128 million, or 42 cents a share, from $158 million, or 52 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter, which ended Aug. 31, rose 4.4 percent, to $5.69 billion. Excluding costs of $82 million, or 27 cents a share, for the retirement program and a benefit of $26 million, or 8 cents a share, from a favorable tax ruling, profit was $184 million, or 61 cents a share. On that basis, the company exceeded analysts' expectations of 57 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call.

title: Concourse Gets Used To Commerce; Street's Historic Character Clashes With Modernity
description: For the Depression-weary strivers who moved there in the 1940's and 50's, the Grand Concourse was the Champs-lyses of the Bronx, a broad boulevard of stylishly sedate Art Deco apartment buildings that filled their craving for modest touches of class like sunken living rooms.

title: Ex-Leader Stole $100 Million From Liberia, Records Show
description: Charles Taylor, for six years the warlord president of Liberia, stole or diverted nearly $100 million of his country's wealth, leaving it the poorest nation on earth, according to a close review of government records, an investigation by United Nations experts and interviews with senior Liberian officials.

title: New York Seeks Vast Changes In Its Purchasing Procedures
description: Trying to make it easier for more companies and agencies to bid on city business, New York City is embarking on a sweeping revision of how it buys $8 billion in goods and services each year.

title: Review/Fashion; Calvin Klein's Successor Loosens the Corset Laces
description: It's pretentious to think that designers can't be replaced once they decide to bow out. After all, Tom Ford would not be the millionaire star that he is if he had stuck to Gucci loafers, and certainly Karl Lagerfeld hasn't spent 20 years pinning camellias on Coco Chanel's portrait. On Tuesday, as Calvin Klein, who this year sold his company to Phillips-Van Heusen, watched from the wings, 32-year-old Francisco Costa took over the designs of the house, and it was definitely a new day.

description: BREENBERG--Minnie. Age 102, known as ''Mom'' and ''Grandma'' at UCP Queens and Hadassah of Great Neck, died September 17, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Morris Breenberg, mother of Bernice and Jerry Rosenthal and the late Zelda and William Grossberg. Grandmother of Elaine and Ken Sonenberg, Randy and Cindy Heller, Margie and Seth Rosenthal-Hanft and the late Barry Douglas, great-grandmother of Zoe, David, Marissa, Tyler and Noah. Services Thursday, at 11 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

Time Warner's management figures that if Russia could do it after an unpleasant seven-decade-long experiment, it can do so after a mere three-year ordeal. Just go back to the old name and pretend it was all a bad dream.

State Senator Tom McClintock, the conservative nipping at the right of Arnold Schwarzenegger, could be running for both governor and a State Senate seat, and Mr. Schwarzenegger's unwieldy campaign could be broke.

description: Let's be honest: it doesn't sound like an appealing combination. Evanescence, from Arkansas, has become one of the country's most popular bands by mixing nu-metal guitar riffs with high, airy vocals, adding lyrics that turn love and religion into a series of pop-psychology analogies. People get lost and found, drowned and saved, held captive and set free; a smart TV producer could turn the band's major-label debut, ''Fallen'' (Wind-Up/BMG), into a grueling reality series.

title: McCartney Finds Fans 'Back in the U.S.S.R.'
description: When Paul McCartney went to Russia in May for his first concert there in a four-decade career, he already knew that the Beatles had had an underground following in the Soviet Union during the dark days of repression in the 1960's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELLOS, HELEN SECUNDA
description: MELLOS -- Helen Secunda. Mother of Evan Mellos and Sophia Mellos; wife of John Mellos, was called home to the Lord on September 12, 2003. A graduate of St. Francis Medical Center School of Nursing and University of Pittsburgh, Helen practiced and taught nursing and served in the U.S. Air Force. Helen taught elementary school and worked as realtor in New Jersey for 15 years. Donations to St. Mary's Byzantine Catholic Church, Hillsborough, New Jersey, may be made in lieu of flowers. Memorial liturgy will be held on September 20th at 10 AM.

title: Court Upholds City Bond Plan, But Sides Differ On Sale Timing
description: A state judge ruled today that New York City's plan to sell bonds to refinance its 1970's debt is constitutional, giving the Bloomberg administration a victory in its ongoing battle over the issue with the state.

title: What Views Cost Across the U.S.
description: In Manhattan, a view of Central Park like the one at left comes at a premium. A two-bedroom 1,500-square-foot apartment at Fifth Avenue and 68th Street is $2.4 million. Without a view, it would be $1.5 million. What does a comparable view cost elsewhere? In San Francisco, said Patrick Barber, of Sotheby's International Realty there, an apartment in Pacific Heights with a view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the bay is worth $1.3 to $1.5 million; $800,000 without a view. In Santa Monica, an apartment facing the ocean costs $1 million. One facing the mountains, said Helmut Lerpscher, of Coldwell Banker, is $700,000 to $800,000. Buyers pay $200,000 more to be in the Turtle Creek-Uptown neighborhood of Dallas with a view of downtown, on Lake Shore Drive in Chicago facing Lake Michigan and on the oceanfront in Miami Beach. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Sexually Abused In Park
description: The police are looking for a man who sexually abused an 11-year-old boy in Prospect Park yesterday morning. Around 9 a.m., four boys, ages 11 and 12, were at the park's Empire Boulevard entrance when they were approached by a man in his 30's who touched one of them improperly, the police said. The boys ran away from the man, and he left the park, the police said. There were no arrests as of last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Rebels Deny Holding Tourists
description: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest leftist rebel group, denied that their fighters had kidnapped eight foreign hikers on a scenic coastal mountain range in northern Colombia. As hundreds of soldiers swarmed over the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta searching for the tourists, the rebels issued a statement on their Web site blaming military intelligence for the kidnapping. Government officials dismissed the claim. But the region is also home to two other insurgent groups. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: MOSES ON THE MOVE Chief Justice Roy Moore, suspended for ignoring a federal judge's order to remove a Ten Commandments monument from the State Supreme Court building, has offered the monument to Congress. Jessica Atteberry, a spokeswoman for Justice Moore, said that he was sending the offer to the Congressional leadership and that the office of Representative Tom DeLay was researching who had the authority to decide whether to accept it. Justice Moore turned down offers from Gov. Ronnie Musgrove of Mississippi and others to display the granite block. Ariel Hart (NYT)

The picture showed the Alexander Dreyfoos Building, not the William H. Gates Building. The Gates building is being financed by the William H. Gates Foundation, not by Microsoft.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Imprisoned New Yorker Seeks Marriage
description: Lori Berenson, the 33-year-old New Yorker serving a 20-year term in a Peruvian jail for having aided Marxist rebels, is planning to marry a law student in his 40's, her lawyer, Jos Lus Sandoval, said by phone from the capital, Lima. He said Ms. Berenson met the law student around 1998, when she was in a prison in southern Peru. Mr. Sandoval declined to identify the man but said he and Ms. Berenson fell in love and continued to correspond after she was transferred to a prison in the northern city of Cajamarca. She wants to marry soon, Mr. Sandoval said, but Cajamarca officials may put up obstacles. She maintains that she is innocent of charges that she helped plan terrorist activities. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Getting Up, Getting Down: The Way It Came to Be
description: In 1854, when the engineer Elisha Otis demonstrated the first elevator safety brake at the Crystal Palace Exposition in New York City, the audience cheered. The history of the elevator is the subject of ''Up, Down, Across: Elevators, Escalators and Moving Sidewalks,'' an exhibition of film clips, illustrations, photographs, drawings, models and mock-ups at the National Building Museum in Washington. Abbott Miller, a partner at Pentagram Design in Manhattan, who curated the show, said that one of the earliest elevators was a ''flying chair'' mounted outside Louis XV's palace at Versailles in 1743. The Dragon Escalators, below, were built in 1997 at Long Qing Xin Gorge, northwest of Beijing, and carry passengers 236 feet to the top of a dam. The show continues through April 18. The museum is at 401 F Street N.W.; admission is free. Information: (202) 272-2448.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: About That Aspen Housing . . .
description: Mayor Helen Klanderud of Aspen is backing away from a campaign pledge of support for the largest affordable housing project ever built in Aspen. The project, approved by voters in 2000, included a plan for up to 330 units on Burlingame Ranch. The mayor said she had changed her mind because the plan had problems, including the potential to create sprawl. Critics say the project would harm the environment. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: FEWER DEATHS ON THE JOB The government's annual tally of workplace deaths showed that 5,524 American workers died on the job last year, a significant decrease from the 5,915 who died in 2001, a number that did not include those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. The decline extended a downward trend since 1997. Workplace homicides also declined, to 609 last year from a peak of 1,080 in 1994. The numbers declined even among Hispanics, who are more likely to work in riskier farm, factory and construction jobs, from 6 per 100,000 workers to 5 last year. Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao credited the government's efforts to reach Spanish-speaking workers. (AP)

description: New rules imposed on space shuttle flights after the Columbia accident will cut by more than half the times when shuttles can be launched to the International Space Station, NASA officials said today.

title: The Case for Smaller Schools
description: New York City is in the forefront of a national movement aimed at converting large, factory-style schools that often have thousands of students into smaller public schools where students have closer contact with teachers. The small-schools movement got a big boost yesterday, when the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation announced that it would provide seven nonprofit organizations across the city with $51.2 million, with the aim of creating 67 new schools along those lines.

title: Pink Is For the Seashore: A House-Paint Primer
description: It's easy to repaint the dining room, a lot harder to repaint the whole house. ''Exterior Style: Inspiring Color Ideas and Expert Painting Advice'' ($22.95, Bulfinch Press) by Benjamin Moore, the paint manufacturer in Montvale, N.J., uses a 19th-century farmhouse to show the power of paint: the door is more prominent when the trim is a contrasting color, near right and center, and more subdued when it nearly matches the trim, far right. Save bright colors for houses on the seashore, the book says, and use earth tones in natural settings or in gray urban settings.

description: CD and DVD discs are handy for storing large amounts of backed-up files, but a disc that takes a scratch or nick to the surface can become unreadable, fouling up the best-laid plans. Although such a disc may be damaged beyond repair, CD/DVD Diagnostic from Arrowkey can help recover the data and copy it back to your hard drive.

description: COLOR may get all the attention, but touch and feel can transform the character of a room, too, as this season's highly tactile fabric offerings remind us.

description: CLASSICS with a twist? Definitely. Tradition? Yes. Modern? Absolutely. When it comes to what's hot in home design this fall, familiarity breeds content, but take note: there are more than a few surprises. Don't expect safe; expect subtle, sexy, comfortable.

title: David Robbins, 61, Unraveler Of Complex Math Equations
description: Dr. David P. Robbins, a mathematician who broke codes and cryptological problems for the government and devised an algebraic formula that became widely recognized in the mathematical world, died on Sept. 4 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 61.

description: As Europe cools off from a summer heat wave that pushed its power plants to the limit, the nuclear industry is trying to seize a rare opportunity to rehabilitate its reputation and attract new investment.

description: Visa International Inc. and MasterCard International Inc. cannot bar 34,000 member banks from distributing credit cards in the United States that were issued by two rivals, the American Express Company and Morgan Stanley, a federal appeals court said yesterday.

description: A former construction official at the city's Housing Authority was sentenced yesterday for accepting bribes. A contractor provided the bribes in exchange for confidential city documents. The official, Pedro Flaquer, 55, of Blooming Grove, N.Y., pleaded guilty in May to receiving bribes of $1,400 and resigned as administrative chief engineer for the authority's design department. Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn sentenced him to six months' home confinement and three years' probation and required him to pay a $20,000 fine and $1,400 in restitution.

description: To prosecutors in Morocco, Pierre Richard Antoine Robert is the leader of a dangerous Islamist group and should be put to death for plotting terrorist acts.

title: Bush Reports No Evidence of Hussein Tie to 9/11
description: President Bush said today that he had seen no evidence that Saddam Hussein was involved in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as the White House tried to correct an assertion that Vice President Dick Cheney left extremely murky on Sunday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airwaves Sale Advances
description: Cingular Wireless's planned $1.4 billion purchase of airwaves from NextWave Telecom has moved closer to completion. Other cellphone providers had until noon on Monday to submit bids. None were made, Michael Wack, a NextWave senior vice president, said in a telephone interview. The licenses cover 83 million potential customers in 34 markets. NextWave, which is under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, would receive $666 million. The transaction is subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission and Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains; he will hold a hearing on the matter on Sept. 25. Cingular, based in Atlanta, is a joint venture of SBC Communications and the BellSouth Corporation.

title: U.S. Doubts Iraq Prisoners' Claims of Being From U.S. or Britain
description: As an Arab channel broadcast an audiotape of a man claiming to be Saddam Hussein and urging more attacks on Americans in Iraq, the United States military today played down the possibility that eight prisoners held here on suspicion of taking part in such attacks might be American or British.

description: Everywhere he turns from the United Nations and Congress to allied capitals and the warrens of Baghdad and Tikrit -- President Bush is finding major obstacles to his effort to secure and rebuild Iraq.

title: Life in the Big Bowls' Shadows
description: They had made the six-hour bus trip from their campus in Oxford, Ohio, shared a meal and then split into offensive and defensive units to watch film of the next day's opponent, Northwestern. Friday had been a long day, and the Miami RedHawks were lethargic from following their coaches' laser pointers on the projection screen and being hectored to remember ''amigo sets'' and ''squirrel patterns'' and ''cover stacks.''

(His initial assignment, in Kingman, Ariz., involved maintenance and operations of the base messes.) He was a member of the 760th Flexible Gunnery Training Squadron, not the 760th Mess Squadron. In 1945 Mr. Bronson was attached to a B-29 squadron of the 39th Bombardment Group, based in Guam, which conducted combat missions against the Japanese home islands.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Prison For Ex-Lawmaker
description: A former legislator who bribed a Chicago official for $4 million in contracts was sentenced to 27 months in prison. The former lawmaker, Roger Stanley, was also ordered to forfeit $67,000 and pay a $7,500 fine. Mr. Stanley, 60, was a state representative for six years ending in 1983; he is also a private political consultant who ran a mail-order company. He pleaded guilty to bribery in May and is cooperating with an inquiry into former Gov. George Ryan's tenure as secretary of state. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

But it's quicker to put them on mobile hard drives, which cost $500 to $600, hold 10 to 60 gigabytes (equivalent to about 20 to 120 CD-ROM's) and emulate trunk-mounted CD changers.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Inquiry Into Children's Hospital
description: Federal and state officials said they were investigating Children's Hospital in Boston after a review of four incidents involving patients revealed violations of several federal Medicare and Medicaid regulations. The review found that the hospital did not ensure that medical staff members were responsible for patient care and that nurses were supervised. In response, the hospital has developed a plan to improve internal communication. The cases included the death of a 5-year-old who suffered a seizure while undergoing electrode monitoring and a patient who had a catheter inserted into the wrong kidney. Three patients died. Katie Zezima (NYT)

They are eager to overhaul their institution, but worry whether any change can give it the freedom it needs to survive without being seen as either a lackey of the United States or an easily swattable gadfly.

title: Woody Allen As Life Coach
description: In his last movie, ''Hollywood Ending,'' Woody Allen played a film director who had gone blind. Not a bad joke, except that it seemed to represent a case of what psychoanalysts might call displacement. Mr. Allen's recent movies, after all, look just fine, full of the usual gorgeous Manhattan light (courtesy of cinematographers like Zhao Fei) and warm, well-appointed interiors (thanks to the efforts of Mr. Allen's longtime production designer, Santo Loquasto). No, the problem with ''Hollywood Ending,'' as with ''Small Time Crooks'' and especially ''The Curse of the Jade Scorpion,'' was that the screenwriter (Mr. Allen, of course) was going deaf. His ear for the idioms of New York speech had faltered gravely, and the timing and concision of his jokes seemed terminally off.

The decision came after Siegfried Ellwanger, an editor and Nazi sympathizer, published books that were deemed by a state court to be ''hostile and violent'' against Jews. He argued that the country's racism statute, used mostly to protect blacks, did not apply to Jews because they are not a race. Larry Rohter (NYT)

The sale of land leases, previously a big source of government revenue, has been weak for the last several years because of a moribund property market. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

description: THE Appalachian Trail, which winds from Georgia to Maine, is a long one (2,167 miles), and the people who emerge from it often look as if they have come from another age, the Stone Age perhaps, with their bedraggled hair, grimy faces, mosquito-ravaged legs, and beatific smiles. Time for them has been measured in footsteps and contour marks on a topographical map, not in television shows, traffic, deadlines and e-mail.

title: W. H. SMITH IS SELLING U.S. RETAIL SHOPS FOR $79 MILLION
description: W. H. Smith, a bookseller based in Britain, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its hotel and airport shops in the United States for 49 million ($79 million). The airport division is being sold to the Hudson Group for 41 million ($66 million), and the hotel retailing unit will be bought by former managers for 8 million ($13 million), W. H. Smith said. The company has closed unprofitable bookstores and newsstands in hotels and airports in the United States to reduce losses that began when demand for tourism and travel slid after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Once the businesses have been sold, the company said, it will close its United States headquarters in Atlanta.

title: A Home of Their Own
description: LIKE dining by candlelight, owning a second home is something couples do. So Anne Waxman knew she was taking an unconventional step when she bought a second home as a single woman. ''I always wanted a home in the country,'' said Ms. Waxman, 47, who lives on the West Side of Manhattan. ''I didn't do it the way that would be best for me -- with a man I'm married to -- but I did it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOGERFO, PAUL
description: LOGERFO--Paul. The faculty, students and staff of Columbia University Health Sciences Division mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Paul LoGerfo. Dr. LoGerfo was the David V. Habif Professor of Surgery and director of the Endocrine-Thyroid Research Laboratory at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons. He also served as co-director of the New York Thyroid Center and chief of surgical specialties at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Recognized as one of the world's leading thyroid and parathyroid surgeons, Dr. LoGerfo began his medical career at Columbia University after attending Upstate Medical College where he graduated Alpha Omega Alpha in 1967. Early in his career he developed the thyroglobulin assay, which remains one of the most commonly used methods for detecting recurrent thyroid cancer. In the late 1980's, he pioneered a new technique in the field of thyroid and parathyroid surgery by using local anesthesia on an outpatient basis. His commitment to research won him the recognition of the NIH with the NIH Investigator Award in Cancer Immunology. In addition to his active clinical practice and research laboratory, Dr. LoGerfo was an artist whose sculptures appeared in several galleries around the US. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his wife, Kristin Larkin LoGerfo, his father Dr. Paul LoGerfo, his brothers Dr. Frank LoGerfo and Dr. James LoGerfo, and his family, friends and patients. He will be deeply missed. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D., Exec. Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University Joseph Tenenbaum, M.D., Senior Associate Dean For Clinical Affairs Columbia University

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: PATAKI DEFENDS BUSH POLICIES Gov. George E. Pataki defended President Bush's Iraq policy yesterday, arguing that it was a continuation of the battle that began on Sept. 11, 2001. "This is a president who knew that there were evil forces," he said, "and he was going to defend us from those forces, not on the streets of New York but on the streets of Baghdad." In a speech to Republican leaders at the Northeast Regional Leadership Conference in Boston, Governor Pataki made repeated connections between the terrorist attacks and the war in Iraq, but his speech made no mention of Osama bin Laden, Al Qaeda or Afghanistan. In recent days, the Bush administration has come under fire for its implication that Iraq was responsible for the terrorist attacks, despite no evidence of the connection. (AP)

title: 36 Hours | Pasadena, Calif.
description: PASADENA, the City of Roses, surfaces in the national consciousness one day a year -- New Year's -- when it presents both the Rose Parade and the Rose Bowl. But those few hours with their flower-bedecked motorized advertisements, marching bands and roaring stadium circled by lazily buzzing blimps are surely the least typical of the year. This midsize city, cleft through by an oak-filled arroyo, was settled at the end of the 19th century by Midwesterners awash in schadenfreude, having discovered a novel and amazing fact: here they had sunshine and roses year-round while their former neighbors endured hard winters. Pasadena's former role as a winter retreat for the wealthy (and the tubercular) can be seen in architectural wonders like the fantastical Green Hotel; the impressive United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, once the Vista del Arroyo Hotel, built in 1903; plus countless charming Craftsman bungalows and bungalow courts -- not to mention the apex of Arts and Crafts optimism and beauty, the Gamble House. Here is Southern California at its best, a self-contained municipality that is accessible, multicultural, awash in culture and still a shopper's playground where you can go to the movies without waiting in line and dine well without reservations. MICHELLE HUNEVEN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Challenger Concedes Election
description: Leaders of the Queens Democratic Party said yesterday that they would not challenge the results in a close City Council race in the Sept. 9 primary election, and that they and their candidate, Yvonne Reddick, left, were conceding the race to the incumbent, Allan W. Jennings. Although the initial balloting showed Mr. Jennings winning by 106 votes, Michael Reich, the executive secretary of the Queens party, said that the party's analysis of the results found that Mr. Jennings had won by even less -- about 90 votes. title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Banned Paper Allowed To Reopen
description: A court ruled that the biggest independent newspaper could resume publication after a six-day suspension, but a senior executive said he was unsure the victory would stand. The High Court said the police could not close The Daily News while it was still battling a law requiring it to register with the government. ''It's good news in the sense that we were granted what we prayed for,'' the publisher's chief executive, Sam Sipepa Nkomo, said. ''But whether it is long term is another issue, because in Zimbabwe, anything can happen.'' As President Robert Mugabe has grown more authoritarian, The Daily News has been one of his few outspoken critics. Michael Wines (NYT)

Two dissenting judges said the legislature, not the court, should decide the question. The appeals court said that only 11 other states recognize the doctrine of common-law marriage. The State Supreme Court may review the decision.
