description: Tanya Bonakdar

title: Shenyang Journal; The G.I.'s Were Japan's Worker Slaves. Believe It.
description: The strangeness of it all was not lost on Robert Rosendahl as he walked through the humming Chinese factory, the place where as a World War II prisoner of war he had been a slave laborer for the Japanese. He had hated this factory, just as he hated the Japanese prisoner of war camp that took three years of his life.

title: IHT drops escort advertising
description: PARIS:  The International Herald Tribune will no longer accept advertising for escort services, Richard Wooldridge, president and chief operating officer of the Paris-based newspaper, announced Thursday.

title: Israeli Envoys Will Sound Out U.S. on West Bank Barrier
description: ABU DIS, West Bank, Sept. 19  Israeli leaders resolved today to send envoys to Washington to test how strongly the Bush administration will resist construction of contentious stretches of the West Bank barrier, which President Bush has called a "problem."

title: So It Is Written: Books Are Memory
description: Once a year, when I was a Hebrew-school student at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Morningside Heights, our class would visit the seminary's rare-book library, which houses one of the great collections of Judaica in the world. Despite our antsy, adolescent irreverence, there was something about those books that commanded immediate attention, even a kind of awe.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor Named To Bench
description: Kenneth M. Karas, co-chief of the terrorism unit in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan, was nominated yesterday by President Bush to be a federal judge in Manhattan. Mr. Karas, 39, a federal prosecutor since 1992, is a member of the team that is prosecuting Zacarias Moussaoui, accused in the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Mr. Karas also helped win the 2001 convictions of four terrorists accused of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in Africa. If confirmed, he would replace Judge Allen G. Schwartz, who died in March. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Profit Soars at Bear Stearns On Bond Underwriting Surge
description: The Bear Stearns Companies, the first Wall Street firm to report third-quarter results, said yesterday that profit almost doubled as it underwrote more mortgage-backed and high-yield bonds and sold a stake in the retailer Aropostale Inc.

title: The World According to Some Glorious Chinese Misfits
description: If you've never seen a Chinese handscroll rolled up for storage, it looks like a collapsible umbrella in a snug silk case, an expandable thing made small. You can get some sense of what expandable in this case means from a 17th-century scroll titled ''A Thousand Cliffs and Myriad Valleys,'' on view at the China Institute Gallery.

title: Life Is Just a Video Game (With Very High Stakes)
description: The enigmatic antiheroine of Olivier Assayas's diabolical techno thriller, ''Demonlover,'' suggests a female cyber-age equivalent of the archetypal Man With No Name. Diane (Connie Nielsen), as she calls herself, is a coolly seductive industrial spy of ambiguous sexuality, with an invented rsum, who sometimes speaks in riddles. During a romantic dinner with Herv (Charles Berling), her suspicious but lustful boss at a Paris-based multinational conglomerate, she declares: ''No one sees anything, ever. They watch but they don't understand.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: 2 U.S. Fronts: Quick Wars, but Bloody Peace
description: The United States' military base in Gardez, Afghanistan -- its perimeter marked by a small woodshed with the words Crack House painted over but still visible -- straddles the smooth asphalt main road that leads southeast.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Johnny Cash on Saturday misstated the number of performers who have been inducted into both the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the Country Music Hall of Fame. Besides Mr. Cash and Elvis Presley, Brenda Lee and the Everly Brothers have been inducted into both halls as performers. Other people are in both halls, but some performers in the Rock and Roll hall were inducted under other categories, like ''early influences'' or ''sidemen.''

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend last Friday about Sofia Coppola's ''Lost in Translation'' misspelled the given name of a director whose movie ''In the Mood for Love'' was compared with Ms. Coppola's, and a correction in this space on Tuesday reversed the relationship between the movies. The director is Wong Kar-Wai, not Wong Kar-Wei; it was Ms. Coppola's film that was described in the review as evocative of Mr. Wong's (which predated it by two years).

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Loss Narrows
description: Palm, the maker of hand-held computers, narrowed its loss for the first quarter of fiscal 2004, reporting a net loss of $21.7 million or 74 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $258.7 and 8.93 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue was $177.4 million, up 3 percent from $172.3 million in the year-earlier period. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., said the increase in revenue was caused partly by a rise in the average selling price of its lead product. The stock closed up $1.63, or 7.78 percent, at $22.57.

title: Times Company Names a Board Member
description: Thomas Middelhoff, a former chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, joined the board of The New York Times Company yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: GOVERNOR STEPS UP DRUG CAMPAIGN Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, left, is enlisting the help of state leaders from across the country in his push to encourage the Food and Drug Administration to let states save money by buying prescription drugs from Canada. In addition to asking the 49 other governors to support his proposal, Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, also sent a letter to Mark McClellan, the federal commissioner of food and drugs, asking him to reconsider his position. The Food and Drug Administration opposes the importation of Canadian drugs, which are far cheaper than their American counterparts, because they have not been approved by the agency. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Houses With Wine Cellars: Always Ready for the Weekend
description: WHO -- Jeffrey LeSage, 43, public accounting executive, with his wife, Sandra LeSage, 40, and their daughter Remi, 1

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Fine Upheld
description: The top court in the European Union upheld a fine of 90 million euros ($101 million) against Volkswagen. The company was fined by the European Commission in 1998 for unfair sales practices. The European Court of Justice dismissed Volkswagen's appeal of the fine and ordered each of the sides to pay costs. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard Sales Plan
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced a marketing push yesterday to sell its computers and printers to small businesses after similar campaigns in the corporate and consumer markets this year. The program, called the Smart Office Initiative, involves current products and new ones, including a more powerful color laser printer and a wireless printer for networks. The company also introduced a line of computer servers that are prepackaged to support 75 users. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., also announced a line of desktop computers, including a model for the health care industry, and new warranty options specifically for companies with fewer than 1,000 employees.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: MOROCCO: FRENCHMAN CONVICTED OF INSURRECTION A Frenchman was convicted and sentenced to life in prison on charges of trying to organize an uprising. The man, Pierre Robert, 31, a convert to Islam, made a final plea of innocence and asked King Mohamed VI to intervene. Mr. Robert and 33 others on trial with him were arrested after suicide bombings in Casablanca on May 16 killed 45 people, including 12 bombers. His case was not directly related to the bombings. Instead, prosecutors said he led a network of Islamic militants in northern Morocco plotting to foment an uprising.    (AP)

title: Despite Rain, Virginia Tech Has an Easy Time
description: The rain was blowing sideways at times inside Lane Stadium. But in the end, Hurricane Isabel was more of a nuisance than an obstacle for Virginia Tech, Texas A&M and the fans who braved the storm to watch tonight's football game.

title: Playing Race For Laughs
description: With colloquial racism deemed no longer noxious but rebellious and plain fun -- especially by comedy writers eager to forsake stale Seinfeldisms and show off their harsher material -- two sitcoms have cartwheeled into prime time to have a ball with race.

title: A Bit of the No-Wave Revival Visiting From the West
description: By now, the no-wave revival has lasted longer than the original movement, which began and ended more than 20 years ago. The genre's building blocks may once have seemed provocative, but by now they seem merely puzzling: pared-down drums, clipped disco-inspired bass lines, petulant vocals and ultratinny guitar parts that sound as if someone is fiddling with an AM radio.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Advertising Loss
description: The French advertis-ing group Havas said it lost 58 million euros ($65 million) in the first half of 2003 and plans to lay off 850 employees, 5 percent of its work force, in the second half. The company said its results were hurt by the rise of the euro against the dollar and slower business in marketing services. Revenue fell 18.8 percent, to 836 million euros ($939 million). The company laid off 750 employees in the first half. The chief executive, Alain de Pouzilhac, said Havas would reorganize into three divisions and 20 companies would be closed or sold. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: U.S. Treasury Chief Pledges $1.2 Billion in Afghan Aid
description: John W. Snow, the United States treasury secretary, promised $1.2 billion in new American aid to Afghanistan today and said he would urge allies to donate at least $1 billion in reconstruction funds at a financial conference this weekend in Dubai.

title: Talk of the Town
description: The fourth annual New Yorker Festival, a three-day celebration of the arts, music, fiction, poetry, journalism and humor sponsored by The New Yorker magazine, takes place today through Sunday at 20 locations throughout Manhattan. Events include author interviews, readings and book signings; master classes in poetry, photography and cartooning; a concert reunion of the fictitious folk groups from the film "A Mighty Wind" ; and, tonight, a dinner and panel discussion to benefit the Chez Panisse Foundation. Many events are sold out; remaining tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (877) 391-0545 or ticketmaster.com. Complete schedule: festival.newyorker.com.

title: 'Underworld'
description: Directed by Len Wiseman

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Steps Up Drug Campaign
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, left, is enlisting the help of state leaders from across the country in his push to encourage the Food and Drug Administration to let states save money by buying prescription drugs from Canada. In addition to asking the 49 other governors to support his proposal, Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, also sent a letter to Mark McClellan, the federal commissioner of food and drugs, asking him to reconsider his position. The Food and Drug Administration opposes the importation of Canadian drugs, which are far cheaper than their American counterparts, because they have not been approved by the agency. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKER, JANE A.
description: BARKER--Jane A., 54, on September 18, 2003. Dearly beloved sister of Carol and Sally, aunt of Alex Permutt, niece of Bert and cousin of Wendy Wallbrunn, sister-inlaw of Alan Permutt, and member of the extended Barker-Werner clan; loving owner of Mabel. Cherished friend, respected colleague, inspiration to us all. Memorial service to be held at a future date. Donations in her memory may be made to the Fay Barker Fund for Child Victims at Safe Horizon, 2 Lafayette St, NYC 10007; the Riverside Park Fund, 475 Riverside Drive, NYC 10115; or Doctors Without Borders USA, PO Box 1856, Merrifield, VA 22116

title: G.M. Plant Will Remain Open Until 2007, Union Says
description: Workers at the General Motors plant in Linden, N.J., which faced a permanent shutdown by 2005, got yet another reprieve that would keep it open into 2007 as a result of a tentative settlement reached yesterday between the company and the United Auto Workers, a union official said.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Private Collection From the First Days

title: 4 Women (And Who Needs Any Men?)
description: There are still too few plays that grant women an equal opportunity to be compelling. Not just above and beyond their relations to men, but also beyond the sentimental and the formulaic feminine: mothers and daughters who meet at the beauty shop, say, or single women who've found professional success but still wish and hope for romantic fulfillment.

title: 'Mambo Italiano'
description: Directed by mile Gaudreault

title: Editorial Observer; Everything Is Not Always So Beautiful at the Bolshoi Ballet
description: When the Bolshoi Theater fired a Russian ballerina because she was not quite anorexic, the storm that followed felt very familiar. Ballet in Russia can never be confined to pink satin shoes and sugarplums. Underneath, it has always been a rough business, its turmoil part of the reason that dance remains one of Russia's national obsessions. Speculation about what happens in the dark, nefarious back rooms of Moscow's famous theater only highlights whatever unfolds on stage before the Bolshoi's enraptured following.

title: Colombia Accepts a U.S. Deal on Exemptions in Rights Cases
description: Under strong pressure from the Bush administration, Colombia's government has signed an agreement that exempts Americans arrested in this war-battered country for human rights violations from prosecution before the new International Criminal Court.

title: Voices of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Barkley Is Dunked (for a Laugh)
description: Charles Barkley was cautious. Awaiting the filming of a commercial in TNT's new National Basketball Association promotional campaign yesterday at a sound stage in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, he said: ''The people who make these spots don't have a clue. They don't know what's funny.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Drops
description: After rising steadily since the end of last year because of a slowing economy and then an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, the unemployment rate in Hong Kong edged down in the period from June through August, to 8.6 percent. It had been 8.7 percent in May through July. Underemployment, people who settle for part-time work because they cannot find full-time jobs, dropped to 4 percent from 4.2 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; Vanderbilt Should Consider Getting Out of This Cottage Industry
description: AT first I got all excited.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STANTON, BERYL I. (NEE SPECTOR)
description: STANTON--Beryl I. (nee Spector) of Brooklyn. September 13th, 2003. Loving mother of Marshall, Alison and Lynn. Beloved sister of Ira Spector. Adored grandmother of Ian, Evan, Kaitlyn, Hayley and Rachel.

title: Six Characters in Search of an Infant
description: Because John Sayles's social mosaics offer no pat solutions or happy endings, they are about as far as you can get from escapist movie entertainment and still call it fictional. His newest film, ''Casa de los Babys,'' adheres to the same essayistic format as many of its forerunners. This coolly observant movie follows six white American women, all but one over 30, who are impatiently waiting out their lengthy residency requirements in an unidentified South American country before picking up their adoptive babies at an orphanage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENRY, AARON
description: HENRY--Aaron. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Aaron Henry, associated with The Times from June 1969 until retiring in January 1991.

title: Schiaparelli's revolutionary legacy
description: 'Shocking attire" reads the invitation for next week's fashion event. That dress code might seem difficult at a time of visible bras and hipster pants. But the party in Philadelphia on Sept. 25 to launch an exhibition on Elsa Schiaparelli, 30 years after her death in 1973, will prove just how revolutionary the designer's work was to 20th-century fashion.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FAIR ISAAC, San Rafael, Calif., a provider of marketing and database management services, said it had bought Diversified HealthCare Services, San Ramon, Calif., a provider of medical bill review products and services to insurers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: China Insistent on Bolstering Currency
description: The head of China's central bank tonight defended his country's determination to hold its currency at the current level against the dollar and to maintain controls on large flows of money across China's borders.

title: Young Afghan Refugees Who Just Keep Going
description: Looking over the body of work that Michael Winterbottom has assembled since he began directing feature films less than 10 years ago, you would be hard pressed to find much continuity or consistency. There have been two Thomas Hardy adaptations (''Jude'' and ''The Claim''), an exercise in grim British realism (''Wonderland''), a Balkan war movie (''Welcome to Sarajevo'') and, last summer, a gaudy chronicle of the Manchester rave scene (''24 Hour Party People'').

title: Republicans Split on Break For Exporters
description: The top Republican tax writer in the Senate split sharply with his counterpart in the House today on how to replace a long-standing tax break for American exporters that was declared illegal under international trade.

title: LARGE SHAREHOLDERS OF MONY SAY AXA'S BID IS TOO LOW
description: Some of the biggest shareholders of the MONY Group said yesterday that a $1.5 billion bid by AXA, the big European insurer, was too low. Shares of MONY, based in New York, rose $3.77, to $33.11, above AXA's offer of $31 a share, indicating that investors are expecting a higher bid. Opponents of the takeover, including Highfields Capital Management, Third Avenue Management, Southeastern Asset Management and Advisory Research, say the price, at 72 percent of book value, is below MONY's liquidation value. AXA and MONY executives said the price reflected Mony's future ability to earn profits. The board of MONY, which sells insurance and mutual funds, has approved the takeover.

title: Married Gay Canadian Couple Barred From U.S.
description: A married gay couple on their way from Canada to a human rights conference in Georgia were not allowed to enter the United States today because the two men insisted on filling out a single Customs clearance form declaring themselves a family.

title: Giuliani Calls Bloomberg to Clarify His Remark on Smoking Ban
description: What's a little secondhand smoke between mayors?

title: Yale in Deal With 2 Unions, Ending Strike
description: Ending a three-week strike, Yale and its two main unions reached a tentative eight-year contract yesterday that will give many workers raises of more than 40 percent over the life of the pact and provide the embattled university with years of labor peace.

title: AOL Time Warner Drops the 'AOL'
description: Trapped in a troubled marriage, AOL Time Warner decided yesterday to return to its maiden name, dropping its first three letters.

title: It's All About The Volume
description: Designers are such swells -- funny, impulsive, so full of themselves. But this week they broke all restraints and puffed their clothes up big. Everyone got in the swing, from Oscar de la Renta with his teacup skirts to Zac Posen with a raffia ball gown the size of a hut. They take the wind out of tight-fitting clothes.

title: Miscellany
description: * Clear Channel Communications, San Antonio, agreed to donate in the coming year commercial time and advertising space worth $120 million to the Advertising Council, New York, which coordinates public service campaigns for the ad industry. The council called the commitment, which would double what Clear Channel donated in the last year, as the largest single donation by a media company in its 60-year history.

title: Appeals Court Will Reconsider Recall Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 — A federal appeals court in San Francisco today effectively dissolved a decision by three of its member judges to postpone the Oct. 7 gubernatorial recall vote in California, meaning the election is on again, unless the full court or the United States Supreme Court rules otherwise.

title: A Deceptive Abortion Ban
description: It now looks likely that in the coming weeks, President Bush will sign into law a ban on so-called partial birth abortion, thereby culminating a long campaign of deception. The measure, which has been constantly misrepresented as limited to late-term abortions, would in fact ban common abortion procedures used after the first trimester of pregnancy but well before fetal viability.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Dr. David P. Robbins, a mathematician who devised a widely recognized algebraic formula, omitted a given name in some copies for a colleague, the former director of the Center for Communications Research at the Institute for Defense Analyses. He is Dr. David Lieberman.

title: It Turns Out You Can Be Too Rich
description: IT takes about 45 minutes to get from Elmhurst in Queens to the financial district in Manhattan. That is the measure of distance and time on the R subway line. In most other respects, though, working-class Elmhurst and the canyons of Wall Street are light-years apart.

title: After Enron, Bankers Weigh Clients' Motives
description: Financial institutions have long been responsible for knowing their customers before doing business with them. But now, in an odd ripple effect from Enron's collapse, a standard is emerging that banks and investment houses need to know their customers' intentions as well -- and could be on the hook for huge sums of money if they do not.

title: Using Fragments of Images As a Mirror of a Culture
description: Headlong Dance Theater

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the cascading power failures that led to the blackout on Aug. 14 omitted a word from the full name of the Midwest ISO, an organization that oversees the power system in the Midwest. (The error also appeared in six earlier articles about the blackout.) It is the Midwest Independent Transmission System Operator, not the Midwest Independent System Operator.

title: Leading a Charge From the Podium
description: IT'S customary for the New York Philharmonic to begin the first concert of the new season by playing the national anthem. But just playing it was not enough for Lorin Maazel at the orchestra's gala opening program on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Maazel interpreted the national anthem in a beefed-up, slowed-down, exacting and deliberate performance that quickly encapsulated his brilliant, willful and often exasperating artistry. Making it clear that he intended to conduct the audience also in the singing of the anthem, Mr. Maazel lifted his arms, turned sideways and stared into the hall with an intensely focused look that said ''Pay attention!'' There would be no bungling of the ''Star-Spangled Banner'' while Lorin Maazel was on the podium.

title: Candidate Joined Crowd With Push From Clintons
description: Behind Gen. Wesley K. Clark's candidacy for the White House is a former president fanning the flames.

title: Dalai Lama Lite
description: I first met the Dalai Lama almost 20 years ago when I was a teenager studying at a college run by Roman Catholic monks. He had come to see a Christian monastery in action. Although the Dalai Lama was not a globally famous figure at that time, I was captivated immediately by his charisma, and by the tragic plight of the Tibetan people. I visited China and Tibet two years later, in 1986, and later became a director of the London-based Free Tibet Campaign.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: More 'Conrail Boyz' Arrested
description: Two men who the authorities say are train robbers with the Conrail Boyz gang were arrested yesterday while attempting to recover merchandise hidden along the New Jersey railroad lines. The accused men were identified as Mikhael Centeno, 23, of Jersey City, and Ronald Feliciano, 22, of Hoboken. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: And Those Silly Folks Thought the City Wasn't Safe
description: A serious filmmaker like Mike Figgis can be forgiven, I suppose, for slumming, when he's got a cast as stellar as the one that infuses the scream-by-numbers thriller ''Cold Creek Manor'' with more psychological credibility than its screenplay merits.

title: 'Meditation for the Hand'

description: To the Editor:

title: Albany's Latest Harvest
description: In a four-hour return to Albany this week, New York State's Senate finally passed an important environmental bill that has been stuck for almost a decade in the Albany mixmaster. The bill, passed in June by the Assembly, should get an enthusiastic signing by Gov. George Pataki. It will restore the Superfund cleanup of toxic sites and begin setting rules for the reclamation and use of more than 10,000 less toxic ''brownfield'' sites around the state.

title: Thousands Lose Power in the South of State
description: Stormy weather in advance of Hurricane Isabel wheeled into the New York region tonight, leaving at least 64,000 utility customers without power, mainly in southern parts of New Jersey.

title: 'Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion'
description: Directed by Tom Peosay

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: EX-MAYOR CLEARED IN SADOMASOCHISM CASE A prosecutor cleared the former mayor of Toulouse, Dominique Baudis, of any involvement in a reported sadomasochistic ring, bringing to a close a sordid and thinly sourced tale that titillated France for six months. But the collapse of the case after a key witness retracted her story on Wednesday left the media and judicial officials stuttering convoluted explanations why the allegations were taken seriously for so long. Mr. Baudis is reportedly considering suing those who lent credence to stories told by two unidentified prostitutes and a serial killer. He could not be reached for comment.    Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Brothers Held In Robbery Spree
description: Two brothers, ages 15 and 10, were responsible for a robbery spree in two White Plains malls during the past six months, the authorities say. On five occasions, the 15-year-old, who lives in a group home in Yonkers, took a bus to White Plains and either stole or tried to steal the pocketbooks of women in parking garages at the Westchester and Galleria Malls, the police said. They said the 10-year-old went along on two occasions. The White Plains commissioner of public safety, Frank G. Staub, said that the older boy was arrested on Tuesday shortly after stealing the purse of an 18-year-old woman whom he knocked to the ground and punched.

title: AVERY DENNISON REDUCES THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT FORECAST
description: Avery Dennison, a maker of self-adhesive stamps and labels, reduced its third-quarter earnings estimate yesterday, citing the effects of competition. The company said it expected earnings of about 65 cents a share, down from its previous estimate of 70 to 75 cents a share. In the third quarter of 2002, it earned 64 cents a share. Despite an upturn in the global economy, ''the benefits have come too late in the quarter to offset the effects of weak demand and competitive market conditions,'' the chief financial officer, Daniel R. O'Bryant, said. The company's stock fell $2.48, or 4.5 percent, to $52.39.

title: Suffolk Executive Proposes Tax Increases in Some Towns
description: The Suffolk County executive, Robert F. Gaffney, yesterday proposed a $2.4 billion budget for next year with $175 million in new spending and some property tax increases.

description: The Dark Ages Lighten Up

description: Friedrich Petzel

title: Foundations Laid In N.F.L. Off-Season
description: The reconstruction of the Buffalo Bills began in a suite inside Ralph Wilson Stadium, where General Manager Tom Donahoe had a pair of binoculars focused on the right arm of New England Patriots quarterback Drew Bledsoe. It was Dec. 16, 2001, and the Bills were playing the Patriots. The wind was up and the salary cap was tight.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Economic Growth Expected
description: Asia's 2003 economic prospects have dimmed only slightly as a result of severe acute respiratory syndrome, with the region, excluding Japan, still on track to post the world's strongest growth this year, the International Monetary Fund said. The fund trimmed its 2003 growth forecast for Asia, excluding Japan, to 5.9 percent from its April estimate of 6 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies on Tuesday about the Dallas Cowboys' victory over the Giants misstated the years in which Bill Parcells, now the Dallas coach, won the Super Bowl as coach of the Giants. They were 1987 and 1991 -- not both in the early 1990's.

title: Iraqi Factions Seek to Take Over Security Duties
description: Five Iraqi leaders devised a sweeping new security proposal today that would call for most American troops to withdraw to their bases and turn over day-to-day police duties to Iraqi militia forces working under a new interior ministry.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're easy targets. If they really want to get us they can.''

description: L'AFFAIRE

title: They're Just Making It Up As They Merrily Go Along
description: Anyone who subscribes to the theory that a passel of chimpanzees, given unlimited time and access to writing materials, will eventually create ''Hamlet'' or its equivalent, would probably agree that the same simians, properly equipped to flail toward a musical, would give theater another ''My Fair Lady,'' ''The Producers,'' ''Into the Woods'' or their equals.

title: 'Emerald Cowboy'
description: Directed by Andrew Molina and Eishy Hayata

title: U.S. and Oil Companies Back Revised Effort on Disclosure
description: The Bush administration and major oil companies are participating in an unlikely alliance with activist groups in support of an international campaign for more disclosure of information about financial transactions in global oil markets.

title: He's Like A Walton, But With A Big Cat
description: If the molasses-drenched coming-of-age movie ''Secondhand Lions'' yanks the pubescent Haley Joel Osment back to Earth from outer space, Hollywood's forlorn Boy With the Faraway Eyes still doesn't seem to have landed with both feet in the real world. As Walter, a wholesome 14-year-old abruptly transplanted from suburbia to a big, crumbling house on the prairie in central Texas, Mr. Osment has a deeper voice and a more focused gaze. But at 15 he still seems emotionally unattached to a character facing fearful challenges that would leave the average middle-school student quaking in his sneakers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about forecasts that the New York region would be spared the worst of Hurricane Isabel misstated the given name of the spokesman who discussed preparations by the Long Island Power Authority. He is Bert Cunningham, not Bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEIM, RABBI LEO
description: HEIM--Rabbi Leo. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, who after retiring from the active rabbinate, served for ten years at Congregation Beth Yeshurun in Houston. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: Jets' Moss Finds His Comfort Level
description: In the days after the Jets lost to the Washington Redskins in the season opener, Coach Herman Edwards made a rare appearance in a meeting of the offense. He had a message to deliver and he wanted to make sure it got through. So he walked in, wrote ''83'' on the board and circled it.

title: FOR CHILDREN

title: Weekender | New Paltz, N.Y.
description: IN 1677 Huguenots fleeing religious persecution in France settled New Paltz, N.Y. Today Manhattanites fleeing the city flock there to climb the Gunks -- the rocks of the nearby Shawangunk Ridge -- and enjoy the youthful energy of a small college town.

title: Argentina Preparing Debt Plan
description: A three-year deal with the International Monetary Fund finally completed, Argentina is preparing to present a plan to renegotiate $90 billion of defaulted debt with private investors across the globe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEIFER, HOWARD
description: LEIFER--Howard. Our dear friend Howard. We are sorry you left us at such a young age. We send our love to you in your higher place and will always remember you with warmth and affection. Ina, Dee and Lee

title: Low-Calorie-Diet Study Takes Scientists Aback
description: Scientists know that very strict low-calorie diets can prolong life. But now they report that it does not matter when you start that diet -- at least if you are a fruit fly. The life-prolonging effect kicks in immediately, continues as long as the diet, and is lost as soon as the dieting stops.

title: On a Train and Uninformed? Survey Says You're Not Alone
description: It might be the information age, but according to a new survey, the information provided every day to a few million subway riders in New York City too often takes one or more of the following less-than-useful forms:

title: Officers Will Face Charges For Handling of S.I. Attack
description: Two police officers, who officials say tried to discourage a black college student and her friends from filing a complaint after they were attacked on Staten Island on Labor Day, will face disciplinary charges in connection with the incident, their lawyer and a police official said yesterday. A sergeant also faces charges in the incident.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In this time of strained relations between France and the United States, Alain Ducasse has staged a culinary intervention. The president and le prsident may not be talking, but that's no reason bouillabaisse and New England clam chowder can't get together on the same table.

title: Every Year, a Family Trip to See Mickey
description: MY Mickey Mouse cap is in a box with a naked Raggedy Ann doll and a stack of Nancy Drew mysteries. But unlike these other girlhood artifacts, the cap is not a symbol of bygone days: it is simply the first memento from a trip that has evolved into a tradition.

title: PARK PLACE TO BUILD CASINO ON INDIAN LAND IN CALIFORNIA
description: Park Place Entertainment, the world's largest casino company, plans to build and run a $250 million Caesars hotel-casino for an American Indian tribe in Southern California, the company's first move into the state. The resort, the Caesars Pauma, will be south of Temecula, Calif., midway between Los Angeles and San Diego, on land owned by the Pauma-Yuima band of Mission Indians, Park Place said. It will have 500 rooms and a 100,000-square-foot casino. Park Place and the tribe must still reach a final agreement, and the contract needs approval from the National Indian Gaming Commission and other regulators before work can start.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLAZER, DOROTHY

title: 3 G.I.'s Killed In an Ambush By Guerrillas Near Tikrit
description: Guerrillas shattered a two-day lull in deadly attacks against American forces in Iraq tonight, ambushing soldiers with small-arms fire near Saddam Hussein's hometown of Tikrit north of Baghdad. Military officials said three soldiers were killed and two were wounded.

description: Fading but still fierce, Hurricane Isabel crashed ashore in North Carolina yesterday, swamped neighborhoods dozens of miles inland and raged north through Virginia to the nation's capital, with winds knocking out power to more than two million people and disrupting air travel across the mid-Atlantic region.

title: Another Connecticut Official Leaves Office Under a Cloud
description: In another blow to a scandal-plagued administration, Connecticut's commissioner of public works resigned today after he admitted taking a gift from an architectural firm that successfully bid for multimillion-dollar contracts with the state.

title: Enron Revises Estimates for Payments to Creditors
description: Enron amended its reorganization plan yesterday and raised estimates of how much would be recovered by creditors, who are owed more than $67 billion.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Settlement For Inmate's Death
description: The two teenage daughters of a mentally ill Mobile County jail inmate who died from an infection he got through wounds from his shackles will receive about $350,000 each in settlements from the county. The death of the inmate, James Carpenter, from flesh-eating bacteria in 2000 prompted a federal investigation. Mr. Carpenter, who was being held on misdemeanor charges, was found dead in his cell two weeks after his arrest, handcuffed and naked, with ulcers on his wrists and ankles from restraints. Though jail personnel were aware he was mentally ill, he was never treated for the condition, a lawyer for the family said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Storm Knocks, but No One Is Home
description: President Bush sought higher ground, leaving the White House for Camp David a day earlier than planned. Air Force One was moved to a safe spot in Georgia. The Senate opened for business, just long enough to pass a resolution honoring the late country singer Johnny Cash, then adjourned at 11:10 a.m.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: U.S. Extends Domain Deal With ICANN
description: The Commerce Department and the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, have agreed to extend for three years an agreement to shift management of the Internet domain name and numbering system to the private sector from the federal government. The Commerce Department serves as the steward of critical elements of the domain name and numbering system, while Icann is the private sector entity responsible for day-to-day management of the system. In November 1998, the Commerce Department entered into the first agreement with Icann; they have since signed a series of one-year agreements. The goal is to complete the transition within this three-year period.

description: Salon 94

title: Struggling Against Teenage Drinking
description: Almost everyone deplores the epidemic of teenage drinking in this country, but it seems devilishly difficult to do much about it. Drinking is so ingrained in the cultural fabric, and the long-ago failure of Prohibition has left such a feeling of futility, that few politicians are willing to take on the alcohol lobbies. Yet a new report from the National Academy of Sciences makes a persuasive case that the battle against teenage drinking could have substantial impact if it engaged all elements of society, from the federal government, with its taxing powers, to parents, who may be unaware that their children are drinking.

title: Bali Bomber Is Sentenced To Life Term
description: An Indonesian court sentenced an Islamic militant to life imprisonment today for his role in the Bali bombings, which last year killed 202 people, many of them tourists.

title: Review/Fashion; Odes to Sophistication and Sloppiness, Too
description: In what continues to be one of the most intoxicating pop cultural artifacts of our age, Us magazine regularly offers its readers a feature called ''Stars -- They're Just Like Us!'' In it, famous people are shown performing chores, ostensibly without the help of managers, agents or other members of their staffs. Here, one has the opportunity to see Drew Barrymore pump her own gas and Courtney Cox take out the garbage. And here one learns that left to their own inclinations, most celebrities dress themselves to look like an overflowing bag of laundry.

title: A Rural Teacher as a Gentle Artist, Molding Young Minds
description: ''To Be and to Have'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12; the full text is available online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 — Hundreds of thousands of people in the nation's capital and its suburbs learned today that they might be without power for days as electric utilities struggled with the worst blackouts in the region's history.

title: New Hall for Meteorites Old Beyond Imagining
description: Spacecraft travel hundreds of millions of miles across the solar system to see what's out there and report back. Yet every day about 100 tons of space stuff comes calling on us, unannounced and mostly undetected, a global fall of extraterrestrial dust grains. Occasionally, a dark pebble or fist-size object will rain down; only rarely, fortunately, something the menacing size of a boulder or larger.

title: Testing Finds Blood Donors Are Carrying Nile Virus
description: A new test has detected the West Nile virus in more than 600 blood donors across the country this summer, preventing transfusions of the contaminated blood, federal health officials said yesterday.

description: ''I thought you were fake for a minute,'' Michelle Feeney, the vice president of M.A.C. cosmetics, said to a friend standing on a spiral staircase at the Visionaire party on Tuesday.

description: Iraq's former defense minister, No. 27 on the list of most wanted government officials, turned himself in to United States forces today in the far northern city of Mosul under unusually cordial circumstances.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: U.S. PRESENTS NEW WEAPON The United States military presented an enhanced version of the Patriot antimissile system, which it said was designed to thwart a ballistic attack from North Korea. North Korea is capable of launching a devastating missile attack against South Korea, according to experts. The deployment of the new Patriot is Washington's latest effort to deal with such a prospect.    Samuel Len (NYT)

title: A Proud Father, His Daughter and Her Financial Baby

But yesterday, he was watching the shares of tiny National Financial Partners, a $413 million revenue financial services firm run by his daughter, Jessica M. Bibliowicz.

title: Germany Will Share The Burden In Iraq
description: Terrorism continues to be a very serious risk to security and stability in the world. With the fight against terrorism far from over, Germans and Americans stand united in the battle. Together, we will prevail.

description: Forget about Republicans and Democrats. This is a real rivalry, a feud more akin to the Hatfields against the McCoys. We're talking New York vs. Boston -- and they're at it again.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Police Dept. Settles Race Suit
description: The New York City Police Department settled a class action lawsuit yesterday accusing it of using racial profiling when stopping and searching black and Hispanic men. As part of the settlement, the department is required to report every instance of stopping and searching to the Center for Constitutional Rights and other lawyers for the plaintiffs. ''This settlement reflects the continuing commitment of the N.Y.P.D. to make certain there is no unlawful use of race by N.Y.P.D. officers in carrying out their duties,'' said Michael O'Looney, the deputy commissioner for public information. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMOROSI, LENORA TOLAND
description: AMOROSI--Lenora Toland. After a courageous battle with pulmonary fibrosis, ''Mimi'' died on September 12, 2003 at home in McLean, VA. She was the cherished wife of Dr. Leo D. Amorosi and beloved mother of ''Muffin'' Lynham, Maureen Cook, Leo, Edmund, Mark and Brian Amorosi and adored grandmother of eight. She will be sorely missed by her family and friends, as well as the many clients she served so well at Miller Real Estate in Washington, D.C. and Maryland. We, too, will miss you, Mimi. The Amorosi, Bennett and O'Brien families

title: Amputee Steps Back on Field For San Jose St.
description: In college athletics, the term walk-on is used to describe a player without an athletic scholarship who volunteers for the team. Neil Parry was such a player three years ago for San Jose State's football team, before the term took on a different meaning for him, before his right foot was amputated after a compound fracture led to a life-threatening infection.

title: At the Bottom Line, Holding Out Hope for a Lifeline
description: THERE are dark-side-of-the-moon crescents beneath Allan Pepper's eyes. And there is no spring to his step as he climbs the narrow staircase that leads to his windowless time warp of an office inside the Bottom Line, the eclectic Greenwich Village cabaret he and a friend have owned for nearly 30 years but could forfeit in New York City Civil Court as soon as Tuesday.

title: BURGER KING TO SELL LOW-FAT CHICKEN SANDWICHES
description: Burger King said yesterday that it would introduce a line of low-fat chicken sandwiches to appeal to health-conscious customers. The sandwiches have five grams of fat and about 350 calories, and will be sold for $2.89 in three varieties: Santa Fe chicken, savory mustard and smoky barbecue, the company said. Television commercials promoting the new line are scheduled to begin on the Emmy Awards on Sunday. The company also plans to advertise in several magazines, including Essence, People, Shape and Fitness. The moves are a part of a turnaround plan, which has focused on improving food and operations. Burger King is owned by theTexas Pacific Group, Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: A No To Common-Law Marriages
description: A state appeals court abolished the doctrine of common-law marriage, saying that such informal arrangements, based only on an exchange of vows, are an anachronism born in an era when not everyone could afford or arrange a marriage ceremony. Two dissenting judges said the legislature, not the court, should decide the question. The appeals court said that only 11 other states recognize the doctrine of common-law marriage. The State Supreme Court may review the decision. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Beaten Woman Dies
description: A woman who died after being found unconscious on a sidewalk in Kensington Gardens on Wednesday had been beaten by her husband, the police said. The husband, Alejandro Dominiques, 34, was arrested on murder charges. The dead woman, Barbara Dominiques, 34, had never reported any domestic abuse, the police said. They said she was beaten while leaving the apartment, and was found four blocks away, at the corner of Rugby and Albermarle Roads. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Change Urged To Diversify Pension Fund In New Jersey
description: Seeking support for a plan that would allow private investment managers to run part of New Jersey's $60 billion pension portfolio, the McGreevey administration released a consultant's report today that urges the state to reduce its risk by diversifying its investments.

title: DISSIDENT GROUP GAINS ALLY IN OPPOSING CONE MILLS DEAL
description: A dissident investor group said yesterday that it had won the support of Institutional Shareholder Services in its opposition to a takeover of Cone Mills by the financier Wilbur Ross. Institutional Shareholder Services, the largest adviser to money managers on proxy votes, urged investors to support a slate of three candidates to the board, the dissident group said. The nominees could play a role in identifying alternatives for the company, the group said. A Cone Mills director, Marc Kozberg, leads the opposition to the plan to sell the company to Mr. Ross's company, W. L. Ross, through a bankruptcy reorganization. The group contends the plan would be costly to shareholders, who are not expected to receive anything under the Ross offer because the expected proceeds would not be enough to satisfy secured creditors.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Expanding Board
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would expand its board to 10 members from 8 to strengthen its corporate governance. The company said the board had unanimously nominated Helmut Panke, 57, chairman of BMW, and Charles H. Noski, 51, a former vice chairman of AT&T. The board has also nominated the eight directors for re-election, Microsoft said. Mr. Panke is Microsoft's first director from outside the United States. ''Helmut will bring a valuable global perspective to our board,'' Bill Gates, chairman of Microsoft, said in a statement. ''His experience as chairman of one of Europe's most successful companies will be invaluable.'' Microsoft's shareholders will vote on election of the two new board members at the company's annual meeting in November.

title: Jewish Group to Honor Friend It Calls 'Flawed'
description: As prime minister of Italy, Silvio Berlusconi has stirred squalls of criticism with his flamboyant statements -- that a German legislator was like a Nazi commandant, that Islamic culture was inferior to Western culture and, most recently, that Benito Mussolini ''did not murder anyone.''

title: Clark Says He Would Have Voted for War
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark said today that he would have supported the Congressional resolution that authorized the United States to invade Iraq, even as he presented himself as one of the sharpest critics of the war effort in the Democratic presidential race.

title: Bears Root Through Garbage, Then Roil Politics
description: Outside the Town Hall here, a mother bear rummaged happily through the trash in a dark blue Dumpster tonight as two of her cubs sat on one of the lids.

title: Measles Outbreak Intensifies In Group of Pacific Islands
description: Perhaps as many as 720 people have developed measles in the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and 3 have died from it in a continuing outbreak that began in mid-July, federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sanitation Worker Killed
description: A city sanitation worker died last night after the truck he was driving hit two parked vehicles, the police said. The worker, a 39-year-old man whom the police did not identify, was heading north on Madison Avenue at 132nd Street around 8:30 p.m. when the accident occurred.

title: Authors, Artists and Actors
description: The main event in the 25th New York Is Book Country festival is on Sunday along Fifth Avenue from 42nd to 55th Streets in Manhattan, and several social events with literary ties, one for children, are planned that day elsewhere in Manhattan. Authors, illustrators and actors are scheduled to appear at more than 220 booths featuring displays from major publishers and small presses, from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., weather permitting. (The fair, which is free, may be canceled if there is heavy rain.) Information: (646) 557-6604.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg teased municipal union leaders yesterday for holding their annual retreat outside the city and warned them not to expect raises unless they agree to money-saving concessions.

description: Qwest Communications International, already investigation for overstating sales by more than $2 billion, said yesterday that the government was considering banning it from federal contracts.

description: Kenneth T. Jackson, president of the New-York Historical Society, announced yesterday that he would step down when his three-year term ends on May 1. Mr. Jackson is also a professor at Columbia University, specializing in social and urban history.

title: The Power of Music, Salacious to Sacred
description: As a young boy in 1980, Darrin Hill sees his mother kicked out of the church choir in her Georgia hometown for singing sexy, sinful R&B music, after which she takes to the road, dragging her son through a nomadic childhood of nightclubs and concert halls. When he returns home for a beloved aunt's funeral two decades later, Darrin, grown into a slick New York advertising executive (and also into Cuba Gooding Jr.), runs into Lilly, his boyhood sweetheart, who has grown into a sultry chanteuse (and also into Beyonc Knowles), and discovers that she has recently suffered a similar ostracism.

title: Families Call for Release of 9/11 Materials
description: An elected official and some relatives of those who died at the World Trade Center called yesterday on federal investigators examining the disaster to subpoena documents that New York City has so far refused to turn over -- materials that include firsthand accounts from firefighters and audio tapes of 911 calls from people trapped in the twin towers.

title: Residential Real Estate; 264 Apartments in 2 Projects Near Lincoln Center
description: As a onetime warehouse on West 64th Street completes its transformation into million-dollar loft condominiums, a 30-story rental tower is rising next door on Broadway, directly facing Lincoln Center.

title: Stock Exchange Is Split on Steps After Grasso
description: The day after Richard A. Grasso's resignation from the New York Stock Exchange, the exchange's directors squabbled yesterday over possible successors and even over how the board itself should be run, reflecting the disarray at the highest levels of Wall Street.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rapper Meets With City Officials
description: Sean Combs, the hip-hop executive, met with top city officials yesterday at the headquarters of the Department of Education to discuss ways that he might help the city's public schools, said Edward Skyler, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's press secretary. Mr. Skyler said that Mr. Combs, the founder of Bad Boy Records, met for 45 minutes with Deputy Mayors Dennis M. Walcott and Patricia E. Harris and Caroline Kennedy, the school system's chief fund-raiser. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein stopped in briefly late in the meeting. Mr. Combs ''expressed interest in learning more about New York City schools and finding areas where he could provide assistance,'' Mr. Skyler said. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: T.G.I. Friday's Switches Agencies
description: T.G.I. Friday's in Dallas, the restaurant chain, has unexpectedly dismissed its agency, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, and shifted its account, without a review, to the Marina del Rey, Calif., office of Deutsch. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: GOODRICH SAYS IT WILL CLOSE A PLANT IN NEW JERSEY
description: Goodrich, a maker of aircraft landing gear, plans to close a repair plant in Englewood, N.J., eliminating as many as 163 jobs over the next year, the company said yesterday. The work will be transferred to a plant that will be built in North Carolina or South Carolina, a Goodrich spokeswoman said. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., needs a bigger plant and will save money by moving, she said. It leases the Englewood plant and uses it to repair commercial-aircraft parts like cargo systems and hydraulic wing controls. About 25 employees will be offered a transfer, Goodrich said.

title: AK STEEL SAYS TOP 2 EXECUTIVES HAVE RESIGNED
description: AK Steel Holding, a leading supplier of automotive steel, is replacing its chairman and chief executive, Richard M. Wardrop, and its president, John G. Hritz, the company said yesterday. The company said that the two executives resigned and that the chief financial officer, James L. Wainscott, would run the company until replacements were found. AK Steel, based in Middletown, Ohio, reported its fourth consecutive quarterly net loss in July as shipments and selling prices fell, and its stock price has dropped 68 percent this year. The automotive industry accounts for about 60 percent of AK Steel's sales. ''The board simply believes that now is the time for a new perspective to address the company's current challenges,'' the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASSEY, JOHN CLIFFORD
description: MASSEY--John Clifford, was born on June 16, 2003, in New York, NY. He died in his sleep on September 14, 2003, in Houston, TX. John Clifford was the light of our lives. He was only with us on this earth for a short time, but his precious little smile will live in our hearts forever. No one has ever been more loved. John Clifford was preceded in death by his great grandparents: Mary Beth and Ray Allen Walker; Clifford Walter Ligon; and Marie Noonan and Eugene Aloysius Massey. John Clifford is the beloved child of parents Kendall and Tom Massey of New York, NY. He is also survived by his great grandparents Joy Barringer Ligon and Katherine and John Brennan Mowry; his grandparents Robert and Linda Ligon of Houston, TX and Mary Ellen and Eugene Aloysius Massey, Jr., of Washington, DC; his aunts Lacey Ligon Thomas and her husband, James Thomas; Elizabeth Whitney Ligon; and Elizabeth Massey Hopkins and her husband, Ryan McGill Hopkins; his uncles, Robert Walker Ligon and Michael Patrick Massey and his cousin Walker Michael Thomas. Services will be held in New York on Saturday, September 20, at 11am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave at 84 St. Interment services private. A reception for family and friends will be held later that afternoon. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NY, NY 10022 and designated for the John Clifford Massey Memorial Fund. A bench at the Central Park Children's Zoo will be dedicated in John Clifford's memory.

title: An Ill Wind From Factory Farms
description: Congress will hold hearings soon on the nomination of Gov. Michael Leavitt of Utah to lead the Environmental Protection Agency. He's bound to be asked about his efforts to eliminate protections for wilderness areas in his state and his close ties to the mining and timber industries. But he should also be asked about another issue that has received far less attention: the threat to the environment posed by the huge factory farms that dominate meat production in the United States today.

title: A Plot on a Train From Here to Here
description: Nolan Hemmings, a son of the British actor David Hemmings, was last seen playing his father as a young man in ''Last Orders,'' the 2002 film with Michael Caine about a band of aging Englishmen on a journey to scatter the ashes of an old friend. Now the young Mr. Hemmings has the unenviable assignment of holding down the lead in ''The Petersburg-Cannes Express,'' a film of outstanding dullness and ineptitude that opened in New York on Friday.

title: Chief Decides To Step Down At Motorola
description: After six tumultuous years as the chief executive of Motorola Inc., Christopher B. Galvin, the grandson of the company's founder, announced yesterday that he would step down, citing strategic differences with the company's board.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Retailer Recovers
description: The retailer Coles Myer said yesterday that its profit rose 21 percent last year, to 429 million Australian dollars ($286 million). John Fletcher, the chief executive, said the Myer-Grace department store division posted a profit in the year, which ended July 27, reversing two years of losses. The company said sales so far this year had increased 11 percent. Those results include gasoline sales under a trial program begun in May. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, DOROTHY DAVIS
description: SILVER--Dorothy Davis. On September 18, 2003 at home in the Bronx. Widow of Maurice Silver; mother of Arthur Silver and the late Bettina Lorris; grandmother of Mara Lorris, Elizabeth Lorris Ritter, and Rebecca Buchanan; mother-in-law of Robin Ritterhoff; great grandmother of Tina and David Ritter and Sean Jenkins; aunt of Sandy and the late Gerald Solomon. A founding member of the Teacher's Guild, predecessor of the United Federation of Teachers, she taught French, Spanish and German to generations of students at the High School of Music and Art. Visitation Sunday night from 6-8PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76 St and Amsterdam Ave - Manhattan. Funeral Monday at 11AM at Riverdale Temple, 246 St and Independence Ave-Bronx. Interment to follow at Mt Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family request contributions to the worthy charity of your choice.

title: 2 Officers Suspended for Handling of Staten Island Bias Case
description: Two police officers were suspended without pay yesterday after they tried to discourage a black woman and her friends from filing a complaint about a racially charged attack on Labor Day in a Staten Island park, the Police Department said. The sergeant who supervised them was brought up on disciplinary charges.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Prisoners Want DNA Preserved
description: Lawyers for prisoners who say DNA testing could exonerate them filed an emergency lawsuit with the State Supreme Court asking it to override a state law that would allow the destruction of DNA evidence in older cases after Oct. 1. This week, the Florida Bar Association filed papers with the court asking it to extend the deadline, also Oct. 1, for making motions for such testing. Both suits said the extensions were needed to safeguard the claims of nearly 600 inmates seeking DNA testing. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Storm Leaves Nearly Two Dozen Dead and Millions Without Power
description: Hurricane Isabel petered out over Canada last night, leaving a wide scar of destruction: nearly two dozen deaths, flooded cities in Virginia and Maryland, millions of people without power and tens of thousands of fallen trees that punctured roofs and blocked roads from North Carolina to New Jersey.

title: Theodore Kupferman, 83, Ex-Congressman and Judge
description: Theodore R. Kupferman, a former city councilman, Republican congressman from the Silk Stocking district and state appellate judge, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: SHELL AGREES TO SELL MICHIGAN WELLS TO MERIT ENERGY
description: The Shell Exploration and Production Company, an arm of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, agreed to sell 491 oil and natural gas wells in Michigan to the Merit Energy Company for $445 million. The sale also includes plants and lines that process and transport natural gas, said Fred Palmer, a spokesman for Shell Exploration, which is based in Houston. Royal Dutch/Shell Group aims to sell $2 billion worth of assets annually as part of a plan to focus on its highest-profit investments. With the sale announced yesterday, Shell has completed $3 billion in divestitures this year, Mr. Palmer said. Merit, which is based in Dallas and is closely held, buys and operates producing oil and gas properties on behalf of its investors.

title: Looking Out, And In
description: If you had opened the newspapers and magazines 50 years ago this week, you would have found the rapturous reviews that greeted Saul Bellow's first great book, ''The Adventures of Augie March.'' Virtually unknown, Bellow had set out to write the Great American Novel, which was audacious because the character he chose to typify the mainstream American spirit was a Jewish kid living in the Jewish neighborhood of Humboldt Park in Chicago.

title: Giants' Third Receiver Has Been a Near Miss
description: Tim Carter bounced up from the sideline, certain he had made the catch that would turn around his fortunes in the Giants' offense.

title: In the Nation's Seat of Power, Storm's Impact Rules the Day
description: The word ''power'' took on a new meaning in the nation's capital today, as hundreds of thousands of residents awoke to the prospect of days, and possibly a week, without it.

title: Ginsberg and His Mother, From a Poem to a Play
description: Poetry is devilishly hard to stage. I'm not talking about Shakespeare or Caldern de la Barca -- they're hard, too, but as playwrights they use words to lure audiences and drive on the story. We can revel in the beauty of their language, but we do so at the pace set by their characters.

description: AT some point, the time will be right for professional women's soccer, in a country where the game is booming at the grass-roots level and where the national team has developed a rabid rooting core.

Treasured and cherished mother of Mary Hammond, James Monaghan and Eileen Monaghan. title: Clinton, on a Visit to Kosovo, Warns Against Getting Even
description: Former President Bill Clinton was welcomed with acclaim here today, more than four years after NATO troops first entered this province, effectively ending two years of conflict and placing it under a United Nations mandate.

title: Fund-Raisers Greet Clark Warmly, but Not All Purses Open
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark has met Democratic fund-raisers from California to New York in recent weeks in an effort to finance his presidential run and has drawn a mixed reaction of curiosity and caution.

description: ''It's a whole new ballgame.''

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: VOLKSWAGEN STRIKE Workers at a Volkswagen car and engine plant in Brazil have called for a strike after the company rejected union demands and said it would go ahead with a transfer of about 4,000 workers to a training unit. Workers at the factory in Taubate, who make the Polo car model and engines, plan to go on strike Oct. 1, when the company is to start the transfers, said Antonio Eduardo de Oliveira, president of the union in Taubate. More than half the transfers are to involve workers at Taubate, with the rest coming from workers at Volkswagen's plant in Anchieta. Volkswagen will reassess the situation on Monday, said Fred Baerbock, a company spokesman.  (Reuters)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Force For Liberia Approved
description: The Security Council passed a resolution authorizing a deployment of up to 15,000 peacekeepers in Liberia, to enforce a cease-fire between the government and two rebel groups, disarm the militants, ensure the delivery of aid and protect United Nations staff members and civilians threatened with violence. The United Nations Mission in Liberia, called Unmil, is expected to retain many of the West African troops already in the country under a previous United Nations mandate. Unmil will take over authority from the West African force on Oct. 1. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: Celebrating Indefinable Electicism
description: Trying to categorize the Tin Hat Trio is a mistake. This is precisely the point. Many people who want to know more about music wonder what they are supposed to like. This eclectic group is about banishing the ''supposeds'' and making, simply, music. Good music.

title: Former Correction Officer Dies In Police Shooting in Bronx
description: The police fatally shot a former correction officer yesterday morning after he waved a toy pistol at officers on a Bronx sidewalk, police officials said.

title: When Love Means Combat
description: The more Geoff Rickly screams about destruction, the more certain you can be that he's singing a love song. He leads the New Jersey-based emo band Thursday, known for entropic songs that are as precarious as the relationships they chronicle.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Police Keep Paper From Publishing
description: The police ignored a high court order that the nation's only independent daily be allowed to resume publishing, the newspaper's editors said, and instead sent the paper's staff home. The Daily News, the nation's most popular newspaper and one of President Robert Mugabe's fiercest critics, was shut down a week ago. The police initially allowed employees to return to the newsroom, but later sent them away, the paper's chief executive, Samuel Sipepa Nkomo, told wire services. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family. Jeffrey S. Tabak, Chairman Barry Tucker, President

title: Isabel's Fury Winds Down After All of the Talking Up
description: For all the apocalyptic forecasting, Hurricane Isabel moved through the New York region with more of a whimper than a bang.

description: France's law-and-order interior minister has threatened to close any mosque in France that is considered extremist and expel any Muslim prayer leader who preaches a radical message.

title: Marsalis and His Russian Counterpart
description: Jazz suggests a spectrum of artistic dispositions, and musicians all over the world take from it whatever suits their own temperaments. Some choose vulnerability. Some choose concentration. Some choose restlessness. And some, like the Russian saxophonist Igor Butman, choose invincibility.

title: Dead Baby Is Found In City Trash Truck
description: Two sanitation workers in Harlem discovered the body of a newborn girl with her umbilical cord still attached as they were loading garbage into their truck yesterday, the police said.

title: In Glare of Politics, Bush Weighs Fate Of Tariffs on Steel
description: With the loss of manufacturing jobs shaping up as a crucial election issue, President Bush received two midterm reports tonight that will help him decide whether to continue tariffs he imposed to help the American steel industry or to bow to other industries opposed to them.

title: Capitol Dispute Threatens To Shut Much of F.A.A.
description: A dispute on whether the government should be permitted to contract out air-traffic-control jobs at dozens more airports has left Congress deadlocked over reauthorizing the Federal Aviation Administration. The result may be an unpaid furlough for thousands of the agency's employees, and a tax holiday for millions of air travelers.

title: TV Sports; Murphy and Kiner Reunited
description: Bob Murphy and Ralph Kiner reunited for one game on television last night, bringing a sweet familiarity to those who have watched and listened to them call the Mets since 1962. Too bad the Mets, 7-1 losers to Montreal, played as if it were 1962 (without all the fun stuff), and baldish Art Howe is not as amazin' as the hairless Marv Throneberry.

title: 14,000 'Hazardous' Swans Get Government Reprieve
description: A bird that has inspired many a fairy tale got a storybook reprieve from its planned demise when the federal Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Wednesday that it would withdraw all permits to kill mute swans, a bird the agency considers an environmental hazard.

title: Listening to the Wrong Iraqi
description: Critics say the Bush administration had no plan for postwar Iraq. In fact, before the war, hundreds of Iraqis were involved in discussions with Washington about securing and stabilizing their country after military action. Today's difficulties are not the result of a lack of foresight, but rather of poor judgment by civilians at the Pentagon who counted too much on the advice of one exile -- Ahmad Chalabi of the Iraqi National Congress -- and ignored the views of other, more reliable Iraqi leaders.

title: Review/Fashion; An American Chorus, Less Two Voices
description: They are the most American of designers, Ralph Lauren and Donna Karan, yet as the New York spring 2004 shows came to a close on Friday, neither lent their big voices, as one might have expected, to the strong American themes blowing through fashion.

title: $1 Million in Fake Goods Seized in Queens and L.I.
description: Nearly $1 million worth of counterfeit cigarettes, batteries and designer goods smuggled from China were seized Thursday night in raids in Queens and Long Island, the authorities said yesterday.

title: U.S. Is Struggling to Make New Iraq Resolution Matter
description: This time around, the intense diplomatic efforts over a new resolution to change the military and political realities in Iraq are not aimed at getting the measure passed. They are aimed at making it matter.

title: CIMA LABS CONSIDERS COMPETING OFFER IN SALE
description: Cima Labs Inc., the drug maker that agreed to be bought by aaiPharma Inc. last month, said yesterday that it was willing to negotiate a sale to another company, Cephalon Inc. Cima's board rejected a $376.6 million, $26-a-share offer from Cephalon, the second rebuff to Cephalon's unsolicited bid. Cima said, however, that it was prepared to discuss a higher offer. Based on the closing share price yesterday, aaiPharma's offer is valued slightly lower, at $25.87 a share, or about $374.7 million. Cima is based in Eden Prairie, Minn., and Cephalon is based in West Chester, Pa. AaiPharma, based in Wilmington, N.C., said it was committed to completing its takeover of Cima.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Freer Trade For Ex-Soviet Republics
description: The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan agreed to create a single economic and trade zone. The agreement, signed in the Black Sea resort of Yalta, is intended to bolster economic ties between the four largest former Soviet republics by ending border tariffs and unifying customs and tax policies. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Yukio Okutsu, who received the Medal of Honor for valor in the Italian campaign of World War II, misidentified the site of the action for which he was decorated. It was Mount Belvedere near the coastal village of Massa, not another mountain of the same name astride a road to Bologna.

description: Radio City Music Hall played host on Thursday night to an enormously entertaining revue that celebrated the songs and styles of Mariah Carey, one of the biggest stars of the Roaring Nineties. In her heyday Ms. Carey could do it all: she sang, she pranced, she gesticulated, sometimes all at once. And this show captured her every quirk and excess with uncanny accuracy.

description: The directors of the New York Stock Exchange appointed a search committee yesterday to find a chairman and chief executive to succeed Richard A. Grasso and said that they would be meeting with some of the exchange's harshest critics in the coming weeks.

title: Iran Cleric Suggests Nation Quit Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty
description: An influential cleric suggested today that Iran opt out of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, adding to signs that the difference over Iran's nuclear policy was increasing among the authorities here.

title: BRITAIN ISSUES WARNING ON WYETH ANTIDEPRESSANT
description: The Efexor antidepressant from Wyeth should not be given to adolescents because of a risk of hostility and suicidal thoughts, British regulators said yesterday. British doctors have prescribed Efexor, sold as Effexor in the United States, for about 3,000 adolescents despite a warning on the drug's label, according to the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency in Britain. The medicine is Wyeth's top-selling drug; its second-quarter sales rose 5.1 percent, to $636.4 million. The company is based in Madison, N.J.

title: Sports of The Times; Despite the Tumult, King Says a Jones-Tyson Fight Could Be a Reality
description: SPEND an hour with Don King and you get a snapshot of what he calls ''his totality'': all the jive, but also the gems of insight into the world of boxing he dominates and the human nature he has observed along the way.

title: TRUSTEE OF RIVERSTONE DEMANDS PAYMENT
description: Riverstone Networks Inc., a computer networking equipment maker, said the trustee for its convertible notes demanded $133.3 million because the company had not filed an annual financial report. Riverstone, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the unidentified trustee argued that the company defaulted by failing to file the report within 60 days of receiving notice from the trustee. Riverstone said it disputed that position because the trustee did not provide proper notice for beginning the 60-day period. Riverstone, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is being investigated over its accounting by the S.E.C. and by its own board.

title: Rethinking Health Care as a Haven for Investors
description: Conventional wisdom has it that health care is a defensive investment. When the overall economy weakens, people still take their medicine and go to the hospital for surgery, so investors tend to favor the stocks of drug companies and hospital chains. But several mutual fund managers say the experience of the last economic downturn has made them question their previous assumptions.
