title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASSEY, JOHN CLIFFORD
description: MASSEY--John Clifford, was born on June 16, 2003, in New York, NY. He died in his sleep on September 14, 2003, in Houston, TX. John Clifford was the light of our lives. He was only with us on this earth for a short time, but his precious little smile will live in our hearts forever. No one has ever been more loved. John Clifford was preceded in death by his great grandparents: Mary Beth and Ray Allen Walker; Clifford Walter Ligon; and Marie Noonan and Eugene Aloysius Massey. John Clifford is the beloved child of parents Kendall and Tom Massey of New York, NY. He is also survived by his great grandparents Joy Barringer Ligon and Katherine and John Brennan Mowry; his grandparents Robert and Linda Ligon of Houston, TX and Mary Ellen and Eugene Aloysius Massey, Jr., of Washington, DC; his aunts Lacey Ligon Thomas and her husband, James Thomas; Elizabeth Whitney Ligon; and Elizabeth Massey Hopkins and her husband, Ryan McGill Hopkins; his uncles, Robert Walker Ligon and Michael Patrick Massey and his cousin Walker Michael Thomas. Services will be held in New York on Saturday, September 20, at 11am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave at 84 St. Interment services private. A reception for family and friends will be held later that afternoon. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NY, NY 10022 and designated for the John Clifford Massey Memorial Fund. A bench at the Central Park Children's Zoo will be dedicated in John Clifford's memory.

title: Of Spindles and Spirituality; Group Pursues Arts and Crafts With Unusual Fervor
description: They talk about painting with breast milk. They talk of knitting the vegan fox, a polyester stole that looks like fur but harms no animals in its creation. They gather on Sundays to sew, tat, crochet, paint and cut up soda cans.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Eviction Notice For Lord Archer
description: The government said it would force the eviction from the House of Lords of Jeffrey Archer, 63, the millionaire novelist and politician who was freed from prison this summer after serving half of a four-year sentence for perjury and perverting the course of justice. The new provision, part of a reform that will also eliminate the remaining 92 members of the House of Lords who inherited their positions by birth, strips the peerage from anyone who has served two years or more in jail, and is retroactive. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Experts Say Court Panel Is Less Likely To Delay Vote
description: The 11-judge panel that will reconsider the California recall case includes eight appointed by Democratic presidents and just three appointed by Republicans, which at first blush might hearten the civil rights groups that had persuaded three judges, all appointed by Democrats, to delay the election in a decision issued Monday.

title: Religion Journal; For Synagogues, Time For the Rarely Faithful
description: A gambler he's not, but even before Rabbi Joseph R. Black of Albuquerque looks out onto a sea of congregants next Friday at sundown to welcome the Jewish New Year, he can lay odds on the view from the pulpit.

title: SHAREHOLDERS IN MIRANT GAIN VOICE IN REORGANIZATION
description: Shareholders in the Mirant Corporation gained a voice in the company's bankruptcy reorganization yesterday, as a Justice Department lawyer charged with overseeing the case named a committee to represent them. The nine-member shareholder panel includes five individual investors and four investment companies. A federal judge must approve a recovery plan before the company, an energy producer based in Atlanta, can exit bankruptcy. The shareholder panel can negotiate for a higher return, possibly complicating the case, adding costs and reducing creditors' recoveries.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE DROPS. Gasoline futures fell after Hurricane Isabel failed to disrupt oil refining along the East Coast. In New York, gasoline for October delivery fell 1.47 cents, or 1.8 percent, to 78.7 cents a gallon.

title: Dance and Profit: Who Gets It?
description: Contentious debates over artistic ownership generally seem to revolve around online music piracy or Mickey Mouse. But dance is facing unexpected and vexing questions about artists' rights as well. Do choreographers own their dances? Or are they simply employees who give up ownership to organizations that commission or support their work?

title: Miami Stars of Soul Pass Their Torch
description: It took a 16-year-old English girl to bring together Miami's soul-music aristocracy for shows on Wednesday night at Joe's Pub. The girl is Joss Stone, a singer and protge of Betty Wright, who had the 1971 hit ''Clean Up Woman.'' Ms. Wright helped produce Ms. Stone's debut album, ''The Soul Sessions'' (S-Curve), and she and other 1970's Miami soul hitmakers -- Gwen McRae, Timmy Thomas and Latimore -- were the core of Ms. Stone's band on Wednesday night. They backed her up as if they were passing on their chart ambitions to a more marketable face.

title: MUSIC ASSOCIATION SUES IMESH.COM OVER FILE SHARING
description: The Recording Industry Association of America, which represents the five largest record labels, filed a copyright infringement suit against iMesh.com, an online service that lets computer users share songs over the Internet. The industry trade group said that it filed suit on Thursday in federal court in Manhattan, accusing the company, which is based in Tel Aviv, of helping computer users copy and distribute copyrighted works.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Official Cleared In Razing Of Mosque
description: A special court cleared India's deputy prime minister, Lal Krishna Advani, left, of inciting the 1992 destruction of a 16th-century mosque in the town of Ayodhya, but charged seven other Hindu nationalist leaders in the case, including the country's minister of human resource development, Murli Manohar Joshi, who immediately offered his resignation. Mr. Advani defended the movement to build a temple at the site, which many Hindus believe is the birthplace of Lord Ram. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: PHONE SHARES SOLD The Dutch government has sold about 2 billion euros ($2.2 billion) worth of its shares in the country's largest telecommunications concern, Royal KPN, to Citigroup Global Markets. The 300 million shares sold amounted to a 12 percent stake in KPN, the country's former national telecommunications monopoly, reducing the government's interest to 19.3 percent. Citigroup plans to sell the shares to investors. Just days after it announced a series of deep budget cuts, the Dutch government said it would use sale proceeds to improve the country's infrastructure.   Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: When Pretty Shoes Turn Cruel
description: There has been a lot of weather going on in New York this year, most of it wet. Not to mention the big blackout. What all these things had in common was the fact that it was almost impossible to deal with them in high-heeled shoes.

title: From Russia, Without Love
description: Evidently inspired by the United States military's Iraqi most-wanted playing cards, a newspaper and a television program in Russia have teamed up to produce their own deck featuring American political figures. ''The United Cards of America,'' as they are called, portray 36 Washington power brokers -- along with some, um, pointed commentary. In an interview in The Moscow Times, the creators said their deck was mostly for educational purposes, not for ''providing material for the Foreign Intelligence Service.'' Apparently so. Here are some examples:

title: With the Common 4-3 Fit, Play Can Be Complicated
description: More than 90 percent of suit contracts are in obvious spots, with the declaring side owning eight or more trumps. The exceptions are almost always interesting. Fits of 6-1 and 5-2 are often appropriate, and there are more exotic cases: 6-0, 5-1, 4-2 and even 3-3 and 5-0 can be right on rare occasions.

title: The Glory Of a Ruin And 9/11
description: Last year Lorin Maazel began the first subscription series program of his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic with the premiere of John Adams's ''On the Transmigration of Souls,'' a work of memory and reflection about 9/11 on its first anniversary. The composition went on to win the 2003 Pulitzer Prize in Music.

title: Board Change at Cisco
description: Cisco Systems, one of the world's largest makers of equipment to link computers, says the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, Carleton S. Fiorina, will leave Cisco's board, ending what some corporate-governance specialists have said is a conflict of interest.

title: For Amputee, Return to Game Is Not Total Hit
description: With the most famous right foot in college football, Neil Parry hears all sorts of questions. He answers them with grace and insight not always evident in young athletes.

title: Devils Struggle in Philadelphia
description: In their preseason opener tonight, the Devils looked out of sync, and they clearly did not meet the intensity of the Philadelphia Flyers, who handed them a 6-1 loss at Wachovia Center.

title: For Spring Lines, Colors and Retailers Return
description: As the last swan-necked model walked her spiky walk down a runway in New York yesterday, ending another Fashion Week, retailers from around the country rejoiced that designers -- at last -- had given American merchants what they had been pleading for: high-fashion gaiety and department-store saleability.

title: Hundreds of Marijuana Plants Seized at Chinatown Apartment
description: Police officers conducting a routine search through a building of clothing manufacturers in Chinatown discovered hundreds of marijuana plants hidden behind secret doors in a loft-style second-floor apartment, the police said.

title: COURT WILL REVISIT DECISION TO DELAY VOTE IN CALIFORNIA
description: A federal appeals court agreed today to reconsider a ruling delaying the California recall election, handing the question to an 11-judge panel that recall proponents confidently predicted would uphold the original Oct. 7 election.

title: World Business Briefing: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RETAILER RECOVERS The retailer Coles Myer said yesterday that its profit rose 21 percent last year, to 429 million Australian dollars ($286 million). John Fletcher, the chief executive, said the Myer-Grace department store division posted a profit in the year, which ended July 27, reversing two years of losses. The company said sales so far this year had increased 11 percent. Those results include gasoline sales under a trial program begun in May.   John Shaw (NYT)

title: Kerry Says Dean Is 'Imploding'
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts today sharply criticized one of the other leading Democrats running for president, Howard Dean, asserting that some of his recent pronouncements show that his ''bubble's bursting a bit.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a commission to help Holocaust survivors collect insurance claims included an erroneous figure in some copies from the commission's statement to Congress on the amount it has persuaded insurers to pay. It is $35 million, not $42.5 million. The commission reported that it had spent $56 million on operations. That is 60 percent more than the insurers have paid, not 30 percent more.

title: Japanese Election Exposes Rents in Party Fabric
description: Under normal circumstances, the weary-looking politician campaigning in the Ginza shopping district here this week, ignored by most passers-by, should become Japan's next prime minister.

title: CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY BACK SOME DEBT
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable television operator, said yesterday that it would buy back $609 million of its convertible notes in privately negotiated transactions. Charter said it also reached agreements with institutional investors to buy back $1.3 billion in high-yield notes. A subsidiary will issue $1.6 billion of 10.25 percent notes due 2010 to finance the transaction and sell an additional $30 million in notes for cash, the company said. Charter, which is controlled by Paul Allen, has been trying to trim its $19 billion in debt. The refinancing will cut debt by $294 million. Charter is based in St. Louis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUSSMAN, MAURICE H.
description: SUSSMAN--Maurice H. On September 19, 2003. Beloved and devoted husband of 65 years to Iona. Loving father of Gordon and Ellen, Edward and Janice. Cherished grandfather of Rod, Cliff, Adam, Josh and Jake. We will miss your wisdom, humor, spirit and kindness. Services Sunday, September 21, at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, West Palm Beach, FL. Donations to UJA preferred.

title: Labor Adopts New Strategy
description: Corporations have often complained that union demands are so outlandish that labor seems ready to drive them out of business. Companies like Bethlehem Steel, Pan Am and Studebaker attributed their demises largely to overambitious union demands.

title: Labor Loses Parliament Seat; Vote Seen as a Rebuff to Blair
description: The Labor Party lost its parliamentary seat in a longtime North London stronghold today in what was seen as a judgment against Prime Minister Tony Blair's involving Britain in the war in Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the board of the New York Stock Exchange included one chief executive erroneously among those who served on the compensation committee that approved the contract of Richard A. Grasso in 1999. Philip J. Purcell of Morgan Stanley joined the board this year.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: PRISONERS WANT DNA PRESERVED Lawyers for prisoners who say DNA testing could exonerate them filed an emergency lawsuit with the State Supreme Court asking it to override a state law that would allow the destruction of DNA evidence in older cases after Oct. 1. This week, the Florida Bar Association filed papers with the court asking it to extend the deadline, also Oct. 1, for making motions for such testing. Both suits said the extensions were needed to safeguard the claims of nearly 600 inmates seeking DNA testing.   Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: About New York; It's Feast And Famine On Mulberry
description: AND to think that I saw it on Mulberry Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, PAUL P.
description: KLEIN--Paul P. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Glenn and Jonathan. Dear brother of Claire Feins and Bernard Klein. Service today, 12 noon, at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Democratic Bangladesh
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Suspends Youth Home Admissions After a Beating
description: New Jersey child welfare officials said today that they are investigating conditions at the state's largest residential treatment center after a staff member was accused of beating a teenage resident, breaking his jaw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOHR, NANCY
description: MOHR--Nancy. On September 18th, 2003. Beloved wife, mother, mother - in - law, grandmother, sister, daughter - in - law, sister - in - law, friend, educator, mentor and cook. Service Sunday 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Separating Iraq From Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Cameras Shoot Where Uzis Can't
description: Saddam Hussein and Osama bin Laden, by releasing audio- and videotapes of themselves, have given new life to their movements of rebellion -- or at least the illusion of new life -- which, in the age of mass media, may amount to the same thing.

title: Airbus Aiming at U.S. Military Market
description: Prompted by an investigation into possible improprieties by Boeing in obtaining a military contract, Airbus is redoubling its efforts to crack the American market for military business, Airbus officials said this week.

title: Local Beer Only at Oktoberfest, Unless It's Belgian, of Course
description: The Oktoberfest starts here this weekend, and even before noon today, the vaulted main hall of the Hofbruhaus was teeming with tourists in boisterous training.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Phone Shares Sold
description: The Dutch government has sold about 2 billion euros ($2.2 billion) worth of its shares in the country's largest telecommunications concern, Royal KPN, to Citigroup Global Markets. The 300 million shares sold amounted to a 12 percent stake in KPN, the country's former national telecommunications monopoly, reducing the government's interest to 19.3 percent. Citigroup plans to sell the shares to investors. Just days after it announced a series of deep budget cuts, the Dutch government said it would use sale proceeds to improve the country's infrastructure. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Antarctica: A Bigger Ozone Hole
description: The hole that forms in the atmosphere's protective ozone layer each September over Antarctica has matched a record extent measured in 2000, officials at the World Meteorological Organization said. The annual hole, actually a broad region of diminished ozone concentrations, is the legacy of decades of emissions of Freon and other ozone-eating synthetic chemicals. The hole this year is larger than North America, according to satellite measurements, officials said. The ozone veil shields the surface from ultraviolet radiation, which can harm some life forms and raise cancer rates.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraqi Ex-Official Surrenders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISINGER, EDWARD S.
description: EISINGER--Edward S. Beloved husband of the late Jean, cherished and loving father of daughter Dale and Mike, and son Allan, daughter-in-law Jerri, and grandfather of Jill and son-in-law of Joe, Eric, Josh and greatgrandfather of Jacob, on September 19, 2003 at his home in Miami, Florida. At nearly 93 years of age, and still a dapper fellow. A dear and devoted father, a true friend and advisor, always there in full support of his family. His sparkling blue eyes and quick smile, his kindness and sweet words combined with his wonderful sense of humor will never be forgotten and he will forever remain in the hearts of all who knew him and loved him. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, September 21st at The Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKER, JANE
description: BARKER--Jane. The Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry of the North Shore University Hospital, North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System mourns the death of Jane Barker, A.C.S.W., Chief Program Officer of Safe Horizons. Our staff sends condolences to her family and colleagues.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trial In Mannesmann Bonuses
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Bank will have to stand trial in a case tied to the Vodafone Group's $186 billion takeover of Mannesmann three years ago, Deutsche Bank said. The executive, Josef Ackermann, left, was charged in February, along with three other Mannesmann executives, with breach of trust for approving about $65 million in payouts to senior Mannesmann managers. Mr. Ackermann was a member of Mannesmann's supervisory board when the company, the German wireless operator, was bought by Vodafone in 2000. He became chief executive of Deutsche Bank last year, and the bank said he had the full backing of its management and supervisory boards in the matter.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Army Sites To Close
description: The Pentagon said it would close two Army storage sites in the Netherlands next year as part of a wider reduction of military forces and matriel in Western Europe. The shutdowns, together with cutbacks at a third facility, will result in the elimination of 400 civilian positions, Dutch officials said. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: GLOBAL CROSSING SALE CLEARS ONE U.S. HURDLE
description: Singapore Technologies Telemedia, a government-owned investor in phone companies, won approval from President Bush to buy 61.5 percent of Global Crossing, the fiber optic network operator with 100,000 miles of cable spanning 27 countries. A White House statement said Mr. Bush would ''take no action to suspend or prohibit the proposed'' investment in the company, which is under bankruptcy protection. The Singaporean company needed White House clearance of the planned $250 million acquisition after military officials expressed concern about foreign ownership. A panel of government agencies began reviewing the proposed transaction last year and submitted its findings to Mr. Bush this month. The company still needs approval from the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Israelis to Go to U.S. to Discuss Barrier Rift
description: Israeli leaders resolved today to send envoys to Washington to test how strongly the Bush administration will resist construction of contentious stretches of the West Bank barrier they call a security fence, which President Bush has called ''a problem.''

title: MOODY'S CUTS RATING ON KODAK DEBT
description: Moody's Investors Service cut the rating on the $3 billion of debt of the Eastman Kodak Company to the lowest investment grade as a drop in film sales drained cash. The company's long-term senior unsecured rating was lowered to Baa3 from Baa2, Moody's said. Moody's and Standard & Poor's had cut their ratings earlier this year on concern that Kodak's acquisitions and weak cash flow from film sales would hinder debt repayment.

title: Airline Gave Defense Firm Passenger Files
description: JetBlue Airways acknowledged publicly today that it had provided a Pentagon contractor with information on more than one million of its passengers as part of a program to track down terrorists and other ''high risk'' passengers. That data, which was turned over in violation of the airline's own privacy policies, was then used to identify the passengers' Social Security numbers, financial histories and occupations.

title: A New Risk at Reactors
description: Fragile space shuttles and a rickety electricity grid are not the only complex technologies this nation is struggling to control. Critics attempting to close the two nuclear reactors at Indian Point, north of New York City, are now pointing to a risk that may endanger dozens of other nuclear plants around the country as well. The risk appears to be slight, but then so did the likelihood that foam insulation would destroy a space shuttle.

title: Mother's Plan to Sue City Over Councilman's Death Is Not the Answer, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday criticized a wrongful-death claim against the city by the mother of slain City Councilman James E. Davis.

title: Price of Labor Peace
description: To end the 22-day strike that was embarrassing Yale and grating on its students, the university gave its two main unions wage and pension increases that are generous by most any definition.

title: Separating Iraq From Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO., -- St. Louis, operator of David's Bridal, said that it had purchased some assets of the closely held Desmonds Formalwear, a renter and seller of tuxedos, and that the Desmonds stores would become part of its After Hours Formalwear business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Edward Teller
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur Kinoy Is Dead at 82; Lawyer for Chicago Seven
description: Arthur Kinoy, one of the lawyers for the Chicago Seven and a founder of the Center for Constitutional Rights, long a force in the civil rights movement, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 82.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: JetBlue Acknowledges It Divulged Data on Fliers

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Block Sale of G.M. Building
description: The auction of the General Motors Building, a 50-story office tower that commands some of the highest rents in the city, drew the highest bids ever for a skyscraper in the United States when Harry Macklowe offered $1.4 billion.

title: The Safety of Imported Drugs
description: The allure of importing cheap prescription drugs from Canada and other advanced nations is proving irresistible, despite federal laws against it and stern warnings from the Food and Drug Administration that imported drugs may not be safe. Individual consumers have been buying drugs from abroad for some time now. The new wrinkle is that state and local officials have become interested. Illinois has asked regulators for permission to import drugs from Canada, California has been exploring the possibilities, and the city of Springfield, Mass., has already started importing drugs from Canada for its workers and retirees, in open defiance of the F.D.A. It is a sign of how untenable the drug industry's outrageously lopsided pricing strategies have become.

title: Pataki Plans A Trip West To Help Republicans
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will head to the West Coast next week to raise money for Republicans in California, Washington and Oregon, his spokeswoman said today. The trip is the first major out-of-state fund-raising trip this year for Mr. Pataki, who has emerged as a fund-raising powerhouse for the national Republican Party.

title: A German Voyager's Bold Vision for Tibet's Blind
description: UPON arriving in Tibet, Sabriye Tenberken decided to tour the countryside, not from the comfort of a car, but atop the hard saddle of a horse. It was a chancy decision, not only because the rugged Tibetan landscape can be unforgiving and treacherous, but also because Ms. Tenberken is blind.

title: In Iraq, Demand Makes Security Growth Industry
description: Politicians may have started negotiating a sweeping proposal to relieve American soldiers of their police duties, but many Iraqis are way ahead of their leaders. They gave up on the Americans some time ago and started paying for their own protection.

title: Fire Marshals Losing Office; Some Say Cuts Hurt Inquiries
description: The Fire Department will close one of New York City's two remaining full-time fire marshals offices on Thursday. Fire union officials warned yesterday that with fewer marshals, more fires were going uninvestigated.

title: Human Rights and Colombia
description: Alvaro Uribe ran for Colombia's presidency promising to crack down on left-wing guerrillas and right-wing paramilitaries while respecting civil rights and the Constitution. New proposals from his government make both promises ring hollow.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SILVERMAN, ROBERT B.
description: SILVERMAN--Robert B. 7/17/ 20-9/20/83. 20 years missing your devoted love & wisdom. 20 years celebrating your inspiring love and strength through your grandchildren.

title: U.S. to Ask Group of 7 to Shift Its Policy on Exchange Rates
description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said yesterday that he would ask the Group of 7 industrialized nations to change its policy for the first time in more than six years and back ''flexible'' currency exchange rates.

title: Hunting Whales
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Starts Linebacker Tradition
description: Harvard linebacker Dante Balestracci sat on the sideline at Franklin Field last November staring at the scoreboard in disbelief and disgust.

title: Jets Focus on Revival Rather Than History
description: This has not been a week for Coach Herman Edwards to give a history lesson to the Jets -- they need to learn some revival techniques.

title: JetBlue Chief's Message to Customers
description: Following is the text of an e-mail message sent by David Neeleman, the chief executive of JetBlue, to customers who complained after the airline provided information about passengers to a Defense Department contractor involved in an antiterrorism project:

title: L.I. Man Dies After Shooting And Stabbing
description: A Lynbrook man was found at his back door early yesterday morning, beaten, shot, and stabbed to death, the police said. Officers are investigating whether his death was connected to a robbery on Thursday night in Rockville Centre, a nearby town on Long Island.

title: A Lack of Trust In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the swearing-in of new United States citizens during a ceremony by the Department of Homeland Security misstated the location. It was the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building, at 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan, not the Javits Convention Center.

title: Coping, One Championship At a Time at Columbine
description: Under the glow of the lights of Jefferson County Stadium tonight, and amid the pomp and cheering and end-around sweeps of what appeared a typical high school football game, the number on decals on backs of the navy blue helmets of the Columbine players was strikingly clear: 70.

title: Fickle Isabel Devastates Parts of Hatteras
description: Hatteras Island is no more. It is several islands now, separated by newly cut inlets, a testament to Hurricane Isabel's deadly force.

title: A Pioneer of Modernism Who's Also Old-Fashioned
description: Not so long ago Pierre Boulez was regarded by many concertgoers as the very symbol of intractable modernism, a composer so committed to Serialism that he applied its ordering techniques not only to pitches, but also to dynamics, note lengths and other compositional elements.

title: Killing Them Softly
description: In fairness to President Bush, he presumably meant well when he cut off funds for some of the world's most vulnerable women.

title: For Heir Accused of Killing, a Loyal and Tough Ally
description: During a decade in which he restlessly wandered the country, losing touch with friends and his influential family, Robert A. Durst had at least one lifeline: his wife, Debrah Lee Charatan.

title: Former Iraqi Defense Minister Turns Himself In to American General
description: The former Iraqi defense minister, who by some accounts ran afoul of Saddam Hussein during the war this spring, turned himself in today, according to the United States Central Command. But his surrender, accepted by an American general with a pointed show of respect, seemed only to add to the mystery surrounding him.

title: Clark Explains Statement on Authorization for Iraq War
description: On the third day of his campaign, Gen. Wesley K. Clark struggled today to clarify his statement on Thursday that he would ''probably'' have voted for the Congressional resolution authorizing the invasion of Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about potential successors to Richard A. Grasso as chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange misstated the titles of two exchange executives, Robert G. Britz and Catherine R. Kinney. They are co-presidents, not acting co-presidents.

title: OxyContin Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: State To Close Youth Home
description: State officials will temporarily close a 120-year-old home for troubled youth in Des Plaines after the suicide of a 14-year-old girl and two reports of sexual attacks among residents. A representative from the Department of Children and Family Services called the home, the Maryville Academy, dysfunctional, saying that it failed to curb fights and rapes and that it provided its 130 residents with substandard care.

title: Storm Passes, Annoyances Linger
description: The Yankees made it here with no problems Thursday, but they still wished they had not tried to play the Baltimore Orioles that day with a hurricane bearing down on Camden Yards. Because the game ended in a five-inning tie after Hideki Matsui threw out a runner at third base, the teams will replay the game as part of a doubleheader at Yankee Stadium at 4:05 p.m. Friday.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ILLINOIS: STATE TO CLOSE YOUTH HOME State officials will temporarily close a 120-year-old home for troubled youth in Des Plaines after the suicide of a 14-year-old girl and two reports of sexual attacks among residents. A representative from the Department of Children and Family Services called the home, the Maryville Academy, dysfunctional, saying that it failed to curb fights and rapes and that it provided its 130 residents with substandard care.

title: Storm or Not, Let the Strutting Begin
description: Outside, winds from Tropical Storm Isabel were whipping down the boardwalk on Thursday night, but inside Boardwalk Hall, Vikki Earp, the mother of Miss North Carolina, was thinking little of the weather. This was about winning.

title: Qaeda Operative Said to Give C.I.A. Inside Information
description: A member of Osama bin Laden's inner circle captured in Thailand last month has provided his C.I.A. interrogators with specifics about plans by Al Qaeda to attack two American-managed hotels in Bangkok, as well as commercial airliners using the international airport there, according to intelligence officials and diplomats from several countries.

title: An Ivy Student, but Only on the Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Expos Reject Splitting Home Games Again in '04
description: Tired of being baseball's traveling sideshow, players on the Montreal Expos voted yesterday to play their entire 81-game home schedule next season in Montreal. They rejected a proposal by Major League Baseball to repeat this year's split schedule, with 22 home games in either San Juan, P.R., or Monterrey, Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FEINMEL, SIDNEY
description: FEINMEL -- Sidney. 9/22/97. Brother, Mentor. Forever in my heart. Time flys but pain is still with me. Love Mychal

title: Margaret Howell, Robin Lawrence Jr.
description: Margaret Billings Howell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Thomas Howell Jr. of Chicago, was married yesterday to Robin Merrill Lawrence Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence of Cohasset, Mass. The Rev. John M. Buchanan performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago.

title: Lira Lee, Jon Cohen
description: Lira Lee, a daughter of Dr. Yong-Yun Lee of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Soon-Sin Lee, was married last evening to Jon Marlowe Cohen, a son of Joseph Meyer Cohen of Manhattan and the late Barbara Weinberg Cohen. Judge Joseph E. Gubbay of the Criminal Court in Brooklyn officiated at the Mark Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, ELAINE
description: KATZ--Elaine. Passed away peacefully on September 17, 2003. Adored by her husband Mel, adorded by her sons, Dr. Howard Katz, and attorney Lloyd Katz; adored by her grandchildren, Sophia and Michael, adored by her daughter-in-law, Wendy Katz. With so much adoration, Marcia and Bob Hill

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE ''Sex and the City'' side of Sarah Jessica Parker was bubbling to the surface way back in the Reagan administration: there she is in FOOTLOOSE (1984), unable to restrain herself from leaping up and dancing, even though such activity has been expressly forbidden by the local clergyman (John Lithgow), who opens the film by preaching a memorable tirade against the evils of rock 'n' roll. Almost everyone in the conservative rural town is following his lead, but lurking in the congregation is Kevin Bacon, a high schooler who has just moved down from Chicago. He sets out to get teenagers dancing again, and with the help of the minister's daughter, played by Lori Singer, and her friend Rusty (Ms. Parker), he succeeds -- Saturday at 10:30 p.m. on TNT.

title: Is It a Happy Birthday for the Blues?
description: CAN a media blitz save the blues? Do the blues need to be saved? And if the blues were to be saved, what would be their 21st-century role?

title: The World; Europe's Money Talks, but Rich Nations Don't Listen
description: SWEDEN'S recent vote to reject adoption of the euro carries a message the founders of Europe's common currency could not have foreseen and cannot welcome: the currency intended to be a catalyst for European unity and rival to the American dollar has become a sort of poor man's tender.

title: Waiting For Spielberg
description: Unlike most urban legends, the one about the Iranian exile stuck at the Paris airport for 15 years is true. Surrounded by a mountain of his possessions near the Paris Bye Bye lounge at Terminal 1 in Charles de Gaulle International Airport, Merhan Karimi Nasseri is still there after all these years -- a celebrity homeless person.

title: Nobles in Coaches, Blood on the Street
description: EVERY eye was on Elizabeth Fondaras as, bejeweled and resplendent in a fox-fur collar and a silk Balmain suit, she stepped from her limousine onto the bloodstained cobblestones of Gansevoort Street. She picked her way over a metal ridge in a concrete floor and into the fanciest showroom in the meatpacking district.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and a picture caption in this section last Sunday about Columbia University's relations with its neighbors referred incorrectly to a residence Columbia is building at 103rd Street and Broadway. It will be faculty housing, not a dormitory.

title: Seeing Gould's Alchemy Up Close
description: HOME video was in its infancy when the Canadian pianist Glenn Gould died in 1982, but had he lived longer, he would unquestionably have embraced video as an extension of what he had been doing for nearly two decades. Gould was as famous for having given up live performance in favor of recordings as he was for his galvanizing interpretations of Bach. Soon after he retired from the stage at 31, in 1964, he began to study the technical side of recording, and he eventually took complete control of his sessions.

title: For Yale Students, City Is Their Oyster
description: BEFORE opening a to-go restaurant in New Haven, Marc Woll cooked for swank restaurants like Le Cirque in Manhattan. In his new place on High Street, called Gastronomique, the cuisine is still haute, but the pace more closely resembles a soup kitchen.

title: Tumbling From the Hip-Hop Heights
description: DRESSED in army green cargo pants and a flouncy white poet's shirt, Derek Khan stood in the study of his modest one-bedroom apartment in West Harlem, showing off a wall of framed photographs, a celebrity-studded monument to the fabled life that was once his.

title: Assault Trial Divides Ground Zero Workers
description: The cleanup of ground zero after the Sept. 11 attack -- widely considered a shining testament to the camaraderie and unity of the many people who worked amid the ruins of the World Trade Center -- also had its ugly disputes. One of them will begin unfolding tomorrow at a trial in Manhattan Criminal Court, several blocks from ground zero.

title: Who Is Equal? What Is Excellent?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Sailmaker's Daughter'
description: Halfway to the dining-room, Olive remembered she should have put on her church frock, because today they were going on a voyage. Not the usual voyage on Dad's little yacht to Nukulau Island for a picnic, but a trip on the steamer to Taveuni. Taveuni was where the Toffs were, and you had to dress up for them. It was seeing Dad that reminded her, going in Grandmother's door. Olive stopped and looked in.

title: Keeping Ancient Egypt Up to The Minute
description: THOUGH ancient Egyptian artists set their sights on eternity, modern-day curators have a much shorter time span in mind. The Brooklyn Museum of Art has recently reinstalled its Egyptian galleries, completing a project that began with the 1993 opening of its galleries of later Egyptian art. The Metropolitan Museum is reworking some of its own stellar holdings, scheduled to open in January. Meanwhile, the third great collection of Egyptian artifacts on the East Coast, at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, has also been updated, with a new gallery devoted to daily life in ancient Egypt. All this commotion and shuffling creates a kind of cognitive dissonance: while these statues gaze out imperturbably across millenniums, curators fret that a display that seemed state-of-the-art only a few years ago now feels dated.

title: Assignment: Homework
description: Did you do your homework?

title: Theodore R. Kupferman, 83, Ex-Congressman and Judge
description: Theodore R. Kupferman, a former city councilman, Republican congressman from the Silk Stocking district and state appellate judge, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Dreamlike Visions of Brutalized Nature
description: A FILIGREE of pipes, chains, wires and rusted steel a huge crane, maybe, or a derelict factory bridge -- laces across the top of the painting, framing mountains and a huge sky. The light is sublime; a golden sunrise or sunset ignites billowing clouds, but the sulfur-yellow clouds could also be dense, poisonous smoke. The hills are barren, fenced off, slag heaps or pyramids of limestone.

title: The Last Word; Will This Be on the Test?
description: Many of us search for a kinder, nobler social world than the one we encountered in high school, only to find the same petty intrigues over and over again. But one aspect of secondary education hardly anyone is in danger of revisiting is the reading list. This month, teenagers across the nation, under the orders of their teachers, crack open books that will offer them their first taste of serious critical reading, of puzzling out an author's theme and hunting the wily symbol. They might read ''Frankenstein'' or ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' and they will almost certainly be assigned ''The Great Gatsby'' -- those works they're likely to return to as adults. But they will also ponder novels they'll never forget but also never re-read, a category you could call the classroom classic; it's the kind of book that never seems to shake off that fine layer of chalk dust.

title: 'An Execution in the Family'
description: IWAS SIX YEARS, ONE MONTH, AND ONE DAY OLD ON MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1953-four days before my parents' execution. That hot June my ten-year-old brother, Michael, and I were living with friends of my parents, Ben and Sonia Bach, in Toms River, New Jersey. I was a thin, dark-haired, olive-skinned child of average height. My face tapered from a high forehead to a somewhat pointed chin. I'm told my most striking feature was brown eyes that were so deep set they often appeared ringed like a raccoon's. I was finishing my kindergarten year at Toms River Elementary School. That summer I played a lot of ball with my brother and several older neighborhood kids in the Bachs' front yard. I was fairly well coordinated: quick with my hands but not particularly nimble on my feet. Better at athletics than most but always not as good as some. It helped having a big brother who looked out for me.

title: Deadly Charge at the Kmart
description: ''Civil War battlefields are touchstones for memory. . . . Photographs of such places are gravestones,'' John Huddleston, a professor of art at Middlebury College, writes in KILLING GROUND: Photographs of the Civil War and the Changing American Landscape (Johns Hopkins University, $35). He has paired archival images of the first modern war with his own, contemporary color shots of the same locations, at the same time of year, at the same time of day. Some sites of suicidal charges have become Kmarts, mini-malls or swamps strewn with metal and plastic trash. The juxtapositions possess surprising power. In an overexposed and damaged archival shot of the Confederate prisoner of war camp at Andersonville, Ga., a filthy crowd of anonymous men packs the frame, while on the facing page Huddleston presents his own fine-tuned image of a muted, borderless sky. For an instant the viewer vaults beyond history and aesthetics to a visceral understanding of what it meant to be a prisoner of war. ''Are physical and spiritual traces of the great slaughter still present in these places?,'' Huddleston asks. The answer is ''Yes.'' Frederick Kaufman

title: 'Pieces of My Mind'
description: In the summer of 1955 I wrote a short book called Romantic Image, published in 1957, inspired largely by love of W. B. Yeats. Yeats was keen on dancers, and the book has a chapter called 'The Dancer', which is partly about the excited response of some fin de siecle poets - English and French, and notably, Mallarme - to dancers, actual, historical and mythical. The object of their admiration might be Salome, the most fascinating of them all, but they could also worship the music-hall dancers of the moment, lavishly courted by poets and reviewers both as performers and as exotically strange women. Dowson and Symons, friends of Yeats, haunted the stage doors. The mysteriously neurotic Jane Avril, familiar from the posters of Toulouse-Lautrec, was one famous name, and there were a good many others, not least among them Loie Fuller, in whom Yeats seems to have had a particular interest.

title: Athens Picks Up the Pace for Olympics
description: With less than a year to go before the 2004 Summer Olympics (Aug. 13 to 29), almost every corner of Athens reflects preparations for the Games and beyond. Two of Athens's best-known hotels, the Grande Bretagne and the Hilton, reopened this spring after renovations and expansions had closed them for several years. The Grande Bretagne (www .grandebretagne.gr) in Syntagma Square was the place to stay for the first modern Olympics, held in Athens in 1896. Now the 327 rooms and suites are again elegant and efficient, the marble lobby gleams. There are indoor and outdoor pools and the spa is scheduled to open to the public by the end of the month, with a hot stone massage attributed to the theories of Hippocrates.

title: Getting It to the Street Just a Little Too Quickly
description: JOHNNY CASH -- For most people who saw Johnny Cash in his last years, his death this month did not come as a surprise. (Listen to his last two CD's or watch the moving video for ''Hurt''; they're all intended to serve as early epitaphs.) Thus, anyone with rights to his music has been working overtime to put it out. In addition to reissues of ''Family Christmas'' and his thematic Sun album ''All Aboard the Blue Train,'' there's a new CD, videotape and DVD of ''A Concert: Behind Prison Walls'' (Eagle Vision), a 1976 various-artists performance from Tennessee State Penitentiary. Musically and historically, the concert is a footnote, though it's worth seeing what a prison-performing pro Mr. Cash was at that point, placing his material firmly in lock-step with the world of the inmates (as opposed to Linda Ronstadt, who sings an ill-advised ''You're No Good'' to them). Of much more interest and importance is ''Live Recordings From the Louisiana Hayride'' (Scena), which includes some of the same songs but was recorded when they were current (as early as 1955), and in some cases, before they were hits.

title: Ingres's Nude May Be Lost, But Her Afterimage Lingers

But the painting in a daguerreotype on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, starting on Tuesday, disappeared some 150 years ago. And had it not been for the invention of photography, the charming, somnolent creature in the painting, posed like one of Titian's Venuses, might have vanished forever.

Preceded in death by his parents and older brother, Robert Crumpton Willson, he is survived by his wife, Barbara of San Diego; daughter, Harper of Walnut Creek, CA; stepson, Bradley Brunson, and his wife, Linda, of Jacksonville Beach, FL; stepdaughter, Jamie Brunson, and her husband, Mark Levy, of Oakland, CA; half-brother, Lloyd ''Toni'' of East Norwalk, CT, and others. title: Children's Books; Lonely Guys
description: When someone says ''tanuki,'' how do you respond? ''You're welcome''? ''I don't dance''? ''Gesundheit''? The real tanuki is a small Japanese mammal, something between a badger and a raccoon. Traditionally thought to be able to assume human form, it is reportedly fond of practical jokes and trouble-making. The tanuki in Tim Myers's story TANUKI'S GIFT: A Japanese Tale (Marshall Cavendish, $16.95; ages 5 to 8), illustrated by R. G. Roth, is cut from a different cloth. One icy night, it calls at the hut of a Buddhist priest, begging shelter. Disregarding the creature's reputation for mischief, the lonely priest offers his hospitality. For years they winter together. Eventually, the tanuki asks what it can do in recompense, and the priest reluctantly admits that three gold coins would buy prayers for his soul to enter Paradise. The tanuki takes its leave. The priest waits and waits, but by the time the tanuki returns, he no longer wants the gold, having learned instead a valuable lesson about friendship. The tale is adroitly told, but the real highlights are Richard Roth's mixed-media collages, a playground of cross-cultural references and Japanese influences from ink painting to paper decoration. The rounded priest in rainbow robes contrasts appealingly with the lithe, scratchy tanuki in black and white. A complement of objects both familiar and mysterious adorns the well-textured settings, and a great sense of whimsy pervades all: watch the tanuki juggle, capering like a river otter; see the priest imagine himself ascending to heaven, wearing a halo and carried by an umbrella, like Mary Poppins. Myers, whose two previous books are set in Japan and Hawaii, notes that he's more interested in telling a story than in elaborating a cultural tradition, and this story is more about universal values of friendship than about either Buddhism or the tanuki. More important, it is lovely and entertaining, and the tanuki, rarely known for repaying generosity in kind, certainly couldn't ask for a better ambassador. Bruno Navasky

title: Testing Handicaps
description: SAT scores are up again, to their highest average since 1974. And no one's happy. Conservatives point to the large, growing gap between the scores of white students and the scores of non-Asian minorities: the white-black gap was 187 points 10 years ago, 206 points today; Mexican-Americans trailed whites by 127 points in 1993 and are now 158 points back. Liberals point to the correlation between scores and income: a combined 864 for test takers from households making under $10,000, 1,123 for kids from households making $100,000 and up -- a differential of 259 points over $90,000, just as if you were to award students an SAT point for every $350 their parents take home.

She is survived by her beloved daughter, Eliza Xiaoli Halle Cowen; her brother, Arthur (Tony) Cowen III; her sisters, Prue Bach Mortimer, and Lorie Cowen Levy, her stepbrother, John Angelo; and her stepfather, Julian Bach. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, September 23, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Interment will be private. title: CRIME

Never mind that the tricky plot tries to cover every criminal enterprise in the state of Louisiana, from the homegrown porn movies that Fat Sammy Figorelli films in New Orleans and the sale of liquor to minors from drive-by daiquiri stores in New Iberia to the wholesale dumping of petrochemical waste in the bayous of St. James Parish. In Burke's grim vision, there's a classic unity to all this unsavory stuff, once you trace the wholesale disregard for human life and dignity to its historic roots on the plantations of greedy slave owners and in hellholes like the Angola penitentiary, the last known residence of a legendary R & B guitarist named Junior Crudup.

title: Why, Isn't He Just the Cutest Brand-Image Enhancer You've Ever Seen?
description: The Extreme skate park in downtown Louisville, Ky., sits between a loop of interstate highway and the headquarters of a grain company whose sign reads ''Producer Feeds -- Since 1869.'' The park looks a little like a homemade Hot Wheels track, something a resourceful toy-deprived child might make out of flour-and-water paste. It has every feature a skateboarder could want, though. The city of Louisville, which opened the park a little more than a year ago, is hoping to attract ESPN's X Games to the city, and maybe other skateboarding competitions, which used to be scruffy, outsiderish sorts of things and are now widely popular and potentially lucrative. So the park has a 24-foot full pipe, two 11-foot bowls, two 8-foot bowls, two 4-foot bowls, a vert ramp and a fun box with grinding ledges -- all smooth and undulating, made of unpainted and slightly scuffed concrete.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. A scooter dressed up in chrome brightwork can mean only one thing: ''You got a guy into Mod,'' says George Russo, the owner of the Bella Classica scooter shop, a garage and storefront for vintage Vespas in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. For customers who want to cruise in the style of the 1960's British youth subculture, Russo customizes scooters with imported parts to recreate the Mod's trademark ride, like the Vespa pictured here. ''In my world,'' Russo says, ''Mod is modification.'' This winter, the scooter shop moves to Manhattan, where Russo plans an on-site clothing boutique and a restaurant. ''Don't worry,'' he says, ''you're not going to smell two-stroke oil when you're eating your panini.'' Call (718) 486-0500.

Many of the Federal houses, most of them now expensively restored with new cedar roofs and freshly painted white picket fences, still took in roomers or housed a solitary widow or the enfeebled survivor of an old whaling family: a few still do. In those days, The East Hampton Star never referred to Sag Harbor without a wink and a snicker, a subtle warning to its respectable readers that a visit to the disreputable old whaling port entailed the risk of public exposure.

She is survived by her loving daughters in-law Ann, Cathy, Jean, and Pat as well as sons in-law, Ken, Paddy, Peter and Kevin. She is mourned by her 24 grandchildren; Shelia, Mary, Rita, Christine, Kenneth, Maureen, Brian, Meaghan, Vincent, Tara, Brendan, PJ, Jamie, Kevin, Colleen, Kelly, Kathleen, Kristine, Regina, Caitlin, Tara, Patrick, Katie, and Sean and five greatgrandchildren. She was a loving aunt to Noreen O'Brien, Nancy Murtha, Thomas and Gerald Spellman. Her loss will be felt by countless other relatives, neighbors and friends. She graduated from Cathedral Girls HS and studied nursing at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was the President of Manhattan College Ladies auxiliary, former Volunteer Commissioner of Girl Scouting for Bronx County, and a very active member of various Church organizations beginning at Sacred Heart in Highbridge, Our Lady of Angels and St. Margaret of Cortona. Well into her eighties she took on the task of directing one of the chapters of Mothers of Priests. She was also predeceased by her loving parents William and Catherine Kitt (nee Farrell) and her sister Ann Spellman. Her wake will be held Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45 AM Monday at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven. In lieu of flowers send roses. She loved them as she did life.

But at a little before 10 p.m. on a recent Friday night, the place is thick with spirituality. Small clusters of bearded men bob furiously in prayer, while a smattering of women watch from behind the plexiglass in the balcony above.

Monkeys rarely refuse food, but in this case they appear to be pursuing an even higher value than eating: fairness.

After escaping from a chain gang and picking up a solitary blues guitarist (the producer Timbaland) -- at a crossroads (natch) -- Bubba and his hillbilly boys make their way to a dilapidated dirt-road shack. When they enter, they're turn-of-the-century bluesmen on the run. When they emerge, their clothes have changed from workaday coveralls to the baggy shorts and sneakers of contemporary hip-hop. The scene and the time frame have shifted, but the message conveyed by the imagery is the same: poverty is fertile creative turf, and the South has had more than its share.

title: The Week Ahead; BUSH AT THE U.N.
description: President Bush goes to the General Assembly of the United Nations on Tuesday to call for more aid for Iraq and stiffer rules to keep nations like North Korea and Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons. In meetings with the leaders of Europe and other regions, Mr. Bush will make the case that past differences over the wisdom of invading Iraq must now be set aside, and that Europe in particular has an interest in transforming the country into a working democracy. David E. Sanger

title: From Ruin to Restoration: Stone Walls, Shored Up
description: THE stone wall running along Route 9 in Tarrytown is crumbling. At one spot, right next to a bus stop, the wall has toppled and the boulders are piled in a heap. In other places, tree roots are undermining the wall and stones are buckling toward the roadway, just five feet away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINKIN, DAVID
description: MINKIN--David. The Board of Trustees, the Administration, Medical Staff and employees of Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center mourn the loss of David Minkin, our beloved President Emeritus. Founder, builder, benefactor and friend, he was an extraordinary and spirited individual who, for many years, was the patriarch of the Kingsbrook family. During his long life, just shy of 100 years of age, he touched many of us as we hope we touched him. We honor him for his many years of devotion, dedicated service and generous support of the Medical Center and will keep his memory and legacy alive. We extend our sincerest and heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. We shall all miss him. Linda Brady, M.D. President and CEO Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center

Baird of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Dr. William H. Littleton, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the vacation home of the bride's parents in Sea Island, Ga.

description: Sara Dian Clinton and Truman Mallory Curtis were married yesterday by the Rev. Michael R. Moynihan, at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Modest Touch of Green Makes Vendors See Red
description: Giant planters are sprouting along the cobblestone streets of SoHo. But their purpose, street vendors say, is neither to make the sidewalks pretty, nor to safeguard the Chanel handbags, nor to stop terrorists from careering into landmark buildings.

title: Pakistan, a Troubled Ally
description: Pakistan was not directly involved in the events of 9/11, but its international standing and the reputation of its leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, were thoroughly transformed in the wake of the terrorist attacks two years ago. By abruptly switching sides in Afghanistan and letting Washington use Pakistani bases to fight the Taliban, General Musharraf managed, in weeks, to lift Pakistan's status in Washington from pariah to strategic partner.

title: Bushel of Ifs and Maybes As Jets Survey 0-2 Season
description: In the halcyon days of training camp, offensive tackle Kareem McKenzie talked about the toll a slow start took on the Jets last season. They expended so much energy and endured so much stress simply to get back to .500, he said, that they were weary mentally and physically by the time they got to Oakland for the playoff game that ended their season.

description: Florida State 47, Colorado 7

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOCHHAUSER, MARSHALL
description: HOCHHAUSER--Marshall. At this very special time of the year, we remember the joy of our years together; how very much you remain a part of our lives, and our love that never fades. May Marshall, Mae, Sophie and Emily follow in the steps of your honored path. Love, Joyce, David, Scott and Beth

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: MIDDLESEX, by Jeffrey Eugenides. (Picador, $15.) Epic in spirit, scope and structure, this exuberant novel turns on the remarkable identity crisis of its Greek-American narrator, Calliope Stephanides, who discovers at the age of 14 that she is a hermaphrodite. How that gene found its home is traced through three generations, from immigrants who escape the Turkish massacre of Greeks in Smyrna in 1922 to their children and grandchildren, who end up in Detroit. Among many other things, the tale, which was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2002, explores the tug of war between destiny and free will. ''It is a colossal act of curiosity, of imagination and of love,'' Laura Miller said in these pages.

title: Corrections

description: PEOPLE'S BANK of Bridgeport is big: $12 billion in assets, 150 branches statewide and 3,800 employees. Imperial Spring Company of Southington, a family-owned manufacturer of industrial parts, is small, with 36 workers and about $3 million in annual revenue.

description: SCHWEIG--Ruth Keller. 81, lifelong Bronx resident, died peacefully on August 23, 2003, in her home in Boulder, CO. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Group of 7's Economic Officials Urge Reopening of Trade Talks
description: On a day that included discussions ranging from terrorist financing to disclosures of questionable uses of public funds by the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, representatives of the Group of Seven richest nations called for the resumption of world trade talks and a global commitment to market-based exchange rates for currencies.

title: Checking on the Safety Of Pets on Planes
description: In response to concerns about the safety of pets traveling aboard airlines, the Federal Aviation Administration adopted a rule last month that will require airlines to submit monthly reports on the loss, injury or death of an animal during transport.

title: Legislators Offer Proposal To Clean Up Reservoir
description: County legislators met on Monday to address an impasse stalling efforts to clean up the New Croton Reservoir, a drinking water source for 900,000 New York City and 45,000 Westchester county residents.

title: Indonesia Bans Foreign Aid Workers From Embattled Province
description: The province of Aceh, where the United Nations estimates that 100,000 people have been displaced as a result of fighting there, is without any foreign aid workers because Indonesia has refused to give them permits, say officials with the United Nations and other organizations.

title: INVESTING WITH: David L. King; Putnam New Value Fund
description: DAVID L. KING, lead manager of the $1.2 billion Putnam New Value fund, describes his style as ''earnings power investing'' -- finding companies that are cheap based on his estimates of their future earnings power.

title: IRAQIS' NEW ARMY GETS SLOW START
description: The mock attack begins with whistles, because the new Iraqi army needs to conserve its blanks.

title: Over The Store
description: It sounded like the most fabulous trip in the world, and I blame my mother. Sleep above arguably the best store in the free world, 10 Corso Como.

title: The Actors Play Agents Who Have to Be Actors
description: He'd be nicer, maybe, but who's got the time? His name is Joe Renato, and he is what's known as a handler, a person who trains and manages undercover agents for the F.B.I. Played by Joe Pantoliano, who is up for an Emmy tonight for his work in ''The Sopranos,'' Renato works out of a beat-up '84 Bonneville that doubles as a props department, speeding around Los Angeles like a dervish, tending to the needs of his crew of impostors as they enact the deadly masquerades that shape the story lines of ''The Handler,'' a new CBS series that has its premiere on Friday night at 10.

title: One Resignation Is Not Enough
description: The resignation of Richard A. Grasso as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange has created a once-in-a-generation opportunity to improve the exchange's commitment and ability to serve the public interest. But if the board and management of the exchange close ranks and resist further change, investors will know that they can expect business as usual in the post-Grasso era.

title: Habitats/Gramercy Park; Weekend Home, Via the Elevator
description: AFTER work most Friday evenings, Bernice Shaftan, a shoe designer and trend consultant, and Dr. Gerald Shaftan, a trauma surgeon, pack an overnight bag and some necessaries -- orange juice, a carton of milk, maybe two steaks -- and head off to their weekend home. They leave their seven-room apartment on the 11th floor of 60 Gramercy Park North, get on the elevator -- and ride up to their 18th-floor penthouse.

title: Simply Seafood
description: This summer seems to be ending before it began, but endless summer awaits at these places that have been inspired by the humble fish shack.

title: The First Duck in Space? That Is So Daffy
description: FIFTY years after first rocketing into space, Duck Dodgers, hapless defender of the oppressed, returned to television last month and can now be seen on Cartoon Network on Saturdays at 11:30 a.m.

title: At a New Spot, Tapas With a Twist
description: LUPO is a new place in Chester with a great menu. The food is largely traditional, inspired by the cuisines of the Mediterranean -- southern French, Italian, Moroccan and Spanish -- along with some Caribbean and South American influences.

title: It's Not Quite Cinema Paradiso At a Film Series In a Cemetery
description: Four years ago, Vivian Germano buried her husband in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, where her grandparents were buried. Two years later, she buried her father there. With its historic tombstones and rolling green hills, she thought, Green-Wood was a tranquil setting to mourn her family and look after their graves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PURSEL, STEWART E., M.D.
description: PURSEL--Stewart E., M.D. September 27, 1930-September 18, 2003. Survived by wife Mary Louise, son Tom, daughter Linda, six grandchildren and sister Joan. Graduated Mercersburg Academy '48, Princeton University '52 and Yale Medical School '56. Chief of Thoracic Surgery at four Detroit hospitals including William Beaumont, where he passed of cancer. A man of integrity, compassion and a skilled surgeon, he will be cherished always.

title: Stamford Horse Farm Put on Market
description: A95-ACRE horse farm once owned by Marylou Whitney, the widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, went on the market last week for $24.5 million, raising concerns among neighbors that developers will be the only ones able to afford it at that price.

title: 'The Little Women'
description: Joanna and Amy left home in the fall of their older sister Meg's junior year at Yale. Meg had already gone ahead to New Haven three days earlier in her car-the family's old green Subaru wagon, which had been her Warren Prep graduation present (along with a trip to France). There would have been no room for Joanna and Amy had they wanted to drive up with her. The car was crammed to capacity with boxes and duffel bags and computers, Amy's music stand (she played the flute), and also her art supplies, including the drafting table, the base of which took up an annoying amount of cargo space. Their three bicycles had been awkwardly tied onto the roof rack with the assistance of Mike the doorman, whose helpful intentions were as genuine as his knot-making skills were poor.

title: Unleashing Creativity at the Waterfront
description: PICTURE a community awaking one morning to find itself in sudden possession of dozens of acres of land on the open waterfront, with the community free to develop it and play with it at will. It's a megabucks lottery win, and it is also the current reality in a good portion of the Hudson Valley.

title: Selling Your Sex Life
description: As an avid fan of ''Coupling,'' I was dismayed to hear that there will be an American version (Adam Sternbergh, Sept. 7). The smartest action NBC could have taken would have been to broadcast the show as is, with the British cast. Americans would have enjoyed this show as much as they have ''Monty Python's Flying Circus,'' ''Fawlty Towers,'' ''Benny Hill'' and ''Mr. Bean.'' If the American ''Coupling'' lasts a season, I will be astonished. Why have skim milk when you could have cream?

title: Giant Elephants and Lumberjacks Can Be Neighborly
description: BEFORE going to bed at night, Joseph and Joshua Buck take one last glance out their window for that reassuring view -- the swish of tail sweeping across the giant rear end of Lucy the Elephant.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Tough Road for Irish

title: Road Rage
description: When the Nascar superstar Jeff Gordon split with his wife last year, race fans in America's Bible Belt never expected their hero to change lanes and pull into New York's party circuit. But since parting with the missus -- a former Winston spokesmodel -- Gordon has been living it up in the Hamptons, dining in SoHo and socializing with bona fide models. He was even spotted trying to crash a fashionable party at a downtown bar (he didn't get in).

title: State Gives Museum $5 Million
description: ARENOVATION and expansion plan that would more than double the size of the New Britain Museum of American Art took a giant step toward reality last week when Connecticut donated $5 million for the project.

description: Tights are back, complementing this season's hemlines while fending off chilled knees (and looking especially smart in vivid hues, as shown at Chlo and Marc Jacobs). Whether striped, solid or sheer, here are what lucky legs will be wearing this fall. STEPHANIE HUSZAR

description: FLETCHER -- Sophie Knoll. Age 92. Wife of the late Jack; mother of Paul, mother-inlaw of Janet, grandmother of Jordan and the late Jenny, sister of the late Jack, Sam, Max, Rose and Frieda. A strong woman with a strong sense of family.

title: Romania Survives, but It Falls Behind in Europe
description: The river comes to an end in a shipping canal that extends a few miles into the Black Sea from this town in Romania, about 1,750 miles and perhaps 50 years of elapsed history from where it begins, in Donaueschingen in the Black Forest.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bedford-Stuyvesant; Brownstones by the Tree-Lined Block
description: TWO colonial villages, Bedford and Stuyvesant, long ago merged to form one Brooklyn neighborhood, but in some ways, the place that took both villages' names remains two communities, represented by $500,000 brownstones to the south and public housing towers in the north.

title: Inside and Out
description: Seventh on Sixth celebrated 10 years under the tents in Bryant Park last week. The once private fashion shows used to be held in crammed designer showrooms and hotel ballrooms. Today, they are a spectacle that starts at the sidewalk entrance, with young designers parading models, hawkers giving away products and self-promoters strutting their stuff. The scene included (clockwise from bottom left): poodles for Damrak gin; free Lacoste pillows; free Gap sweaters; and free Gap tote bags. A Jackie Kennedy look-alike plugged her one-woman show. Inside a tent, Patricia Hearst Shaw and family applauded Lydia Hearst-Shaw's runway debut. Fashion brass attend the Sunday shows with their children. Seen on the best-dressed guests (interior photos): a 50's revival, the one-piece dress with a zipper up the back, worn with spidery heels and flats.

description: HERBSTMAN--Mandel. Gone, but words and wit always remain. Love, Vera

title: Coin Collector
description: Providing both flash and function, the new Flatiron messenger bag by Coach comes in taxi-yellow canvas with leather trim and satin nickel hardware. The carryall has pockets for a cellphone, a PalmPilot, pens and business cards. There's a leather handle as well as a shoulder strap. The bag is 15 by 11 inches, costs $328, and includes a built-in key ring that minimizes fumbling at the door. The Flatiron is also available in black or parchment.

title: The Golden Rule in a Gray Area Called Business
description: IT'S tough to argue with the golden rule without sounding like a misanthrope. What's not to like about the ethics of reciprocity?

title: Building Pressure Slowly, Then Moving In for the Kill
description: The Pan-American Continental Championship in Buenos Aires, Aug. 16 to 30, ended in a tie for first place between the grandmasters Giovanni Vescovi of Brazil and Alexander Goldin of the United States. Each scored 8 1/2 points in the 11-round, 151-player Swiss-system tournament.

title: As Scandals Still Flare, Small Victories for Investors
description: NEVER mind the $140 million paid to Richard A. Grasso for his work as a casino greeter. Never mind the hypocrisy of the New York Stock Exchange directors giving Mr. Grasso his money and then booting him for taking it. The big shocker in the Grasso imbroglio may be that two years after Enron, almost a year and a half after WorldCom and long after corporate America told us that we were through with scandals and back on ethical ground, anyone who turns over a corporate rock can still find the earth crawling with maggots.

title: Marisa Levine, Todd Marlin

title: Corrections
description: An article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday about subdividing properties in Greenwich referred incorrectly to a broker who commented on the subdivision potential of a 10-acre estate that is for sale for $29 million. The broker is Dee Weber, not Don.

title: 'A Mighty Heart'
description: Dawn will rise soon over Karachi. Curled in Danny's warm embrace, I feel safe. I like that this position is called "spooning" in English. We are like spoons in a drawer, pressed to each another, each fitted to the other's shape. I love these sweet moments of oblivion and the peace they bring me. No matter where we are - Croatia, Beirut, Bombay - this is my shelter. This is our way of meeting the challenge, of confronting the chaos of the world.

title: Dining Where the Ingredients Are the Island's Bounty
description: AS savvy travelers we seek out the local wines and foods of the regions we visit. Yet, back home on Long Island we routinely put up with restaurants that serve plastic-tasting tomatoes that have made the journey from the West Coast; seafood that hails from tropical waters or, worse, spent last night in the freezer, and wines from foreign countries or distant states. Ignoring the local bounty is especially nonsensical at this time of year when local farm stands are overflowing with just-picked produce. Also baffling are East End restaurants, in the heart of the wine country, that don't have a single Long Island wine on their lists.

title: The Nation; The Deficit Disappeared, but That Was Then
description: A decade ago, concern over the country's budget deficits dominated political and economic debates, just as it does now. Many of the same people who now worry that a fiscal disaster is on the horizon envisioned a similar catastrophe in the early 1990's.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Commercial Developers Start to Discover East Lyme
description: THIS town, situated on the shore and at the confluence of Interstates 395 and 95, has promoted itself in recent years as the gateway to southeastern Connecticut. Now it appears that developers are starting to listen.

title: Corrections
description: The Food column on Aug. 17, about the hot dog, misspelled a common name for it inspired by Vienna, where some of the earliest versions were made. It is wiener, not weiner.

title: Nilmini Gunaratne, Joel Rubin
description: Nilmini Gunaratne and Joel Martin Rubin were married last evening by Rabbi Michael Stanger at Bacon House in Washington. Earlier in the day, Kumar Herath, a friend of the bride's family, led a Sri Lankan cultural celebration, also at Bacon House.

title: The Secret Love Affair Behind the 'Lyric Suite'
description: ALBAN BERG'S ''Lyric Suite,'' newly recorded on Nonesuch by the Kronos Quartet and Dawn Upshaw, is vivid testimony to the power and mystery of musical expression. Its emotional force is apparent on first hearing, yet the connection between its visceral effect in performance and the biographical facts and musical techniques that went into its making seems to grow ever more mysterious.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: It was therapy for me to see your photograph (Sept. 7) of Julianna Martin. I'm 71 and have been allergic to floral chemical odors all my life. Last month I flew to Ireland with trepidation, not because I feared terrorists but because I feared being seated near someone wearing perfume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, JACOB
description: WEISS--Jacob. Of New York City. Born January 1, 1917, died September 18, 2003. Beloved husband of Gertrude for 58 years. Caring father of Diane and Mark. Grandfather to Simone, uncle to Dee and Donald, and brother to the late Evelyn and Max. He will be remembered fondly by those who were customers of Clark Stores in Jackson Heights for 70 years. Missed terribly by those who had the pleasure of knowing him and most especially by his family who loved him. Services Sunday at 1 PM, Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills, NY.

title: With a Big Victory, Japanese Premier Gains Momentum
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was re-elected leader of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party today in a decisive victory that could give him renewed momentum to push through reforms in the world's second largest economy and to keep nudging the country toward a more muscular role internationally.

title: Please Pass the Salt (and the Terrorism)
description: CONSIDERING all the superheated verbiage tossed around in ''Omnium Gatherum,'' a dark comedy that touches on such pressing issues as faith, ''Star Trek'' and the true meaning of the word vegan, it's probably not surprising that the two authors say their writing process most closely resembled a late-night undergraduate bull session.

title: A Change of Tone: Pitfalls Emerge in Iraq
description: By the standards of a White House that insists that nearly everything at all times is proceeding precisely according to plan, and where misjudgment is typically held to be a stranger, the last few weeks have brought a new, unvarnished tone.
