title: Rules Of The Road
description: No. 1: At a stop sign, you must come to a complete halt so that you can style your hair.

title: The Nation: Golden Rules; As California Goes, So Goes the Country?
description: MORE than 60 years ago, the columnist Westbrook Pegler, noting California's penchant for political experimentation and social turmoil, proposed that a guardian should be appointed and the state declared incompetent to manage its own affairs. Last week, California's recall election drama led the columnist George F. Will to call it ''the sick man of the Republic.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HARTE, STANLEY J.
description: HARTE--Stanley J. Adoring and devoted son, brother, husband, father, great and grandfather, nephew, uncle and friend. You have so greatly influenced our lives. Hope you and Sissy are happy together. Ten years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, ANDREW MEYER
description: ADLER -- Andrew Meyer. Passed away tragically on Sept. 17, 2003. Born August 31, 1952. Beloved companion of Dale Goday. Adored son of Mort and Sunny. Dearly loved brother of Kiva and Bil. Caring nephew, cousin, and respected friend of many. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91 St, Monday, September 22, 9:30AM.

title: Hotel California
description: To the Editor: ''San Francisco's Woes a Boon for Visitors'' (Correspondent's Report, Aug. 31), showed a decrease in prices for hotel rooms in San Francisco. During dot-com days, even the price of hotels in San Jose, south of San Francisco were obscene. A room at the hotel nearest the San Jose airport jumped from $79 to $470 a night. In response our company limited business trips from San Diego to the area to day trips.

description: JOHN WINTHROP

title: 'John Winthrop'
description: October 1498. Adam Winthrop was carrying his infant son, the next Adam, from his home to the church of Saints Peter and Paul sitting on the hill overlooking the prosperous town of Lavenham. There he would present the baby to the parish priest, Thomas Appleton, to be baptized according to the rites of the Catholic Church. Accompanying Adam were some of his friends from the parish, perhaps including members of the prominent Lavenham families, the Springs, the Risbys, and the Ponders. Jane Burton Winthrop, young Adam's mother, was left lying in at home, denied entry into the holy precincts of the church until she was purified in a rite that usually came about a month after the childbirth.

description: This was Wesley K. Clark at his best.

title: 'The Miss Stone Affair'
description: By the time the American consul general, Charles Dickinson, reached Sofia, the Bulgarian capital was full of foreign journalists. Six thousand miles and an ocean to the west, the American public had awakened from its trance of mourning. Leon Czolgosz, the President's assassin, had been found to be acting alone, quieting fears that anarchists were about to seize the levers of government. The press was now fully alive to the possibilities of Miss Stone.

title: Why Are We in Iraq? (And Liberia? And Afghanistan?)
description: Ignatieff's theme is historical precedent, but he seems to forget that terrorism of the sort that led to Sept. 11 is unprecedented. Stateless, fueled by helplessness and the rage it engenders, armed with modern technology and, finally, the overwhelming power of the suicide bomber, it defies the ideas, descriptions and strategies with which scholars like Ignatieff and politicians like George Bush and Ariel Sharon answer threats to national security and identity.

title: China's Strange Hybrid Economy
description: FROM the popcorn stands at the amusement park to the jewelry stores of the Mongkok shopping district, many retailers here post the exchange rate they offer for purchases made with mainland China's currency, the yuan. That makes life convenient for the flood of mainland tourists arriving now that Beijing has relaxed visa restrictions, but not for China's central bank.

title: 'Eve in the City'
description: They say the city never sleeps. It does. Just before dawn you can hear it snore. Light hangs in the air, directionless, not yet pressed into rays. The smell of a hidden sea soaks through stone. The streets themselves have that booming emptiness of a shell held to the ear. Everyone is dreaming. It's when I began to wander, that time in between. I had been in New York a year, and even though I worked until five, five in the morning, still I couldn't close my eyes. I had the urgent sense something was happening, something important, the very reason I had come here in the first place. I felt there was a secret structure to the city, a true form, and if I gave myself up to it, became one with the seeming chaos, then I could master it and, I don't know, attain magical powers, become who I was destined to be. I was seventeen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHRISTMAN, HENRY M., PH.D.
description: CHRISTMAN -- Henry M., Ph.D. 71, of Manhattan, died on August 18, 2003. Active in both government and publishing, Dr. Christman served in the administrations of Mayor John Lindsay as Director of the City Record, under Governor Hugh Carey as a Member of the Worker's Compensation Board, as well as serving under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. His most notable governmental achievement was the work done for the Worker's Compensation Board from 1977 to 1984. During that time, he adjudicated approximately 25,000 cases on appeal and jointly administered about $1 billion annually in insurance benefits. Among the many books he edited and wrote introductions for are ''The South as it Is 1865-1866,'' a collection of articles by John R. Dennett that first appeared in The Nation, published by Viking Press 1965, and more than several other works: ''The Public Papers of Chief Justice Earl Warren,'' Simon and Schuster, 1959, ''Walter Reuther--Selected Papers,'' The Macmillan Company, 1961, ''This is Our Strength-The Selected Papers of Golda Meir,'' The Macmillan Company, 1962; ''Walt Whitman's New York,'' The Macmillan Company, 1963, and for the New American Library, 1966, ''The American Journalism of Marx and Engels.'' Some of these titles are still available from other publishers. He continued to publish until not long before his death. For all the heft of his other works, probably his most widely read book was ''Mahout,'' an original fable that received not only international attention, but an award from an organization of Christians and Jews for its celebration of the triumph of good over evil. He is survived by his companion of 48 years, Abraham Feldman. There will be a memorial service on Friday, October 17, at the Religious Society of Friends, 15 Rutherford Place on Stuyvesant Square, Manhattan. A reception starting at 6 PM, will be followed by an informal Friends service.

title: On the Road

In the 50's, Jack Kerouac drove across America, defining the beat generation along the way. And today, there's almost no one alive who is not on the move -- on the ground, in the air -- a phenomenon we wish to celebrate not only for the fun and adventure, but also for the requisite style involved in getting from here to there.

title: Gods and Heroes; Sure, Bonds Is No Mays. But Mays Wouldn't Be Mays Today.
description: HISTORY tells us that sports records are made to be broken, but history also tells us that many of the men and women who do the breaking are destined to be scorned. In baseball, some players have been lucky enough to top the records of unpopular figures, as Pete Rose was when he cracked the mark for career hits held by Ty Cobb, a man with a temperament so foul he was despised by many of his own teammates. Others, like Hank Aaron when he out-homered a hugely popular player, Babe Ruth, are greeted with hate mail and even death threats.

They are also lost in their marriages, lost in their lives. Then, of course, there is the simple matter of language.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: JANITORS' UNION CHIEF RE-ELECTED Workers in the region's largest janitors' union overwhelmingly re-elected Michael Fishman to a new three-year term as president, the union announced on Friday. The union said Mr. Fishman received 84 percent of the 18,000 votes cast. Mr. Fishman heads Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, which represents 70,000 janitors, doormen, elevator operators and repair workers in apartment buildings and office towers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Mr. Fishman was named trustee of the local in 1999 after the parent union forced out the previous president, Gus Bevona. Mr. Fishman then was elected to his first full three-year term in 2000. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: I Was a Middle-Aged Anosmic
description: I CAN clearly recall the first time I nibbled corn on the cob in rural New Jersey, my first meaty lobster on Cape Cod and when I first bit into a crunchy chimichanga in southern Arizona. Pleasurable taste sensations like these stay in one's memory for a lifetime. Then, about two years ago, I had a nasty virus that left me with a cough, and when that subsided I realized that the food I was eating had no flavor, only texture. At times it seemed as though I had metallic residue in my mouth.

title: The Tyranny of Robert Mugabe
description: In The Daily News of Zimbabwe readers could follow the long, cheerless saga of President Robert Mugabe's slide into dictatorship. But the most telling illustration of Zimbabwe's decline is the case of the newspaper itself. The four-year-old daily, the only one not controlled by the government, has been bombed twice, its staff and distributors beaten and harassed, its founding editor driven into exile. Now the government has closed the paper, using undemocratic laws to extinguish one of the last embers of free speech in Zimbabwe.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Animal-Cruelty Law Sought
description: The Westchester County district attorney and two legislators said they would urge the passage of legislation making animal cruelty an easier crime to prosecute. The action follows the death of hundreds of animals last month in a Mount Vernon pet store that was abandoned. The five people held responsible could be charged only with misdemeanors, said District Attorney Jeanine F. Pirro, above. Under current law, intentional cruelty must be shown in order to pursue more serious charges, she said. Nicholas A. Spano, a state senator, and Amy Paulin, a state assemblywoman, said they plan to introduce legislation making the killing of an animal in a way that is likely to cause extreme pain a felony punishable by up to four years in prison. In addition, a misdemeanor animal cruelty charge would be upgraded to a felony when 10 or more animals are involved. Marek Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAFFEL, MAX
description: TAFFEL--Max. 94, died September 19, 2003, at the Yale New Haven Hospital, where he had been a surgeon for 46 years. He was a graduate of the College of the City of New York and the Yale School of Medicine, 1931. He received the Bronze Star Medal for meritorious service as the only neurosurgeon on the island of Saipan from 27 January 1945 to 1 August 1945, during the period of the Iwo Jima and Okinawa campaigns. Dr. Taffel's lifetime goals were ''to be an honest surgeon and a devoted father, to instill the joy of learning into the hearts and minds of all the young people with whom he came into contact, and to do harm to no one.'' He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Helen Southon Taffel, sons, James of Barre, VT, William of Tokyo, Japan, and David of Watertown, MA, and daughters Ann Hutchings of Anchorage, AK, Margaret Hodge of Belvidere, IL, and Sarah Taffel of Wilton, CT. He is also survived by 15 grandchildren. He was predeceased by his daughter Katherine Ellen Taffel. There will be no visiting hours. A family service will be celebrated at a future date. Gifts in his memory may be sent to the Katherine Taffel Scholarship Fund at The Neighborhood Music School, 100 Audubon St, New Haven, CT 06510.

title: Tough Guys, Or Big Babies? How Real Men Deal With Pain
description: HEARD the one about the husband who agrees to be hooked up to a machine that transfers the pain of childbirth from the laboring mother to the father? The doctor sets the dial at 10 percent pain level, and the man feels nothing. Thirty percent, again nothing. Fifty percent, ha! not a tickle. Finally, the doctor cranks the dial to full-bore, pass-a-pachyderm-through-a-keyhole stage, and still the fellow shrugs smugly and says: ''Feh! I've had worse pain from clipping my toenails.''

title: Reaping the Myriad Whims and Quirks of Aretha Franklin
description: Aretha Franklin works by her own regal whims. On Saturday night at Radio City Music Hall, she operated in a realm far removed from most performers' attempts to please a crowd: a realm of long memory, odd caprices and ambivalence about the confines of pop. Listeners are welcome to admire the way her voice dives into sultriness, dodges the beat, cascades through long melismas or rushes heavenward. But where most soul and rhythm-and-blues turns listeners into a congregation, Ms. Franklin leaves them on the sidelines as spectators.

title: Iraqi Leaders to Press Congress For Control Over Rebuilding
description: In a 6,000-mile end run around American and British occupation authorities, leaders from the Iraqi Governing Council say they will go to Congress this week to argue that American taxpayers could save billions of dollars on Iraq's reconstruction by granting sovereignty more rapidly to the council, the 25-member interim government here.

title: Bringing the U.N. Into the 21st Century
description: President Bush's turn to the United Nations for help in Iraq was a welcome, if belated, recognition that global policing can acquire legitimacy only through multinational endorsement. But the records of the major political bodies of the United Nations -- the General Assembly and the Security Council -- have little to show that this is the place to find that sort of legitimacy in the 21st century. The Assembly is usually mired in speechmaking. The Council is increasingly perceived as an antiquated relic of the cold war. These are not just the sentiments of neoconservatives in Washington; they were voiced most recently by Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Wins Ruling On Beard
description: The Department of Correction was wrong to require a Muslim correction officer to trim his beard, an act that would violate his religious beliefs, an administrative law judge has ruled. Since July 2002, Officer Hasani Shabazz, who works at Rikers Island, has refused orders to trim his beard, now about five inches long. Departmental regulations require beards be ''closely trimmed and shaped in conformity with the jaw line.'' In her ruling, Administrative Law Judge Rosemarie Maldonado said the department had failed to show that accommodating the beard posed an undue hardship. The department had argued that beards prevented airtight seals in gas masks, which are used when pepper spray is required to remove an inmate from a cell. But Judge Maldonado ruled that even a five-inch beard could be accommodated in ways that allowed the mask's proper use. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

Since many such attacks -- including, of course, those of Sept. 11, 2001 -- have been perpetrated by Muslim terrorists professing religious motives, it might seem obvious that Islamic fundamentalism is the central cause. This presumption has fueled the belief that future 9/11's can be avoided only by a wholesale transformation of Muslim societies, which in turn was a core reason for broad public support of the invasion of Iraq.

description: A school bus driver accused of leaving a sleeping kindergartner inside his parked bus on Tuesday has been dismissed. The boy was on his way back to his Wethersfield home after classes at the Webb Kindergarten Center. He was alone in the bus for about 15 minutes before he was found about 1 p.m. His mother alerted school officials when he was not dropped off. The driver did not follow procedure and check the bus for children, said David Urgo, director of school bus operations for the bus company, Double A Transportation in Rocky Hill. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

description: Workers in the region's largest janitors' union overwhelmingly re-elected Michael Fishman to a new three-year term as president, the union announced on Friday. The union said Mr. Fishman received 84 percent of the 18,000 votes cast. Mr. Fishman heads Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, which represents 70,000 janitors, doormen, elevator operators and repair workers in apartment buildings and office towers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Mr. Fishman was named trustee of the local in 1999 after the parent union forced out the previous president, Gus Bevona. Mr. Fishman then was elected to his first full three-year term in 2000. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: HARRY POTTER ON THE STREET
description: Homeless vendors of 19 street newspapers in Germany, Austria and Switzerland will have first crack at peddling the opening chapter of the German translation of J. K. Rowling's new best-selling novel, ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix.'' Two weeks before the translation's long-anticipated official release date, Nov. 8, the newspapers, sold by the homeless in subways, shopping districts and bars, will carry the start of the boy wizard's latest adventure. ''We were thrilled when we heard about Ms. Rowling's offer,'' said Jrgen Angerer, the managing director of the Hamburg street newspaper Hinz & Kunzt. ''For us this is a gift from heaven. For our Harry Potter issue, we'll double the circulation to 120,000 copies and we're convinced that it is going to sell out right away.'' In Hamburg, about 400 vendors, who sell the monthly for the equivalent of about $1.70, are allowed to keep about 90 cents of the proceeds. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANN, DR. SIDNEY
description: MANN--Dr. Sidney. 75, of Old Tappan, NJ, formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ, on September 20, 2003, following a brief but courageous battle with cancer. An orthodontist for four decades, born in the Bronx and graduated from New York University with a Bachelor of Arts in 1950. He graduated NYU School of Dentistry in 1954 and received his certificate in orthodontics from the State University of Iowa in 1957. Dr. Mann treated over 5,000 patients throughout the course of his career. Survived by his wife of 46 years, Harriet (nee Griss), children Steven and his wife Susan, and Linda Spelling and her husband Ian; grandchildren Justin, Max and Jamie, mother Mary Mann, sister Racelle Hill; nephews Larry, Sam and Ted; and niece Susan. The family will receive visitors at the Mann residence in Old Tappan through Friday. Donations in the name of Dr. Sidney Mann to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, attn: Gall Bladder Research.

This public-relations offensive comes, however, at a time when a growing number of Americans are saying the original act already gives government too much power. Faced with these reasoned objections, the administration is becoming more shrill. Last week, Attorney General John Ashcroft named librarians as the latest group to pose a threat to freedom. Rather than lash out at well-intentioned critics, the administration should listen to the thoughtful voices from across the political spectrum who are saying we need less Patriot Act, not more.

And as John S. Reed, the former Citigroup banker, steps in as the exchange's acting chairman, he will have to wrestle with growing questions about the effectiveness of its regulatory performance.

title: The Evolution of the Popular Music Machine
description: Since popular music became a big business in the mid-19th century, and as the means of production and distribution have changed, so has the nature of the companies that control the music industry. Popular music has long been a capital-intensive business, favoring big companies that can benefit from economies of scale. But in the Internet era, the 20th-century business model may no longer fit. LISA NAPOLI

title: Taping Them Up or Sitting Them Down
description: THE most popular after-school spot at Garden City High School these days is not an arcade or a pizzeria but a cluttered room the size of a walk-in closet, in a far corner of the gymnasium.

title: These Stones Pack a Punch To the Kidneys
description: LAST June, while on duty for the Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan, Police Officer Joseph Lozupone was suddenly overcome with agonizing pain and rushed to the emergency room at New York Weill Cornell Center.

title: Wolfowitz Stands Fast Amid the Antiwarriors
description: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz plunged into a bastion of antiwar liberalism -- Greenwich Village -- yesterday to voice a vigorous defense of the Bush administration's Iraq policy.

title: Little Chance of Pakistani Troops in Iraq
description: The president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said in an interview today that his government needs more military and intelligence help from the United States to fight Al Qaeda and the Taliban, and more political support from Iraqis and the Islamic world before it can send troops to help stabilize Iraq.

title: A Breakthrough and a Four-Peat; 'Raymond' and 'West Wing' Are Cited as Best Shows at the Emmys
description: The NBC series ''The West Wing'' unexpectedly won the Emmy again tonight, beating ''The Sopranos'' as best drama series, and ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' won the comedy award for the first time.

description: Wearing a strapless floor-length confection with a fitted bodice and a full skirt in a color she described as ''cotton-candy'' pink, Sarah Jessica Parker alighted at the 55th annual Emmy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles last night like an envoy from a couture galaxy.

title: H. Harfield, Innovator In Banking, Dies at 89
description: Henry Harfield, a lawyer specializing in banking who also participated in the release of prisoners taken at the Bay of Pigs, died on Sept. 13 in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Chirac's Words: Sovereignty Must Shift
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jacques Chirac of France. The interview was done in French and translated by The New York Times. The full transcript is at nytimes.com/world.

title: Redskins Find Hole In Secondary
description: When Giants cornerback Will Allen made one of the most picturesque plays of the game, when he dived in front of Washington Redskins receiver Laveranues Coles and snared an interception in the third quarter today, it looked as if the Giants' secondary might just have left its troubles behind.

title: The Fire's Out, but the Mystery Is Thriving

description: Dwarfed by a dominant rival and losing money at an alarming rate, Advanced Micro Devices plans to take another step in its strategy to outmaneuver Intel by introducing the Athlon 64-bit microprocessor tomorrow.

title: Body Maintenance: A Mature Guide
description: TO understand your middle-aged body and its capacity for abuse, picture a rubber band that has been sitting around in a drawer. It is not as supple as a new one, may even be brittle in places, and it is certainly more prone to snap. But before you curl up in a drawer yourself, utterly deflated, remember, there are ways you can stay strong and limber. Just as steady, gentle use can prolong the life of a rubber band, regular exercise and taking time to warm up can help you avoid injury and stay active. It is folly to go on a ski trip or sign up for the club tennis tournament without some preparation, experts advise. Be realistic and pace yourself, they say.

title: 2 Blair Aides Again Deny Misleading Britons on War
description: LONDON, Sept. 22  Two senior members of Prime Minister Tony Blair's government made return appearances today before the inquiry investigating the suicide of weapons expert David Kelly and resisted vigorous attempts by lawyers to shake their earlier testimony.

title: Chirac Urges a Transfer of Power
description: PARIS, Sept. 21  President Jacques Chirac called today for the immediate transfer of sovereignty in Iraq to the Iraqi people, and indicated that France would approve only a new United Nations resolution that recognized this need.

title: Appeal of Man's Sentence in Wife's Slaying Renews Focus on Death Penalty Law
description: To the defense, James F. Cahill 3rd is a man of ''broken mind and spirit'' who deserves to live. He killed his wife, Jill, with cyanide in 1998, as she recovered from being beaten by him with a baseball bat, and his lawyers suggest he did so because he was distraught over the breakup of his marriage.

title: Ian Hunter, 84, an Impresario Who Shaped Edinburgh Festival, Dies
description: Sir Ian Hunter, a British impresario and organizer of arts festivals who played a major role in shaping the annual Edinburgh Festival, died on Sept. 5 at his home in West Sussex, England. He was 84.

Indy. It was the Belmont Stakes, the last race in the series. A.P. Indy was injured and did not run in the Kentucky Derby, the first of the series.

description: Since Thomas A. Edison recorded the human voice in 1877, the music industry has grappled with the uncertainties wrought by new technologies.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Executive Close to Grasso Is Retiring From Big Board
description: A senior executive at the New York Stock Exchange who was closely involved with Richard A. Grasso's compensation package has retired, officials at the Big Board said yesterday.

title: Weaver Lets White Sox Put Yankees' Celebration on Ice
description: The Yankees knew what could happen here as soon as they walked into their clubhouse today. Sheets of plastic, bunched up and hanging by wires above their lockers, dominated the room. Six cases of Champagne were ready.

title: Clarett's Lawyer Meets With N.F.L. on Draft
description: Lawyers for the suspended Ohio State running back Maurice Clarett and the National Football League met last night in Washington to discuss Clarett's potential entry into the 2004 draft.

title: IRAQ COUNCIL HEAD SHIFTS TO POSITION AT ODDS WITH U.S.
description: Ahmad Chalabi, the president of Iraq's interim government, is in New York this week to press alternatives to the Bush administration's occupation policy in postwar Iraq, he and his aides say. In the process, he may complete a personal transformation from protg of Pentagon conservatives to Iraqi nationalist with a loud, independent voice.

title: Air Passengers' Carry-Ons: No, Not the Baggage, Dinner
description: Munching on mahi-mahi, Laura Malone sat in the airport here and told of a recent run-in with security. Screeners at the metal detector had found no weaponry or sharp objects but had stopped her anyway. The offending item? A tin of smoked shrimp with tarragon.

title: Question Time for Governor Leavitt
description: Democrats on the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee have little prospect of blocking committee approval of Michael Leavitt, the Utah governor who is President Bush's choice to succeed Christie Whitman as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Yet they owe it to the country and to the environment to use today's confirmation hearings to cross-examine Mr. Leavitt and to ask how he intends to restore the credibility and independence of an agency that for two years has been little more than an extension of Karl Rove's political operation in the White House.

title: JetBlue Target Of Inquiries By 2 Agencies
description: Two federal agencies announced today that they had opened investigations into JetBlue Airways in response to the airline's admission that it had provided travel records on more than a million passengers to a Pentagon contractor, violating its own privacy rules.

title: Clark Calls for a 'New American Patriotism'
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark called today for ''a new American patriotism'' that would encourage broader public service, respect domestic dissent even in wartime and embrace international organizations like the United Nations.

title: Energy of Africa Draws the Eyes of Houston
description: When Angola recently opened its only consulate outside New York, few people here were surprised that Houston was chosen.

title: Sentencing Delayed for Korean Immigrant Who Shot at U.N.
description: Sentencing for the Korean-born postal worker who fired a gun at the United Nations last year to protest the mistreatment of North Korean citizens was delayed yesterday amid continued wrangling over how to arrive at his punishment.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Tuesday about the announcement that YankeeNets had asked the Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs investment banks to seek buyers for the New Jersey Nets misstated Lehman's role in the sale of Nelson Doubleday's 50 percent of the New York Mets to Fred Wilpon. Lehman represented Mr. Wilpon; J. P. Morgan represented Mr. Doubleday.

description: KRISER--Sidney P. On September 22, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Loving father of Judy Feldstein. Dear father-in-law of Richard Feldstein. title: Iraq and Ailing Economy Leave Bush Aides on Edge, They Say
description: When George W. Bush addresses the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday as the unapologetic commander in chief, administration officials acknowledge, behind the proud words will be a president in a less potent political position than a year ago because of setbacks in Iraq and the loss of jobs at home.

title: In Chiracs Words: Call a Summit
description: The following is the text of President Jacques Chirac's remarks to the General Assembly as recorded by Federal News Service, Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; In Need of Pit Stop, Sputtering Defense Wants to Dismiss the Past
description: THE Giants will get a break this week. After pulling off an overtime victory over Washington on Sunday, the Giants' defense, wheezing by the end of regulation, has a chance to catch its second wind. The breather was so needed that Mike Barrow, the 33-year-old middle linebacker, invoking a biblical passage, suggested the bye was divine intervention.

title: American Cup Returns
description: The Visa American Cup, which through the years has introduced such up-and-coming gymnasts as Nadia Comaneci, Mary Lou Retton, Kurt Thomas and Bart Conner, will return to Madison Square Garden on Feb. 28.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Arthur Kinoy, a civil rights lawyer who helped defend the Chicago Seven antiwar protesters in 1969, misstated his role in the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, as well as the charges against them. He was the lawyer in 1951 for their final appeal against the death penalty, not a lawyer at their trial. They were charged with conspiracy to commit espionage, not with actual atomic espionage.

title: 'Tired Blood' Warning: Ignore It at Your Peril
description: Thanks to advertisements for the once-popular tonic Geritol, most people of a certain age know about ''tired blood,'' a disorder more accurately called anemia, involving a shortage of healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen to body tissues and cleanse them of carbon dioxide.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Built-In Eyeshades

title: Schools Get $4 Million to Recruit Principals
description: The Broad Foundation, which gives grants to improve public education, is donating $4 million to a program to recruit and train New York City principals, officials announced yesterday.

title: Frank Lowe, 60, Saxophonist in Free-Jazz and R&B Styles
description: The jazz tenor saxophonist Frank Lowe, who first appeared in the wave of New York free-jazz players influenced by John Coltrane and then went on to explore an earlier jazz and rhythm-and-blues feeling, died last Friday in St. Clare's hospital in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: The Week That Was: New York Sends Some Signals; Backs, To the Front
description: Clothes should look as good coming as going, especially in the spring, when more skin shows. This season designers seemed to pay especially close attention to back details. Carolina Herrera edged knit tank tops with tiny bands of black organza, giving the casual a dressy touch. For some of her lovely charmeuse and silk jersey evening dresses, Vera Wang let sashes hang down bare backs, or knotted them. Ralph Lauren used silver chain mesh, after fencing clothes, to finish the racer back of a white silk gown.

title: HALLIBURTON SEEKS SUPPORT FOR ASBESTOS SETTLEMENT
description: The Halliburton Company, the oil field services provider, is asking about 425,000 individuals suing over asbestos exposure to endorse the restructuring of DII Industries, Kellogg Brown & Root and other units in an estimated $4 billion settlement. Approval by at least 75 percent of those with claims would clear the way for the units to file for bankruptcy protection in November under a plan to create a trust that would pay asbestos claims and erase future liability. The plan would allow Halliburton, based in Houston, to settle its asbestos liability while avoiding bankruptcy.

title: Elusive Force May Lie At Root of Blackout
description: It is a little-understood component of electricity, so arcane that engineers sometimes call it ''imaginary power.''

title: Spawning Salmon Haul Toxins to Alaska Lakes, Experts Find
description: Pacific salmon contaminated by industrial pollutants in the ocean are carrying the chemicals to Alaska's lakes, where they may affect peopleand wildlife, according to a new study published in the Sept. 18 issue of Nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COUFOS, ELLIE
description: COUFOS--Ellie. Of Bay Harbor Island, FL, formerly of Jamaica, NY passed away suddenly September 20, 2003. She was the wife of the late Louis P. Those left to cherish her memory are her loving children: Peter (Elizabeth) Coufos and Valerie (Burton) Bachrach and her adored grandchildren: Eleanor and Penelope Coufos. She also leaves a brother, Harry G. Voziou and brother-in-law, Alexander P. Coufos. The family will receive friends Tuesday, September 23, 3:005:00 & 7:00-9:00PM at Forest Lawn Funeral Home, 200 West Copans Road, Pompano Beach. Funeral services will be Wednesday, 11:00AM at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church, 815 NE 15th Avenue, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33304. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions be made in her memory to St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church, Ft. Lauderdale, FL.

title: Student Shot in Standoff at a Spokane High School
description: A 17-year-old student at a Spokane, Wash., high school, fired a gun today, barricaded himself in a science classroom with three other students and a teacher, the authorities said, and was then shot by the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: KIRSTEIN--Sidney. On September 20, 2003. Beloved husband of Ann. Devoted father of Larry and his wife Jane. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Funeral service Wednesday, 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery.

title: TIAA-CREF Lays Off 8% Of Workers In Overhaul
description: TIAA-CREF, the largest provider of individual pension plans for universities and colleges, said yesterday that it was laying off 8 percent, or 500, of its 6,500 employees as part of a sweeping reorganization intended to improve its efficiency.

title: Republican Official Rebukes Bush Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Ed Gillespie, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that recent attacks on President Bush by Democratic presidential candidates amounted to "political hate speech" that would not sway public opinion.

title: Worry Over a New Conflict for Accounting Firms
description: A law intended to ensure the independence of auditors has some accountants worried about a new conflict of interest.

title: Giants Have Issues, But Collins Isn't One
description: The roar of Redskins fans rang in Giants quarterback Kerry Collins's ears. The game around him seemed to be in the late stages of collapse. The once-fierce Giants defense was springing leaks by the minute. The special teams could do little without drawing a penalty flag.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths   TAVENNER, BARBARA ANN
description: TAVENNER--Barbara Ann. Sept. 23, '02. Extraordinary friend, hostess, gardener and decorator. Wonderful memories of you keep us uplifted. Fly happily, Countess. Love, Betsy, Jim and Tabith

title: Earnings Climb at 3 Big Investment Banks
description: Three of Wall Street's biggest investment banks reported earnings today that were better than industry analysts expected. The beneficial effects of more two years of cost-cutting and an improved climate in many important segments of their businesses helped to boost bottom-line results.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: MEMORIAL REJECTED The leaders of Germany and Poland rejected a plan that a memorial to the several million Germans deported from eastern Europe after World War II be built in Berlin. The leaders, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and Prime Minister Leszek Miller, met at a soccer stadium in the western city of Gelsenkirchen, where Mr. Schroder kicked a ball during a break. "Given the risk of one-sidedness in creating such a center, if we want it at all, then certainly not in Berlin," he said at a news conference. The idea of such a memorial has aroused anger among Poles, who feel it would distort the distinction between Germans as aggressors and as victims. (AP)

title: For Billions of Birds, an Endangered Haven
description: It's autumn, and the vast boreal forest of Canada is spilling birds. Ducks and geese are pouring out of it, and songbirds in the billions.

title: Betraying One's Passengers
description: JetBlue Airways passengers, more than a million of them, have been unsuspecting guinea pigs in a Defense Department contractor's experiment in mining commercial databases to assess the risk of a person turning out to be a terrorist. The airline admits it violated its own privacy policy when it acceded to the Pentagon's request to give passenger records to Torch Concepts, a private technology business that was ostensibly creating a program to enhance security at military bases.

title: The Week That Was: New York Sends Some Signals; Aspirations With a Faraway Look
description: No one can predict which models will ''break out,'' as agents say, until after the European fashion shows, which begin this week. But there were definite comers in this season's crop of lovelies, which resembled a caucus from the United Nations General Assembly, but a great deal prettier. Among the promising faces were a swan-necked 16-year-old from Estonia, a leggy Cambodian with a shaved head, an Indian beauty-contest winner and an African-American teenager ''discovered'' at a Dallas-area mall.

description: SAY it ain't so, Gordo.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: JUDGE EASES ACCESS TO BAR EXAM A federal district court judge has overturned a State Supreme Court rule that foreigners with temporary visas may not take the state bar exam. The judge, Eldon E. Fallon of Federal District Court in New Orleans, ruled that the restriction represented arbitrary and unconstitutional discrimination. In July, Judge Jay C. Zainey of the same court, using a less restrictive standard of law, upheld the rule in a similar case. The State Supreme Court argued that if a lawyer was deported, a client would be in difficulty. Vincent Booth, who represented the plaintiffs, said the real issue was the success of foreign lawyers who take on indigent death penalty cases. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: GLAXOSMITHKLINE WINS COURT RULING ON DRUG PATENT
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the drug maker, won an appeals court ruling in its bid to block generic competition to Wellbutrin SR, an antidepressant that brings in $1.4 billion a year. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit overturned a judge's decision that the Andrx Corporation's application for a version of the twice-a-day form of the drug would not infringe GlaxoSmithKline's patent. The appeals court said the judge interpreted the scope of the patent incorrectly and sent the case back for further review. The ruling may delay cheaper generic copies of the antidepressant, giving Glaxo more time to switch patients to its newer, longer-lasting version of the treatment, called Wellbutrin XL.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC MAY SELL LUMBER DISTRIBUTION UNIT
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the paper and lumber maker, said it might sell a unit that distributes building products to pay down debt and focus on consumer goods. Georgia-Pacific hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to advise the company on options for the unit. The company did not say what the unit might be worth. A price of at least $1 billion would be consistent with Georgia-Pacific's plan to evolve into a consumer products company that competes with the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, analysts said. The lumber-distribution unit accounted for 16 percent, or $3.8 billion, of Georgia-Pacific's sales last year.

description: In percent

description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23  Following is transcript from a speech today at the General Assembly by Secretary General Kofi Annan as supplied by the United Nations.

title: Huge Ice Shelf Is Reported To Break Up In Canada
description: A large ice shelf that has jutted into the Arctic Ocean from northernmost Canada for at least 3,000 years has broken up over the last two years, providing fresh evidence that the region is warming past thresholds that can produce abrupt changes, scientists said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Abrief article in some editions yesterday about the announcement of a new cabinet by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan omitted one position held by Heizo Takenaka. He retains his old position as minister for economic policy and financial services, along with the economic policy position.

title: Stewart's Approach Pays Off For Twins
description: The big hits and the key runs driven in do not tell the full story of outfielder Shannon Stewart's value to the Minnesota Twins, at least not to Paul Molitor, a member of the 3,000-hit club and a special instructor for the organization. Molitor chose to look deeper, to a plate appearance in which Stewart never put the ball in play.

title: Studies Say Tax Cuts Now Will Bring Bigger Bill Later
description: President Bush's tax cuts will put a trillion dollars in people's pockets over six years, but because the government is spending far more than it is taking in, the president's policies also mean that Americans face a much larger future tax bill -- or equally large cuts in government spending -- to balance the government's books.

title: All 9 Members of a NASA Safety Panel Resign
description: All nine members of an expert panel established by Congress to advise NASA on safety resigned today, with several citing frustration over a lack of influence.

title: Suicide Attacker Who Struck at U.N. Carried 2 Bombs
description: The bomber seemed prepared to die in any of several ways here this morning. In the trunk of his car, was one bomb. Around his waist, in the form of an explosive belt, was another. In all, one Iraqi investigator said, the man was wired to 50 or more pounds of explosives that he detonated at 8 a.m. in the parking lot of the United Nations compound, a month after another suicide bomber killed 22 people there.

title: U.S. Fighter Jets Bomb House in Falluja, Family Says
description: SICHIR, Iraq, Sept. 23  Tahseen Ali Khalaf was asleep beside his brother Hussein when the shooting started early this morning outside their ramshackle house in this farming community 40 miles west of Baghdad.

description: BILL CLINTON

title: Medals for His Valor, Ashes for His Wife
description: It was back on April 4 when Birgit Smith last wrote her husband, Sgt. First Class Paul Ray Smith. ''Life without you here is just not the same,'' she wrote in a tight, neat cursive.

title: The Week That Was: New York Sends Some Signals; Yellow, Seriously
description: Yellow is such a funny color. But so many designers showed the tulip-time favorite that you might want to give it at least a second look. Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler showed a hooded slicker with panels of yellow sequins on leather, and Oscar de la Renta sent out sunny yellow dresses with full skirts.

title: Deal Cleared to Save Alstom of France
description: The troubled French engineering company Alstom appeared saved from near-certain bankruptcy today when the European Commission approved a short-term bailout, involving the French government and creditor banks, worth 3.2 billion euros ($3.66 billion).

title: A Foul Mouth With a Following; 20 Years Later, Pacino's 'Scarface' Resonates With a Young Audience
description: Twenty-five years ago Al Pacino was walking down Sunset Boulevard with some friends when he passed a revival theater showing ''Scarface,'' the 1932 classic directed by Howard Hawks and written by Ben Hecht about the rise and fall of a Chicago gangster, played by Paul Muni. Mr. Pacino promptly purchased a ticket.

title: Cheeseburger and Fries, Wrapped Up in One
description: If the National Cattlemen's Beef Association has its way, beef will not be just for dinner anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOREY, GABRIELLA TUSSU SOV
description: MOREY -- Gabriella Tussu sov. Born September 15, 1961. Died September 20, 2003, in New York City. Beloved wife of Alexander R. Morey. Mother of Miranda Allen Morey. Loving daughter of Lilly and Wassil Tussusov. Service today, Tuesday, 11:30AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St.

title: Rules Eased On Financing Social Work
description: The Bush administration acted today to make it easier for religious organizations to receive federal financing for a variety of social welfare programs and awarded $30.5 million in grants to encourage religious and community groups to do more to help people in need.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFLAND, HOWARD W.
description: EFLAND--Howard W. January 3rd, 1933-September 21, 2003. Beloved husband of Alice (nee Friedman), devoted and adoring father of Stephen, Michael and Jordana. Loving Pop Pop of Jessica and Matthew Efland. Adored brother of Margi and Gerry Friedman and Phyllis Alpert. Dear uncle of Glenn and Jeff Alpert and their families and John and Beth Friedman. He touched many lives with laughter and will be greatly missed. Contributions in Howie's memory to Hospice Care Network, Westbury, L.I. or your favorite charity. Funeral services Tuesday September 23, 1:30 PM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', Hewlett, L.I. NY.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: DNA DATABASE TO BE EXPANDED Gov. James E. McGreevey signed legislation yesterday that requires all newly convicted criminals in New Jersey to submit saliva samples for the state and national DNA databank. Officials said the new law would expand the state's database to more than 140,000 DNA samples in the next two years. A previous law required samples only from those convicted of sexual assault or other violent offenses. The new law will also require offenders on parole or probation to provide samples. It also budgets $8 million a year for 40 scientists to process the DNA. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Judge Eases Access To Bar Exam
description: A federal district court judge has overturned a State Supreme Court rule that foreigners with temporary visas may not take the state bar exam. The judge, Eldon E. Fallon of Federal District Court in New Orleans, ruled that the restriction represented arbitrary and unconstitutional discrimination. In July, Judge Jay C. Zainey of the same court, using a less restrictive standard of law, upheld the rule in a similar case. The State Supreme Court argued that if a lawyer was deported, a client would be in difficulty. Vincent Booth, who represented the plaintiffs, said the real issue was the success of foreign lawyers who take on indigent death penalty cases. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: In Death Penalty Appeal, Judges Focus on Broad Questions of the Law's Enforcement
description: Several judges on the state's highest court expressed reservations today about central provisions of New York's 1995 capital punishment law and the way it is being enforced, as they considered the second death sentence under the law to reach them.

title: Morocco's World Cup Bid Takes Off
description: Alan Rothenberg is planning to spend Yom Kippur, the holiest day on the Jewish calendar, in Morocco, a Muslim nation.

title: AT&T WILL BUY BACK $1.1 BILLION IN BONDS
description: AT&T said yesterday that it would buy back $1.1 billion of bonds to reduce debt, paying cash to redeem the three issues on Oct. 22. AT&T and rivals are lowering interest expense by reducing debt amid waning demand for phone service. The company, based in Bedminster, N.J., announced last month the early redemption of $506 million of long-term notes and said in July that it would buy back as much as $2 billion in debt.

title: As Many as 6 Bids Are Expected For Freedom Communications
description: As many as a half-dozen bidders were preparing last night to submit offers for all or part of Freedom Communications, one of the nation's last privately held newspaper and television companies. At least one of the bids was expected to be at least $2 billion, according to executives involved in the auction.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gillette To Start Fuel Cell Venture
description: MTI MicroFuel Cells has linked up with Gillette and its Duracell battery subsidiary to pursue commercialization of MTI's portable fuel cell technology, according to a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Shares of MTI's Albany-based parent, Mechanical Technology, soared $1.24, or about 33 percent, to $4.98 yesterday. The strategic alliance will be a multiyear exclusive relationship for sharing intellectual property and royalties. Gillette is investing $1 million in MTI and providing financial support for continuing development of its technology, which MTI hopes to sell as an alternative to batteries for many consumer electronic products. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Debt Review
description: Moody's said China's long-term foreign-currency debt was under review for a possible upgrading in recognition of China's rising exports, foreign direct investment and foreign exchange reserves and its ''relatively modest level of external debt,'' as well as the recent peaceful transfer of power to a younger generation of Communist officials. Moody's said that it would also review the foreign-currency debt of China's two special administrative regions, Hong Kong and Macau, for a possible upgrading along with the foreign-currency debt of China's big four state-owned banks. But Moody's cautioned that the banks' dismal financial strength ratings, which range from E to D-, were not being changed. Moody's also said it would review several Hong Kong banks and the China National Offshore Oil Corporation for possible upgrading. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Level 3 Lowers Sales Forecast
description: Level 3 Communications Inc., the data-network company partly owned by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, pared its third-quarter sales forecast yesterday and said that it would sell $500 million in senior notes to retire other debt. Sales will fall as low as $865 million, compared with a July forecast of $930 million, Level 3 said. Revenue in the third quarter of the previous year was $1.07 billion. The notes, due 2011, will be sold to institutional buyers. ''The communications business is a reflection of the economy at large,'' the chief executive, James Crowe, said. ''Businesses are not investing in new infrastructure.'' Level 3, which is in danger of defaulting on its debt last year because of slumping sales, tried to shore up revenue by buying the bankrupt network operator Genuity Inc. and two software companies. Shares of Level 3 fell 2 cents, to $4.76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, FRIEDA
description: MEYER--Frieda. Frieda, age 91, was reunited with her beloved husband and soulmate, Walter, on September 21. Originally from Cologne, Germany, she resided in Forest Hills, N.Y. and, of late, in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. She is deeply mourned by her cherished daughters Karen Rosenberg and June Blume and loving son-in-law Harry Rosenberg. She is the treasured Oma of Jennifer and Pamela Rosenberg, Mark (Erika) and Jonathan (Jessica) Blume and ur-oma of Harrison and Rachel Blume and sister-in-law to Lotte Meyer. Special thanks to her wonderful, compassionate caretaker, Christina Mensah and to Pat Taah who assisted Christina. Our Frieda was the most loving and gentle mother. She was a real lady in every way. A bright light has gone out. We already miss her terribly and will love her forever.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Music Merger Talks
description: The EMI Group confirmed that it was in talks with AOL Time Warner about the recorded music group of Warner Music. The announcement followed the breakdown of talks between Warner Music and BMG last week and comes after the two let an exclusivity agreement lapse. People close to EMI said it could be months before anything concrete was accomplished. Foremost in the mind of EMI and Warner advisers is structuring a deal that will be approved by regulators, these people said. Opposition from European regulators derailed proposed combinations between EMI and Warner and between EMI and BMG in the last few years. EMI's offer is expected to value the Warner unit at about $1.5 billion, and give AOL two seats on its board. EMI was cautious in its statement: ''Discussions are at a very preliminary stage and there is no assurance that they will result in an agreement acceptable to both parties.'' Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Sentenced For Role In Fatal Shooting
description: An 18-year-old girl was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison after she admitted a role in the shooting death of another young woman, who the authorities said was trying to avoid contact with a street gang known as M-18. In August, the teenager, Augustina Lopez, pleaded guilty to manslaughter and admitted possessing a handgun that was later used to shoot Maria Azusena, 22, in July 2002. Ms. Azusena, a waitress, had failed to show up for an M-18 gang meeting, law enforcement officials said. Prosecutors said Ms. Lopez suspected that the handgun would be used by Miguel Martinez, 19, of Queens, to shoot Ms. Azusena. Mr. Martinez, who was convicted in the fatal shooting, is scheduled to be sentenced today. Roberto Batista, 21, of Queens, also accused in the shooting, is awaiting trial. Stacy Albin (NYT)

George Ryan, which is supposed to be added to the Hall of Governors in the Executive Mansion in Springfield, waits in limbo instead, because state officials are unsure how Mr. Ryan wants to unveil his likeness. But a federal investigation has resulted in several indictments against Mr. Ryan's top aides, and he has yet to give the state a directive. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

Back in Car 10, the luggage racks are festooned with the occupants' belts, dangling above them like snakes. ''Their trousers are too big,'' one officer said. description: KATZ--Rose. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rose Katz, beloved mother of Saul B. We offer our most sincere condolences to Saul, his wife, Iris, their children, and to the entire Katz family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAY, SID
description: KAY--Sid. Died on September 18 in New York Hospital. Leaving behind the love of a family that will miss him deeply: his adored and adoring wife of 62 years, Rose; siblings Estelle, Jack, Mel, Herbert, Gloria and Alvin. Nieces, nephews, great nieces and great-nephews. Mr. Kay, who founded Miss Youthform Lingerie and Peacock Linens had interests that included religion, politics, journalism, literature and theatre. The key to Sid's personality was his ability to read, to listen, to learn and then to speak profoundly and knowledgeably. He was a gentleman and a gentle man. Mr. Kay was put to rest in Hebrew Friendship Cemetery in Baltimore, MD. His family will be home September 22-24 from 12-8PM at 220 E. 72nd, NYC. We bid him farewell and a peaceful journey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUSHING, ZINN, JEAN (DALZELL)
description: CUSHING-ZINN--Jean (Dalzell). Died September 22, 2003, in Greenwich, Connecticut. She was 79. Born January 23, 1924 in Brooklyn, she was the daughter of the late Lloyd Hunter Dalzell and Frances Jones Redmond and the stepdaughter of the late Cyril James Redmond. She is predeceased by her husband, Charles M. Cushing and a sister Barbara Redmond Ryan. She is survived by two daughters Deborah Zinn Prouty and Kathryn Zinn Cerussi, both of Greenwich, and three grandsons. A service will be held on Wednesday, September 24, 2003, at 3 P.M. at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, Conn.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Bloomberg Urges Action Against Bias Crimes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he had written to the city's five district attorneys to urge them to vigorously prosecute people charged with bias crimes. ''I strongly urge,'' the mayor wrote, ''that you punish such criminals to the fullest extent permitted by law and vigorously utilize'' a law passed in 2000 that strengthened the penalties for crimes that are motivated by bias. The mayor talked about the letter at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge during the opening ceremony of a small waterfront park. The letter comes after two weeks of escalating criticism from several black City Council members over the Police Department's handling of an attack on a black college student and her white and Hispanic friends by a group of white youths in a Staten Island park. Several more possible bias attacks were reported during the weekend. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

description: California today adopted the nation's first law meant to protect the privacy of drivers whose cars are equipped with ''black boxes,'' or data recorders that can be used to gather vital information on how a vehicle is being driven in the last seconds before a crash.

The preponderance of high heels marked a departure from recent spring seasons, which were dominated by thongs, slides, ballet flats and the like. This time ''everything was very elevated,'' said Jeffrey Kalinksy, the owner of Jeffrey New York -- and calibrated ''to go with collections that were very pretty and feminine.''

Her husband was killed in the attack on the World Trade Center. Yet she has also risen from the catastrophe to build a new identity, as one of the state's best-known advocates for 9/11 widows and as the new executive director of the New Jersey Lottery.

description: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, chose Selina Chow, one of two vice chairwomen of the Liberal Party, to join his cabinet, the Executive Council. She succeeds James Tien, the Liberal Party's chairman, who quit the council on July 6 to protest an internal security bill. Mr. Tien's resignation forced Mr. Tung to postpone the bill indefinitely the next day, and Mr. Tung withdrew it on Sept. 5. Mrs. Chow is the chairwoman of the Hong Kong Tourism Board and a pro-business member of the Legislative Council. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOELLERING, MICHAEL F.
description: HOELLERING--Michael F. The Board and staff of the American Arbitration Association are deeply saddened by the passing of Michael F. Hoellering, longtime General Counsel of the Association and recognized international leader in the field of arbitration and mediation. Mr. Hoellering devoted many years of exceptional service to the Association, marked by his wisdom, grace, and high personal standards. Joining us as New York Regional Director in 1959, he moved to serve as General Counsel for 19 years until his retirement in 1999. Mr. Hoellering continued to contribute his skill to the field post-retirement, serving as a preeminent arbitrator and mediator on our commercial and international panels. In recognition of his distinguished service as counsel and champion of alternative dispute resolution procedures, the Association established the Hoellering Fellowship in his honor. The fellowship is awarded to an outstanding individual committed to advancing international dispute resolution. We extend our most sincere and heartfelt condolences to Mr. Hoellering's family.

title: The Recall Reargued
description: California's gubernatorial recall election was back in court yesterday, as the appeals court that delayed the vote heard arguments about whether it should reverse its decision. Last week's ruling felt uncomfortable: courts are rightly reluctant to stop elections. But with the near certainty that many voters would be disenfranchised by defective machines, it was the right choice. The court should stick with its decision to delay voting until March.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: VeriSign Asked To Suspend New Service
description: The agency that oversees Internet domain names has asked VeriSign to suspend voluntarily a new service that redirects Web surfers to VeriSign's site when they try to reach unassigned Web addresses. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, on Friday posted a notice on its Web site with its response to the so-called wild-card service, which began Sept. 15. The wild-card service sends people to a VeriSign page with search results, including links to paid advertisements. Until now, Web surfers would have received an error message. VeriSign runs the registry for the .com and .net domains, which are among the most widely used top-level domains on the Web. The wild-card service is for .com and .net domains. Icann said it was investigating complaints about the wild-card service and asked VeriSign to pull it pending further study. ''Recognizing the concerns about the wild-card service, Icann has called upon VeriSign to voluntarily suspend the service until the various reviews now under way are completed,'' the agency wrote in a notice posted on its Web site.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon.com Adds Sports Products
description: Amazon.com Inc. has signed up more than 90 companies, including Foot Locker Inc., to help it expand into sporting goods, a growing sales category for online merchants. Amazon.com, which began testing sales of sports items a month ago, is offering equipment, clothing and other items for more than 50 sports. The company will receive a commission for operating the store and processing orders for its partners, who will provide inventory, handle shipments and customer service, a company spokeswoman, Kristin Schaefer, said. Amazon.com said it might add more sporting-goods partners and merchandise to the site, which now has about 95 retailers like SportsLine.com Inc., and the Sports ''R'' Us unit of Toys ''R'' Us. Shares of Amazon.com dropped 11 cents, to $47.47. Shares of SportsLine.com rose 32 cents, or 18 percent, to $2.10. Amazon.com has been increasing offerings by teaming with traditional and other Web retailers to sell items through the site. Last year it opened an apparel and shoe store, signing up partners that included Gap Inc. The company is offering a $10 certificate to people who spend at least $50 at the sporting-goods shop.

description: Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest meat processor, said it expected fiscal fourth-quarter profit to rise from a year earlier, beating analyst projections, because of improved results in its beef business. Net income for the quarter ending Sept. 27 will be 35 cents a share to 40 cents a share, Tyson said. That would be up from 24 cents a year earlier and would beat the average estimate of 23 cents from analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company has benefited from a ban on imports of cattle from Canada, where a case of mad cow disease was discovered in May, the chief executive, John Tyson, said.

title: Some Dow Jones Workers To Avoid TV Appearances
description: The union representing 1,700 editorial and other employees at Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that, as a result of a contract dispute, its members would refuse to appear for at least a month on televised segments arranged by Dow Jones and broadcast on CNBC, the financial news channel.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Chrtien Has A Successor
description: Former Finance Minister Paul Martin locked up the Liberal Party leadership race, winning 90 percent of the delegates who will attend a national party convention in November. Mr. Martin, a moderate who wants to improve relations with the United States, defeated Heritage Minister Sheila Copps. He will succeed Prime Minister Jean Chrtien no later than February, then face a national election. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: More Forensic Science In the Service of America
description: Now is the time for fans of ''JAG,'' who are known for keeping the show second only to country in their hearts, to open their homes to another well-plotted show by Donald P. Bellisario that involves patriotism and forensics. It is ''Navy NCIS,'' and it will have its premiere tonight on CBS. When ''JAG'' is not on, ''Navy NCIS'' works very well for a fix of martial badinage, wholly justified gunplay and women in epaulets.

description: Is it possible for runway fashion, that seeming instrument of ageist oppression, to make a woman feel too young? Have the forces of style conspired to turn 54 into the new 22? Should anyone sprouting gray hair reject a colorist?

title: ING Sues Deloitte And J.P. Morgan
description: ING Groep is contending in a lawsuit filed yesterday that J. P. Morgan Chase & Company and Deloitte & Touche helped the health care financier National Century Financial Enterprises Inc. defraud ING of hundreds of millions of dollars.

description: FITZGERALD--Benjamin J., age 82, of Mendham, NJ (formerly of Brooklyn), on September 21st, 2003. Retired Special Agent, DEA. Husband of Agnes (Dowling). Main Street, Mendham, NJ 07945 or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUELLER, STEPHANIE

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Oil Executive Resigns
description: The chairman of the board of Norway's flagship oil producer, Statoil, resigned as pressure increased on top managers in connection with an 11-year, $15.5 million consulting contract that Norwegian police are investigating as a possible attempt to buy influence in Iran. Statoil's chairman, Leif Terje Loeddesoel, who called the affair a ''gross violation'' of ethical guidelines last week but admitted knowing about it for several months without notifying the rest of the board, stepped down Sunday. The chief executive, Olav Fjell, is expected to face more questions from the board about the June 2002 contract with Horten Investment, a small Caribbean-registered company. It is led by a London-based Iranian whom the newspaper Dagens Naeringsliv has linked to Mehdi Hashemi Rafsanjani, the son of the former Iranian president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani. The younger Mr. Rafsanjani has denied any connection to the case. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Health Insurers Gain A Huge New Lobby
description: Two powerful insurance groups announced today that they would merge, forming a huge lobby that could speak with one voice on Medicare and industry regulation.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: BLOOMBERG URGES ACTION AGAINST BIAS CRIMES Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he had written to the city's five district attorneys to urge them to vigorously prosecute people charged with bias crimes. "I strongly urge," the mayor wrote, "that you punish such criminals to the fullest extent permitted by law and vigorously utilize" a law passed in 2000 that strengthened the penalties for crimes that are motivated by bias. The mayor talked about the letter at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge during the opening ceremony of a small waterfront park. The letter comes after two weeks of escalating criticism from several black City Council members over the Police Department's handling of an attack on a black college student and her white and Hispanic friends by a group of white youths in a Staten Island park. Several more possible bias attacks were reported during the weekend. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Decision in Rent Dispute Yields Only More Questions
description: The residents of Peter Cooper Village know their stabilized rents are about to rise, and they know the increase has something to do with new wiring that was installed four years ago. Beyond that, though, many are baffled.

title: Making Science Rock, Roll and Swing From the Treetops
description: Ever since science became a world apart from the arts and culture and daily life, and there were no more da Vincis painting a Mona Lisa one day and carrying out a scientific experiment the next, there have been scientists trying to bridge their isolation from the rest of the world.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: State To Appeal Use Of Disputed Cable
description: Seeking to stop the use of an underwater cable that sends power across Long Island Sound, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal announced yesterday that the state would appeal in federal court to overturn the Department of Energy's order allowing indefinite operation of the cable. ''Federal officials cannot unlawfully declare an emergency by dictatorial edict, enabling operation of an illegally located cable that endangers Connecticut's environment, consumers and economy,'' Mr. Blumenthal said. The cable was turned on after the blackout in the Northeast in August. New York officials have argued that the 24-mile, 330-megawatt cable is an essential source of extra energy. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: New Cabinet In Japan Emphasizes Fiscal Reform
description: Bolstered by his sweeping re-election as leader of Japan's governing party, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi put together a new cabinet today that strongly suggested he would press ahead with tough economic reforms in the world's second largest economy.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Former Pentagon Spokeswoman Joins Cnn As Analyst
description: Victoria Clarke, the Pentagon's spokeswoman during the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, has joined CNN as a political and policy analyst, the network said. Ms. Clarke, who is known as Torie, retired from the government in June. As the assistant secretary of defense for public affairs, she helped rewrite military rules so reporters could join troops on the front lines in Iraq. Before joining the Pentagon, Ms. Clarke was general manager in Washington for Hill & Knowlton, the public relations and marketing firm.

title: Mismatched Lovers and Contrasting Brothers
description: Generic emotion can be cued no more reliably these days than with a few bars from Coldplay's ''Clocks.'' That keyboard phrase and those high ''oohs'' may constitute the ''Nadia's Theme'' of our time. It would be foolhardy to pass up such a bargain means of raising lumps in viewers' throats, and thus the song makes its way into ''I'm With Her'' and ''One Tree Hill,'' a comedy and a drama that have their premieres tonight.

title: Iran Parades New Missile on War Anniversary
description: Iran showed off its midrange missile today for the first time, during a military parade marking the 23rd anniversary of the start of the war with Iraq.

description: With advances toward ultrastrong fibers, the concept of building an elevator 60,000 miles high to carry cargo into space is moving from the realm of science fiction to the fringes of reality.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Technology Acquisition
description: The French comput-er services company Atos Origin agreed to purchase the information technology unit of Schlumberger for about 1.3 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in cash and stock. Atos will pay 400 million euros in cash and 19.3 million shares of Atos. Atos said the purchase of the unit, Schlumberger Sema, will create one of the leading information technology companies, with an annual revenue of more than 5 billion euros. Schlumberger acquired Sema in 2001 for 5.2 billion euros. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

description: For 29 years, the Nikon Small World competition has looked for art where many people do not know it exists, on the microscopic level.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Brother Of Qaeda Operative Held
description: Law enforcement authorities confirmed the arrest of a brother of Riduan Isamuddin, the Indonesian better known as Hambali who is said to be the link between Al Qaeda and the Indonesian group Jemaah Islamiyah. The brother, Rusman Gunawan, was arrested with 14 students from Malaysia and Indonesia in raids on seminaries in the port city of Karachi, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry said. The authorities said they were ''terrorists or suspected to have links with terrorists.'' Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: DNA Database To Be Expanded
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed legislation yesterday that requires all newly convicted criminals in New Jersey to submit saliva samples for the state and national DNA databank. Officials said the new law would expand the state's database to more than 140,000 DNA samples in the next two years. A previous law required samples only from those convicted of sexual assault or other violent offenses. The new law will also require offenders on parole or probation to provide samples. It also budgets $8 million a year for 40 scientists to process the DNA. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Upbeat Trio In a Groove Of Control And Flux
description: Twenty years into their continuing project, the Keith Jarrett-Gary Peacock-Jack DeJohnette trio has grown both very tight and very loose. You can't open up the basic small-group principle of theme-solos-theme as much as these musicians do without a commitment to indeterminacy, and you can't get through as many songs as they did at Carnegie Hall on Friday night without an intuition for knowing the most efficient paths to cross.

title: L.I. District Is Criticized In Hazing Case
description: The Long Island school district where three varsity football players are suspected of sexually abusing several younger teammates has not cooperated with a criminal investigation into the allegations, the Pennsylvania prosecutor who is handling the case said yesterday.

title: Frustration Is Growing As Storm Blackouts Persist
description: Utility companies made major strides to restore power today in parts of Maryland and Northern Virginia, but severe damage sharply slowed work in southern Virginia and North Carolina, where more than 700,000 homes and businesses remained dark for yet another day.

title: Q & A / Robert Shiller : More bubbles, more risk of inequality
description: Just as the stock market bubble began to burst in early 2000, Robert Shiller, an economics professor at Yale University, published "Irrational Exuberance," a book that explained the psychological and social dynamics behind the bubble. In his latest book, "The New Financial Order: Risk in the 21st Century," Shiller describes new risks of inequality in the coming decades. He recently spoke with Sharon Reier for the International Herald Tribune.

title: 5 Die in Dutchess County Crash; Witnesses Reported Wild Driving
description: Five people were killed in a head-on collision on a two-lane highway in Dutchess County, N.Y., on Sunday night, shortly after one of the cars was seen driving erratically, the state police said yesterday.

title: Bon Jovi Moves From Rock to Soul
description: At a pep rally today outside the Wachovia Spectrum in Philadelphia, the rock star Jon Bon Jovi, a New Jersey resident and a devout Giants fan, will be introduced as the co-owner of the Philadelphia Soul, an Arena Football League expansion team.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Dabhol Claims
description: Bechtel and General Electric said they had filed arbitration claims of about $600 million each against the Indian government to recover investments in the Dabhol power plant. The companies hold 10 percent each in the $2.9 billion Dabhol Power. Enron holds 65 percent and the government-run power utility owns the rest. The plant ran into trouble in June 2001 and stopped generating power when a utility run by the government of Maharashtra, which was trying to buy the plant, defaulted. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Holders of Argentine Bonds Reject 25% Redemption Offer
description: Argentina's gambit of offering to pay back a quarter of the $94 billion it owes private bondholders worldwide provoked a predictably angry rejection from investors yesterday, and analysts predicted long and painful negotiations.

description: LONDON, Sept. 23  Hugo Young, 64, a leading columnist, political author and chairman of the Scott Trust, which owns The Guardian and The Observer newspapers, died of cancer Monday in London.

title: 2 Teams Going In Different Directions
description: Thirteen days ago, George Steinbrenner was still grousing about the Yankees and the delirious fans in Chicago were still hoping for a repeat of 1906, the only time the White Sox played the Cubs in the World Series.
