title: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Strong Quake
description: An early morning earthquake with a magnitude of 6.5 sent thousands of frightened people scrambling for safety into the streets but caused minimal damage and loss of life. The epicenter was just north of Santiago, close to the north coast resort town of Puerto Plata. According to wire service reports, two people died of heart attacks and an office building collapsed. The quake was clearly felt in the capital, Santo Domingo, about 95 miles south of the epicenter. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Base Abroad
description: Russia signed an agreement with Kyrgyzstan to establish a military air base there, countering the increased American military presence in Central Asia that has followed the war in Afghanistan. The agreement clears the way for Russia's first new overseas military base since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. Russia first announced its plans to deploy a squadron of fighter jets and helicopters in Kant, Kyrgyzstan, last fall. The base will include roughly 10 aircraft and 300 troops, a smaller force than announced initially. Officials said the base would provide air power for a collective security treaty among Russia, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan and Tajikistan and was intended to cooperate with rather than compete against American forces in Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Candidate Loses Finance Ruling
description: A county judge today ordered Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante to stop using nearly $4 million raised through an old campaign account and funneled into a new one to finance his bid in the recall election. Furthermore, the judge ordered the money returned to donors.

title: At U.N., Bush Stands Firm on Iraq, but Also Asks for Help
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23 - President Bush challenged the United Nations today to put aside its sharp differences over Iraq and to help the Iraqi people build a peaceful and democratic country on a timetable that made sense to them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRILL, SELMA S.

Proud great-grandma of Sam and Alissa. Interment private. Contributions in memory may be made to Westchester ARC, 121 Westmoreland Ave, White Plains, NY 10606.

title: Troops In Iraq: More Isn't Better
description: It has become almost an article of faith among Bush administration critics on both the left and right: more troops are needed to straighten out the ''mess'' in Iraq. Even President Bush is expected to repeat his call for other countries to contribute forces when he appears before the United Nations today. Few proponents, though, have stopped to explain just how flooding the country with more soldiers will fix the problems on the ground, accelerate the transfer of power to an elected Iraqi government, or pave the way for American troops to return home sooner.

title: A Lesson for the Immune System
description: Two new studies have found that teaching older people how to relax or manage stress can result in measurable improvements in the ability of their immune systems to protect them from infection.

title: Caught In The Iraqi Dramatics
description: During the first half of the 90's, I spent some time on the ''Whither NATO?'' circuit. I'd sit in stately European palaces with diplomats, parliamentarians and multilateral men who used the word ''modality'' a lot, and we'd discuss the post-cold-war international order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUPFERMAN, THEODORE R.
description: KUPFERMAN--Theodore R. Judge Kupferman, rest in peace. You had a wonderful and honest life and I learned so much from you. May you rest in heaven, too. Since you left the appellate division, everything in New York City and New York State is very disappointing. And there are very few judges that remain in your honest class. Our city and state are in a tragic condition, but the great obituary in The New York Times and supported in The New York Law Journal reveals one very good solution, your punch line, ''It does not take Gertrude Stein to know that a contract is a contract is a contract.'' And hopefully with your words this basic law will be reinstated in the minds of all of the state's political leaders. Judge Kupferman, rest in peace. Your honesty and dignity I learned from and followed all of my life. I will die with it. When I get there with you, let's leave it a dignified world. All of your family is certainly proud of your 100% honesty. Sincerely, Abraham J. Hirschfeld

title: California Officials Confident After Hearing on Recall
description: Encouraged by hard-hitting questions posed by a federal appeals court here, California officials predicted today that the recall election for Gov. Gray Davis would occur as scheduled in 15 days.

description: The New York Times Company and its development partner are expected to take control tomorrow of a large parcel on Eighth Avenue, across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where they plan to build a new 52-story headquarters for the newspaper company.

Klein, Rabbi Gerald Cohen, President

title: Star Starts a Show; Tom Waits Ends It
description: The star isn't usually the opening act at a concert, but things work differently with the Dalai Lama, who begins his daily spiritual practices at 3:30 a.m. Since he had to be in bed early, he spoke at the beginning of the concert on Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall to benefit Healing the Divide, an American organization that tries to use technology to preserve and provide access to ancient cultures like that of Tibet.

title: Corrections

He is a Republican. The article also misspelled the given name of a departing spokeswoman for Gov. John G. Rowland whose job included answering questions about the investigations. She is Michele Sullivan, not Michelle.

title: The Week That Was: New York Sends Some Signals; A Universal Invitation: Slip On a Dress
description: History, one might argue, has not produced a more liberating garment for womankind than the day dress, as it was conceived in the late 20th century. Though retailers have prattled on for years about the success of separates -- cardigans, blazers, trousers -- they require time and thought to put together. Dresses ask only to be pulled out of the closet and slid over the head.

title: Giants Stadium Talks Continue
description: Officials of the Giants and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority met yesterday over their continuing dispute about improvements to Giants Stadium and will meet again today. Unless they reach an agreement, it will be impossible for the stadium to be a candidate for the 2008 Super Bowl.

title: DOMINION EXPECTS TO SELL UNIT AT $650 MILLION LOSS
description: Dominion Resources Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its telecommunications business at an expected loss of $650 million because of an overabundance of fiber optic lines. The company said it would record a charge in the quarter to reflect the unit's drop in value. Dominion Telecom connected midsized cities east of the Mississippi, like Wilmington, N.C., and Albany, to regions that were better served by fiber optic networks. Demand for the services did not grow as expected. ''Our best course of action now is to take steps to minimize the impact, learn from it and get it behind us, and that is exactly what we are doing,'' the chief executive, Thomas Capps, said in a statement.

title: Reddick of U.S. Proves She Is Ready for Prime Time
description: Brandi Chastain attended practice on crutches today, a Californian with a little deuce coupe sensibility giving way to Cat Reddick, a former debutante from Alabama who prefers John Deere caps and pickup trucks.

title: Dressing (and Undressing) For a Stomp Back to the 70's
description: It's one of pop's eternal cycles. A style has its moment, curdles into kitsch, lingers as a guilty pleasure, then re-emerges as a fond and shameless revival. That cycle has now yielded to the Darkness, an English band whose album ''Permission to Land'' (Atlantic) has reached No. 1 in Britain. The group played a sold-out show at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night.

title: Tiny Goals Can Yield Big Gains
description: Adding behavioral teaching techniques to a rehabilitation program led to significant improvement for stroke and brain injury victims trying to regain use of their limbs, a study released yesterday found.

title: Uncoupling Campus and Company
description: In the late 1970's, Dr. Sheldon Krimsky was a young assistant professor at Tufts -- politically nave, by his own admission -- when he was asked to lead a team of students investigating whether a chemical company had polluted water wells in a nearby town.

description: The Ills of Overeating

title: The Filthy Truth About the Hands
description: The SARS outbreak in Toronto apparently caused men there to start washing their hands after using the bathroom, according to a new survey conducted for the American Society of Microbiology.

title: Clarett Sues N.F.L. Over Draft Eligibility
description: Maurice Clarett, the suspended sophomore running back for Ohio State, sued the National Football League today, asking that a judge throw out a league rule that prohibits players from joining the N.F.L. unless they have been out of high school for at least three years. It is the first time a player has challenged the rule in court.

title: Plenty of Clues In Iraqi Crimes, But Few Trails
description: Investigators have recovered a severed hand, an Iraqi license plate and vehicle parts bearing a unique identification number from a Russian flatbed truck that carried the tremendous bomb that exploded on Aug. 19 outside the United Nations mission in Baghdad, senior government officials said.

title: American Express To Seek Banks As Card Partners
description: The American Express Company, encouraged by a recent court ruling, said yesterday that it would begin pursuing partnerships with United States banks that belong to Visa and MasterCard networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINKIN, DAVID
description: MINKIN--David. 99, of New York, and Palm Beach, FL. Passed away September 19, 2003. Adored uncle of Patricia and Howard Lester. Greatuncle of Peter and Prescott Lester and Pamela Ford. Great-great-uncle of Owen Ford and Scott Lester. He was a true renaissance man, a leader of the community and a second father to us all. He will be sorely missed. Services Wednesday, September 24, 10 AM, at Riverside Nassau North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI; 516487-9600. Contributions may be made to the Mayo Foundation, attn: Paul Harkess, Rochester, MN 55905.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Attacked At Nightclub
description: Two men were injured in separate incidents at a Midtown nightclub early yesterday morning, the police said. In the first case, a bouncer working at the nightclub, Vue, on East 50th Street, was slashed with a razor after ordering patrons to leave during a dispute, the police said. The police later arrested Gregory Moore, 30, of Staten Island, and charged him with assault. About an hour later, at 3:20 a.m., a dispute broke out in the club, with another bouncer ordering patrons to leave. Once outside, a patron was stabbed in the neck. He was not immediately identified, and his condition was listed as stable at Bellevue Hospital Center. No arrests have been made in the stabbing. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: High Costs Bring Indian Motorcycle to a Halt
description: When the gleaming reincarnations of Indian Motorcycles rolled off the factory floor four years ago, enthusiasts wondered whether the new machines would recapture the glory of the vintage line that had ceased production nearly a half-century earlier.

title: Despite Losing Some Biggies, Cable Triumphs at the Emmys
description: The Emmy Awards, which usually confound television executives, critics and viewers alike, remained true to form this year, rewarding many of the networks' war horses, like ''Everybody Loves Raymond'' and ''The West Wing,'' while signaling an apparent sea change in what constitutes high-quality television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, JAMES
description: LERNER--James, 92. Husband of Gert. Father of Dick and Betty. Grandfather and great-grandfather. His light will shine forever within us. Services 11 AM Wednesday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 91St/Amsterdam Ave.

title: JetBlue Moves to Repair Its Image After Sharing Files
description: Airline executives, industry analysts and privacy groups said yesterday that JetBlue might have to do more to appease fliers than issue an apology to those who complained about its decision to share information on 1.1 million customers with a Pentagon contractor investigating security issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, JOHN F. II
description: RYAN--John F. II, 71, died peacefully on September 20, 2003 at home in Barnegat, NJ. Former Deputy Mayor of Barnegat, he was extremely active in the Ocean County Democratic Committee. Survived by Dorothy, his wife of 50 years, his daughter Lisa, sons Robert, John F. III, and Steven, all of New Jersey and grandchildren, Justin, Kali, Dylan, Sean, Danny & Derek. He will be remembered by family, friends and colleagues for his charm, wit and love of all things Irish. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Southern Ocean County Hospice and Home Care Services, 1140 Route 72 West, Manahawkin, New Jersey 08050.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILEY, JOHN M.
description: BAILEY--John M. Former Chief State's Attorney for the State of Connecticut. Husband of Elizabeth D. Bailey. Passed away peacefully at home Monday, September 22nd. Survivors include his two sons, John and Brian, his three sisters, Barbara, Louise and Judith. Friends may call at Ahern Funeral Home, 180 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT, Wednesday, 4-8 PM. Funeral Mass on Thursday, 10 AM, Cathedral of St. Joseph, Hartford, CT.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Brooklyn Scheduled For Spraying
description: The New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene plans ground spraying of pesticides to kill mosquitoes that may carry the West Nile virus in areas of Brooklyn from 7:30 p.m. Wednesday to 6 a.m. Thursday. Trinity Cemetery in Manhattan is also scheduled for spraying. Maps are available at www.nyc.gov/health/wnv.

description: The first report card on the United Nation's two-year-old commitment to defeat AIDS gives the world's countries generally low marks in their efforts to overcome ignorance about the disease and provide access to prevention and treatment measures, United Nations officials said here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIPS, WILLIAM M.
description: GIPS--William M. Born August 22, 1919 in NYC. Died September 23, 2003 in Scarsdale, NY. Proud graduate of Baruch College, CCNY. Major in Finance Corps WWII. Master Mason King SolomonBeethoven Lodge. Retired partner Deloitte & Touche. Officer New York State Society of CPAs. Yankees fan. Teller of stories and jokes. Devoted volunteer. He leaves his beloved wife Joan Stern Gips; children Kathy and Jim Gips; grandchildren Amy and Jonathan Gips; stepchildren Edie Stern, Emily Lasser, Lisa Tamarin and Seth Stern; stepgrandchildren Sandra and Mark Tamarin, Jonina, Jesse, Josh and Jonathan Lasser. Services September 25, 1:30 pm at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers.

Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth and Christopher Rile and Julie and Mark Kessler. Adoring greatgrandfather of Jessica, Nicholas, Lily and Ryan. Dear brother of Henrietta and the late David and Leonard. He will be deeply missed. Memorial services Thursday, September 25, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. title: 'West Wing' Comes To Terms With G.O.P.
description: John Wells has been the driving creative force behind the most popular television show of the last decade, ''E.R.,'' but he says the prospect of stepping into the breach to take over NBC's admired White House drama, ''The West Wing,'' has left him feeling daunted.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Drug Ring Broken, Authorities Say
description: A sophisticated drug ring selling about $8.3 million of crack and powder cocaine a year has been dismantled by the police, the Burlington County prosecutor's office announced yesterday. Twelve suspects were arrested this week and accused of dealing about two kilos of cocaine a week, worth $160,000. The operations were said to be in Willingboro, Edgewater Park, Burlington City, Beverly and Burlington Township. The yearlong investigation also resulted in the seizure of large amounts of cocaine, more than $10,000 in cash, and nine luxury automobiles, the prosecutor's office said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAROLL, LEONIE
description: FAROLL--Leonie. On September 18, 2003 at age 75. Beloved daughter of the late Joseph and Berenice Faroll and sister of the late Miriam Stich and survived by one nephew and two nieces. Miss Faroll was the bastion of strength of the residents and staff of 1120 Park Avenue and served as a historian and treasurer for more than 30 years. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Tuesday, September 23rd, 7-9 PM with services Wednesday, September 24th, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Linden Hill Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Wellesley College or a charity of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Bank Candidate Endorsed
description: The governor of the French central bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, left, won the endorsement of the European Parliament in his bid to become president of the European central bank, moving him closer to taking the job on Nov. 1. The parliament voted at a session in Strasbourg, France, 315 to 83 with 75 abstentions, to back Mr. Trichet as the bank's second president since the debut of the euro in 1999. He will succeed Wim Duisenberg once the governments of the member nations give final approval.

title: Bush, at U.N., Defends Policy Over Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23  President Bush stood today before the allies who had opposed the invasion of Iraq and rebuffed calls from some of them to transfer sovereignty rapidly to Iraqis as a means to calm the anti-American violence there.

title: White House Presses Its $87 Billion Request for Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  The Bush administration told senators today that the $87 billion it seeks for the campaigns in Iraq and Afghanistan would be invested, in a larger sense, in the security of the United States and the cause of freedom itself.

title: Washington Post Realigns Unit
description: The Washington Post Company said today that it had completed its revamping, which was mainly done to turn The Washington Post into a subsidiary. Previously, the newspaper was an operating division.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Reuters And Lotus To Join On Instant Messaging
description: The Reuters Group and the Lotus division of I.B.M. plan to connect their corporate instant messaging products. An agreement is expected to be announced today that would permit Reuters Messaging subscribers to connect with Lotus Sametime instant messaging, a Reuters spokesman said. A similar agreement was struck this month between Reuters and AOL Time Warner's AOL Instant Messenger and ICQ. Sametime will be available on Reuters Messenger in early 2004.

title: Partisan Battle Builds in Congress Over Bush's Spending Request
description: The huge sums requested by the White House to occupy and rebuild Iraq sharply inflamed partisan tensions on Capitol Hill today, with Republican leaders accusing Democrats of undermining the military and sowing division by criticizing the Bush administration's postwar policies.

title: Celebrating Connections Between Food And Holidays
description: In ''A Sweet Year: A Taste of the Jewish Holidays'' (Doubleday, $12.95) Mark Podwal describes in text and paintings how each of nine holidays relates to food. The brief text is suitable to read to young children or for school-age youngsters to read themselves. The 32-page book begins with Rosh Hashana, which starts on Friday evening. Apples and honey are shown in the accompanying illustration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAFT, SALLY (DENENHOLZ)
description: KRAFT--Sally (Denenholz). On September 23, 2003. Good friend of Trini Montes. Beloved sister of Mollie Scheff and Lee Kleeman. Dear aunt and loving friend. Visiting Wednesday 5-9pm. Services Thursday 10am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave (at 10th St), NYC.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: 30 Million Guns
description: A new study of weaponry in sub-Saharan Africa says there are far fewer small arms than the 100 million typically estimated around the continent. But the 30 million guns and other small arms that do exist, according to the survey results, are more likely to be in the hands of civilians than armies or police agencies. ''This new estimate should renew confidence that the small-arms problem in Africa can be brought under control through conventional means, such as increased regulation, strong enforcement and collection and destruction efforts,'' said Peter Batchelor, director of the Small Arms Survey, an independent research group based in Geneva. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Scholastic Loss Narrows to $24.8 Million
description: The Scholastic Corporation, the publisher of the Harry Potter children's books in the United States, said its quarterly loss narrowed to $24.8 million as sales rose more than expected.

title: A Crisp As Easy As Pie. No, Easier.
description: ''YOU could make this dessert with your eyes closed,'' Rebecca Charles said as she stood in front of her Cuisinart processor making the crumbly topping for a blackberry nectarine crisp.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Long Island; A Big REIT Is Taking A New Tack
description: Members of the family that founded the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, the Long Island-based real estate investment trust with more than 20 million square feet of office and industrial space in the New York area, are in the process of taking part of their properties private in a $315 million transaction.

title: A Corner Shadowed by Racial Tensions
description: The day after the fight, the pool hall was quiet. There was the occasional deliveryman or a couple of teenagers looking for a quiet thrill banging on the video game machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLACH, RHODA (AGATA)
description: BELLACH--Rhoda (Agata). The Agata family expresses its sorrow over the passing of Rhoda Bellach, sister of Burton Agata, sister-in-law of Dale Agata, aunt of Seth and Gail and the late Abby Agata and great-aunt of Adam. Our heartfelt thanks to Steger cousins Dr. Wilbur Steger, Sue and Dr. Bruce Steger, Barbara and Jerry Lipps and Fran and Charles Sloane for their magnificent contributions to her comfort and happiness during a most trying time. Our condolences to Rhoda's children Steven and Francine.

title: In a Poll, Baghdad Residents Call Freedom Worth the Price
description: After five months of foreign military occupation and the ouster of Saddam Hussein, nearly two-thirds of Baghdad residents believe that the removal of the Iraqi dictator has been worth the hardships they have been forced to endure, a new Gallup poll shows.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Director Of Public Affairs
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft named Mark Corallo, a senior adviser who has been a defender of the Bush administration's antiterrorism initiatives, as his chief spokesman and director of the Justice Department's public affairs office. Mr. Corallo had been the top deputy to the last public affairs director, Barbara Comstock, who left the department last week. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

description: The Dalai Lama's people were getting a bit tense. ''Is he here yet?'' one aide asked under her breath. The clock was ticking, and the Rev. Al Sharpton's aide was out in the street staring into the traffic as if trying to will the minister's presence.

title: HOME DEPOT IS PLANNING SECOND STORE IN MANHATTAN
description: Home Depot Inc., the home-improvement retailer, said yesterday that it planned to open a store on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, on Third Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, in mid-2004. At 83,000 square feet, it will be about a third of the size of a typical Home Depot. It is the second store that the company has announced for Manhattan. Home Depot, which is based in Atlanta, said earlier this month that it would open a store in the Chelsea neighborhood next year.

description: California is trying a deceptively simple approach to the problem of junk e-mail: it is banning spam.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Agreement For Abuse Victims
description: Lawyers for 552 people who brought sexual abuse claims against the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston have completed a settlement agreement for their clients. Under the agreement, plaintiffs will receive $80,000 to $300,000 based on the severity of their abuse as judged by a mediator. Parents who filed suit will automatically receive $20,000. Plaintiffs' lawyers have until Oct. 23 to get the mandatory 80 percent of survivors to agree to the deal, which lawyers say should not be a problem. The archdiocese will pay the claims on Dec. 22. The $85 million settlement was announced as a memorandum of understanding on Sept. 9. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Sept. 11 Panel Weighs Ideas For Domestic Intelligence
description: The independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks said today that it was weighing proposals for an overhaul of American intelligence and law enforcement agencies, including the creation of a special domestic intelligence agency that would most likely take over some F.B.I. responsibilities.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EASTMAN KODAK CO., Rochester, the world's largest photography company, said it had acquired disease-detection software from MiraMedica Inc., Los Gatos, Calif., to broaden its line of digital health-imaging products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Go Pursue Your Dream, as Wild as It May Seem
description: The only voice heard in ''7 Year ZigZag,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinema in the Greenwich Village, belongs to Richard Green, the film's director, writer, co-composer, leading actor and principal subject.

title: PEP BOYS SAYS PROFIT WILL FALL AS MUCH AS 18%
description: Pep Boys - Manny, Moe & Jack, the auto parts and services chain, said yesterday that its profit would fall as much as 18 percent in its current quarter after costs for closing or redesigning stores. Analysts overestimated the benefits of cost-cutting and underestimated the costs of the changes, the chief financial officer, George Babich, said in a statement. The company, which had net losses in the last three quarters, said in July it would eliminate about 860 jobs and close 33 stores. Profit, before a gain, will drop to 23 cents to 25 cents a share in the third quarter, which ends in October, from 28 cents a year earlier, the company said. Pep Boys is based in Philadelphia.

title: Retail Wizards Prepare for a Big Test: Minnesota
description: The temperature outside may have been hovering around 30 degrees, a raw September day even for this provincial capital in western Canada, but inside the West Edmonton Mall, it was still summer. Dozens of people were swimming in a five-acre heated water park complete with palm trees, cabanas, a simulated strip of sand and machine-made waves. A short walk away, hundreds more looked on as a trainer cavorted with a dolphin.

title: Swiss Carrier and British Air Reach Accord for Partnership
description: The carousel of European airline alliances took a further turn today after the troubled Swiss International Air Lines announced a partnership with British Airways, and said it would join the OneWorld Alliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, BETTE
description: KAHN--Bette. On September 18 in NYC after a brief illness. Beloved mother of Hilary Shaw. Cherished grandmother of two and great grandmother of two.

title: Republicans Seek Offshore Energy Inventory
description: Congressional Republicans today proposed taking a national inventory of offshore oil and gas reserves as part of a new energy policy, a move that drilling opponents say is a step toward exploration in coastal areas now off limits.

title: INTRODUCTION OF NOVARTIS PAINKILLER IS DELAYED
description: Novartis, the Swiss drug maker, said yesterday that it would not be able to introduce its Prexige painkiller in the United States before 2005 because the Food and Drug Administration had requested more information. Analysts had said that sales of Prexige, which won British approval earlier this month, might top $2 billion a year. Novartis had said it expected to introduce the drug globally in 2004. Prexige would compete with the world's top-selling painkiller, Celebrex from Pfizer Inc., as well as Vioxx from Merck & Company. Novartis is based in Basel, Switzerland.

title: The Turkish Card
description: ''Self government for the people of Iraq,'' a resolute President Bush told the U.N., would be ''reached by orderly and democratic process . . . neither hurried nor delayed by the wishes of other parties.'' That was America's answer to those who want to see us fail in rebuilding a free Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the refusal of unionized employees at Dow Jones & Company to make voluntary appearances on CNBC because of a contract dispute included a company spokeswoman's erroneous reference to the union status of Michael Santoli, a senior editor of Barron's who appeared on the channel on Monday. He is a union member. While he has an agreement under which he makes regular appearances on CNBC, he said he did not intend to make appearances beyond those required by that deal.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Leaves Fleet Street
description: The Reuters Group will move from Fleet Street in London, where it has made its headquarters since the start of World War II. The company, which is 152 years old, is the last news organization based in Britain to leave Fleet Street, which was once the industry's home. In an agreement with the Canary Wharf Group, Reuters said, it will shift most of its London employees to the Docklands in 2005 to save about 5 million ($8.3 million) a year. The Docklands, in East London, were once covered with derelict warehouses but now have Britain's tallest skyscraper.

title: For a Daughter, Rosh Hashana Is a Holiday Frozen in Time
description: WHEN I asked my 90-year-old mother, Pearl, why the shank bone I buy every year for my Passover Seder does not look like hers, she thought a second. Maybe it's because she has been refreezing the same bone for 20, 30, maybe 40 years, she said.

title: A Red With the Steak? A White? A Blue?
description: WHAT is this? Some kind of international intrigue? One of the best-known chains of steakhouses in the country has decided to rid itself of foreign wines. Not America First; America Only.

title: Restaurants Try to Unchain America
description: EVERY six weeks Don Luria invites four or five middle schoolers to dine with him and his wife at Cafe Terracotta, their restaurant in Tucson, as part of a program called Kids Dine Out. Most youngsters, he said, have eaten only in fast-food or chain restaurants, but at Cafe Terracotta they sample unfamiliar foods like calamari and duck, are encouraged to ask questions about the menu and learn basic restaurant etiquette. ''The kids' eyes totally open up,'' Mr. Luria said.

title: Hugo Young, Leading British Columnist, Is Dead at 64
description: Hugo Young, a leading columnist, political author and chairman of the Scott Trust, which owns The Guardian and The Observer, died Monday in London. He was 64.

title: President Bush at the U.N.; Afghan Women's Rights
description: From some of the most desperate corners of Afghanistan, about 45 brave women have embarked on a cause that hardly seems on Washington's powerful radar. President Bush's speech to the United Nations yesterday barely mentioned Afghanistan's struggle to build what he calls a ''decent and just society.'' Yet recently, these Afghan women endured great risk in that very cause. They traveled to Kandahar, now considered a dangerous city, deep in Taliban territory. There, they crafted an extraordinary document they have called the Afghan Women's Bill of Rights.

title: Rangers Aim to Fix Power Play
description: The one bright spot during the Rangers' first three preseason games was an experiment on the power play on Saturday night against Detroit.

description: In percent

description: O'BRIEN--James M. of Rockville Centre, NY, on September 22, 2003. Beloved husband of Dolores Rose. Loving father of Elizabeth (Richard) Nyachiro, Jeannemarie (Yves Achille) Casimir, and Kathryn (John) Bracciante. Dear grandfather of Isabelle and Yves Casimir. Also survived by his brother Gerard. Reposing Towers Funeral Home, Inc., Long Beach and Foxhurst Rds., Oceanside, NY. Hours Wednesday 79pm, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre, NY, Friday, 10am. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column last Wednesday and a review on Saturday about an appearance at Symphony Space in Manhattan by Habimah, the National Theater of Israel, misstated the precedent. The company came to the United States in the 1990's, a spokesman said; the visit was not its first to this country in 40 years.

title: STARWOOD AWARDED $21 MILLION FROM FORMER LAW FIRM
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, owner of Westin and Sheraton hotels, was awarded $21 million from its former law firm, LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, after a jury ruled yesterday that the firm had mishandled a case in 1999. Starwood said a jury in New York Supreme Court found that the law firm committed malpractice in the case. Under the ruling, the firm must pay punitive damages, which Starwood estimated at $21 million. LeBoeuf Lamb said that it would seek to overturn the verdict. In the case, the owners of the Sheraton Washington Hotel claimed that Starwood improperly managed a purchasing program at the hotel. Starwood said LeBoeuf Lamb's negligence led to the ruling against the company.

title: Keeping Dieters Away From The Kitchen
description: Metro Diet, which just opened a shop at 141 East 56th Street, has dietitians to make its meals healthful and Matthew Tivy, a chef who had been at Chez Louis, to make them tasty. Metro Diet meals follow the Zone diet formula of 40 percent carbohydrates, 30 percent protein and 30 percent fat. The food is sold to go at the shop; three meals and two snacks, totaling 1,200 calories a day for women and 1,400 to 1,600 for men, will be delivered to homes or offices for $29.95 a day, if at least a month's worth are ordered.

title: Judges Seek Repeal of Law On Sentencing
description: The 27 judges who make policy for the federal courts voted unanimously today to ask Congress to repeal a new law that curbs judges' discretion over criminal sentences and subjects judges who issue more lenient sentences to special scrutiny.

title: Reunion for Drer Works, Some Stolen Long Ago
description: You could call it a homecoming of sorts, 200 years late, of art stolen so long ago that most people have forgotten that a theft ever took place. But among the 200 drawings, paintings and watercolors by the 16th-century German artist Albrecht Drer on display at the Albertina Museum here are about 30 that disappeared from the very collection where they are now, once again, being exhibited.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: WOMEN IN CLASS-ACTION SUIT AT MINT A federal sexual harassment complaint against the United States Mint in Denver now includes all 126 women who work there, and not just the 32 women who came forward in June with accusations, making it a class-action case. Over the years, the complainants said, women at the Mint were subjected to sexual insults, jokes and pornographic materials by many of their 400 male co-workers. In the complaint filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, they also said promotions, raises and training were affected if they complained. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Israeli Officers In Love, Trying To Elude Death And Detection
description: The pressures and privations of military life have rarely been portrayed in as much telling detail as they are in ''Yossi and Jagger,'' Eytan Fox's compact (71-minute), touching portrait of a group of bored Israeli soldiers stationed at a cramped army base on the Israeli-Lebanese border. The area they're patrolling is a rutted, snow-covered no-man's-land that appears almost completely lifeless until the moment that enemy firepower explodes out of nowhere.

title: AIRMAN IS CHARGED AS SPY FOR SYRIA AT CAMP IN CUBA
description: An Air Force translator at an American prison camp for captured militants and suspected terrorists at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has been charged with espionage and passing military secrets to Syria, the Pentagon said today.

title: Effort to Void Transit Fare Increase Dies in Court
description: With a terse epitaph -- ''motion for leave to appeal denied'' -- the long fight to wrest fare money from turnstiles and return some of it to riders' pockets was pronounced thoroughly dead yesterday.

title: Nurse Is Charged in Death of Her Mother, 87
description: A Brooklyn nurse who specializes in geriatric care was charged yesterday in the death of her 87-year-old mother, the authorities said.

title: Biggest Union In 8-Year Pact With Times
description: The New York Times and its largest union, the Newspaper Guild of New York, said yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on an eight-year contract that would raise wages a total of 23 percent.

title: Gay Wedding Bells. Why No Hubbub? It's Canada.
description: Gay marriage is the most contentious issue to emerge on the Canadian political scene since Quebec threatened to secede in 1995. Opinion polls show it cuts a fissure across class, age, regions, gender and religious lines -- a recipe for sharp discord in most societies, rich or poor.

title: OPEC Surprises Oil Market by Cutting Production Quotas
description: VIENNA, Sept. 24  Joined for the first time by a representative of post-Saddam Hussein Iraq, OPEC members agreed today to cut oil production, in a surprising move that drove oil prices sharply higher.

title: Broncos Are Rewarded for Taking a Risk on Plummer
description: Jake Plummer was booed by Broncos fans during the preseason. He had arrived as a marquee free agent from the Arizona Cardinals with plenty of baggage. In the preseason, he sometimes looked like the Cardinals quarterback who in six seasons threw 90 touchdown passes with 114 interceptions and had a paltry 69.1 passer rating.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Thousands Enroll In Ground Zero Survey
description: More than 10,000 people have enrolled in New York City's registry to track health problems caused by the destruction of the World Trade Center, the city reported yesterday, 18 days after the registration began. The participants live in 47 states and nine countries. People who sign up go through a 30-minute interview about where they were on Sept. 11, 2001, their exposure to smoke and dust, and any health problems they have suffered since. The city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will conduct periodic follow-ups over the years and will compare the participants' health with that of the general population. People can enroll by calling, toll-free, 1-866-NYC-WTCR (1-866-692-9827), or by visiting www.wtcregistry.org. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Pro-Aristide Gang Leader Found Dead
description: Amiot Mtayer, a longtime supporter of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and the fugitive leader of a gang that terrorized government opponents with impunity was found dead Monday night in the town of St. Marc, shot in the heart and in each eye. Mr. Mtayer, 39, was the leader of the so-called Cannibal Army, a Gonaves-based gang condemned by the Organization of American States for having carried out violent attacks on opponents of Mr. Aristide. He was jailed in 2001 on charges stemming from a fight with a rival gang, but supporters freed him in a spectacular jailbreak. Earlier this year, the authorities voided an arrest warrant against him in connection with the arson of 20 homes during politically motivated violence. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: A. G. Edwards Takes Humorous Approach
description: A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, the brokerage firm, is introducing what it is calling its first broad-based national campaign, which uses humor to play up its relationship with its customers.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Inflation Slows
description: South Africa's inflation slowed to a 21-month low in August, fueling expectations that the central bank will cut interest rates next month for a fourth time since June as the strong rand reduces the prices of imports. The CPIX inflation rate, which excludes mortgages, fell to 6.3 percent from 6.6 percent in July. Prices rose 0.4 percent in the month. The central bank has cut rates three times since June 12 by a total of 3.5 percentage points as inflation slowed toward its 3 percent to 6 percent target.

title: BMW Begins Creative Review
description: BMW of North America in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., part of BMW, said yesterday that it had begun a review of its Western regional creative account, which has been handled for 10 years by Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising in Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Islanders' Goalie Matures Into Role With Big Boys
description: Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro still acts like a brash and hilarious fraternity brother. That should not be a shock. DiPietro would have graduated from Boston University a few months ago had he stayed in school.

title: Lab Infection Blamed for Singapore SARS Case
description: A World Health Organization committee of experts in virology and occupational safety has concluded that a Singaporean researcher who developed SARS last month most likely became infected through contamination in a laboratory in which he worked, Singapore health officials said yesterday.

title: Comcast and Liberty Settle Their Dispute Over Starz Channels
description: Comcast, the largest United States cable operator, won new terms yesterday from Liberty Media for the right to run Starz Encore movie programming on its systems, settling a lawsuit aimed at reducing the price.

title: JETBLUE SUED OVER RELEASE OF PASSENGER DATA
description: The JetBlue Airways Corporation has been sued for disclosing passenger information to a Defense Department contractor. Two lawsuits filed Monday -- one in a state court in Salt Lake City and the other in a federal court in Los Angeles -- seek class-action status to represent other passengers whose names, addresses, phone numbers and flight itineraries were disclosed to Torch Concepts of Huntsville, Ala. The airline, which has apologized, did not return telephone calls seeking a comment.

title: Charges May Be Filed In Release Of Teenager
description: Troublesome and possibly criminal issues have turned up in an internal investigation of the mistaken release of a teenager suspected in the killing of a 7-year-old boy, the Essex County executive, Joseph N. DiVincenzo Jr., said today. The child's death prompted sweeping changes in the state's child welfare system.

title: Corrections
description: The Ivy League Outlook article on Saturday, previewing the football season, misstated the location of this year's Yale-Harvard game, on Nov. 22. It is at Yale.

title: An Italian Classic Looks to the East
description: THERE are almost no limits to what can be used for a braising liquid: stocks, wine, soy sauce, the liquid exuded from onions and other vegetables, or even water.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SALE OF GENERAL MOTORS BUILDING ADVANCES The developer Harry Macklowe is expected to close on his record-breaking $1.4 billion purchase of the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue by the end of this week, despite a last-minute attempt to derail the transaction. The Chancery Court in Delaware yesterday rejected a request from a rival bidder, Sheldon H. Solow, to block the sale. Mr. Solow, who also bid $1.4 billion, claimed that the seller, Conseco , and its broker had acted unfairly in awarding the deal to Mr. Macklowe. Reed Oslan, a Conseco lawyer, said, "We're moving as expeditiously as possible to sell our building to Mr. Macklowe."

title: Guilty Pleas in Securities Case Widen AOL Inquiry
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that two senior executives of the now-defunct online commerce company PurchasePro have pleaded guilty to violating securities laws, escalating its larger related inquiry into America Online, the company's business partner .

title: 'Mama' Is Italian For Meddling
description: 'In Spite of Myself'

title: Death of Dana's Chairman Complicates Takeover Move
description: The death of Joseph M. Magliochetti, the chairman and chief executive of the Dana Corporation, is expected to make it even more difficult for ArvinMeritor to continue its hostile takeover bid for Dana, analysts said.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec To Buy PowerQuest For $150 Million
description: The SymantecCorporation, maker of the Norton antivirus program, agreed yesterday to buy the PowerQuest Corporation for about $150 million to expand its line of disaster-recovery software. PowerQuest products permit computer users to restore files and complete systems after a hardware malfunction or a virus infection. Symantec bought Nexland, a security company, in July, a spokesman, Cris Paden, said.. The acquisition of PowerQuest, based in Orem, Utah, will close by year-end, he said. Shares of Symantec, based in Cupertino, Calif., rose $3.01, to $65.79.

title: 3,200 Apartments to Be Built In Glow of Giant Pepsi Sign
description: Pepsi-Cola is the spot.

title: Goodbye to Gallant Galileo
description: Space engineers called it ''the little engine that could.'' The spacecraft Galileo, which ended its 14-year mission on Sunday when it was sent on a suicidal plunge into Jupiter's atmosphere, overcame daunting obstacles to produce some of the most important planetary observations ever made. Its odyssey was a tribute to human ingenuity in the face of potentially disabling failures, its discoveries testimony to unmanned spaceflights.

title: A New Regime at the White House
description: The new season of ''The West Wing'' begins tonight exactly where the show left off so startlingly in May -- with a Republican president in command.

title: Social Expectations Pressuring Women at Duke, Study Finds
description: Like their male counterparts, the women who win acceptance to Duke University usually have high SAT scores, nearly perfect grade-point averages, and all the right extracurricular activities.

title: David Minkin, 99, Developer and Builder
description: David Minkin, a successful New York-area real estate developer who was also president emeritus of Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn, died on Friday. He was 99 and lived in Queens and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Shares Regain Some Ground as Worries on Dollar Ease
description: Stocks rose broadly yesterday after posting their biggest drop in almost seven weeks on Monday, when the dollar slumped.

title: Pfizer Extends Florida Program for Poor
description: Pfizer Inc. and Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida announced yesterday that they were extending a program for Pfizer to pay for health counseling for poor patients, saying that millions of dollars were saved and that patients' health had improved.

title: Corrections
description: The About New York column on Saturday, about real estate pressures that threaten businesses on Mulberry Street in Little Italy, omitted a word in describing the dining experience at one of them, Paolucci's. It should have said (with the omitted word shown by brackets) that the ambience was the kind that ''tablecloths and Mario Lanza tapes can [not] replicate.''

title: He Loves New York. That's Why He's Selling It.
description: ANYBODY thirsty? In Joseph M. Perello's office suite, there's Snapple by the caseload. After all, drinking the stuff is tantamount to a civic duty now that Snapple is paying for the privilege of being the official un-cola of New York City.

title: Giants' Super Bowl Bid Gets Crucial Backing
description: The Giants and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority agreed in principle yesterday to let the team privately finance extensive renovations to Giants Stadium that would make it eligible to be the location of the 2008 Super Bowl.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Police Identify Wounded Student
description: The police identified the student shot by Spokane Police Department officers on Monday after a standoff in a high school classroom as 16-year-old Sean Fitzpatrick and said a long suicide note was found in his home. At a news conference, Chief Roger Bragdon characterized the shooting as an attempted ''suicide by cop.'' On Monday the student took a 9 millimeter semiautomatic pistol to Lewis and Clark High School and barricaded himself in a third-floor classroom. Three officers shot him after he threatened them with the gun, Chief Bragdon said. The youth is in critical condition. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Clinton 'History' Doesn't Repeat Itself in China
description: In her autobiography, ''Living History,'' Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton recounts how China's imprisonment of a prominent human rights activist, Harry Wu, caused a sensation in the United States and nearly derailed her plans to attend a United Nations women's conference held in Beijing in 1995.

title: Diplomats Check In, Security Hits a High And Tips Hit a Low
description: The concierge has nothing to do -- no plays to book or restaurants to reserve for this crowd with a higher purpose. The maids have only 20 minutes to clean the most important rooms, and are trailed by Secret Service officers who watch them, and their cleaning supplies, with suspicion. The tips are terrible; the doormen try to call in sick. Almost everyone in the place dreads this week.

title: Cubs Gain In Race Against History
description: Jim Hendry knew the numbers better than his birth date, but seeing the identical records of the Chicago Cubs and the Houston Astros flashing across the television screen this morning still surprised him and still made him think of a special season that might be prolonged.

title: Two Titles in a Row for the Twins
description: Looking into the Indians' dugout during batting practice today, Minnesota Manager Ron Gardenhire grew wary. The Twins were on the verge of clinching their second consecutive American League Central Division title, but he felt uneasy playing the Indians, whom the Twins clinched against last season.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Move Against the G.O.P. Convention
description: Councilman Charles Barron, left, a Democrat of Brooklyn, urged the Republican Party yesterday not to hold its national convention in New York next year. ''New York City doesn't need this convention,'' said Mr. Barron, who asserted that the average New Yorker would not benefit from it. Accompanied by Councilman Bill Perkins and labor organizers, community advocates and members of the clergy, Mr. Barron announced plans to pressure President Bush to call off the convention by conducting protests and boycotts. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that Mr. Barron ''couldn't be more wrong.'' ''The people that will benefit from the $250 million spent in this city live in all five boroughs,'' the mayor said. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Murphy Gave Voice to Hearts Of Mets Fans
description: BOB MURPHY covered the Worst Team in the History of Baseball, a title worthy of capital letters. He knows the Detroit Tigers could break the Mets' modern record of 120 losses in the next few days, but he said: ''I don't care. I lived through the 1962 season.'' The Tigers are mere arrivistes, just dog-awful. The 1962 Mets were profoundly and amusingly abysmal.

description: PARIS, Sept. 24 — Vivendi Universal , which has been shedding assets to reduce debt, reported today that it had increased its operating profit and reduced its net losses in the first half of the year.

description: Three of Wall Street's biggest investment banks reported better-than-expected earnings for the latest quarter yesterday as the effects of more than two years of cost-cutting and an improved climate in many important segments helped bolster results.

Graveside services will be held on Thursday, September 25, 2003, at 11AM, at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J. For further information call ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack.

Bush got off to a rocky start with the United Nations even before he was elected president, with declarations at the end of the 2000 presidential campaign that the American military should not take part in the sort of ''nation building'' in the Balkans, or Somalia, for which the United Nations had long been known.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKER, PEARL REISSMAN
description: BECKER--Pearl Reissman. On September 21, of North Bethesda, MD. Beloved wife of the late Steven Becker. Devoted mother of Robert Becker, (Hazel); Sandy Hyman, (Dan); and Dr. Judith Becker. Beloved sister of Beatrice Horton, (Sheldon). Grandmother of Allison and Loren Becker, and Joshua, Melissa, and Paul Hyman. Donations may be made to The American Heart Association, 1-800-634-1242 in memory of Pearl Becker, earmarked for research.

title: For the Seed-Challenged, Pomegranate in a Bottle
description: Juicing pomegranates is best left to professionals, which is why Pom Wonderful, a new line of California pomegranate juices, is so welcome. The pleasantly astringent, deep burgundy juices come plain or flavored with mango, tangerine, cherry or blueberry. Extra-large pomegranates, called Wonderful, are used for the juices, which are fine on their own or as mixers, especially with tequila. The 15.2-ounce size is about $4, and the 24-ounce size is around $6 at Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory, Dean & DeLuca, Citarella and Fairway markets. Some are also sold at www.pomwonderful.com, $19.90 plus shipping for six of the 15.2-ounce size.

Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, to defend the Bush administration's new aid request for Iraq and Afghanistan misidentified the senator shaking hands with Mr. Bremer before a hearing by the Senate Appropriations Committee. He was Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico. (Ted Stevens of Alaska stood at Senator Domenici's right.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUS, JESSIE
description: STRAUS--Jessie. On September 21. Beloved by her late husband Henry, her children, Margaret and Walter, her daughter-in-law, Karen, and her grandchildren, Samuel, Alex, and Eliana. Social worker, humanist, activist, and loyal alumna (Barnard, Smith), she devoted her life to making the world a fairer place. If desired, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

Under federal rules, telemarketers could be heavily fined for calling those numbers.

title: On Front Lines, Casualties Are Tied to New U.S. Law
description: IN 20 years as a public school administrator on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Lawrence Lynch, the principal of Booker T. Washington Middle School on 107th Street, has never seen such a disastrous start to a school year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SORIANO, LILIANE
description: SORIANO -- Liliane. Passed away on September 16, 2003 at her home in Blue Hill in the company of husband and her children. A memorial service will be held in New York.

title: Talks Produce Hope of a Prisoner Exchange in Mideast
description: Working through a German intermediary, Israel and the Lebanon-based Hezbollah guerrilla movement appear to be making headway toward a possible exchange of high-profile prisoners held for years.

description: The pursuit of a championship can seem joyless for the Yankees, who are expected to deliver nothing less for their hard-driving principal owner, George Steinbrenner.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Sept. 13 about the new Nickelodeon show ''Romeo!'' misstated part of the name of a rapper in a group with Master P (Percy Miller), who produces and stars in the show. He is Silkk the Shocker, not Sikk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, SHIRLEY L.
description: LEVINE--Shirley L. Died on Sunday, September 21, 2003. Beloved wife of Alvin L. Loving mother of Dr. James A., Linda A. and the late Lawrence W. Devoted mother-inlaw of Ronald Urban and Dr. Joan Levine. Devoted sister and sister-in-law of Leo and Rhonda Federman. Devoted aunt to Douglas and Richard Federman. Cherished grandmother of Jessica, Joshua, Lauren and Amy Beth. She was a woman of impeccable taste and possessed many talents and numerous abilities. Rest in peace, my darling, your pains are over. Services 11:30 A.M. at Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, September 24. Please send donations in memory of Shirley Levine to Briarcliff Manor Volunteer Fire Department, 1111 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510.

description: A report in the Arts Briefing column last Wednesday and a review on Saturday about an appearance at Symphony Space in Manhattan by Habimah, the National Theater of Israel, misstated the precedent. The company came to the United States in the 1990's, a spokesman said; the visit was not its first to this country in 40 years.

title: Fighting the Fevers
description: Here's a titillating scoop: Bill Gates has an assignation planned today with Botswana prostitutes, not just one of them but a whole team!

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Closing Of Detention Center Is Urged
description: Protesters called yesterday for the closure of the Union County Juvenile Detention Center. A teenager was found hanged there this year, and the center has been cited for overcrowding and safety violations, but center officials said that the juvenile residents could not be moved until a new location was found, a process they said could take at least two years. About 40 demonstrators gathered on the steps of the Union County Courthouse and joined the family of the dead teenager, Edward Sinclair, 17, of Elizabeth. Authorities said that Mr. Sinclair committed suicide 12 hours after being placed at the center on May 10. His cell had been cited as a safety hazard by state inspectors because of an exposed sprinkler head, which Mr. Sinclair used, with a bedsheet, to hang himself. Alicia Zubikowski (NYT)

title: Deadly Bombings on Rise in Iraq; 1 Killed in Baghdad Blast
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 24  It was not until after the powerful explosion here today that Rasoul Khalid Ibrahim, a security guard, remembered: The morning before, two men, one in the clothes of a street cleaner, had been digging a hole in the dirt of a median strip. It is such a common sight, as Baghdad tidies up after war, that he did not give the workers a second thought.

title: Amid Concern Over His Health, Pope Misses Appearance
description: VATICAN CITY, Sept. 24  Pope John Paul II did not show up here today for one of his regularly scheduled public appearances, an unusual absence that comes at a time of increased concern over his health.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: ANIMAL GROUPS URGE HALT TO BEAR HUNT Two animal-rights groups have started a court fight to block the state's first black-bear hunt since 1970. In a motion filed on Monday, the groups  the New Jersey Animal Rights Alliance and the Bear Group  asked a state appeals court to overturn the State Fish and Game Council's approval of the hunt. A lawyer for the groups, William Strazza, argued that the hunt, scheduled to begin on Dec. 8, was unjustified because it was not based on a valid count of the bear population and would threaten the safety of hikers and others. Martin J. McHugh, director of the state's division of fish and wildlife, disagreed, calling the six-day hunt a "conservative" one. "We have a bear population that can sustain a very limited hunt," he said. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: A. G. Edwards Takes Humorous Approach
description: A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, the brokerage firm, is introducing what it is calling its first broad-based national campaign, which uses humor to play up its relationship with its customers.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bicycle Company Pays $1 Million To Settle Claims
description: An Illinois bicycle company agreed to pay $1 million to settle federal claims that it did not report injuries in a timely manner that were caused by defects in its Mongoose and Roadmaster bicycles, officials said. The company, Brunswick Corporation, of Lake Forest, was slow in reporting 31 serious incidents involving defective forks on its bicycles, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. The forks broke during normal use, causing serious head and face injuries. The company had recalled more than 100,000 bicycles.

title: A Little Bit of the French Renegade in Red Hook
description: I DREAM about finding restaurants like 360, a storefront in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where passion, generosity, commitment, eccentricity and skill outweigh any semblance of good common sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL, LEONORA DINGEE
description: KIMBALL--Leonora Dingee. Born September 30, 1904 in Wilmette, IL. Wife of the late James Brewster Kimball. She died peacefully at St. Joseph's Manor, Trumbull, Ct. on September 20, 2003. Survived by daughters Barbara Cohen and Elizabeth Dempsey, six grandchildren and six great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TERRY, JAMES HENDRICK, JR., M.D.
description: TERRY -- James Hendrick, Jr., M.D. Age 76. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. Passed away suddenly, at home, on September 22, 2003. He was the dear husband of Virginia (Ginny), loving father of Jane, James III, Emily and Karen, beloved grandfather of seven, devoted brother of Anthony and Stephen of Tucson, AZ. Dr. Terry attended Phillips Exeter Academy and Stanford University and graduated from the University of Arizona. He received his medical degree from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was a respected head and neck surgeon and teacher for many years at Saint Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital and the Brooklyn Hospital Center. Following a private interment, a memorial service will be held September 26th, 3PM at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, 114 St at Broadway, N.Y.C. In recognition of his love of gardening & flower painting, his hobbies, donations may be made to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY SOLD FIRST DATA AND BOUGHT HCA
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment company run by Warren E. Buffett, reduced its stockholdings in the First Data Corporation, the Duke Energy Corporation and Iron Mountain Inc. during the second quarter, according to regulatory filings. Berkshire also reported that it owned 16.6 million shares of HCA Inc., the hospital chain, as of June 30, a stake worth about $532 million, yesterday's filings showed. Berkshire, based in Omaha, reported the holdings after the Securities and Exchange Commission denied the company's request to keep them confidential, Berkshire said in the filing.

title: Bush and Schrder Look to Move Past Differences on Iraq
description: President Bush made some diplomatic headway here today, gaining a German offer of help with Iraqi reconstruction and a vow from its chancellor to move past the sharp differences the two countries have had over the war.

title: One-Dimensional Jets See the Error Of Their Offense
description: For the Jets' offensive coordinator, Paul Hackett, the game film seems like the goriest horror movie on a continuous loop, one attempt to score a touchdown dying a painful death after another. ''Agony,'' he called it. And this is the sequel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRAGUTSKY, LENORA (NEE LAFNER)
description: DRAGUTSKY--Lenora (nee Lafner). Passed away peacefully on Monday, September 22. Beloved wife of David. Her spirit will live on through her two daughters Karen and Joan; her grandchildren Amy, Jamie and Kevin; her sisters Mildred and Ruth; her sons-in-law Sumner and Larry; grand son-in-law Jeff

title: Piazza Is Now Officially More Met Than Dodger
description: Mike Piazza stood alone at first base without the protective screen that usually accompanies him during batting practice. About four hours before last night's game against the Pirates, Piazza resumed his stutter-step transition from behind the plate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, JOHN F. II,
description: RYAN--John F. II, 71, died peacefully on September 20, 2003 at home in Barnegat, NJ. Former Deputy Mayor of Barnegat, he was extremely active in the Ocean County Democratic Committee. Survived by Dorothy, his wife of 50 years, his daughter Lisa, sons Robert, John F. III, and Steven, all of New Jersey and grandchildren, Justin, Kali, Dylan, Sean, Danny & Derek. He will be remembered by family, friends and colleagues for his charm, wit and love of all things Irish. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Southern Ocean County Hospice and Home Care Services, 1140 Route 72 West, Manahawkin, New Jersey 08050.

title: About New York; Here, Murder Dials 'R' For Routine
description: MURDER was on the docket in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday, lots of it. This meant that one judge in a third-floor courtroom faced a full morning of cases involving truncated lives. He took his place behind the elevated bench, where two desk lamps cast his beefy countenance aglow. Court was now in session.

title: Off the Menu
description: The first restaurant JACK and GRACE LAMB, below, opened was Jewel Bako, perhaps the most elegant and expensive restaurant in the East Village. This year, they added Blue Goose, a spot for coffee, pastries and sandwiches. On Friday, they are opening JACK'S LUXURY OYSTER BAR, a small marble bar with chandeliers at 246 East Fifth Street, across the street from Jewel Bako. ALLISON VINES, who worked at Alain Ducasse, is preparing inventive $75 prix fixe dinners served in a cozy 12-seat dining room upstairs.

title: Met Orchestra Enjoys a New Hall's Spaciousness
description: James Levine and the musicians from the Metropolitan Opera's orchestra have made full use of Carnegie Hall's facilities in recent years, offering programs by the full Met Orchestra in the main hall and chamber concerts at Weill Recital Hall. Other subgroups, most notably the Met's percussionists, have deployed elsewhere around town, mainly because neither of Carnegie's halls was quite right, in size or acoustics, for the repertory at hand.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Bid For Miner
description: Randgold Resources has offered $1.8 billion in stock for the Ashanti Goldfields Company of Ghana, rivaling an offer from AngloGold of South Africa. Randgold, based in St. Helier, Jersey, offered 0.5 share for every share of Ashanti, the company said. AngloGold made an all-stock offer for Ashanti in May. That offer is now worth $1.32 billion. Randgold has said it wants to combine its business with that of Ashanti to create an Africa-focused gold company. AngloGold wants to buy Ashanti to decrease its dependence on South Africa, which accounts for more than half its output.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOV, CARMELA DITRAPANI
description: BOV--Carmela DiTrapani. On September 22, 2003. Beloved wife of Frank Bov, sister of Rosario Baglio. Godmother, Aunt, Stepmother and Friend of many. Funeral Friday 9:15 A.M. from Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th St, Brklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45 A.M. St Saviour Church. Interment in St John Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OLDEN, MARC
description: OLDEN--Marc. Novelist, on September 5 in New York City. A highly regarded crime writer with 40 published books, his book ''Poe Must Die'' is considered the definitive novel on Edgar Allan Poe. With advanced degree black belts in Japanese Karate and Aikido, he coached and mentored many members of the NYPD in Aikido. He was President of the Vedanta Society of New York. At the time of his death he was nearing completion of a circa 1939 spy thriller. Adored son of Courtenaye. Beloved companion of 30 years to Diane Crafford. His integrity, humor and wisdom will be deeply missed by his many friends.

title: The Senate Tries an Odd Experiment
description: A doughty few members of the United States Senate, dogged by the mythic conceit of membership in the ''world's greatest deliberative body,'' got together in the chamber Monday evening to actually try debating a major issue of the day. They chose Social Security reform as the topic and set firm limits on speaking times, interruptions and cross-examination, finishing in an hour with the lan of prep school debaters. The odd event was as close to man bites, or at least gums, dog as things can get in the Senate. More routinely, the modern Senate is an echo chamber for a single solon's speechifying to the cable television cameras in a very lonesome setting empty of fellow lawmakers actually listening. To visitors in the gallery, the scene seems more voyeuristic than spellbinding, like watching someone sing in the shower.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Animal Groups Urge Halt To Bear Hunt
description: Two animal-rights groups have started a court fight to block the state's first black-bear hunt since 1970. In a motion filed on Monday, the groups -- the New Jersey Animal Rights Alliance and the Bear Group -- asked a state appeals court to overturn the State Fish and Game Council's approval of the hunt. A lawyer for the groups, William Strazza, argued that the hunt, scheduled to begin on Dec. 8, was unjustified because it was not based on a valid count of the bear population and would threaten the safety of hikers and others. Martin J. McHugh, director of the state's division of fish and wildlife, disagreed, calling the six-day hunt a ''conservative'' one. ''We have a bear population that can sustain a very limited hunt,'' he said. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Retrial Date For Ex-G.O.P. Official
description: A federal judge in Trenton has set Nov. 12 for the retrial of the former chairman of Passaic County's Republican Party, Peter A. Murphy. He is charged with mail fraud and bribery related to what his indictment said was his pervasive control over the issuance of county contracts. This year, Mr. Murphy's 2001 conviction was overturned by an appeals court after he had served a year of a 43-month sentence. The appeals panel found that the trial judge had erroneously allowed the jury to view Mr. Murphy, a political party official, as having the same responsibility of fairness and trustworthiness as an elected official. Mr. Murphy was ordered freed pending the retrial, and the prosecutors were directed to use other theories of culpability. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: They Saw the Hurricane Coming, but the Tornado Was a Surprise
description: A tornado and fierce rainstorms blitzed parts of New Jersey today, knocking down hundreds of trees, damaging businesses and houses and cutting power for thousands of customers in areas already battered by last week's storm.

title: Elvis Costello Returns, Brooding and Restless
description: Style, it might be argued, is the sum of a musician's reflexes: the melodic contours, harmonic turns, rhythms and verbal patterns that come most naturally. Elvis Costello is determined to refute that argument. Whenever he grows secure in a style, he sets it aside and seeks out another one, fighting his own reflexes to a draw.

title: Amid Concern Over His Health, Pope Misses Appearance
description: VATICAN CITY, Sept. 24  Pope John Paul II did not show up here today for one of his regularly scheduled public appearances, an unusual absence that comes at a time of increased concern over his health.

title: Strong Dollar, Weak Dollar: Anyone Have A Scorecard?
description: Rarely have so many people in so many countries been pushing for the dollar to get weaker rather than stronger.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Ford Expanding
description: Ford Motor said yesterday that it would expand its factory to triple production to 150,000 vehicles a year. Ford's factory in Chongqing in Southwestern China was intended to make as many as 50,000 Mondeo and Fiesta cars a year when production began in January. ''The market here is expanding incredibly fast, so we need to bring in as many products as soon as we can to take advantage of the growth,'' said Dale Jones, Ford Motor China's marketing vice president.

title: Annan Tells General Assembly That U.N. Must Correct Its Weaknesses
description: Saying that the United Nations has ''come to a fork in the road,'' Secretary General Kofi Annan argued today that fundamental weaknesses in the architecture of the institution must be remedied for it to retain any effectiveness in combating genocide, terrorism and the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Death at 18 Spurs Debate Over a Pill For Abortion
description: Last Wednesday, a California teenager died at a hospital in Pleasanton, just days after taking prescription pills to abort her early pregnancy. The circumstances surrounding her death are unclear, and an autopsy is under way.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about efforts by L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, to defend the Bush administration's new aid request for Iraq and Afghanistan misidentified the senator shaking hands with Mr. Bremer before a hearing by the Senate Appropriations Committee. He was Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico. (Ted Stevens of Alaska stood at Senator Domenici's right.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 10 about the efforts of Dominique Loiseau, the widow of the chef Bernard Loiseau, to maintain the standards of La Cote d'Or, his three-star restaurant in Saulieu, France, referred imprecisely to the status of the restaurant when Mr. Loiseau began working there in 1975. In the 1950's and 60's, when it was owned by the chef Alexandre Dumaine, it had three Michelin stars. For most of the period between its sale by Mr. Dumaine in 1964 and Mr. Loiseau's arrival, it maintained two stars; it was not obscure.

title: 4 Are Charged In Stampede At Nightclub In Chicago
description: The owners and two others associated with a nightclub where 21 people died in a stampede in February have been charged with involuntary manslaughter and could face up to 10 years in prison, a prosecutor said today.

title: Golden West, Slightly Tarnished
description: WHERE I WAS FROM

title: Schwarzenegger Learning His Lines, and Others', for Debate Tonight
description: As Arnold Schwarzenegger prepared for his first and only debate, his handlers said they expected few specifics from any participant.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Grammy's Will Return
description: After touching down in New York City this year, the annual Grammy Awards ceremony will return to Los Angeles for its 46th edition, to be held on Feb. 8, 2004, at the Staples Center there. The 2003 awards, at Madison Square Garden, were the first to be held in New York since 1998. Academy officials have said it is less expensive and more convenient to have the show at the Staples Center. ''There's a great desire to be back in New York, and we surely will,'' said Neil Portnow, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. Jon Pareles (NYT)

title: U.S. Appeals Court Puts Recall In California Back on Schedule
description: With just two weeks to go before the recall election for Gov. Gray Davis, a federal appeals court today removed a legal obstacle to the vote, ruling that it would be held on Oct. 7, as scheduled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, MIRIAM
description: GOLDBERG -- Miriam. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Miriam Goldberg, mother of Ellen Hershkin, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. June Walker, Nat'l President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLYNN, MONSIGNOR FRANCIS J.
description: GLYNN--Monsignor Francis J. Founder of the Church of the Holy Family, Staten Island, NY of Chester, NY. On September 22, 2003. Beloved son of the late Francis J. Glynn and Agnes Donovan Glynn. Loving brother of Robert D. Glynn and the late Margaret Mary Glynn. Devoted uncle of Robert D. Glynn, Jr., Thomas V. Glynn, Mary Glynn Auer, Anne Glynn Mackoul, F. Joseph Glynn, Grace M. Brockel and Stephen V. Glynn. Mass of the Eucharist Wednesday, 7PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, 10AM at Holy Family Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Parishioners and friends may call Wednesday, 3-9PM at the Church of the Holy Family, 366 Watchogue Road, SI, NY. For further information Matthew Funeral Home, 718-761-5544

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sailor Sentenced In Shipmate's Death
description: A United States Navy petty officer who pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in the death of a female shipmate he pushed from a sixth-floor window in a Midtown hotel last year was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in prison. The officer, Brian Cooley, 30, of La Porte, Ind., had been charged with second-degree murder and could have faced 25 years to life in prison had he been convicted of that charge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Charles Tedstone, the father of the victim, Seaman Lisa R. Tedstone, 30, told Petty Officer Cooley, ''You may have difficult years ahead of you, and I hope that you think about receiving forgiveness from God.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Lifting Human Spirits From Sorrow to Joy
description: The Carnegie Hall artistic planning team keeps coming up with amusing tongue-in-cheek names for the ensembles of freelancers it has been presenting in the inaugural concerts at Zankel Hall.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: LABORERS UNION ENDORSES GEPHARDT The Laborers International Union of North America will endorse Representative Richard A. Gephardt today for the Democratic presidential nomination, union officials said. The endorsement, to be made at a union conference in Chicago, will be the 13th union endorsement that Mr. Gephardt has received, far more than any other Democratic candidate. The union has 840,000 members and represents construction workers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Head of BSkyB Quits, With Murdoch's Son Possible Heir
description: The chief executive of the satellite-television network British Sky Broadcasting Group, one of the few media companies to prosper amid an industrywide shakeout in Europe, announced his resignation today.
