title: Judge Allows Antitrust Case Against Seed Producers
description: A federal judge on Friday let proceed an antitrust case that accused the Monsanto Company and other big agricultural seed giants of conspiring to control the world's market in genetically modified crops.

title: Recipe: Pearl Nathans Chicken Soup
description: Time: About 4 hours

title: Reviving a Classic Without Reinventing It
description: SOME restaurants age gracefully. Others just age. Caf des Artistes, in business since 1917, has never quite decided which way it's going to go. On a bad day, or in a bad decade, it can seem lackluster and dispirited, a tired old Continental restaurant that keeps going by sheer force of habit. Then, when things look bleakest, it can snap back to life, and even disillusioned diners rediscover what it is about the place that makes it one of the city's best-loved restaurants.

title: A Vulnerable Singer's Farewell To a Beloved Troublemaker
description: Jane Birkin's concerts at Florence Gould Hall of the Alliance Franaise were both a debut and a farewell. They were the first American performances by an English singer and actress who has been well-known for decades in Europe, particularly in her adopted country, France. And they were Ms. Birkin's farewell to Serge Gainsbourg, who wrote songs for her, was her lover from 1969 to 1981, and died in 1991. He was a singular figure in pop: a gruff, cigarette-loving, troublemaking songwriter and performer whose elegant melodies held lyrics full of romance, cynicism and enigmatic wordplay.

title: Senate Wins Support on a Medicare Issue
description: The Bush administration has quietly told Congress that it should not provide Medicare drug benefits to six million poor elderly and disabled people because they are already eligible for similar help through state Medicaid programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a decision by the chief executive of Motorola, Christopher B. Galvin, to step down misstated the year that Mike S. Zafirovski, now president and chief operating officer, joined the company. It was 2000, not 2002.

title: Joseph M. Magliochetti, 61, Chief of Auto Parts Company
description: Joseph M. Magliochetti, the chairman and chief executive of the Dana Corporation, a big auto parts company, died here Monday night. He was 61.

title: In a City of Few Limits, One Just Got Lower
description: A state law lowering the blood alcohol limit for drivers went into effect one minute after midnight today in this archetypal good-time town, but most revelers seemed too busy drinking to notice.

title: Cameras Watching Students, Especially in Biloxi
description: A digital camera hangs over every classroom here, silently recording students' and teachers' every move. The surveillance system is at the leading edge of a trend to outfit public schools with the same cameras used in Wal-Marts to catch thieves.

title: With Role in Doubt, Weaver Fails Test
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 - Joe Torre said he was only trying to win a game when he summoned Jeff Weaver from the bullpen in the 10th inning against the White Sox on Monday. But Torre admitted it was also a test for Weaver, the right-hander who struggled as a starter and is now struggling to make the postseason roster.

title: Man Charged in Killing of Ex-Wife's Boyfriend
description: While at least one of his children looked on, a New Jersey man shot his ex-wife, wounding her, and fatally shot her boyfriend at a house in New London, Conn., on Monday morning, the police said.

title: Sex and the City, Old Vienna, That Is
description: 'Far and Wide'

title: President Bush at the U.N.; Finding a New Path in Iraq
description: On the surface, President Bush's speech to the United Nations yesterday seemed a Panglossian report on how well things are going in Iraq with little to draw the broad international assistance he desperately needs. But behind this, there is something closer to a consensus on the goals for Iraq's future. The international community, Mr. Bush and his allies all want to see the Iraqis become self-governing as soon as possible and to take over their own security operations. There also seems to be agreement that the United States should remain in command of military operations. This is a good starting point.

title: Last Call: The Fade-Out of a Modern Pest
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 New England Brothers, With Sow's Ear and Silk
description: It is not hard to imagine how David E. Kelley dreamed up his new drama on CBS, ''The Brotherhood of Poland, N.H.'' It must have come to him in a fit of pique.

title: DUBLIN: THE FRINGE AND BEYOND
description: To the rumbling bass and jangling guitars of the Asian Dub Foundation, playing a live version of the soundtrack to the 1995 film ''Hate,'' the ninth Dublin Fringe Festival opened on Monday for a run through Oct. 11. It will present about 130 shows, from chaotic clowning and Japanese Butoh to a soap opera in daily 30-minute installments and new drama by up-and-coming Irish playwrights. The fringe festival in Dublin is not as big as those in Edinburgh or New York, but its curators, led by the Australian director Vallejo Gantner, select aspiring companies from a pool of applicants to keep the standard high. Starting on Monday the regular Dublin Theater Festival will run concurrently and feature new works by the Irish playwrights Brian Friel, Martin McDonagh and Tom Kilroy, and the choreographer Michael Keegan-Dolan. BRIAN LAVERY

title: Some Bonbons With Those Bifocals?
description: On a trip to his native Chile several months ago, Alfonso Escobar, above, an optician who has owned Page & Smith, 42 East 59th Street, with his brother, James, for the past 10 years, tasted some chocolates made by Flix Brunatto. The Escobars now import the treats from Mr. Brunatto's shop, L'Atelier del Cioccolato, and sell them along with their designer spectacles.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank Forecasts Profit Rise
description: The Bank of Ireland said first-half profit before tax and some expenses would probably increase about 5 percent, helped by rising stock markets, demand for home loans and cost savings. Earnings per share will probably increase about 5 percent in the period, which ends Sept. 30, the bank said. Without a new government tax on Irish banks this year and the euro's gain against the British pound, earnings would have grown more than 5 percent, the bank said. The bank, based in Dublin, said it expected net interest margins to shrink in the first half because of low interest rates, and the company's stock fell 4 percent.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Vail Drops Leased Saab Police Cars
description: The Town of Vail has decided not to renew leases on Saab police cars and will instead begin using Ford Explorers next year. The Town Council came to the decision after Saab officials said they would have to increase the lease prices. The town and the car company had an arrangement since the 1970's that served as a promotional tool for Saab. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: First Wave Of Suits Hits Mutual Funds Under Inquiry
description: The lawyers who have filed hundreds of claims against investment banks, research analysts and corporate executives are now training their guns on mutual funds.

title: Hearing on E.P.A. Nominee Takes an Ideological Turn
description: Senate Democrats used the confirmation hearing today on Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, President Bush's choice for administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, as a forum to sharply criticize the administration's environmental record, all but ignoring the nominee sitting in front of them.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: A.C.L.U. Sues Secret Service
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Philadelphia against the Secret Service, seeking to allow demonstrators to gather near the sites of presidential and vice-presidential visits. The suit also named as defendants the City of Philadelphia and its police. It contends that the police, at the direction of the Secret Service, regularly forced groups into ''protest zones'' far from the president and vice president. A spokesman for the Secret Service, John Gill, said it recognized ''the constitutionally protected right of the public to demonstrate.''

description: WILL macho guys use their mamas' Mr. Clean to wash their muscle cars?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINER, JAMES PATRICK BENJAMIN
description: WINER--James Patrick Benjamin. Age 65. Born and raised in New York City. Architect and City Planner in Philadelphia. A valiant soldier in his fight against Multiple Sclerosis. Loving father of Alison and Sarah. Proud grandfather of Zoe, Sammy, Isabel, Olivia and Benjamin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOENGOLD, ELSIE. (NEE FLIESLER)
description: SCHOENGOLD--Elsie. (nee Fliesler). Age 94, born March 15, 1909, passed away peacefully on September 22, 2003. Her family loved and honored her. Rest in peace. Services Wednesday, 1:00 PM in Ferncliff Cremetory Chapel, Hartsdale, NY. For directions phone 914-693-4700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKEL, ARTHUR
description: FRANKEL--Arthur. Beloved husband of Severine (nee Kohn). Stepfather of Elisabeth Szegho. Uncle of Roy Rosenstein, Jane Shivers, Robert and Peter Woog. Passed away peacefully at home on Monday, September 22, 2003. He will be much missed.

title: Democracy, Closer Every Day
description: Many Americans, not to mention our European allies, may be shaking their heads over President Bush's defiant speech at the United Nations yesterday. With the coalition forces under daily attack and billions being spent to rebuild Iraq, shouldn't Mr. Bush have been more conciliatory in an effort to get other countries to send troops?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sale Of General Motors Building Advances
description: The developer Harry Macklowe is expected to close on his record-breaking $1.4 billion purchase of the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue by the end of this week, despite a last-minute attempt to derail the transaction. The Chancery Court in Delaware yesterday rejected a request from a rival bidder, Sheldon H. Solow, to block the sale. Mr. Solow, who also bid $1.4 billion, claimed that the seller, Conseco, and its broker had acted unfairly in awarding the deal to Mr. Macklowe. Reed Oslan, a Conseco lawyer, said, ''We're moving as expeditiously as possible to sell our building to Mr. Macklowe.''

title: Judge Allows Defense Tactic in Tyco Case
description: Two former Tyco International executives, L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, can tell jurors at their trial that loans and other compensation they are accused of obtaining without authorization were approved by company auditors, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: WALTER INDUSTRIES SELLS UNIT TO OXBOW CARBON
description: Walter Industries, a homebuilder and finance company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its industrial materials unit to Oxbow Carbon and Minerals for $127.7 million to focus on house building, home finance and pipe manufacturing. The unit, Applied Industrial, sells petroleum coke, a refining byproduct used as a fuel, and metals used as additives and alloys in the steel industry. Walter Industries acquired the business in 1997 for $400 million. Since then, annual profit slipped 37 percent in 1999 from 1998 and the company had two annual losses, in 2000 and 2002. Oxbow, a closely held company in West Palm Beach, Fla, imports and exports petroleum, and produces electricity and coal.

title: 2 Iraqi Boys, Injured, Tell Of a Jet Attack in the Night
description: Tahseen Ali Khalaf was asleep beside his brother Hussein when the shooting started early this morning outside their ramshackle house in this farming community 40 miles west of Baghdad, he said.

title: A Private School That Thrives on Rules; Minority Students Excel at Brooklyn Site. Is It a Model or an Anomaly?
description: At the Trey Whitfield School in a bleak corner of Brooklyn, toddlers imitate consonant and vowel sounds and learn that ''cup'' starts with C, not K. Teenagers understand that the rules prohibit gold teeth, coarse talk in the hallways and hip-hop fashions.

title: Excerpt From Court Ruling on California Recall Vote
description: Following is an excerpt from a ruling yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that the California recall election is to proceed as scheduled on Oct. 7. The full text is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Laborers Union Endorses Gephardt
description: The Laborers International Union of North America will endorse Representative Richard A. Gephardt today for the Democratic presidential nomination, union officials said. The endorsement, to be made at a union conference in Chicago, will be the 13th union endorsement that Mr. Gephardt has received, far more than any other Democratic candidate. The union has 840,000 members and represents construction workers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: McDONALD'S PLANS 25 MORE RESTAURANTS IN RUSSIA
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it planned to open 25 restaurants in Russia next year. McDonald's opened its first Russian restaurant on Pushkin Square in Moscow in January 1990, months before the Soviet Union collapsed. That outlet is now the company's busiest in the world. 'McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., has invested more than $250 million in Russia and employs about 15,000 people in 104 restaurants in the country.

title: Afghan Warlords Thrive Beyond Official Reach
description: The fighting in this fertile bowl flared as the harvest neared, and that was not a coincidence. From bountiful crops of cotton, corn and wheat would come a cut for local commanders. The more land the commanders controlled, the more crop they could claim. So in a place ostensibly at peace 20 months after the fall of the Taliban, they went to war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about John S. Reed, the former Citicorp chairman who was named interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, misstated a comparison of Citicorp's stock price in 1991 and the recent price of Citigroup, which was created in 1988 by a merger with the Travelers Group. Adjusted for the merger, a share worth $8.50 in 1991 was worth $122.78 on Friday, not the closing price of $46.99.

description: Howard Dean, whose campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination has been built on an antiwar message, yesterday questioned the antiwar credentials of his newest opponent, Gen. Wesley K. Clark.

title: Harvard Adds a New Biology Department
description: Harvard Medical School said yesterday that it was setting up a new department, the school's first in two decades, devoted to the emerging field of systems biology.

title: Shipbuilders Steer Past South Korea's Economic Downturn
description: Park Min looked over the hull of a 100,000-ton vessel in the dry dock of Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest maker of merchant ships.

title: U.N. Official Plans to Urge U.S. to Reconsider Its Food Policies
description: Jacques Diouf, the director of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, dedicated to helping solve the world's hunger problems, knows he has a hard sell on Capitol Hill.

title: Devils Exact Revenge, Albeit the Preseason Kind
description: Playing with a physical edge that was clearly missing from last Friday's preseason opener, the Devils defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 3-0, in tonight's rematch at Sovereign Bank Arena.

title: Before the Sunday Kickoff, Tailgating With Gusto
description: THEY come here to the Arrowhead Stadium parking lots from Independence, Grandview, Boonville and from out in Benton County by the reservoir, all with a passion for food and football. They come dressed in red, driving red vans and red pickups. They light fires in the parking lots before finishing their morning coffee. They are fans of the Kansas City Chiefs, but more than this, they are tailgaters, heartland enthusiasts of al fresco cuisine.

title: Belgian Beer Trend Is 70 Years Old Here
description: WHEN word spread that Trappist-brewed Belgian beers were the rage at nightspots in New York, all the Cadieux Cafe regulars could do was smile. They have been drinking the stuff here for decades.

description: For weeks, Coach Jim Fassel has been -- in his words -- yelling and screaming at the Giants. And just what is causing him to constantly raise his voice? He does not want costly retaliatory penalties -- particularly from a team that has split two overtime games in successive weeks.

title: Tight Election Looms in Largest Municipal Union
description: With a vote still more than three months away, the president of New York's main union of social workers opened his campaign yesterday to take charge of the city's largest municipal union, District Council 37, by announcing his slate of running mates and a long list of local presidents who already support him.

title: Outer Banks' Residents See Good and Varieties of Bad in a Storm
description: Families who have passed this vacation spot down through the generations expect certain landmarks: Jennette's Pier, 64 years old and stretching 600 feet into the Atlantic; the Sea Foam Motel, all teal-colored kitsch; and Crabtree Court, a cluster of 50's-era cottages hard by the beach.

title: Viacom Cuts Profit Forecast as Ad Sales Remain Sluggish
description: In a sign that the economy may not be rebounding as rapidly as some data suggest, Viacom Inc. , the nation's third largest media company, said today that it was cutting its full-year profit and revenue forecast because local advertising sales were not picking up as rapidly as had been expected.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Panama: Thousands Strike
description: Workers participating in a 24-hour national strike protesting what they say is mismanagement of the social security fund clashed with riot police officers on the paralyzed streets of the country's two largest cities. According to reports from Panama City and the port of Coln, protesters numbering in the tens of thousands threw rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who returned fire with rubber bullets and tear gas. The strike was the first nationwide work stoppage in six years. Union leaders called it after the government dismissed the head of the heavily indebted fund, which covers health care and retirement. They accuse the government of mismanaging the fund to the point of bankruptcy. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dalai Lama Visit Barred
description: Russia refused to grant a visa to the Dalai Lama, citing Chinese diplomatic sensitivities. The Dalai Lama, who has been met by sold-out crowds on his current tour of the United States, was invited to visit Russia by political and religious leaders in the southern republic of Kalmykia, where roughly half of the 300,000 residents are Buddhists. He visited Russia's Buddhist regions in 1992 and received a transit visa in 1996, but the Foreign Ministry has now denied him visas to visit three times in the last two years. A ministry statement said the decision was made ''to strictly comply with international commitments of the Russian Federation,'' including its friendship treaty with China. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Strike Response
description: Volkswagen will fire any Brazilian workers who go on strike over a plan to cut jobs, the chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, said. ''Everyone who goes on strike will lose his job,'' Mr. Pischetsrieder told journalists at a dinner in Wolfsburg, Germany, where the company is based. ''We'll see if we hire any of them back after the strike.'' Volkswagen plans to cut 4,000 jobs in Brazil by transferring workers to a training unit. Workers at the Volkswagen plant in Taubat will go ahead with a plan to strike on Oct. 1, when the transfers are set to begin, Antonio Eduardo de Oliveira, president of the union in Taubat, said in a telephone interview from Taubat. Mr. Oliveira declined to comment on Mr. Pischetsrieder's statement.

title: Learning From 9/11, Bloomberg Seeks High-Rise Safety Changes
description: Legislation that would enact most of the fire safety improvements for tall buildings recommended by a task force that studied the World Trade Center collapse was announced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: MAKER OF AUTO EXHAUST SYSTEMS TO SHUT INDIANA FACTORY
description: ArvinMeritor Inc., a maker of automotive exhaust systems, said yesterday that it would close an Indiana factory, eliminating 850 jobs, to move production closer to customers. The factory, in Franklin, Ind., opened in 1935 and makes automotive air and exhaust systems. It will close by September 2004, the company said. The work will be shifted to plants in Indiana, Michigan, Missouri, South Carolina and Mexico. Some of the Franklin workers may be able to get jobs at the plants that are taking on the production, the company said. ArvinMeritor is based in Troy, Mich.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Shares Of Multimedia Games Surge
description: Shares of Multimedia Games Inc. rose as much as 16 percent after the National Indian Gaming Commission made a favorable ruling on the company's Reel Time Bingo 1.2A, a step that could expand the game's distribution. The shares rose $4.65, or 15.5 percent, to $34.60, after rising as high as $34.89. The stock had risen 9.1 percent this year. The company, based in Austin, Tex., said it expected increased orders as some tribal gambling halls had delayed purchases pending the ruling. As of June 30, Multimedia had 6,700 older versions of Reel Time Bingo at 68 tribal halls, the statement said. The ruling designates Reel Time Bingo 1.2A as a Class II game, joining the company's MegaMania game in that categrory, Multimedia's chief executive, Clifton Lind, said. The designation classifies Reel Time as a legitimate electronic bingo game that can be used in Indian gambling centers. Neither Mr. Lind nor Rita Homa of the commission returned telephone calls seeking comment.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Woman Won't Be Prosecuted
description: A woman who obtained a protective order against her ex-husband cannot be prosecuted for violating the order by inviting him to their child's birthday party, the State Supreme Court ruled. It reversed a decision by an appeals court last year that held that the woman, Betty S. Lucas, had ''recklessly exposed herself to the offender from whom she has sought protection'' and affirmed a sentence of two years' probation. The Supreme Court said such prosecutions would unduly chill people from seeking protective orders. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: From Memory to Memorial: A Synagogue Arising
description: Before World War II, Poland had 185 wooden gingerbread synagogues, some dating from the 17th century. The Nazis torched them all. Scholars are planning to recreate one of the oldest and fanciest (right, from about 1930), finished around 1640 in Zabludow, near Bialystok. At workshops in Poland organized by the nonprofit Annihilated Heritage-Zabludow Project, historians and artisans from Europe and the United States are examining other 17th-century buildings to see how the synagogue's carved larch beams were assembled. The reconstruction is expected to cost $885,000. Organizers hope to erect the synagogue on the grounds of a folk architecture museum in Bialystok. Information: www.zabludow.com. EVE M. KAHN

title: A Jug Band That Casts A Glow
description: Julian Lwin, a Brooklyn industrial designer who has worked for Nike and Gillette, calls his five plastic laundry bottles threaded on a 40-watt fluorescent tube, right, the $250k Lamp (because, he says, each bottle represents a $50,000 minimum investment in industrial design). The lamp, $300, is sold from Mr. Lwin's studio through (718) 486-6103. The studio will be open this weekend as part of Firstop, an annual design festival in Brooklyn. From noon until 8 p.m., 80 participants will sell furniture, products and fashion at 51 locations in Williamsburg. This year the central exhibition, Open Up!, will be held for the first time in an old factory at 181 North 11th Street (entry on Driggs Avenue). Maps at www.firstop.org.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Brazil's jobless rate rose in August, adding to evidence that its economy, which is South America's largest, is struggling to recovery after four months of interest rate cuts. Unemployment in Brazil's six largest metropolitan areas increased to 13 percent, matching a two-year high, the government said.

title: Not as Sweet as They Sound: Watch Your Back, Peter Pan
description: On ''Heart'' (Arts & Crafts), the beguiling new album by the Montreal-based indie-pop group Stars, the singer Torquil Campbell comes across as a dreamy, romantic fellow, a bit shy perhaps and slightly acerbic. But during the band's bravura performance at the Mercury Lounge on Sunday night Mr. Campbell proved it was the other way around. ''We are Stars and so are you,'' he said at the beginning, and these were the sweetest words he uttered. Onstage he played the part of the pop-star misanthrope, outlandish and playfully nasty. He kept his dreaminess hidden, except when he sang.

title: Clintons Say They Haven't Endorsed Clark
description: Former President Bill Clinton has called at least three Democratic presidential candidates in recent days to assure them that he is not favoring former Gen. Wesley K. Clark in the party's presidential contest and would help any Democrat who wants to run against President Bush, officials familiar with the discussion said today.

title: Where Life Used to Be Like a Box of Chocolates
description: A few months ago, the trucks driving through here were carrying away freshly made Nestl products. The smell of roasting cocoa beans wafted through the streets when the wind was out of the west. And the booths at Mimi's Drive-In restaurant were filled with workers from the Nestl plant, either starting their day with a cup of coffee or ending it with some benign gossip.

title: Brazil to Lift Ban on Crops With Genetic Modification
description: Brazilian farmers, the world's No.2 producers of soybeans, got the go-ahead today to plant genetically modified seeds this season after the country's vice president said he would lift a ban on transgenic crops.

title: JetBlue Chief Says He Wasn't Told About Release of Data
description: The chief executive and founder of JetBlue Airways was not informed last year when it decided to give records on more than a million passengers to a military contractor for use in identifying terrorists, the airline said today.

title: SureBeam Hires Accountants for a Review
description: The SureBeam Corporation, which has fired two auditors this year and faces possible delisting from the Nasdaq, said yesterday that it was still looking for an auditor.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Who Hit Wife Dies, Police Say
description: An East Village man died yesterday from injuries he received in a fall on Monday, after he hit his sleeping wife in the head with a frying pan, the police said. The man, Patrick Nelson, 34, of East Ninth Street, hit his wife, 35, around 1 a.m. on Monday, the police said. She fought back, and he tried to choke her, they said. After she left their fifth-floor apartment to call the police, Mr. Nelson was found on the ground outside the building, with self-inflicted stab wounds on his wrists and chest. The police said he had fallen from the fire escape. The couple were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, the wife in serious condition, the husband in critical condition. He was arrested there and charged with attempted murder. He died at 4:30 p.m. yesterday. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Drugs From Canada Studied
description: Gov. Tim Pawlenty said the state would study how much it might save if it bought prescription drugs from Canada. Mr. Pawlenty, left, said he expects the study will find at least $20 million in potential savings on drugs bought from Canada for the state's 50,000 employees and for more than 600,000 others who receive medical care through state programs. Mr. Pawlenty, a Republican, joins two Democrats, Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa and Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois, calling for similar studies. The Food and Drug Administration considers the practice of buying drugs in Canada for use in the United States illegal, but some members of Congress are pressing to change that. Monica Davey (NYT)

title: SELLER OF MEDICAL GEAR GETS BIG AWARD IN SUIT
description: Beckman Coulter Inc., which sells testing equipment to medical laboratories and drug companies, won a $934 million jury verdict, which included $931 million in punitive damages, from Flextronics International Ltd. A Superior Court jury in Orange County, Calif., concluded that Flextronics defrauded Beckman by forcing it to pay $655,000 and concealing a $355,000 overpayment. The jury awarded Beckman $3 million in compensatory damages and about $931 million in punitive damages. A spokesman for Flextronics, which is based in Singapore, did not return a phone call seeking comment. Trading in Flextronics shares was halted on Nasdaq because of the verdict.

Mr. Roh's office said the president gave proper instructions on coping with the typhoon both before and after the performance. The typhoon killed 117 people and caused damages of $3.4 billion. (Reuters)

More than 50 of the 225 service members, roughly a quarter, who landed in Liberia last month were hospitalized because of a longtime scourge of mankind: malaria.

title: Herb Gardner, Hit Broadway Playwright, Dies at 68
description: Herb Gardner, whose 1962 play "A Thousand Clowns" was the first of a string of Broadway successes in which his eccentric characters conveyed the whimsical charm and dark truths that grew out of the author's youth in New York, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

QuickShades, by Levolor/Kirsch, attach to window frames with adhesive, can be painted and are supposed to last up to three months. The shades, which can be cut in different sizes, are $5 to $6 at Lowe's, (800) 445-6937, or Wal-Mart, (800) 925-6278. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Design Contests
description: New York City got into the architecture-competition business in a big way yesterday, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, announcing dueling design contests. Mayor Bloomberg is soliciting designs of environmentally friendly buildings: the city will pay a $5,000 award to the winners in five categories. Mr. Miller is soliciting designs for affordable housing; the Council promises ''cash prizes,'' but the amounts have not been set. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Start Teaching or Lose Semester's Pay, C.W. Post Strikers Are Told
description: The C. W. Post campus of Long Island University has ordered striking faculty members to return to teaching by Monday or face cancellation of their classes and the losses of their jobs and pay for the fall semester, officials said yesterday.

title: Toward a Real-Life HAL?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Killed By Truck
description: A truck carrying portable toilets bound for the Dave Matthews Band concert in Central Park last night struck and killed an elderly man at Lenox Avenue and 110th Street in Harlem Street, the authorities said yesterday. The driver was apparently unaware of the accident and continued to 70th Street and Fifth Avenue, where he was stopped by the police, officials said. No summons was issued after a preliminary investigation, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALPER, ARTHUR
description: ALPER--Arthur, 79, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Oceanside, N.Y. Survived by his beloved wife Audrey, loving children Stuart (Wendy), Lee (Elyse), Marc (Wendy), adored grandfather to Lindsay, Jared, Kyra, Lexi, Adam and Andrew. Former president of the Lily Lake Cheese Company. He will forever be remembered by all who loved him. Services today at 2PM, Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y., 516-487-9600.

title: VEOLIA TO SELL NORTH AMERICAN WATER OPERATIONS
description: Veolia Environnement said yesterday that it planned to sell most of its water operations in North America. Veolia, the former water utility of Vivendi, said it would sell most of its U.S. Filter unit, including Culligan and Everpure, leading distributors of water filters and bottled water to residential and business customers. Veolia said it took a loss of 2.1 billion euros ($2.4 billion) in its first half as it wrote down the value of the water assets it plans to sell by 2.2 billion euros ($2.4 billion) to account for the proposed sale. Veolia said it planned to use proceeds from the sale to reduce debt.

title: Proposed Rule Would Ease Stance on Feeding at Nursing Homes
description: The Bush administration is relaxing regulation of nursing homes to allow low-paid workers with one day of training to feed patients who cannot feed themselves.

title: Initial Stock Offering Raises $259 Million
description: Journal Communications, owner of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, raised $259 million yesterday in an initial public offering of stock.

title: Wilpon Can Always Find Reasons for Optimism
description: Mets fans may carry more skepticism into next season than they have for any other season in recent history, but Fred Wilpon, the team's owner, says he sees nothing but better days ahead.

title: Lowe Takes Prize At Newspaper Awards
description: Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York took top honors, winning the $100,000 grand prize, in the Athena Awards competition sponsored by the Newspaper Association of America.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Outlook For Steelmaker
description: The Corus Group, which makes steel, reported a first-half loss yesterday and said the second half would be no better because of declines in European construction and manufacturing. Recent price increases failed to help Corus, based in London, end a four-year run of losses. Corus lost 125 million ($206 million), more than analysts had forecast, but an improvement from a loss of 237 million a year earlier.

title: Doubts Expressed As Bush Presses Asia on Currency
description: Publicly berating China and Japan over their exchange rates is winning the Bush administration praise from American manufacturers, but is not playing so well among economists.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 305 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: The Presidential Bubble
description: Four progressive political groups sued the Bush administration this week, charging that the Secret Service is systematically keeping protesters away from the president's public appearances. They make a serious point about free speech rights, but they also point out a disturbing aspect of the Bush White House: the country has a chief executive who seems to embrace the presidential bubble.

title: NASD Filing Discloses Salary and Bonus of Chief
description: Robert Glauber, the chairman and chief executive of NASD, was paid a salary and bonus totaling $2.1 million in 2002, according to a filing with the Internal Revenue Service released yesterday by NASD.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metropolitan Diary on Monday about a reader's recollection of almost fainting while skating in Central Park misstated the day of the week on which the New York City Marathon is held. It is Sunday, not Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PODGAINY, MARILYN SPINER, ESQ.
description: PODGAINY--Marilyn Spiner, Esq., of Dix Hills, September 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Dr. Martin, loving mother of MSgt. Vivian L. and Mark D., adored grandmother of Elizabeth and Edward Goldsworthy, Lila and Georgia Podgainy, dear sister of Frances Dembling, dear motherin-law of Thomas Goldsworthy and Lisa Usdan. There was nothing that she couldn't do, once she made up her mind to do it. LSAT, law school and bar exams of 3 states--all after the children were grown. The only battle she lost was to lung cancer. G-d, you picked a winner. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Temple BethEl of Huntington, NY, Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center (Dr. Marvin Bernstein Memorial), West Islip, NY, Good Shepherd Hospice, Babylon, NY, and the Pastoral Care Dept. at Our Lady of Consolation, West Islip, NY.

description: QUESENBERRY -- Joseph Francis, 9/25/02, beloved by Phil and family, RIP.

title: Inquiry Into Death of British Arms Expert Concludes
description: LONDON, Sept. 25  It began off a remote country path in Oxfordshire in July with the suicide of a reclusive weapons expert, and it came to a highly publicized head in a central London courtroom today with spokesmen from warring sectors of the British establishment exchanging charges of lying, hypocrisy, bullying and deceit.

title: Self-Taught Designer Honored at a College
description: Harvey Probber, above, who died this year, taught himself drafting. Nonetheless, he was the father of the modular sofa and the slab-side executive desk. His residential pieces, often misattributed to Edward Wormley, will be at Baruch College in ''Harvey Probber: Modernist Furniture, Design, and Graphics.'' A focal point will be a dining table topped with bleached Brazilian rosewood. Evan Lobel, the Manhattan dealer, has lent a terrazzo occasional table, right, from Lobel Modern; (212) 242-9075. (The tables can be found on the Web for under $1,000.) The show opens Oct. 3 at the Sidney Mishkin Gallery at Baruch, 135 East 22nd Street (Lexington Avenue); (212) 802-2690.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARKE, LUCILE KING
description: CLARKE--Lucile King, of Bill Hill Road, Lyme, Connecticut died Monday, September 22, 2003. Mrs. Clarke was born on September 22nd, 1919 in Los Angeles, CA the daughter of Gale Curtis Peck. Mrs. Clarke is survived by her husband Harry R. Clarke, a daughter, two brothers and two grandchildren. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, September 27th, 2003 in Lyme. Donations may be made in her memory to the Lyme Garden Club, Judy Davies Treasurer, 332 Joshua Town Road, Lyme, CT. 06371.

title: Better Off Without E-Mail?
description: You already know that individuals and businesses worldwide are struggling to fix e-mail. The spam, the viruses, the irrelevant forwarding, the insipid joke mailing lists...whatever productivity gains e-mail once offered are rapidly being offset by the time we spend weeding through the chaff.

title: In Giants' Plan, Jets Still Play Second Fiddle
description: The Jets have never felt quite at home at Giants Stadium. The Giants got there first, so their name is on the building, not the Jets'. The Giants have won two Super Bowls since they moved there; the Jets, none.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEEDLE, IRVING
description: NEEDLE -- Irving. Beloved father of Laura and Murray Cantor and Sol and Maxine Needle. Cherished grandfather of Michelle and Jodi Needle, Cheryl Blumberg and Dr. Alan Cantor. Services are today 11:30 at the Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY (corner of Avenue V). ''Adored by all who knew him. Rest in peace, Pop-Pop.''

title: Immigrants' Rights Drive Starts
description: Ninety immigrants and supporters left their buses and marched outside the Roman Catholic cathedral here today, carrying foot-high crosses to commemorate people from south of the border who died in the desert as they sought a better life in the United States.

title: 27 Israeli Reserve Pilots Say They Refuse to Bomb Civilians
description: Twenty-seven reserve pilots in the Israeli Air Force presented a signed petition tonight saying that they would not take part in ''illegal and immoral'' strikes in Palestinian areas in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The airstrikes, aimed at Hamas militants, sometimes kill Palestinian civilians.

title: She Says She's No Music Pirate. No Snoop Fan, Either.
description: Sarah Ward was stunned when the record industry sued her for being a music pirate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, MORTON
description: GREEN--Morton. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date for Dr. Morton Green, 85, who died at his home on September 23. Dr. Green was born in Brooklyn, NY on October 25, 1917 to Leon and Nessa (Lackow) Green. He graduated from PS 153 and Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn. He was a professor of vertebrate paleontology for over 45 years. Dr. Green married Elizabeth A. Griffith on June 6, 1946. She survives. Other survivors: Leon M. Green of Wilmington, DE, Joel G. Green, Kirkland, WA, Julie Green Rombough, Lawrence, KS, and five grandchildren.

title: More Weapons-Grade Uranium Found in Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 25  Inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency have found traces of highly enriched uranium at an electrical plant on the outskirts of Teheran, the second site where such evidence of unreported enrichment activities has been discovered in recent months, a western diplomat with access to agency reports said today.

title: Beat Mystique Endures at a San Francisco Landmark
description: The shelves at the City Lights bookstore were pushed aside, and two chairs were arranged against a wall near the erotica section. It was standing room only as Lawrence Ferlinghetti, San Francisco's celebrity poet and a founder of the bookstore, took a seat with a friendly, twinkling smile.

title: Market Place; Viacom Cuts Forecast As Local Advertising Is Slow to Rebound
description: Viacom Inc. told investors yesterday that its revenue and profit for the full year would come in below earlier forecasts because the market for local advertising has not recovered as strongly as the company had expected.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MINNESOTA: DRUGS FROM CANADA STUDIED Gov. Tim Pawlenty said the state would study how much it might save if it bought prescription drugs from Canada. Mr. Pawlenty, left, said he expects the study will find at least $20 million in potential savings on drugs bought from Canada for the state's 50,000 employees and for more than 600,000 others who receive medical care through state programs. Mr. Pawlenty, a Republican, joins two Democrats, Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa and Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois, calling for similar studies. The Food and Drug Administration considers the practice of buying drugs in Canada for use in the United States illegal, but some members of Congress are pressing to change that.    Monica Davey (NYT)

title: In the Lair of a Tender Giant
description: ''FRANK CABOT says I mollycoddle this plant,'' said Caroline Burgess, the director of Stonecrop Gardens, as she pulled aside one of the 5-by-5-foot leaves of the monster plant, Gunnera manicata, a native of Brazil, to show off a flower spike the size and shape of a torpedo. Mollycoddle? She gave it its own drip hose and surrounded it with horse manure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DINITZ, SIMCHA
description: DINITZ--Simcha. The Governors, Officers, Faculty and Students of the Schechter Institute of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem mourn the loss of our esteemed friend and colleague, Ambassador Simcha Dinitz, a distinguished and committed member of the Schechter Institute's Board of Governors. We remain eternally grateful for his life of service, wisdom, guidance and commitment to promoting pluralistic Jewish education in Israel. To his wife and children and all those who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Board of Governors Professor Alice Shalvi, Chair of the Executive Committee Professor David Golinkin, President Raquel H. Flatow, National Executive Director

title: No-Call List Dealt Setback In Court Ruling
description: Federal regulators overstepped their authority in establishing a national do-not-call registry, according to a federal district court ruling made public yesterday. The decision appears to block, at least temporarily, the national program scheduled to begin Oct. 1 that is aimed at preventing telemarketers from calling the 50 million phone numbers Americans have put on the list.

title: South African Leader Defends Delay in Offering AIDS Drugs
description: President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa yesterday defended his government's delay in distributing anti-AIDS drugs until this year, saying that it had been necessary to create a critical mass of public health care workers who knew how to instruct patients on the drugs' use.

title: Court Overturns Stoning Sentence of Woman in Nigeria
description: KATSINA, Nigeria, Sept. 25  Amina Lawal, the Nigerian peasant woman sentenced under Islamic law to death by stoning for having had sex outside marriage, was acquitted and set free today by the highest religious court in her state.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: McDONALD'S CORP., Oak Brook, Ill., the hamburger restaurant chain, increased its annual dividend by 70 percent, from 23.5 cents a share to 40 cents a share, its largest increase in 25 years.

title: Lottery Numbers
Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Order Of Protection Is Strengthened
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he had signed a law to strengthen a court order frequently used by victims of domestic violence. The new law extends the duration of an order of protection banning contact by a named offender, like a husband. Previously, an order of protection remained in effect for one year, or for three years in cases with aggravating circumstances. For a complainant to get the three-year order, however, the offender had to violate the order repeatedly. Under the new law, an order will remain in effect for two years, or five with aggravating circumstances, which now can apply to one-time offenders. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Thinning Ice
description: There has been no end of scholarly studies confirming the gradual rise in global temperatures over the past century. Yet nothing focuses the mind on global warming and its potential consequences quite so sharply as the occasional news flash from some remote corner of the globe documenting startling changes in landscapes once thought to be immutable. Two years ago, for instance, scientists told us that the snows of Kilimanjaro, which inspired Ernest Hemingway's famous short story, could vanish in 15 years, and that the seemingly indestructible glaciers in the Bolivian Andes might not last another 10. Last year brought evidence of disturbing and apparently irreversible changes in Alaska's environment -- melting permafrost, sagging roads, dying forests -- arising from an astonishing rise of 5.4 degrees in Alaska's average temperature over the past 30 years.

title: For Those Who Believe That Ivy Is an Ivy Is an Ivy
description: Think ivy is ho-hum? Check out Hedera helix Duck Foot, right, with its cute little inch-wide leaf. Just named ivy of the year for 2004 by the American Ivy Society, Duck Foot has been tested for hardiness in areas as cold as Zone 5, where temperatures drop to 20 below. ''I like it because it's little and the leaves don't look like regular ivy,'' said Suzanne Pierot, the president of the society, who grows Duck Foot in Woodstock, N.Y. It thrives in sun but will tolerate shade, does best if planted out of the wind and looks good indoors in a pot. Nurseries sell Duck Foot for $2.50 to $5.95 a plant, and the American Ivy Society gives a free plant to those who join, for $20 (www.ivy.org). ANNE RAVER

description: OPEC to Cut Oil Output In Effort to Keep Prices Up

THE unrepentant cheats among the big-time athletes and mercenary scoundrels inside the circle of coaches have been humming along with a Dire Straits tune for years until ''Money for Nothing'' has all but become a college fight song.

title: Party Music, for the Downhearted
description: The Dave Matthews Band's contradictions were easily large enough to fill the Great Lawn of Central Park when it performed there last night. Mr. Matthews is used to audiences like the more than 85,000 people who danced and sang along with most of his songs, bouncing to the intricate, light-fingered vamps that drive the songs like happy clockwork.

title: The L.C.D. Screen Wins Color-Obsessed Converts
description: IN the tech world, the slender liquid crystal display monitor has become synonymous with cool, making steady inroads against its rotund predecessor, the cathode ray tube. By the fall of 2002, sales of flat-panel L.C.D. monitors in the United States had exceeded those of C.R.T.'s in terms of dollars spent, and by the end of this year L.C.D.'s should surpass C.R.T.'s in units sold, according to the research firm iSuppli/Stanford Resources.

title: Bomb in Baghdad Misses Humvees, Blasts 2 Iraqi Buses
description: It was not until after the powerful explosion here this morning that Rasoul Khalid Ibrahim, a security guard, remembered: the morning before, he saw two men, one in the clothes of a street cleaner, digging a hole in the dirt of a median strip.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz's comments at a forum on Iraq misstated President Bush's position on whether there were contacts between Al Qaeda and the government of Saddam Hussein. Mr. Bush has said there were such contacts; he has not said they were unsubstantiated.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intel Invests $450 Million In Micron Technology
description: Intel, which stopped making computer-memory chips in 1987 as Asian companies undercut the price, invested $450 million in Micron Technology to assure an adequate supply of advanced memory. Micron, the world's second-biggest memory-chip maker behind Samsung Electronics of South Korea and the only major manufacturer left in the United States, has had losses for 11 straight quarters and has lagged behind some rivals in introducing the latest, most-expensive manufacturing techniques. ''The availability of high-performance memory is critical as we continue to develop advanced microprocessors and communications components,'' Intel's chief executive, Craig Barrett, said yesterday. Intel, the world's biggest semiconductor maker, receives rights exchangeable for 33.9 million Micron shares, the companies said. Shares of Micron rose to $14.64 in extended trading after the report. They had fallen 57 cents, to $14.10 in regular trading.

title: Plan to Rebuild Iraq Gains Some Backing on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 — The commander of American forces in Iraq said today he is pessimistic about the prospects of another international troop division joining the campaign, meaning that United States troops may have to bear the burden of peacekeeping and reconstruction.

title: Empire Maker to Miss Gold Cup at Belmont
description: Empire Maker, winner of the Belmont Stakes, has reinjured his left front foot, and that will keep him out of the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup on Saturday at Belmont. The foot bruise is similar to one he had before the Kentucky Derby, compromising his training routine.

title: Not Lost in Translation
description: CHINOISERIE never goes out of style. ''Alors, la Chine,'' a show of contemporary Chinese arts, is at the Pompidou Center in Paris (through Oct. 13), and in October an exhibition and sale of Chinese housewares, new and vintage, will be at the Terence Conran shops in New York, London and Paris. Until then, Chinese furnishings and memorabilia can be found at the following sources.

title: Bed Bath Profit Rises 29%
description: Bed Bath and Beyond , the housewares retailer, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings increased 29 percent after it opened more stores and customers bought more bedding, dinnerware and lamps.

description: A federal court ruled that regulators overstepped their authority in establishing a national do-not-call registry. title: Along With Population and Diversity, Stress Rises on Staten I.

title: Royalties From PBS Dismay Bluesmen
description: On Sunday PBS is scheduled to begin its weeklong documentary series ''The Blues,'' with Martin Scorsese as executive producer. In the episodes, directed by Clint Eastwood, Wim Wenders, Mike Figgis and others, the past, present and future of the blues are honored, explored and explained.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Candy, Not Explosives
description: An anonymous package prompted a bomb scare, emptying Athens city hall, but it was actually filled with taffy and Jolly Rancher candy that had been left by children as a ''random act of kindness.'' The police doused the package with water ''and then when they were collecting the evidence it was determined that it was candy,'' a spokeswoman for the Athens-Clarke County Police Department, said. The box was left in the barrel of a display cannon. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Currency Controls Backed
description: The governments of the United States and other countries should stop seeking changes to foreign currency controls to win votes at home, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Horst Khler, left, said yesterday, four days after the Group of 7 nations called for more flexible exchange rates. Countries must ''stop their short-term games for domestic political reasons,'' Mr. Khler said. G-7 finance ministers said on Saturday that they would welcome less rigid exchange policies.

title: A. O. SMITH SHARES FALL ON PROFIT WARNING
description: The A. O. Smith Corporation, a leading maker of commercial water heaters, cut its profit forecasts yesterday for the third quarter and 2003, setting off a 14 percent decline in its share price. Sales were hurt after customers stocked up on older-model water heaters ahead of a July federal deadline to use safer, yet more expensive, heaters, said A.O. Smith, which is based in Milwaukee. The company also said it cost more than expected to move half of its motor production to plants in Mexico and China. Third-quarter profit will be 18 cents to 20 cents a share, less than half of the 42 cents to 46 cents forecast in July. Profit for the year will be $1.75 to $1.80, down from $2.10 to $2.25, A. O. Smith said. Shares fell $4.68, to $29.75 a share.

Ms. Lindh, 46, died a day after being stabbed in a Stockholm store on Sept. 10. The public prosecutor said that the first detainee was no longer suspected of her slaying but that there were "probable grounds" to believe that the second man had committed the crime. description: Tito Dupret

title: Monitor Sheds Some Buttons In Favor of Savvy Software
description: Liquid crystal display computer monitors are sleek, bright and, increasingly, inexpensive. But Samsung, a leading maker of monitors, has introduced a 17-inch model with a different attribute: hands-free operation.

title: Gams To Gladiators
description: Everybody was watching the big guy last night to see whether his high-priced handlers had managed to mold all that muscly clay into Serious Arnold. The tyro Tyrolean pol had to offer more to California voters than the same message he gave to the distressed Linda Hamilton in ''Terminator 2'': ''Come with me if you want to liff.''

title: The Sweeping View From Inside a Digital Bubble
description: BORDERS don't bother Tito Dupret. When Mr. Dupret, a Belgian photojournalist, travels in his homeland, an hour's drive in almost any direction will put him in another country. ''A border is something I don't really understand,'' he said in a recent telephone interview.

title: OPEC Says It Will Cut Output, And Price of Oil Climbs Sharply
description: OPEC unexpectedly agreed today to cut oil production on Nov. 1, just as most of the developed world will be heading toward winter and demand for heating oil is likely to be rising.

title: UNITED AIRLINES TO TRY SELLING FOOD ON FLIGHTS
description: UAL, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it would sell food in economy class for 90 days, starting Oct. 31. The food will be sold on more than 200 flights from Chicago and Denver, two of United's main domestic hubs. United said that offerings would include items from relatively well-known restaurant chains like Bennigan's, Hard Rock Cafe and T.G.I. Friday's. Breakfast will cost $7 and lunch and dinner will be $10 each, the airline said. Passengers in business and first class will be served free. UAL also said its loss last month fell to $46 million from $112 million in July and that its results met covenants in its bankruptcy proceeding. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: At the Mighty BBC, Cracks in the Facade
description: For 81 years the undisputed voice of Britain and the country's most enduringly credible institution, the BBC is being subjected to public scrutiny and criticism as never before. The current furor over the BBC reporter who admitted overstepping strict accuracy when he accused the government of exaggerating an Iraqi weapons report to gain support for the war has touched off fresh charges that the BBC has lost its way and that its partisan scrappiness matches or even outdoes that of Britain's independent news media.

title: Education Law Experts Back District's Response to Inquiry
description: Experts in education law say a Long Island school district acted wisely when it refused to turn over information from its own investigation into allegations that three varsity football players sexually abused younger teammates at a preseason training camp in Pennsylvania.

title: Scheduling In Some Dawdle Time
description: ON Fridays after school, when the Fitzer and Magruder children play soccer at North Main Rotary Park in Greenville, S.C., the usual rules of the game apply, but not the usual annoyances. Their parents decided to pass up the local Y.M.C.A. league, along with the rush-hour drives and the dinner delays it would entail, in favor of old-fashioned pickup games. The players -- mostly 4 to 7 years old -- meet half a block from their elementary school. There is no rush, no $50 fee and no pressure to join the game.

title: Paying for War's Aftermath
description: How about forcing the Iraqi people to take out a mortgage on their newfound freedom, using their nation's future oil revenue as collateral? A proposal to do that -- making a loan out of the $20 billion the Bush administration is seeking to cover the first round of reconstruction costs -- is gaining support in Congress. Of all the bad ideas that have been floated recently about Iraq's future, this is one of the worst.

title: Critics Attack Microsoft Over Security
description: Over the years, Microsoft's flagship product, the Windows operating system for personal computers, has been denigrated by the company's critics as buggy, crash-prone and confusing to use. But a group of computer security experts went further yesterday by asserting that Windows is a threat to national security because of its complex design and monopoly reach.

title: Marlins and Reliever Show They Belong
description: Two months after being released by the Boston Red Sox, reliever Chad Fox stood in the Florida Marlins' clubhouse tonight and felt as if he were approaching the apex of his career.

title: A Bug's Death
description: Should we send the malaria mosquito the way of the dodo?

title: Iraqi Council Member Dies 5 Days After She Was Shot
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 25  Akila al-Hashemi, a member of Iraq's 25-person Governing Council, died this morning, five days after unidentified gunmen ambushed her in the street as she drove to work.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHLACHET, PETER
description: SCHLACHET--Peter. Beloved, I trust you are sailing. Godspeed. Always, Your Anna

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: City Admits Suicide Watch Didn't Prevent 2 Jail Deaths
description: Two of the six Rikers Island inmates who killed themselves this year were on suicide watch, despite previous public statements by Department of Correction officials to the contrary, an agency spokesman said yesterday.

title: Pay Deal for Actors in Ads
description: The Screen Actors Guild, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, and an advertising trade group reached a tentative new pay agreement yesterday covering TV and radio commercials.

title: Parcells Carries On; Edwards Won't Be Carried Out
description: Bill Parcells revived a moribund Jets franchise, leaving it stocked with players who have sustained the team in the two seasons since he left. But on Sunday, Parcells, in his latest incarnation as Dallas Cowboys coach, has a chance to undo much of the good.

title: Mortgage Index Declines
description: An index of applications for mortgages fell last week as home purchases declined for the first time in four weeks, an industry report showed.

title: Two Nations Split by a Sense of Humor
description: NBC's racy new comedy, ''Coupling,'' about the tangled sex lives of six single men and women is shameful, but not because it is so singlemindedly focused on sex.

title: Microsoft's Rivals Won't Shut Chat Rooms
description: Microsoft's two major competitors in providing Internet services said yesterday that they had no plans to emulate its decision to shut down many free chat rooms in the United States and abroad.

title: Mongolians Return to Baghdad, This Time as Peacekeepers
description: In 1258, the Mongol general Hulegu, a grandson of Genghis Khan, sacked Baghdad, killing 800,000 people and ending its primacy as the largest city in the Arab world.

title: Park Plan Ruins Romance, Critics Say
description: So much for a romantic stroll along Central Park South. The Central Park Conservancy is planning to install bigger and brighter lights along the park's southern perimeter, a move that could sharply alter the fairy-like ambience of that particular patch of Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Acquisitions Sought
description: Two years after its purchase of Optus, an Australian company, for 14 billion Australian dollars ($9.5 billion), Singapore Telecommunications is again looking for investments in cellular services in Asia. In two reported interviews on Wednesday, the head of the company's cellular business said the company would be seeking investment opportunities in the region. With growth in its home market stagnant, the company counts on foreign investments for earnings and revenue.

title: From Found Objects, A Gothic Dcor
description: IN a 1981 book called ''The Meaning of Things: Domestic Symbols and the Self,'' two Chicago sociologists asked 315 people what item in their home they cherished most. In happy families, people tended to name items they associated with a loved one or event, like an old toy or photograph, or the couch where the family gathered. The people who named items for their intrinsic quality -- a new stove, the latest big television -- were those in the least happy homes.

title: New York Views That Will Make Eyes Open Wide
description: The interior of the Tweed Courthouse, far left, will be available for scrutiny on Oct. 11 as part of Open House New York, a weekend when private homes, oddities like the catacombs at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn and unfamiliar parts of public buildings will be open. (Tours of the courthouse are from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., with entry through City Hall.)

title: Giving Voice to Life's Emotion: A Documentarian's Calling
description: As a documentary filmmaker Heddy Honigmann has interviewed war widows living in a village outside Sarajevo (''Good Husband, Dear Son''), former United Nations peacekeepers who served in Bosnia, Cambodia, Lebanon and Rwanda (''Crazy'') and musicians exiled from their homelands and making their living performing in the Paris Metro (''The Underground Orchestra''). In Rio de Janeiro she handed the erotic writings of the Brazilian poet Carlos Drummond de Andrade to elderly people and filmed them reading (''O Amor Natural'').

title: Invisible Cable Links the Gamer To the PC Modem Upstairs
description: The latest Internet-ready game consoles may let you play against other gamers halfway around the world, but getting them connected to the Net may well require stringing Ethernet cables halfway around the home, since consoles and computers often don't share the same room.

title: 2 Holocaust Survivors to Sue Group Set Up to Collect Insurance
description: Five years after the creation of an international commission to help Holocaust survivors collect on claims from European insurers, two survivors plan to file a lawsuit today asserting that the commission has sided with the insurers and made it more difficult to receive fair payment on decades-old policies.

title: Dr. Barnes's Hidden Trove
description: Help is at hand -- poetically enough, in a Pennsylvania orphans' court -- for the Barnes Foundation, the hideaway outside Philadelphia that houses one of the world's most highly prized but secluded art collections.

title: A Family's Fatuousness (And Publishing's, Too)
description: WINNER OF THE NATIONAL BOOK AWARD

title: Bush Officials See Long Road To Resolution
description: President Bush held an intensive round of meetings with allies yesterday to press for help in Iraq, but he won no immediate offers of aid, and administration officials said it might take as long as a month to negotiate a United Nations resolution on Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: New Suspect In Assassination
description: The police released a man they detained last week in connection with the murder of Foreign Minister Anna Lindh and arrested a new suspect, the public prosecutor said. Ms. Lindh, 46, died a day after being stabbed in a Stockholm store on Sept. 10. The public prosecutor said that the first detainee was no longer suspected of her slaying but that there were ''probable grounds'' to believe that the second man had committed the crime. The police have not identified either man. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINKIN, DAVID
description: MINKIN--David. 99, of New York, and Palm Beach, FL. Passed away September 19, 2003. Adored uncle of Patricia and Howard Lester. Greatuncle of Peter and Prescott Lester and Pamela Ford. Great-great-uncle of Owen Ford and Scott Lester. He was a true renaissance man, a leader of the community and a second father to us all. He will be sorely missed. Services were held. For information call Riverside Nassau North, 516-487-9600. Contributions may be made to the Mayo Foundation, attn: Paul Harkess, Rochester, MN 55905.

title: For Children, an AOL Playground With Games and a New Link Fence
description: America Online has long been both a jumping-off place and destination for children who are exploring cyberspace. On Sept. 29, it will introduce a version of its online service intended entirely for children.

title: Accounts
description: * DuPont, Wilmington, Del., expanded its relationship with McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, by selecting the agency to handle creative duties for Invista, the division formerly known as DuPont Textiles and Interiors. The division will be promoted in campaigns of its own in addition to ads for its products like Lycra. Billings were estimated at more than $20 million. McCann-Erickson, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has handled the creative assignment for Lycra since last year.

title: Army Chaplain in Detention Sought to Teach About Islam
description: Within days of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Capt. James J. Yee, a Muslim chaplain stationed at the Fort Lewis Army base south of here, dedicated himself to a new mission. He would tell anyone who would listen, according to people who heard his sermons, that Islam was not a violent religion, and he would deliver that message at the base, in churches and mosques, on college campuses and on the streets of Olympia, where he lived with his wife and young daughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, GERARD S.
description: GROSS--Gerard S. Age 72. Beloved husband of Mary, sonin-law of Clara DiGrigoli, brother of Elsie (Irv) Farber, uncle and great uncle. He was loved. Service Friday 11:15AM at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This was a message to Washington: 'You can send a delegation to OPEC, but we control the oil price.' ''

title: A German Court Accepts Teacher's Head Scarf
description: Treading into a debate that has flared across Europe, Germany's highest court ruled today that a Muslim teacher cannot be forbidden to wear a head scarf in a public school.

title: Congress Moves Ahead on U.S.O.C.
description: Legislation intended to reform the United States Olympic Committee was passed unanimously by the Senate late Tuesday night. A similar bill was introduced yesterday in the House. Both bills would pare the U.S.O.C. board to 12 voting members, five of them independents, and create a 120-member assembly.

title: Herb Gardner, 68, Playwright; Tony Winner for 'Rappaport'
description: Herb Gardner, the award-winning playwright whose credits include ''A Thousand Clowns'' and ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' died last night at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 68.

title: COURT BLOCKS SEVERANCE PAYMENT BY VIVENDI
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has won a court order blocking a $22.9 million severance payment to Jean-Marie Messier, the former chief executive of Vivendi Universal, while the agency investigates the company. Judge Kevin T. Duffy of Federal District Court in New York barred Vivendi yesterday from transferring money to Mr. Messier, ordering the company to put the payment in an escrow account. ''Basically what we're trying to do is prevent this extraordinary payment from moving forward while we're in the midst of our investigation of Vivendi for the benefit of Vivendi shareholders,'' an S.E.C. lawyer, Gary Klein, said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Fired McCann executive gets back in the game with a newly created senior post at Euro RSCG.
description: JAMES R. HEEKIN, fired in February from his posts atop the problem-plagued McCann-Erickson World Group in New York, is returning to advertising.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Islip: Two Students Attacked In School
description: Two brothers from Colombia were attacked yesterday at East Islip High School by at least two other students yelling anti-Hispanic epithets, the police said. Detective Sgt. Robert Reecks of the Suffolk County police said that the immigrants were a 10th grader and a 12th grader. The students accused in the attack have been suspended from school, but no arrests have been made, Sergeant Reecks said, adding that the incident was being considered a bias crime. The brothers were treated for minor injuries at Southside Hospital. Sergeant Reecks said there was no history of ethnically motivated crimes at the school. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Simon Breines, 97, an Architect And a Critic of Hurried Projects
description: Simon Breines, a New York City architect who was the first president of the Landmarks Conservancy of New York and the architect member of the Art Commission of New York City, died on Sept. 16 at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 97.

title: Kazakhstan Faith Talks Seek To Subdue Religious Clashes
description: More than 120 delegates from 18 religions gathered today in Kazakhstan's political capital to condemn terrorism and lay the foundations of an organization they advertised as a diverse effort to reduce violent clashes between faiths around the world.

title: Service Is a Struggle For Virtual Town Halls
description: AS the Internet has grown up and consumers have become accustomed to going online for everything from banking to buying movie tickets, cities large and small have joined in by making more municipal services available on the Web.

title: Office Buzz: Check The E-Mail
description: WHAT would be a good motto for Microsoft? ''Winning is everything''? ''Might makes right''? ''Money can't buy you love''?

title: 2 Big Advertisers Pick New Agencies
description: Two big advertisers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Restrained
description: Canada's annual inflation rate fell to 2 percent in August, the slowest pace in 13 months, suggesting that the central bank would keep interest rates unchanged this year. The consumer price index rose 0.2 percent from July, with almost all of that gain caused by surging gas costs, Statistics Canada said yesteday in Ottawa.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   TRAFTON, ALFRED (KIPP)
description: TRAFTON--Alfred (Kipp). Who can say for certain maybe you're still here, I feel you all around me, your memory so clear. You're still an inspiration, can it be? 15. Love, Tod

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Dog-Shelter Law Signed
description: Under a new law that is to go into effect in November, dog owners who abuse their pets by leaving them outdoors during stormy or freezing weather may be fined up to $250 or lose possession of the pets. Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he had signed legislation requiring owners to provide pets with ''structurally sound shelter,'' insulated and with a waterproof roof. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Deep Into Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRISER, SIDNEY P.
description: KRISER--Sidney P. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Sidney Kriser, a longtime friend and supporter. Along with his late brother Leonard, Sidney was the recipient of ADL's Haym Solomon Award for their generous support of the League. We extend our sincere condolences to his daughter Judy, his nephew Charles, who serves on ADL's National Executive Committee, and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Flight 737, Now Departing From Your Garage
description: IN the quarter-century that flight simulator software has been on the market, many pilots have cited the fun of such programs as their inspiration for learning to fly. But Matt Ford, a Los Angeles lighting designer, cites the opposite, tracing his infatuation with simulation programs to his real-world flight school days.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Later, in the Hutch, He Fired His Agent

title: Some Visitors Get Passport Rule Reprieve
description: The State Department has decided to delay enforcement of a rule requiring Western Europeans and citizens of other developed countries to have computer-coded passports if entering the United States without a visa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELLA FEMINA, MICHAEL
description: DELLA FEMINA--Michael. On September 24, 2003. A lifetime employee of 49 years with the New York Times. Beloved husband of the late Concetta. Devoted father of Jerry and Joe. Fond fatherin-law of Barbara, Carol and Judy. Cherished grandfather of Donna, Michael, Danielle, Elisa, Jodi, Mark, Jessie and J.T. Funeral mass today, September 25, 10:00 AM at St. Jean Baptiste, R.C. Church. Arrangements entrusted to Frank E. Campbell.

title: The Dalai Lama's Fans
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sabre To Cut Work Force
description: The Sabre Holdings Corporation, the owner of the Internet travel agent Travelocity.com, plans to cut an undetermined number of jobs in the fourth quarter because it expects reduced profits because of discounted fees. The company, based in Southlake, Tex., notified employees of its plans yesterday and disclosed them in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A Sabre spokesman, Michael Berman, said the company did not know how many of the 6,500 employees would be affected or what the financial effect would be, though savings would be accrued in 2004.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Costume Change For Princely Role

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Amendment Approved
description: Voters approved an amendment that will allow Gov. Bill Richardson to appoint a state secretary of education. But the vote was too close to call on a second amendment, which would increase financing for education. Hundreds of ballots cast by people whose names did not appear on registration rolls are still uncounted, and officials said the results might not be final until Oct. 14. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: EAST ISLIP: TWO STUDENTS ATTACKED IN SCHOOL Two brothers from Colombia were attacked yesterday at East Islip High School by at least two other students yelling anti-Hispanic epithets, the police said. Detective Sgt. Robert Reecks of the Suffolk County police said that the immigrants were a 10th grader and a 12th grader. The students accused in the attack have been suspended from school, but no arrests have been made, Sergeant Reecks said, adding that the incident was being considered a bias crime. The brothers were treated for minor injuries at Southside Hospital. Sergeant Reecks said there was no history of ethnically motivated crimes at the school. Patrick Healy (NYT)
