description: EUROPE

title: Nonagenarian Keeps Going; His Partners Keep Guessing
description: It is well-established that bridge players have a greater life expectancy than the general population. Mental activity helps the production of white blood cells.

title: Stretched Pentagon Says It May Need to Call Up Thousands More Reservists to Serve in Iraq
description: The Defense Department may be forced to call up thousands of additional National Guard and Reserve troops for duty in Iraq if foreign nations do not volunteer sufficient forces for a third international division, one of the Pentagon's most senior generals said today.

title: Guns Used in Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Tramping Immigrant Byways With a Whisper in Your Ear
description: These days, Manhattan's Lower East Side is a veritable hipster central: the shabby-chic home to trendy bars, clubs and boutiques. But there is no denying the neighborhood's immigrant past, with its tenements and sweatshops, entertainers and gangsters, bialys and pickles.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Telemarketer Accused Of Fraud
description: A telemarketing executive has been accused of using inflated invoices to bilk companies out of more than $1.5 million, prosecutors announced yesterday. A subsequent search of office computers led to charges of possessing child pornography when obscene images were found on the computer hard drives, investigators said. The executive, Mark S. Kleinman, who owns several telemarketing companies, was arrested yesterday on a 15-count federal indictment that charged him with mail fraud and possession of pornography. According to the indictment, Mr. Kleinman's employees bribed employees at client companies into buying maintenance supplies at inflated prices. The employee would receive a kickback of about 10 percent of the bill, the indictment said. If convicted of the charges, Mr. Kleinman would face up to 20 years in prison. His lawyer, Steven Robert LaCheen, did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: For the World's ABC's, He Makes 1's and 0's
description: MICHAEL EVERSON, a 40-year-old typographer who lives in Dublin, considers himself blessed because he has found his life's work: to be an alphabetician to all the peoples of the world. Mr. Everson's largest project to date -- a contribution to a new version of Unicode 4.0, an international standard for computerizing text -- is cementing his reputation.

title: Debate Gives A Rare Burst Of Exposure To Pace U.
description: For many colleges, the chance for broad television exposure comes when their athletic teams make it into nationally televised playoff games.

title: Upsets Earn Perfection, Credibility And Ranking
description: Northern Illinois football fans have not had much reason to celebrate since their team gained major-college status 34 seasons ago. Sure, there was the California Bowl victory in 1983. And there was a triumph over Central Michigan in 1998, but that brought joy to campus only because it snapped a 23-game losing streak.

title: F.B.I. Says Souvenir Seller Used a Hard Sell, With Fists
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says a Midtown souvenir merchant had his own method for bringing business into his hard-to-find shop on Fifth Avenue: if a tour bus did not stop and unload customers, somebody got a beating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, PETER
description: MILLER--Peter. Of New York City on September 24. He was the beloved husband of Rhoda Miller and devoted father to Justin and Dana Miller. Peter Miller was the former Chief Tax Counsel for W.R. Grace, a past President of the NY State Bar Association's Tax Section. Former consultant to Governor Nelson Rockefeller's Special Tax Structure Study Committee and former Chairman of the Tax Club. He was a graduate of the Horace Mann School, Columbia University and Yale University Law School. His father, Julius Miller, was a NY State Supreme Court Judge and Manhattan Borough President. Peter Miller had immense integrity and loved social justice. He will be deeply missed. His funeral will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. at 11:15 AM, Thursday, September 25.

title: The President, Iraq and the World
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Palestinians and 1 Israeli Are Killed in Overnight Raids
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 25  Israeli troops staged overnight raids against Palestinian militants in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip today that left five militants and one soldier dead in the bloodiest day of fighting in more than two weeks.

title: The U.N. Must Change
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tire Company Cuts Outlook
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, the tire maker, cut its full-year profit goal yesterday by 2 billion yen ($18 million) because of a fire that destroyed a factory in Japan. Bridgestone expects to earn 78 billion yen this year. The company did not change its sales forecast. The plant burned for two days this month. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Edward Said, Leading Advocate of Palestinians, Dies at 67
description: Edward Said, a polymath scholar and literary critic at Columbia University who was the most prominent advocate in the United States of the cause of Palestinian independence, died in New York City today. He was 67.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about the addition of a portrait of former Gov. George Ryan to the Illinois Hall of Governors misidentified the location. The hall is in the Capitol, not the executive mansion.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Service Spending Falls
description: Spending on services fell in July at its fastest rate in five years because of colder-than-normal weather. The so-called tertiary activity index, which tracks spending at retail outlets and on services, declined 2.5 percent. The weak figure is a signal that Japan's gross domestic product could grow at a lower rate in the July to September period than in the second quarter. The ministry of economy, trade and industry's all sector index of economic activity fell 1.5 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Cutting Jobs
description: The Japanese subsidiary of the McDonald's Corporation plans to cut 15 percent of the jobs at its Tokyo headquarters as it tries to increase profit. The subsidiary, McDonald's Holding Company, introducing its first early retirement program, will offer retirement packages to 130 workers age 40 and older. The company will include the cost of the packages in its earnings for the year that ends in December. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Boxx Goes From Spectator to Steadfast Midfielder
description: Shannon Boxx planned to attend the Women's World Cup all along, but as a spectator instead of as a player.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Solutions Settles F.T.C. Charges
description: The Network Solutions unit of VeriSign Inc. yesterday settled charges by the Federal Trade Commission of misleading customers of competitors into transferring their registered Internet names to the company for a fee, the agency said. The unit last year mailed to consumers what looked like notices from their current registrars stating that their registrations would expire soon, when that was months or years away in some cases, the agency said on its Web site. Network Solutions offered renewals that actually moved an address to the company, and those who accepted paid ''significantly higher'' fees, the agency said. Network Solutions, the largest registrar, still manages the database for registered Internet addresses ending in .com and .net. VeriSign, which sells electronic-commerce security software, acquired the company in 2000. Tom Galvin, a company spokesman, was not available to comment immediately. VeriSign's shares fell 97 cents, or 6.6 percent, to $13.72.

title: Vote on Judge Is Planned
description: Senate Republicans have revived the nomination of Judge Charles W. Pickering Sr. to a federal appeals court.

title: Fall Back
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including haiku about fall and arguments for and against foie gras.

title: U.N. Pulls More Workers From Iraq After Bombings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Secretary-General Kofi Annan ordered a further cut in the United Nations presence in Iraq today, but he stopped short of removing all international employees as his security adviser and an employees union had urged.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Secretary General Kofi Annan's speech to the United Nations General Assembly quoted incorrectly from a remark he made about the organization's failure to include more developing countries in the Security Council after more than a decade of debate. Mr. Annan told the delegates that unless they address the issue with greater urgency, history ''will not forgive us'' (not ''forget us'').

title: For a Family of Sharers, Unique XP Identities
description: Q. I have heard that the Windows XP operating system will let users set up individual identities when they boot up a shared PC. How does this work?

title: The BBC Loses a Bit Of Its Luster; A Venerable Institution Braces for a Battle
description: Called in to anchor the BBC's coverage of the death of the Queen Mother last year, the broadcaster Peter Sissons made a simple choice that set off a complicated furor. Instead of the traditional black necktie traditionally worn by BBC presenters at times of national mourning, he wore maroon.

title: Just Add Imagination: A Desert Springs to Life
description: Flora and fauna of the American Southwest groove together in ''Opus Cactus,'' another of Moses Pendleton's ingenious pantheistic hymns to nature for his dance troupe, Momix.

title: Red Sox Fritter Away a Chance to Clinch
description: The Fenway Park employees hauled cases of beer and Champagne to the clubhouse, and Red Sox officials bantered on their walkie-talkies about finding plastic to cover the team's lockers. The fans buying sausages on Yawkey Way buzzed in anticipation of seeing their Red Sox clinch the American League wild-card spot.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York City fire safety legislation recommended by a task force that studied the World Trade Center collapse misstated the given name of the city building commissioner, who discussed the measures. She is Patricia J. Lancaster, not Barbara.

title: Clark Issues Job Plan While Criticizing Bush
description: Under pressure to broaden his presidential candidacy beyond his experience in national security, Gen. Wesley K. Clark issued a detailed proposal yesterday for creating jobs, saying, ''We simply cannot have strong security without a strong economy.''

title: Sports Briefing
description: COURT NEWS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg Backs Fashion Program
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, taking a break from the bare-knuckle politics of Albany and New York, held a fashion-industry dinner last night at his Upper East Side town house, with invited guests including Anna Wintour, left, the editor in chief of Vogue magazine. The occasion was the establishment of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, sponsored by Vogue and the Council of Fashion Designers. It is hoped that next year a committee will be able to award up to $100,000 each to two promising designers. Also invited were the veteran designers Donna Karan and Calvin Klein and the new designers Peter Som and Zac Posen. Kari Haskell (NYT)

title: Balanced Diets
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a deadlock over legislation to renew the authority of the Federal Aviation Administration to accept and spend money referred incorrectly to the status of aviation taxes after Oct. 1. While the F.A.A. could no longer receive various taxes without a renewal of the law, they would continue to be paid to the federal treasury; the taxes would not cease entirely.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ex-Finance Minister To Retire
description: Masajuro Shiokawa, who stepped down Monday as Japan's finance minister, will retire from politics. Now 81, Mr. Shiokawa, left, entered politics 33 years ago and was finance minister for the last two and a half years. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Confidence Rises
description: German business confidence jumped to its highest level in two and a half years this month, according to a survey of 7,000 western German companies released by the Ifo Institute in Munich. The overall index rose to 91.9, from 90.8 in August, the highest reading since April 2001. The gain was led by increased optimism among manufacturers and retailers. Construction companies, however, became more pessimistic during the month.

description: Inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency have found traces of highly enriched uranium at an electrical plant on the outskirts of Tehran, the second site where such evidence of unreported enrichment activities has been discovered in recent months, a Western diplomat with access to the agency's reports said today.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SALE OF G.M. BUILDING COMPLETED The developer Harry Macklowe yesterday completed his record-breaking $1.4 billion purchase of the General Motors Building, the white marble skyscraper on Fifth Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets. He outmaneuvered more than two dozen rival bidders. The sale  at the highest price ever paid for a single office tower in the United States  completes a three-year struggle to sell the 50-story tower, best known as the home of the flagship store of F.A.O Schwarz. This week, the Chancery Court in Delaware rejected a request from a rival bidder, Sheldon H. Solow, to block the sale. Mr. Solow, who also bid $1.4 billion, claimed that the seller, Conseco , and its broker had acted unfairly in awarding the deal to Mr. Macklowe. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Is My House Still There?
description: GERRY MOOHR and her husband, Roger Sherman, spent just one weekend in their new vacation house near the Chesapeake Bay before Hurricane Isabel came barreling up the East Coast last week. So when the storm hit, the couple could do little more than sit at home in Lexington, Va., watch the Weather Channel and worry. ''We were thinking we were going to lose the whole house,'' said Ms. Moohr, a professor at Washington and Lee University's law school.

title: With Just a Few Months to Live, A Lifetime of Changes to Make
description: In the venerable Hollywood weepie ''Love Story'' -- or at least in the Mad magazine parody of it -- Ali McGraw suffered from a fatal disease that made her more beautiful as it progressed. Judging from ''My Life Without Me,'' a new indie weepie that opens today in New York and Los Angeles, three decades of medical progress have failed to wipe out this terrible, mysterious malady. Sarah Polley, the pale, radiant young Canadian actress who has also starred in Atom Egoyan's ''Sweet Hereafter'' and ''Exotica'' and Hal Hartley's ''No Such Thing,'' grows simultaneously paler and more radiant as her character grows sicker. This bolsters two of the film's principal conceits, which might otherwise be a little shaky: that dying is a voyage of self-fulfillment, and that terminal illness can and should be kept secret until the last minute.

title: 30 Years And a Cloud Of Dust
description: Age 30 can be both full of promise and frustrating. Some days, you feel like your own boss, unmoved by society's whims, free to choose, to breathe, to be. Other days, you wake up and your back hurts.

title: McCall to Quit Stock Exchange After Pay Furor
description: H. Carl McCall, the politician who vowed to change an ossified New York Stock Exchange but found himself defending the $139.5 million pay of its chairman, resigned from the exchange's board yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP: DISGRACED MARSHAL FOUND DEAD A disgraced deputy United States marshal, under house arrest since his conviction in July for embezzling from the government, died after being found unconscious on Wednesday. The marshal, Dominick Russo, left, had been suspended from duty and was scheduled for a sentencing hearing Oct. 30. Mr. Russo, 42, showed no signs of injury, bruises or other signs of foul play when he was found, the Brick Township Police said. His death has not been listed as a suicide, and an autopsy is scheduled for today. Mr. Russo had scheduled a meeting with his lawyer, Stephen Turano, yesterday and planned to appeal his conviction. He faced five to six years in prison for embezzling from the United States Marshal's Asset Forfeiture Unit, which he directed.

title: Aquino's daughter accuses boyfriend of abuse
description: MANILA:  In a riveting display of rage and self-flagellation, a popular television host and daughter of a martyred politician has appeared on national television alleging that her womanizing lover beat her up, aimed a gun at her during a fight and infected her with a sexually transmitted disease.

Daley of Chicago were indicted on fraud charges accusing them of getting more than $100 million in city contracts through schemes like passing off male-controlled businesses as owned by women. The two  James Duff, 45, of Burr Ridge and his mother, Patricia Green Duff, 75, of Chicago  were among seven charged with fraud and other counts. (AP)

title: Who's Poor? Don't Ask the Census Bureau
description: Today the Census Bureau will release the official poverty rate for 2002. While that figure is likely to indicate that the ranks of the poor have increased, it unfortunately won't really tell us much of anything about the true extent of poverty in America.

title: The Blues: A History, A Homage
description: ''THIS is the one thing they could never take away from black people,'' says the dreadlocked blues performer Corey Harris in ''Feel Like Going Home,'' the Martin Scorsese documentary that on Sunday night begins the seven-part PBS series ''The Blues.'' Mr. Scorsese, who is also the series' executive producer, opens his film with a very sexy double-bass-drums and fife trio pounding and trilling out counterrhythms that challenge the de rigueur imagery of distended-chord guitar playing. This scene connects the blues solidly to Africa and America in a way that will be new to many.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Avon To Build Plant
description: Avon Products Inc. said it would spend $40 million to build a factory near Moscow to supply its Russian business. The plant, in Narofominsk, will employ more than 800 people and manufacture makeup, skin-care products, fragrances and deodorants, Avon said. It is Avon, which isbased in New York, said it forecast sales in Russia would more than triple to $500 million in 2007 from $142 million in 2002.

title: In Reversal, Brazil Will Permit a Gene-Modified Crop
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 26 — After several days of high-level waffling, Brazil's left-leaning government, a bastion of global opposition to genetically modified foodstuffs, has abandoned a campaign pledge and decided to allow Brazilian farmers to grow genetically modified soybeans.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: AID WORKERS DIE IN AMBUSH Two Afghan aid workers were ambushed and killed on a main highway in southern Afghanistan by suspected Taliban, the local police said. Gunmen opened fire on their vehicle in an attack on the main road in Helmand Province, west of Kandahar, killing a chief engineer for the Afghan organization VARA, the Voluntary Association for the Rehabilitation of Afghanistan. His driver, also shot, died later in a hospital. The police arrested some suspects who were almost certainly Taliban members, a police official said. More than 30 people have been killed in similar attacks this month, including four aid workers pulled from their car and shot two weeks ago. Attacks on aid workers have sharply increased over the last year, to once every two days from once a month, according to the relief agency CARE.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)

Baseball runs the Expos, and the labor agreement requires the players' approval to move games.

The few voters who could spare two hours in late afternoon to find the debate on television saw little internecine savaging. Less sensational and more substantive, the event was steeped in the nation's record budget deficits, persistent unemployment, uncertain recovery and costly adventure in Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Watertown: Teacher Quits After Indecency Arrest
description: A Watertown High School teacher has resigned after being caught in a child sex sting, the police said. The teacher, David G. Simonin, 53, was arrested in New York on Aug. 20 as he strolled through Washington Square Park expecting to meet a 14-year-old boy with whom he had exchanged e-mail messages for two weeks, the police said. Instead, Mr. Simonin met a New York City undercover detective and was arrested. Mr. Simonin, who had taught mathematics since last December, was charged with disseminating indecent materials to minors, attempted sodomy and attempting to endanger the welfare of a child. The police said that the investigation was continuing. Stacy Stowe (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rikers Warden Demoted
description: A Rikers Island warden, Roger Slattery, 47, was demoted this week for not properly responding to a recent emergency, officials of the city and the deputy wardens' union said. Commissioner Martin F. Horn demoted Mr. Slattery, who has been the warden of the George R. Vierno Center since 1999, to deputy warden on Tuesday, union officials said. Sidney Schwartzbaum, the union president, called Mr. Slattery's punishment shocking and unfair. A spokesman for Mr. Horn declined to comment. Union officials said that Mr. Horn was punishing Mr. Slattery, a 19-year Correction Department veteran, for not taking charge of a weekend incident in late August in which a sewage backup and a 24-hour water disruption at the jail led to a confrontation between correction officers and angry inmates. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Billing Concepts To Act As Customer Clearinghouse

Currently, users typically receive two bills, one from their Internet service provider and another from their Wi-Fi provider. Paul Buehler, director of development at Billing Concepts, said yesterday that the company was working with Internet service providers as well as the Wi-Fi companies, but has not finalized any deals yet. ''We're basically facilitating the communication,'' he said, adding that the company, based in San Antonio, has provided similar services in the telephone industry.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: BERKELEY CHANCELLOR LEAVING The chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, Robert M. Berdahl, announced he would step down in June after seven years. Dr. Berdahl, an expert in German history, plans to take a yearlong leave and then return to teach. Dr. Berdahl, 66, became chancellor in July 1997 and has worked to increase minority enrollment on campus. He took over just after the University of California system dropped affirmative action in admissions, a move that led to a 61 percent decrease in blacks, Hispanics and American Indians admitted to Berkeley in the fall of 1998. Although enrollment figures have rebounded, they are not at pre-1998 levels. (AP)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Lays Off 400 In Software Business
description: I.B.M. laid off about 400 marketing and administrative workers in its software business to reduce costs, a spokesman, Tim Breuer, said yesterday. The employees were notified Wednesday and represented about 1 percent of the 38,000 workers in I.B.M.'s software division, Mr. Breuer said. They will be able to apply for other I.B.M. jobs, he added. I.B.M. has been seeking cost cuts amid a slowdown in corporate spending on software, computers and related services. Last month, the company said it would lay off 600 workers in its chip-making business and would furlough another 3,000. Shares of I.B.M. rose 1 cent, to $89.41.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACCABE, MARGARET I.
description: MacCABE--Margaret I. Windsor ''Molly'', age 93, of New Canaan and Rowayton, CT, died August 9, 2003, at Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT. ''Molly'' came to the U.S. from Croydon, England, in 1936 when her work on the coronation of Edward VI was curtailed by his abdication. At the outbreak of war, she joined the WREN's (U.K. Navy), working in Boston, Washington and New York. In 1946 she joined the original staff of the U.N. ''The Mohigans'', in the transportation department. At the U.N., she met her husband, Joseph W. MacCabe, who, after working in Palestine in 1947 and 1948, went on to a career as a UNDP staff member. She left the U.N. in 1951 to be mother to her only son, Alistair, and the family moved to Connecticut. Always engaged, in 1965 she launched a new career in real estate and promptly opened her own firm as one of the first successful women-owned businesses. After 25 years and many accomplishments, she sold the business. Widowed in 1992, her final years were spent pursuing her lifelong passion for photography, photos taken all over the world, and winning numerous amateur awards. At age 89, she had her own one-person show. Over the years her generous support of community and charitable activities from gardening to the symphony evidenced her belief that to be global citizens we must be manifest in our local community life. She is survived by her son, Alistair W.W. MacCabe of San Diego, CA, and her sister, Daphne Chotteau of Brussels, Belgium. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Darien, CT, on September 27, 2003, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations are welcomed to Darien Book Aid Plan, Inc., 1926 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820, or UNICEF, 3 U.N. Plaza, New York, NY 10017.

More than 30 people have been killed in similar attacks this month, including four aid workers pulled from their car and shot two weeks ago. title: South Africa Study Says Race Is Not Behind Attacks on Farmers
description: A long-awaited report from South Africa's national police agency concluded today that crime, not racial hatred, was to blame for almost all the attacks on rural farms that have led to the murder of some 1,500 white farmers since 1991.

title: Solectron Loss Narrows
description: The Solectron Corporation, a maker of electronics for other companies, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed sharply as acquisition costs plunged.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Money Needed Quickly For Vaccine
description: The World Health Organization said it was running out of time to raise money for a vaccine to protect people from a vicious new form of meningitis in the so-called meningitis belt that stretches from Senegal to Ethiopia. The agency said $9 million was needed within two weeks to produce enough vaccine before the onset of the meningitis season. GlaxoSmithKline rushed to make a vaccine and is offering it at $1 a dose, which the company says is a quarter of the cost. The W.H.O. is trying to build a stockpile. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Mineshaft Alone at Top And Still Getting Better
description: Should Mineshaft be named Horse of the Year -- a possibility growing more likely with each race -- he will have earned the title not just because he is talented, but also because he has survived a long campaign of racing while so many others have not.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Acterna Set To Leave Bankruptcy
description: The Acterna Corporation, a maker of fiber optic network test equipment, won a bankruptcy judge's approval for its reorganization plan yesterday and said that it would leave court protection within 10 days. The company, with $1.13 billion in sales last year and a $374.8 million loss, filed for Chapter 11 in May in Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York after defaulting on a $680 million bank loan. The company, based in Germantown, Md., has laid off about 1,300 of almost 5,000 workers since last year as losses mounted because clients like Lucent Technologies Inc. and Alcatel slashed spending. ''Acterna is ready to move forward as a re-energized company with a stronger balance sheet,'' said John R. Peeler, the chief executive, in a statement. Acterna said last month that the recovery plan would give senior lenders about 41 percent of their claims, including all the company's new common stock and $75 million in 12 percent secured notes maturing in five years. Unsecured creditors will get about 10 percent of their claims and common stockholders will receive nothing.

title: Some Twists in the Old-New Basketmaker's Art
description: For countless generations of Native Americans, there was nothing quite so useful as a basket. Woven by hand, of course, from carefully cultivated roots and plants, a basket could be a baby carrier, a saddlebag, a purse, a bowl for cooking or serving, a tray, a jar, a water bottle, a fish trap, a trunk, a seed scoop, a hat and even a coffin.

title: Shopping List | Hiking Gear
description: AUTUMN has officially arrived: the leaves are turning, the weather's pleasantly cool, the sun is out. In short, perfect hiking weather. So get out while it's still good, and gear up with some top-of-the-line picks to keep comfortable and stylish from head to toe. BONNIE TSUI

title: U.N. Chief Orders Further Reduction of Staff in Baghdad
description: Making a strong statement about the magnitude of security problems in Iraq, Secretary General Kofi Annan decided today to remove most of the United Nations' remaining 86 foreign staff members there.

title: Former Ad Executive Charged With Fraud
description: Thomas Sebastian, a former chief financial officer of L90, an Internet advertising company, was accused yesterday of using fraudulent advertising deals to inflate L90's revenue.

title: Management Shuffle at Nokia, With Perhaps More on Way
description: LONDON, Sept. 26  As it struggles for growth in the no-holds-barred mobile phone market, Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest cellphone manufacturer, announced changes in its top management today, spurring speculation that it may be preparing to change its chief executive.

title: Kodak to Stress Digital Business And Cut Dividend
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, officially acknowledging that the era of soaring sales and gushing profits from film is gone, said yesterday that it would concentrate on bolstering its digital businesses and would cut its dividend by more than two-thirds to finance the effort.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the fossil skeleton of a giant rodent in Venezuela misstated the number of living species of rodents. It is about 2,000, not 2,600. The article also misidentified the habitat of a giant extinct beaver. It was North America, not South America.

title: Bush Prods Lawmakers to Step Up Pace of Medicare Talks
description: President Bush intervened in talks on a Medicare drug bill today, trying to galvanize negotiations that have been slowed by deep disagreements between Republicans from the House and those from the Senate.

title: Formula One:a way of fine-tuning an image
description: MOGYOROD, Hungary  The first time the hills outside this village northeast of Budapest echoed with the roar of the world's fastest racing cars, Soviet tanks were parked on the crests, soldiers with Kalashnikovs walked the streets and the wealthier locals drove to the race in tin-can-like Trabant cars.

title: Number of People Living in Poverty in U.S. Increases Again
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 — The Census Bureau reported today that the number of Americans living in poverty jumped by 1.7 million people last year, the second year in a row the number has increased, and that median household income declined.

title: Martin Luther's Passion, Still Resonating Today
description: Although ''Luther,'' Eric Till's teeming screen biography of Martin Luther doesn't strain to make parallels between the 16th century and the present, the comparisons between then and now are obvious. The handsome, fact-filled historical epic, in which a fiery-eyed Joseph Fiennes portrays the father of the Reformation, depicts the events that gave birth to Protestantism as a life-and-death political struggle between a corrupt, repressive, intransigently conservative establishment (the Roman Catholic Church) and a liberal populist movement that spins out of control and wreaks havoc.

description: Most of the people at the center of corporate scandals have played a cat-and-mouse game with investigators, laying low and trying to keep their assets out of the limelight. But not Richard M. Scrushy, a founder and the former chief executive of HealthSouth, the nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals and surgery centers.

title: Edward W. Said, Literary Critic and Advocate for Palestinian Independence, Dies at 67
description: Edward W. Said, a polymath scholar and literary critic at Columbia University who was the most prominent advocate in the United States of the cause of Palestinian independence, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: Swimming the Salmon Back Home
description: ON an overcast afternoon, eight snorkel divers and two guides -- all of us encased in snug, full-body wet suits -- gathered under a logging bridge on Vancouver Island in British Columbia and waded into the fast-rushing Campbell River. We took a few moments to acclimatize in the shallows, hyperventilating a little as the glacier-born river flooded our suits.

title: Good Design, As the Modern Conceives It
description: ''What is modern design?'' is a question the Museum of Modern Art has been asking itself for 75 years. For the museum's curators, a modern design must have an idea behind it as well as functionality and beauty. That idea might include rethinking found objects, using new materials in unexpected ways or infusing functional objects with emotion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZWERLING, GERTRUDE R.
description: ZWERLING--Gertrude R. Of Stamford, CT, died peacefully on Thursday, September 25, 2003. Mrs. Zwerling was born on September 18, 1907 in New York City. She is survived by her daughters, Louise Orkin and Alice Kaplan, by her son, Steven Drucker, and by eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. She was blessed with a rich and rewarding life. A graveside Funeral Service will be held on Monday, September 29, 2003 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY at 11:30am. Donations may be made in her memory to Ziv Tzedakah Fund, 384 Wyoming Ave, Millburn, NJ, 07041.

description: A former partner with Ernst & Young was arrested yesterday and charged with obstructing a federal investigation of one of his clients by altering and destroying documents that were relevant to the inquiry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sale Of G.M. Building Completed
description: The developer Harry Macklowe yesterday completed his record-breaking $1.4 billion purchase of the General Motors Building, the white marble skyscraper on Fifth Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets. He outmaneuvered more than two dozen rival bidders. The sale -- at the highest price ever paid for a single office tower in the United States -- completes a three-year struggle to sell the 50-story tower, best known as the home of the flagship store of F.A.O Schwarz. This week, the Chancery Court in Delaware rejected a request from a rival bidder, Sheldon H. Solow, to block the sale. Mr. Solow, who also bid $1.4 billion, claimed that the seller, Conseco, and its broker had acted unfairly in awarding the deal to Mr. Macklowe. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Debates, Coast to Coast; California Shouts and Murmurs
description: The ultimate question left unanswered in the freewheeling debate on Wednesday night in the California recall election was exactly why this was necessary in the first place. Based on the candidates' performances, the recall seems less part of the solution to the problems of California, the nation's most populous state, than a bread-and-circus distraction from them. The tattered record of Gov. Gray Davis is at stake. Yet he was not even invited to the debate, despite the sponsoring broadcasters' boasts about a ''controversial'' format, which favored the cross-talk bickering of cable shows. Most of the sniping one-liners seemed like rehearsed retreads as candidates worked to establish stage personalities instead of governing agendas.

description: One of Africa's longest-running and deadliest wars took a major turn toward peace today as the government of Sudan agreed to withdraw most of its troops from the rebel-held south of the country and begin integrating its soldiers with those of the rebels in a unified army.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility Acquisition Canceled
description: A British utility, Scottish and Southern Energy, abandoned its acquisition of Midlands Electricity from Aquila Inc. after bondholders turned down the offer. They were not prepared to accept 86 percent of face value for their bonds, Scottish and Southern said. The company, which is based in Perth, Scotland, agreed in May to assume almost 1.1 billion ($1.8 billion) in debt and pay 43 million ($71 million) in cash to acquire Midlands. The end of the agreement leaves Aquila and a partner, the First Energy Corporation of Akron, Ohio, without a buyer for the unit.

title: Yet Again, Shoreham Seeks to Keep a Plant Away
description: Fourteen years after opposition stopped the opening of a $6.5 billion nuclear power plant here, local groups are fighting the possibility of a giant incinerator and electricity generator that could burn 1.5 million tons of trash annually, some of it brought by barge from New York City.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: TESTING THE WATERS The Queen Mary 2, the biggest passenger ship ever built, left the port of Saint-Nazairet for the first time for a series of tests ahead of its maiden trans-Atlantic voyage. Thousands of spectators applauded as the liner, the first Cunard ship assembled outside Britain, left for a weekend trial run. The $800 million liner stretches the length of four football fields and stands as high as a 23-story building. The QM2 is to make its first trip from Southampton, England, to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Jan. 12. That voyage is already booked by passengers who paid from $3,500 for a cabin without a view to $47,000 for a duplex.   (Agence France-Presse)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Brick Township: Disgraced Marshal Found Dead
description: A disgraced deputy United States marshal, under house arrest since his conviction in July for embezzling from the government, died after being found unconscious on Wednesday. The marshal, Dominick Russo, left, had been suspended from duty and was scheduled for a sentencing hearing Oct. 30. Mr. Russo, 42, showed no signs of injury, bruises or other signs of foul play when he was found, the Brick Township Police said. His death has not been listed as a suicide, and an autopsy is scheduled for today. Mr. Russo had scheduled a meeting with his lawyer, Stephen Turano, yesterday and planned to appeal his conviction. He faced five to six years in prison for embezzling from the United States Marshal's Asset Forfeiture Unit, which he directed.

title: Sports of The Times; For Clarett, How Early Equals How Much
description: THE best-known player in college football isn't playing football, but he is in college. Maurice Clarett, the suspended sophomore running back who is going to court for the right to be battered by the behemoths of the National Football League next season, is also going to classes at Ohio State. His major there? Family resource management. One of his courses? Financial planning.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retail Expansion
description: Germany's largest department store operator, KarstadtQuelle, said yesterday that it planned to double mail-order sales in Eastern Europe in the next five years. The company, based in Essen, said it would expand in Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Montenegro, Serbia, Slovakia and Slovenia, aiming for $207 million in sales this year. KarstadtQuelle will also enter markets in Latvia, Lithuania, Romania and Ukraine.

title: FORMER TRIANGLE EXECUTIVE IS NAMED CHIEF OF INTERMUNE
description: InterMune, which makes medicines to bolster the immune system, said yesterday that its board had named a former chief of Triangle Pharmaceuticals, Daniel G. Welch, as its chief executive and president. Mr. Welch succeeds the interim chief, William R. Ringo, who will remain chairman, the company said. The founder, Scott Harkonen, who was once chairman, chief executive and president, is leaving the board and will become a consultant to the company. Mr. Welch was chairman and chief executive of Triangle, a maker of H.I.V. treatments, before its acquisition by Gilead Sciences in January.

description: HENLINE--Darrell. Cabaret and its music have lost one of their greatest champions with the passing of Darrell Henline, founder, publisher and editor-in-chief of Cabaret Scenes magazine. We will miss his passion for the highest standards of the art, and his warm devotion to cabaret and its community. Manhattan Association of Cabarets & Clubs (MAC)

title: For Music Industry, U.S. Is Only the Tip Of a Piracy Iceberg
description: Hang around any schoolyard in Germany or college campus in Indonesia and it becomes clear that the recording industry's problems with the illegal online distribution of music in the United States pale beside the rampant piracy that goes on overseas.

title: 36 Hours | Coral Gables, Fla.
description: THE staid and the silly have always existed side by side in Coral Gables, an exclusive enclave (so exclusive that residents are prohibited from parking pickup trucks in their own driveways) surrounded by Miami, as one glimpse of the eight eye-popping pagodas in the Chinese Village will attest. They and other ''international villages'' -- small housing developments -- were planned by George Merrick, the founder of Coral Gables, to offer architectural diversity in the otherwise Spanish Mediterranean-style town. When William Jennings Bryan, the three-time Democratic nominee for president, was hired to promote the brand-new town in the early 1920's, he proclaimed, ''You can wake up in the morning and tell the biggest lie you can think of about the future of Coral Gables, and before you go to bed at night you will be ashamed of your modesty.'' The latest residents to buy into the undeniable charisma of the place are members of the affluent YUCA population, the local acronym for Young Urban Cuban Americans, who have helped to create the economic miracle referred to in the name Miracle Mile, a centrally located shopping street. Coral Gables today retains some of the most striking architectural and natural sights in Miami-Dade County, but it also has some of its most luxurious hotels and shops, and, many food critics agree, better restaurants than South Beach. It all adds up to a super, if relatively sedate, tropical trip. PAMELA ROBIN BRANDT

title: Fancy Goods a Tougher Sell in Japan
description: To Natsuko Namba, $500 leather handbags are for suckers. Sure, they are well made, stylish and popular with the in-crowds in Tokyo's more trend-conscious neighborhoods. But at the end of the day, Ms. Namba, a 30-year-old office worker, says the bags have become a clich for those who, at least for a day or two, want to feel wealthy.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Attack On Holocaust Panel Chief
description: The insurance commissioner of California, John Garamendi, joined several Holocaust survivors in calling for former Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger to resign as chairman of the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims, created to help Holocaust victims. The survivors urged the resignation after filing a lawsuit accusing the commission of bias. Mr. Garamendi, one of three American regulators on the commission, said, ''When the team does not perform you change the coach.'' Anais O. Haase, Mr. Eagleburger's aide, said he had ''no intention of resigning.'' Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Long Island Nursing Home Accused of Ignoring Complaints About Mold
description: A former employee of the A. Holly Patterson Extended Care Facility accused the nursing home today of ignoring reports that mold growths in the basement had made him and other employees sick, and one man blamed the mold for his wife's death.

title: State to Give Liver Donors Safeguards In Transplants
description: The State Health Department has proposed new rules for live liver transplants, including a requirement that all living donors be assigned a team of advisers to help them decide whether the operation should go forward.

description: The player, ordered to his feet by the longtime referee Dick Bavetta, stood up like a timid first-grader in an auditorium packed with his schoolmates.

title: Emotion Without Flourishes
description: An entertainer with a voice as heroic as that of the popular tenor Ronan Tynan really doesn't have to do much to please an audience except sing. In the case of Mr. Tynan, that also means finding a judicious mix of sentimental warhorses and Irish pop songs and flavoring the mix with a pinch of opera.

title: An Irksome Neighbor, Inspiring Fantasies
description: Religious tradition enjoins us to love our neighbor, no doubt because somebody thought we needed reminding. This may be especially true of New Yorkers, who mostly live stacked up and shoved together in too-small spaces that cost too much money. Our natural neighborly impulses tend toward envy, annoyance and, when the walls are thin, the hour late and the television loud, murderous rage. These base, recognizable instincts are the foundation of Danny DeVito's ''Duplex,'' a refreshingly mean-spirited gothic real estate comedy that opens nationwide today.

title: Red Sox Thrill Fans by Blasting Way to Wild Card
description: In few places do the undulations of momentum so inherent to a baseball season inspire such volatile swings of emotion as in New England. Red Sox fans, tormented by the team's tortured history of autumn free falls, temper the joys of summer by always fretting about the worst.

title: No Penalties Due for G.I.'s For Killings
description: American soldiers will probably face no penalties for two recent incidents in Iraq in which they killed at least a dozen people who apparently offered little or no resistance, Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, the commander of allied forces in Iraq, said at a news conference here today.

title: After a Storm, Is My House O.K.?

title: TUPPERWARE REVISES PROFIT FORECAST; SHARES FALL 15%
description: Tupperware, the direct seller of plastic food-storage containers, forecast a third-quarter loss and a decline in annual profit as a result of falling sales in the United States, setting off a 15 percent decline in its share price. The third-quarter loss will be 2 cents to 3 cents a share, the company said late Wednesday. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected Tupperware to earn 7 cents a share. Sales in the United States will fall 30 percent this year because the sales force has shrunk and demand may not rebound until the second half of 2004, Tupperware said. Stock in Tupperware fell $2.53 yesterday, to $13.81 a share.

title: Choosing Athletes Over Students
description: Swarthmore College is known more for classics studies than athletics. Its football team once lost 28 straight games. But when Swarthmore scrapped its football program, it did so not because of its record. The problem was that too many places at the 1,400-student college were set aside for athletes. Swarthmore feared that building a competitive football team would make it necessary to turn away too many would-be scholars in fields like humanities.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Meat Concern Acquired
description: The Canadian meat processor Maple Leaf Foods Inc. has agreed to buy the Canadian food processing business of Smithfield Foods Inc. for $378 million. The deal is for the Smithfield unit Schneider Corporation, which had sales of $770 million in its 2003 fiscal year. title: The Failure to Find Iraqi Weapons
description: This page did not support the war in Iraq, but it never quarreled with one of its basic premises. Like President Bush, we believed that Saddam Hussein was hiding potentially large quantities of chemical and biological weapons and aggressively pursuing nuclear arms. Like the president, we thought those weapons posed a grave danger to the United States and the rest of the world. Now it appears that premise was wrong. We cannot in hindsight blame the administration for its original conclusions. They were based on the best intelligence available, which had led the Clinton administration before it and the governments of allied nations to reach the same conclusion. But even the best intelligence can turn out to be mistaken, and the likelihood that this was the case in Iraq shows why pre-emptive war, the Bush administration's strategy since 9/11, is so ill conceived as a foundation for security policy. If intelligence and risk assessment are sketchy -- and when are they not? -- using them as the basis for pre-emptive war poses enormous dangers.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: TUNDRA BUYS PRODUCT LINE FROM MOTOROLA Shares in the Tundra Semiconductor Corporation surged yesterday after it agreed to buy the PowerPC Host Bridge product line from Motorola Inc. for $20 million. Tundra said that it would immediately market the line, which is typically used in Internet and telecommunications work, as the Tundra Tsi106 and Tundra Tsi107 PowerPC Host Bridges. At the same time, Tundra, based in Ottawa, announced that it had signed a multimillion-dollar agreement with Motorola to develop the next generation PowerPC host bridge technology. Tundra said the new product line would increase Tundra's revenues by 35 percent to 40 percent in the second quarter from the first quarter. It expected second-quarter pro forma earnings to rise to a range of 9 to 10 Canadian cents a share (about 7 cents). Tundra had already raised its second-quarter sales forecast, saying last week that orders for its products have increased across the board. On Sept. 17, Tundra said second-quarter sales would rise 30 percent over the first quarter. It also said it expected pro forma earnings a share to be about 8 Canadian cents to 9 Canadian cents, up from 4 Canadian cents in the first quarter. Shares closed up 1.41 Canadian dollars, or 8 percent, at 19.01 Canadian dollars.    (Reuters)

When last spotted, he was turning out highly imaginative Asian-influenced cuisine at Mi, a restaurant that looked like a glorified sushi diner. He disappeared as mysteriously as he had arrived. Now, almost two years later, he resurfaces at the Biltmore Room, an elegant outsider on a scruffy block.

description: The differences between renderings and the buildings they depict casts highlight a little-discussed facet of real-estate and architectural development.

title: Hiking Gear
description:
By BONNIE TSUI
Autumn is perfect hiking weather. Gear up with some top-of-the-line picks to keep comfortable and stylish from head to toe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, HERBERT IRA
description: ROSENTHAL--Herbert Ira. On September 26, 2003 in Palm Beach, FL, age 92. Beloved husband of Shirley Kate for 63 years. Devoted father of Judith (deceased) and Audrey Goodman (Sheldon). Loving grandfather of Victoria (Jonas). He led a successful and exciting life as an executive of MCA. His generosity of spirit was recognized by all who knew him. His kindness and humor will be remembered forever.

title: Gunman Kills Two as Family Celebrates Jewish New Year
description: A Palestinian gunman killed two people, one of them a baby girl, and wounded two more when he opened fire tonight on an Israeli family celebrating the Jewish New Year at their home in a settlement outside the West Bank town of Hebron. Israeli troops rushed to the scene and fatally shot the attacker.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bids For Bank
description: South Korea's largest lender, Kookmin Bank, and the United Overseas Bank of Singapore have bid to buy Bank Internasional Indonesia, aiming to expand in Indonesia as an economic slump crimps profits in their home markets. Kookmin Bank joined Asia Financial Holdings, a Singapore fund, in a consortium called Sorak Financial Holdings. United Overseas, Singapore's second-largest lender, made a separate bid. Panin Bank of Indonesia is part of a third group bidding for Bank Internasional, said the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency. At stake is a lender that was formerly part of the Sinar Mas Group, owned by Eka Tjipta Widjaja's family. The bank was taken over and bailed out by the government in 2001, three years after the Asian financial crisis.

title: Studio Anti-Piracy Drive Could Alter Oscar Race
description: The race for this year's Academy Awards has been thrown off stride by a move by the major Hollywood studios to curb movie piracy. The studios hope to halt the distribution of thousands of DVD and VHS copies of Oscar-contending films to those whose votes decide the winners.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN TO OFFER INCENTIVES TO QUIT
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation will offer salaried employees with at least two years at the company incentives to quit in a bid to control labor costs. The severance program includes three weeks' pay per year of service and a year of paid health-care benefits. Employees who accept the offer will leave the company by Oct. 31 in most cases, said Susan Terpay, a spokeswoman for the company. Wage and benefit costs rose 4 percent at Norfolk Southern in the first half of this year. The company last offered managers incentives to leave the company in 2000, Ms. Terpay said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the stabbings of two brothers on a No. 2 subway train in the Bronx misstated the details of a reward poster posted in a station booth. It showed a victim of an earlier stabbing on a Bronx subway platform; it was not about the attack on the brothers.

title: 21 Pianos (Skimpy It Wasn't)
description: The Winter Garden at the World Financial Center is undoubtedly one of the few spaces in which an ensemble of 21 pianos could almost seem lost in the surroundings. On Thursday night, for the finale of the ''88 Keys'' piano festival, the stage was set up like a three-tier wedding cake, the pianos arrayed in semicircles on the two lower tiers and the conductor, Antonio Ballista, at the top.

title: Executive Resigns at British Internet Bank
description: Egg, the worst performing British banking stock this year, said its chief financial officer, Stacey Cartwright, had resigned after four years at the bank.

title: Attack of the Telemarketers
description: More than 50 million Americans have signed up for the federal ''do not call'' registry to protect themselves from phone solicitations. Rather than let these people eat dinner in peace, the telemarketing industry rushed into court. It persuaded two federal judges this week to strike down the registry. These decisions are as legally flawed as they are unpopular. They should be reversed on appeal, and the ''do not call'' registry should go forward.

title: Freshman Representatives Get Involved in Another Election: The Big One
description: As a freshman member of Congress, Ral M. Grijalva has little experience in presidential politics. But on a balmy night in early September, Representative Grijalva, a Tucson Democrat, boarded a sleek campaign bus and rode to the University of Maryland to appear before hundreds of screaming college students alongside the man he hopes will win the White House: Howard Dean.

title: 3 at Hamilton Bancorp Charged With Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged three Hamilton Bancorp Inc. officers with securities fraud on Thursday, saying they hid ''tremendous losses'' at the company's Hamilton Bank unit before bank regulators shut it down last year.

title: Son's Wish to Die, And Mother's Help, Stir French Debate
description: ''I Ask the Right to Die,'' written by Vincent Humbert, a 22-year-old French paraplegic, hit bookstores here on Thursday. Today he died, two days after his mother put an overdose of sedatives into his intravenous line.

title: U.S., Russia And Europe Meet at U.N. On Mideast
description: The United States joined senior envoys from the United Nations, the European Union and Russia today to try to salvage the deteriorating situation in the Middle East. They plan renewed appeals to the Palestinians to stop suicide bombings and other attacks, and to Israel to exercise restraint in cracking down on terrorist groups.

title: With Issues to Resolve, Bush Welcomes Putin to Camp David
description: President Bush welcomed President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to Camp David today for another meeting intended to show the two as problem-solvers who work best in informal settings, even as they appear still divided on Iraq and on Russia's continued insistence that its sales of nuclear technology to Iran are benign.

title: After a Jab From Sharpton, Mayor Jests Back
description: Did anyone say Michael R. Bloomberg for vice president?

title: Restaurant Is Ordered to Pay Ex-Waitresses $3.4 Million
description: A Federal District Court judge in Newark has ordered the owners of a Chinese restaurant in northern New Jersey to pay nearly $3.4 million to two former waitresses who claimed that they had been deprived of wages and tips, forced to work long hours and housed in a substandard and crowded apartment.

title: Receiver Makes Himself Right at Home at U.S.C.
description: Mike Williams never met his father. His mother has not been a part of his life since he was 11 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MODIGLIANI, FRANCO
description: MODIGLIANI--Franco. The administration, advisors, scholars and staff of The Levy Economics Institute of Bard College mourn the passing of Franco Modigliani, whose unparalleled brilliance in economic theory will forever work to advance and enrich the discipline. The Levy Institute was privileged to have him serve for many years on our Board of Advisors, where his wisdom, insight, and guidance proved invaluable. He will be sorely missed. Dimitri B. Papadimitriou, President The Levy Economics Institute of Bard College

title: Loss as the Fuel for Emotional Power
description: As the senior member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, Patrick Corbin is a fabulous dancer. He moves with quicksilver wit, technical brilliance and crystalline clarity.

title: Behind Makeover of Schools, A Bookish 'Kid From Queens'
description: Joel I. Klein is leaning back in a sleek leather chair in a meeting room that he often commandeers for private conversations at the city's Department of Education headquarters, reflecting on the unlikely course of his life.

title: For Unleashing 'Hulk' Online, Fines and 3 Years of Probation
description: A New Jersey man who released a bootleg version of the movie ''The Hulk'' on the Internet before it opened in theaters, violating copyright law and costing Universal Pictures what it estimated to be millions of dollars in lost ticket sales, was sentenced yesterday to probation and ordered to pay fines and restitution.

title: Mortar Shell Kills at Least 7 Iraqis Near U.S. Position
description: A mortar shell crashed down in the cool of early evening here on Thursday, killing at least seven Iraqis -- a peddler chatting with his brother, the owners of the local computer store, a pair of sheep sellers from the north -- in a town square. At least 20 people were wounded.

title: Science Journals Tighten Rules For Disclosure of Financial Ties
description: The editors of an influential group of scientific journals said yesterday that they were greatly expanding their policy requiring contributors to disclose financial ties to products or companies that could benefit from the articles they write.

title: CONE MILLS ADVANCES ITS PLAN FOR REORGANIZATION
description: The Cone Mills Corporation, the world's largest denim maker, won interim court permission to finance its bankruptcy reorganization by selling as much as $35 million in uncollected bills to the GE Capital Corporation. Cone Mills will also sell as much as $15 million in inventory in the next two weeks, as part of the bankruptcy reorganization intended to clear the way for a $90 million buyout by Wilbur Ross's W L Ross & Company, lawyers said at a court hearing yesterday in Wilmington, Del. Judge Mary Walrath scheduled a hearing on Oct. 10 to consider extending the bankruptcy financing beyond that date.

title: Same Old Law Firm, New Snake
description: Financial hardship has its rewards. When peasants had to eat stale bread, they turned it into French toast. Forced to spend less, the Anaheim Angels figured out a strategy to beat the profligate New York Yankees last fall.

title: Sports of The Times; Johnson Can Learn From Coach
description: NEW YORK has often been the scene of ego clashes between team owner and head coach, and this week the Jets' normally reticent owner, Woody Johnson, and his upbeat coach, Herman Edwards, found themselves in a public disagreement.

title: Allegheny Energy Outlines Efforts to Avoid Bankruptcy
description: Allegheny Energy, an important supplier of electricity and natural gas service in five states, said yesterday that it was considering several measures to stave off a bankruptcy protection filing, including a purge of its accounting department and the possible sale of additional assets to raise badly needed cash.

title: Beliefs; 'Search your deeds' is no call to punishment; it's an invitation to re-energize your life.
description: ''Awake, O sleepers, awake from your sleep! O slumberers, awake from your slumbers! Search your deeds, repent and remember your Creator.''

title: Chicken Littles and Ostriches at NASA
description: One hears lots of talk these days about the need to change the culture, habits and attitudes of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to head off any repeat of the disaster that destroyed the space shuttle Columbia. The urgency of that task becomes inescapably clear when one ponders the trials of Rodney Rocha, an obscure engineer who tried repeatedly, and in vain, to warn shuttle managers of a potential catastrophe, only to be rebuffed and ultimately pounded into acquiescing with the prevailing view that all was well.

title: 3-Year Deal Ends a Strike By the Faculty At C.W. Post
description: The 19-day faculty members' strike at C. W. Post College in Brookville, N.Y., ended yesterday as union members unanimously ratified a three-year contract and prepared to return to their classrooms on Monday.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Polluters Pay $40 Million
description: Viacom, an affiliate of Comcast and Horsehead Industries will pay $40 million to the Superfund to clean up a toxic waste site in Palmerton, 15 miles from Allentown, the Justice Department said. Corporate predecessors of Viacom and the affiliate, TCI Pacific, were responsible for the contamination caused by zinc refining and smelting since 1898. Horsehead Industries and Horsehead Resource Development have recycled zinc there since 1981.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Growth Forecast Upgraded
description: The Japanese government has raised its forecast for economic growth in the fiscal year that ends in March 2004 to 2.1 percent, from 0.6 percent. The brighter outlook comes on the back of a surprisingly strong 3.9 percent annualized expansion in the April-June quarter. It also follows similar upgrades made by private economists. But the government sees only 0.1 percent growth in nominal terms, which strips out the effect of falling prices, a sign deflation remains rooted in the economy. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Cultural gaffes : Bathing rituals in Thai village aren't always what they seem
description: It seemed like such a good idea at the time. The prospect of staying as a guest in a real Thai house, speaking nothing but Thai in a Thai village was too much to pass up.

title: Marlins Make Wild Card a Reality
description: A half-dozen television cameras set up before the home dugout at Pro Player Stadium this afternoon were taping the Marlins' workouts as if they were football practice. Baseball has never mixed with South Florida as well as football has, but people turned out tonight to see if their Marlins could cap their dramatic season by nailing down a postseason berth.

title: Long-Distance Runners
description: Mohamed Khadraoui, the reigning New Jersey state cross-country champion, collected his running gear to head out for practice as the fall season began recently at John F. Kennedy High School. Before departing, Khadraoui's English teacher, Mary DeMoor, embraced him in the corridor.

description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Conviction For Protesting Tobacco Farmer
description: A tobacco farmer who drove a tractor into a decorative pond on the Mall in March and threatened to blow himself up was convicted of two federal felony charges. The farmer, Dwight W. Watson, 50, of Whitakers, N.C., was convicted of making a false threat to detonate explosives and of destroying federal property. The charges carry a prison term of up to 20 years. Mr. Watson has said he was protesting reductions in tobacco subsidies, actions that made him give up his farm. The protest caused a 48-hour standoff with the police, closing three federal buildings.

title: Nokia Names An American To a Top Post In an Overhaul
description: As it struggles for growth in the no-holds-barred mobile phone market, Nokia, the world's biggest cellphone manufacturer, announced changes today in its management, spurring speculation that it may be preparing to change its chief executive.

title: A Kenyan Iconoclast and Her Unusual Husband
description: FEW here bat an eyelash when an elderly man gray-haired, toothless, wrinkled and bent -- marries a fresh-faced schoolgirl. It is just the way things have always been done in Africa.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Quake Injuries Rise
description: The toll of injured people in the earthquake that struck Hokkaido in northern Japan rose to 450, while two people were still unaccounted for. The quake, which hit in the middle of the night while most people were still asleep, had a magnitude of 8.0. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINKIN, DAVID

Great-great-uncle of Owen Ford and Scott Lester. He was a true renaissance man, a leader of the community and a second father to us all. He will be sorely missed. Services were held. For information call Riverside Nassau North, 516-487-9600. Contributions may be made to the Mayo Foundation, attn: Paul Harkess, Rochester, MN 55905.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZWERLING, GERTRUDE R.
description: ZWERLING--Gertrude R. Of Stamford, CT, died peacefully on Thursday, September 25, 2003. Mrs. Zwerling was born on September 18, 1907 in New York City. She is survived by her daughters, Louise Orkin and Alice Kaplan, by her son, Steven Drucker, and by eight grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. She was blessed with a rich and rewarding life. A graveside Funeral Service will be held on Monday, September 29, 2003 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY at 11:30am. Donations may be made in her memory to Ziv Tzedakah Fund, 384 Wyoming Ave, Millburn, NJ, 07041.

title: Lonely Campus Voices
description: Most good universities have at least one conservative professor on campus. When, for example, some group at Harvard wants to hold a panel discussion on some political matter, it can bring out the political theorist Harvey Mansfield to hold up the rightward end. At Princeton it's Robert George. At Yale it's Donald Kagan.

title: Quarterback Bides His Time
description: Although the freshman quarterback John David Booty spent some of his practice time over the last two weeks with Southern California's first-team offense, Coach Pete Carroll said he had not yet decided whether Booty would play this season or be redshirted.

description: Another HealthSouth Corporation vice president has agreed to plead guilty as part of a $2.5 billion accounting fraud investigation, the 15th executive charged in an inquiry focused on the former chief executive, Richard M. Scrushy.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday about California's budget crisis misstated the year in which some power generators shut down for maintenance, demonstrating the vulnerability of the state's power supply. It was the spring of 2000, not 2001. The column also referred incorrectly to decisions by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The agency indeed imposed some price caps in California, in December 2000 and June 2001.

title: Saved From Stoning
description: The decision this week of an Islamic court in Nigeria to acquit a woman who faced death by stoning for adultery is a triumph for sanity. If Nigeria, a huge nation encompassing various faiths, had upheld the sentence, it would have given such a punishment legitimacy in other Islamic nations and regions. But the verdict leaves many troubling questions. As the legal codes of more places reflect the influence of Koranic principles, known as Shariah, they must do so in ways that do not violate international law and the rights of their citizens.

title: Honk if You Hate Foie Gras
description: My friend Arthur considers himself a sophisticate, especially when it comes to food. The subject came up recently as an antidote to the soggy sandwiches we had grabbed for lunch one day. I nodded blankly as he rattled on about the pleasures of cinnabar chanterelles, morels and other wild fungi, but when he switched to the subject of pt de foie gras, I jolted back to attention.

title: He Bent Over Backward, for This?; Limbo King of 60's Says He'll Sell Mementos to Pay Rent
description: The Limbo King still lives in Greenwich Village, in the same one-bedroom apartment on Bedford Street he has had since 1966.

description: Detectives questioned members of the New York branch of the Universal Zulu Nation yesterday after one of its members, a Hunter College honors student, was fatally shot in the back on Wednesday night in Harlem.

title: Robert Palmer, 54, Singer With Image of a Pop Romeo
description: Robert Palmer, a debonair English singer who channeled his fondness for American rock and soul into a string of hits in the 1970's and 80's, died yesterday in Paris. He was 54 and had resided in Switzerland.

title: The Truth Is Out There, but It's Classified
description: The corners of the Internet frequented by fans of ''X-Files'' and alien-creature sightings were abuzz last week when President Bush extended for another year the total secrecy of Area 51, a large Air Force base in the Nevada desert.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CHECHNYA: GROUPS DECIDE AGAINST OBSERVERS Two human rights watchdogs  the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe and the Council of Europe  have decided that because of security concerns they would not send observers to monitor the Oct. 5 presidential election. The Vienna-based O.S.C.E., which did not send observers to a Chechnya referendum in March that approved a pro-Moscow constitution, is choosing not to send a delegation "because it is not safe," a source said. The council, based in Strasbourg, announced its decision on its Web site and cited "the difficult security situation." (Agence France-Presse)

title: Novelist's New Math: A Calculus Of Violence
description: The novelist William T. Vollmann lowered his pistol, removed his hearing protectors and hobbled across the dusty shooting yard to assess the damage.

Putin of Russia was on hand to ring in the change, coffee cup in one hand and Krispy Kreme doughnut in the other.

title: ELECTRONIC ARTS GAINS EXCLUSIVE NASCAR RIGHTS
description: Electronic Arts Inc., the video-game maker, said it had won exclusive global rights from Nascar to develop, publish and sell games based on the stock-car racing series. Terms of the six-year agreement were not disclosed. Electronic Arts, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., said it has made Nascar-themed games for seven years. Sales at Electronic Arts have almost doubled in the last two years, with net income rising to $317.1 million in the year ended in March from an $11.1 million net loss two years earlier.

title: Full Disclosure on Full Disclosure
description: Last week Arnold Schwarzenegger proclaimed his desire for greater openness in politics. ''We need to throw open the doors and windows of government,'' he said. At the same time, however, Mr. Schwarzenegger has forced his campaign staff to sign strict confidentiality agreements. Under threat of termination, staff members must agree not to disclose information about ''Arnold Schwarzenegger and his family, friends, associates and employees.'' The policy, first described in The Los Angeles Times, stipulates that Mr. Schwarzenegger can obtain an injunction against anyone trying to break it and a fine of $50,000 per violation.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank Takes Oil Stake
description: Santander Central Hispano, Spain's biggest bank, has bid 1.2 billion euros ($1.38 billion) for a larger stake in Compania Espanola de Petroleos, the oil company, raising expectations of a potential battle for control. Santander offered 28 euros a share in cash, or 17 percent more than Thursday's closing price, for 16 percent more of the company, known as Cepsa. Total, another European oil company and Cepsa's largest shareholder, indicated that it opposed the bid. Santander owns a fifth of Cepsa and has been sharing control with Total, which owns 45 percent.

description: International Business Machines added copyright infringement to its patent-violation case against the SCO Group Inc., which has sued I.B.M. for as much as $50 billion. I.B.M. amended its lawsuit against SCO late Thursday in United States District Court in Utah, said Trink Guarino, a spokeswoman for the company. I.B.M. has filed a barrage of counterclaims against the SCO Group, the software company that has put the computer industry on edge by asserting that users of Linux must pay it a license fee. title: DOLLAR THRIFTY TO SPLIT THE JOBS OF TOP EXECUTIVE
description: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, which operates the Dollar and Thrifty car-rental services, said it would be splitting the jobs of chief executive and chairman when Joseph Cappy leaves the positions next week. Gary Paxton, the co-chief operating officer, will become chief executive, succeeding Mr. Cappy, 69, who has led the company since it was spun off from the Chrysler Corporation in 1997. Cappy will keep his board seat. Thomas Capo, the former Chrysler treasurer who is a Dollar Thrifty director, will become chairman, the company said. The changes will take effect Wednesday. Mr. Paxton, 57, has been with the company for 35 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: S.E.C. Joins Statoil Inquiry
description: Norway's biggest oil producer, Statoil, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started an inquiry into an Iranian consulting contract that is the focus of a bribery investigation in Norway. The S.E.C. has requested documents related to the $15 million contract with the consulting firm, Horton Investment, said Kai Nielsen, a spokesman for Statoil, based in Stavanger, Norway. The chief executive, Olav Fjell, and the chairman, Leif Terje Loeddesoel, resigned this week, less than two weeks after the Norwegian police began an investigation. The authorities in Norway are investigating whether Statoil paid bribes to gain the right to tap natural gas in Iran.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Conviction Of Ex-University Head
description: A former president of the University of South Carolina, James B. Holderman, was convicted in Miami of conspiring to launder money and sell false immigration documents. Mr. Holderman, who left the university in a financial scandal in 1990, said he had planned to take part of the money offered him in an F.B.I. sting last year and buy treatment for his mental illness without providing the fake visas in return. He said he would obtain the papers through his influence with former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee and the White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., according to the prosecutor, Richard Gregorie. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Don't Tread on D.C.
description: Congress has the constitutional right to impose a school voucher program on the District of Columbia. It also has the legal power to relax the district's strict gun control laws. But that doesn't mean it should. In fact, doing so -- as some senators are now proposing -- violates the basic social compact the Constitution's framers envisioned between Congress and the district.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany Health Package Approved

The vote was 517 to 54 for the package, the first in a series of tough reforms designed to revive the country's economy. Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's center-left government intends to cut health spending by more than $23 billion in the next four years, making the health system more efficient and shifting more costs to patients. The agent, Curtis Hall of Nashville, was taking a Turkish detainee being held on a felony charge and awaiting deportation back to jail from a doctor's appointment on Monday when they stopped at his hotel room in Springdale for sex, the police said. There is no evidence the sex was forced, but an inmate is not in a position to consent to sex with an officer, Lt. Richard Farris of the police said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Improvising But Always In Control

It was in tune with the room, not only because its drummer plays quietly enough to deal with the reverberant acoustics, but also in a larger sense as well. With brushed, rustling drums, bass alertly lining out the beat and Mr. Mehldau's clean, classical keyboard touch, the group puts its mysteries within an organized, focused experience. It found its parallel in the hall, which encourages a churchlike feeling in a physical atmosphere of neatness and functionality.
