title: TENET HEALTHCARE'S GENERAL COUNSEL PLANS TO RESIGN
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the hospital owner under investigation by at least three federal agencies, said its general counsel would step down. The counsel, Christi Sulzbach, who oversaw government compliance for Tenet, will resign as of Nov. 1, the company said. Her resignation follows other recent departures at the company, including the former chief executive, Jeffrey Barbakow. Ms. Sulzbach said she was quitting so that she would not be a distraction to Trevor Fetter, the new chief executive, as he attempts to resolve the government's inquiries. Two deputy general counsels, Gary W. Robinson and Rod Stone, will handle legal functions until a successor is found, and Ms. Sulzbach will help with a transition until March 31, the company said. Tenet is based in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILL, ERROL GASTON
description: HILL -- Errol Gaston, re nowned scholar, academic, theater historian, playwright and director, died of cancer on September 15, at the age of 82 at his home in Hanover, NH. The John D. Willard Professor of Drama and Oratory, Emeritus, at Dartmouth College, Hill spent 35 years at the College beginning in 1968. He officially retired in 1989. He was the first tenured African American faculty member at Dartmouth. Over his life, Hill produced and directed over 120 plays and pageants in the West Indies, England, the United States and Nigeria with amateur, semi-professional and professional companies. In the world of academia and scholarship, Hill wrote 11 plays, authored or edited 15 major books and periodicals (many of which won professional association and national awards), and wrote 25 major articles on drama and theater history. Hill's study of the African American and Caribbean theater earned him worldwide acclaim and a reputation as the foremost historical scholar in these fields. Hill was born on August 5, 1921 in Trinidad, West Indies. He graduated from the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London, England. From 1958-1962 he studied at Yale University and the Yale School of Drama, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts (summa cum laude), a Master of Fine Arts in Playwriting and Doctor of Fine Arts in Theater History. Hill is survived by his wife of 47 years (Grace Hope Hill), their four children (Da'aga Hill Bowman, Melina Hill Walker, Claudia Hill, and Aaron Hill), a brother, two sisters, and three grandchildren. The Hill family asks that in lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to The Errol G. Hill Scholarship Fund, C/O Dartmouth College, 6066 Development Office, Hanover, N.H. 03755.

title: Geneticists Report Finding Central Asian Link to Levites
description: A team of geneticists studying the ancestry of Jewish communities has found an unusual genetic signature that occurs in more than half the Levites of Ashkenazi descent. The signature is thought to have originated in Central Asia, not the Near East, which is the ancestral home of Jews. The finding raises the question of how the signature became so widespread among the Levites, an ancient caste of hereditary Jewish priests.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Cattle On Federal Land
description: Six conservation groups filed for an injunction on Wednesday to stop ranchers in Catron County from grazing 300 head of cattle in the Gila and Apache National Forests without a permit. The ranchers, Kit and Sherry Laney, owners of the Diamond Bar ranch, near Silver City, say they have grazing rights based on use before the national forests existed. A federal court ruled in 1997 that the Laneys were trespassing and ordered their cattle removed. They returned the cattle in April. The conservationists say the cattle are damaging streams where trout are struggling to survive a drought. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: The Tracking System
description: If Superintendent Peter Horoschak had his way, most of the sixth graders who entered the middle school in Maplewood, N.J., this month would truly be on the same page. Last spring, Horoschak led an effort to reduce the practice of stratifying new middle-schoolers based on previous academic performance. Such ''tracking'' would have been limited to math classes, where students would still be sorted by elementary-school grades and test scores. For all other core subjects, students -- save extreme underachievers, who would get special help -- would have been randomly assigned to classes and given common curriculums and instruction. Wider-scale tracking (or ''leveling'') would begin only in seventh grade. But an outcry from parents who wanted their children in the high level delayed the ''detracking'' process, at least for one more year.

title: Where I Was From
description: My great-great-great-great-great-grandmother Elizabeth Scott was born in 1766, grew up on the Virginia and Carolina frontiers, at age sixteen married an eighteen-year-old veteran of the Revolution and the Cherokee expeditions named Benjamin Hardin IV, moved with him into Tennessee and Kentucky and died on still another frontier, the Oil Trough Bottom on the south bank of the White River in what is now Arkansas but was then Missouri Territory. Elizabeth Scott Hardin was remembered to have hidden in a cave with her children (there were said to have been eleven, only eight of which got recorded) during Indian fighting, and to have been so strong a swimmer that she could ford a river in flood with an infant in her arms. Either in her defense or for reasons of his own, her husband was said to have killed, not counting English soldiers or Cherokees, ten men. This may be true or it may be, in a local oral tradition inclined to stories that turn on decisive gestures, embroidery. I have it on the word of a cousin who researched the matter that the husband, our great-great-great-great-great-grandfather, "appears in the standard printed histories of Arkansas as 'Old Colonel Ben Hardin, the hero of so many Indian wars.'" Elizabeth Scott Hardin had bright blue eyes and sick headaches. The White River on which she lived was the same White River on which, a century and a half later, James McDougal would locate his failed Whitewater development. This is a country at some level not as big as we like to say it is.

title: The Drama's Still There
description: THE DARKNESS -- When I first heard Justin Hawkins, the flamboyant singer for the swaggering new English pomp-rock band the Darkness, I imagined him as a prodigy. Perhaps he was an exceptionally talented child in a small English town, whose mother insisted on twice-weekly lessons in power ballads; with teachers who force-fed him the complete works of the most self-serious, peacockish male singers of 70's and 80's rock, especially those specializing in falsetto. I could see him winning a talent contest at a local pub, being written up in the local paper and taken for the first time to London by a sharkish manager. But this is 2003, so his act could just as easily be a finely calibrated irony. Actually, it's a bit of both. His aunt has a pub in East Anglia; he sang Queen's ''Bohemian Rhapsody'' with the rest of the band one night and ended up a member. On the other hand, according to a report last month in Campaign, a British trade magazine for the advertising industry, he wrote commercial jingles until he joined the band three years ago. In any case, the band's first album, ''Permission to Land'' (Atlantic), seems a high-water mark in how confusing it is to know whether to take rock seriously anymore, even when it's good.

title: Wish I Were Here

And that fellow crossing the street at Watchung Plaza, with its 1920's low-rise commercial buildings -- could those be Merrells on his feet? The temporal dislocation in these and 13 other cards depicting Montclair is intentional. In fact, they are called RetroCards and were created by Joe Zeff, a Montclair resident and a graphic designer who is often asked by magazines to use his computer to make contemporary photographs look old. Mr. Zeff got the idea when he looked at digital photos he took of classic cars in a July Fourth parade.

Having been told by the railroad that the tracks were abandoned, she and her husband extended a hedge from their front yard across them and erected a fence over them in back.

title: Immigrant Workers Share a Bus and Hopes
description: As the bus sped through the New Mexico desert and into West Texas, Federico Gonzlez talked of his dream, an odd dream for an immigrant from Colombia. He wants to be an F.B.I. agent.

title: Marshals Worry as Cuts Leave More Fires Uninvestigated
description: The fire was in the bedroom of a Bronx apartment. Firefighters broke down the door and found a mattress ablaze. They put the fire out, a battalion chief recorded that it was not suspicious, and they left. The charred mattress could have been quickly forgotten, just another remnant of the city's many anonymous fires that claim neither life nor limb, simply property.

title: A Swirl of Foreboding In Mahogany's Grain
description: After a month in the Amazon, feeding on spider monkeys and wild pigs, tormented by infected feet and mosquitoes, Jos Valderrama was about to see his efforts pay off.

title: Fan Wear
description: The free-spirited dressing of students and style enthusiasts attending New York Fashion Week this month suggested that there is still fun to be had with fashion. They wore dresses from the 1920's and 1940's, top left; gloves from the 50's, left; and watch-chain earrings, right. Some do-it-yourselfers tied ribbons high or low for an instant remake, top right. Also part of the scene: high-tech fabric for a man's bubble-shape top, and bagel-shape tote bags from the downtown designers As Four. Below, ankle warmers and a front-row show of men's legs.

title: Sleepless in Seattle
description: WAXWINGS

title: The Small Boat of Great Sorrows
description: November 1998

title: Japan Makes New Pitch To Lure Americans
description: CONJURING up a return to the 1960's, when Japan was a popular and affordable tourism destination, Japan wants to double its foreign visitors to 10 million a year by 2010. With the hubris and sky-high prices of the 1980's a fading memory, tourism officials are trying to sell Japan as a destination with newly reasonable prices, no recent history of terrorism and streets that can be walked without fear all night long.

title: Timmie Friend, Scott Haskins
description: Elizabeth Robinson Friend, an interior designer, and Scott Marshall Haskins, a real estate executive, were married yesterday. The Right Rev. C. Cabell Tennis, a retired Episcopal bishop of Delaware, officiated at the summer house of the bride's family in Wainscott, N.Y.

title: More Bad Experiences With Nassau's 911
description: Re ''Nassau 911 Callers Are Being Put on Hold'' [Sept. 14]: My two experiences calling 911 were far worse than you reported. I've dialed 911 twice in my life, both this year, during the summer. The first time, on a Sunday morning at roughly 10:45, I called from a supervisor's land line at Coe's Neck Park after a softball teammate of mine collapsed after hitting his head. I was left on hold for 25 minutes before I gave up. Luckily, by the time I sprinted back to the field, someone with a cellphone had gotten through and an ambulance was on its way.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Legacy of Gold

title: Bluebird Hatching Heralded
description: IT took five years of trying, but it finally worked: Audubon Society volunteers managed to engineer the hatching of two baby Eastern bluebirds at Lenoir Preserve in Yonkers this summer, as part of an effort to re-establish the bird in Yonkers after a 50-year absence.

title: Second Thoughts On a Thoughtful 'Finta Giardiniera'
description: Mozart was 18 and quite cocky when he wrote ''La Finta Giardiniera,'' his first mature opera buffa, for a production in Munich. The music, though expressive, nuanced and often ingenious, has generally been considered too elaborate for the story, which abounds in typical opera buffa contrivances and confusions.

title: Nicole Woodard, Dwayne Brown
description: Nicole Danielle Woodard, the daughter of Elaine and Daniel A. Woodard of White Plains, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Dwayne Thomas Brown, a son of Loretta and Paul Brown of West Hempstead, N.Y. The Rev. Gastrel L. Riley, a United Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bride, officiated at a residence rented for the occasion in Chilmark, Mass.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF the baby circus elephant in DUMBO (1941) hadn't accidentally gotten high on champagne, he might never have learned that he could fly. This is one of Disney's shorter (64 minutes), lower-budget animated features, and it's a little politically incorrect. Dumbo's experience makes a drunken binge look at least partly like fun (complete with dancing pink elephants), and a couple of musical numbers (one sung by crows, the other by roustabouts) convey unfortunate racial stereotypes. Despite that, Dumbo's story, of a newborn with monstrously huge ears who learns that they're his best feature, is a favorite among those who know it. The film, directed by Ben Sharpsteen, won the Oscar for best score -- Tuesday at 8 p.m. on Disney.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Writer and the World: Essays, by V. S. Naipaul. (Vintage, $15.) This fat collection of essays, spanning roughly three decades, showcases the Pulitzer Prize-winning author's relentless independence of mind, his melancholy and pessimism, and his talent for putting himself in other people's shoes without patronizing them. ''Possessed of a vigorous, casually elegant prose style and infinite curiosity, he has managed to elude every possible ideological niche while producing an extraordinary body of work,'' Daphne Merkin said here last year. ''This volume is as good a place as any to discover why he is a figure of such consequence.''

title: DNA COLLECTION WIDENED
description: State law enforcement officials will begin collecting the DNA samples of about 140,000 parolees and convicts serving in the state's prisons, as a result of legislation signed by Governor McGreevey last week that is intended to widen the state's database. Under the new law, those convicted of murders, sex crimes and burglaries would be required to surrender a swab sample taken from the mouth, although those persons convicted of shoplifting, drunken driving and less serious offenses would not be tested. The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey has protested, arguing that the program could constitute an invasion of privacy and that youthful offenders would be tracked unfairly.

title: Upper East Side Apartment Fire Kills Man
description: A fire killed a middle-aged man early yesterday who was apparently asleep in an Upper East Side studio apartment, fire officials said. There were no batteries in the apartment's smoke detector, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JEROME, LUCILLE
description: JEROME--Lucille. On September 25, 2003, age 90, of Highland Beach, FL, and NYC. Beloved widow of Harry, with whom she had a wonderful love affair for over 55 years. Lucille was a person who truly loved life, her family and friends in a very special way. She touched the lives of everyone who was privileged enough to know her and share in her warmth and compassion. Lucille was generous in spirit, and philanthropic in nature. One of the founders of Monroe College in 1933, she dedicated her life to educating young people and was instrumental in the success of countless students. Survived by her three children, Regina Einstein, Stephen Jerome and Diane Lambert, and their spouses, Joseph, Leslie and Ross. Also, nine grandchildren, 12 great grandchildren, and one on the way. Services will take place on Monday, September 29, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lucille Jerome's name to the Boca Raton Community Hospital Foundation --Center for Excellence in Nursing, 800 Meadows Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486.

title: Medical Center Starts To Shut St. Agnes
description: The Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla will start a step-by-step process this weekend to close down the campus of the former St. Agnes Hospital, which it has operated as its White Plains campus since April, according to a notice released by the medical center.

title: Grapes, Cucumbers and Monkey Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Reality Programming
description: CONSCIOUSNESS

title: L.I.@WORK
description: $9.7 Million Profit Reported at Comtech

title: In Earnings, A Stack Of Reasons To Cheer
description: IN large measure, the steady rise in stock prices this year has been based on the conviction that corporate earnings will accelerate, particularly in the second half of 2003. In a couple of weeks, earnings reports for the third quarter will start flowing in earnest.

title: GRADING SCHOOLS
description: The percentage of parents who are pleased with their children's schools has grown steadily since the 1980's with 86 percent now saying they are satisfied or very satisfied, according to a Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers poll released last week. The number of satisfied parents grew to 82 percent five years ago from 74 percent in 1987. Parents said they were highly satisfied with classroom instruction. Karen DeMasters

title: Corrections
description: A column last Sunday about the debate over the forthcoming film ''The Passion'' misspelled the surname of a Boston University professor who wrote an article for The New Republic critical of it and its director, Mel Gibson, and misstated her academic specialty. She is Paula Fredriksen, not Fredrikson, and she is a historian, not a theologian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HETZLER, PETER
description: HETZLER--Peter. Formerly of Rumson, NJ on September 23. Beloved by his late wife Sally (Littell), his children Peter (Christine), Elizabeth (Andrew McBrian) and Jennifer, his grandchildren Sarah Frances, Peter, Stephanie and William, and his devoted companion, Nancy. He will be dearly missed. Donations: Peabody Museum, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA or Sally Hetzler Fund, Riverview Hospital, Redbank, NJ.

title: Web research, stem to stern
description: More than 85 percent of cruise aficionados research their vacations online, according to industry officials. Given the vast array of such material online, though, surfing a sea of cruise Web sites can quickly lead to cybersickness. There are a few cruise sites that are useful starting (or ending) points.

title: Streetscapes/Former Colony Club at 120 Madison Avenue; Stanford White Design, Elsie de Wolfe Interior
description: WHEN its clubhouse went up in 1907, the Colony Club instantly became the premier women's social club in New York, but it occupied the little building at 120 Madison Avenue (near 30th Street) for less than a decade. Although damaged by later changes, the original interior is still wonderfully intact, and the building sparkles amid the tatter of lower Midtown. The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, the building's owner since 1963, has almost finished a facade restoration.

title: Sometimes Fate Can Cut Both Ways
description: The arrival of fall means the arrival of foul and dangerous weather for New England's surf casters, who must plan trips between the uneven march of hurricanes from the south and the wallops of line storms and northeasters from points north.

title: Reborn Opera House In Napa Valley
description: California Wine Country visitors can now attend performances at the newly restored Napa Valley Opera House, which has recently reopened after an 89-year hiatus and a $14 million renovation.

title: Ex-Gov. Hugh Gregg, 85, New Hampshire Republican, Dies
description: Hugh Gregg, a former governor of New Hampshire who was Ronald Reagan's campaign manager in the state in the 1976 presidential primary campaign, died on Wednesday in Lebanon, N.H. He was 85 and lived in Nashua in southern New Hampshire.

title: The Nation: Spend Some, Lose Some; In California, the Propositions Keep Rolling Along
description: IT was the last question of a long and raucous debate here, almost an afterthought, and for many television viewers it probably sounded like a lot of bureaucratic mumbo jumbo after the evening's theatrics.

title: Doing Right by the Songwriters
description: IN a season teeming with singer-songwriters, from the VH1 heartthrob John Mayer to the indie-rock crooner Josh Rouse, is there any room for a ringer?

title: Women on Campus: Still Not Truly Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Street Scene in Gaza: An Outdoor Gallery of Gore
description: On the elaborately painted walls in the Gaza Strip, the themes are fire and blood. The Palestinian factions that attack Israel have, in effect, their own art departments that spread their message with explicit graffiti that seem to cover most of the flat spaces there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMAN, ELLEN EVE
description: SELIGMAN--Ellen Eve. Beloved daughter of Adele and Malcolm Seligman. Devoted mother of Charlotte Wing. Died suddenly in Oakland, CA September 23. Loving sister of Pat Grant Litowitz and Lynne Vantriglia, sister-inlaw of Chris Wing, daughterin-law of Shirley Wing. Donations in her memory may be made to Center for the Vulnerable Child, C/O Children's Hospital Oakland, 747 52nd Street, Oakland, CA. 94609.

title: The Scariest Action Movies Around
description: AT the beginning of Michael Winterbottom's ''In This World,'' two young Afghans, Jamal and Enayat, leave the refugee camp in Pakistan where they have lived most of their lives and set off on a perilous overland journey to London. The movie emphasizes the danger and frustration of their trip, which only one of them completes -- shady traffickers, harsh weather, unsympathetic soldiers and border guards, as well as traveling conditions that range from the uncomfortable to the potentially deadly -- and also the terrifying loneliness of being uprooted in a world that, when it is not indifferent to their fates, often seems actively hostile.

title: But Seriously
description: WHEN 250 clowns, some from as far as Costa Rica, converge on your town for a four-day festival, normally you'd hear about it, or at least glimpse a red-nosed goofball in grease paint and floppy shoes scooting around a corner somewhere. But that wasn't the case last weekend, which is the way Vince Pagliano wanted it.

title: 2 Servings Of Reality, Please
description: The American public got a real tutorial in diplomacy last week, one that I suspect it could have done without. It was introduced to two concepts: the free rider and the war of choice. How the U.S. public digests these two concepts is going to have a huge impact on our next presidential election.

title: Maureen Langan, Peter McDermott
description: Maureen Langan, a comedian, and Peter James McDermott, a civil engineer, are to be married today in Parsippany, N.J. The Rev. Bernard Smith is to perform the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In this country, whoever is in power will bring his relatives in from the village and give them important positions. That is what Saddam did, and now those relatives are fulfilling their obligation to protect him from the Americans.''

title: The World: Common Ground in Paris; 'This Is Not as Serious as People Think'
description: LISTENING to pundits and politicians on both sides of the Atlantic, it's easy to think relations between France and the United States is horribly damaged. But there is another dimension, beyond the deep divide over Iraq: most of the rest of the relationship remains fine. And what is often missed is that the French just haven't been very good at telling their side of the story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, HENRY VON L. JR.
description: MEYER--Henry von L. Jr., 94, of Wainscott, NY, died peacefully at home on September 22nd. The son of Laura Hard and Henry von L. Meyer, he was born in Lawrence, NY, in 1909. The family moved to Suffern, NY, where they established Cobblestone Farm. It was to be his home for many years and where he and his first wife Isabelle Heins, now deceased, raised their two sons. He was educated at Middlesex School in Concord, MA, and at Harvard University , and he managed a family-held investment concern well into his 70's. An avid woodsman and fisherman, Mr. Meyer particularly enjoyed surfcasting off Long Island beaches. In 1975 he married Barbara Osborn Babinski, and Wainscott became their year-round home. He is survived by his beloved wife of 27 years, Barbara; his son, Henry von L. Meyer, III and his wife, Sheila, of Stuart, FL, and his son, Thomas H. Meyer and his wife, Betsy, of Bedford Hills, NY. He leaves four grandchildren: Thomas H. Meyer, Jr., William A. Meyer, Henry von L. Meyer, IV and Brooke D. Meyer, and four great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his stepson, Andrew Babinski, of Wainscott, and his stepdaughter, Jane Weigley, and her husband, Jim, of Clarksville, MD, and five stepgrandchildren, Bill and Lisa Babinski and Michael, Lindsay and Jill Weigley. Mr. Meyer's family will hold a private memorial service at Wainscott Chapel. His loss will be deeply felt by all who knew and loved him.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DAUGHTER'S KEEPER

title: As Tobacco Warnings Loom, Scornful Spaniards Light Up
description: MADRID, Sept. 27 — All José Sanz asked for at his local tobacco shop one recent day was "a pack of Fortuna, please." It came with a biology lesson.

title: Is Buddhism Good for Your Health?
description: As a meditator, I felt reassured that my (sometime) meditating has not been a vain exercise to banish stress. As an artist, I am, however, troubled about the consequences a life without tension and stress might have on the creative process, not only for artists, but also for scientists and anyone wrestling with problems and searching for solutions. Buddhism itself might not exist had the Buddha been content to stay in his parental palace and meditate instead of agonizing over human misery and venturing forth to find an answer.

title: What Motivates a Terrorist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kids at the Movies, Only These Made Their Own
description: IT was the kind of night that filmmakers dream of. The limo pulls up, the red carpet rolls out, cameras flash and fans call to their beloved stars. Then the crowd rushes into the theater to see the premiere of the first movie by the hot young talent.

title: Launching the Newest Oceangoing Ships
description: Cunard's new flagship, the Queen Mary 2, is garnering attention as it prepares to enter service in January and take over trans-Atlantic service from the Queen Elizabeth 2, whose unmistakable deep bass whistle has announced its departures on the Hudson River for 34 years. The Queen Mary is the most glamorous of a number of new ships that are joining the world's vacation fleet: at least 33 over the next five years, according to Cruise Lines International Association. The largest will carry more than 3,000 passengers, but not all are behemoths: Radisson's Seven Seas Voyager, which entered service in April, carries only 700. When Norwegian Cruise Line's Pride of America, with a capacity of 2,146, enters service in May, it will be the first new American-flag ship in almost 50 years. VERNON KIDD

title: U.S. Compound in Baghdad Is Hit in Attack
description: Three projectiles penetrated the concrete and barbed-wire cocoon of security around the main compound for Americans in downtown Baghdad today, hitting the 14th floor of the Rashid Hotel inside the compound but causing little damage and no injuries.

title: Views of Nature Teeter From the Whimsical to the Ominous
description: At Woodstock, Kuniyoshi

title: An Idealist in D.C.? Must Be Rob Lowe
description: FINALLY, Rob Lowe is in control. Call it maturity or common sense or the experiential equivalent of showing up a day late to a fire scene. For even among the tempest-tossed members of his generation of American actors, Mr. Lowe, 39, has experienced more than his share of, um, distractions, from the cringeworthy public moments of his ''brat pack'' years to his slow-motion departure from ''The West Wing'' and, most recently, his quasi-entry into Arnold Schwarzenegger's gubernatorial campaign. But now, on the set of ''The Lyon's Den,'' an NBC drama series that has its premiere tonight at 10, Mr. Lowe is the bright, confident leading man he's always promised to become.

title: Raising Minimum Wages, City by City
description: REMEMBER the minimum wage? It used to go up regularly, but that stopped happening 20 years ago. We are now in the seventh year of the latest drought, and increasingly the states and lately a few cities are constructing their own ad hoc network of minimum wages.

title: Giving a Nod to Diversity, One Ethnic Sport at a Time
description: This past summer, one sport prompted parties almost every Sunday afternoon on the south courts of Lincoln Terrace Park in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Spectators from the community and from neighboring East Flatbush poured onto the concrete courts to watch. The fans bought cod and Caribbean soda from food vendors, and reggae bounced from under a yellow tent.

title: I Dream of Royalties
description: A CLUTCH of suited dignitaries, standing beneath a makeshift thatched roof of dried palm fronds, don floppy white sailor caps on cue as a band blares the ''Gilligan's Island'' theme song. One of them, Kenny C. Guinn, the governor of Nevada, is struggling to retain his dignity as he shares a spotlight with Gilligan, the Professor and Mary Ann -- the actors Bob Denver, Russell Johnson and Dawn Wells -- during the opening ceremony of the gambling industry's big annual trade show, held here earlier this month.

title: To Stay 19 Forever
description: WHEN I was young, I felt like I had to be around music in some way. So I took guitar lessons and I wrote poetry and songs and they were pretty horrible. Somehow I made the progression of going to law school, because at that time all the people running record labels were former lawyers, like Clive Davis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURANTE, VINCENT A.
description: DURANTE--Vincent A., 61, on September 22. Born in Manhattan, resident of Bay Terrace, formerly of Brooklyn. Mr. Durante was employed at the New York Times as a payroll supervisor. He attended Pace University, was a gourmet cook, amateur horticulturist and gardener. He served in the Army National Guard infantry division in the 1960's. Mr. Durante is survived by his wife of thirtyseven years, Carolyn (Palo), two sons Vincent Jr. and Anthony, daughter-in-law Christine, grandsons Dante and Devin, sister Joann Ferrara, Michael and Carmela Palo (son-in-law of) and nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERN, HELEN ARMIN
description: HALPERN -- Helen Armin died August 19, 2003, at age 91. Wife, mother, grandmother, great grandaunt, college administrator. We will remember her gracious hospitality, informed intelligence, steady determination, independence, unflappability. We will miss the sustenance and safe haven she provided.

title: McKeon, 72, Lights Cigar for Age and Playoffs
description: Jack McKeon knows that he was not the popular choice to be the Florida Marlins' manager this season. He realizes that many people thought he was too old and too out of touch with players who could be his grandsons. And he understands that Major League Baseball was upset that the Marlins handpicked him to succeed Jeff Torborg in May and did not interview any other candidates, ignoring Commissioner Bud Selig's 1999 directive to consider members of minority groups for decision-making positions.

title: The Tax-Cut Con
description: Krugman for president!

title: Southern Cal Takes a Tumble
description: The No. 3 Trojans rallied to force overtime, only to fall to California in the third extra session, 34-31. They weren't the only team to fall hard No. 10 Oregon, rolling off last week's defeat of Michigan, took a pounding from Washington State, 55-16. Florida, though, escaped when the freshman Chris Leak rallied the Gators to a 24-21 victory over Kentucky.

title: On Alert for Al Qaeda in Iraq, U.S. Is Tracking 2 Suspects
description: As United States officials try to determine what role Al Qaeda may have had in recent attacks in Iraq, investigators and Special Forces are also pursuing two men known to have had previous connections to Osama bin Laden, American officials said this week.

title: Emily Grossman, Thomas Reilly
description: Emily Margaret Grossman, a daughter of Dana and Daniel Grossman of East Thetford, Vt., was married last evening to Thomas Michael Reilly, the son of Janet Reilly of Mechanicsburg, Pa., and Richard Reilly of Saylorsburg, Pa. The Rev. Beverly M. Boke, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Inn at Idlewood in Sharon, Vt.

title: The Second Time Aboard
description: LET'S not say what year it was. Let's just say that in the photograph taken on the top deck, I'm wearing a light-green-and-white-checked minidress and mod matching kerchief. My college friend Louise and I were on a Labor Day weekend cruise from Miami to Nassau and Paradise Island. It was the first time I had traveled outside the United States and the first vacation I had ever taken without a parent or chaperone.

title: Montoya in Stretch Run Against Schumacher
description: With his bullish frame and curled lip, Juan Pablo Montoya looks like a cross between Pablo Picasso and Elvis Presley.

title: The Sharer
description: Q: You gave Linux, the operating system, to the world free, in effect jump-starting the open-source movement. Now this previously obscure company, SCO Group, claims ownership of some of the code and threatens to close the door on open source and Linux. I suppose it's to be expected that when you send your offspring out into the world, you have to be prepared for your kid to run with a crowd you don't approve of.

title: Writing the Textbook for 'The School of Rock'
description: MIKE WHITE wrote the movie ''The School of Rock'' for Jack Black, a musician, comic actor and all-around school-of-rock cult hero. In the movie, which was directed by Richard Linklater and opens on Friday, Mr. Black plays a fervent believer in the world-changing powers of rock 'n' roll. When he gets kicked out of his band, he takes over a fifth-grade classroom at the elite Horace Green Elementary School and turns it into a lean, mean, rocking machine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORTNOY, SARA
description: PORTNOY--Sara. On September 25, 2003. Dear mother of Sharon Siegel and Robert Portnoy. Loving grandma of Jessica Siegel, Michael and Leah Beth Portnoy. She will be greatly missed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 14 about David Bowie misspelled the given names of his longtime bassist. She is Gail Ann Dorsey, not Gayle Anne.

title: Jessica Olich, Joachim Trautmann
description: Jessica Megan Olich, a daughter of Jean and Jack Olich of Mahopac, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joachim Friedrich Trautmann, the son of Rosemarie and Friedrich Trautman of Munich. The Rev. Brian McHugh performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Amenia Union, N.Y.

title: Subversive Reading
description: From a certain perspective, there is something thrilling about the recent face-off between Attorney General John Ashcroft and the librarians. The American Library Association and many of its members, indignant about a provision of the U.S.A. Patriot Act that could oblige them to cooperate with federal agents by turning over the records of what some library patrons have checked out, have managed to unleash the most rigorous re-examination of the entire Patriot Act since its passage in October 2001. It wasn't long after the librarians started kicking up a fuss that Don Young, an extremely conservative Republican congressman from Alaska, said during a radio interview that the passage of the Patriot Act, for which he'd voted, was ''stupid.''

title: Another Good News, Bad News Kind of Day
description: For Governor McGreevey, the news these days offers a mixed bag. For instance, while voters do not seem to be overly fond of the Governor, they don't think he's the state's biggest problem either.

title: Riley Wants to Cast the Miami Heat in a New Version of Showtime
description: There was a time when Pat Riley's name was synonymous with beautiful basketball, when Magic Johnson led the greatest fast break ever, when James Worthy finished with statuesque dunks, when the half-court set was the domain of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's majestic sky hook.

title: What if There Is Something Going On in There
description: Daniel Rios is 24 years old, with wavy black hair, a thick mustache and a glassy stare that seems to look both at you and through you. One day almost four years ago, while he was taking a shower, a blood vessel ruptured in his brain, and he collapsed on the bathroom floor. After emergency surgery, he lay in a coma for three weeks. When he finally opened his eyes, he could not speak or move his body; his head simply lolled. In the months that followed, the doctors monitoring him at the Center for Head Injuries at the J.F.K. Johnson Rehabilitation Institute in Edison, N.J., saw few signs that he had any meaningful mental life. Sometimes he looked as if he were crying. Other times his eyes would follow a mirror passed before his face. On his best days he was able to close his eyes on command. But those days were rare. For the most part he lay unresponsive, adrift in a neurological twilight.

title: Commercial Property/Westchester; Fortunoff Opens $92 Million Building in White Plains
description: FORTUNOFF has opened its doors here in a 265,000-square-foot, four-story retail complex, with Christmas trees already twinkling in the top floor-to-ceiling windows beckoning shoppers from the street 75 feet below. It is the sixth in a chain of stores in New York and New Jersey for the retailer, which first opened 81 years ago on Livonia Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn, under the elevated railroad tracks.

title: The Ultimate In Self-Medication
description: For what could be considered a form of psychotherapy, three New York therapists were shown pictures of the latest crop of speedsters, muscle cars and S.U.V.'s and asked to free-associate. It was a vehicular Rorschach test of sorts. The goal was to learn a bit about the positive and negative desires that motivate people to buy certain types of automobiles -- is there a car for every midlife crisis? -- and to uncover the tactics car designers use to lure customers.

title: Editors' Note; Another Homework Assignment
description: Did you do your homework?

title: Country Comfort
description: The first time I interviewed Tammy Wynette, I was greeted at the kitchen door by her fifth husband, George Richey, who was in the process of making sausage with biscuits and gravy, a classic combination. Richey's biscuits were homemade, and his gravy was ''cream,'' the kind made with milk and flour and sausage grease. Cream gravy looks a little too much like cat throw-up to me, but the sausage was good and so were the biscuits, and I was impressed that Richey, who is also a talented producer and songwriter, was doing his own cooking. (He was, too -- when he checked the biscuits through the oven window, he grinned and said, ''Oh, yeah, those are gonna be award winners right there.'')

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Under $20 column last Sunday gave an incorrect address for P. J. Wine. It is at 4898 Broadway (near 204th Street) in Manhattan, not 4948 Broadway.

title: Fighting in Kashmir Revives Rancor in Pakistan and India
description: Speaking this week to the United Nations General Assembly, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said that India was fueling an arms race that would ''destabilize South Asia.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, LILLIAN R. (NEE WROTZLAWSKY)
description: KAPLAN--Lillian R. (nee Wrotzlawsky). On September 26, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Herbert Kaplan. She is survived by her children Leon, Karen Behar & Myra, five grandchildren & a greatgranddaughter. She leaves us with memories of her devotion to family and friends, her wit and great meals. Services Monday, September 29, 11:30 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, Brooklyn.

title: The Tax-Cut Con
description: I have long thought of Paul Krugman as the dean of doom and gloom. In his efforts to persuade us to favor higher taxes, he compares the United States to those paragons of greatness, Sweden and France. Some pundits have been saying for years that Americans should be less like themselves and more like somebody else. Fortunately, Americans continue to be themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HONIG, JOEL
description: HONIG--Joel. On September 25, 2003. Beloved son of Rae Adele and the late Mack. Dear brother of Lynda Williams. Devoted uncle of Janine and Jordan Dicola. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Elaine Sutherland, Mark Warnken
description: Elaine Margaret Sutherland, a daughter of Christine and Raymond Sutherland of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Jeffrey Warnken, a son of Patricia and Wayne Warnken of Scarsdale, N.Y. title: Karen Lyski, Graham Beatty

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Grown Men Crying
description: In two of his last four novels, John Grisham has abandoned the tropes of the legal thriller to try his hand at a social-realist bildungsroman (''A Painted House'') and a satire of yuletide hype (''Skipping Christmas''). His new novel, BLEACHERS (Doubleday, $19.95), finds him venturing into Pat Conroy territory, where youthful hero worship and idealized manliness collide with adult disillusionment. Neely Crenshaw was once the star quarterback of the Messina Spartans, a high school football team in a small Southern town that deifies its players and coaches. A college injury exiled Neely to life's sidelines, where he wandered aimlessly before accepting the unheroic role of a divorced real-estate agent in Orlando. What brings Neely back to his hometown is the terminal illness of Eddie Rake, the legendary Spartans coach whose win-loss record ''almost anyone on the streets of Messina could rattle off from memory.'' As they keep vigil in the bleachers, Neely and an intergenerational assortment of former Spartans must reconcile their memories of Rake as both a monster and a best friend -- a coach who gleefully drove them into the ground but was always there to lift them up when they truly needed help. This is a book designed to make a certain type of grown man cry, and the author knows exactly which buttons to push: dying father figures, the scars of tough love, middle-aged regret and the mythology of the gridiron. What saves the story from melodrama is Grisham's refusal to offer pat resolutions; he allows his ambivalent characters to remain so. It also helps that he's a sure-footed storyteller with an undeniable mastery of plotting, pacing and tone. Jeff Turrentine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, MICHAEL PATRICK
description: JOHNSON--Michael Patrick, 51, died peacefully at his home in Kirkland, Washington on September 19, 2003. Over seven years earlier, Michael was diagnosed with brain cancer. Through a powerful intellect and sheer perseverance, reinforced by the loyalty of his family and friends, Michael battled his disease much longer than the doctors predicted. Michael was born to Harold and Fritz Johnson on August 20, 1952. The Johnson household was a loving and nourishing environment that with the addition of his younger sister Barbara, prized intellectual excellence and high competitiveness, both of which Michael put to good use, winning one chess tournament after another. While attending Menlo College, Michael excelled in computer programming. Together with his future business partner Mark Mahan, they had their first commercial success, computerizing the school's grading & admission systems. Following graduation, Michael worked for Data General, and then went on with his partners to start Redmond-based MAJIQ, Inc, which became a major supplier of computer systems for the Pulp and Paper industry. Michael's subsequent success in the business world came through a winning combination of his computer talents, his phenomenal tenacity, and his unusual people and communication skills. And hard work: Day after day, month after month, he traveled from one paper mill to another, winning contract after contract-and making countless friends along the way. In 1990, Inc. Magazine listed MAJIQ as one of the fastest growing private companies in America. At his fiftieth birthday party, a competitor paid tribute to his success and to the man, stating they ''couldn't lose out to a nicer guy''. As MAJIQ went international, Michael garnered recognition from his industry and served as Affiliate Chairman of the PIMA Information Systems Specialist Group. Mike was fortunate in his family life. In 1990 he married Irene (nee Ankudinova) and became a second father and a loving mentor to her daughter Sasha. The warmth of his family helped Michael in his ordeal. Irene was at her husband's side every step of the way and, along with his mother and sister, was at his bedside when he died. Michael Johnson set forth examples for his survivors to live by. He was caring and generous. He attacked life with a steadfast will and quiet confidence to get what he wanted and to share it with those he loved. He laughed. He made others laugh. And, during his illness, he never once felt sorry for himself, or asked ''why me?'' He simply kept looking for solutions with grace and dignity. He was overcome, but he never quit. Michael was preceded in death by his father Harold. He is survived by Irene, Sasha, his mother Fritz, sister Barbara, nephews Cody and Collin, mother in-law Inna, caregiver and friend William Houston, life-long friends and his legacy which will live in the hearts of those who knew him best.

title: Jack Out Of The Box
description: On the Paramount studio lot, in a trailer near the corner of ''Fifth Avenue'' and ''38th Street'' on an ersatz New York set, Jack Black rubs his red-rimmed eyes with his beefy fists, trying to shake off the Tylenol PM he took last night. A White Stripes song bashes out of speakers wired to his iPod. Arrayed on the table in front of him are a bottle of Gatorade, a paperback copy of the Dalai Lama's ''Path to Tranquility'' and a magazine about trucks. It's 2 in the afternoon, the time that Black is usually just getting out of bed. ''I'm nocturnal by nature, like a vampire,'' he says. ''Two to 6 a.m. -- those are my best hours.'' The actor is here to make a music video for a song from his new movie, ''The School of Rock,'' and he needs to ramp up his energy level considerably for the comedic exertions today's shoot involves: leaping down stairs three at a time with arms flapping, hurling himself ''Dukes of Hazzard''-style over the hood of a car and erupting with all manner of crazed gesticulations and demonic grimaces.

title: The Personal Is the Antipolitical
description: The Sacramento directory offers no listing for Charlotte Goland, and so I have no choice but to show up, unannounced, at the address on her check. I don't usually hunt down strangers in their homes, but unusual times call for unusual methods. This woman, unreachable by phone, is herself a clue to a mystery: how did California go so quickly from order to chaos? Republicans say it's because Gray Davis caused and then covered up the state's financial crisis. Democrats claim the attempt to remove Davis from office just six months after he was legally elected is a right-wing conspiracy. Both are obviously wrong. What we have here is a crime of passion, committed by the people upon their ruler. It demands an investigation.

title: Corrections

title: Your Grill Grease, My Stomach
description: I HAVE an etiquette problem that Emily Post doesn't exactly cover. The issue flares up like a brush fire throughout the extended grilling season that lasts from spring thaw to first snowflake here in the suburbs. I'm not a classic vegetarian. I eat fish, and my wife eats fish and chicken. The fact that neither of us consumes red meat hardly qualifies us as a particularly tough invite to someone's deck party, but as a courtesy we always inform our hosts beforehand of our special culinary needs.

title: Bearer of Bad News
description: Telling people they are H.I.V.-positive is the only thing about my job I don't like. People's reactions vary. A lot of people shut down; they start to space out; they want to bolt. We can't make them stay and talk with us about how they are feeling and what the next steps are, but that is what we try to do. I do H.I.V. testing at H.O.P.E. Inc., a clinic in Tulsa, Okla. In my six years doing this, I've had some people become very upset, because they were pretty certain about who infected them. They said they were going to attack the person. In one case, a client started screaming about how he was going to go kill his partner. But the people who react the most strongly are those who don't consider themselves to be in the ''high risk'' groups. When those people are positive, it's a lot to deal with.

title: College Football | Roundup; Another Season, and Paterno Is Steamed at the Officials Again

title: SECURITY INQUIRY
description: Port Authority agents seized personnel records from a security company last week as part of its investigation of claims by a former employee that the company left key guard posts understaffed and that it acted to hide these actions. Haynes has more than $100 million in contracts with the Port Authority. The company has denied Pampalone's accusations.

title: Is Buddhism Good for Your Health?
description: Meditation does not seem ''flaky,'' as the University of Wisconsin neuroscientist Richard Davidson suggests, so much as it seems self-indulgent (Stephen S. Hall, Sept. 14). Could the benefits of meditation -- positive emotion as demonstrated by left prefrontal cortical activation -- be achieved by less passive pursuits, for instance, by volunteerism? If the participants in Jon Kabat-Zinn's study at a Wisconsin corporation spent the three hours daily for two months helping in a soup kitchen rather than meditating, would they have also cultivated emotional states like compassion and achieved improved personal and societal well being, as meditation purports to do?

Robinson is survived by his wife, Sondra Kurtin Robinson, sons Joshua Robinson and Andrew Robinson, step-son Abner Kurtin, step-daughter Sarah Kurtin Levy and seven grandchildren. title: Travels With George And Carville
description: WITH all due respect to ''National Lampoon's Animal House'' and Brian De Palma's ''Scarface,'' the American movie in most pressing need of an anniversary resuscitation on DVD is ''The War Room.'' It was 10 years ago this fall that James Carville and George Stephanopoulos got their big-screen break in the D. A. Pennebaker-Chris Hegedus documentary about the '92 Clinton-Gore campaign. The film did for them what ''The Graduate'' once did for Dustin Hoffman. But instead of going on to perform in ''All the President's Men'' in Hollywood, they played some of the president's men for real, and that turned out to be their way station to TV stardom. To watch ''The War Room'' now is to realize just how radically our media culture has changed in the wake of their success.

You sit there without anything to do and start thinking about the situation and it becomes hopeless and lonely.''

He was true to himself and conducted the divorce the way he conducted the marriage, as a symbiotic partnership.

title: Dirty Harry Wants To Say He's Sorry (Again)

The first is the discovery of a beautiful teenage girl whose battered corpse is seen from on high -- in the same shot in which her father wails and rages with grief as a line of policemen struggle to hold him back. The second happens on screen, and is even more grueling and invasive. Every act of violence in ''Mystic River'' has momentous and rippling consequences. To watch Mr. Eastwood's mournful noir chamber-drama in the same week as, say, ''Once Upon a Time in Mexico,'' Robert Rodriguez's splattery pseudo-epic, is to see the twin poles of contemporary screen violence: one that wants you to loathe brutality, the other that wants you to whoop with glee at every punctured, pinwheeling body.

The findings, by the Straphangers Campaign and Transportation Alternatives, provide analytical ammunition for advocates of the tolls. Officials in Brooklyn and Queens oppose tolls for the bridges. Unhappily, although many top Democrats and Republicans still see economics as destiny for the People's Republic, getting rich and becoming free are not cause and effect.

title: In a Change of Pace, the Redskins Win With Defense
description: The fire and brimstone was missing from Steve Spurrier's offense today. The Washington Redskins were more methodical than freewheeling on an afternoon when their defense deserved most of the accolades. There is, however, something to be said for winning gritty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRY, SUZANNE, ''SYLVIA BARRY'', ''SYLVIA BENJAMIN.''
description: BARRY -- Suzanne, ''Sylvia Barry'', ''Sylvia Benjamin.'' Died in New York City on September 27, after a long illness. Survived by her niece Jo Stecher Pardoe and nephews Jamie and Joseph Stecher. Funeral services private. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: White House Says Top Aide Was Not Behind C.I.A. Leak
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 — The White House said today that it was "ridiculous" for anyone to suggest that President Bush's top political adviser had leaked secret information in an effort to discredit an outspoken critic of Mr. Bush's policy on Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Called To Rabbi's Home
description: A rabbi walked out of his home in Midwood yesterday to find two bottles that appeared to contain flammable liquid next to his front door and a singe mark under a window, the police said. The incident, on the second day of Rosh Hashana, occurred on East 8th Street at 4 p.m. and led to a broad police response, with detectives and arson investigators descending on the predominantly Jewish neighborhood. The police said last night that arson was a possible motive, but there was no evidence of a bias crime. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: The Energy Bill Gets Worse
description: This country needs a purposeful long-term energy strategy that reduces its dependence on foreign oil and deals with climate change and all the other air-quality issues that are directly related to the burning of fossil fuels like oil and coal. So how has Congress chosen to develop such a strategy? By passing two mediocre energy bills and then handing the task of reconciling them to Senator Pete Domenici and Representative Billy Tauzin, both reliable allies of the fossil fuel industry (although Mr. Domenici is also a big fan of nuclear power) and neither a visionary thinker. Since Labor Day, these two veteran deal makers have been cherry-picking provisions they like, discarding those they don't and for good measure infuriating their colleagues by adding new items of their own.

description: POWER--Catherine C. (nee Clark). Of Bellerose Village and Southold, on September 28, 2003. Loving wife of Austin. Reposing Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave., New Hyde Park, Monday, 79:30 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Victory R.C. title: Clear Channel To Begin Tie-In To Restaurant
description: First, ESPN put its name on a restaurant chain. Then Fox Sports followed with its own branded restaurants. Now Clear Channel Communications in San Antonio, the nation's largest owner of radio stations, has licensed the name of the biggest local sports radio station in Minnesota to start KFAN the Restaurant.

title: A Desperate Victim in a Trunk? No, a Trickster With 2 Cellphones
description: The woman sounded frantic, and her 911 call to the police in Meriden, Conn., on Saturday night was nightmarish: she had been raped by four or five men, she said, then locked in the trunk of their car. She was being driven around -- she did not know where -- and was calling from a cellphone.

title: New Economy; Guarding Privacy vs. Enforcing Copyrights
description: Sometimes, it seems, the sanctity of data is in the eye, and ideology, of the beholder. The libertarian stripe found in many meets some seeming contradictions when the discussion turns from swapping songs to sharing personal information.

title: Mezzina/Brown Is Now 'Agent 16'
description: Mezzina/Brown in New York is being renamed Agent 16, reflecting changes that include a reorganization and the departures of its founders, Bill Brown and John Mezzina.

title: Reagan, Man of Letters
description: Critics who judged Ronald Reagan a regrettably ordinary man, disengaged even when he wasn't on stage as president of the United States, may be surprised to discover that he was dedicatedly dashing off thousands of letters to a wide assortment of pen pals, political allies and even a few global enemies. A sampling from decades of letters has just been published, revealing a hunger for contact with all manner of people.

title: Ian Hunter, 84, Festival Organizer
description: Sir Ian Hunter, a British impresario and organizer of arts festivals who played a major role in shaping the annual Edinburgh Festival, died on Sept. 5 at his home in West Sussex, England. He was 84.

title: Playboy Focuses on Wal-Mart, Which Doesn't Sell the Magazine
description: The November issue of Playboy takes on Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer. But no one who shops for magazines exclusively at Wal-Mart is likely to see the article, because Playboy is among the titles it does not sell.

description: FALLINGWATER RISING

title: Bigger Theater For Washington
description: Arena Stage, an anchor of Washington's theater scene, plans a major overhaul of its Southwest waterfront location. Based on a design by the Canadian architect Bing Thom, the plan will double the theater's square footage. It will incorporate the Arena's signature in-the-round Fichandler Stage as well as its Kreeger Theater and include a new 200-seat experimental theater unified under a soaring roof.

title: Democrats Discuss Programs But Leave Time for Bickering
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark emerged today as a target in the crowded field of Democratic presidential hopefuls, while Howard Dean continued to be criticized by his rivals over Medicare.

title: OPEC Seeks Outside Help on Supply
description: OPEC does not plan to cut production further to keep oil prices stable unless Russia, Mexico and other non-OPEC members agree to make cuts to help offset growing Iraqi production, the president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said over the weekend.

title: Interpublic Executive Plans to Join Endeavor
description: Mark Dowley, who has served since June 2002 as chairman and chief executive of the Sports and Entertainment Group at the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, is leaving to join Endeavor, the Beverly Hills, Calif., talent agency, executives briefed on Mr. Dowley's plans said.

title: Feeding Rules for Nursing Homes
description: The Bush administration is relaxing the rules governing who can feed patients in nursing homes, much to the alarm of patient advocacy groups. Instead of requiring that only trained health care workers feed patients, the administration will now allow the job to be performed by feeding assistants with minimal training and low pay. The plan looks like a sensible way to help nursing homes cope with a severe labor shortage. It should free up nurses and nurse's aides to perform more complex tasks, such as bathing and delivering medical care, and it might even make feeding more enjoyable for patients. The concern is that nursing homes may assign assistants to inappropriate tasks or reduce their cadres of trained health workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORAN, ELIZABETH ANN (GIRVIN)
description: FORAN--Elizabeth Ann (Girvin). On September 26, 2003, Libby Foran, beloved wife of John Richard (Dick) Foran, passed away in her 69th year in Toronto, Ontario. Survived by her husband, her daughters Susan and Lynne (Michael Spragge), two grandchildren, Kathleen and Liam Foran-Spragge, her brother David Girvin (Kathleen Brown), and her sister-in-law Jill Foran. Funeral services will be held in Toronto at 4 PM at the Morley Bedford Funeral Chapel, 159 Eglinton Avenue West, Toronto, Ontario M4R 1A8, on Tuesday, September 30, 2003. In lieu of flowers, contributions to her favorite charity, Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Avenue, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10001 (www.doctors withoutborders.org) would be appreciated.

title: It's Dj Vu All Over Again With Fantasy In the Outfield
description: Balls fly as high as moons. Beer cans cavort, larger than life. But Moses Pendleton achieves even more astonishing things in ''Baseball.'' That 1994 piece plunges the viewer back into the world of baseball as it once was, without a bit of preachifying. Mr. Pendleton and his Momix company, which performed the work on Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater, have made a witty stylized movement vocabulary out of the moves and swagger of baseball on the field and in the bleachers.

title: Critic's Notebook; Back Together, for Better or Worse
description: Back in 1968, Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel imagined themselves at the unthinkable age of 70 and sang, ''Preserve your memories, they're all that's left you.'' Those men, now 61, have also preserved something far more marketable: their once-a-decade reunions. Tickets have been moving fast for the Simon and Garfunkel ''Old Friends'' tour, which starts on Oct. 16 in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and includes a three-night stand at Madison Square Garden Dec. 2 to 4.

title: Sports of The Times; With Emperor Exposed, Coach Is Safe
description: AS their beloved coach stood on the opposite side of a concrete wall under the stadium, the Jets lined up like piano keys after the game, ready to take the blame for their ineptitude, steeled to take the hit for their undisciplined ways.

description: John Hancock Financial Services, the 141-year-old Boston-based life insurer, agreed last night to be acquired by Manulife Financial of Canada for $11 billion in stock, creating the second largest life insurer in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINGER, RALPH O.
description: WINGER--Ralph O. A retired Senior Tax Partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP, died Thursday, September 25, 2003 of an apparent heart attack. He was 84 years old. He was born in Keokuk, IA, and graduated from the State University of Iowa in 1940 (B.A. magna cum laude). After his law school career was interrupted by active duty in the Navy during 1942-1946, he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1947 (LL.B. magna cum laude) and joined Cahill, Gordon, Zachry & Reindel. He was a partner at the Cahill firm for more than 30 years before his retirement in 1991 when he became Senior Counsel to the firm. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Irene, and his son, Ralph; he is survived by two sons, Allen and Robert, a daughter, Louise Koch, and a granddaughter, Mignon Winger. He will repose at the Lloyd's Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, on Monday, September 29, from 7-9 PM. A funeral service will be held at Lloyd's Funeral Home on Tuesday, September 30, at 1 PM. Interment in Flushing Cemetery will follow the service. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Church on the Hill, 168th St. and 35th Ave., Flushing, NY 11358.

title: CD Price Cuts Could Mean New Artists Will Suffer
description: About three weeks ago, a Universal Music salesman arrived at Looney Tunes, an independent music store in West Babylon, N.Y., bearing what he presented as entirely good news. He came to explain Universal's plan to cut the prices of its CD's, and he brought an eight-foot-wide banner promoting Thursday, an up-and-coming New Jersey band.

description: The crazy California recall election, the one that has defied prediction and confounded veteran political strategists for two months, enters its final week with the oddly familiar look of a more conventional horse race.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Cancer Campaign Aimed At Hispanics
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday announced a $350,000 advertising campaign intended to increase cancer screening among Hispanics. The campaign, which will begin in November, comes after an American Cancer Society study found that cancer was the second leading cause of death among Hispanics after heart disease. The campaign will feature advertisements in Spanish-language publications and radio programs. They will urge people to get screened for cancers that have a higher prevalence among Hispanics, like cancers of the liver, stomach and cervix, as well as those that occur in the overall population, like breast and colorectal cancer. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Drugs Show Promise in Children With Arthritis
description: Deanna Friedman began worrying when her daughter was not crawling by 11 months. ''They said I was being a paranoid first-time-around mother,'' she recalled. ''But I just knew something wasn't right.''

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Police Kill Moose In Front Of Crowd
description: Portland police officers shot and killed a 900-pound moose in a tidal pond near a busy downtown recreational area. The police said they had no option because a crowd had gathered to watch the animal, which could have run loose. It would have drowned if it had been tranquilized, the police said. Many in the crowd, which was warned about the plan to kill the animal, shouted angrily as an officer shot it. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Lopez Backtracks
description: Atlanta catcher Javy Lopez created a stir with comments that appeared in an Atlanta newspaper yesterday, but he said his remarks were taken out of context. description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation won a contract worth up to $243.5 million yesterday to support shuttle missions and programs on the International Space Station and a one-year contract extension worth up to $184 million to help NASA's research and development laboratories. The shuttle and space station contract is initially for nine months and worth $64.9 million, but can be extended for up to two years, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. Shares of Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., rose 48 cents, to $45.91.

title: States Fail to Meet No-Smoking Goals for Women
description: Tobacco-related diseases are still the leading cause of preventable death in women, and most states are not meeting the nation's goals to discourage women from smoking, according to a report released today by the National Women's Law Center and Oregon Health and Science University.

title: Sun Says Quarterly Loss Will Be More Than Expected
description: In a surprise announcement, Sun Microsystems said yesterday that it would post a wider-than-expected loss for its first fiscal quarter and that it would restate its results for the previous quarter to reflect a $1.05 billion write-down.

title: Minnesota Wins Opener in the Bronx
description: The Yankees' mastery of the Minnesota Twins ended at the wrong time. After losing 13 straight to the Yankees during the last two regular seasons, the Twins defeated their nemesis, 3-1, in the opening game of their American League division series.

title: The Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, 84; Longtime St. John's President
description: The Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, who as president of St. John's University for 24 years saw it grow into the largest Catholic university in the United States, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived in Cape May, N.J.

title: U.S. Charges Islamic Leader Who Met Bush
description: A prominent Islamic leader who has met with President Bush and been an aggressive defender of militant Middle East causes was charged today in connection with possible terrorist financing.

title: Drafting of Charter Deeply Divides Iraq
description: As the Iraqi Governing Council presses for a transfer of sovereignty to Iraqis, a dispute over who will control the drafting of a constitution is embroiling Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: North Korea Refugees Secretly Ousted
description: A journal published by North Korean defectors has reported that China secretly sent back 58 North Koreans arrested in January while trying to escape China in boats. The journal, Defectors, reported that the Chinese secretly sent the manacled refugees back to North Korea for fear of negative international publicity. Since January China has been holding incommunicado a South Korean freelance news photographer, Seok Jae Hyun, who was arrested while documenting the escape attempt. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Together Again, That Colorful Couple, Art and Fashion
description: Amanda Church is an artist. She is also a pragmatist. Ms. Church, whose anthropomorphic abstract paintings in Pucci-esque hues of mauve and pink are on view at the Artek Gallery in Chelsea, sat in her Manhattan studio last week caressing a fleshy pink Fendi bag. She was thrilled, she said, to have been asked by Fendi to embellish the company's latest handbag, which it calls its ''chef'' bag, with her own artwork: fabric-stuffed letters stitched inside that spell out ''Fendi.'' The bag, one of several commissioned by Fendi from contemporary artists, will be auctioned at a benefit in November for the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo.

title: China Angered by Reported Orgy Involving Japanese Tourists
description: The police said today that they had detained half a dozen people in connection with assertions that hundreds of Japanese tourists had hired similar numbers of local prostitutes and staged a public display of promiscuity on a sensitive anniversary in Sino-Japanese relations.

title: Paris Journal; A Photo Op: O Say, Can You See the Eiffel Tower?
description: For White House planners, the image had to be picture perfect: the first lady, the American flag and the Eiffel Tower all in the same photo frame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISCHER, JAMES
description: FISCHER--James, formerly of Bayside, NY, died on September 28 in Syracuse after a long illness. Loving father of Collin Fischer. Dear brother of Louise Fischer Cozzi. A Memorial service Thursday, October 2, 1:30 at the Plaza Community Memorial Chapel, 91 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HACK, HENRY
description: HACK--Henry, died on Friday, September 19, 2003, after a long illness, at La Vida Llena Senior Residence in Albuquerque, NM. He was 95. He is survived by his wife of 69 years, Dorothy; his son, Alan, and daughter-in-law, Karen of Los Alamos, NM; granddaughter Samantha Hack of Brooklyn, NY; granddaughter Shana Hack and her husband, Scott Cox, of Santa Fe, NM; and sister, Elsie Josephs of Floral Park, NY. He was predeceased by a son John; a brother Sam; a sister Fannie; and a sister Rose. Dr. Hack, a graduate of NYU Dental School, practiced dentistry for 55 years in the Bronx, NY. First Lieutenant Hack served as a dentist in the U. S. Army during WW II. He was president of the Bronx County Dental Society in 1956.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAHILL, REV. JOSEPH T., CM
description: CAHILL--Rev. Joseph T., CM, 84, Priest and Educator of the Congregation of the Mission (Vincentian Community) on September 27. Former pres. (24 yrs) St. John's University, NY. Mass 12 noon Thursday, Star of the Sea Church, Cape May, NJ. Viewing Thursday 10-11:30AM Sudak-Danaher Funeral Home, Cape May. Mass also on Friday 10:30 AM at St. Joseph's Seminary Chapel, Princeton. Interment St. Joseph's Seminary Cemetery. Donations Lilian & Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Box 1070, NY, NY 10029. It was through this institute that Fr. Cahill received extraordinarily competent, compassionate and respectful care.

title: Lack of Communication Doomed Mackovic
description: When Mike Price, Rick Neuheisel and Larry Eustachy lost their coaching jobs earlier this year, the dismissals made clear that win or lose, college coaches would be held accountable for their behavior.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: PRESIDENT QUITS PARTY President Roh Moo Hyun gave up his membership in the governing Millennium Democratic Party. The move was expected and came after 37 lawmakers who support his policies but seek bigger roles for younger lawmakers broke away from the party to form a new one. It remained unclear if Mr. Roh would join the new People's Participatory United New Party.    Samuel Len (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Standoff Ends Gorilla Trip
description: A 300-pound gorilla escaped from Franklin Park Zoo in Boston for the second time this year, injuring a zoo employee and a 2-year-old girl. The gorilla climbed out of its indoor exhibit, which was surrounded by electric wire, into the viewing area, scaled a moat, and made its way to a bus stop outside the zoo, a zoo spokeswoman said. About 50 police officers, zoo employees and volunteers spent two hours in a standoff with the gorilla, which was eventually sedated using a tranquilizer gun. The zoo plans to add security cameras and modify the exhibit to prevent escapes. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Dispute Over Captain America Is Settled
description: Marvel Enterprises Inc. , publisher of "Spider-Man" and "X-Men" comics, and the comics creator Joe Simon said yesterday that they had settled their legal dispute over the superhero Captain America.

title: Two Boys, Joined Skulls, One Goal: Two Lives
description: Crying furiously, Carl Aguirre grabbed the hand that reached out to soothe him and shoved it away. His twin, Clarence, glassy-eyed and coughing from a cold, chimed in and began crying, too.

title: Martin Will Platoon if That Will Help Jets
description: Jets running back Curtis Martin volunteered to accept virtually any changes today, including sharing playing time with the backup running back LaMont Jordan, to help the team pull out of its tailspin.

title: The Gold in Baseball's Diamond
description: As this season drew to a close, remarkably half of baseball's teams had a chance to make the playoffs. Has Major League Baseball's year-old collective bargaining agreement, with its revenue-sharing plan and luxury tax, leveled the playing field? Not exactly.

title: Market Place; Once-Cold Stock Is Hot, and Hot One Is Not
description: They were the two most notable initial public offerings of January 2000. One was cold, and one was very hot. Now the underwriter of the hot offering is on trial, and buyers of the cold one are counting their profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MODIGLIANI, FRANCO
description: MODIGLIANI -- Franco. On September 25, 2003. The Trustees, faculty and staff of New School University mourn the loss of Franco Modigliani, an alumnus of, and former Professor at the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science. The winner of the 1985 Nobel Prize for Economics for his theories about people's savings habits and the functioning of financial markets, he also irreversibly changed the way the world understood Keynesian economics. His death has deprived the economics profession of an energetic, independent and powerful mind. Our condolences to his wife Serena, two sons, Andre and Sergio, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren. An academic conference in his honor is being planned for the Spring. Philip Scaturro, Chairman, Board of Trustees Bob Kerrey, President, New School University Michael E. Gellert, Trustee and Chairman, Board of Governors Walter A. Eberstadt, Trustee and Member, Board of Governors Richard J. Bernstein, Dean, Graduate Faculty

title: MEMO PAD
description: An airplane ticket is probably going to cost a few more dollars later this week, if airlines, as expected, pass on to customers the $2.50-a-flight-segment security tax that is being reinstated by the government, effective tomorrow.

title: Disease Is Often at Fault in Falls
description: When elderly people have problems with falling, the cause is less likely to be any medications they are taking than any of a number of common chronic diseases, a new study reports.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett In Joint Research Venture
description: Hewlett-Packard and Partners HealthCare System, a large hospital and research organization in Massachusetts, plan to announce today a multiyear, multimillion-dollar joint research program that seeks to accelerate progress in clinical genomics. The goal is to use computer technology to help collect, store and analyze the genetic information of patients, then tailor preventative and therapeutic regimens for individual patients, a concept known as individualized medicine. About two million patients a year are treated by Partners HealthCare, an umbrella organization that includes Brigham and Women's Hospital and Massachusetts General Hospital. The research program is probably the largest clinical genomics project undertaken to date, said Raju Kucherlapati, scientific director of the Harvard Medical School-Partners HealthCare Center for Genetics and Genomics. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLIMPTON, GEORGE
description: PLIMPTON--George. For 30 of New York Philomusica's 32 years George provided consisently good-natured and inspired leadership. We shall carry his legacy, informed by that special quality of inquiry he brought in his quest for perfection in all that he touched, into the future. On behalf of the artists, the Board of Directors and our many music-loving friends, I thank you George, for all that you represent, and all that you have done to help our cause. With deep love for you, and with heartfelt sympathies to your wife Sarah, your twins Lauren and Olivia, your former wife Freddy, and your devoted son and daughter Taylor and Medora, and all your loved ones, please rest peacefully, your perpetual smile of assurance intact through all the ages. Bob Johnson, Founder and Artistic Director, New York Philomusica
