title: Boom Times on the Poverty Roll
description: An additional 1.7 million Americans slipped into official poverty last year, ground down by the pernicious joblessness that remains the most salient fact of the economic recovery. Job growth -- promised by Republican architects of the new tax cuts favoring the affluent -- remains a national dream. The poverty roll rose to 34.6 million people, more than a third of them children, according to new census data. And the grimness of this trend is hardly reversible in the immediate future as the president and the Republican-led Congress pay for the tax cuts, postwar Iraq and other programs with budget deficits that are projected to sap $5 trillion from the nation's revenue flow over the next decade.

title: McCann Loses 2 Coke Accounts
description: Offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising have lost two assignments to create campaigns for the flagship soft drink brand of the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEINFELD, ROBERT H.
description: SEINFELD--Robert H. died September 28, at his residence after a long illness. Adored husband of Judy, dear father of Marc, Lori (Paul) and Jill (Jeff), loving step-father of Steven and Jeffrey Greenberg, precious grandfather of Ginger, Jackson and Gerard and cherished brother and uncle of the Soloway family. His values, informed intelligence, steady determination, indepden dence, love of life and passion, gentleness and kindness have made his life a tribute to love, hard work and pleasure. ''Meum et tuum.'' Donations to Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Ave, Bethpage, NY 11714, are appreciated.

description: The criminal trial of Frank P. description: Nassau County government, until recently a symbol of fiscal mismanagement, was notified today that its bond rating is in line to be upgraded for the second time this year.

title: A Ruling of Natural Death for a Foster Child
description: Stephanie Ramos, the severely disabled foster child whose 28-pound body was discarded in a trash bag by her foster mother in July, died of natural causes, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday.

title: Deadly Twist on Bursting Vessels
description: People who use Medicaid or have no health insurance are much more likely to die from aneurysms in the abdominal aorta than people with private insurance, researchers report.

title: Doctors Call Attention to Bladder Cancer
description: There are no marathons to raise money to find a cure for the disease, nor are there celebrities raising its profile. But bladder cancer has become the fourth leading type of cancer in men.

description: Alcan Inc. received approval today from regulators in Europe and the United States for its 4-billion-euro takeover of a rival aluminum producer, Pechiney of France.

He was John Taylor. (Nick Rhodes is another member of the band.)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Parliamentary Elections
description: Rwandans began two days of legislative elections amid charges that the Rwandan Patriotic Front of President Paul Kagame had cracked down on major opposition parties to ensure victory for the governing party. Two ethnic Hutu politicians were disqualified by the electoral commission for fraud in recent days. Their party had already been banned, forcing them to run as independents. Mr. Kagame, who comes from the minority Tutsi ethnic group, won a seven-year term as president in August with a reported 95 percent of the vote. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Yankees Not Cocky, But More Confident
description: Gene Michael, the Yankees' top scout, stood outside the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium at noon yesterday, holding a thick blue binder with hundreds of pages of reports on the Minnesota Twins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINGER, RALPH O.
description: WINGER--Ralph O. A retired Senior Tax Partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP, died Thursday, September 25, 2003 of an apparent heart attack. He was 84 years old. He was born in Keokuk, IA, and graduated from the State University of Iowa in 1940 (B.A. magna cum laude). After his law school career was interrupted by active duty in the Navy during 1942-1946, he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1947 (LL.B. magna cum laude) and joined Cahill, Gordon, Zachry & Reindel. He was a partner at the Cahill firm for more than 30 years before his retirement in 1991 when he became Senior Counsel to the firm. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Irene, and his son, Ralph; he is survived by two sons, Allen and Robert, a daughter, Louise Koch, and a granddaughter, Mignon Winger. He will repose at the Lloyd's Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, on Monday, September 29, from 7-9 PM. A funeral service will be held at Lloyd's Funeral Home on Tuesday, September 30, at 1 PM. Interment in Flushing Cemetery will follow the service. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Church on the Hill, 168th St. and 35th Ave., Flushing, NY 11358.

title: F.C.C. Chief Will Enforce Phone Curbs
description: Federal regulators told a Senate committee today that they planned to enforce a national do-not-call registry starting on Wednesday despite logistical complications caused by a federal judge's ruling on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULLIVAN, GAIL A.
description: SULLIVAN--Gail A., Senior VP of Daytime Network and Soapnet Sales for ABC Television Network, died suddenly September 27, 2003. Loving daughter of Ann (nee Ross) and the late John L. Sullivan. Beloved sister of the late John Joseph. She will always be loved and remembered by Ralph Gorthey. She was a devoted niece, cousin and friend to many. Reposing Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9PM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45AM Thursday at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Odjfell Chief To Be Jailed
description: Odfjell, the world's biggest operator of deep-sea chemical tankers, said that two top executives would go to prison in the United States and the company would pay a $42.5 million fine after pleading guilty to price fixing. The chief executive, Bjoern Sjaastad, will serve four months as part of the agreement with prosecutors, the Justice Department said. A vice president, Erik Nilsen, will serve a three-month sentence. The guilty pleas are the latest developments in an investigation of bid-rigging and price fixing on trans-Atlantic shipments of specialty liquids. European Commission investigators raided the offices of Odfjell, based in Bergen, Norway, and its rival Stolt-Nielsen in February. Jo Tankers, a smaller rival, was also a part of the investigation. American authorities also raided Odfjell's offices in Houston.

title: The Presidency Wars
description: Have you noticed that we've moved from the age of the culture wars to the age of the presidency wars? Have you noticed that the furious arguments we used to have about cultural and social issues have been displaced by furious arguments about the current occupant of the Oval Office?

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: President Declares His Wealth
description: President Mwai Kibaki submitted a statement of his wealth in a sealed envelope to his government and called on the country's 70,000 civil servants to follow suit by Wednesday. By forcing politicians, no matter their status, to detail their income, assets and liabilities, Mr. Kibaki hopes to combat graft in a country where corruption has become commonplace. But analysts said the disclosure exercise was undermined when Parliament voted earlier this year to limit public access to the wealth declarations. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: SAFECO INSURANCE TO SELL UNITS AND CUT JOBS
description: The Safeco Corporation, a Seattle-based home and car insurer, said yesterday that it planned to sell its life insurance and asset-management unit and cut 500 jobs as higher-than-expected workers' compensation claims eroded profit. Safeco said it would set aside $205 million in reserves for workers' compensation policies, or 96 cents a share after tax. Analysts had expected the company to earn 73 cents in the third quarter, according to a Thomson Financial survey. Safeco said the sale and job cuts were aimed at increasing profits in the auto and home businesses. Safeco hired Goldman Sachs to sell the life insurance and asset management units.

title: Davis Contends Schwarzenegger Is Avoiding the Issues
description: This 15-second television advertisement, titled ''Ducks,'' began being shown across California yesterday. It was produced and paid for by Californians Against the Costly Recall of the Governor, the main group supporting Gov. Gray Davis.

title: Graft Trial Of Ex-Premier Opens in Paris
description: A former prime minister, Alain Jupp, went on trial here today over charges that French companies made illegal payments to cover the salaries of employees of President Jacques Chirac's former political party.

title: William C. Morris, 74, Innovator In Children's Book Marketing
description: William C. Morris, who as vice president and director of library promotion at HarperCollins Children's Books is often credited with developing the modern marketing of children's books, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: G.O.P. Senators Say Money for Iraq Must Be Grant, Not Loan
description: Senate Republican leaders, preparing for whirlwind votes this week on the administration's request for $87 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan, today forcefully rejected a growing Congressional sentiment to lend, rather than give, $20.3 billion of that to Iraq for its reconstruction.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for tonight at the Jazz Standard club, 116 East 27th Street, in Manhattan, was outdated. The performer will be Hiromi, a Japanese pianist, not the Stryker-Slagle Band.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: 2 Students At 2 Schools Are Stabbed
description: Two high school students were wounded yesterday in stabbings at separate schools and were hospitalized. In Flushing, Queens, an 18-year-old student at John Bowne High School was slashed across the left ear and face after a dispute over a girl, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education. The victim, whose name was not released, was in stable condition at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. The police arrested Owen Beckford, 17. Charges were pending further investigation. In Midwood, Brooklyn, a 15-year-old ninth grader at Edward R. Murrow High School was stabbed in the lower back, possibly by an intruder in the school building, Ms. Feinberg said. The victim, who was also not identified, received three stitches at Kings County Medical Center, where he was listed in stable condition. Witnesses reported hearing an argument. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about concerns in Britain that the BBC is eroding its status as the country's most enduringly credible institution misspelled the name of a BBC World Service correspondent whose interviewing style some listeners consider more contentious than that of her predecessors. She is Lyse Doucet, not Lise Ducette.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Forces Ambushed In Two Towns
description: American forces were compelled to call in helicopters, tanks and warplanes to fight off an ambush by Iraqi insurgents today in the rebellious city of Khaldiya, military officials and witnesses said. Several soldiers were wounded in the firefight, which lasted at least six hours.

title: INTERIM CHIEF IS MADE PERMANENT AT UNUMPROVIDENT
description: The UnumProvident Corporation, the large disability insurer, said yesterday that had it named Thomas J. Watjen president and chief executive. Mr. Watjen, 49, has served as interim chief executive since March, when the company fired Harold Chandler amid losses from under-priced policies and below-investment-grade bond investments. Mr. Watjen, who was chief operating officer under Mr. Chandler, anticipated his appointment earlier this month at a conference in New York, where he said the company, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., needed a permanent chief before making strategic decisions.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association is adding two categories to its annual Effie Awards competition, which honors effectiveness in advertising. The new categories are for ads aimed at African-American consumers and Hispanic consumers. The two categories will be part of the 2004 awards ceremony, to be held on June 8.

title: GENENTECH SEEKS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF CANCER TREATMENT
description: Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company, said yesterday that it had filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration for approval of its Avastin medicine as a treatment for colon cancer. The company said it had asked for a decision within about six months, a so-called priority review that the agency often grants for cancer medicines. Colon cancer causes more than 50,000 deaths a year in the United States, the National Institutes of Health estimates. Avastin could become the first approved drug that stops tumors by preventing them from building blood vessels, a process known as angiogenesis. Shares fell 39 cents to $80.

title: S.E.C. Demands Documents From Former Enron Chief
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal judge yesterday to compel the production of certain documents from Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, in response to a subpoena issued in the agency's investigation into the company's collapse.

title: For a Changing City, New Pieces in a Lead-Poisoning Puzzle
description: A single stark image has imprinted itself on the American health system about the dangers of lead: a chip of peeling paint on a child's bedroom wall and a small hand reaching up to touch.

title: Giants Hope Red Zone Won't Be a Black Hole
description: The Giants spent significant time today inside the Miami Dolphins' 20-yard line, a sector from which no team has scored a touchdown this season.

title: Taking the Oceans' Pulse, With Help From Robot Subs
description: Oceanographers can talk about the ocean like the climate, describing the arc of major currents and how phenomena like the warm waters of El Nio in the eastern Pacific evolve over months.

title: COMPUSA TO ACQUIRE 71-STORE RETAIL CHAIN
description: CompUSA Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Good Guys Inc., a retailer based in Alameda, Calif., for $55.3 million in cash to expand sales of plasma-screen televisions and home-theater systems. CompUSA, an electronics chain controlled by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hel, will pay $2.05 a share for the 71-store chain, a 37 percent premium to its closing price on Friday. CompUSA, based in Dallas, is expanding sales of digital and other television sets within its 226 stores and will use Good Guys's expertise to help with product selection and supplier relationships. CompUSA will add stores in California, Nevada, Oregon and Washington. The transaction is expected to close in the next five months.

title: Lottery Numbers
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Jersey Split On Gay Marriage
description: A slight majority of New Jersey residents would permit civil unions for same-sex couples, while half stop short of sanctioning marriage rights equal to those of heterosexuals, according to a poll released yesterday. Fifty-two percent of those polled said they would allow civil unions, while 50 percent said they opposed gay marriage, according to a Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers poll. Forty-three percent favor full marriage rights, while 7 percent have no opinion. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points, and 802 residents were surveyed Sept. 2 through Sept. 8. Earlier this year, Lambda Legal, a gay rights group, filed suit in New Jersey on behalf of seven same-sex couples denied marriage licenses. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Amex Is Accused Of Breaking Pact
description: The American Stock Exchange failed to police options trading, in violation of an order requiring stricter enforcement, and then lied to regulators to cover up its lack of supervision, according to Securities and Exchange Commission inspectors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pedophile Tourist Is Convicted
description: A former pediatrician, Stefan Irving, was found guilty yesterday of crossing international borders to have sex with children, a federal crime. A federal jury in Manhattan convicted Mr. Irving, 56, of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, of traveling to Mexico and Central America to have sex with boys as young as 6. He faces life in prison when sentenced. Mr. Irving lost his medical license after being convicted of attempted sexual abuse of a child 20 years ago. At the time of his arrest in May, after a long nationwide search, prosecutors in Federal District Court described Mr. Irving as having gone on more than one ''pedophiles' holiday.'' They told jurors that he had frequented a guesthouse where boys were recruited off the streets and given food and shelter in exchange for sex. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Washington: Back-To-School Disturbance
description: The police were called to back-to-school parties when several hundred people gathered near Fraternity Row at the University of Washington in Seattle, a university spokesman, Robert Roseth, said. Revelers overturned a car, set a bonfire in the street and pelted police cars with rocks and bottles, officials said. It took two hours to disperse the crowd, which caused several thousand dollars in damage. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Chief Executive Plans to Leave United Rentals
description: Bradley S. Jacobs wants to do another deal.

title: 3 Suffolk Parks Are Closed Nightly After a Deadly Virus Is Detected
description: Suffolk County has declared a public health threat for the Eastern equine encephalitis virus and closed three Montauk parks indefinitely from dusk to dawn.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DirecTV Expects More Customers
description: DirecTV, the satellite broadcaster, said yesterday that it would add more subscribers this year than expected because of promotions like a football programming package. Revenue at DirecTV, owned by Hughes Electronics, will also exceed its recent forecasts, Hughes said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. DirecTV said it now expects to add 1.05 million subscribers this year, more than a previous forecast of 900,000. Revenue will increase to $7.6 billion, from $6.45 billion last year. DirecTV has 11.8 million customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOWNSEND, FELICIA T.

Andrade and Lydia A. de Sanctis and the late Maria F. Andrade. Mother-inlaw of Malle T. Andrade and Francesco M. de Sanctis. Stepmother of Rosalind T. Hodgkins and Victoria T. Roschen. title: Remembering 9/11, With Numbness and With Rage
description: CHARLES B. STROZIER, a psychoanalyst who was at his office in Greenwich Village when the World Trade Center collapsed, alternated between watching the catastrophe unfold before him and viewing it on three television screens in a coffee shop where he sought refuge. The experience was unsettling. He switched between watching the TV screens and the real-life scenes as if he were in a mirrored hall seeing images bouncing off of images in endless succession.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Ten Commandments Tour
description: State politicians, including Gov. Sonny Perdue, spoke in support of displaying the Ten Commandments in public buildings at a rally at the Capitol staged by the Christian Coalition. The event was part of a five-state tour of the foam prototype of the Ten Commandments monument that Chief Justice Roy Moore of the Alabama Supreme Court placed in that state's judicial building. The tour is scheduled to end in Washington at the United States Supreme Court, where Chief Justice Moore has filed an appeal of the federal court order to remove the monument, his spokeswoman, Jessica Atteberry, said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: American To Lead Bank
description: Aozora Bank has appointed Edward Harshfield as its new chairman, the second foreigner to lead a bank in Japan. Aozora is 62 percent owned by the United States investment fund Cerberus, which has assembled a three-year business plan to increase profits. A smaller bank, Tokyo Star, named an American as chief executive and president in June. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: NORSTAN TO CUT AN ADDITIONAL 100 JOBS
description: Norstan Inc., which sells and services telephone and computer systems, said yesterday that it would eliminate another 100 jobs, layoffs that would be in addition to 100 cuts announced last month. The company, based in Minnetonka, Minn., had about 1,400 employees before the previously announced job cuts. A spokeswoman, Jan Drymon, did not immediately return a call to her office. Norstan is reducing its work force to lower its costs and improve its cash position. Earlier this month, the company reported a net loss of $1.9 million for the quarter ended Aug. 2, in contrast to net income of $2.2 million a year earlier. Restructuring costs this quarter will be from $3.3 million to $3.8 million, the company said.

title: New Museum Joins Forces With Artists' Web Site
description: In an unusual instance of an established cultural organization taking an upstart arts group under its wing, the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo is forging a partnership with Rhizome.org, an Internet site where digital artists can exhibit their online projects and crow about their status as art-world outsiders.

description: David King's wife signed him up on a whim, and curiosity and prickly pride made him go through with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERT, ROSE
description: LIEBERT--Rose. Of New York City, died in her home on September 28, 2003. She was the beloved mother of the late Michael Liebert, widow of Herbert, and longtime companion of the late Harry Silverman. She was loved and will be missed by friends and family. ''Tutta bella cosa''. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 30th, 1:30PM at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, RUTH O'BRIEN

Born on October 11, 1930 she was the daughter of Abbie Aldridge and Charlie O'Brien and the wife of the late Melvin Miller. Ruth had been a nurse and a teacher. She was a muse to her late husband, and possessed a love of life and friends that will be remembered by all with whom she came into contact. We will miss her. As she wished, there will no service. A donation in her memory may be made to The Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Ave at 16th St., NY, NY 10003.

Scheindlin, according to her law clerk, an indication that Clarett's suit against the league may progress more quickly than some observers expected.

Kucinich. He was responding to the question ''What in office, as president, would be the least popular, most right thing you would do?'' He was not discussing his priorities.

description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington will induct seven people into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives in marketing and the media who are 40 and younger.

description: A group of businessmen linked by their close ties to President Bush, his family and his administration have set up a consulting firm to advise companies that want to do business in Iraq, including those seeking pieces of taxpayer-financed reconstruction projects.

title: Rusty and Radioactive
description: On Aug. 30, the K-159, a Russian November-class nuclear submarine, sank during bad weather in the Barents Sea, taking with it nine sailors. The K-159, which had been decommissioned by the Russian Navy in 1989, broke loose as it was being towed to the Nerpa dismantling site near Murmansk.

title: 6-Hour Siege At Campsite Ends Fatally
description: A six-hour siege of a gunman believed to have fatally shot one man and wounded three others, including two police detectives, ended at a New Jersey campground yesterday afternoon when a cordon of heavily armed officers closed in after hours of silence and found two men and a woman dead inside the suspect's trailer.

description: LET'S dwell a bit on New York and the Mahatma. We're talking about Mohandas K. Gandhi, and not someone closer to home who had the same nickname, Branch Rickey, onetime owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers (requiescat in pace).

title: Big Teeth in Ancient Jaw Offer Clues About Our Ancestors
description: A jawbone complete with a set of large pearly molars, discovered in a cave in Romania, is the earliest fossil evidence yet found of modern humans in Europe, scientists reported last week.

title: FIDELITY TO CUT COMMISSIONS FOR ACTIVE TRADERS
description: Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund company, will follow a move by Charles Schwab and cut commissions next month on stock and options trades by 42 percent for its most active customers. The new rate of $8, down from $14, applies to Fidelity's ''gold level'' customers who make at least 120 stock, bond or options trades a year and have $30,000 in household assets at the company, which is based in Boston. Customers who make fewer trades and have $1 million in assets at Fidelity also qualify, down from 240 trades a year or $2 million previously required. Charles Schwab, the discount broker, said earlier that it would allow traders who make at least 30 trades a quarter to qualify for $14.95 commissions, down from 60 trades a quarter.

title: Executive Changes Planned at WB Network
description: The WB television network will make a series of executive changes, setting up a succession to the longtime head of the network, Jamie Kellner, Warner Brothers Entertainment, the network's parent company, announced last night.

title: McCann Loses2 Coke Accounts
description: Offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising have lost two assignments to create campaigns for the flagship soft drink brand of the Coca-Cola Company .

title: Small, Isolated Elephants Follow Own Evolutionary Path
description: The small Borneo elephant represents the last remnant of an ancient lineage, a team of international biologists has determined. The finding, based on DNA samples, overturns a long-held prevailing theory of the animals' origins: that they were descended from domesticated elephants that reverted to the wild.

title: Mr. Reed Goes to Work
description: John Reed, the former Citicorp chief executive, is beginning his first week as interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. His mandate is to overhaul the beleaguered Big Board in the wake of Richard Grasso's departure. He has his work cut out for him.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: DECISION ON 9/11 SUIT IS UPHELD A panel of federal appellate judges upheld a decision to dismiss lawsuits from survivors of victims of the World Trade Center attack who charged that the special master of the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund would unfairly limit awards to certain families. On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a May decision by the United States District Court for the Southern District, which dismissed three lawsuits on behalf of families of victims who worked for Cantor Fitzgerald. The cases involve victims whose income was in the top 2 percent and whose survivors were considering seeking compensation from the fund for their losses, estimated in one case to be up to $52 million. According to court papers, the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg, has spoken about considering awards of up to $7 million. In their decision, the judges wrote that "any cap on compensation would be a direct violation of the statute" governing the fund. They also wrote that they saw no evidence that Mr. Feinberg had established a cap. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: SALES OF COLLECTIBLES HELP TOPPS IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The Topps Company, the maker of trading cards and Bazooka bubble gum, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 12 percent as sales of collectibles increased. Net income in the quarter ended Aug. 30 rose to $5.27 million, or 13 cents a share, from $4.69 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 4.1 percent, to $72.9 million from $70 million. Sales in Topps's biggest business, candy and gum, fell 1.2 percent, to $41.8 million, and the company turned to stickers, trading cards and other collectibles acquired with the July purchase of WizKids. Candy and gum sales fell as orders declined at warehouse club stores. Shares of Topps rose 29 cents, to $9.66.

title: Appeals Strategy Lies Behind Prosecutors' Decision in Terror Case
description: Bush administration officials said today that federal prosecutors had decided not to object to a motion to dismiss the indictment of Zacarias Moussaoui because they wanted to present an appeals court with a blunt choice: reinstate the charges or acknowledge that civilian courts cannot prosecute a terror suspect like Mr. Moussaoui.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: President Quits Party
description: President Roh Moo Hyun gave up his membership in the governing Millennium Democratic Party. The move was expected and came after 37 lawmakers who support his policies but seek bigger roles for younger lawmakers broke away from the party to form a new one. It remained unclear if Mr. Roh would join the new People's Participatory United New Party. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Government To Sell Stake
description: Taiwan plans to sell a 3 percent stake in the Taiwan Semi- conductor Manufacturing Company, the nation's biggest company by market value, for as much as $45.9 billion ($1.4 billion) to help offset a budget deficit, an opposition lawmaker said. The Taiwan Development Fund aims to sell the shares for about $71.50 each, an 8 percent premium to Friday's closing price, the lawmaker, Thomas Lee, said, citing information obtained from the government. A fund executive said the stake would be sold next year. The government is planning more asset sales to finance spending as President Chen Shui-bian prepares for an election next March.

title: Losing Is Never an Option
description: April Heinrichs, coach of the United States women's soccer team, was speaking with reporters the other day when the subject turned from soccer to baseball and the reality that the best major league teams lose dozens of games a season.

title: Deal to Acquire U.S. Insurer Is Part of a Canadian Trend
description: By proposing to acquire John Hancock Financial Services, Manulife Financial has joined a growing group of Canadian financial institutions that have come to view expansion in the United States as one of the most critical drivers of their growth.

title: Short Line. Small Train. Little Graffiti.
description: Time and circumstance have rarely been kind to a modest piece of Brooklyn railroad that stretches like a medium-size Band-Aid from Bedford-Stuyvesant to Prospect Park.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Quickly Acquired Taste

title: Tony Blair Fights to Regain Traction at Party Meeting
description: It was early in his premiership, and Tony Blair was facing an explosive charge that his government did a political favor in return for a $1.5 million party donation.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Myrtle Beach, S.C.; A 60-Mile Strip Of Surf and Golf
description: MYRTLE Beach claims to be the nation's golf capital, and given its 123 golf courses, it is hard to dispute the title. The city has just invested $1 billion to improve the roads along the 60-mile-long beach strip, called the Grand Strand, home to most of the hotels and other big attractions catering to the 14 million tourists that pass through each year. The biggest news on the local business scene is a plan by Hard Rock Cafe International to build a 150-acre rock 'n' roll theme park, with a 15,000-seat outdoor theater.

title: On Guard Against SARS, Inside the Laboratory and Out
description: In their vigil for a possible return of SARS, health officials have focused mainly on finding where the virus hides in nature.

title: U.S. and Russia Enter Meat and Poultry Deal
description: The Bush administration announced a trade agreement with Moscow today that could increase American poultry and meat exports to Russia as well as remove some of the obstacles blocking Russia's entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: Funny Cide Works Out
description: Funny Cide worked a strong five furlongs in 59.52 seconds yesterday at Belmont Park and is a possible starter in the Breeders' Cup Classic in Santa Anita on Oct. 25. The gelding, who won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, has not started since finishing third in the Haskell Aug. 3 and has been sidelined with an illness.

title: U.S. Road to 06 Cup Could Start in January
description: The United States men's national soccer team could begin play in qualifying matches for the 2006 World Cup in January under a plan submitted yesterday to FIFA, the sport's worldwide governing body. FIFA must approve the proposed schedule, which would have matches played through November 2005.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about plans to publish ''Killed,'' an anthology of magazine articles that were originally rejected, misstated the surname of one contributor. He is Ted Rall, not Rawls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNIRRING, WILLIAM
description: SCHNIRRING -- William, on September 27, 2003, age 65, of Westport, CT. Born in NYC on May 18, 1938 to Fredrick William and Alice Mary Schnirring, Bill grew up in Larchmont, NY. Graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, 1956 and NYU, 1960. Served in US Coast Guard, honorably discharged 1964. Bill owned and operated the Charles Meyer Cosmetics Company before beginning his career in publishing. He was editor and advertising manager of American Hairstyling and Barber's Journal in the 1960's. Married Melissa, 1967. Traveled the world 1969-1972 as a freelance photojournalist. Upon returning to the US in 1972, he started Associated Business Publication, which published Convenience Store Merchandisers, The Confectioner and Vegetarian Times. Currently, ABPI publishes NASA Tech Briefs, Photonics Tech Briefs and AFRL Technology Horizons. Bill enjoyed travel, boating, golf and spending time with his family. He is survived by his wife Melissa, son Luke and daughterin-law Blake. A celebration of Bill's life will take place Saturday, October 4 from 1-5PM at home, 50 Shorehaven Road, Norwalk, CT. 203-855-1866.

title: Schools Seeking Alternatives To Granting More Transfers
description: New York City school officials, already struggling with overcrowding as a result of transfers from failing schools, are looking for ways to avoid giving thousands more students the opportunity to transfer this year.

title: Uneven Progress Is Found for Women on Princeton Science and Engineering Faculties
description: Women on the faculties of the sciences and engineering at Princeton University feel less job satisfaction and less of a sense of inclusion than men, according to a new study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORITZER, ROSE
description: BORITZER--Rose. Beloved wife of Arno, with whom she had a wonderful life for over 62 years. Rose was a person dedicated to others, in her personal life, through her love for her children, family and friends, and in her professional life, as the Executive Director of the Kingsbridge Heights Health Facilities, Board Member of the NYS Health Facilities Assn., Delegate to, The White House Council on Aging, and an innovative trailblazer, in the care of New York's geriatric population. Born in Leipzig, Germany, the scars of the Holocaust, and her later life as a pioneer in the building of Israel, motivated her work and giving, on behalf of Jewish and Israeli causes. She was a loving mother to Rafi and Ruti, mother-in-law to Milli and Ira, and grandmother to Jesse. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 30, at 4:00pm at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center, 311 Central Park Ave., Yonkers. Donations to the Alzheimer's & Related Disorders Assn. 914-428-1919 or Friends of the Israel Defense Forces 212-244-3118.

title: WASHINGTON POST OFFERS TO BUY KAPLAN STOCK OPTIONS
description: The Washington Post Company offered yesterday to pay $138 million to purchase stock options held by managers of its Kaplan Inc. test-preparation services unit. The company offered to buy back 55 percent of the options, representing about 6 percent of Kaplan's total stock, which is not publicly traded. The offer carries a 10 percent premium over the current valuation as long as 90 percent of the eligible shares are tendered by Oct. 28, the company said. If fewer shares are tendered, the offer will lapse. Shares of the Washington Post Company closed at $676, up $15.50.

title: Letters
description: When Mistakes Mean Malpractice

title: Persistence Pays: Japan's Bank Regulator Makes Gains
description: Heizo Takenaka is nothing if not persistent. After a year of fighting with bankers, politicians and bureaucrats in his own ministry, Mr. Takenaka happily accepted an invitation from Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi last week to continue as Japan's banking czar. Someone else might have thrown up his arms in despair.

title: Dialing for Dollars
description: The Federal Trade Commission's do-not-call registry, the most popular consumer protection initiative in American history, is in jeopardy. Although President Bush signed the law authorizing the list yesterday, a federal judge last week ruled that it violates the First Amendment because it allows households to block commercial telemarketing calls but not calls from charities, political parties, religious groups or other nonprofit organizations.

title: Supreme Court Takes Case on Nazi-Looted Art
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  A closely watched legal dispute over the ownership of works of art once looted by the Nazis reached the Supreme Court on Tuesday as the justices accepted an appeal by the Republic of Austria and one of its state art museums on whether American courts have jurisdiction to resolve such cases.

title: The Letters and the Law; Should New York Change Its Awnings or Its Code?
description: Last summer, the Bloomberg administration came under fire for issuing what New Yorkers widely perceived as a barrage of nickel-and-dime tickets -- to a pregnant woman sitting on the subway stairs, drivers talking on cellphones, parents double-parking in front of school buildings while dropping off their children. Business owners from the Lower East Side to Jackson Heights claimed that they, too, were being unfairly cited for having information-packed awnings in front of their stores.

title: In Latest Nod To S.I. Voters, Mayor Has Plan For a New Park
description: Memo to Staten Islanders: If you want to keep getting goodies from City Hall, keep telling pollsters you are unhappy with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. It seems to be working.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The advertising is a lot less about 'What I can do for California' and a lot more about what is wrong with the other guy.''

title: Trading Memories
description: Bill Clinton talked a great deal during his presidency about building a bridge to the 21st century, but now that we are here, the 10 Democrats trying to occupy his old residence on Pennsylvania Avenue are pitching the country on the idea of crossing that bridge back into the late 20th century, to a happy time of high growth, low unemployment and government surpluses. As Richard Gephardt, the House minority leader, wistfully put it in last week's debate among the Democratic contenders, ''Why wouldn't we want to go back to that?''

title: Network Ratings: Frowns Or Smiles
description: The first week of network ratings competition in the new television season produced a bit more grief than grins. Three networks -- NBC, CBS and Fox -- had fewer viewers than they did in same period last year, and there were few shows that showed immediate promise of becoming hits.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Nurses Avert Strike At Hospital
description: A nurses' union and Virtua Memorial Hospital Burlington County averted a strike that was set to start today. Health Professionals and Allied Employees Local 5105, a union representing 700 nurses, voted last night to approve the contract, which calls for pay increases of 15 to 22 percent over the two-and-a-half-year contract. The new contract becomes effective tomorrow. The contract also improves pensions and sets guidelines for staffing levels at the hospital, which has 369 beds. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Yankees Want Dellucci
description: The Yankees want to put outfielder David Dellucci on their postseason roster and take 10 pitchers, but they will wait until this morning to announce their final roster. Dellucci, who sprained his left ankle on Aug. 27, played in the final game of the regular season and went through intense running drills yesterday. ''Everything's fine,'' he said.

description: Anna N. Aldukhova, 19, stood on a corner of Uprising Square wearing a blue cap and windbreaker that bore the name of the front-runner in this city's approaching gubernatorial runoff. She passed out leaflets promising a better quality of life. No one paid much attention.

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Rise Again
description: Worldwide chip sales grew 4 percent in August, raising prospects of stronger third-quarter growth, according to a new study. The Semiconductor Industry Association announced yesterday that chip sales reached $13.4 billion in August, up from $12.9 billion in July, the sixth consecutive monthly increase. Revenue increased 12.5 percent from $11.9 billion in August 2002. Sales of microprocessors were up 7.8 percent, and sales of dynamic random access memory devices had risen 11 percent since July. Chips used in consumer devices like digital video players and cameras rose 5.3 percent, while flash memory chips were up 6.9 percent since July. The wireless sector posted 4.7 percent growth.

description: FIRESTEIN -- Allan. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Gloria, and the entire family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Paying Heed To Problems Of the Heart
description: My symptoms were hardly exotic: mild vertigo, a touch of indigestion, light-headedness, not exactly grounds for an all points bulletin. I was sure it was only a virus and I knew the drill: rest, drink plenty of fluids and this too shall pass. It did not.

title: Boiling Brew: Politics and Health Insurance Gap
description: The jump in the number of Americans without health insurance is not just another bad economic statistic.

title: Linked Again: Fat and Disease
description: Being overweight is known to be associated with Type 2 diabetes, the disease that generally begins in adulthood. But new research suggests that it may also hasten the onset of Type 1 diabetes, which usually occurs in children and young adults.

title: Lax Training and Inspection Are Cited in Chemical Blast
description: Lax supervision and training at a sign-making company was the main cause of a chemical explosion that ripped through a Manhattan building last year, injuring at least 42 people, federal investigators have concluded.

title: Disclosure at the Medical Journals
description: A troubling case of hidden financial conflicts has forced the publisher of some of the world's most influential scientific journals to expand its editorial disclosure policies. Last week the Nature Publishing Group, part of Macmillan Publishers, announced that it would henceforth require the authors of review articles to disclose any financial ties to the products they evaluate. It was a welcome if belated step to close a loophole in the journals' previous disclosure policies, which covered only research reports and not the review articles that evaluate progress in a particular field.

title: Iraqi Groups Badly Divided Over How to Draft a Charter
description: As the Iraqi Governing Council presses for a more rapid end to the occupation and a transfer of sovereignty to Iraqis, a new dispute over who will control the drafting of an Iraqi constitution is bringing to the surface deep divisions between Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds.

title: Gadgets to Go: A Little Something for the Road
description: The prevailing image of the business traveler is a laptop-toter with a cellphone attached to one ear and some kind of hand-held device stashed in a coat pocket.

title: S.E.C. Staff Recommends Tighter Limits Of Hedge Funds
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission today recommended tighter regulation of the growing hedge fund industry, including registration of the funds and greater disclosure of the way they operate.

title: Big Board's Interim Chief Tells Washington About His Plans
description: John S. Reed spent his first day as the interim head of the New York Stock Exchange meeting with its directors and with top officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission to go over his plans to overhaul the way the exchange governs itself.

title: Trade Pact Gives Hong Kong Edge in the Chinese Market
description: Officials from mainland China and Hong Kong signed off today on the final details of a free trade agreement that gives Hong Kong service companies a slightly speedier entry to China's vast market than foreign rivals might receive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLICK, HOWARD SAMUEL
description: GLICK--Howard Samuel. On September 28, 2003, age 75, of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of Norwich, CT. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Michael (Sharon) and Andrea (Seth) and the late Karol. Loving Papa of Alex and Kayla Glick and Sophia and Evan Lieberman. Cherished brother of the late Barbara Yarin (Murray). Beloved uncle and loyal friend. His funeral will take place on Tuesday, September 30, 10AM, at Beth Jacob Synagogue, 400 New London Tpk, Norwich, CT. 06360. Burial will follow at New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. Memorial contributions may be made to the Karol S. Glick Fund, Beth Jacob Synagogue, Norwich, CT.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEW JERSEY SPLIT ON GAY MARRIAGE A slight majority of New Jersey residents would permit civil unions for same-sex couples, while half stop short of sanctioning marriage rights equal to those of heterosexuals, according to a poll released yesterday. Fifty-two percent of those polled said they would allow civil unions, while 50 percent said they opposed gay marriage, according to a Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers poll. Forty-three percent favor full marriage rights, while 7 percent have no opinion. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points, and 802 residents were surveyed Sept. 2 through Sept. 8. Earlier this year, Lambda Legal, a gay rights group, filed suit in New Jersey on behalf of seven same-sex couples denied marriage licenses.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: N.F.L. Analysis; Unlike Stadium, Bears in Need of Renovation
description: The renovated Soldier Field has been called everything from a flying saucer to a toilet bowl and a mismatch in style between ''Star Trek'' and an old Western movie. Descriptions of these current Bears have been even more crude.

title: BIG INCREASE SEEN IN PEOPLE LACKING HEALTH INSURANCE
description: The number of people without health insurance shot up last year by 2.4 million, the largest increase in a decade, raising the total to 43.6 million, as health costs soared and many workers lost coverage provided by employers, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: F.C.C. Chief Will Enforce Phone Curbs
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that the agency would enforce restrictions on unwanted telephone solicitations that were scheduled to take effect Wednesday.

title: City Firefighter Dies After Queens Blaze
description: A New York City firefighter has died of a heart attack after fighting a fire in Queens, becoming the first firefighter to die in the line of duty since Sept. 11, 2001, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Second Computer Disappears From Plum I. Research Center
description: Federal investigators are searching for a laptop computer that disappeared last week from a supposedly secure biocontainment building at the Plum Island Animal Disease Research Center, its acting director said yesterday.

description: On his return to New Jersey last week with D.C. United, Alecko Eskandarian spent more time renewing his drivers license at the state division of motor vehicles office in Franklin Lakes than he has spent on a soccer field recently.

title: Anachronism in a T-Shirt, Bewildered by a Fast-Moving World
description: You know this guy, right? That big lug with the killer's mitts and the little-boy-lost expression? He's been hanging around for as long as actors have been wearing dirty T-shirts on stages and screens, always unaware of his own clumsy strength and searching for a good woman's love.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MAINE: POLICE KILL MOOSE IN FRONT OF CROWD Portland police officers shot and killed a 900-pound moose in a tidal pond near a busy downtown recreational area. The police said they had no option because a crowd had gathered to watch the animal, which could have run loose. It would have drowned if it had been tranquilized, the police said. Many in the crowd, which was warned about the plan to kill the animal, shouted angrily as an officer shot it. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: U.S. Attorney Says Ex-Employee Lied to Conceal Fraud at Medco
description: The United States attorney in Philadelphia yesterday accused a former senior executive of Medco Health Solutions of lying to investigators to cover up financial fraud that officials said occurred in Medco's $1.2 billion mail-order drug program for millions of federal employees.

title: Bonds for a Midtown Skyscraper Bring Out Supporters and Critics
description: The announcements for public hearings by the city's Industrial Development Agency are usually buried in the back of a newspaper and rarely draw more than a handful of people to consider what amounts to hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies for private projects.

title: I.B.M. to Disclose Power-Saving Chip Design
description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to announce a new semiconductor design today that it asserts could greatly improve the performance or reduce the power consumption of wireless devices like cellphones compared with today's technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JEROME, LUCILLE
description: JEROME--Lucille. The Board of Directors and Staff of Family Services of Westchester note with sadness the loss of Lucille Jerome, matriarch of the Jerome Family, our 2003 Family of the Year. As a founder of Monroe College, Lucille Jerome's life was dedicated to providing educational opportunities for young people and to nurturing potential. That tradition continues today at Monroe College through her son, Stephen, her daughter-in-law Leslie, and her grandchildren, Marc, Evan and Lauren. It will also continue through the Lucille and Harry Jerome Technology Learning Center, established at Family Services of Westchester in 2003 as a result of the Jerome Family's community leadership and generosity.

title: Sharpton Campaign in Disarray; at Least 1 Top Aide Quits
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's long-shot bid for the Democratic presidential nomination stumbled today, with a top campaign aide quitting and a second threatening to resign.

title: Huffington to Address Recall Candidacy Tonight
description: Arianna Huffington, the independent candidate for governor of California and sharp-witted campaign provocateur, plans to announce the future of her candidacy on national television tonight, her campaign aides said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Cleared In Ground Zero Scuffle
description: A jury has acquitted a city engineer who was charged with assaulting Port Authority police officers during a scuffle at ground zero last year. The engineer, Michael Kenny, 41, faced up to one year in jail before the jury cleared him in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday. Mr. Kenny, who works for the Department of Design and Construction, which oversees the ground zero cleanup, was accused of interfering with the arrest of a laborer involved in a dispute with the officers. Mr. Kenny resisted arrest, the complaint said. Last Friday, he testified that he was trying to help a man and did not know he was interfering with an arrest. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Rocky Mountain Higher
description: Denver has long billed itself the Mile High City, and a plaque on the Capitol steps marks where the elevation reaches 5,280 feet above sea level. The city is not known to be rising, but the plaque has dropped. With technology having made measurements more accurate, Gov. Bill Owens moved the plaque down five steps, to the 13th step. The plaque had been moved twice before. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Rite Aid Lawyer Falsified Earnings, Prosecutor Says
description: Franklin C. Brown, the former top lawyer for the Rite Aid Corporation, helped inflate the company's financial performance and lied about it to investigators, a prosecutor charged yesterday in opening statements at Mr. Brown's trial.

description: 6-Hour Siege Ends Fatally

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; The Twins Are Hoping The Past Is the Past
description: Lambasted. That was the perfect word Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire used to describe what the Yankees had done to Minnesota immediately after it happened last April. The only thing is, Gardenhire initially mispronounced it. So Gardenhire then pronounced it properly, and repeating the description of those seven losses made it seem twice as deplorable.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Ex-Rikers Warden Convicted
description: Mitchell Hochhauser, a former assistant deputy warden at Rikers Island, was convicted yesterday of attempted grand larceny for his role in the attempted theft of a $250,000 Salvador Dali drawing on display at Rikers. Mr. Hochhauser, 40, of Queens, admitted in State Supreme Court that he conspired earlier this year with another assistant deputy warden and two correction officers to steal the drawing, which Dali donated to the Correction Department in 1965. Mr. Hochhauser, who remained free on $25,000 bail, is scheduled to be sentenced on Nov. 17 and faces one to three years in prison, according to Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney. The three other employees are awaiting trial. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

description: KAZAN--Elia. He was a ''swell'' guy. Our love to the family. Carter and Howard Berg

title: Justice Verniero to Step Down in August
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30  Justice Peter G. Verniero of the New Jersey Supreme Court, who came close to impeachment in 2001 in the furor over racial profiling in the state, said today that he would step down next August.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Increase In Bar Production
description: The Saudi Iron and Steel Company, or Hadeed, plans to increase production of iron bars by 500,000 metric tons a year as Saudi Arabia seeks to reduce its dependence on oil. Hadeed's board recently approved a plan to increase steel output by 2 million tons, its owner, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation said. The Saudi government formed Sabic, the largest producer of petrochemicals in the Middle East, in 1976. Sabic said in July its second-quarter profit more than doubled to 1,794 billion riyals ($478 million) as product prices rose and sales were helped by the purchase of the bulk plastics unit of its rival DSM in 2002.

Kucinich. He was responding to the question "What in office, as president, would be the least popular, most right thing you would do?" He was not discussing his priorities.

title: Addiction: A Brain Ailment, Not a Moral Lapse
description: For all that has been written and spoken about addiction as a medical disease, most people, including most physicians, understand little about what draws people to drugs and keeps them hooked, often despite severe consequences and repeated attempts to quit.

title: Guantnamo Bay Aide Is Arrested at Boston Airport
description: Anaturalized American of Egyptian descent who works at a United States prison camp for captured militants at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has been arrested in Boston after he was found to be in possession of what appeared to be classified information, the Department of Homeland Security said today.

title: Like a Children's Author, For the Very First Time
description: Dana Spera says she has no interest in children's books. But yesterday at noon she was outside the Barnes & Noble store on 48th Street and Fifth Avenue, begging to be let in for a glimpse of her favorite author.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC., Rochester Hills, Mich., a maker of solar panels and batteries for electric cars, said it would delay reporting its yearly results because it needed more time to determine the purchase price of its acquisition of stakes in United Solar Ovonic and United Solar Ovonic.

title: A Closer Look at Women's Hearts
description: Stress tests are a well-established method for doctors to assess the risk of heart disease in men, but their effectiveness among women has been unclear.

title: Speculation on Weaker Dollar Leads to Gains for Euro and Yen
description: The dollar tumbled against the euro and the yen in New York trading yesterday, on speculation that United States officials might seek a weaker currency to bolster corporate profits and extend a recovery.

title: Who's Sordid Now?
description: It's official: the administration that once scorned nation-building now says that it's engaged in a modern version of the Marshall Plan. But Iraq isn't postwar Europe, and George W. Bush definitely isn't Harry Truman. Indeed, while Truman led this country in what Churchill called the ''most unsordid act in history,'' the stories about Iraqi reconstruction keep getting more sordid. And the sordidness isn't, as some would have you believe, a minor blemish on an otherwise noble enterprise.

title: Joint Service From Reuters And Microsoft
description: The Reuters Group, the information services company, said yesterday that it would announce today a deal with Microsoft to connect the companies' instant messaging systems as an offering for financial services companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOBENFELD, SAM
description: LOBENFELD--Sam. On September 27th, 2003 at the age of 89 in the home of his daughter in Brooklyn, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Rifkin Lobenfeld. He is survived by his daughter Frann Giambanco and his son Eric Lobenfeld, their spouses Glenn and Trish, grandchildren Jessica and her husband Keith Oechsner, Claire and Margot, and great granddaughter, Dylan Annice. He was an Army Captain in WWII, a POW and received the Purple Heart in 1945. A generous, quiet man, he will be greatly missed by his family. A funeral service will be held at 10AM Tuesday, September 30, 2003 at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Hospice of Greater New York.

description: SIEGAL -- Florence. 90. Passed away peacefully on September 28, 2003. Cherished wife of the late Samuel Siegal. Loving mother of Joel and Dr. Elliot Siegal. Devoted grandmother of Lauren Shannon, Samuel and Evan Siegal. Dear great grandmother of Ryan Shannon. Beloved mother-in-law of Helen and Ronny. You will forever have the most special and loving place in all of our hearts. Shivah at homes of Mr and Mrs Joel Siegal, 9/30 and 10/2 and Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Siegal, 10/1: 5:30 to 9PM.

title: White House Denies a Top Aide Identified an Officer of the C.I.A.
description: The White House today dismissed as ''ridiculous'' the suggestion that Karl Rove, senior adviser to President Bush, had illegally disclosed the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer, as the F.B.I. opened an investigation into the case.

Loving grandmother and great - grandmother. Funeral Tuesday, 12:15, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Tough Going As Negotiators Hammer Out Energy Bill
description: Six weeks after the worst blackout in United States history, Congressional Republicans are entering the difficult final stage of negotiations over an energy policy that goes far beyond electricity issues to encompass a host of power initiatives, including new coal and nuclear plants and stepped-up domestic oil production.

title: Cubs Trump The Yankees In Prime Time
description: Cute as the Chicago Cubs are, do they deserve the prime-time slot given them by Fox Sports for Game 1 of tonight's National League division series against Atlanta?

title: Man Killed, Possibly in Murder-Suicide
description: A man was killed by a commuter train yesterday afternoon in Millburn, N.J., and the police were investigating a possible link between his death and a crime scene at his home, the authorities said.

title: Bill Seeks to Discourage Wealthy From Swaying Charter Changes
description: A bill meant to discourage wealthy New Yorkers from using their money to sway public opinion on proposals to revise the City Charter was introduced in the City Council yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Accounting Rules Approved
description: The European Commission approved rules that would require all publicly traded companies in the European Union to adopt common accounting standards by 2005, though it left out, for now, regulations that are being revised after opposition from banks. The movement toward a set of International Accounting Standards gained momentum after corporate scandals erupted in the United States and Europe. When the new rules take effect a little more than a year from now, roughly 7,000 publicly listed companies will be subject to them. ''That will put an end to the current Tower of Babel in financial reporting, improve competition and transparency and make the free movement of capital much easier,'' the union's single market commissioner, Frits Bolkestein, above, said. Guidelines on how companies account for financial instruments were not included after objections by banks. Eric Pfanner (IHT)

title: Twelve-Tone Works Pitched To the Emotion of Protest
description: One piece of conventional wisdom among classical concert programmers is that most audiences don't like choral music. Another is that audiences don't like 20th-century music -- especially that nasty 12-tone stuff. But Leon Botstein, the music director of the American Symphony Orchestra (and president of Bard College) has virtually made a career of bucking conventional wisdom, and he certainly did with the American Symphony Orchestra's first concert of the season, on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: The Trouble With Eagles and Owls
description: FEAR'S EMPIRE

title: Air France Backs Stock Swap in a Union With KLM
description: A sweeping combination of Air France and KLM moved closer tonight when Air France's board approved a proposed stock swap with KLM shareholders, a member of the board said. If the deal wins the approval of KLM, the big Dutch airline; of the French and Dutch governments; and of regulators on both sides of the Atlantic, the combination would surpass British Airways to become Europe's largest airline company.

title: Method Man: Kazan's Landscape of Desire
description: Movie directors are known for being vain, autocratic and egomaniacal, but the curious nature of their art form also makes them invisible. Their own powerful personalities most often find expression in the faces and gestures of others. Think of John Ford, for example, and the picture you see in your head will probably be of John Wayne. Elia Kazan, who could be as passionate, difficult and dictatorial as any of his peers, will live on primarily through the images of a handful of actors.

title: Israel Expected to Approve Plan for New West Bank Barrier
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's government is expected to approve a plan on Wednesday for building a controversial separation barrier deep inside the West Bank around Ariel, one of the largest Jewish settlements.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Delays Climate Pact
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia had not yet decided whether to ratify the international treaty aimed at reducing emissions linked to global warming. Speaking at a scientific conference opening in Moscow, Mr. Putin did not commit Russia to any timetable for adopting the treaty, known as the Kyoto Protocol, as many international leaders and environmentalists had hoped he would. Although 118 countries have ratified the treaty, it will not go into effect without the participation of the world's largest polluters. The Bush administration has rejected the treaty as onerous to the American economy, making Russia's participation decisive. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: F.D.A. Faults Quality of Imported Drugs
description: Most imported drugs are counterfeit knockoffs that could seriously endanger the health of those taking them, say federal drug and customs officials who conducted a spot inspection over the summer that they disclosed yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Best of All Possible World Series
description: IF baseball is a romance language, the World Series is its wedding vows. And this year, several possible pairings in the World Series are to have and to hold. Or at least to hope for.

title: A Year With a Mentor. Now Comes the Test.; Protgs and Masters Assess What They Have Learned Thanks to a Corporate Nudge
description: It used to be that great artists took on protgs the way people fall in love, in a burst of infatuation, often laced with narcissism. For Robert Schumann, the German composer, lightning struck when he heard Johannes Brahms play his compositions; for George Balanchine the flash materialized while watching a young Suzanne Farrell perform his dances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, ADELE S.
description: LEVINE--Adele S. On September 29, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry Levine. Beloved mother of Luetta Gould and the late Dr. E. Judith Krasnow. Beloved grandmother of Susan and Harold Gould, Michael and Cathy Krasnow. Beloved sister of the late Ralph, Irving, Morris and Sidney Steinhauer. Also survived by loving sons-inlaw, Erwin Krasnow and Jay Gould. Member of Congregation Agudath Shalom of Stamford, CT for over 50 years. Retired manager of the Norwalk office, CT State Employment Service. Services at Leo P. Gallagher & Sons, at 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT, (203-327-1313) at noon on Wednesday, October 1, 2003.

title: Intruders Ransack Apartment and Stab 2 Residents
description: Three intruders broke into an apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, on Sunday night, ransacked it and bound and stabbed two people who lived there, the police said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Computer Sciences In Army Deal
description: Computer Sciences, the information technology company, has won a contract from the Army to help manage its flight simulator and aviation training operations, the company said yesterday. The deal is worth as much as $1.1 billion. Under the 12-year contract, Computer Sciences will provide simulator-based flight training and support at the Army Aviation Center at Fort Rucker in Alabama. The pact includes an eight-year extension option, with the value of the deal exceeding $1.1 billion if the additional years are picked up. Computer Sciences, based in El Segundo, Calif., has provided similar services at Fort Rucker for roughly six years.

title: Tourism and Optimism Spread in Hong Kong
description: I WAS standing in a tight knot of maybe 20 people waiting to cross the street at a light on Nathan Road in downtown Kowloon when I felt the sneeze coming on. The crosswalks all have audio signals that rattle like toy drums to let pedestrians know when it is safe to walk, and the tinny tattoo was at full crescendo when I abruptly and inadvertently sneezed into my fist.

title: A Division Title Is Not Enough For the Braves
description: Braves General Manager John Schuerholz stood along the first-base line recently at Turner Field and waved his hand toward the string of division championship flags that hang in left-center field. One moment he is proud and beaming. The next he is mystified, even a little angry, that there are people who want Atlanta to apologize for winning only one World Series in 11 consecutive postseason appearances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUETLINGER, FAY S.
description: HUETLINGER--Fay S. In her 93rd year, Fay died peacefully on September 28th in Boca Raton, FL. She was the mother of Ruth H. and Paul Eisen and Mark and Bonnie Heutlinger; grandmother of Andrew, Jonathan, and Gregg Eisen; great-grandmother of four. Formerly a fashion consultant in Newark and West Orange, New Jersey, Fay was a woman of elegance and style, intelligence and independence. Interment will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAUER, STANLEY, M.D.
description: BAUER--Stanley, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the passing of our distinguished professor of pathology. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Bauer family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Universities Tighten Rules on Faculty-Student Relationships
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The University of California is beginning the academic year under a new policy that bans professors from engaging in "romantic or sexual" relationships with their students.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Hope Fades For 4 In Boiler Fall
description: Officials feared that four maintenance workers, including at least one American, would die before rescuers could reach them at the bottom of a 270-foot-deep boiler they had fallen into at a power plant in Geertruidenberg, near the southern city of Breda. Eight men, four of them American, were cleaning the inside surface of the boiler early Sunday when the scaffolding they were standing on gave way, setting off a terrifying free fall in the dark. Rescuers managed to free three men near the top of the scaffolding wreckage, including two of the Americans. One worker was confirmed dead, but Dutch authorities declined to say whether he was an American. The rest of the crew remained pinned underneath. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Torre Goes With Johnson
description: It is a delicate topic for Joe Torre because his highly paid veteran star Jason Giambi enjoys playing first base. But Nick Johnson is a better defensive player, and he does not have the knee problems that wear down Giambi.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Columbine Papers To Be Destroyed
description: A federal judge has ordered that documents from disputes in the aftermath of the 1999 Columbine High School shootings be destroyed. Included are depositions of the parents of the gunmen, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold. Because the evidence stems from two cases that have been settled, the judge determined that it could be destroyed. Parents of some of the victims have until Oct. 7 to appeal. Mindy Sink (NYT)

But on the presidential campaign trail, he has bemused the Washington establishment by transforming himself into a one-man grenade launcher. His target is President Bush.
